title: A Club Moves Across Town And Welcomes Newcomers
description: One of the country's leading clubs completes a metamorphosis today. The Beverly, which has been on the East Side of Manhattan for 40 years and was for a time the biggest anywhere in terms of total tables, is now on the West Side. Its new home, beautifully furnished, is in Hampshire House at 150 Central Park South. The principal proprietors, Joan Dziekanski and Bob Blanchard, have worked furiously to prepare for the opening while mourning the death on May 22 of their chief duplicate director, Erik Berger.

title: Poor Ice Conditions Hardly Hinder the Red Wings
description: One more victory over the Dallas Stars will put the Detroit Red Wings in the Stanley Cup finals for the third time in four years. Defending their first championship since 1955, the Red Wings squelched a Stars comeback today and won by 3-2 to take a 3-1 lead in the four-of-seven-game Western Conference finals.

It's an owner's prerogative to change his mind, and it's logical to assume club executives today will review all the reasons why they shouldn't trade Pettitte for Johnson.

Yet for all Ms. Manson's aggressive motions, she and her band mates remained as if behind a screen -- a television screen -- as the coolest group of the moment performed a consummate computer-age set.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHIN, JAMES P.
description: CHIN-James P. 11/6/36-6/1/96. It broke our hearts to lose you, but you didn't go alone. Part of us went with you the day God called you home. Eternal love, Elaine and Children

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a renovation at the Algonquin Hotel misstated the relation of Roger Angell, the New Yorker writer, to the author E. B. White. He is White's stepson, not his son. The article also misspelled the given name of Mr. Angell's mother, an Algonquin habitue who was The New Yorker's fiction editor, and misstated the surname she used professionally. After her marriage to White in 1929, she was known as Katharine S. White, not Katherine Sergeant Angell.

title: Long Boom or Bust; A Leading Futurist Risks His Reputation With Ideas on Growth And High Technology
description: Peter Schwartz is a professional marketer of big, brow-furrowing ideas. By 2020, he says, the internal combustion engine will probably have gone the way of the dodo bird as conventional automobiles are replaced by hybrid cars powered by fuel cells that mostly use hydrogen.

title: Essay; Barry & Dick
description: At the 1964 G.O.P. convention in San Francisco's Cow Palace, I helped hoist a Rockefeller-Scranton banner proclaiming ''Stay in the Mainstream.'' Then Barry Goldwater stuck it to the moderates with a line about the blessings of extremism.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's a job. Right now you can get killed out in the street for free. I prefer if you hit me, I make some money.''

title: New Owners of Byte Suspend Publication
description: When the computer magazine Byte was started in 1975, there was no such thing as the personal computer, and virtually no competition in the computer publishing market. For 23 years, as the computer revolution changed society, the magazine held on, despite the emergence of a number of rival publications.

title: India Calls for Talks On a Treaty to Limit All Atomic Arsenals
description: India appealed today for early negotiations on a new global treaty limiting nuclear arsenals that would include ''all nuclear weapons states.''

title: Santo Domingo Journal; It's a Scandal! Dominicans Desert Beloved Lottery
description: People in this country love to gamble on everything from cockfights to baseball games, and there seems to be a casino in every major hotel and a sports betting parlor in every neighborhood. So why has the national lottery felt a need to sponsor advertisements that beg, beseech and implore Dominicans to spend money on what has traditionally been the nation's favorite game of chance?

title: Small Alabama Newspaper Prevails In Crusade to Expose Corrupt Sheriff
description: In a tiny Alabama town where people like to recall the legacies of long-dead hunting dogs, and where the courthouse janitor has to stop twice in a crosswalk to say hello to people who call him by name, a weekly newspaper editor and his ace reporter, his wife, picked a fight with a corrupt county Sheriff's Department.

title: Millennium-Bug Fixers
description: To the Editor:

title: New Novel to Be Acid Test for Booksellers
description: Hey! It's Tom Wolfe! Star of true fiction, college anthologies and New York literati.

title: Valentine Happy Before Piazza
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine bristled today when suggestions that he is more comfortable managing a more nondescript team, without a star like Mike Piazza, were relayed to him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECESARE, DR. RONALD L.
description: DeCESARE-Dr. Ronald L. Of Greenwich, CT. On May 29, 1998. Son of Louis DeCesare of Lake Worth, FL. Husband of Providence DeCesare of Greenwich, CT. Father of Anne Bergman, Bronxville, NY, Pamela DeCesare of Rowayton, CT, Michelle Goodman, Ridgefield, CT, James DeCesare, Greenwich, CT. Brother of Russell DeCesare of Marina Del Rey, CA, Robert DeCesare, North Palm Beach, FL, Mary Ann Gangi and Justine DiIanni both of NYC. Four grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Tuesday, 10:30 AM, St. Mary's Church, Greenwich, CT. The family will receive their friends on Monday from 2-5 and 7-9 at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Heart Association or The Covenant House.

title: In the Hall of Biodiversity
description: Biodiversity is a word that still trails its newness behind it. Because it gained currency during a time when multiculturalism and political correctness also became watchwords, biodiversity, to many people, still carries a whiff of postmodern sanctimony. But that is a mistake. Biodiversity is a hugely important concept that stresses the coherence and interdependence of all forms of life on earth and a new willingness to appraise the meaning of that interdependence, not just for humans but for every one of life's component parts.

title: Violent Storms Leave Damage, Injuries and Darkness
description: A storm system that had already killed more than a dozen people in the Midwest blew through the Northeast with violent wind and rain yesterday, spawning a tornado north of Albany that injured scores of people, destroyed 30 homes and downed power lines that spit sparks and caused brush fires.

title: The White House Dismissed Warnings on China Satellite Deal
description: The caution signs made it evident that the application by Loral Space & Communications to export a satellite to China earlier this year was anything but routine.

title: Heavy Thoughts for a Heavyweight: Grant Awaits Turn
description: For all those who doubted that Michael Grant was the heir apparent to the current heavyweight champions, Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis, Grant showed his best against Obed Sullivan on Saturday night at the Atlantic City Convention Center.

title: Political Briefing; Slugfest in Alabama Bruises Republicans
description: The Republican gubernatorial primary in Alabama has become so verbally heated in the final days leading up to Tuesday's balloting that the state party chairman, Bill Harris, is already calling on the candidates to pledge to attend a post-primary unity gathering. He says the ''bring the family back together'' meeting, as he characterizes it, is needed so that the party can heal its wounds and antagonisms and prepare for the fall fight with ''the true enemy,'' the winner of the Democratic primary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, RENEE
description: GREENBERG-Renee. Died May 28, at the Hebrew Home at Riverdale after an extended illness. She was the devoted wife of Irving, loving mother of Steffi and Joel, and adoring grandmother of Kathy, Linda and Mike.

title: Biology and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: The Week That Will Be Begins in the Fog at Belmont
description: Thoroughbred racing began a week of drama yesterday that will reach a peak Saturday when Real Quiet tries to become the 12th horse to win the Belmont Stakes and complete his sweep of the Triple Crown.

His memory will be a blessing because he was a blessing to us and so many others. Service at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, NJ, Monday, June 1, at 11:30 A.M.

title: Cardinal Passes Up a Chance to Hurl Thunderbolts
description: The media turned out in force at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, anticipating yet another in what has lately been a series of public pronouncements by John Cardinal O'Connor on issues like Little League play on Sundays and domestic partnership legislation. Perhaps he would weigh in on Terrence McNally's controversial new play, or comment on some other pressing social issue.

title: Metros' Meola: Forgotten But Not Gone
description: MetroStars goalkeeper Tony Meola, a veteran of two World Cups, was not even asked by the United States team to try out to play in this World Cup. He did not complain off the field, and he has not sulked on it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, ROBERT F.
description: YOUNG-Robert F. Former president and publisher of Family Circle magazine, he was a longtime resident of Hastings-on-Hudson and Carmel, NY, recently moved to Greensboro, NC. Died May 27, 1998. Cherished husband of Judith, devoted father of Melinda Rosengarten, Julie O'Connor, Steven and Christopher. Beloved brother of Lenore Cerrone and proud grandfather of Caitlin, and Justin; Robbie & Rennie; Kristen, Brianne and Kenneth. Memorial contributions to the Louis August Jonas Foundation, Rhinebeck, NY. A memorial service will be held in June in Manhattan.

title: Travelers Deal With Nikko Set for Today
description: With the world's most powerful financial companies rushing to build global franchises, Travelers Group Inc. and the Nikko Securities Company are expected to announce today an extensive partnership in the securities business, with Travelers investing about $1.6 billion to acquire as much as a quarter of Japan's third-largest brokerage firm.

title: Investing in a Taxi Permit Looks Riskier
description: When Jack Lin heard his winning bid for a newly minted taxi medallion announced at City Hall last September, he felt a flush of love for his adopted country.

title: Rumbas, With Slaps, Rattles And Bells
description: Saturday night's show at Symphony Space, featuring the Cuban percussionist Pancho Quinto and the pianist and singer Bellita, and presented by the World Music Institute, was a good-natured mess. Bellita, also Cuban, brought a trio to play a jolly Cuban version of 1970's fusion, mixing Brazilian and American music with sounds from her native country. And Pancho Quinto went straight into the heart of the rumba, traditionalist's territory.

title: Treasury Bills Scheduled for Auction Today
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Goldman Expected to Name Co-Chief Today
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company is expected to announce today that Henry M. Paulson Jr. has been named co-chairman and co-chief executive of the firm, Wall Street's last big partnership, working alongside Jon S. Corzine, according to people at the firm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, PETER K.
description: SMITH-Peter K. Of New York and Palm Beach, on May 31. Native of Crosskeys, Cavan, Ireland. Founder and President of Smith Limousine Co. Beloved father of Patricia and Maureen. Dear brother of Frank, John, Joseph, Kathleen and Mary of Ireland. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Avenue at 76 Street, Thursday, 10 AM. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: MONEY AND POLLS TAKE CENTER STAGE IN CALIFORNIA RACE
description: After the most high-priced and volatile primary campaign in California history, this state's voters will pick nominees for Governor on Tuesday in an election that has rekindled a debate over the potency of television commercials and underscored the perils for wealthy candidates who finance their own campaigns.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Circuits on Thursday about the drive for simpler computers misspelled the surname of a consultant and misstated her role in data recovery for a computer user, Irena Chalmers. The consultant was Jennifer Macdonald, not MacDonald. She began helping Ms. Chalmers after another consultant recovered the computer files; it was not she who salvaged them.

title: TV Guide to Introduce Coverage of Advertising
description: Viewers who believe that commercials are as good as -- if not better than -- many of the television programs they interrupt will soon have a new way to keep track of favorite product pitches, celebrity endorsers and anthropomorphic spokescharacters.

description: Boston led by 11-0 in the fourth inning yesterday, and Bernie Williams stalled and waited before getting into the batter's box. Pedro Martinez, the Red Sox pitcher, finally got tired of waiting and yelled at Williams, in Spanish, to hit.

description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

Contributions to charity of one's choice.

title: Bird Revisits a Thrill, If Only From the Bench
description: Larry Bird was wrapping it up, having acquitted himself well under difficult circumstances. ''The number of offensive rebounds ripped our heart out,'' he said last night, his voice trailing off. A fawning reporter finally thanked him for his candor, adding, ''You've been a breath of fresh air.''

title: Advantage, India
description: Nawaz Sharif, Pakistan's Prime Minister, claimed that the country's nuclear tests last week ''evened the score with India.'' But if any country gained an advantage, it was India.

title: Metro Matters; One Hot Dog, But Hold The Mayor
description: FOR the last 16 years, in the shade of a blue and yellow Sabrett umbrella, Peter Nikolopoulos has been selling hot dogs from the same spot in Manhattan: the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 45th Street.

title: Budget Baloney
description: In 1981, a newly inaugurated President Reagan proudly announced plans to cut taxes, boost defense spending and balance the Federal budget within three years through ''additional savings to be proposed'' later. In fact, the Reagan team had been unable to agree on just what to cut, so that little line was an effort to finesse the problem.

title: Trial Starts in 2d Case Under Death Penalty Law
description: On the opening day of the second trial under New York's three-year-old death penalty law, a police officer testified that a 6-year-old boy had implicated his father in a double homicide.

description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman faces growing opposition in the State Legislature over her proposal to raise the gasoline tax by 7 cents a gallon to help finance improvements in transportation and preserve open space.

description: Over and over today, the prosecution in the contempt trial of former President P. W. Botha used its first witness to lay out the questions that remain unanswered.

title: HALL OF HARD QUESTIONS
description: Like, where to fit it all? The creation of the American Museum of Natural History's new biodiversity exhibit was an adventure in itself. Page 4.

title: Nassau's Sales-Tax Revenue Seen Slumping
description: Despite a healthy economy, Nassau County could be running a $30 million deficit by the end of the year if sales tax revenues continue to lag behind budget projections, the County Comptroller said today.

title: Out of Violence, a Survivor and a Scholar
description: Three years ago, Daira Hodges was a 14-year-old ninth grader and honor student who lived with her family in a middle-class suburb. ''I thought everything was a utopia,'' she said recently. ''I mean, to me, the next best place to be besides home was school.''

description: If Bob Costas pursued NBC's original plan, he would be completing his eighth season of National Basketball Association play-by-play. But he chose to be host of the studio show for seven years, deferring to Marv Albert to call games.

title: Market Research Sees Revenue Gain
description: Research marketing revenue rose last year, according to the 25th annual Honomichl Report to be published next week by the American Marketing Association. It states that the 50 largest market research agencies had total revenue in 1997 of $5.5 billion, up 9 percent from 1996. That increase compared with a gain of 7.1 percent in 1996 from 1995.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Ideas pages on Saturday with excerpts from a lecture about melancholy delivered by Andrew Delbanco, the Levi Professor in the Humanities at Columbia University, omitted the credit. The picture, of ''Office in a Small City,'' a 1953 painting by Edward Hopper, should have been credited to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, George A. Hearn Fund.

title: In an Old Orchard, Tastes the Supermarket Forgot
description: I FINALLY understood why Adam was so enticed by Eden's apples when we walked for the first time through our orchard near the northern coast of Lake Michigan. More than 100 apple trees -- some gnarled and thick at the trunk like an old ash, others mere saplings -- stood scattered on a sandy ridge between the maple forest and a dun-colored meadow.

title: What 'Historical Jesus'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Coup Charges Dropped, and Zambia's Ex-Leader Is Freed
description: Kenneth D. Kaunda, the former President of Zambia, was set free today after Zambian prosecutors dropped charges that he had a role in a botched coup attempt last year.

title: A White House Legal Dodge
description: The latest maneuvering by the White House to avoid accelerated Supreme Court review of its flimsy privilege claims should not deter the justices from grabbing the case. This is an instance where the Court, in its constitutional role, should see the need to intervene in the interest of orderly government and the rule of law. The nation needs a definitive resolution of the issues that have been raised by the White House to impede the investigation by independent counsel Kenneth Starr.

title: CityHawks Fall
description: Barry Wagner snared a 13-yard touchdown pass with one hand with 3 minutes left last night to give the Orlando Predators a 43-41 victory over the CityHawks before an announced crowd of 6,714 Madison Square Garden.

title: Montenegro Chief's Victory Widens Rift With Belgrade
description: President Milo Djukanovic of Montenegro today celebrated his governing coalition's sweeping victory in crucial parliamentary elections, insuring his domination of a Government that will defy integration with Serbia. The victory is considered certain to widen the schism between Mr. Djukanovic and the Belgrade Government of President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARONOWITZ, GEORGE
description: ARONOWITZ-George. You're remembered every day. Our love is endless, Sweetheart. Lydia, Steve, Merrill, Andy, Julie

title: National News Briefs; Teamster Group Takes Sides in Union Elections
description: Teamsters for a Democratic Union, a rank-and-file anti-corruption group, announced yesterday that it had endorsed Tom Leedham, director of the teamsters' warehouse division, in this summer's race for the union's presidency.

title: Collecting, Classifying, Naming, Knowing: The Tasks of Tring
description: ALL nature lovers know about the great natural history museums, from the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago to the Musee d'Histoire Naturelle in Paris. But have you ever heard of Tring?

title: Strategy as Intricate as a Double Helix
description: Ask Hendrik A. Verfaillie, president of the Monsanto Company, about the benefits likely to emerge from the announcement today of Monsanto's proposed merger with the American Home Products Corporation, and he turns the clock back four years.

title: Sprint in Plan To Enter Local Phone Market
description: The Sprint Corporation, the No. 3 long-distance telephone carrier, plans to announce today its long-awaited strategy for competing in local communications markets, executives close to the company said yesterday.

title: Mission Accomplished: Pioline Ousts Russian
description: Giddy as a man who had just won the lottery, or at the very least won his first career Grand Slam event at the doddering age of 28, Cedric Pioline kissed his racquet, his wristband, and almost kissed Moscow's Marat Safin, the towering neophyte he had outwitted and outlasted in a five-set test today.

title: Jawboning Russian Markets
description: You know you are on new economic terrain when the White House decides to rush out a pronouncement on Russia on a Sunday, not because of some impending Russian Government action but in hopes of influencing financial markets to be more inclined to lend money to the Moscow Government.

title: Indonesia Pumping Aid Funds Into Banks
description: Bank Indonesia, the central bank, said yesterday that it had injected 83.5 trillion rupiah ($7.4 billion) into banks swamped by depositor withdrawals and bad debt since the nation's economic crisis began 10 months ago. The Bank Indonesia governor, Sjahril Sabirin, said that the Government intended to recover all of that debt through its Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency.

title: The Endangered Species Act Gets a Makeover
description: IT has been more than 20 years since advocates of saving the snail darter, a minnow-sized fish believed to be on the brink of oblivion, blocked the mighty Tennessee Valley Authority from building the $137 million Tellico Dam. That case went to the Supreme Court, which sided with the fish, and only when Congress intervened did the dam go forward.

title: Kasparov, Fast on His Feet, Takes Match From Topalov
description: At the quick-play rate of 25 minutes per game for each player, one has to expect more errors than at the regular tournament pace of 2 hours each for 40 moves. But in the four-game exhibition match in Sofia, Bulgaria, between Garry Kasparov and Veselin Topalov, the top Bulgarian grandmaster, blunders fell haphazardly thick and fast.

title: BioWhat? A Diversity Of Opinions
description: JUST what is biodiversity? The definition in Webster's New World College Dictionary is short and sweet: ''diversity, or variety, in the living things in a particular area or region.''

title: TV Channel With Its Eye On All Europe
description: Most Europeans still think of themselves as French, German, Italian, British or whatever first and Europeans second. Even the weather reports on the nightly television news in any country seldom report what is happening just across the border. So building a truly European public television station was a mighty challenge for Arte, a Franco-German cultural broadcasting channel based in this European city, when it started up six years ago.

title: Philippines Sues Christie's for Lost Picasso
description: Twelve years after a Picasso painting disappeared from the New York office of the Philippine Government at the end of the Marcos regime, officials of that Government say they have discovered the painting's whereabouts; about 10 blocks away, in the hallowed halls of the auction house Christie's. Now the Government is suing to get it back.

title: Ferry Company Will Get Funds for New Terminal
description: Under an economic incentive package announced yesterday, New York Waterway, a private company that runs ferries to Manhattan, will receive a $12 million Federal grant and $11 million in low-cost loans from New Jersey and Hudson County to build a ferry terminal linked to a light rail station along the Hudson River in Weehawken.

title: Mother's Love, Despite 'Terrible Crime'
description: Telling jurors who are deciding whether her son should be executed that his fate was really ''in the Lord's hands,'' the mother of a former jail guard recounted yesterday how she fell apart when the police told her that her ''special child'' killed three people.

title: The Mets' Streak Stops With Mlicki
description: Hideo Nomo is looking for work. Brian Bohanon would rather start than relieve. And a certain hyperactive young left-hander named Bill Pulsipher is chafing at Norfolk over the chance to pitch in the major leagues again.

title: Brooklyn Woman Indicted in Officer's Slaying
description: The Brooklyn woman accused of helping her boyfriend kill a police officer who had gone to their apartment to arrest him last week was indicted yesterday on charges including second-degree murder, robbery and assaulting a police officer.

title: By Design; Only the Look Is Lighter
description: Once June arrives, those indispensable leather tote bags look awfully heavy. It is definitely time to switch to fabric or straw.

She is survived by her sister Rachael Klausner, her nephew Philip Allen and their families who loved her and will miss her greatly. She was one of a kind.

title: Goldman, Sachs Nears Decisive Talks on Going Public
description: The partners of Goldman, Sachs & Company are deep in discussion about how best to structure their storied firm and whether to open it to public ownership, Jon S. Corzine, Goldman's senior partner, told employees yesterday morning, executives at the Wall Street firm said.

description: The invitations surprised Bobbye Sloan. Her husband wanted her to come into the locker room after his team, the Utah Jazz, won the Western Conference finals. He wanted her to ride the team bus back to the hotel.

title: Wireless Phone Will Operate Abroad
description: The Audiovox Corporation and the Bosch Telecom unit of Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. of Germany plan to announce today the availability of a wireless telephone that can operate on different continents without modification.

title: Jarvis Interviews With St. John's
description: Mike Jarvis of George Washington met last night with Ed Manetta, St. John's athletic director, becoming the fourth coach to interview for the Red Storm's head basketball job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, MARTIN L.

title: TROUT TRUTHS
description: As a devastating disease infects the pristine rivers of Montana, questions arise about whether human efforts to improve on nature are to blame. Page 10.

title: Dodgers Cut Nomo Loose And Will Try to Trade Him

title: SCIENCE WATCH; Making the Best of It

Now the Research Service of the Federal Department of Agriculture is exploring a factory-style solution to the problem: a 77,000-square-foot composting center that can handle 100 tons of cow and poultry manure and used livestock bedding a day.

title: Reasons To Ratify, Not To Stall
description: The nuclear tests by India and Pakistan have led some in the United States Senate to seek further delay on the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, which has already been awaiting ratification for more than a year and a half. Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Senate majority leader, said on Friday that ''the nuclear spiral in Asia demonstrates the irrelevance of U.S. action'' on the treaty, calling the pact ''unverifiable and ineffectual.''

title: Life's Ups and Downs: Charting Extinctions
description: Extinction is a steady process, exacting a continuous toll of species even in the best of times. Biologists believe this is a device that continually opens niches for new species, thereby fueling the engine of natural selection and the growth of biological diversity, which has grown, if unsteadily, ever since the first explosion of large animal life in the Cambrian era 540 million years ago.

title: Once Upon a Magnetar
description: Traces of a dark relic of a once-bright star 40,000 light-years from Earth have confirmed the existence of a class of neutron stars called magnetars, according to a team of scientists at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala.

title: ARCO IN TALKS OVER SALE OF CHEMICAL BUSINESS
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, the Los Angeles-based oil company, is talking to potential buyers of all or part of its 82.3 percent stake in the ARCO Chemical Company and will decide what to do with the business by year-end, the chairman, Michael R. Bowlin, said yesterday. Analysts say a sale of the chemical business could fetch $6 billion. ARCO Chemical generated about 20 percent of Atlantic Richfield's 1997 revenue but only 7.2 percent of the company's $1.77 billion in net income last year. Shares of Atlantic Richfield fell 68.75 cents yesterday, to $78.1875, while ARCO Chemical slipped 31.25 cents, to $55.4375.

description: IT is difficult to know for sure, but there may be more kinds of creatures living on earth now than ever before in the planet's 4.6-billion-year history. Or at least there were that many before human beings appeared very late in the game and began changing the rules.

title: Travelers to Get 25% Stake in Japanese Brokerage House
description: The Travelers Group and the Nikko Securities Company formally announced an agreement today that will give the Wall Street powerhouse a 25 percent stake in Japan's third-largest securities brokerage firm for $1.6 billion. The deal immediately raised questions about how quickly the Japanese financial industry would consolidate.

description: After three months of fruitless negotiations, the city's largest transit union went on strike today, shutting down a nexus of buses, trolleys and subways that serves up to 435,000 people a day.

description: The nation's accounting rule makers said yesterday that they had given final approval to a new rule that will force companies to record the value of derivatives in their financial statements.

description: IN New York City, there are 30 million rats, four for every person, and billions upon billions of cockroaches. But the nation's largest city, unbeknown even to many of its residents, abounds with other life -- some unexpected, some rare and almost all as tough as their concrete-jungle ecosystem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, EDWARD J, DR.

He is survived by a daughter, Maryanne Hall Smith of Bethel, a son of J. Edward Hall, Jr. of Mirror Lake, NH, 7 grandchildren, 6 greatgrandchildren and a sister, Helena Orben of NJ. Contributions in memory of Dr. J. Edward Hall may be made to the charity of one's choice.

To the scientists, the palm, with its unusual flowers and soaring trunk, was a special, splendid thing. But to the farmer about to cut it down, it was blocking his plans to expand his sparse field of stunted corn stalks.

title: KEMET TO DISMISS 1,440 WORKERS IN U.S. AND MEXICO
description: The Kemet Corporation, a maker of capacitors used in computers and other electronic equipment, said yesterday that it was cutting 1,440 jobs in the United States and Mexico because its sales were slowing down. Kemet said it would lay off 540 workers in the United States and 900 in Mexico in a move intended to reduce expenses by $14 million a year. The layoffs are the second in six months for Kemet, which has been under pressure because of the soaring cost of palladium and the slackening worldwide demand for electronic equipment. The company, based in Greenville, S.C., dismissed 1,000 workers in November. Its shares fell 65.625 cents yesterday, to $15.4375.

title: Rex's Hungry Cousin
description: The bones of a huge meat-eating dinosaur have been discovered in Madagascar, off the east coast of Africa. The specimen, Majungatholus atopus, would have been 25 to 30 feet long. Majungatholus is a distant relative of the famous Tyrannosaurus rex and closely resembles South American predatory dinosaurs. The new fossils could revise thinking about how these dinosaurs evolved and how the positions of continents have changed since they died out more than 65 million years ago. Dr. Scott Sampson of the New York Institute of Technology, writing in the journal Science, said the discovery suggests that South America, India and Madagascar were all connected, probably through Antarctica, when this species developed, and that Africa had already split off as a separate island continent. The dinosaur's skull and lower jaws, with wicked teeth, are shown above; an artist's reconstruction is at right. JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

title: Goodwill Team at 17

title: Appealing to the Imagination (and to Youngsters' Patience)
description: Although most children surely know the story of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' the great ballet of that title is, at least in its complete form, essentially for grown-ups. Just as long, rhapsodic speeches in a poetic drama may delight adult ears but make children restless, so the many beautiful solo variations of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' may tax young dancegoers' attention spans.

title: Inevitabilities, Inevitably, Along With Some Surprises
description: By one count, Dmitry Rachmanov, a Russian-born pianist now widely active in the New York area, played three encores on Thursday evening in his recital at Merkin Concert Hall. Almost inevitable under the circumstances were Liadov's ''Musical Snuffbox'' and Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Flight of the Bumblebee,'' but a Scriabin nocturne for the left hand made for a distinctive close.

title: The Aging Boys of Barcelona
description: Michael Jordan had just enough energy left on Sunday night to forklift the Chicago Bulls into yet another National Basketball Association final. That seemed fitting, since it is hard to imagine a final without Jordan. It is even harder to imagine rooting against him in his twilight years, but the seditious thought occurs that there may actually be more people pulling for his opponents, the Utah Jazz, an admirable and workmanlike team that lost to the Bulls in the final round last year.

title: YELLOW CORP. TO SELL PRESTON UNIT TO MANAGEMENT
description: The Yellow Corporation, one of the nation's largest long-haul trucking companies, agreed to sell its struggling Preston regional trucking unit, taking a second-quarter after-tax charge of as much as $65 million. Yellow will sell Preston to three senior Preston officers. Terms were not disclosed. Preston contributed $451 million, or 13 percent, of Yellow's $3.35 billion in revenue last year. The unit, based in Preston, Md., has generated scant profit since Yellow bought it for $23.9 million in 1992. Yellow said it would buy back as much as $25 million in stock to bolster shareholder value. Shares of Yellow, based in Overland Park, Kan., rose 31.25 cents yesterday, to $19.0625.

title: Urine Test for H.I.V. Wins U.S. Approval
description: The Calypte Biomedical Corporation said today that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing its urine test for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The test is the first complete urine-based diagnostic kit for H.I.V. that does not require confirmation by blood test.

title: BRADLEY REAL ESTATE BUYING MID-AMERICA REALTY
description: Bradley Real Estate Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Mid-America Realty Investments Inc. for around $87 million in securities and $66 million in assumed debt. Shareholders of Mid-America Realty, which is based in Omaha, will swap each of their 8.29 million shares for 0.42 share of Bradley convertible preferred stock with a par value of $25 each. The exchange ratio values Mid-America's shares at $10.50 each. The shares closed at $10.125 yesterday, down 43.75 cents, while shares of Bradley, based in Northbrook, Ill., slipped 6.25 cents, to $20.8125. Under the deal, Bradley will gain ownership of 25 shopping center properties, increasing its holdings to 88 properties.

title: HEICO ADDING FRENCH AERONAUTICAL PRODUCTS CONCERN
description: The Heico Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Teleflex Lionel-Dupont of Paris for about $64 million in class A stock. Heico, an aerospace, aviation and military products company based in Hollywood, Fla., will also assume debt of $53 million to buy the larger Teleflex Lionel-Dupont, a maker of aeronautical products and ground-support equipment. Heico said the purchase, along with the ground-support business it acquired when it bought Trilectron Industries in 1996, would give it the largest share of the highly fragmented industry of providing equipment to service aircraft while on the ground. Teleflex Lionel-Dupont had revenue of $146 million last year, while Heico had $64 million. Heico's class A shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $28.

title: EMERITUS SELLING 6 ASSISTED-LIVING COMMUNITIES
description: The Emeritus Corporation said yesterday that it was selling six of its unprofitable assisted-living operations to an undisclosed buyer for $53.1 million, reducing the company's losses by about $4 million a year. The six communities for the elderly have a total of 750 units. Emeritus, a long-term-care provider based in Seattle, holds interests in about 126 centers in 27 states and Canada. Four of the centers being sold are in Florida, one is in Kansas and one is in Arizona. In April, Emeritus said its loss, before a charge, widened to $8.4 million, or 84 cents a share, from $3.6 million, or 32 cents, a year earlier.

title: More Turmoil in Asia and Russia Lifts Blue-Chip Shares
description: Investors seeking to avoid the turmoil in Asian and Russian financial markets bought blue-chip stocks and Treasury bonds yesterday.

title: Vending Ban Widens: Not Just Food but Also Books and Art
description: Broadening their efforts to limit what they see as dangerous congestion on New York City's sidewalks, Giuliani administration officials said yesterday that their vending ban would include not only food carts but also street sales of books, baseball cards, art, T-shirts and all other goods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, SHIRLEY
description: LEVINE-Shirley. Beloved wife of Jules. Devoted mother of Dr. Robert and Dr. Johanan. Dear sister of Rose Fischner. Dearest aunt of Aaron and Ronald Neretin and their families. Fond grandmother of Didi. Devoted teacher of generations of New York City kindergartners. Loved by all who knew her. She was a source of warmth, dignity and inspiration; perpetually joyful and an accomplished Hebrew scholar. Service Tuesday, 11 AM, at the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 122 W. 76th St.

title: Study Links High Heels to Arthritis
description: CLOTHES may or may not make the man, but high-heeled shoes almost certainly make a woman's knees susceptible to arthritis, a study in Boston has shown.

title: Political Memo; Economy Fades as Big Issue In Newly Surging California
description: The most striking thing about the primary election campaigns here, from the candidates' debate to the deluge of 30-second television commercials and the speeches on the stump, was that the topic that dominated California politics for years rarely surfaced: the economy.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Ultimate Fin-de-Siecle Designer
description: Flush fashion companies have thrown a lot of money at a lot of talented young designers in the last few years, setting them up at the ritzy labels that rule the duty-free shops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINDRED, GLORIA E.
description: KINDRED-Gloria E. Widow of Rollan Rochelle. A native New Yorker, she spent many years in advertising becoming a highly respected systems analyst. She returned to school in 1985 and graduated Summa Cum Laude from Fordham University at Lincoln Center in 1995. She belonged to two honor societies. For many years, Mrs. Kindred volunteered an evening each week to Reading for the Blind and Dyslexic. In addition to her interest in magic and slight-of-hand, Mrs. Kindred enjoyed art, music and poetry. She is survived by her sister June Lawton of Corona, NY.

title: Military Budget in India Is Increased by 14 Percent
description: Declaring that there can be ''no compromise on defense preparedness'' in the wake of the nuclear tests conducted by India and Pakistan, the Government of Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee announced today that it has approved large budget increases for the country's armed forces, as well as for nuclear research and missile programs.

title: Dangerous Liaisons, On Line or Otherwise
description: If there is any act more vicious than the hoax perpetrated against Robert, the tormented hero of Craig Lucas's tortured new play, ''The Dying Gaul,'' it might be labeled a psychic atrocity.

title: Nonequal Compensation For Equal Positions
description: John R. Stafford, chief executive of American Home Products, and Robert B. Shapiro, his counterpart at Monsanto, emphasized yesterday that the $34.4 billion stock-for-stock deal they had just constructed was a merger of equals. But as is almost always the case in life, one player in this high-stakes game is more equal than the other.

title: Manhattan Woman Dies In Hit-And-Run Accident
description: A Manhattan woman who was crossing the street near her Upper East Side home early yesterday was struck and killed by a hit-and-run driver, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOBRICK, DAVID H.
description: BOBRICK-David H. We recall with fondness and gratitude Uncle Dave's happy visits during our childhood days. The ever-present, fun-loving, twinkle in his eye showed three youngsters that giving joy to others is very much a part of one's life. Carol Barrish, Edgar and Michael Lampert

title: The Life of a Child, Minute by Detailed Minute
description: THE EVERLASTING STORY OF NORY

title: Fruit of the Loom redesigns its sales pitches with a modern edge for -- no surprise -- 'fruitness.'
description: SINCE the days when Carmen Miranda wore fruit on her head, consumers have been urged to wear Fruit of the Loom apparel on their bodies. Now the brand is changing its advertising in an attempt to create a more contemporary image.

title: Authority Votes to Cut Long Island Power Rates
description: With Gov. George E. Pataki beaming and a host of other state and local dignitaries applauding, the Long Island Power Authority voted unanimously yesterday to cut local electricity rates an average of 20 percent, retroactive to 12:01 A.M. last Friday.

title: Big Losses To Confront Livent's New Leader
description: Michael Ovitz had better relish a challenge. Livent Inc., the Toronto-based entertainment company that Mr. Ovitz is to assume control of this week, has announced that it lost $20 million in the first quarter of the year, which, added to grim financial results for 1997, means the company has lost approximately $50 million over the last 15 months.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVENKRON, RACHEL
description: LEVENKRON-Rachel. 6/21, 19046/1, 1988. 10 years have passed. Our love for you is undiminished by time. Your Family

title: The High Price of Getting Something for Nothing
description: ONE of the most appealing aspects of the Web is getting something for nothing, not counting connection fees. One short-term no-cost offering is Outlook 98, the latest version of Microsoft's ambitious calendar, E-mail and address book package.

title: Russia's Finance Picture Darkens Further as Market Falls
description: Despite President Clinton's effort to bring about an end to Russia's financial crisis, the outlook continued to darken today.

title: Sports of The Times; For Duran, It's a Garden Of Memories
description: NEARLY 100 fights and 27 years ago, Roberto Duran arrived in New York, a 20-year-old Panamanian lightweight with a 25-0 record and the sneering snarl of a Caribbean pirate in an old Errol Flynn movie. All he needed to fit the part was a bandanna around his head and a knife between his teeth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, CAROL S.
description: BARON-Carol S. Born September 26, 1912 in New York City passed away May 30, 1998 in Los Angeles where she resided for nearly fifty years. A Smith College graduate, she was a secretary at CBS Television for more than twenty years until her retirement in 1977. During her career, she worked on such programs as Playhouse 90, The Danny Kaye Show, The Judy Garland Show and The Eve Arden Show. She is survived by her son, Roger (wife Margi) of Northbrook, IL. and grandsons Jeffrey (wife Pamela) and Gregory. Graveside services and interment will be in the family plot at Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Sighs of a Fictional Playwright As Decorous as the Real One
description: The smile, to tell the truth, is a little scary. Worn fixedly by Josef Sommer in ''Labor Day,'' A. R. Gurney's new play at the Manhattan Theater Club, it has a beleaguered, on-the-edge quality, like that of a long-persecuted martyr who is finally about to crack.

title: In Otherwise Quiet Primary, 2 Intriguing Races
description: New Jersey's primary elections on Tuesday have hardly roused much excitement among the voters -- the state expects a minimal turnout -- but the contestants in the two Congressional races that have attracted the most attention at least provide an interesting pair of contrasts.

title: Excerpts From Clinton's Response to a Motion by Starr
description: Following are excerpts from papers filed today in the United States Supreme Court by President Clinton in response to a motion on Thursday by the independent counsel for an expedited review of claims made by Mr. Clinton that would block the testimony of some of his top aides:

title: West Wayne Names Chief Creative Officer
description: West Wayne Inc. in Atlanta has named Luke Sullivan to oversee its creative output as chief creative officer. Mr. Sullivan, 43, a copywriter at Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis for almost a decade, assumes responsibilities from Martin Macdonald, vice chairman and executive creative director, who left in February.

title: Robert Young, 78, Ex-Magazine Publisher
description: Robert F. Young, a longtime president and publisher of Family Circle magazine who guided the publication through growth here and abroad, died after a short illness last Wednesday in Greensboro, N.C, where he lived. He was 78.

title: Primary Lessons
description: New Yorkers who take perverse pride in complaining about the state's dreadful political process must be humbled by today's California primary. Gov. George Pataki's $12 million campaign chest looks like bus fare compared with the money that has already been spent there, just on the race for a gubernatorial nomination. The three Democratic contenders together have forked over about $60 million. In company like this, even Senator Alfonse D'Amato could end up looking impoverished.

title: What 'Historical Jesus'?
description: To the Editor:

title: High Court Lowers Shield of Election Panel; Also Agrees to Hear Deportation Appeal
description: The Supreme Court today opened the door to lawsuits against the Federal Election Commission by voters claiming that the commission has not adequately enforced the disclosure requirements imposed by Federal law on certain political groups.

title: D'Amato Campaign Fund Awash In Donations by Hopeful Lobbies
description: The amendment was brief, so it attracted scant notice when Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato helped tuck it into a bill he was shepherding through the Senate as chairman of the Banking Committee. But the provision, which weakened a consumer protection statute governing the real estate industry, was decidedly important to one company.

title: Dow Jones Decides to Buy Back Shares
description: Dow Jones & Company plans to buy back as much as $300 million of its shares and take a $98 million second-quarter charge as it completes the sale of its financial information unit to Bridge Information Systems Inc.

title: Indonesia, in Drama's Grip, Warily Awaits Finale
description: Suddenly, after decades of repression, Indonesia feels like a country without rules -- and that, for many people here, is as frightening as it is exhilarating.

title: Hypocrisy on H.I.V.
description: To the Editor:

title: Raines's Dash Home Lifts Yanks
description: Most teams wouldn't run from three-game losing streaks as if the players' lives depended on it. Most teams are not like the Yankees, however, as their major league-best record of 38-13 bears out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONERKAMP, FRANK W., SR.
description: HONERKAMP-Frank W., Sr. on May 30, 1998. Beloved husband of Ruth (nee McManus). Devoted father of MaryLou Lorenz (late Henry), Frank Jr. (Gina), Philip (Debbie), Peter (Marcie) and the late Robert. Dear brother of Fred (Mary), Peggy McNally (late Charles). Loving grandfather of Frank III (Kelly), Stephen, P.J., Katherine, John, Jeffrey, Beth, Meg, Max and Ruby. Brother-inlaw of Virginia McManus (late John) and the late Philip and Betty McManus. Also many godchildren, nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends at Donza Funeral Home, 333 Atlantic Ave, East Rockaway, L.I. Tuesday, 24:30 and 7-9PM and until 9:30 AM Wednesday. Funeral mass following at 10:45 AM, St. Anastasia Church, Douglaston. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Dominican Village, 565 Albany Ave, Amityville, NY 11701.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Wednesday about the end of remedial courses at the senior colleges of the City University of New York used an erroneous estimate for the plan's cost. The figure, $80 million, was for the entire university system, not solely the affected colleges. The university said the loss to senior colleges enacting the policy in 1999 -- representing tuition revenue and the cost of added summer immersion programs, offset by savings -- would be $9.5 million the first year. For those adopting the policy in 2000, it would be $6.9 million the first year; for those adopting it in 2001, the figure is $1.4 million.

title: The Last of the Girls' School Grande Dames
description: EDES GILBERT will soon be the last of the grande dames to step down as head of a selective New York City private girls' school, and thus ends an era of powerful women who cloaked their ambitions in plummy diction and good manners.

title: Miller Set for Hefty Pay Cut In New Pact With Giants
description: The contract impasse between the Giants and linebacker Corey Miller will end Tuesday when Miller signs a restructured deal that calls for a substantial pay cut from the $1.5 million he was scheduled to make next season.

title: New Serb Assault On Albania Rebels
description: President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has started a major campaign to wipe out a separatist rebel movement in the Serbian province of Kosovo, senior NATO officials and Western diplomats say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADISON, GEORGE
description: NADISON-George. The Board of Governors and membership of Edgewood Country Club record with deep sorrow the death of Mr. George Nadison, an esteemed member, and extend to his beloved wife, Bernice, and family its deepest sympathy. Saul Friedland, President Sidney Gottlieb, Secretary

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline on Friday about the contribution of automobiles' catalytic converters to global warming misstated the amount of nitrous oxide that the Environmental Protection Agency believes comes from the devices. A draft study by the E.P.A. said that about 3 percent comes from cars and trucks, out of a total contribution of 7 percent from all manmade sources. Cars and trucks alone do not account for 7 percent. In a statement issued yesterday in response to the article, the E.P.A. said the production of the gas by converters ''could be closer to 2 percent or less.''

title: Rocket Launching, on the Cheap
description: The controversy over President Clinton's decision to allow American satellites to be launched atop Chinese rockets has focused on campaign contributions and on whether China received technical help from American companies to improve the accuracy of its intercontinental ballistic missiles. But the root-cause question of the scandal has gone unasked: why are American satellites sitting atop Chinese launchers at all, rather than arcing skyward from the space installations American taxpayers have spent billions to construct?

title: Subway Series, Part I? It May Be Up to Piazza
description: It won't be long before the inter-league series between the Mets and the Yankees will be billed as a World Series preview. Who knows? By that weekend, June 26-28, the Mets may even be in first place.

title: Meet the New Spice Girl
description: The news that the Spice Girls have lost Geri Halliwell -- a k a Ginger Spice -- has loosed a flurry of rumor and innuendo. But the most extraordinary claim, apparently factual, is the Girls' own assertion that the pop group will continue, albeit as a foursome.

title: Record for Exchange Seat
description: A record $225,000 has been paid for a seat on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, the exchange said yesterday. The New York-based exchange said the sale beat the previous record set on May 13 of $200,000, which tied with the last high price set in 1996. The Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange is in the process of merging with the New York Cotton Exchange.

title: Jets Release Williams, One of '96 Gang of Four
description: The Jets lost another key component of the high-profile influx of offense they made two years ago when they released right tackle David Williams today.

title: Park Is Creative Challenge for Nicklaus
description: Jack Nicklaus has designed golf courses in the desert, on tropical islands and in remote wooded areas. But building a golf course on a Bronx garbage heap should rank as one of his most creative projects.

title: Committee Approves Bill To Change Seat Belt Law
description: The police will be authorized to stop vehicles if a front-seat occupant is not wearing a seat belt, under a bill approved yesterday by the Assembly Transportation Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERSON, HAROLD I.
description: MEYERSON-Harold I. 91. On May 31. Beloved husband of Leona. A faithful friend and loved by many. Graduate of Rutgers University and Law School. Officer in the U.S. Navy during WW II. Member of the law firm of Kressel & Meyerson and Hale Grant Meyerson O'Brien & McCormick and of the Bar for over 65 years. No services. Will rest in peace in the North Country.

title: Adding Years to Life and Life to Years
description: PEOPLE with bad health habits that they will not or cannot abandon often make excuses: ''What's the point of living longer -- you'll only spend more years in a nursing home?'' or ''A healthy life really isn't any longer, it just seems that way.''

title: Bulls Have Championships, Jazz Has the Home Court
description: The Bulls will leave the plane and take their first giant steps of this finals appearance with the trepidation of an astronaut. There will be excitement, but uncertainty as they plant themselves on the Delta Center floor in Salt Lake City for Game 1 Wednesday in a land that might as well be another planet this year.

title: Milton Hindus, the Last of the Brandeis Pioneers, Dies at 81
description: Milton Hindus, a scholar of American and European literature and the last of Brandeis University's original faculty, died on Thursday when he collapsed outside the main entrance to the campus in Waltham, Mass. He was 81 and lived in Newton, Mass.

title: One False Note in a Musician's Life; Billy Tipton Is Remembered With Love, Even by Those Who Were Deceived
description: On the morning of Jan. 21, 1989, Billy Tipton, 74, a gifted jazz musician who was a veteran of the tiny clubs and V.F.W. posts of small-town America, collapsed on the floor of a mobile home in Spokane, Wash. Tipton's son William summoned paramedics, and as they opened Tipton's pajamas to perform resuscitation, they made an extraordinary discovery. Tipton, who most people had assumed to be a man, who had had at least five wives and had adopted three sons, was in fact a woman.

title: Romiti Is Expected to Use Retirement Payment to Buy Into Rizzoli-Corriere : Fiat President Is Moving to Publishing Group
description: ROME  Cesare Romiti, the departing president of Fiat, will be named Tuesday as chairman of the Rizzoli-Corriere della Sera newspaper and publishing group and will acquire an indirect equity stake in the business as well, according to the Milan-based newspaper.

title: With a Song on Your Web
description: LISTEN carefully: Is that the song of a cerulean warbler outside your window?

title: Silver Launch to Miss Belmont With an Injury
description: Nick Zito, who lost Halory Hunter five days before the Preakness with an ankle injury, lost his shot at the Belmont Stakes yesterday when an ankle injury forced him to withdraw Silver Launch six days before the final race in the Triple Crown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, JOYCE
description: PERLMAN-Joyce. A devoted, caring friend. Her family and friends were the backbone of her life. Our shared memories will be forever. To Norman, her children and grandchildren she leaves a loving heritage. Tanya and Ronald LeBovici Marcia and Carl Turetsky

title: Metro Business; Ex-MCI Executives Admit Guilt in Fraud
description: Three former managers at MCI International in Piscataway, N.J., pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges of accepting $312,000 in kickbacks from companies seeking to do business with the company.

title: It's Been a Cosmic Half-Century For Palomar's 200-inch Telescope
description: FIFTY years ago tomorrow some 800 astronomers and V.I.P.'s gathered under the new Hale Telescope on the summit of Palomar Mountain, near San Diego, to celebrate the telescope's ''first light,'' as astronomers call the moment when a new telescope is opened to the night sky for the first time. The Hale Telescope, named for George Ellery Hale, who proposed it in 1928, was the largest and greatest working telescope on earth.

title: AMSOUTH SHEDS SOME OPERATIONS IN 2 SEPARATE DEALS
description: The Amsouth Bancorp said yesterday that it had sold its bond administration and stock transfer businesses to the Bank of New York Company for an undisclosed amount. In an unrelated deal, Amsouth sold $170 million of its credit card portfolio to Associates National Bank (Delaware), a unit of the Associates First Capital Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Amsouth said that employees affected by the sales would be offered other positions, and that the transactions would not have a material effect on current Amsouth earnings. The Bank of New York said it planned to open an office for the acquired businesses in Birmingham, Ala., where Amsouth is based.

title: Drug Giants to Merge In a $34 Billion Deal
description: Monsanto agreed to be acquired by American Home Products for $34.4 billion in stock, the largest deal ever in the pharmaceuticals industry.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about aviation education in Queens misstated the number of air passengers in the United States in recent years. According to the Air Transport Association, the number grew to more than 580 million (not 580,000) in 1996, from 450 million a year (not 450,000) in the early 1990's.

title: Dominick Corso, 90, Civil Court Judge
description: Dominick Corso, a New York Civil Court judge and former City Councilman, died May 23. He was 90 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: SEOUL LEADER ASKS END TO SANCTIONS ON NORTH KOREANS
description: In an effort to ease a half-century of enmities on the Korean Peninsula, President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea called today for the United States and other Western countries to end sanctions against North Korea and to show greater flexibility in dealing with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLET, ANNETTE (NEW BERENBERG)
description: POLLET-Annette (new Berenberg). Passed away in her home in West Palm Beach, May 30. Harlem Hospital Chemist, New York City elementary teacher, dancerfolk, square, rounds, bridge and tennis player, firm friend, lover of husband Henry, son Robert, daughter-in-law Donna, and three accomplished grandchildren, Joshua M., Adam N., Sarah J. Funeral services are to be held in Florida today. 1-800-94-SHALOM. Memorial contributions may be make to the Leukemia Society.

title: . . . Economists Point To Values Beyond Price
description: IN the big picture and in the long run, it's true: to paraphrase Yosemite Sam, there is biological gold in them thar rain forests. The active ingredient in roughly one in four prescription drugs comes from plants. And biotechnology companies are eager to gain access to exotic environments containing tens of millions of plant and animal species that have yet to be scrutinized. In the most visible deal, Merck, the giant pharmaceutical maker, is paying Costa Rica cash plus royalties to preserve the country's fragile tropical forests.

title: Traditions And Charm Of Colombia
description: What would a newcomer to Colombian folk dance have learned from the program presented by the Ballet Nacional de Colombia on Friday night at City Center? Not a great deal if that newcomer understood no more than rudimentary Spanish, since the commentary and single-sheet program information were in Spanish. But this was an event that was clearly aimed at nostalgic displaced Colombians, though the presentation was supported in part by City Center. And their delight was eventually infectious, as they sang and clapped along, sighed when a favorite dance was announced, and cheered at the frequent mention of their native land.

title: Ex-Professor Sues Emory for Slander After Vandalism Accusation Cost Him a Job
description: Jeffrey A. Sonnenfeld, a former Emory University business professor who lost an appointment at the Georgia Institute of Technology after Emory officials accused him of vandalism, has filed a lawsuit charging Emory with trumping up charges against him and sabotaging his career.

title: Of Frankenstein Fish and the Call of the Wild: A Trout's Tale
description: TWO decades ago, when most other states were caught up in the mechanics of manufacturing ever more fish for anglers, Montana decided to go the other way. The state stopped planting trout in streams and tried to seal its borders from fish that did not belong in the cold, Rocky Mountain waters under the Big Sky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, MAURICE
description: SILVER-Maurice. On June 1, 1998 at home. A gentleman and a scholar. Loving and beloved husband of Dorothy; father of Arthur and the late Bettina Lorris; grandfather of Mara Lorris, Elizabeth Lorris Ritter, and Rebecca Buchanan; Pop-Pop of Tina and David Ritter and Sean Jenkins; uncle of Gerry and Sandy Solomon. Born in Leeds, England, on November 19, 1905, Maurice Silver emigrated to New York in 1923. He earned his B.A. from CCNY in 1929, his M.A. from Columbia University in 1930, and his Ph.D. from Columbia in 1942. He began teaching in the New York public school system in 1927, and taught French, Spanish, and Latin at New Utrecht High School from 1929-1941, and at the Bronx High School of Science from 1941-1956. In 1956 he became the Chairman of the Department of Foreign Languages at Bayside High School until his retirement in 1968. From 1968-1974 he served as Associate Professor of Foreign Languages and International Education at New York University. An able and committed guidance counselor, a skilled and caring supervisor, a founding member of the United Federation of Teachers, and a frequent consultant to the Board of Regents in various capacities, his first professional love was always classroom teaching. ''Fear no more the heat of the sun/Nor the furious winter's rages./Thou thy worldly task hast done,/Home hast gone, ta'en thy wages.'' Visitation at Riverside Chapel, NYC, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave., Manhattan, on Tuesday, June 2, 7-9 pm. Funeral at Riverdale Temple, 246th St. and Independence Ave. (off Henry Hudson Parkway, Bronx) at 2 pm. on Wednesday, June 3, 1998. Contributions to the charity of your choice in lieu of flowers.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Thursday about the concert given by James Levine and the American Composers Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on May 24 misidentified one work. The new composition by Tan Dun is ''Red Forecast,'' not ''Red Forest.''

title: Buying Land, Crying Foul; Preservationists Accused Of Overzealous Tactics In Bid to Keep Land Wild
description: Karen Pardini and Michael Fink, two middle-aged children of the back-to-the-land 1960's, had long had their eyes on a largely untamed patch in the Shawangunk Mountains.

title: Two Men Are Charged In Separate Sex Attacks
description: In two separate cases of sex crimes, the authorities said yesterday that a martial arts instructor in Bergen County was charged with sexually assaulting one woman and trying to assault three others, and another man in Essex County was charged with raping four women who said he identified himself as a police officer.

title: A Soldier Of Christ On the March
description: WHEN visited yesterday in his corner office at the Catholic League for Religious and Civil Rights, William A. Donohue was not burning books. He was not chopping up reels of film into celluloid guitar picks. He was not tossing video cassettes into the trash can.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, LILLY
description: GOTTLIEB-Lilly on May 30, 1998. Beloved mother of George Brent and mother-in-law of Chickie Bucco. Devoted sister of Gizella Klein. Adoring grandmother of Andrew Brent. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st St Tuesday, June 2 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to The American Heart Association.

title: The 'Other' Drug Problem: Forgetting to Take Them
description: PEDRO Lopez left his Bronx home in a big hurry one morning several months ago and became a medical statistic by nightfall.

title: President Decides to Abandon His Claim of Executive Privilege
description: President Clinton today dropped the claim of executive privilege he had invoked in the Lewinsky investigation, moving to reduce the prospect of a quick Supreme Court review in the highly charged constitutional clash between the White House and the independent counsel.

title: Mere Tinkering on Health Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MELLON BANK CORP., Pittsburgh, said it would buy Clair Odell Group, Plymouth Meeting, Pa., a private property and casualty insurance broker, for an undisclosed sum.

title: Shuttle Pays a Final Call To the Celestial Dragonfly
description: ASTRONAUTS report that one of the most striking visions in space is approaching the Russian Mir space station, which first appears as a distant point of light. Drawing closer, Mir -- with its cruciform configuration of modules and arrays of wing-like solar panels -- slowly begins to resemble a giant cosmic insect glowing bright against the blackness of space.

title: Citing Record, Vacco Says He Will Seek Office Again
description: Saying he has reduced crime, protected the environment and fought consumer fraud more voraciously than his predecessors, Dennis C. Vacco announced today that he would seek a second term as New York State's Attorney General.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE DOWN 4.7 PERCENT. Orange juice fell to the lowest level since last Thursday after rain improved prospects for a large crop in Florida, the top orange-growing state. July contracts fell 5.1 cents, to $1.0325 a pound.

title: Suspect Agrees to Plead Guilty in Spy Case
description: One of three people arrested in October in an espionage sting has agreed to plead guilty to spying for East Germany, lawyers in the case said today.

title: Stock Swap to Create No. 1 Paper Maker
description: Stora A.B. and Enso Oyj, the second-largest forest-products companies in Sweden and Finland, respectively, agreed yesterday to a $5.6 billion stock swap, creating the world's biggest paper maker.

title: P.& G. takes a most unusual tack with its new, in-your-face ads.
description: THE nation's largest and perhaps most staid advertiser, the Procter & Gamble Company, is unexpectedly kicking up its corporate heels with an unconventional marketing ploy.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You know, I was always sitting on that side. The President was always here. Now I am here!''

title: At Top New York Restaurants, China to Go
description: THE prix fixe dinner at Lutece includes three courses of the restaurant's specialties like smoked codfish with white truffle oil, black bass with lobster sauce and pineapple mille-feuille. It's $65, wine, tax and tip not included. The signature deep-blue and white Limoges plates aren't included either, but they are, in fact, for sale ($180 for a five-piece setting).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINN, MARION R. (NEE ROONEY)
description: FINN-Marion R. (nee Rooney). On June 2, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Joseph W. Finn, M.D. Loving mother of Mary Ann and Melvyn Gelb, Ann Marie and Hank Linden and John, Joseph and Lisa Finn. Proud grandmother of William Joseph Finn, Jonathan and Daniel Linden. Visiting Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 10AM, St. Anselms Church.

title: Publisher of Los Angeles Times Says He 'Misspoke' on Women
description: The publisher of The Los Angeles Times sent an unusual memorandum to his staff on Monday, apologizing for causing offense by suggesting that the newspaper could increase its female readership by offering more emotional and less analytical articles.

title: CALIFORNIA PASSES MEASURE TO LIMIT BILINGUAL SCHOOLS
description: Californians today approved a ballot measure that would curtail three decades of bilingual instruction in the public schools here, paving the way for similar assaults on such programs around the nation, according to early election returns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARE, BARBARA K.
description: CLARE-Barbara K. Died on Saturday, May 30, 1998 from complications of cancer, which she had fought with courage, determination and humor. She was the widow of N. Holmes Clare. She is survived by her three children Marcia C. Lucas of Charleston, SC, Christina C. Evans and N. Holmes Clare Jr, both of New York and six grandchildren. Friends may call Wednesday 5-7pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral Mass Thursday 10am at St. Thomas Moore, 65 E. 89 St.

title: Excerpts From Starr's Legal Response
description: Following are excerpts from court papers filed with the Supreme Court today by Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, in response to President Clinton's court motions against Mr. Starr's appeal for an expedited review of privilege claims by the Supreme Court in the Monica S. Lewinsky investigation.

title: DUTCH GIANT AGREES TO SELL TWO U.S. UNITS OF COURTAULDS
description: Akzo Nobel N.V, the largest Dutch chemical and drug company, has agreed to sell two American paint units of Courtaulds P.L.C. of Britain to PPG Industries in exchange for PPG ending its talks to buy all of Courtaulds, Akzo Nobel and PPG said late yesterday. PPG, based in Pittsburgh, will pay $285 million for the two businesses, which make coatings for beverage cans and decorative architectural coatings, PPG said. The deal clears the way for Akzo Nobel to complete its $:2.26 billion acquisition of Courtaulds, which would make Akzo Nobel the world's largest maker of paints. Akzo and Courtaulds agreed to the terms of the takeover in April. But last month, Courtaulds disclosed that it was in talks with PPG and the investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette about a possible higher bid.

title: BEVERLY ENTERPRISES TO SELL A HOSPITAL UNIT

Financial terms were not disclosed for the unit, which runs 15 hospitals in eight states. The hospitals being sold to the Select Medical Corporation, based in Mechanicsburg, Pa., primarily provide extended care for very ill people. The hospitals tend to be less profitable than Beverly's nursing homes or outpatient-therapy business, analysts said. Select Medical provides therapy and long-term hospital-care services.

Passed away on May 24th while jogging near his home in Morristown, NJ. Mr. Davis graduated from North Carolina A&T State University in 1976, and in 1995 attended the Wharton School's Strategic Planning and Management Program at the University of PA. Mr. Davis had been Senior Vice President of magazine sales for R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company. He served as a member of the Board of Advisors for New York University's Prism Award. description: Dorothy Stickney, who created the role of the mother in ''Life with Father'' and also appeared in many other Broadway hits during a career that spanned more than 50 years, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 101.

title: Kim Dae Jung Courts North Korea
description: Since becoming South Korea's President earlier this year, Kim Dae Jung has brought a new tone to diplomacy with the Communist North. Instead of emphasizing historic grievances, Seoul now tries to draw Pyongyang toward cooperation. Just days before departing for a state visit to the United States, Mr. Kim is calling on Washington to reinforce his efforts by ending American trade sanctions against North Korea that date back to the Korean War. His plea deserves a serious hearing, especially from Congressional Republicans inclined to treat any American overture toward Pyongyang as a mortal threat to the security of South Korea.

title: A Lusty Pale Ale With a Long Finish
description: THE initials I.P.A. may be the most mysterious three letters in the world of beer. The letters, which appear on every label of Bass, stand for India Pale Ale, and they designate a style of beer that is neither pale nor Indian. Rather, it was developed for the Indian export market in the English brewing city of Burton-on-Trent, whose copper- or russet-colored ales were pale by comparison with brown ale or porter. To insure that the beer would survive the long sea voyage without souring, it was brewed to a high alcohol content, as much as 9 percent by volume, and heavily hopped. Full-bodied, dry and refreshing, India pale ale gained favor all over the world.

Valuevision, a television home-shopping and mail-order company based in Minneapolis, agreed to merge with National Media in January in a transaction then valued at $3.50 a share, or $104 million. Valuevision shareholders, however, rejected the merger agreement, sending the companies back to negotiations. title: The Breeder of Real Quiet Is Enjoying the Golden Ride
description: The breeder of Real Quiet doesn't think the colt was an ''ugly duckling,'' as racing people say. And he doesn't agree that his mother was ''a blue-collar mare.'' He doesn't deny that Real Quiet was born with crooked legs and had operations on both knees as a yearling, or that he grew so thin from lack of exercise that he was nicknamed the Fish. Or that he was sold for the giveaway price of $17,000 because it looked as though he might break down. And he certainly doesn't think his colt is a ''freak'' who has outraced his pedigree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, MAURICE
description: SILVER-Maurice. On June 1, 1998 at home. A gentleman and a scholar. Loving and beloved husband of Dorothy; father of Arthur and the late Bettina Lorris; grandfather of Mara Lorris, Elizabeth Lorris Ritter, and Rebecca Buchanan; Pop-Pop of Tina and David Ritter and Sean Jenkins; uncle of Gerry and Sandy Solomon. Born in Leeds, England, on November 19, 1905, Maurice Silver emigrated to New York in 1923. He earned his B.A. from CCNY in 1929, his M.A. from Columbia University in 1930, and his Ph.D. from Columbia in 1942. He began teaching in the New York public school system in 1927, and taught French, Spanish, and Latin at New Utrecht High School from 1929-1941, and at the Bronx High School of Science from 1941-1956. In 1956 he became the Chairman of the Department of Foreign Languages at Bayside High School until his retirement in 1968. From 1968-1974 he served as Associate Professor of Foreign Languages and International Education at New York University. An able and committed guidance counselor, a skilled and caring supervisor, a founding member of the United Federation of Teachers, and a frequent consultant to the Board of Regents in various capacities, his first professional love was always classroom teaching. ''Fear no more the heat of the sun/Nor the furious winter's rages./Thou thy worldly task hast done,/Home hast gone, ta'en thy wages.'' Visitation at Riverside Chapel, NYC, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave., Manhattan, on Tuesday, June 2, 7-9 pm. Funeral at Riverdale Temple, 246th St. and Independence Ave. (off Henry Hudson Parkway, Bronx) at 2 pm. on Wednesday, June 3, 1998. Contributions to the charity of your choice in lieu of flowers.
