description: TO date, no vegetables have filed any of the so-called veggie libel lawsuits. The only cases so far have been brought on behalf of cattle, eggs, lawns and emus.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAMBERT, MILDRED
description: LAMBERT - Mildred. Dearest mother, it's been three years, and you are remembered each and every day with love. Steven, Barbara, Corey and Joseph

title: Sales of Chrysler Vehicles Jumped 27% in May to a Record
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that sales of its cars and trucks in the United States rose 27 percent in May, making it the best sales month ever for the No. 3 auto maker.

title: Transportation Board Ponders Planned Conrail Takeover
description: Two years ago, Federal railroad regulators approved, with hardly a blink, Union Pacific's acquisition of Southern Pacific to form the nation's largest railroad. The result was one of the nation's worst rail tie-ups, costing businesses billions of dollars throughout the West.

title: Youth With Heart Problem Dies After Running Up School Stairs
description: A Bronx teen-ager with a heart problem died yesterday morning after running up five flights of stairs to a class and collapsing in the hallway of his school, officials said.

title: Restaurants; A Chef at the Right Time and Place
description: BILL TELEPAN is a quiet chef. His menus don't jump up and down shouting, ''Look how creative I am!'' His dishes contain no ingredients requiring explanation. And nobody ever looked at one of his plates and said: ''It's much too pretty to eat. It belongs in a museum.'' In fact, people lucky enough to try Mr. Telepan's cooking tend to become quiet, too. Because in your mouth his food becomes extremely eloquent; each of those unassuming dishes roars with flavor, and the minute you finish one bite you instantly want another.

title: On Africa's Back Streets, Abortions Take Heavy Toll
description: In a panic when she found herself pregnant for the first time three years ago, Fernande Aka, a slender, soft-spoken high school senior, drank a concoction of nearly frozen Coca-Cola and wine mixed with a heavy dose of sugar that her schoolmates swore would make an unwanted pregnancy go away.

title: Parisii (as in Paris), on French Rarities
description: The Parisii Quartet, indeed from Paris, is a decent ensemble. If the musicians seem unduly cautious in their interpretive stance, their lightness of tone brings its own satisfactions. They also have a distinctive sound, nervous and fragile, due to the wide and slowish vibrato affected by the two violins. Against them, the viola is plain and solid, the cello lively. Given these different characters, chords can sound confused, but again there is a countering virtue, in the openness of their contrapuntal playing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUCHINCLOSS, GORDON
description: AUCHINCLOSS-Gordon.On June 1, 1998. Writer, director and communications executive. Beloved husband of Anne, devoted father of Stuart, Gordon S. and Sibley Anne, step-father of Eric Davis and Julianne Davis. Loving brother of Douglas, cherished grandfather, great grandfather, step grandfather and step great grandfather. Funeral mass will be Saturday June 6, 1998 12noon at the Episcopal Church of St. Ignatius of Antioch, W 87 St between Broadway and West End Ave. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions can be made in his name to Groton School, Groton, MA 01450-0991

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERHAVE, THOM
description: VERHAVE-Thom. Of Falmouth, formerly of Armonk, NY, June 1, 1998. Thom Verhave, beloved husband of Helena ''Anneka'' (Baan) Verhave. Father of Menno Verhave of Wellesley, MA; Eric Verhave of Poughquag, NY, and Marya Gabriel of Mattapoisett, MA. Brother of Nella Loree of Clovis, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to either the 300 Committee, 157 Locust St., Falmouth, MA, 02540-2658 or the Habitat for Humanity International, 121 Habitat St., Amerious, GA, 31709-3498

title: Food Stuff
description: What's New at Zabar's

title: Trump's Backers Trying to Sell First 2 Riverside Apartment Buildings
description: With Southeast Asia's real estate market in turmoil and New York's soaring, the Hong Kong investors who financed Donald Trump's Riverside South development in Manhattan are trying to sell the first two apartment buildings at the $2.5 billion project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB, RALPH
description: GOLDFARB-Ralph. Devoted husband of Donna; beloved father of Dana Goldfarb, Eric Goldfarb and Karen Kudler. Dear brother of Maurice Goldfarb, David Goldfarb, Samuel Goldfarb and Sonia Brody. Cherished grandfather of Nicole, Ashley, Jessica and Courtney. Services today 1 pm at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI

title: Wild Alaskan Salmon: The Glory Days Are Here; For the next two weeks, Copper River salmon reign supreme.
description: THE Gulf of Alaska was tossing up waves of 20 feet or more and the winds roared to 40 miles an hour, but the storm did not deter the fleet in pursuit of what is arguably the world's best-tasting fish -- Copper River salmon -- on their first run of the season.

title: India's Strategic Misstep
description: In the three weeks since India conducted its nuclear tests, the tough talk of Indian leaders seems to have faded to a whisper. They are now proposing that their country and Pakistan sign a treaty agreeing not to be the first to use such weapons against each other. They have denied Pakistan's claim that India will conduct yet another nuclear test, and they have reiterated the country's longstanding call for global disarmament.

title: Panel Finds Medicare Costs Are Underestimated by U.S.
description: A bipartisan Federal advisory panel said today that the long-term costs of Medicare were likely to be higher than estimated by the Clinton Administration, because the program was likely to continue growing at a brisk pace.

title: C.I.A. Study Details Failures; Scouring of System Is Urged
description: United States intelligence ''needs to be scrubbed'' from the top down, from its spies to its analysts to its chief bureaucrats, according to the author of a classified report on the intelligence agencies' inability to foresee India's May 11 nuclear tests.

title: School Slaying Suspect on Trial in Mother's Death
description: At the very beginning of the terrifying national string of school shootings is a 17-year-old boy who prosecutors say began a day of violence by stabbing his mother to death, because he believed she did not love him.

title: CAPITAL AUTOMOTIVE TO BUY 30 DEALERSHIP PROPERTIES
description: Capital Automotive REIT said yesterday that it had agreed to buy, in separate transactions, 30 auto-dealership properties for about $125 million. Capital Automotive did not release the terms of the purchases or the identity of the sellers. The company, based in McLean, Va., will lease the land and buildings back to the auto dealerships, which will continue to use them to sell cars and trucks. Capital Automotive, which raised $300 million in an initial public offering in February, is the first real estate investment trust, or REIT, in the United States to focus on auto-dealership properties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARVER, MARY LUCIA
description: CARVER-Mary Lucia. Dearest Lucia, we will miss you and never forget you. Ernie and Jane Jaffe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, ROBERT F.
description: YOUNG-Robert F. On May 27, 1998, former President and Publisher of Family Circle Magazine. In memory of a good friend and a great boss, from the Officers and Employees who worked with him. You will be missed by all those who knew you.

title: Wash Cycle Dreams, Via Berlioz
description: It all sounds about as exciting as staring at a glass-sided washing machine. Pieces of cloth unfurling in the water? Floating fringes of threads and white sheets swathed in bubbles?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOOD, WILLIAM P.
description: FLOOD-William P. On May 10, 1998. Beloved husband of Dana, loving father of Billy, devoted brother of John, Bernadette, and the late Michael, Frank, Maurice and Peggy. Memorial Mass at the Epiphany R.C. Church, 22nd Street and Second Avenue on Saturday June 6th at 11AM. In memory, please contribute to the American Cancer Society.

title: Father Assails Man's Release In Bensonhurst Racial Killing
description: The father of Yusuf K. Hawkins, the black teen-ager who was murdered nine years ago during a racially motivated attack by a large crowd of white youths on a Brooklyn street, harshly criticized state officials yesterday for the release of Keith Mondello, one of the men convicted in the case, from prison.

title: What's Green And Has Stripes? A Zebra Tomato
description: TAKE heart, all ye who harbor a taste for green tomatoes. No longer do you need to wish in secret that the sun will dim and the winds will blow, so that regular tomatoes will not ripen but will fall to the ground prematurely. No longer must your hankerings for fried green tomatoes leave you dependent on the unkindness of nature.

title: A Romance to Stymie Women of the 90's
description: True to the content of ''The Sea Gull,'' which begins with the presentation of an amateurish backyard play, the Blue Light Theater Company's production of Chekhov's tragicomedy of thwarted ambition has the feel of something slapped together for a few supportive friends.

title: Race to Buy the Browns Has a New York Flavor
description: Howard Milstein, the real estate developer, and Chuck Dolan, the cable television magnate, have three things in common: lots of money, businesses that are located in the New York metropolitan area and a desire to own the soon-to-be-revived Cleveland Browns.

title: Yeltsin Tells Businessmen To Help Out By Investing
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin gathered the nation's most powerful businessmen at the Kremlin today and pressed them to use their money to help steady Russia's financial markets.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Merrill Lynch Settles Suit Brought by Orange County

title: Nuclear Tests Are No Big Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Kin Earned Riches, Says New Leader Of Indonesia
description: Nearly immediately after becoming President of Indonesia, B. J. Habibie, pledged to create ''a clean government, free from corruption, collusion and nepotism.'' But one of the biggest threats to his rule may be growing concern that he and his family, following the model of former President Suharto, used public office to amass a private fortune.

title: Commencements; Brooklyn College
description: If public colleges continue to lose the support of voters and legislators at the present rate, they could become like ''dead spacecraft, with no new missions to fly,'' Vernon E. Lattin, the president of Brooklyn College, told 3,000 graduates seated in the leafy quadrangle of the Flatbush campus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENNIE, JEAN TOWER
description: RENNIE-Jean Tower of Palm Beach, Florida and Milwaukee, Wisconsin died Sunday at her home in Florida. Her zest of life and energy will be missed by all who knew her. Burial will be Tuesday in Louisville, KY. Memorial service will be held in Palm Beach in November. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Vassar College or The English Speaking Union. She leaves behind 2 children Roxburgh Rennie of Providence, R.I. and Milbrey Rennie Taylor of NYC and 5 grandchildren, all of whom adored her.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MADDOX, GLORIA JEAN
description: MADDOX-Gloria Jean. Actress and theatre teacher, died in her Connecticut home on May 11th. A celebration of her life will be held June 7th at 6 P.M. at The John Houseman Theatre, 450 W 42 St.

title: Russian Bond Auction: A $1.2 Billion Balancing Act
description: Raising the money that it needs each week to pay off debt that is coming due and finance its persistent budget deficit has always been a tricky proposition for Russia, given its tumultuous political and economic climate.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Union Square's Resurgence Exceeds Landlords' Wildest Dreams
description: In late 1996, W & M Properties spent more than $16 million to buy 58,000 square feet of retail space at the base of the Zeckendorf Towers condominium on the east side of Union Square. It was a time of continuing renewal for the once-seedy neighborhood, and W & M expected that the rents from the tower's dozen stores would make the deal profitable. But even W & M did not reckon on the rents it is getting today.

title: Pepsi Cuts Link With Bottler After Threat on Coke's Suit
description: In a highly unusual move, Pepsico broke off a 32-year franchise agreement with one of its largest independent bottlers yesterday, saying that the bottler had threatened to intervene in Pepsico's lawsuit against the Coca-Cola Company.

title: Bits And Bytes; Folksy and Personal In the Cyberkitchen
description: MARSHALL McLUHAN, the 1960's media critic, looked at television and saw the world turning into one electronic global village, a sort of plugged-in melting pot. But on the Internet individualism is still alive and well, and the myriad food sites, at least, have a human face.

title: TV Notes; Ohlmeyer Vs. Macdonald
description: NBC has canceled a deal with MGM studios for a series of commercials promoting its forthcoming movie ''Dirty Work,'' on the order of Don Ohlmeyer, president of NBC's West Coast division, because the film stars Norm Macdonald, the onetime anchor of the ''Weekend Update'' segment of ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: Why Must Farms Use Migrant Labor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROEGER, ARTHUR
description: KROEGER-Arthur. Died May 29, 1998 in Mystic, CT at the home of his daughter, Mary Katherine Porter. Survived by a daughter, Mary Katherine Porter, Mystic, CT; grandaughter, Sarah H. Porter, Menlo Park, CA; grandson, Philip K. Porter, Carrboro, NC; brother, William Kroeger, Borriego Springs, CA; brother, Edward Kroeger, La Quinta, CA; and sister, Marguerite Spitzer, Fullerton, CA. Was predeceased by wife, Julia Rose Kroeger; grandson, Paul Arthur Porter, and brother, Roland Kroeger. Born Fullerton, CA. on Sept. 15, 1908 to William Kroeger and Katherine Oefinger Kroeger. Graduated from Stanford in 1931. Was elected Phi Beta Kappa in 1930. Received MBA from Stanford in 1933. After graduation, operating and managing many Mannings Coffee Company restaurants in the Bay Area. Taught marketing and advertising at the University of Idaho from 1940-1943. Served on active duty in the U.S. Navy from 1943-1946. Reached rank of Lt. Commander in the Supply Corps. Returned as Professor to Stanford Graduate School of Business in 1946, retiring as emeritus in 1973. His field was marketing and advertising. Taught at the University of Santa Clara part-time for 15 years. While at Stanford, served on many committees. Chairman of Bookstore Building Committee; President of Stanford Faculty Club, 1964-1965; consultant to European Productivity Agency, Paris, France in 1957-58 helping to setup the Common Market. Gave first business lectures at University of Athens, Greece. Taught in Peru; lectured in New Zealand. Coauthored several books, including six editions of ''Advertising Principles and Problems.'' Member of the University Club of Palo Alto and Stanford Faculty Club. Life member AMA, and member SIRS and St. Vincent de Paul Society. Interests included orchid growing, gardening and world traveling. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to: VNA of Southeastern Connecticut, 200 Boston Post Road, Waterford, CT. 06385 or to Oakwood Retirement Home, 140 Valpariso, Atherton, CA. Services Oakwood Chapel, 140 Valpariso Ave, Atherton, CA on Wednesday, 10 a.m. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Los Altos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, ANN
description: SOLOMON-Ann. On June 1, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Loving mother of Eileen and Alan. Adoring grandmother of Lisa, Wendy and Steven. Dear great grandmother.

title: Republicans Pick Challenger for State Comptroller
description: Bruce A. Blakeman, the Presiding Officer of the Nassau County Legislature, was selected by Republican leaders yesterday to challenge State Comptroller H. Carl McCall in the November election.

title: Volvo Sells Shares In Pharmacia & Upjohn
description: Volvo A.B. has sold all of the 19.8 million shares it held in the Swedish-American drug maker Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc., as part of its strategy to divest itself of nonauto interests, according to J. P. Morgan & Company. Volvo said earlier yesterday that it had sold half of its holding in Pharmacia & Upjohn, or 9.9 million shares, at 334 kronor apiece for a capital gain of 2.090 billion kronor ($268 million).

title: You Can Take the Girl Out of the City . . .
description: How difficult is it to find the simple life these days? About as difficult as it is to come up with a situation comedy that's fresh, smoothly paced and cleverly written. You'll find abundant proof of this in ''The Simple Life,'' a forgettable new show that CBS is mercilessly sending into the early-summer void tonight at 8:30.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about fund-raising by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato reversed the titles of two executives of the MBNA Corporation, one of the Senator's biggest benefactors, and misstated their positions in the photo, as well as its date. Charles M. Cawley is president of MBNA; Alfred Lerner is chairman. Mr. Cawley was at the left and Mr. Lerner in the middle. The scene occurred in November 1997, not December 1997.

title: Blue-Chip Issues in Retreat, With Dow Declining 31.13
description: Stocks ended mixed yesterday, as blue chips slipped and technology issues rebounded from Monday's slide.

title: London Journal; Jeers Across the Channel From the Rowdy Press
description: It is an exercise familiar to the millions of readers of Britain's populist tabloids. In times of national anxiety about their country's place in the world -- when Britain is upset about Europe's impending single currency or its anti-British beef policy -- the papers dust off their jingoistic lexicon, trying to buck up Britain by being rude about the French and the Germans.

title: Canadian Colleges Look Across Border to Fill Their Classes (and Coffers)
description: ''You can study here and be home for supper,'' declared an advertisement for the University of Windsor published recently in The Detroit News.

title: Real Quiet's Final Work Leaves Baffert Smiling
description: In his final workout before his bid for the Triple Crown in Saturday's 130th Belmont Stakes, Real Quiet covered five furlongs yesterday at Churchill Downs in 1:01, a drill that encouraged his trainer, Bob Baffert.

title: New Blasts Shake Foundation of Effort to Limit Nuclear Arms
description: The nuclear tests by India and Pakistan have undermined the agreements and assumptions on which efforts to stop the spread of nuclear weapons have been based for the last 30 years, a range of officials, analysts and diplomats say.

title: TV Notes; Top of the World
description: CBS will offer an unusual hourlong special this summer that documents the efforts of Tom Whittaker, a mountain climber, to reach the summit of Mount Everest.

title: Commencements; At City College, Crew Speaks of Public Service
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew exhorted City College graduates yesterday to pursue ''the beauty'' of public service, but he did not remark on the issue dominating talk on campus: the decision by the Board of Trustees of the City University of New York to phase out remedial courses at its four-year colleges.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about clothing designers' inroads into independent films misstated the name of a new Perry Ellis award in the field. It is the Breakthrough award, not the Breakout award. The article also misstated the subject of ''The Faculty,'' a movie in production with costumes by Tommy Hilfiger. It is about aliens, not werewolves.

title: Flirting With Disaster
description: Watching a disaster movie is a little like imagining your own funeral. You would not be able to witness your own funeral, of course, but in your mind's eye you can. And no matter what happens to Earth in the final reel of a disaster movie, when the popcorn has all been eaten and the audience is feeling a little salty, the observer's eye persists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, MIRIAM, NEE ELLIN
description: FELDMAN-Miriam, nee Ellin on June 1, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Herbert. Beloved mother of Madeleine, Amy, Peter, Sharon, Leslie & Michael. Adoring grandmother of Spencer, Harrison, Courtney, James, William, Jillian, Sandy, Dana, Kimberly & Joshua. Dear sister of Selma and Helen. Services ''Boulevard -Riverside'', 1450 Bway, Hewlett L.I. 11:30 am, Thurs.

title: April Sales Of New Homes Set a Record
description: Sales of new single-family homes rose to a record level in April and the United States index of leading economic indicators increased for the fourth consecutive month, signs that the economy will keep growing in the months ahead.

title: GIULIANI WILL PUT FOSTER CARE TO BID
description: In the most drastic revamping of New York City's child welfare system in more than a generation, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he would put hundreds of millions of dollars in foster care contracts up for competitive bidding in an effort to care for abused and neglected children in their own neighborhoods.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WIENER, GABE
description: WIENER-Gabe. Dearest Gabe, your beautiful voice will always sing loudly for all of us. Happy 28th Birthday. We hold you close and cherish you always. With love forever, Z, M and J

title: Mozart, Bach and Lunch al Fresco
description: Sunday night's torrential rainstorm gave way to Monday morning's clear dry sky in time for the first concert of this summer's Bryant Park Young Performers Series, the outdoor lunchtime programs held at 12:30 in the lovely green behind the New York Public Library. The series will present more than 20 concerts of some 45 minutes each and will showcase emerging musicians in performance with established artists.

title: For 2d Year, Pupil Reading Scores Gain
description: For the second year in a row, scores by elementary and middle-school students on citywide reading tests improved slightly, just shy of the national average, according to Board of Education figures released yesterday. Scores went up in each of the city's 32 community school districts, though the gains across the board were smaller than in 1997.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about MacArthur Foundation Fellowships misstated the nationality of one recipient, Peter Miller. He is American, not German.

title: Arts in America; Toreador, Look Out for the Floor (It's Now Hydraulic)
description: What do you get when you cross classical opera with a contemporary rock concert? You get Carmen in a rhinestone-studded bustier belting out the Habanera into a headset microphone. At least, that's Houston Grand Opera's answer. In an effort to reach a broader (read younger, hipper) audience in the kinds of outdoor sites more likely to reverberate with the sounds of Bono than Bizet, the opera company has designed a portable, multimedia stage like those used by touring rock bands. And it has created a flashy production to match.

title: At a Jazz Party, Kindred Spirits In Feeling and Fact
description: The Knitting Factory opened the doors to its New York Jazz Festival on Monday night, and it gave a party that inadvertently showed exactly how big and wide the jazz road is in the city. Two big bands played, one led by Joseph Bowie, the other by his brother Lester. A trio with Reuben Wilson on organ grooved through sweet and funky music. A saxophonist, Michael Blake, moved from Duke Ellington to Ornette Coleman with utter conviction, and to end the night, sometime after 1 in the morning, a band of three baritone saxophonists -- Ronnie Cuber, Charles Davis and Gary Smulyan -- swung some smooth be-bop, idiomatically correct and exuding the pleasure of a good conversation.

title: NATIONWIDE MUTUAL AND ALLIED CLOSE TO DEAL
description: The Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company and Allied Group Inc. said yesterday that they were close to an agreement for Nationwide to acquire Allied and its affiliates for $1.75 billion, helping Nationwide expand into the Western United States. Allied said it was prepared ''in principle'' to recommend that shareholders accept a sweetened Nationwide offer to acquire the company for $48.25 a share, up from the $47 a share Nationwide offered in an unsolicited takeover bid. Nationwide is the nation's sixth-largest property and casualty insurer. Allied Group has links to about 2,000 independent agents, who use an Allied computer system to facilitate underwriting policies and claims handling. Nationwide, which is owned by policyholders, plans to swap the interests of Allied policyholders for new ones at Nationwide.

title: A Flutist's Version of Ego In a Night of Varied Works
description: It is for others -- the performers themselves, no doubt -- to fret about the economics of the situation: how so small an audience could sustain so rich and varied a recital program as the one presented by Don Hulbert, a flutist, on Saturday evening at the Church of St. Luke-in-the-Fields, in the West Village. The listener had only to sit back and, for the most part, enjoy the music-making.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKSTEIN, GUSSIE
description: DICKSTEIN-Gussie. The beloved wife of the late George Dickstein, former Umpire-in-Chief and Official Rules Interpreter of The Amateur Softball Association of America, died at the age of 89 in Boca Raton, on Monday June 1. She was one of a kind and will be sorely missed by son Dick, her daughter-in-law Marilyn, her grandson Mark and his wife Elyssa and their children Max, Billy and Charlie, and by granddaughter Karen, her husband Jimmy and their children Dani and Jack.She is also survived by her sister Lee Thielle. The family will be sitting at 5 Dorchester Drive, Muttontown, New York, Wed. and Thursday evenings between 6pm and 10pm. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to: The Cure for Lymphoma, 215 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10016.

title: Skeleton Found in Park Is of Long-Lost Woman
description: A skeleton that was discovered last week by city workers cleaning out drain pipes in a Queens park has been identified as that of a woman who disappeared 10 years ago, and detectives have now reclassified her case as a homicide, the police said.

title: James in Alabama Runoff
description: Gov. Fob James Jr., a favorite of religious conservatives, finished first in the Republican primary but did not receive enough votes to avoid a runoff. Page A16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, ANNE
description: KRAUS-Anne. Devoted wife of the late Walter. Beloved mother of Lawrence and Lori and the late Melvin. Adored grandmother of Mark, and Jason. Services Thursday 11:30AM at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Bill Would Replace State Commerce Dept.
description: The State Department of Commerce and Economic Development would be replaced by a commission including business leaders under a bill introduced on Monday.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Cuisinart of Phone Technology Fails to Whip Up Enthusiasm
description: When the Sprint Corporation decided to whip up attention for a planned new communications network, it followed a careful plan. On Monday, it invited stock analysts and reporters to come the next day to the Richard Rodgers Theater in Times Square for an announcement about ''a revolutionary capability that will change the way businesses and homes use telecommunications.''

title: Hingis Makes Venus Williams Jittery
description: Venus Williams, the Williams sister favored to give top-seeded Martina Hingis true trouble in her attempt to monopolize a fourth consecutive Grand Slam, instead submitted, 6-3, 6-4, today in the quarterfinals of the French Open. Williams gave her least impressive performance in five meetings with her fellow 17-year-old this year. She was so jittery in the center-court spotlight that her beaded headdress shivered and quivered even when she wasn't in perpetual motion trying to chase down the backhands Hingis used to leverage their match in her own favor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLET, ANNETTE (NEE BERENBERG)
description: POLLET-Annette (nee Berenberg). Passed away in her home in West Palm Beach, May 30. Harlem Hospital Chemist, New York City elementary teacher, dancerfolk, square, rounds, bridge and tennis player, firm friend, lover of husband Henry, son Robert, daughter-in-law Donna, and three accomplished grandchildren, Joshua M., Adam N., Sarah J. Funeral services were held in Florida. 1-800-94-SHALOM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Leukemia Society.

title: Why Must Farms Use Migrant Labor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, FRANCIS (FRANCESCO, SARDO, FONTANA)
description: LEE-Francis (Francesco-Sardo-Fontana), age 85. Rare pioneer of independent and avant-garde film. As an official wartime cameraman, he survived the second wave of D-Day landings on Omaha Beach. He used the footage in one of his best known works, ''World War II and Me.'' His footage of the Liberation of Paris so thrilled Charles de Gaulle that he was given a Croix de Guerre. Much loved and missed by friends and family, he will be remembered for his inspiration, determination and tremendous courage. Survived by son, Michael West Lee. Service Wednesday June 3, 11AM, Krtil Funeral Home 1297 First Avenue.

title: Two Makers Of Phone Gear Join Forces
description: Combining two fast-growing telecommunications equipment companies, Tellabs Inc. has agreed to acquire the Ciena Corporation for $7.3 billion in stock, people close to the deal said yesterday.

title: Disney Official Hired For Post at Comcast
description: The Comcast Corporation named a Walt Disney Company executive head of its cable television unit today as it moves toward selling digital television service and Internet access through cable lines.

title: Pakistan Wants India Pressed on Kashmir
description: Pakistan is hoping to turn the crisis over the South Asian nuclear tests into Western, and particularly American, pressure to wrest the disputed territory of Kashmir from Indian control, Government officials and foreign diplomats say.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LONG JOHN SILVER'S RESTAURANT INC., Lexington, Ky., a fast-food seafood chain, filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 in United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware.

title: Treasury Prices Edge Lower As Home Sales Show Strength
description: Treasury prices slipped yesterday for the first time in four sessions amid signs that the economy was still growing at a brisk clip. Prices were also held down by the prospects of more corporate and Government agency debt coming to market.

title: GEC Alsthom to Offer Shares in Public Offering
description: GEC Alsthom, the British-French transportation and engineering company, said yesterday that it would offer between 52 percent and 57 percent of its shares in an initial public offering on June 22, which could raise as much as 26.6 billion francs ($4.45 billion).

title: Commencements; Quoting Mandela, but for One Problem
description: Commencement speakers this year are turning to Nelson Mandela for words of inspiration to share with graduates. Hillary Rodham Clinton quoted the President of South Africa in her address to Howard University, as did the astronaut Mae C. Jemison in her speech to Duquesne University. Johnnetta B. Cole, the former president of Spelman College, cited him to Mount Holyoke.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Journal; The Right Stuff
description: Among the participants in Barry Goldwater's funeral today in Tempe, Ariz., will be Ty Ross, a former Zoli model turned interior decorator, a gay man who is H.I.V. positive but remains in good health. Mr. Ross, 36, is Barry Goldwater's grandson, and when I reached him by phone at his home in Tucson yesterday, he summed up his grandfather's philosophy thus: ''Live and let live -- and party on!''

title: Nasty, Costly Battle Shapes Up Over Changing Managed Care
description: Not long after Senator Edward M. Kennedy introduced a bill this spring to overhaul managed care, his staff put out a feeler to the unwitting heroine of the movement, Helen Hunt, the actress who portrayed the exhausted, angst-ridden, H.M.O.-bashing mother of an asthma sufferer in the movie ''As Good as It Gets.''

title: Mets' No. 1 Draft Selection Snubs Agent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMART, LOUIS EDWIN
description: SMART-Louis Edwin, of counsel and a former partner at the law firm Hughes Hubbard & Reed LLP, died on Monday, June 1, at St. Luke's Hospital in New York City. He was 74. Mr. Smart was born in Columbus, OH on November 17, 1923, and served as a lieutenant in the U.S. Naval Reserve from 1943 to 1946. He graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University in 1947. In 1949, he received his J.D. magna cum laude from Harvard Law School, where he was an editor of the Law Review, and became associated with Hughes Hubbard & Reed (then Hughes, Hubbard & Ewing) the same year. He joined the firm's partnership in 1957. During his tenure with Hughes Hubbard, Mr. Smart handled major corporate transactions for Bendix Corporation. He left the firm to assume the position of President of Bendix International in 1964. In 1967, he moved to Trans World Airlines, Inc. (TWA), and over the next decade he held the positions of senior vice president of corporate affairs, vice chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Smart served as chairman of the board at TWA from 1979 to 1985, and also served as chairman and CEO of Transworld Corp. from 1978 to 1987. He returned to Hughes Hubbard as of counsel in 1989. Mr. Smart has served as chairman of Hilton International Company (1978-86), as a member of the Board of Directors of the New York Stock Exchange (1982-88), and on the board of numerous major corporations, including Continental Corp., Sonat Inc. and the corporation formerly known as Flagstar Companies, Inc. In addition to his wife, Jeanie M. Smart, whom he married in 1964, Mr. Smart is survived by his sister, Esther Monteith, and her family; his three children, Cynthia S. Smart of San Antonio, Texas; Douglas E. Smart of Madison, CT; Dana G. Smart of Long Beach, CA; and five grandchildren. In lieu of service, a private reception for family, friends and colleagues has been scheduled for Monday, June 15, from 1PM to 3PM at the Marco Polo Club at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York City. Mr. Smart's family requests that expressions of sympathy be made in the form of memorial contributions to the L. Edwin Smart Lecture Series Fund at Ohio State University. Contributions should be directed to Chairperson, Department of Economics, Ohio State University, 410 Arps Hall, 1945 North High Street, Columbus, OH 43210.

The venture with Maderas Condor S.A. will build a plant capable of making about 600 million square feet a year of the structural paneling, which is often used as a substitute for plywood. The project also includes plans for a $20 million port. Boise Cascade, based in Boise, Idaho, will own 60 percent of the venture, to be called Compania Industrial Puerto Montt, and Maderas will have the remaining 40 percent. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERKA, HARRYETTA
description: PETERKA-Harryetta. The American Academy of Dramatic Arts announces with sorrow the tragic passing of Harryetta Peterka, Director of Instruction, on Tuesday, June 2. Herself a graduate of the Academy, she was a recipient of the Jehlinger Award in 1958, the highest honor bestowed upon an Academy student. She toured as a member of the school's post-graduate performance ensemble, the Academy Repertory Company, in the 1958-59 season, playing Abigail in ''The Crucible,'' and Elizabeth I in ''Young Elizabeth.'' She began teaching at the Academy in 1964 while still acting professionally, eventually becoming Director of the Evening School, and Associate Director of the Professional Training Program, prior to being named Director of Instruction in 1992. She is survived by her beloved husband, William Damon. To her students and colleagues, Harryetta was a unique and powerful force, a friend, mentor and guiding light. Her dedication to the theatre and to all the students who pursued a life in the theatre was without limit. Her love of the craft of acting forced her to continue to educate herself and those around her, and her love and concern for her students carried on beyond their enrollment at the Academy. She will be missed, but never forgotten, and she will live on in the hearts of those whose lives she touched. A memorial service will be held in the near future.

title: HANDLEMAN TO ELIMINATE UP TO 1,000 JOBS AND SELL A UNIT
description: The Handleman Company, a maker of entertainment and computer-software products, said yesterday that it would cut 900 to 1,000 jobs, or 30 percent of its work force. The company also said that it was selling its Sofsource educational-software unit to the Learning Company Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., for $45 million. The moves are part of Handleman's effort to concentrate on its main music-distribution business. They are expected to generate cash flow of more than $150 million and produce annual pretax savings of more than $25 million. Handleman, based in Troy, Mich., also said it would buy back up to $70 million of stock. Shares of Handleman slipped 6.25 cents yesterday, to $11.9375.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE TO CLOSE A PLANT IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it would close a plant in Greenville, N.C., that produces adult diapers and sanitary napkins, affecting 585 workers. P.& G. said it would move production of its Always sanitary napkins to its plant in Belleville, Ontario. The company, which is trying to sell its Attends adult-diaper unit for North America, will move diaper production elsewhere if a buyer is not found. The company said it would try to find the 500 factory workers and 85 managers jobs at other P.& G. plants and offer early retirement if they qualify. P.& G., based in Cincinnati, is paring its product lineup to well-known brands like Crest toothpaste and Tide laundry detergent.

Spanish flamenco dance can also be creatively reshaped, as Joaquin Cortes sought to demonstrate in ''Pasion Gitana (Gypsy Passion),'' the show he presented at City Center on Tuesday night.

In September, she will open the doors of the Girls' Middle School, a private school for sixth through eighth grade in Mountain View, Calif., that will focus on math, science and technology. Ms. Bennett said she believed that the school would be the first of its kind in the nation.

description: The British Government said yesterday that it would hand over construction of the troubled project for a fast-train link from London to the Channel Tunnel to Railtrack Group P.L.C., while a group that includes British Airways P.L.C. will help run the Eurostar high-speed trains traveling through the tunnel.

title: P.S.: American Pop Is Big in Foreign Stamps
description: POPULAR culture has been a dominant international theme in stamps for 20 years. Chad honors Einstein, Mongolia honors the X-Men comics. When it comes to pop postage, America is way behind tiny Antigua, where 220 stamps have been designed by the Walt Disney Company with images ranging from Donald Duck to Sleeping Beauty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENDIGS, CHARLES W. JR.
description: RENDIGS-Charles W. Jr. of New York City died after a long illness May 27, 1998 at home. He was a graduate of Trinity Pauling class of 1940, and of Dartmouth College class of 1944. During World War II, he enlisted and was 1st Lieutenant in the 104th Airborne. He was honorably discharged in 1946. He returned and graduated from Dartmouth College and continued his studies at the Amos Tuck School class of 1949. He was a member of SAE. Mr. Rendigs was associated with Bache, Halsey, Stuart and its predecessors, since 1949, he was head of their syndicate department and also participated in overseeing corporate finance, over-the-counter, municipals and other departments. He was a partner, Vice President, and then Senior Vice President as well as a Director of Bache. He retired from Bache in 1979. He then went on to become a Managing Director at Whitney & Company, and President and CEO of Whitney Holdings LTD. During his career, he was active in the Bond Club of New York, a member of the Dartmouth/Yale Club, Doubles, and a member of the Point O' Woods Club. He also maintained a residence at Point O' Woods. He is survived by his wife of thirty-four years, Jean Smith, a son Charles W. III, and sons Richard Riker and Robert Ward from a previous marriage, and a sister Frances Lunsford of Florida. In lieu of flowers, for those who wish, contributions may be made to the Brick Presbyterian Church of New York or to the Point O' Woods Church, NY 11706. A memorial will be held at a later date.

title: Which Computer Is Just Right?; 3 New Near-Notebooks Have Real Keyboards but Fit in a Pocketbook
description: GOLDILOCKS would have had no end of criticism for portable computing devices. They're either too big or too little. They're either too smart (read: short battery life because the bigger processors eat electricity) or too dumb (read: stripped-down functions).

title: A Small Card Maker Finds Itself Atop the Web
description: THE appearance of the site www.bluemountain.com at the top of various lists of popular sites has left Web watchers scratching their heads. Blue Mountain Arts is a small greeting card company based in Boulder, Colo., and known for its sincere if slightly treacly sentiment. But on the net, the Blue Mountain site is beating out big names like Disney Online, the bookseller Amazon.com and the Hotmail free E-mail service.

title: A Nonmanufacturing Index Shows Growth
description: Activity rose at nonmanufacturing companies in May from April, according to a new monthly survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management released yesterday.

title: Final Sprint Decides Race
description: When a 105-mile bicycle race comes down to a tightly bunched field in a final sprint, timing usually makes the difference. It did in yesterday's Christiana Care Cup race through downtown Wilmington, Del., and the Brandywine Valley countryside.

title: 2 Horse-Racing Syndicates Flourish on Line
description: HORSEPLAYERS are by nature second-guessers. So perhaps it is not surprising that, in 1994, a group of racing fans who had been second-guessing trainers and owners regularly on an Internet mailing list decided to see if they could do better. So they pooled their money and bought a horse.

title: F.D.A. AUTHORIZES FIRST FULL TESTING FOR H.I.V. VACCINE
description: The Food and Drug Administration has given a California company approval to conduct the world's first full-scale test of a vaccine to prevent infection with the AIDS virus, the company announced yesterday.

title: Junior Wraps Up A Perfect Season
description: Murad Campbell, a junior at Overbrook High, completed an undefeated season with his second straight 3,200-meter victory yesterday in the New Jersey State high school championships in South Plainfield, N.J..

title: No Race Profiling Found In Stops on Turnpike

title: F.T.C. to Call for Laws to Protect Children on Line
description: Amid mounting public concern about the abuse of personal data in an increasingly digital world, the Federal Trade Commission is expected to censure the Internet industry today in a report to Congress for doing virtually nothing to insure adequate consumer privacy protection on line.

title: Willis Armstrong, 86, Ex-State Dept. Aide
description: Willis Coburn Armstrong, a former Assistant Secretary of State for economic affairs, died on Sunday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 86.

title: Sent Back to China, Man Washes Up Again
description: Wang Wu Dong was a skinny man of 40 when he washed up on the shores of Queens five years ago, a passenger on the Golden Venture, a freighter loaded with a human cargo of 286 illegal Chinese immigrants that shuddered to a halt on a sandbar within sight of the city's lights.

title: Somnambulant Spies
description: It was troubling to learn last month that American intelligence agencies had failed to spot the preparations for India's nuclear testing. Now a review of the case shows that the cause was not an isolated problem like the misinterpretation of a telling satellite photo, but a more disturbing systemic failure. Many of the photos, for instance, were not even closely examined. David Jeremiah, a retired admiral who investigated the case for the Central Intelligence Agency, has produced a stinging indictment of Washington's espionage operations. President Clinton and Congress need to make sure his report is not quietly shelved by the agencies it lacerates.

title: WATSCO TO BUY AIR-CONDITIONING PRODUCTS DISTRIBUTOR
description: Watsco Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Kaufman Supply for an undisclosed price to expand its distribution of air-conditioning and heating products into the growing manufactured-housing market. Watsco, with $635 million in 1997 revenue, is the largest United States distributor of air-conditioning, heating and refrigeration equipment. Kaufman, based in Atlanta, distributes those products to owners of manufactured homes and had $102 million in revenue last year. Watsco, based in Miami, distributes its products in 22 states. Kaufman sells nationally to more than 2,500 contractors and dealers. Shares of Watsco slipped 43.75 cents yesterday, to $29.

title: After Emotional Summations, Jury Weighs Death Sentence
description: After a prosecutor urged a death sentence for a ''malignant'' triple killer and a defense lawyer appealed for ''justice tempered by mercy,'' a Brooklyn jury began deliberating yesterday whether to sentence a former jail guard to execution for murdering three people during a robbery.

title: Commencements; Ferraro Urges Hunter Graduates to Stay Active in Political Process
description: While avoiding any mention that she is an active candidate for the Senate, Geraldine A. Ferraro urged Hunter College graduates yesterday not ''to drop out of the political process.'' She spoke at the first of two sessions celebrating the college's 177th annual graduation.

description: The Nippon Steel Corporation, the world's biggest steelmaker, and three other Japanese steel companies had their long-term credit ratings cut by Moody's Investors Service Inc. on falling demand for steel in Japan and Asia. Nippon Steel, the Kawasaki Steel Corporation, the Tokyo Steel Manufacturing Company and Sumitomo Metal Industries were downgraded, and all except for Sumitomo may be further downgraded, Moody's said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEALE, CLAUDIA GARESCHE
description: NEALE-Claudia Garesche of Chappaqua, New York died June 3 at her home following a lengthy battle with Cancer. Mrs. Neale was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Claude F. Garesche of Saint Louis, Missouri. She was born on November 29, 1923. She was an Alumna, and active benefactor of The Convent of The Sacred Heart in Noroton, CT, The Kent Place School in Summit, NJ and Vassar College. She was married on May 24, 1947 to Richard L. Neale of Cleveland, OH. Mrs. Neale was a member of The Junior League of Northern Westchester, a volunteer for Hospice of Northern Westchester and Putnam, and at The Northern Westchester Hospital. She also pursued a successful 25 year career in real estate with The Coldwell Banker agency in Chappaqua. She was a parishioner of The Church of St. John and St. Mary for 45 years. Mrs. Neale is survived by her husband, 2 sons, Richard Garesche Neale of Atlanta, GA, and Peter Charles Neale of New Canaan, CT, 3 daughters, Patricia Neale Van Clief of Lexington, KY, Claudia Neale Brodlieb of Ridgefield, CT and Mary Corinne Neale of Pleasantville, NY, a brother, Thomas Knapp Garesche of Chappaqua, NY, and 9 grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at The Church of St. John and St. Mary in Chappaqua on Friday, June 5 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers the family asks that contributions be made to The American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, NY 10601, or to The Church of St. John and St. Mary, 15 St. Johns Place, Chappaqua, NY10514

title: The Tried and True in California Triumph Over the Rich and New
description: Despite record spending by a handful of wealthy candidates, Californians embraced the established political order in their primary election on Tuesday and set the stage for a fall contest between two conventional career politicians, the Democratic Lieutenant Governor, Gray Davis, and the Republican State Attorney General, Dan Lungren.

title: One Man's Journey to the Center of Baseball
description: Before throwing his first pitch for the Yankees last night, Orlando Hernandez stood behind the mound for several seconds and stared around the outfield at Yankee Stadium. These were moments to remember for Hernandez, the realization of a lifelong goal and the culmination of a harrowing journey that began six months ago with a risky escape from Cuba and ended last night on baseball's grandest stage.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the News Summary yesterday about the 1989 shooting of Yusuf K. Hawkins in Brooklyn referred incorrectly in some editions to the charges on which Keith Mondello was convicted and served prison time in the case. They were rioting, unlawful imprisonment, menacing and possession of a weapon, not murder.

title: Defeat of Bilingual Education Is Challenged in Federal Court
description: Minority-rights advocates, stung by the decisive success of a voter initiative in California ending bilingual education there, filed suit in Federal District Court in San Francisco yesterday to prevent the resolution from taking effect. They said the initiative violated the United States Constitution's promise of equal protection as well as Federal education and civil rights laws.

title: Currents; INTERIORS -- Posh Goes the Hotel
description: With the economy aloft, hotels are tilting toward design extravagance. But at the staid Regency Hotel in Manhattan, a redesign required subtlety. In other words, don't expect to see Philippe Starck's latest surreal zoominess. Instead, the Regency asked a little-known residential designer in Greenwich, Conn., to make the interiors homier. The designer, Connie Beale, equipped guest rooms with ergonomic chairs and mahogany furniture. The poshest detail: in the restaurant embossed, glazed red leather paneling (above), stenciled by Patty Garvey. The Regency is at 540 Park Avenue (61st Street); (212) 759-4100. TIMOTHY JACK WARD

title: Rebellion At Drugstore; Caught in a Cost Squeeze, Pharmacies Make a Stand, Rejecting Managed Care
description: Martin J. Keane has spent two decades refining his skill at mixing custom-made prescriptions, helping customers sort through the maze of medications and making sure they get Feldene for their arthritis and Seldane for their hay fever, not the other way around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUEHL, PROFESSOR JOHN
description: KUEHL-Professor John. The Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Science and the Faculty of the English Department of New York University announce with sorrow the death of our colleague and friend, John Kuehl. A noted scholar of F. Scott Fitzgerald and contemporary writing, Professor Kuehl was also a novelist and short story writer. His wit, engaging manner and brilliant teaching earned the admiration of his students and friends. In his memory, the English Department will establish the John Kuehl Prize for Research on F. Scott Fitzgerald by an NYU Graduate student. We extend our warmest condolences to his widow, Professor Linda Kuehl.

title: Currents; GARDEN TRENDS -- I Am Curious (Lemon)
description: ''It used to be that you had to be a witch to use medicinals,'' said Sal Gilbertie, the owner of Gilbertie's Herb Gardens, which supplies 800 garden centers in the Northeast. This year, Mr. Gilbertie has trouble keeping up with gardeners' demands for echinacea, ginseng, gotu kola and most of all St. John's wort, above, which is touted as nature's Prozac but, he says, is ''actually a weed.'' Why are people buying? ''Curiosity, I guess,'' he said. ''It certainly doesn't make any sense to make your own extract.'' Also hot now at Gilbertie's: lemon anything, from thyme to lemon grass. Gilbertie's retail operation is at 7 Sylvan Lane in Westport, Conn. LINDA LEE

title: Executive Changes

description: IS it warm weather that inspires the desire to put household objects in order? Something that provokes the taking up of arms against a winter's accumulation, the determination to stem the relentless tide of miscellany, to put things at last in their place?

description: Manhattan Tap took a trip around the world in ''Excursion Fare'' on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. And with this imaginative new show, the company comes close to bridging the gap between old- and new-style tap, with dancing that is intimate and as intimately involved with the music as any tap soloist and instrumentalist.

title: BELLSOUTH TO BEGIN OFFERING TV SERVICE TO ATLANTA
description: The BellSouth Corporation plans to announce today that it has begun to offer television service to Atlanta residents using digital wireless technology. The company says it will offer the service, which includes more than 160 channels, to more than 700,000 households in the Atlanta area. The service's introduction there is expected to be good news for Americast, a television venture of BellSouth, Ameritech, GTE, Southern New England Telecommunications and Walt Disney. Americast is locked in a legal battle with SBC Communications Inc., which has withdrawn from the group, over whether SBC owes the venture more money. The service began in New Orleans last fall, and BellSouth plans to expand it to cover more than two million homes in Florida by the end of the year.

title: Currents; MAGALOGUE -- Furnishing the Home With the Turn of a Page
description: For all those who are hypnotized by the homes mythologized in glossy interior design magazines, only to be snapped back to reality because the stuff belongs to someone else, here comes Room. A mail-order catalogue that looks like a high-end home magazine, Room, a quarterly, features the kind of ''modern, luxurious merchandise that can be found only in a handful of local boutiques,'' said Amy Crain, the merchandizer in chief of Room. And it's all for sale, every streamlined stick of furniture, say, in the Wallpaper-cool living room of a young pajama-clad couple. The first 36-page issue will be mailed in August.

description: IN rain, snow, sleet and hail, and even wind that will ruin a teen-ager's perfect hair, students around the country are trudging outside daily to gather precise weather data that will be used by teams of scientists studying the environment.

title: Ever Polite, Always Convenient, Superbly Efficient: The A.T.M.
description: IT is a fantasy for modern times: You ask an automated teller machine for $100 from your account and like a slot machine showing three cherries, it just keeps spitting out money.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERSON, IVAN D.
description: GERSON-Ivan D. ''A Unique Man''. Four birthdays without you. Time has not healed our broken hearts. We miss you and love you more each day. Happy Birthday in heaven our dear Ivan, lots of hugs and kisses. Mom, Dad and Adrienne

title: Korean Air, Bucking a Trend, Will Buy 27 Boeing 737 Jets
description: Korean Air, bucking a trend that has seen many Asian airlines delay orders for new airplanes as a result of the region's economic crisis, plans to announce next week that it is buying 27 new Boeing 737 passenger jets valued at $1.35 billion.

title: At Least 80 Die in German Train Crash
description: A high-speed passenger train roaring through northern Germany plowed into a concrete pillar of a road overpass at 125 miles an hour today, spun from the tracks and killed at least 80 people, possibly including children on a school excursion. Hundreds more were injured.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA RISES HALF A PERCENT. Futures prices of cocoa rose for the first time in three days amid concern that harvests in West Africa might be damaged by excessive rain. July contracts rose $8, to $1,634 a metric ton.

title: Hernandez Is Everything Yanks Hoped
description: Had Orlando Hernandez kept the Yankees close last night, his manager would have been pleased. If he had lasted five innings, that would have been enough. But in his major league debut, Hernandez gave the Yankees much more, beating Tampa Bay, 7-1, before 27,291 fans at Yankee Stadium.

title: A Question of Balance: Where Did It Go, Anyway?
description: You'd think the Texaco Jazz Festival concerts at the TriBeCa Arts Center, an airplane-hangar-size gallery on Franklin Street, would be among its choice slots. But as proved by Tuesday night's show there -- a double-bill of the band Sephardic Tinge and Muhal Richard Abrams's quartet -- the space is large beyond a realistic audience scale, acoustically reverberant and ultimately unsatisfactory for the musicians. Meanwhile, at the Knitting Factory, the festival's home base, the feeling the same night was uncomfortably packed but exciting. It's a local symptom of the New York problem: it's either too hot or too cold, people are either snooty or salt of the earth, cultural events overcrowded or a flop. We just can't get the right balance.

title: 38 Shots, Only One Goal
description: The MetroStars unleashed a league-record 38 shots last night, but only one found the net in a 2-1 loss to the Tampa Bay Mutiny at Giants Stadium. Tampa forward Musa Shannon took a crossing pass from Gilmar and volleyed it in for the go-ahead goal in the 66th minute.

title: Ethiopians and Eritreans Resume Border Battle
description: Heavy fighting broke out early this morning between Ethiopian and Eritrean troops along the two countries' border, dealing a serious blow to diplomatic efforts to avert a full-scale war between the former allies, Eritrean officials and witnesses said.

title: Delay of the New Intel Chip Won't Affect Consumers Much
description: The manufacturing problems that have set the delivery of Intel's next-generation chip back by at least six months mean a blow to Intel, but for the average personal computer user, the impact of the delay is likely to be imperceptible.

description: To the Editor:

title: FORTUNE BRANDS TO ACQUIRE ELECTROLUX CABINET UNIT
description: Fortune Brands Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Schrock Cabinet Company from Electrolux A.B. for $107.5 million in cash, making Fortune Brands the second-largest cabinet maker in the United States after the Masco Corporation. Fortune Brands, which makes Aristokraft cabinets, Master Lock padlocks and Titleist golf equipment, said that adding Schrock's annual sales of $183 million would almost double its sales of kitchen and bath cabinets. The company, based in Old Greenwich, Conn., said the acquisition of Schrock, based in Hilliard, Ohio, would bolster earnings immediately. Its shares slipped 18.75 cents yesterday, to $38.6875.

title: Corrections
description: The notes at the end of the tennis article about the French Open yesterday misstated the surname of the Russian player who defeated Gustavo Kuerten. He was Marat Safin.

title: Shunning the Art of Spin, Bahrain Seeks Investors From U.S.
description: In his first visit to the United States in seven years, the Emir of Bahrain came this week not to buy American military hardware or ask for more protection against Saddam Hussein, but to woo American investors.

title: Currents; TRANSLUCENCE -- Walls of Foam and Light
description: When designers want to create a translucent wall, they usually choose glass or plastic. But foam? That is what Vignelli Associates of Manhattan used for Poltrona Frau's booth (below) at a furniture show in Milan, Italy, this spring. ''We chose the foam sheets because of the quality of the translucence,'' said Massimo Vignelli, who designed it with his wife and partner, Lella. ''It's less expensive than using sandblasted glass.'' The walls, with double sides, were made by gluing foam on wood frames and installing fluorescent lights between the sides. ''It became walls of light,'' he said, adding that the wall can be used as a room divider. The foam, Forex EPC foam polycarbonate, is $1.73 a square foot at Alusuisse Composites; (800) 626-3365. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Bridge; When Opponents' Bidding Shows the Path to Victory
description: The second-oldest bridge event in the United States and perhaps in the world is the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, which was just played for the 69th time. In the final on Sunday at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street, the winners were Richard De Martino of Riverside, Conn., Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn., William Ehlers of West Orange, N.J., Bruce Rogoff of Hackensack, N.J., and Arnold Malasky of Westport, Conn. De Martino has now finished first-second-first in three years, while Rogoff was recording his fourth victory and Smith his third.

description: From South Korea, Boeing To Get $1.35 Billion Order

title: Bordeaux Winemaker Is Charged With Fraud Over Contents of Its Products
description: In what could become France's biggest wine scandal in decades, one of Bordeaux's most prestigious wine properties, Chateau Giscours, has been charged with fraudulent winemaking practices.

title: Apologies Made for Mix-Up That Listed E-Mail Codes
description: When the 35,000 subscribers to the on-line version of Advertising Age checked their E-mail this week, they found an unsolicited -- and some would say alarming -- piece of mail from TheGlobe.com, an on-line ''community.'' The message invited recipients to sign on to the service, and it included a preselected user name and password.

description: It's an instant classic, a brand-new building that Jefferson might have felt at home in -- especially if he needed to plug in his laptop to take notes from a video data projector.

title: 6 Degrees of Networking
description: SIX degrees of separation, the theory that everyone on the planet is connected by a chain of only six people, carries the grace of logic and the tantalizing lure of being impossible to disprove. The idea of six degrees of separation was advanced by Guglielmo Marconi, the inventor of the wireless telegraph, and popularized in the 1990 play of the same name by John Guare.

title: Effie Awards Are Presented
description: The M&M/Mars division of Mars Inc. won the top prize last night when the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association presented its 30th annual Effie Awards, which recognize effectiveness in advertising.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on May 25 about the United States' increasing use of National Guard troops in Bosnia misstated the uniqueness of the Guard's service overseas. While a combat unit of the Army National Guard sent to Bosnia was the first such unit deployed overseas in nearly three decades, combat units of the Air National Guard have served overseas in recent years.

title: Gov. James, in Runoff, Tries Body Blows
description: After forcing Gov. Fob James Jr. into a runoff in the Republican gubernatorial primary on Tuesday, Winton Blount 3d today cast his coming four-week duel with Mr. James as a chance for Alabama to stop electing leaders who ''continually embarrass us.''

title: Nevada Resort Plans to Rival Broadway's Grip on Talent
description: In a move designed to alter the type of entertainment now seen in Las Vegas, Nev., Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman of Mirage Resorts Inc., announced the appointment today of Sandy Gallin, a top talent manager, to join his company and start new theaters, arenas and cabarets.

title: Police Investigate Threatening Messages at School
description: A series of vulgar messages threatening violence against certain teachers and students at Canarsie High School in Brooklyn has prompted heightened security and a police investigation, Board of Education officials said yesterday.

title: Blackout Ends Evening Of Fantasy
description: Mordecai Shehori, a pianist who has developed a considerable reputation among connoisseurs, found himself unable to finish his recital on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. Mr. Shehori began the program with Beethoven's Fantasy in G minor, playing with his typical searching intensity though experiencing difficulty in passage work. Then he started Schumann's Fantasy in C but fell to a halt in the fiendishly difficult second movement.

He was one game from winning a five-set epic with the acrobatic Hicham Arazi, one game from reaching his first French Open semifinal after a decade of disappointment at his hometown Grand Slam tournament.

title: Stars Need 46 Seconds In Overtime
description: Cagey old Guy Carbonneau was trying to center the puck in front of the net. His junior teammate, Jamie Langenbrunner, was just trying to dump it in to finish his shift. When both shots found the net, the Dallas Stars earned a trip to Detroit and at least one more game in the Western Conference finals.

Volkswagen said it planned an annual production of 80,000 of the vehicles, while Porsche said it would produce 20,000. The vehicles, which will bear the car makers' individual trademarks, will be available beginning in 2002.

title: EXOR GROUP PUTS ITS U.S. INSURANCE UNIT UP FOR SALE
description: Exor Group S.A., an investment company controlled by the Agnelli family in Italy, said yesterday that it had put its Constitution Re United States insurance unit up for sale after rising competition hurt profits in its main business, nonstandard auto coverage. Performance of Constitution Re's other lines of insurance improved, offsetting the drop, said Bard Bunaes, Constitution Re's chief executive. Exor paid the Xerox Corporation $400 million for Constitution Re in 1995. Exor typically buys companies with the intention of selling them several years later at a profit. It has hired Morgan Stanley & Company to find a buyer willing to pay $900 million for the company, a person who has seen the company's sales materials said.

George E. Pataki and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: E-TRADE AND SOFTBANK TO FORM ON-LINE CONCERN IN JAPAN
description: E-Trade Group Inc. will set up an on-line securities company in Japan with the Softbank Corporation to take advantage of deregulated trading commissions, the companies said. Softbank, based in Tokyo, will own 58 percent of the venture, which will be set up this month with capitalization of 2.7 billion yen, or $19.4 million. E-Trade, an on-line securities company based in Palo Alto, Calif., will own the other 42 percent. The venture, which will be aimed at individual investors, will handle transactions for stocks, bonds and other financial products, and will provide corporate and stock market data. It plans to start operations later this year, Nikkei English News reported.

description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved a powerful combination of two antiviral drugs to treat chronic hepatitis C, a liver infection that can lead to cirrhosis, liver cancer and liver failure.

description: Russia's unsteady economy survived a critical test today as the Government sold nearly $1 billion in Treasury bills without paying the colossal interest rates that the bonds traded at just a week ago.

title: Offices Money Can't Buy
description: If nothing else, the results of California's primary elections may cause multimillionaires to rethink their plans for midlife career changes. Never have so many spent so much to win so little. The businessman Al Checchi could have gotten a better return by spending his $40 million on Lotto tickets than by seeking the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Representative Jane Harman, who finished right behind Mr. Checchi in the race, lost both her Congressional career and about $15 million of her husband's fortune. The car alarm magnate Darrell Issa spent $10 million of his own money chasing the G.O.P. Senate nomination, to no avail.

title: Prices Close on Downside, With Dow Retreating 87.44
description: Resilient concerns about weakness in the technology sector pushed stocks lower yesterday, with the Nasdaq composite index falling more than 1 percent.

title: Killer Tells Of Rewards For Defending Apartheid
description: One of apartheid's most notorious killers took the stand today to say he was rewarded with rare medals and congratulated by generals and at least one Cabinet minister for his work in killing off political opponents.

title: Mexico to Prosecute U.S. Agents Who Ran an Anti-Drug Sting
description: Mexico has advised the United States that it will prosecute American Customs agents and informers who carried out an undercover money-laundering operation on Mexican soil and will seek the agents' extradition to face criminal trial here.

title: Breaking Ground; Seed. Reseed. Secede.
description: WHERE do you go to shoot a movie about a perfectly ordinary American whose whole life, unbeknownst to him, is a scripted show for television? Ideally, you'd find a place that looked so stereotypically small-town America, so thoroughly front-porched and picket-fenced, that it could pass for a movie set. This is what the producers of ''The Truman Show,'' which opens tomorrow, were looking for -- and what they found in Seaside, Fla., the famous neotraditional town on the Gulf Coast. But there was one thing missing from the real Seaside that the producers felt their hero absolutely had to have: a lawn.

title: South Korea Banks Criticized Over List

title: Can the Internet Be Addictive, Or Is the Problem Elsewhere?
description: The results of a small new study cast some doubt on the notion of Internet addiction as a psychiatric problem. The report, presented earlier this week at the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association in Toronto, suggests that people who seem unable to curtail the number of hours they spend on the Internet may suffer from a raft of other psychiatric disorders.

title: Awards With a Wink but With No DiCaprio (Live)
description: When Leonardo DiCaprio didn't show up for the Oscars ceremony this year (some said because he hadn't been nominated as best actor for his role in ''Titanic''), there was a little public grumbling. When Mr. DiCaprio didn't show up for the MTV Movie Awards last Saturday but thanked the voters on tape for his best male performance award, the producers followed his thank you with ''The Making of the Leonardo DiCaprio Acceptance Speech.''

title: Extended Pact For Jazz Coach
description: Larry Miller, the Utah Jazz owner, has watched the turmoil unfold in Chicago and has decided he does not want what the Bulls have: disgruntled stars, an unappreciative management and the anxiety of the end of an era.

title: Labor Defeats Threat to Its Muscle
description: In an impressive assertion of organized labor's political might, California voters on Tuesday dealt conservatives a considerable setback by rejecting a measure championed by Republicans that would have pinched the flow of money to Democratic candidates and causes.

title: 'A' Train to Show House
description: SHOW houses in New York are generally not racially or ethnically diverse, from the designers for whose works they are a showcase to the ticket buyers who come by to gawk and sometimes hire. The first Harlem United Show House, which opens Saturday and will remain on view through July 3, however, aims to change that situation.

title: EXXON TO CREATE UNIT TO FOCUS ON DEEP-WATER PROJECTS
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it was forming a subsidiary, the Exxon Upstream Development Company, to focus on developing deep-water oil and gas projects. Exxon, the largest United States oil company, said that Exxon Upstream would develop the Hoover-Diana project in the Gulf of Mexico and the Girassol project off Angola. It will also take over development of offshore projects in West Africa. The new unit, to be based in Houston, will begin operation on July 1 and will have 350 employees assigned to it this year.

title: Real Quiet Arrives at Belmont for His Date With History
description: Like a king who has been proclaimed but not yet crowned, Real Quiet arrived in New York yesterday amid movie-star fanfare and with an entourage that declared him ready to win the Belmont Stakes and become the 12th horse in racing history to sweep the Triple Crown.

title: Vehicle Sales Are Highest Since 1986
description: The nation's auto industry reported that May was the best month for car and truck sales since September 1986, with sales totaling 1,511,661 cars and trucks, a 12.1 percent increase from the corresponding period last year.

title: Representative Barely Beats Conservative
description: Representative Marge Roukema, a moderate Republican and veteran lawmaker, survived a challenge from the party's conservative wing in primary voting on Tuesday to win the nomination to run for a 10th term in her northern New Jersey Congressional district.

title: German Boat Wins Series Title
description: Illbrick-Pinta, a 48-foot German boat, won the overall title in the Newport-Manhattan Series after capturing one of the three windward-leeward races staged in New York Harbor yesterday.

title: M.T.A. Renews Pact With Korey Kay
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority in New York said yesterday that as expected it had renewed its advertising contract with Korey Kay & Partners in New York for another three-year term. Billings were estimated at $10 million for 1998.

title: Many Buying Home Shredders to Thwart Garbage Snoops
description: THE Nixon Administration did it. So did Oliver North. And so does Carole H. Harris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, ALBERT
description: NORTON-Albert of heart failure. Beloved friend of: Edward Jarvis, Paul Secor, Jane Brown, Margery Shaw, Diane Porembski, Jim Gemmell and Meriam Michelle, all of New York City. Affectionate and loving cousin of: Judy and Doug Hakola, Steve and Kathy Young, Don and Vicki Johnston and Curt Hughes, all of South Jersey. Donations may be made to the Albert Norton Wettstein Memorial Fund, Drew University, Madison, NJ 09740.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Thomas Trosch

title: With the Argol and Rebob, The Ethos of Exploration
description: Yusef Lateef performed at TriBeCa Hall on Wednesday night as part of the Texaco New York Jazz Festival, and his show in some ways was about the jazz ethos of exploration. Mr. Lateef, in the 1950's, made some quite beautiful recordings for Prestige and Riverside records, and even then he was synthesizing all his cultural and musical interests. On ''Other Sounds,'' recorded in 1957, he used the argol, rebob and small percussion, along with the tenor saxophone in some essentially mainstream jazz performances.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Artistry at the Hoop By Players in a Park
description: Slicing down the lane, Fred Brown, a 6-foot-4 leaper, tossed the ball off the backboard, spun, snatched it in midflight and dunked backward. Pulling on the iron rim, he remained suspended above the painted asphalt in Holcombe Rucker Park, on Eighth Avenue and 155th Street, in Harlem. Head bowed, elbows splayed, his legs crossed at the ankles, he hung for what seemed like an endless moment above the fray.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOYLER, FREEMAN W.
description: MOYLER-Freeman W. on June 2, 1998 of Mt. Vernon, N.Y. Beloved husband of Aline (nee Glover) Moyler. Devoted father of Stephanie and Joy. Dear brother of John, Muriel, Champlin, Melvin, Elaine. ''Uncle Pancho'' to all youngsters who knew him; brother-in-law, and loyal friend to those of kind spirit. Reposing at Camelot Funeral Home Inc., 174 Stevens Avenue, Mt. Vernon, N.Y. Friday, June 5th, 6-9PM. Funeral service Saturday, June 6 at 12 noon at Macedonia Baptist Church, 141 South 9 Ave, Mt. Vernon, N.Y. Interment Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, N. Y.
