description: To the Editor:

title: On My Mind; He Didn't Do It Alone
description: Bill Clinton did not do it all by himself.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Dare Is Released
description: Yinka Dare, the former Nets center, was released by the United States Basketball League's New Jersey Shorecats. The 7-foot-1-inch Dare was averaging 14.2 points, 9.9 rebounds and 3.6 blocks a game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIZNER, MORRIS
description: CIZNER-Morris. Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of its member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Publicis Acquires Evans Group
description: Publicis S. A. in Paris continued its American acquisition streak yesterday by buying Evans Group, an agency with billings estimated at $350 million, and merging Evans with Publicis/Bloom, one of two Publicis American shops. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Two Studios Cutting Back
description: Studio executives here cry ''wolf'' so often that it's hard to believe them. They complain about the soaring costs of films but pay millions of dollars and give elaborate perks to actors whose movies keep failing. They grumble about the sameness of films but produce movies that are often alike. They groan that the marketplace is too crowded every weekend but keep churning out movies.

title: Oran Henderson, 77, Dies; Acquitted in My Lai Case
description: Col. Oran K. Henderson, the highest-ranking officer to be tried as a consequence of the killings of Vietnamese civilians in My Lai in 1968, died on Tuesday at the Lebanon Veterans hospital in Lebanon, Pa. He was 77 and had pancreatic cancer.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Heavy Buying in Blue Chips Sends Dow Up 66.76 Points
description: The stock market rebounded yesterday, as investors were soothed by reports that the economy remains resilient and merger activity is still vibrant..

title: One Rhythm to the Next, His Thoughts Race Out Loud
description: Michael Brecker's first note was out of tune, and Mr. Brecker, a saxophonist, lifted it gently into pitch. He did it again, then spent the rest of his solo playing with intonation, repeating a phrase, but pushing a note or two out of tune. He resolved phrases to mild dissonance, and his soft, milky tone let him experiment without losing the audience.

title: Will the Fed Follow London's Lead?
description: The economies of the United States and Britain have moved in surprisingly similar ways in recent years, whether by coincidence or because both freed their economies in the 1980's. Now Britain's central bank has stunned observers by raising interest rates, posing the question whether the Federal Reserve will be the next to do so.

title: German Output Rises Faster Than France's
description: Germany's economy picked up strength in the first quarter while France's rebound slowed somewhat, bringing Europe's two biggest economies more in step as the region prepared for the start of a common currency in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, JACK
description: WEISS-Jack. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Jack Weiss, associated with The Times from August 1, 1946, until retiring on March 1, 1976.

title: Mets Just Keep Dealing, and Nomo Comes Aboard
description: Two weeks after the Mets acquired Mike Piazza from the Los Angeles Dodgers, they reunited him last night with one of the pitchers he caught every five days, Hideo Nomo.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Concerning Expressionism'

title: French Workers Strike Railroad As Pilots Seem Closer to Deal
description: PARIS  Striking Air France pilots appeared to be closer to an agreement on Thursday that could avoid chaos during the World Cup soccer tournament next week, but rail workers walked out, and traffic in Paris was snarled as tens of thousands of disgruntled workers staged protests in the capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAFORGIA, FELICE DR
description: LaFORGIA-Felice Dr. on May 29, 1998 in Naples, Italy. Beloved father of Vincenza, Elena and Guiseppe. Loving son of the late Cav. Joseph and the late Vincenza. Cherished brother of Frank and Marie Antonia Connolly. Devoted grandfather of 5. Dear father-inlaw of Fulvio Conte and Dr. Luigi Irace. Cherished brother-in-law of Josephine and Jim. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Memorial mass will be held on June 29th at 8PM at St. Dominic's RC Church, 2001 Bay Ridge Parkway. Interment Toritto Bari, Italy.

title: The Streets of a Crumbling El Dorado, Paved With Poetry and Desire
description: The flowering of art in the East Village in the mid-1980's was brief and uneven, but rich. Graffiti came in off the street, bringing black and Latino artists into galleries. Expressionist painting and conceptualism shared the field. An explicitly gay art emerged in the work of figures like Arch Connelly, Keith Haring, Nicholas Moufarrege and David Wojnarnowicz. Political content was everywhere, as was the theme of childhood innocence -- and experience -- that has played so important a role in 1990's art.

title: Bank of Thailand Sees Weak Currency as Aid
description: Thailand's central bank will accept a weaker baht to increase exports but will raise interest rates to limit the currency's fluctuations. The Bank of Thailand governor, Chatumongkol Sonakul, said yesterday that the economy could accept an exchange rate of 45 baht to the dollar -- 25 percent weaker than the rate he called ''the most suitable'' when he took office a month ago. In May, the governor said 38 to the dollar was best for stoking exports while still attracting foreign investment and tourists.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SUNTRUST BANKS INC., Atlanta, a bank holding company, agreed to buy the five offices of Citizens Bancorp, Marianna, Fla., for about $50 million in cash and stock.

title: Real Quiet Is Made Early Favorite to Finish Sweep
description: Thirteen horses were entered yesterday in the 130th running of the Belmont Stakes tomorrow, with Real Quiet drawing the No. 8 post position and favored at 6-5 to become the 12th winner of the Triple Crown.

title: Teaching Tolerance to Students; Wiesel Gives Personal Account of Holocaust's Horrors
description: Elie Wiesel has berated presidents, debated philosophers, chided popes and harangued dictators. The world-traveled Holocaust writer and Nobel laureate rarely falters. But then, rarely has his audience been as direct as the eighth graders of Public School 111 in Hell's Kitchen.

title: Giants' Back Optimistic in Cancer Fight
description: Giants running back LeShon Johnson smiled when he referred to his wife of six weeks as ''a computer geek.''

title: Old (but Gold) And Slapstick
description: For a look at the month ahead in video, one person to consult is Bob Helland of Asymmetrical Entertainment, a Brooklyn mail-order company that previews coming releases in its monthly bulletin. June looks moderately promising. While not overwhelmingly rich in big feature films -- ''Amistad,'' ''Wag the Dog,'' ''Welcome to Sarajevo'' and ''Wings of the Dove'' are among the better-known titles scheduled -- the list includes several older films that people have been waiting for.

title: US West Ordered to Halt Marketing Tie-In
description: A United States District Court in Seattle has ordered the U S West Communications Group to suspend a marketing alliance with Qwest Communications.

title: Investors Aglow Over Entrepreneurs
description: As recently as two years ago, a small German company like Kinowelt Medien A.G. had almost no hope of selling stock to outside investors.

title: Five Nations Join in Plea To Pakistan And India
description: The United States, Russia, China, Britain and France called on India and Pakistan today to freeze their nuclear weapons development and agree not to test nuclear missiles or arm them with warheads.

title: Let Vendors Pay for Sidewalk Space; Shrinking Demand
description: To the Editor:

title: Venice Journal; A Gondola (as It Were) Built for 2,600, Plus Crew
description: The Grand Princess twice the size of the Titanic -- sailed into port on Sunday night and seemed to eclipse even the cupola of St. Mark's Cathedral. As passengers spilled out to inspect the canals of Venice, most of Venice stared, awestruck, at the world's largest cruise ship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STICKNEY, DOROTHY
description: STICKNEY-Dorothy. The Board, Staff, Member Playwrights and Alumni of New Dramatists pay loving tribute to Dorothy Stickney, a leading light in the theater of this century. Her brilliant lifelong costar and beloved husband, Howard Lindsay, created and led New Dramatists almost 50 years ago with his writing partner, Russel Crouse, and a young playwright, Michaela O'Harra. They and fellow Broadway luminaries, John Golden, Rodgers & Hammerstein, Moss Hart and John Wharton, built a lasting safe haven for new writing talent, dedicated to artistic freedom and experimentation. Dorothy was a friend and champion, mentor and model for so many young theater artists. Their plays and musicals are born in The Lindsay and Crouse Studio at New Dramatists and will play the world's stages into the next millennium, carried on the wings of an angel in show biz 7th Heaven.

title: Guidelines Are Sought for Internet Privacy
description: Civil liberties advocates and children's groups urged the White House today to abandon its hands-off stance to Internet privacy regulation after a Federal Trade Commission report painted a dismal picture of the effectiveness of companies' self-regulation, especially in regard to children.

title: China Lifts Year's Ban On 3 Brokerage Firms
description: Three Chinese stock brokerage firms have resumed proprietary trading after a one-year ban imposed for market manipulation. The return of the Shenyin and Wanguo Securities Company, China's biggest brokerage firm; the Haitong Securities Company, and the Guangfa Securities Company is expected to bolster the domestic A-share market as companies that Beijing wants to wean off state support look for financing. (Bloomberg News)

title: In Newest Deal, Alcatel to Buy DSC for Stock
description: Alcatel Alsthom of France, one of the world's largest makers of telecommunications equipment, enhanced its position in the United States yesterday with the announcement of its acquisition of the DSC Communications Corporation for $4.4 billion in stock.

title: Banks Let Indonesia Postpone Repayment
description: Thirteen foreign banks agreed on a framework to allow Indonesia to delay repayment of nearly $80 billion in corporate and bank debt that was a barrier to restarting the economy.

title: Fujitsu Will Merge Division and Affiliate
description: Fujitsu Ltd. will spin off its electronics device division to consolidate it with its electronics device affiliate, the Fujitsu Towa Electron Company, company officials announced yesterday. The move is aimed at altering the structure of Fujitsu's electronics device businesses for faster reaction to changes in the mobile phone market and for improved competitiveness in all aspects of the business, including development and production, they said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, REBECCA P.
description: GOLDBERG-Rebecca P. On June 4, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jesse G. Loving mother of Laura Friedman and David E. Dear mother-in-law of Dr. Robert A. Friedman. Adoring grandmother of Joshua H. Friedman and Erika B. Friedman. Services today 11:30 AM at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont, NY, 914-834-0144.

title: In Love With the Past and a Vision of Perfect Beauty
description: The prolific Pre-Raphaelite painter and designer Edward Burne-Jones (1833-1898) is an artist whom generations of cognoscente have loved to hate, or at least ignore. In the 1870's and 80's, after two decades of relative obscurity, he was considered England's greatest living painter and celebrated in France and Belgium, where his work influenced Symbolism, and he established ties with such like-minded artists as Gustave Moreau, Pierre Puvis de Chavaunnes and Ferdinand Khnopff.

title: Patients' Rights Bill Restores Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: PMC COMMERCIAL AGREES TO BUY SUPERTEL HOSPITALITY
description: PMC Commercial Trust SBI signed an agreement yesterday to acquire Supertel Hospitality Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $134 million. PMC Commercial, based in Dallas, will issue six-tenths of a common share for each share of Supertel, based in Norfolk, Neb. The ratio is subject to adjustment. Shares of PMC Commercial Trust lost 50 cents yesterday, to $19.75. Shares of Supertel rose 75 cents, to $13.75. The agreement also calls for Supertel shareholders to receive a preclosing dividend based on its earnings. PMC Commercial will lease Supertel's 62 hotels to the Norfolk Hospitality Management Company. Supertel owns and operates limited-service motel properties under the Super 8, Comfort Inn and Wingate Inn names.

title: Commerce Can Do the Job
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee began its hearings this week on the American satellites launched by Chinese rockets. Among the issues are whether our export control laws were violated and whether private companies committed illegal acts in the aftermath of the 1996 Loral rocket launch in China. Those specific charges should be investigated thoroughly, and if there was any wrongdoing it should be punished.

title: 2 Arrested in Murder Of Artist in Mexico
description: The police in Mexico have arrested two men suspected of raping and killing a well-known New Haven artist on a beach near the Pacific resort of Puerto Escondido, the Attorney General of Oaxaca State said yesterday.

title: Oil Prices Up 2% After 3 Producers Agree to Cut Output
description: Oil prices rose by 2 percent in the futures markets yesterday after Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico, three of the world's largest producers, agreed to cut production by 450,000 barrels a day.

title: William Abrahams, 79, Editor Of the O. Henry Story Awards
description: William Abrahams, a Harvard-bred poet who tried his hand at novels before finding a lasting literary niche as a distinguished book editor credited with almost single-handedly preserving the short story as a viable genre, died on Tuesday at his home in Hillsborough, Calif. He was 79 and had presided over the annual O. Henry short story awards for more than three decades.

title: Metro Business; Polo Jeans Leases Space
description: The Polo Jeans Company, a supplier of fashionable casual wear, has signed a long-term lease on 43,000 square feet of space, the entire fourth floor, at 115 Fifth Avenue, in the heart of Manhattan's Flatiron district.

title: TRAINING ORDERED FOR CONTROLLERS AT U.S. AIRPORTS
description: A near-collision by two big passenger jets at La Guardia Airport in April has prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to order retraining for the 10,000 air traffic controllers working in airport towers nationwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKON, ALAIN HENRI
description: MARKON-Alain Henri. Born in Toulouse, France on June 13, 1941. Died in Paris on May 31, 1998, after a long, heroic battle with cancer. Beloved son of Raya of New York City and the late Alexander. Devoted brother of Genya of Washington, D.C. Loving uncle of Dov and Yaron Yarkoni of Israel. Cherished friend to many in all corners of the world. Alain was a distinguished international attorney before the French and American courts of law. A person of rare sensitivity, wisdom and inner strength, he enriched and inspired the lives of those around him. Services Sunday, June 7th, 10:45AM at Riverside Memorial, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

description: To the Editor:

title: Torn Between Music and the Deaf
description: The recovery movement is filled with stories of children who grew up having to take care of emotionally dysfunctional parents. But what about those children who had to run interference for emotionally healthy parents with physical disabilities? In Caroline Link's film ''Beyond Silence,'' the story of a gifted young musician and first-born child in a family where both parents were deaf becomes a powerful metaphor for the inevitable communication gap between children and parents in even the happiest of homes. Imagine the frustration of being a gifted musician whose parents are literally unable to hear.

title: Fighter Scratched From Bout: She's 21 Weeks Pregnant
description: Maria Nieves-Garcia got a surprise during her prefight medical examination for her bout at Madison Square Garden tomorrow: She found out she was pregnant. Yesterday, when a third test confirmed what Nieves-Garcia could not believe, she was scratched from the bout.

title: EARNINGS FORECAST PUSHES NORTHWEST STOCK LOWER
description: Investor jitters about brewing labor problems and the continued weakness in Asian economies sent the stock of the Northwest Airlines Corporation down 6 percent yesterday. Late on Wednesday, the airline, the nation's fourth largest, warned that preliminary results for May suggested a deterioration in earnings and that second-quarter results might be significantly below profits a year ago. The company, based in St. Paul, said the Asian economic woes, severe weather that grounded more than two dozen planes for several days and operational difficulties caused by employee work actions were responsible for the downward earnings outlook. Northwest Airlines' stock fell $2.8125, to $39.8125, in Nasdaq volume of 3.2 million shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, EARL T.
description: BENNETT-Earl T. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Earl T. Bennett, associated with The Times from March 1, 1961, until retiring on January 1, 1977.

title: Difficult Lesson in Fund-Raising
description: At 10 A.M., Paul J. Feiner, the normally irrepressible Town Supervisor here, was mumbling his way through an embarrassing telephone sales pitch.

title: High School Students Arrested After Teachers Get Threats
description: Four teen-age boys who are accused of sending lewd notes threatening violence against certain teachers and students at a Brooklyn high school earlier this week have been arrested, school and police officials said yesterday.

title: St. John's Develops Backup Coach Plan
description: The search for a head basketball coach at St. John's plodded on yesterday, with the school insisting it has not given up hope of hiring George Washington University Coach Mike Jarvis, but also moving to secure a backup plan.

title: Riksbank to Cut Repurchase Rate
description: The Swedish central bank, the Riksbank, will cut its securities repurchase rate by 25 basis points, to 4.10 percent, the bank said yesterday as it published its quarterly inflation report. The cut will be made in connection with the weekly repo allocation on Tuesday and will be effective as of Wednesday, the Riksbank said.

description: To the Editor:

title: Displaying Her Past Form, Seles Has a Surprise for Hingis
description: This was no screeching apparition in black scaring the world's top player, Martina Hingis, half out of her wits on the French Open's center court in what turned out to be a one-sided semifinal that sent a clear message on a hazy afternoon at Roland Garros.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WONG, REVEREND MAURICE KING
description: WONG-Reverend Maurice King Fan, S.J. Aged 66, professor of Mathematics at Fairfield University, Fairfield CT, died June 3, 1998. Friends may call at the Chapel of St. Ignatius Hall, 86 Barlow Rd., Fairfield CT, Saturday 7-9 p.m., Sunday 2-4, 7-9 p.m. A Mass of Resurrection 11 a.m. on Monday, at the Eagan Chapel, of St. Ignatius, Fairfield University. In lieu of flowers, donations in Father Wong's memory may be made to the Jesuit Scholarship Fund, Fairfield University, Fairfield, CT.06430.

description: Andrew Thomas officially ended his 130-day mission aboard the Russian space station Mir today when the shuttle Discovery arrived to pick him up.

title: City Dreams and Heartbreak
description: The 18 songs in ''I Love New York,'' a breezy four-person revue that's playing an open-ended engagement at Rainbow and Stars, offers a lighthearted tourist's-eye view of the city that jumps around in time from the era of Victor Herbert (''The Streets of New York'') to Billy Joel (''New York State of Mind''). Each song is the musical equivalent of a tourist snapshot taken during a mad dash around the city.

title: JUSTICES REBUFF STARR'S REQUEST TO SPEED REVIEW
description: The Supreme Court delivered a swift rebuff today to Kenneth W. Starr's effort to short circuit the ordinary appellate process and get a quick ruling from the Justices on disputed claims of privilege for four grand jury witnesses.

title: Earlier Incident Allowed In Police Brutality Trial
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a jury may be told of allegations of an earlier incident of police brutality by Francis X. Livoti. The former police officer is charged with violating the civil rights of Anthony Baez, a Bronx man who died after he was choked during a 1994 arrest.

title: Reports of U.S. Plan Hint at New Israeli-Palestinian Talks
description: Two Israeli newspapers published details today of what they said was an American plan that would finally restore negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians. Neither American nor Israeli officials would confirm the authenticity of the reported plan, but they did say an agreement could be reached in days.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''People are trying to hang on, desperately hoping that the world will intervene to save them. We could not hold out any longer. There are thousands more behind us. Once they realize there is no hope, they will follow.''

description: Walter C. title: Senate Panel and C.I.A. Fight on China Documents
description: The Director of Central Intelligence caused a stir today by refusing to share some information with a Senate committee investigating the transfer of satellite technology to China, prompting Justice Department officials to backtrack and permit the release of certain information.

title: Mass Found in Elusive Particle; Universe May Never Be the Same
description: In what colleagues hailed as a historic landmark, 120 physicists from 23 research institutions in Japan and the United States announced today that they had found the existence of mass in a notoriously elusive subatomic particle called the neutrino.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Whitman to Consider Building a New Arena
description: With the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority preparing to formally seek proposals from developers for a new basketball and hockey arena in the Meadowlands, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday that she would also consider building an arena to insure that the Nets and Devils do not leave New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YELLEN, PAULA. (NEE KURZMAN
description: YELLEN-Paula. (nee Kurzman), June 2, 1998. Wife of John J. Yellen, Jr., of Narberth, PA, formerly of NY. Mother of Cathy D. Rebennack and Amy J. Yellen-Shaw. Mother-in-law of Malcolm Rebennack and Carl Shaw. Grandmother of Sarah and Emma. Memorial services will be held Sunday. The family respectfully requests contributions in her memory be made to Leukemia Society of America. Joseph Levine & Son-Phila.

title: Gains Continue, as Retailers Post 7.1% Rise in Sales
description: American retailers continued an impressive growth spurt last month, one that bodes well for coming company earnings.

title: Bowe Pleads Guilty to Abducting Wife and 5 Children
description: Riddick Bowe, the former undisputed world heavyweight champion, pleaded guilty in Federal court in Charlotte, N.C., yesterday to abducting his estranged wife and five children from their suburban Charlotte home on Feb. 25. Under a plea agreement, Bowe could face a minimum of 18 to 24 months in prison.

title: Body of Boy Is Recovered From Waters Of the Bronx
description: A widespread search for an 11-year-old boy who stumbled on the slippery rocks along the Bronx Kill ended early this morning when the boy's body was found in the shallow channel waters at low tide.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Setting Limits on Teen-Age Drivers
description: CONGRESS and the state legislatures have bogged down in their efforts to pass new laws on a risky group of drivers, those who drive drunk. But lawmakers are still voting new restrictions on another group who have a disproportionate share of auto accidents: teen-agers.

title: Sports of The Times; Horse Racing Tracks Down Its Real Deal
description: THE jockey burst into the room, minutes after his horse, the Triple Crown aspirant, had drawn post position No. 8 yesterday at Belmont. Someone at this moment handed Kent Desormeaux a cellular telephone. His wife, Sonia, was on the line.

title: TWO TO SELL STAKES IN TRAVELERS PROPERTY CASUALTY
description: The Travelers Property Casualty Corporation said yesterday that two of its investors would sell their remaining stakes in the insurer -- 8.9 million shares worth about $371 million -- after the stock underperformed the market in the last year. Travelers Property Casualty rose 12.5 cents, to $43.25. Its 11 percent gain for the past 52 weeks lagged behind a 24 percent rise in the Standard & Poor's property-casualty index and a 70 percent advance by its 83 percent owner, the New York-based Travelers Group Inc. The investors are a unit of the Hartford-based Aetna Inc. and divisions of New York's J. P. Morgan & Company.

title: Thompson Defends Title in Shot-Put
description: Tressa Thompson of Nebraska lost her meet record and then recaptured it in winning the women's shot-put for the second straight year at the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships with a put of 61 feet 2i inches.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; A Lesbian and Gay Festival With Mainstream Appeal
description: With homosexual characters popping up in more and more mainstream films, it is increasingly difficult nowadays to make a clear distinction between gay-oriented movies and those with mass appeal. And this blurring of categories can be felt in the programming of the 1998 New York Lesbian and Gay Film Festival, also known as the New Festival, which opened its 10th anniversary last evening with a screening of Lisa Cholodenko's ''High Art.'' (There is an additional screening tomorrow at noon at the New School's Tishman Auditorium.)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOCS, E. STEPHEN
description: GOCS-E. Stephen. Born 6/5/25, died 11/11/97, survived by sister Blanche, wife Helen, children Diane, Elizabeth, grandsons Andrew, Colin, Jack, Shawn, niece Stef, ex-wife, Marie. Condolences to 4600 University Drive, Springfield 1602, Durham, NC 27707. ''Man's reach must always exceed his grasp or what is Heaven for.''

title: Bright Receipts, Dark Houses
description: The Broadway season, which came in like a Lion King's roar, is going out with a whimper.

title: Biology Takes On Its Own Form of Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, FRANK
description: WEISSMAN-Frank. Of Pompano Beach, FLorida, formerly of Merrick, NY. Died on June 4, 1998. Cherished husband of Bea, loving father of Kurt & Patricia Weissman and Carla & Jon Schraub. Adored grandfather of Scott, Noah, David & Jason. Dear brother of Pearl Stieber & Harriet Firtel. Beloved uncle and friend.

description: SUMMERS-LeVerne. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of LeVerne Summers, associated with The Times since January 22, 1995.

title: Three R's, Plus One
description: Now that the House has defeated the proposed amendment to the Constitution that would have allowed prayer in public schools, some conservatives will again attribute the collapse of our moral fiber to the Supreme Court decision, in 1962, that prohibited mandatory prayer in public schools.

title: Motorola Says It Will Cut 15,000 Jobs
description: Motorola Inc. announced late today that it would eliminate 15,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, and take a $1.95 billion charge against second-quarter earnings, the direst indicator yet of tough times in the semiconductor industry.

title: Nissan to Cut U.S. Production Sharply
description: The Nissan Motor Company, the loss-plagued Japanese auto maker that announced a broad reorganization last month, said today that it would reduce vehicle output at its United States factory by 25 percent, the sharpest cut since it opened in 1983.

title: D.M.B.& B. Sues For Its Expenses
description: The D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications unit of MacManus Group in New York filed suit yesterday against the computer company Gateway Inc., contending that Gateway still owes the agency at least $9 million for expenses related to work performed before D.M.B.& B. was dismissed.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Vice Adm. Arthur R. Gralla on Sunday omitted the names of two surviving sisters. They are Lynn Kritzer of North Palm Beach, Fla., and Muriel Minkoff of Marlboro, N.J.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Rosana Palazyan

title: Europe Official Cites Concern On Worldcom-MCI Merger
description: The top European regulator reviewing Worldcom Inc.'s proposed $37 billion acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that MCI's proposed sale of part of its Internet business might not allay his antitrust concerns.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: POUND SPUTTERS. Sterling rallied against the dollar after the Bank of England surprised the market and raised an interest rate. But it finished the day lower. In New York, the pound eased to $1.6369, from $1.6399 on Wednesday.

title: VW Acts to Bolster Its Rolls-Royce Bid
description: Seeking to increase its chances of acquiring Rolls-Royce Motors Cars Ltd., Volkswagen A.G. agreed today to buy an engine supplier, Cosworth, from Rolls-Royce's parent, Vickers P.L.C., for $:120 million, or $195 million.

title: Swiss Banks Said to Offer Holocaust Payment
description: Switzerland's three major commercial banks have offered a settlement totaling more than $1 billion to end suits brought by Holocaust victims and their survivors who contend that the banks failed to return their assets after World War II, according to people familiar with the negotiations.

title: Voyage Back to Paradise, Birds and All
description: THE SPICE ISLANDS VOYAGE

title: Some Dwell in the Past, While Others Draw on It
description: It's natural for composers to look to music's past for inspiration. Too many creators in all fields, especially younger ones, make the mistake of trying to come up with something entirely and shockingly new.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEPONIS, WILLIAM VINCENT
description: LIEPONIS-William Vincent. 89, of Dunedin, FL, formerly of Jackson Heights, NY, passed away on May 26, 1998. He was a member of Saint Michael The Archangel Catholic Church, Clearwater, FL, where he was an usher and member of the Mens Club. He was also a member of the Moose 1030 Lodge Golf League. Survivors include his wife Alice, a son Robert, a daughter Muriel, both of Jackson Heights, NY, and a grandson Robert Leeponis, of Pearl River, NY. Interment Lakeview Chapel, Sylvan Abbey, Clearwater, FL.

title: Ethiopia Accepts Plan to End Eritrea Battles
description: Ethiopian and Eritrean troops continued to exchange artillery fire along their border today, but the Ethiopian Prime Minister accepted a peace plan proposed by the United States and Rwanda that would end the widening war. There was no immediate response from Eritrea.

title: Trying to Broaden the Appeal of Shakespeare, Even at His Least Digestible
description: The wide world beyond the small one in which she has always lived beckons through the fog, as tempting as it is unknown. For Imogen, the sorely tried heroine of Shakespeare's ''Cymbeline,'' this shadowy future can't arrive quickly enough. ''O, for a horse with wings!'' she exclaims, and it's impossible not to share her exhilaration and impatience. Yet her face suddenly melts from ardent resolve into an expression that, for just a second, betrays a terrified uncertainty. Anything could happen out there, couldn't it? Anything at all.

title: Residential Real Estate; 10 Years After First Sale, Co-op Makes Comeback
description: Sales are expected to restart next month at Turtle Bay Towers, putting the 337-unit co-op at 310 East 46th Street back in the market for the first time in a decade.

title: 2 on Taxi Panel Join Owners' Lawsuit
description: Deepening the dissension at the Taxi and Limousine Commission over Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's strict new taxi rules, two commission members filed affidavits yesterday supporting a suit by fleet owners against the commission and the Mayor.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 27 about restaurants and bars in New York that re capture some of the sophistication of the 1940's and 50's with classic dishes, cocktails and decor misstated John McClement's role at the Temple Bar. He is the manager; the owner is Dr. George Schwarz.

title: Art Museums Promise To Review Holdings For Seized Nazi Loot
description: The Association of American Art Museum Directors pledged today that its member museums would immediately begin a review of their collections in search of artworks that were illegally taken from their owners in the Nazi era and never returned.

title: What Set Noguchi Apart: He Was Apart
description: During the two decades before he died in 1988, at 84, Isamu Noguchi spent half of each year at a studio in Mure, a village on Shikoku, one of Japan's four main islands, making stone sculptures. He liked materials that he thought matched the character of the places where he worked, so in the United States he tried metals like aluminum, and in Italy he tried marble. In Japan he favored basalt and granite (Swedish granite sometimes), partly because for him they, like Japan, evoked nature, the earth, a durable past.

title: Let Vendors Pay for Sidewalk Space; Toughness Gets Results
description: To the Editor:

title: Bulls' Lament: Jordan Looking 3 Breaths Short
description: The teammate he had relied on the most over the years was in the middle of an awful dream, in which the rim shrinks and every shot careens out. John Stockton knew Karl Malone was in trouble, so he whittled his offensive options down to one: himself.

title: Joseph C. Harsch, 93, a Journalist Who Witnessed History
description: Joseph C. Harsch, a dashing newspaper, radio and television journalist and author who had a knack for being on hand when history was made, died on Wednesday at his home in Jamestown, R.I. He was 93.

description: Jane and Louise Wilson

title: Crashing the Computer, Not the Car
description: IT'S not Doom or Flight Simulator, but the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety has concocted a lively computer game for teen-agers called Driver-ZED that shows half a dozen ways to crack up a car, in city, suburban or country driving.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CUFFE, EDWARD W.
description: CUFFE-Edward W. Born February 16, 1936, Fall River, MA. Died June 5, 1996, NYC. He has gone where savage indignation can no longer lacerate his heart. Go traveler, imitate him if you can. He served liberty. Rage on whereever you are. The Ding Ansich Dynasty

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, GERTRUDE
description: LEWIS-Gertrude. The partners and staff of Lipsky, Goodkin & Company, PC, are deeply saddened at the passing of Mrs. Gertrude Lewis, beloved mother of Mrs. Janice Schneider wife of ourvery much respected and esteemed partner and friend Mr. Daniel Schneider, and grandmother of our also esteemed partner and friend, Mr. Ronald Schneider. Cherished, adored and admired mother, grandmother and great grandmother, an exemplary woman of strong character, keen mind, fortitude and determination, she leaves behind a legacy of love and a family of solid and sound foundation. She is deeply mourned and greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire bereaved family. Lipsky, Goodkin and Company, PC.

title: Terry Nichols Gets Life Term In Bombing Plot
description: Calling him ''an enemy of the Constitution,'' a Federal judge sentenced Terry L. Nichols today to life in prison without the possibility of parole for conspiring to bomb the Oklahoma City Federal Building, the deadliest terrorist attack on American soil.

title: So, What's Wrong With This Picture?
description: trumania (troo-MAY-nee-uh) n. 1. obsessive national interest in the surreal ordinariness of Truman Burbank, as spurred by the 30-year television show chronicling his every move. Manifested by a willingness to find the most nondescript of Truman's experiences more poignant and meaningful than one's own. Truman bars, T shirts, baseball caps, greatest hits videotape and sleeping scenes indicate the rare depths of media madness behind this fascination. 2. An imaginary planet, playfully named by Truman Burbank. 3. Euphoric reception afforded to ''The Truman Show'' as an earthshaking millennial event arriving today on movie screens. Peter Weir's must-see new film is guaranteed Oscar bait and delectably clever entertainment, but hosannas and cartwheels are over the top.

title: U.S. Halts Some Military Aid to Bosnia
description: The United States has suspended part of a military aid program for Bosnia because the republic's Muslims and Croats refuse to cooperate on even the most minor issues of joint security, State Department officials said today.

title: Mallalieu Woolfolk, 92, Lawyer And Adviser to Black Officials
description: Mallalieu S. Woolfolk, a lawyer who gave legal and political assistance to prominent black elected officials, including David N. Dinkins, Percy E. Sutton and Charles B. Rangel, died on Saturday at Beth Israel Hospital in Passaic, N.J. He was 92 and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Shuttle Leaves for Ohio; El Duque Stays in Bronx
description: Orlando Hernandez was supposed to be a one-day wonder. Promote him for one night on a big stage, then send him back to Class AAA for more seasoning. But he pitched beautifully Wednesday and impressed George Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner, and now Hernandez may be here to stay.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Two of the best-looking new restaurants in Manhattan are actually old. Each, however, has recently gained a new lease on life.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on May 28 about a concert by the American Composers Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on May 24 misidentified one work, a new composition by Tan Dun, and a correction in this space on Tuesday misidentified the conductor. The work was ''Red Forecast,'' not ''Red Forest''; the conductor was Mr. Tan, not James Levine.

title: NATIONWIDE MUTUAL REACHES $1.7 BILLION DEAL FOR ALLIED
description: Successfully completing negotiations that were disclosed earlier, the Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company has agreed to buy Allied Group Inc. and its affiliates for $1.7 billion. Nationwide, which is owned by policyholders, said it would pay $48.25 a share, or about $1.5 billion, for all of Allied's shares. It also plans to combine with the Allied Mutual Insurance Company -- which owns 18.2 percent of Allied Group's voting rights -- distribute $110 million to Allied policyholders and pay $30 a share, or $84 million, for 2.8 million publicly held shares of the Allied Life Financial Corporation, a unit of Allied Mutual. Nationwide, based in Columbus, Ohio, is the nation's sixth-largest property and casualty insurer. The stock of Allied, which is based in Des Moines, rose 37.5 cents, to $46.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Trade Panel Backs Europe On Tariffs
description: European Union nations can continue to impose tariffs on United States computer-networking equipment exports ahead of a July 1, 2000, deadline for eliminating all such tariffs, a trade arbitration appeals panel said today.

title: An Extension For Brosius?
description: The Yankees have opened preliminary negotiations on a contract extension for Scott Brosius, the third baseman who could become a free agent after this season. The discussions were acknowledged by Brian Cashman, the Yankees' general manager, and the agent for Brosius, Tony Attanasio.

title: Accounts
description: -- Mattel Inc., El Segundo, Calif., to Foote, Cone & Belding, Los Angeles, part of True North Communications, as the first agency to handle advertising for two new assignments from its Disney Entertainment division. One is for Winnie the Pooh and Disney activity toys, and the other is for action figures. Billings were not disclosed.

title: WORLD ACCESS IN $187 MILLION DEAL FOR TELCO SYSTEMS
description: World Access Inc. will acquire Telco Systems Inc. for about $17 a share in stock, or about $187 million. The deal was announced after Telco's shares closed yesterday at $11.21875, up $1.65625. World Access's shares closed at $29.25, down 50 cents. The agreement has been unanimously approved by both boards. The combined company will retain the World Access name. World Access makes wire line and wireless switching, transport and access products used in telecommunications. Telco Systems, based in Norwood, Mass., supplies products and related services to the telecommunications industry and generated revenues of about $120 million during its latest fiscal year.

title: Sports of The Times; Seles Back in Picture With Hingis
description: THE two of them first met nearly a decade before. Nine-year-old Martina Hingis was escorted by her mother to a tennis match in Zurich, where 16-year-old Monica Seles was playing. Hingis was enough of a prodigy herself to have her photograph taken with the older prodigy.

title: Justices Leave Starr With Dilemma in Clinton Inquiry
description: The Supreme Court's refusal today to intervene quickly in the legal fight between Kenneth W. Starr and President Clinton in the independent counsel investigation means that Mr. Starr now faces an unpalatable set of choices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMONTE, JAMES DANIEL
description: LaMONTE-James Daniel. Cherished husband of Fredericka. A man for all seasons, truly will be missed forever. Bell Atlantic 1972-1995. U.S. Navy Veteran WWII. Distinguised Service.

title: Jury Still Deliberating In Death Penalty Case
description: A Brooklyn jury considering the death penalty for a former jail guard who killed three people reached no decision yesterday. The jury spent a second day deliberating the fate of Darrel K. Harris, 40. Mr. Harris was convicted on May 19 of first-degree murder in a 1996 robbery in a Brooklyn social club.

title: Many Women 60 and Older Abuse Alcohol and Prescribed Drugs, Study Says
description: When her husband died, leaving her a widow at the age of 77, Genevieve May started drinking to assuage her grief.

Constantine & Helen Greek Church in West Nyack. Services Saturday, June 6, 9AM, Transfiguration Church, Pearl River. Visiting Friday 5-9 PM, Joe Sorce Funeral Home, West Nyack.

title: The Reply, It Turned Out, Was Bilingual: No
description: English can still be a riddle to 60-year-old Rosario Gomez, even after three decades here in a house with red and yellow roses in the front yard on Chicago Street.

title: LARGEST BURGER KING FRANCHISEE TO BUY POLLO TROPICAL
description: The Carrols Corporation, the largest Burger King franchisee in the United States, said yesterday that it would buy Pollo Tropical Inc. for $90 million in cash as the company adds quick-service chicken restaurants to its burger business. Carrols, a closely held company, will pay $11 each for the shares of Pollo Tropical, which is based in Miami. Pollo Tropical owns 36 restaurants and franchises 19 others. Pollo Tropical shares rose 75 cents, to $10.75.

title: Petersen Acquires Inside Sports Magazine
description: The Petersen Companies has purchased the magazine Inside Sports and plans to merge it with its 51-year-old title Sport magazine, the company announced yesterday. Petersen executives declined to disclose terms.

title: Next Test For Yanks: Winning Minus Jeter
description: A third of the 162-game season is complete, and the Yankees are on a pace to win 123 games after beating Tampa Bay, 6-1, at Yankee Stadium last night. But the Yankees will have to play at least the next two weeks without the star shortstop Derek Jeter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: New Judge Won't Walk in Father's Footsteps
description: AS they stood together on the thick carpet of City Hall for the swearing-in ceremony a few days ago -- the father a legendary retired justice, the son just about to ascend to the bench -- it seemed to be a storybook moment of generational passage. The son recalled the moment 30 years before when his father took the oath, and even talked explicitly about the path of his father's footsteps. The father beamed.

title: An African 'Peter Pan'
description: J. M. Barrie probably never imagined Wendy Darling as American, much less black and living in Brooklyn. But John Byrd and James E. Carter have done just that, and more. Their new musical, ''Forever Mpeta,'' is an inventive retelling of ''Peter Pan,'' with Shelby Simmons, an aspiring young writer, as its heroine, and Mpeta, a boy who has escaped from a slave ship, as the magical character who flies her and her brothers to an enchanted island.

title: Time to Talk in South Asia
description: Now that India and Pakistan have at least temporarily halted their nuclear tests and toned down their rhetoric, there is an opening for diplomacy aimed at freezing further weapons development. A modest step was taken yesterday in Geneva, where Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and the foreign ministers of Russia, China, Britain and France urged India and Pakistan to refrain from further testing and open negotiations with each other. The meeting also called on the two countries to sign the international treaties banning the testing and spread of nuclear weapons.

title: A Demimonde in the Pacific Northwest
description: Bleary, purple-faced, waving a fly swatter and his middle finger, covered with tattoos and accompanied by a mean-tempered dog, a man nicknamed El Duce lumbers over to Nick Broomfield asking, ''Where's the booze?'' They have been introduced by a third party identified as ''Divine Brown's pimp.'' El Duce, whose night job is delivering ugly rants with a rock band (the Mentors) while wearing an executioner's mask, claims to have valuable information about Courtney Love's role in the death of her husband. ''She offered me fifty grand to whack Kurt Cobain,'' he says, talking tougher than he looks. He offers to reveal more about this if Mr. Broomfield will buy him a beer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSE, STEPHEN YUNG NIEN
description: TSE-Stephen Yung Nien. On June 3, 1998 at home in New York City. Devoted son of K.K. and T.Y. Koo. Survived by his wife Margaret Miray Lock, four sisters, four sons Chida, Chiming, Chiyung and Chikai, their wives, and eleven grandchildren. Born in Shanghai, China on February 14, 1931, Stephen started working for C.V. Starr, founder of the American International family of companies, in 1956. He served with great dedication and enterprise with AIG companies in Hong Kong and New York, retiring as President, AIG Associates and Senior Vice President of AIG in 1996. Stephen will be deeply mourned and greatly missed by family and friends. We, the management and employees of AIG companies extend our deepest condolences to Stephen's family. For many years, Steve was a close colleague and friend to many of us. He was a devoted family man and invaluable member of AIG's financial management team. The memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Sunday, June 7 at 4:00 p.m. Stephen's family has suggested that those who wish to remember him may make a donation in his name to Watchtower Bible and Tract Society, Inc., 25 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, NY 11201. M.R. Greenberg, Chairman American International Group, Inc. and the worldwide staff of AIG

title: Tobacco Bill on Edge as Partisan Fight Erupts in Senate
description: A fierce partisan fight broke out in the Senate today on tobacco and income tax legislation that could swamp the anti-smoking bill, one of the biggest and most contentious measures of the year.

title: China Warns Ex-Official To Keep Quiet
description: Two days ago, shortly after finishing years of prison and probation, a former senior Chinese official openly criticized the Government, questioning its slow progress toward democracy and condemning its decision in 1989 to send in soldiers to quell student-led demonstrations in Tiananmen Square. He then challenged the Government -- which has professed its commitment to the rule of law -- to respect his right to speak.

title: House Rejects Drive to Allow Formal Prayer In the Schools
description: For the first time in more than a quarter of a century, the House today debated -- and rejected -- an effort by religious conservatives to amend the Constitution to allow organized prayer in public schools.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Appointment in Schuylkill County
description: For a fleeting moment, you are Julian English and the road is yours, roaring in a sleek Caddie through scenic highways of fact and fiction, past coal-patch taverns and slatty wood houses, gin cocktail parties and country clubs vibrating to the tunes of Tommy Lake's Royal Collegians.

title: Celebrating Day in Their Honor, Firefighters Brawl in Restaurant
description: A celebration of heroism by New York City firefighters degenerated into a bacchanalian brawl at a cafe in Bryant Park Wednesday night as firemen harassed patrons, urinated publicly, exposed themselves, ran through a women's restroom and got into bloody fights with each other and anyone who tried to intervene, outraged city officials acknowledged yesterday.

title: SPARE TIMES: ATTRACTIONS
description: Museums and Sites

title: Signs of Shift in Senate Stance on Bank Law
description: In all the cheerleading about legislation to rewrite the nation's banking laws, one of the loudest voices belongs to Merrill Lynch & Company, which, each week, takes out a back-page ad in the Washington political journal The Hill, a must read for the Capitol Hill crowd.

title: Accused Nazi Guard Has Sympathy Of Ukrainian Immigrant Neighbors
description: In this tiny hamlet in the far reaches of Sullivan County, where about a quarter of the residents are elderly Ukrainians, the few people who knew Dmytro Sawczuk were more sympathetic than alarmed about the news that the Federal Government had moved to revoke his citizenship because he apparently lied about his Nazi past when he immigrated to this country 50 years ago.

title: Trautwig Offers a Textbook Lesson in the Art of the Interview
description: Conducting a decent post-game interview is not that difficult, if you watch the game, show the curiosity to prepare questions that can produce illuminating answers and think reasonably well on your feet.

title: Yiddish Paper Handles Loss As a Survivor
description: SAMUEL NORICH, publisher of the Yiddish-language version of The Forward, managed both a smile and the faintest wisp of a sigh when asked how things were going. ''It's been more interesting here than is absolutely necessary,'' he said.

title: Capitals Take a Giant Step into the Finals
description: A few hours before the Washington Capitals defeated the Buffalo Sabres in overtime to qualify for the Stanley Cup finals, Coach Ron Wilson spoke to his players about the moon.

title: Steinbrenner Warns Vallone to Drop Bid For a Stadium Vote
description: Opening a new front in the political battle over the future of Yankee Stadium, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, all but threatened last night to leave New York City unless Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, abandoned his push for a referendum on whether city money should be used to help build a new ball park.

title: CABLE MICHIGAN AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED BY AVALON CABLE
description: The cable operator Cable Michigan Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired by Avalon Cable of New England for $40.50 a share, or $435 million. Cable Michigan, which was spun off from the C-Tec Corporation last fall, is based in Princeton, N.J. It serves more than 210,000 subscribers in four Michigan cities. Avalon Cable is backed by Boston's ABRY Partners Inc., a private equity fund. Under the agreement, Avalon authorized Cable Michigan to acquire the 38 percent interest in Mercom Inc., a cable television provider in southern Michigan, that it does not already own for about $19.6 million. Cable Michigan's shares rose $3.1875, or 9 percent, to $38.4375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: In Children's Book, Giuliani Puts Smiles on Cabbies and Vendors
description: Cabbies, street vendors and jaywalkers. These may not sound like a few of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's favorite things, but they all wear big grins in a new picture book written and published for the Mayor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERKA, HARRYETTA
description: PETERKA-Harryetta. The American Academy of Dramatic Arts announces with sorrow the tragic passing of Harryetta Peterka, Director of Instruction, on Tuesday, June 2. Herself a graduate of the Academy, she was a recipient of the Jehlinger Award in 1958, the highest honor bestowed upon an Academy student. She toured as a member of the school's post-graduate performance ensemble, the Academy Repertory Company, in the 1958-59 season, playing Abigail in ''The Crucible,'' and Elizabeth I in ''Young Elizabeth.'' She began teaching at the Academy in 1964 while still acting professionally, eventually becoming Director of the Evening School, and Associate Director of the Professional Training Program, prior to being named Director of Instruction in 1992. She is survived by her beloved husband, William Damon. To her students and colleagues, Harryetta was a unique and powerful force, a friend, mentor and guiding light. Her dedication to the theatre and to all the students who pursued a life in the theatre was without limit. Her love of the craft of acting forced her to continue to educate herself and those around her, and her love and concern for her students carried on beyond their enrollment at the Academy. She will be missed, but never forgotten, and she will live on in the hearts of those whose lives she touched. A memorial service will be held in the near future.

Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: Speaking critically of cutbacks in social programs, Allen Lee Sessoms, the president of Queens College, urged about 3,800 graduates of the institution at its 74th commencement yesterday to ''use your advantage to change things for the better.''
