description: BONGIOVANNI-Raymond 5, June 1996 What's the frequency, Raymond?

title: Analysts and Denial on Wall Street
description: Talk about denial. Even as more and more corporate managers warned that their second-quarter results were looking grim, investors piled into the stock market. And they piled most heavily into those companies most vulnerable to near-term earnings disappointments -- the technology group.

title: Looking Glass Reflected A Shy Victorian Don
description: Could the mathematician who in 1867 published ''An Elementary Treatise on Determinants With Their Application to Simultaneous Linear Equations and Algebraical Geometry'' also be the author of ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland''? To be sure. His real name was Charles Lutwidge Dodgson (1832-1898), and under it he functioned as an Oxford don who taught math, a cleric, a poet, a pamphleteer, a deviser of games and puzzles, an ardent theatergoer and a gifted amateur photographer. But the pseudonym Lewis Carroll, a Latinization of Charles Lutwidge in reverse order, is the name that belongs to his most brilliant achievement, the ''Alice'' stories.

title: Maryland Troopers Stop Drivers by Race, Suit Says
description: A civil rights group and 11 black motorists filed a class-action lawsuit in Federal court here today charging that the Maryland state police used race as a factor in stopping and searching drivers along Interstate 95.

title: Let Vendors Pay for Sidewalk Space; Make More Room
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Government crash tests involving several types of vehicles misstated the predicted result when a Ford Explorer, a mid-size sport utility vehicle, hits a car from the side. The two-wheel-drive version of the Explorer, which was part of the test, is less likely to ride over the car -- not more likely -- than the four-wheel-drive version is.

title: When Excess Was the Rule In Venice
description: Many guests were caught off guard at the recent opening of the Chinese Porcelain Company's exhibition of Venetian glass, which continues through June 20 at its gallery at Park Avenue and 58th Street. Interior designers like Albert Hadley were hoping to find the sleek modern vases that Venini, Barovier and other Venetian companies began to produce in the 1930's. Such wares, designed by Carlo Scarpa, Gio Ponti and other renowned 20th-century Italian architects, are now hotter than the Portofino sun.

title: In Pursuit of Love, Romantically or Not
description: In the 1970's San Francisco of ''Armistead Maupin's 'More Tales of the City,' '' the characters may be homosexual, heterosexual or transsexual, but they are all hopeless romantics. In the brash new comedy series ''Sex and the City,'' the heroine cultivates an anti-romantic pose that suits Manhattan in the 90's, with its post-politically correct attitudes. ''I'm a sexual anthropologist,'' says Carrie (Sarah Jessica Parker), a newspaper columnist who writes: ''Welcome to the age of uninnocence. No one has breakfast at Tiffany's and no one has affairs to remember. Instead we have breakfast at 7 A.M. and affairs we try to forget as soon as possible.'' Though one is gauzy and the other hard-edged, both these shows alight on a particular patch of ground where their characters roam through a hyperrealistic landscape searching for the meaning of love.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Paint and Passion'

title: Foreign Banks to Allow Indonesia More Time to Repay $80 Billion in Debts
description: Indonesia and a group of foreign bankers agreed today on a framework for rescheduling the repayment of nearly $80 billion in corporate and bank debt, which constituted one of the biggest barriers to restarting the economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSTON, SYD (SARAH SCHATTMAN
description: WINSTON-Syd (Sarah Schattman), at age 97 in Palm Beach, FL. Mother of Arthur and Richard. Grandmother of Kenneth, Peter, Perry, Donald, Elizabeth, Jennifer and James. Services Friday, 10 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 No. Station Plaza (opp. LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: A Test for Charlton Heston
description: The National Rifle Association opens its annual convention today in Philadelphia in a nation where parents worry about bullets in the schoolyard and about the easy access that disturbed children have to loaded guns. But it is impossible to discern a glimmer of civic or parental concern in the N.R.A.'s official program for the gathering.

title: Stern Talks Lockout, Questions Patriotism
description: David Stern stopped short of calling them unpatriotic, but he did question the wisdom of players who are considering boycotting this summer's world championships in Athens.

title: Novus of Australia Gets Samsung's Egypt Stake
description: Novus Petroleum Ltd. of Australia has bought a $40 million stake in five Egyptian oil and gas properties in a debt-induced fire sale by a South Korean consortium, led by the Samsung Corporation. In a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange, Novus said the acquisition included existing joint oil and gas production, oil and gas fields under development, a major gas trunkline under construction and exploration acreage.

title: Patients' Rights Bill Restores Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: At a Harvard Rite, Solace for Seniors
description: With all the pomp and pomposity at Harvard's 362d commencement today, there came one oasis-like moment of reassurance, both divine and earthly, for young souls queasy with fear at the thought of exiting the Yard and entering the world.

title: Catalogue of Sorrow: Belongings of Flight 800 Victims
description: If it is possible to catalogue heartbreak, then the workers at the hangar in Calverton, N.Y., where the ruins of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 are stored, have done it. It takes the form of a blue plastic three-ring binder, with 200 pages of color photos of personal belongings, from cameras to underwear to hair dryers, anything that 230 people could bring aboard a Boeing 747 for a long trip abroad, and that a diver could then bring up from the bottom of the Atlantic.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about May automotive sales misstated some percentage changes. The figures were correct in the table with the article: General Motors truck sales rose 20.1 percent, not 19.2; Ford car sales fell 5.2 percent, not 5.5, and Ford truck sales rose 8.6 percent, not 6.2.

title: Saluting the Dingell-Maloney Switch
description: One of the most frustrating roadblocks to campaign finance reform has been the inability of Congressional supporters to unite behind a single coherent strategy. Yesterday Democratic legislators eliminated a roadblock to reform by announcing that they would not vote for a toothless commission that could have displaced serious reform.

title: New Video Releases
description: The End of Violence

title: Germans Find Possible Crash Links and Inspect 60 Trains
description: One day after Germany's worst rail crash in more than 50 years, authorities pulled scores of express trains out of service today after the discovery of a broken wheel and track damage possibly linked to the disaster.

title: House Leaders Act to Avert Split as Budget Is Debated
description: House Republican leaders scrambled today to avert a crippling split in their ranks over their budget plan for next year, seeking to mollify both conservatives who are demanding big tax cuts and moderates wary of a bitterly partisan election-year fight over deep spending cuts.

title: Left Their Art In San Francisco
description: Even before the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art's $63 million building was completed three years ago, the trustees had been determined to fill it with world-class art, the kind that is not only hard to find but hugely expensive. And over the last few years, they have consistently bought works in ever larger numbers, at auction, from dealers or directly from artists.

title: Czech Rider Wins A Race in Trenton
description: The course was so flat and the speeds so high in yesterday's First Union Classic in Trenton, that none of the 153 cyclists from 15 nations could break away for too long. So the 90-mile race -- 12 laps of 7.5 miles each -- ended in a field sprint at perhaps 45 miles an hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOYLER, FREEMAN W. JR
description: MOYLER-Freeman W. Jr. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Freeman W. Moyler Jr., associated with The Times from February 10, 1950, until retiring on June 1, 1994.

title: Spectrum of Interpretations In Three 'Sleeping Beauties'
description: ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' set to one of Tchaikovsky's most sumptuous scores, is a standard against which performers may be measured. It is also a ballet that is capable of a surprising number of interpretations, as American Ballet Theater suggested in well-danced performances on Monday night and Wednesday afternoon and evening at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: City Fights Delay in Sex Shop Restrictions
description: Lawyers for the city filed papers with a Federal appeals court yesterday asking that New York be allowed to immediately enforce three-year-old zoning laws intended to weed out and isolate sex businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JABARA, DELORES DIANA
description: JABARA-Delores Diana, of Westport, CT. Beloved daughter of the late Saleem and Olga Jabara. Precious sister of Claudette Jabara Hadad and the late Paul Jabara. Loving aunt to Suzanne Hadad and Henry and Lara Hadad and their children, Christopher Paul and Henry Robert. Funeral services today, 10 AM, at St. Mary's Church in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

title: U.N. Arms Experts Brief Security Council on Iraqi Compliance
description: Four months after Secretary General Kofi Annan stepped in and took charge of a crisis with Iraq, the initiative in dealing with the Government of President Saddam Hussein moved back this week to the Security Council and the commission charged with destroying Iraq's prohibited weapons.

title: Broadway gets its own platinum card as theaters try a unified approach to mass marketing.
description: ALTHOUGH the current Broadway season formally ends with the Tony Awards on Sunday evening, the theater industry's efforts to market itself will actually be stepped up immediately afterward, with the debut next week of a ''Live Broadway'' platinum Visa credit card.

title: At Pataki's Nomination Party, Giuliani Rebuilds Bridges He Burned
description: State Republican leaders coalesced behind the re-election campaign of Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday, offering a display of unity highlighted by an effusive public tribute by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to two of his most famous rivals: Mr. Pataki and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Brawley Trial Plaintiff Says Adviser Never Questioned Him in 1987
description: Though Alton H. Maddox Jr. publicly accused a young prosecutor of raping and kidnapping Tawana Brawley late in 1987, he never asked his suspect, Steven A. Pagones, a single question 10 years ago when Mr. Pagones was in court ready to testify under oath.

title: Refugees From Kosovo Cite A Bitter Choice: Flee or Die
description: President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has unleashed the largest military operation in the Balkans since the end of the war in Bosnia, driving thousands of ethnic Albanians from the border area with Albania and reducing their villages to rubble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, EDWARD J.
description: HALL-Edward J. The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at State University of New York-Health Sicence Center at Brooklyn was very saddened to hear about the death of Dr. J. Edward Hall. Dr. Hall was an active member of the faculty in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology for 19 years during the period 1952-1971. Dr. Hall was appointed to the faculty in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology as a Clinical Assistant Professor in 1952, he was promoted to the level of an Associate Professor in 1954 and as a Professor in 1962. Dr. Hall served as Chief of Service at King's County Hospital Center during the period 1969-1970. He was appointed an Emeritus Professor in 1971. Dr. Hall made enormous contributions to the field of obstetrics and gynecology on a national and international level. He was an excellent teacher to the medical students and residents in the department. The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at State University of New York-Health Science Center at Brooklyn and King's County Hospital Center extends its deepest sympathy to the family.

title: Perfect Plan: Kill My Wife. Please.
description: You don't have to believe a word of the strained dialogue in ''A Perfect Murder'' to be seduced by the movie's chilly high-gloss ambiance and its skillfully plotted update of Frederick Knott's play (and Alfred Hitchcock's film) ''Dial M For Murder.''

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Television; Sundance Offers a Weekly Festival
description: The photographer William Wegman dresses up his Weimaraners in summer camp clothes and sends them out to solve a mystery, Hardy Boys style, in the funny parody ''The Hardley Boys in Hardley Gold.'' (''Hardly boys, they were girls and dogs,'' Mr. Wegman says in his deadpan narrative.) That half-hour film is one of the quirky treats appearing this Sunday when the Sundance Channel finally arrives in Manhattan in a big way. Devoted to independent film, the Sundance Channel (a spinoff of Robert Redford's Sundance Institute and Film Festival) will be available on Time Warner Cable on a daylong pay-per-view basis every Sunday, beginning with a free preview this week.

title: Patients' Rights Bill Restores Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: In Therapy, As a Front For Snooping
description: Noah Baumbach has described his second film, ''Mr. Jealousy'' (after the bright, witty ''Kicking and Screaming''), with reference to the directorial pantheon, invoking filmmakers from Billy Wilder to Francois Truffaut to Ernst Lubitsch as inspirations for his own comic style. Without knowing that, it would be easier to cite the two most imitated contemporary influences on independent comedies, Woody Allen and ''Seinfeld'' (in that order). Articulate, self-defeating romantics who discuss their troubles at coffee shops are again on the loose, this time in the story of Lester Grimm (Eric Stoltz) and his wild possessiveness about his girlfriend, Ramona Ray (Annabella Sciorra). Since Ramona is the sort to explain she's been home having a shampoo when her unwashed hair looks suspiciously tousled, Lester has his hands full.

title: ARMSTRONG WORLD SEEKS GERMAN FLOORING CONCERN
description: Armstrong World Industries said yesterday that it would make a $275 million tender offer for all the outstanding stock of the German flooring maker DLW A.G. Armstrong said that it would also assume about $55 million of DLW's debt. Armstrong said the offer had been approved by DLW's board as well as by two of the company's key shareholders: Allianz Holding A.G. and Baden-Wuerttembergische Bank A.G. The two companies own 23.4 percent of DLW's stock. Armstrong makes floors, ceilings and other home products.

title: Let U.S. Companies Use Chinese Rockets; Not NASA's Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: RENO LIFTS BARRIER TO OREGON'S LAW ON AIDED SUICIDE
description: Attorney General Janet Reno today removed the last legal obstacle to the full operation of Oregon's landmark assisted-suicide law, declaring that doctors who used the law to prescribe lethal drugs to terminally ill patients would not be prosecuted.

title: Tutu Asks Botha to Give An Apology, But in Vain
description: There were times during Archbishop Desmond Tutu's two days of testimony, which ended today, when the head of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission looked weary, and times when he seemed unable to hold back sarcasm.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEORGE, SALLY
description: GEORGE-Sally. 31 May 1991. Missing you as ever. Wishing you were still on earth, and not only in my heart and soul. You were one of a kind-and simply, the Best. Love, Catherine

title: Let U.S. Companies Use Chinese Rockets; Space Station Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GUTENBERG, LARRY
description: GUTENBERG-Larry. March 5, 1949-June 6, 1995. Larry will always be remembered and honored for his fight against racism, homophobia and AIDS. Jose Anselmi & Bernie Durham

title: Sensing a Defeat
description: If a referendum is held in November on whether city money should be used for a new ball park for the Yankees, it wouldn't be hard to imagine the motifs opponents would use in their campaign commercials attacking the project: a tormentingly long traffic jam, backed by a soundtrack of car horns and coughs. A procession of public schools disfigured by age and neglect. Or perhaps an unflattering picture of George M. Steinbrenner 3d, with dollar signs cavorting around him.

title: Toll Reaches 96 as Hunt for German Crash Victims Nears End
description: With rescue efforts virtually ended after Germany's worst rail crash in more than 50 years, officials said today that the death toll stood at 96.

title: Corrections
description: The American Stock Exchange table in Business Day yesterday misstated the change in the shares of the Balchem Corporation on Thursday. The stock rose 37.5 cents, after a 3-for-2 stock split; it did not fall $12.75.

title: A Nice New York, or Indianapolis on the Hudson?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethnic Albanians Leave Northern Europe To Fight in Anti-Serb Rebellion in Kosovo
description: The rusted hulk of a ferry, its bilge pumps spewing water into the emerald green Drinit River and its diesel engine rattling, has become for hundreds of young men the last leg on a journey to war.

title: Oops. Bob Hope Is Not Dead.
description: When Representative Bob Stump announced the death of Bob Hope today, he felt a sense of personal loss. Mr. Stump, an Arizona Republican, was a homesick teen-ager in the Pacific in World War II when the comedian lifted his spirits with his stand-up routine.

title: Setting the Value Of Wall St. History; If Goldman, Sachs Goes Public, How Will It Divide the Spoils?
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company has taken so many companies to market, putting its prized imprint on the value of thousands of public offerings of shares.

title: National News Briefs; Youth Sentenced to Life In Killing of His Mother
description: A jury made up predominately of mothers today found Luke Woodham, the teen-ager accused of killing two classmates and wounding seven others at Pearl High School last October, guilty of stabbing his mother to death with a butcher knife.

title: A Bush-League Brushback Pitch
description: The Yankees owner George Steinbrenner virtually threatened to move his team out of New York City this week, but his intemperate words must not be allowed to chill a robust public debate about whether and where to build new baseball stadiums and how to finance them. ''I do not want to move the Yankees from New York, but I must warn: He is bringing us dangerously close,'' Mr. Steinbrenner said in a formal statement.

title: A Darker Picture of Firefighters' Brawl
description: A drunken brawl among New York City firefighters at a Bryant Park cafe Wednesday night was more extensive and brutal than first reported, senior law enforcement officials said yesterday. But they acknowledged that it was unlikely that any of the participants would face criminal charges unless the brawlers filed complaints against one another.

title: Ted Dunbar Is Dead; Jazz Guitarist, 61
description: Ted Dunbar, a jazz guitarist who performed with some of the leading musicians of his day, died on May 29 at a hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 61 and lived in Kendall Park, N.J.

title: Foster Care for Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: Vivendi Sells Its Stake In Electrafina of Belgium
description: Vivendi S.A., the French municipal services, media and telecommunications conglomerate, said yesterday that it had sold its 24.6 percent stake in Electrafina S.A. of Belgium, an energy and communications company, to Groupe Bruxelles Lambert for 7.1 billion French francs, or $1.2 billion.

title: Cold and Definite, a Band's Attributes
description: When the M Base movement in jazz came into being in the mid-1980's, it organized several strains of jazz rhetoric into a point of view that wasn't always backed up musically. But the early members -- the saxophonists Steve Coleman and Greg Osby, the pianist Geri Allen, the trombonist Robin Eubanks, the cornetist Graham Haynes and the singer Cassandra Wilson -- worked on a communal sound that was easily identifiable, mixing textures and jazz improvisation. And often idiosyncratic improvisation: Mr. Coleman and Mr. Osby came up with a distinct school of soloing, jagged and abstract and virtuosic, that hadn't been heard before.

title: Belmont Is the Stage for Real Quiet's Quest
description: For the second year in a row, the racing world presents its ultimate drama at Belmont Park: Real Quiet, an ugly duckling foaled with crooked legs who was sold for only $17,000 as a yearling, races 12 rivals today in a bid to win the Belmont Stakes and complete his Triple Crown.

title: A Big Night of Fights Suffers a Knockout
description: The night of fights at Madison Square Garden, once one of boxing's glamorous stages, had been advertised as D-Day, a mix of bouts that included Evander Holyfield, a heavyweight champion; Roberto Duran, an aging legend, and Christy Martin, the boxing world's top-ranked woman.

title: Foreign Affairs; Mr. Toad's Last Ride
description: In 1989 in Canterbury, England, the world's leading experts on frogs and other amphibians gathered for their first ever world congress. In the lobby, in the bar and in chance encounters in the hall, the experts swapped frog stories. At some point they realized that they were all seeing the same problem: Their frogs and toads were dying -- not just in disturbed habitats, but in the most pristine nature preserves -- from brown toads in Yosemite National Park to golden toads in Costa Rica.

title: Cuts Are Urged In Internet Fund Clinton Praises
description: While President Clinton was speaking enthusiastically yesterday in favor of a program to help schools and libraries connect to the Internet, the Federal Communications Commission, under pressure from Congress, was preparing to scale back the program, officials close to the commission and to Congress said yesterday.

title: BAY VIEW CAPITAL IS PLANNING AN EXPANSION
description: The Bay View Capital Corporation is in talks to acquire a nonbanking concern, the company said yesterday in a statement. The bank, based in San Mateo, Calif., which had about $5.3 billion in assets as of March 31, said it was not in discussions to sell itself. Bay View, which has a market capitalization of about $653 million, said it made the announcement in response to ''increased market activity.'' Bay View's stock fell $1.625, to $32.25, in trading of 1.8 million shares. The stock jumped as high as $37.50 yesterday before the company made the announcement.

title: Radar Images Of Clinton's Jet Fall Off Screen
description: Radar images of Air Force One flickered mysteriously twice this morning, and according to air traffic controllers, vanished entirely from radar screens as the plane flew over New Jersey. It was the second time this year that the Presidential jet has trailed off the same radar system.

title: Speaking the Unspeakable (No Blushing Is Required)
description: In corporate conference rooms, in dentists' chairs and over dinner, the continuing news about both Viagra and Monica Lewinsky appears to have accelerated a change in the way many Americans speak about a subject that some would prefer be barely spoken about at all.

title: Kings Point Senior Is Sailor of the Year
description: The college sailing season ended officially yesterday with the announcement that Bill Hardesty of San Diego was named the Ronstan college sailor of the year. The annual award is conferred by the Inter-Collegiate Yacht Racing Association of North America. Hardesty is a senior at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at King's Point, N.Y.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Shares Roar Back on New Data; Dow Advances 167.15
description: Stocks roared back to life yesterday after the Government said that economic growth remained robust.

title: Royals-Angels Brawls Result in 11 Suspensions
description: Measured by the suspensions that Gene Budig, the American League president, issued to members of the Anaheim Angels and the Kansas City Royals yesterday, last month's brawl between the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles was only a preliminary. Budig suspended managers Terry Collins of the Angels and Tony Muser of the Royals for eight games each and nine players for one to four games for their roles in a game filled with beanballs and fights on Tuesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, BENJAMIN
description: ALPERT-Benjamin of New York City, June 4. Husband of Rose (Wilfand). Father of Gordon and Robert Alpert. Father-in-law of Judith Alpert and Marcia Eisenberg all of NYC. Brother of Warren Alpert of NYC and Pearl Starr Newton, MA. Grandfather of four. Services were held Friday in Boston.

title: Investment Banks Set In Indonesia Privatizing
description: The Indonesian Government named seven investment banks yesterday to advise it on the reorganization and privatization of 12 state-owned companies, with Goldman, Sachs & Company and Lehman Brothers Inc. appointed overall advisers to the program. The sale of the 12 companies, five of which have already been partly privatized, is expected to raise more than $2.5 billion for the Government and to generate $50 million to $100 million in fees for the investment banks.

title: AGREEMENT IS SET ON CLASS-ACTION LITIGATION
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to settle pending shareholder securities class-action litigation against it and several former officers. Philip Morris said that under the proposed settlement, it would establish a $105 million fund for the benefit of the class, which includes people who bought its common shares from June 11, 1991, through May 6, 1994. The fund will also cover any lawyers' fees and other expenses ordered by the court. Philip Morris said it had agreed to settle the Kurzweil suit, first brought in April 1994, to halt the expense, inconvenience and distraction of continued litigation.

title: A Degree of Better Late Than Never, Defined by an Octogenarian
description: Joseph DiFede hunched over a desk in his spartan chambers at State Supreme Court in the Bronx and began mulling over why, at this stage of his life, he decided to become a candidate for a master's degree in history at the University of Rochester. He is 89.

title: NO MORE JOB CUTS EXPECTED BY MOTOROLA CHIEF
description: The chief executive of Motorola Inc., Charles Galvin, said yesterday that the company did not expect, at this time, any additional job cuts beyond its announced plans to eliminate 15,000 positions in the next year. After the close of the stock market on Thursday, Motorola reported that it planned a major reorganization and series of job cuts. The company expects to record a $1.95 billion charge to its second-quarter earnings for the restructuring. Mr. Galvin said that the semiconductor industry is expected to shrink by 2 percent this year, a sharp contrast to predictions of 17 percent growth at the beginning of the year. But he believes the company will overcome these problems and accomplish cost savings to counteract the decline.

title: Civilians Suffer in Latin Drug War
description: To the Editor:

title: Off to Worlds Old and New, On Line
description: Last month the New York Public Library started up its Digital Library Collections Web site (http://www.digital.nypl.org).

title: Tempers Flare Among Jurors Pondering Execution
description: Two jurors nearly came to blows yesterday as a Brooklyn jury was unable for a third day to decide whether a former jail guard should be sentenced to death for killing three people, a court officer told the judge.

title: Civilians Suffer in Latin Drug War; Police Need Help
description: To the Editor:

title: House Approves Budget With Deeper Cuts In Spending and Taxes Than in 1997 Deal
description: The House narrowly approved a plan today to cut taxes and spending far more deeply than last year's bipartisan balanced budget deal. The move put Republicans on another ideological collision course with the White House over the size and role of the Federal Government.

title: Save the Vendors, Change the System
description: The hot dog is under attack. That icon of New York, the sidewalk frank, is being threatened with extinction, along with its relatives, the knish, souvlaki and $5 sunglasses.

title: Pataki, in a Sharp Rebuke, Criticizes 'Secret' Lilco Bonuses
description: Gov. George E. Pataki accused the Long Island Lighting Company's directors today of ''robbing their shareholders'' of $67 million by paying ''secret'' bonuses to executives, including $42 million to the chairman, Dr. William J. Catacosinos.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Wednesday about Princeton University's commencement misspelled the surnames of the university president and of an honorary degree recipient. The president is Harold T. Shapiro, not Sharpiro; the recipient is John Wilder Tukey, not Turkey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPMAN, ROBERTA
description: LIPMAN-Roberta. Loving and missing you always. You are in our hearts and minds continuously. Sandy, Donna, Larry and Beth.

title: Former Korean Dissident Returns to Land of Exile as Head of State
description: Fourteen years ago, Kim Dae Jung was a pro-democracy activist living in exile in Washington, struggling with his English and with American officials who saw him as a pest.

title: State to Limit Coverage Of Viagra Prescriptions
description: Concerned that the popularity of Viagra has increased the cost of Medicaid and other publicly funded prescription plans, the state has announced that it would limit its coverage of the anti-impotence drug to four tablets per month.

title: Foster Care for Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, EVA
description: LEVINE-Eva. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICATA, ANTHONY D.
description: LICATA-Anthony D. June 5, 1998, of Middleboro Mass., formerly of Brooklyn, NY, aged 73 yrs. Father of Damien T. Licata of Troy, N.H and Kathryn A. Black of Middleboro. Funeral from the Ashley Funeral Home, 35 Oak St. Middleboro on Mon at 8:15 A.M. followed by a Mass of Christian Burial in Sacred Heart Church, 340 Centre St., Middleboro at 9 A.M. Visiting hours Sun 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. Burial in Mass National Cemetery, Bourne. Army Air Corp, WW II veteran.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENECK, CARMINE
description: FENECK-Carmine. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Carmine Feneck, associated with The Times since May 1, 1959.

title: A Return to the Old Ball Game; Minor Leagues Capitalize on Nostalgia for Sport as It Was
description: They filled the brand new Yogi Berra Stadium tonight to watch a team that did not exist until this year and that plays in a league few have even heard of.

title: The Ultimate College Reunion
description: My college reunion was different from yours.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN AT NEARLY 1-YEAR LOW. Corn fell 1.1 percent after Southern rains eased fear that a prolonged heat wave would spread to the Midwest. July contracts fell 2.75 cents, to $2.37 a bushel, the lowest since July 11, 1997.

title: The Marlins Help Pettitte Rediscover His Stuff
description: Andy Pettitte is his own harshest critic, often berating himself with the gusto of a Bob Knight or Mike Ditka. So Pettitte's manager and pitching coach took it upon themselves to counterbalance Pettitte's negativism. Your stuff is great, they told him, in so many words. Trust yourself. You're a heck of a pitcher.

title: T.C.U. Sets Record In Men's 400 Relay
description: Texas Christian set a collegiate record for the men's 400-meter relay at the National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships yesterday in Buffalo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSE, STEPHEN YUNG NIEN
description: TSE-Stephen Yung Nien. On June 3, 1998 at home in New York City. Devoted son of K.K. and T.Y. Koo. Survived by his wife Margaret Miray Lock, four sisters, four sons Chida, Chiming, Chiyung and Chikai, their wives, and eleven grandchildren. Born in Shanghai, China on February 14, 1931, Stephen started working for C.V. Starr, founder of the American International family of companies, in 1956. He served with great dedication and enterprise with AIG companies in Hong Kong and New York, retiring as President, AIG Associates and Senior Vice President of AIG in 1996. Stephen will be deeply mourned and greatly missed by family and friends. We, the management and employees of AIG companies extend our deepest condolences to Stephen's family. For many years, Steve was a close colleague and friend to many of us. He was a devoted family man and invaluable member of AIG's financial management team. The memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Sunday, June 7 at 4:00 p.m. Stephen's family has suggested that those who wish to remember him may make a donation in his name to Watchtower Bible and Tract Society, Inc., 25 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, NY 11201. M.R. Greenberg, Chairman American International Group, Inc. and the worldwide staff of AIG

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWY, GERHARD
description: LOWY-Gerhard. Of New York. On June 5, 1998. Cherished husband of Irma, devoted father of Frank and Ruth, grandfather of Alexander, Andrew and Evan. Contributions to the New York Public Library.

title: An Emotional Buffing of a Legend
description: The career of Robert F. Kennedy was made for legend: the youthful privilege giving way to early sorrow, the transformation from bare-knuckled political operative to compassionate spokesman for the underdog, the life cut short as its climax seemed within reach. Tomorrow's three-hour memoir, which arrives just after the 30th anniversary of his assassination, taps the affections of those who knew him well and can only burnish the image.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SPECIALIZED PACKAGING INTERNATIONAL,

title: A Shantytown Near Hoboken Is Razed
description: Hidden in the wooded bluffs overlooking the Hoboken railroad tracks, at least a dozen homeless people have built makeshift shacks in recent years using scraps of wood and and corrugated tin, tree branches, plastic tarpaulin and other junk. But on Thursday morning, a crew from the city's Department of Public Works, assisted by the police, took axes and a buzz saw and razed the shacks.

title: With Plea Bargain, Man Avoids a Capital Trial
description: Avoiding what would have been the first Federal death penalty trial in Manhattan in more than four decades, a Connecticut man made a plea bargain in Federal District Court yesterday, admitting that he had burned his fiancee to death while she was locked in the trunk of his car, prosecutors said.

title: Schoolboy Is Accused Of Threatening Teacher
description: In the latest gun-related incident in the public schools, the police in New Providence discovered a shotgun under the bed of a 15-year-old boy accused of threatening his English teacher after she gave him an assignment he did not like.

title: Auto Makers Find Faults In Crash Tests
description: American, European and Japanese auto makers said at a conference here today that increasingly high-speed Government and insurance industry crash tests were forcing engineers to design sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and large cars that pose extra dangers to other motorists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAHN, FRED
description: ZAHN-Fred. Of Hewlett, on June 4, 1998. Loving husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Gary, David and Linda Janice. Grandfather of five grandsons. Son-in-law of Ceil Weber. Brother of Jack, Len and Irwin. In place of flowers please send donations to the Justin Zahn Memorial Fund or the Liver Transplant Association. Graveside services. We know your lessons are prepared for the ''Schoolroom in the Sky.''

title: U.S. Team Sets Up Camp in Wine Country
description: The United States soccer team arrived in the heart of the Beaujolais wine region today, setting up camp for the World Cup in a 14th to 17th century chateau that has been fitted with air-conditioning but still relies on roosters for alarm clocks.

title: Osgood Is Good Enough To Take Wings to Finals
description: Chris Osgood's goaltending tonight helped the Detroit Red Wings beat the Dallas Stars, 2-0, and eliminate the Western Conference regular-season champions in six grueling games. But his public demeanor afterward reflected little of the joy that might have been expected for a player on a team returning to the Stanley Cup finals to defend its title, this time against the Washington Capitals starting here Tuesday.

title: CRAWFORD GETS ALL OF UNIT FOR ABOUT $36.1 MILLION
description: Crawford & Company. said yesterday that it had acquired the stake in Crawford-THG that it did not already own for about $36.1 million in stock. Crawford, a provider of risk and claims management services, said it had exchanged 1.9 million shares of its class A common stock for a 40 percent stake in Crawford-THG from Swiss Reinsurance Group, a reinsurance provider. Crawford-THG, a wholly owned subsidiary of Crawford, provides the company's services outside the United States. Crawford, based in Atlanta, had 1997 revenues of $692.3 million.

title: League Work Done, Green Now Has More Time to Play
description: America's bridge players owe a debt of gratitude to a quiet man who retired last week. He is Roy Green, who in five and a half years as head of the American Contract Bridge League greatly increased the organization's net worth, to $4 million from $1.5 million. His successful initiatives include the Bridge Hall of Fame and an expansion of the league's library.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRANIS, ELI
description: KRANIS-Eli. Beloved husband of Mary. Devoted father of Jay Kranis and Ronnie Kranis, father-inlaw of JoAnn. Loving grandfather of Andrew, Jordan and Elizabeth. Services 10:45 AM, Sunday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Memorial contributions may be made to Boca Raton Cancer Research, c/o Ruth Hoffman, Guildford A, Boca Raton, FL 33434.

title: U.S., in Shift, Drops Its Effort to Manage Internet Addresses
description: The Clinton Administration renounced the last vestige of control by the United States Government over the Internet's basic structure yesterday, acknowledging that the computer network had grown too big, too global and too commercial to be overseen by any one nation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Rally Sharply On Vibrant Economy News

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERKA, HARRYETTA
description: PETERKA-Harryetta. The American Academy of Dramatic Arts announces with sorrow the tragic passing of Harryetta Peterka, Director of Instruction, on Tuesday, June 2. Herself a graduate of the Academy, she was a recipient of the Jehlinger Award in 1958, the highest honor bestowed upon an Academy student. She toured as a member of the school's post-graduate performance ensemble, the Academy Repertory Company, in the 1958-59 season, playing Abigail in ''The Crucible,'' and Elizabeth I in ''Young Elizabeth.'' She began teaching at the Academy in 1964 while still acting professionally, eventually becoming Director of the Evening School, and Associate Director of the Professional Training Program, prior to being named Director of Instruction in 1992. She is survived by her beloved husband, William Damon. To her students and colleagues, Harryetta was a unique and powerful force, a friend, mentor and guiding light. Her dedication to the theatre and to all the students who pursued a life in the theatre was without limit. Her love of the craft of acting forced her to continue to educate herself and those around her, and her love and concern for her students carried on beyond their enrollment at the Academy. She will be missed, but never forgotten, and she will live on in the hearts of those whose lives she touched. A memorial service will be held in the near future.

title: New Reports Conflict on Security Breach
description: Top intelligence and security officials in the Clinton Administration are divided over whether two American satellite companies illegally gave technology to China.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN WEAKENS AGAIN. The Japanese currency fell once again against the dollar on news of strong United States job growth with little inflation. In New York, the dollar rose to 139.75 yen from 138.27.

title: Scientist Assured China of His Help
description: The scientist at the center of an investigation of whether two American companies improperly helped China improve its rockets told the Chinese that he would do everything he could to make their rockets the most reliable in the industry.

title: Some Voters Face a New Hurdle in the 'Land of No'
description: This Fire Island summer colony is often called the ''Land of No'' for its many rules and regulations, including some banning beach Frisbee games, shirtless men and drinking on walkways.

title: DIEBOLD, A.T.M. MAKER, TO TRIM WORK FORCE 9%
description: Diebold Inc. said yesterday that it would cut as many as 600 jobs, or 9 percent of its work force, as sales fall at the largest United States maker of automated teller machines because of bank mergers and year 2000 computer problems. The company plans to eliminate the jobs worldwide, with as many as 250 coming from its headquarters and manufacturing plant in North Canton, Ohio. Diebold warned last month that its second-quarter earnings would not meet analysts' estimates. A wave of acquisitions has swept the banking industry, reducing the goods and services that combined companies need, including new A.T.M. locations. Its shares fell 37.5 cents, to $26.625.

title: Job Growth Surges
description: Despite Asian tremors, stock market jitters and fears that America is running out of workers, the economy is still booming. In May, the Labor Department reported yesterday, employers added nearly 300,000 new jobs, unemployment held steady at an almost unbelievably low 4.3 percent -- the lowest rate in 28 years -- and pay continued to rise.

title: Sports of The Times; The Hero Must Accept Others' Help
description: CHICAGO had finished shooting around yesterday morning and now the news media followed Michael Jordan and finally surrounded him, listening for gems regarding Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals.

title: Religion Journal; Where There's Strength in a Scarcity of Numbers
description: In American life, competition is widely regarded as an almost unmitigated boon to the public good, producing great feats of athleticism in organized sports and spurring creativity, efficiency and consumer choice among businesses. In politics, competition among candidates is considered vital to promoting a full discussion of public issues.

title: A Nice New York, or Indianapolis on the Hudson?
description: To the Editor:

title: Printing of Senator's Letter Revives U.S.-Mexico Fight
description: A dispute over an undercover money-laundering operation by American customs agents has escalated into a full-scale diplomatic altercation that has strained the close ties between the United States and Mexico.

title: Mets Face Martinez: Four Homers and One Piazza X-ray
description: The most distressing development of the evening for the Mets tonight occurred before the game was five minutes old. Pedro Martinez drilled Mike Piazza in the left hand with a fastball, quickly causing Piazza to grimace and the Mets to feel a little queasy. Hideo Nomo arrives and Piazza gets injured; is this some type of practical joke? The Mets wondered.

title: Council Votes Own City Budget, Starting a Fight With Giuliani
description: Combining a righteous resolve with the nervous bravado that comes from venturing into the unexplored, the City Council adopted its own $34 billion budget yesterday, starting what is likely to be a protracted confrontation between the usually compliant Council and the city's combative Mayor.

title: Jordan Steals Home-Court Edge From the Jazz
description: Michael Jordan listened and read about the Chicago Bulls' sudden fallibility. They could not put away good teams in the final minutes. Their title run was in jeopardy.

title: Sam Yorty, Maverick Mayor of Los Angeles, Dies at 88
description: Sam Yorty, the blunt-talking, self-promoting Mayor of Los Angeles who took credit for building up the city yet denied any responsibility for the Watts riots in 1965, died today. He was 88.

title: Dinner Will Wait For Friends In Final
description: They eat clay, drink clay, sleep clay, think clay. According to them, they were born with their sneakers covered with the stuff and have been sliding around on it since. For them, it is terra firma.

title: A Nice New York, or Indianapolis on the Hudson?
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow Journal; A Nation Moving So Fast It Can Ignore Its Prophet
description: By the time the first copies of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's latest book landed at a Moscow bookstore on Thursday, its arrival had been heralded far and wide. Excerpts were published in half a dozen newspapers, and there were announcements on radio and television -- just the kind of fanfare that might be expected for a work by the great Soviet dissident, Nobel Prize winner and tireless defender of Russia's battered soul.

title: 2 Men Sought in Killing Elude an Army of Police
description: As hundreds of law-enforcement officers combed miles of desert canyon near here for two armed men wanted in the killing of a Colorado police officer, officials conceded today that the pair seemed to have vanished as completely as the mirages on the blacktop highways.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: The Media column in Business Day on Monday about recent changes at The New Yorker gave an incomplete account of possible job talks between Tina Brown, the magazine's editor, and the CBS news program ''60 Minutes.'' While a report from inside Conde Nast, the magazine's parent, said that an overture had been made to Ms. Brown about joining ''60 Minutes,'' Don Hewitt, the executive producer of the program, denies that he or any other top CBS official made such a move.

title: Rival Trainers Like Their Chances for an Upset
description: They are running, but they are not scared. Emboldened by doubts regarding the ability of Real Quiet to win the Triple Crown, rival trainers have entered 12 horses to face him in today's 130th Belmont Stakes.

title: Episcopal Diocese To Choose New Bishop
description: The Episcopal Diocese of Newark could elect the nation's first openly gay Bishop today when its members meet to select a new leader.

title: U.S. Ready to Resume Sanctions Against Serbs Over Kosovo Strife
description: The Administration has reversed course and is ready to impose new sanctions on Yugoslavia to punish President Slobodan Milosevic for his attacks on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, senior American officials said today.

title: Clinton Calls for Techno-literacy in Schools
description: President Clinton called on states today to impose a ''technology literacy'' requirement on all children in middle school, declaring that ''students should feel as comfortable with a keyboard as a chalkboard.''

title: 3,400 Strike G.M. Plant; Assembly Put at Risk
description: All 3,400 hourly workers at a General Motors metal stamping factory here walked off the job today, waving American flags and hoisting green and white placards that protested what they called broken promises of job security.

title: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On
description: The first showers of the rainy season have fallen across parts of Mexico and Central America but have failed to quench many wildfires that are destroying virgin forests and feeding a smoke cloud that is drifting across the southern United States, officials said today.

title: About New York; Camera Shy, But on Stage For 3 Brands
description: THE Mendez triplets from Woodside, Queens, are camera shy. This is unfortunate, because their father loves photography. It is also too bad, because their names have a certain quality that courts exposure. In fact, although they just graduated from college yesterday, their names are already in lights and on billboards throughout the world.

title: Judge Tries To Find Cause Of Car Crash Fatal to Diana
description: Nine months after the car crash that killed Diana, the Princess of Wales, and her companion, Emad Mohamed al-Fayed, a French investigator today questioned photographers who pursued the couple, relatives of the dead and witnesses to try to determine how it happened.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEVIN, JOHN FRANCIS
description: NEVIN-John Francis, 87. Died unexpectedly on May 26. Beloved brother of Maureen, Stasia, Dermot and Donal. Beloved friend of Judy Keele and deceased wife Karlene. Oldest graduate in America of the Univ. of Dublin. Major in the British Army in the retreat in Burma. Memorial funeral mass, Tues, June 9, 7PM at Church of Our Saviour, 38th St and Park.

title: D'Amato Stirs State G.O.P And Borrows Some Themes
description: Six years after vowing not to run for office again, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato accepted the unanimous nomination of state Republican Party leaders for a fourth term yesterday, then launched into a rousing speech salted with traditionally Democratic themes and appeals to crossover voters.

title: The President as Defense Lawyer
description: The Supreme Court made a disappointing call this week in rejecting independent counsel Kenneth Starr's request for immediate high court review of the Clinton Administration's expansive and dilatory privilege claims. Bypassing the traditional appellate process is not a step to be taken lightly. But Mr. Starr was right about the serious nature of his inquiry and the nation's strong interest in a prompt resolution.

title: INSIDE
description: Firefighter Killed in Blaze

title: Nuclear Minefield Of What to Do
description: ''Thinking the unthinkable'' is how the nuclear priesthood refers to it. The Indian and Pakistani nuclear tests have reignited fierce debates over doctrine. Do nuclear weapons make the world a more dangerous or a safer place? Can or should the United States try to prevent other nations from acquiring nuclear bombs?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about job reductions planned by Motorola Inc., misstated the number of low-orbit satellites the company had envisioned for a network that it is now abandoning. It was 63 low-orbit satellites, not 66.

title: Iraq Rejects U.N. Agenda For Lifting Of Sanctions
description: Iraq's Foreign Minister today dismissed as a ''nonstarter'' the agenda that the United Nations' chief arms inspector for Iraq plans to take to Baghdad next week.

title: David Walsh, 52, Promoter Caught Up in Gold Mine Scandal
description: David G. Walsh, a journeyman stock promoter whose gold mining company, Bre-X Minerals, was at the center of a fraud that wiped out the holdings of investors in Canada and the United States, died on Thursday at Doctors' Hospital in Nassau, the Bahamas.

description: To the Editor:

title: Moody's Plans to Review Its Ratings for Malaysia
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it might cut Malaysia's credit ratings, warning that the nation's economy will contract this year and cause bad loans to surge amid higher interest rates. The ratings company in New York placed Malaysia's foreign currency rating for bonds and notes and rating for bank deposits on review for possible downgrade.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metropolitan Diary column on May 25 about a nun who bought a package of cookies at an airport was published in error. The incident -- in which the nun thought that a man was helping himself to her cookies when in fact she was helping herself to his -- did not occur recently at Kennedy International Airport. It is a current myth and has been recounted by a folklorist, Jan Harold Brunvand, in a variety of renditions in two books, ''The Choking Doberman'' and ''The Mexican Pet.''

title: Berlin Holocaust Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Friend of Black Militant Fugitive Is Held After Siege in New Jersey
description: After a 23-hour siege punctuated by police bursts of tear gas and water from high-pressure hoses, a robbery suspect once active in a black militant group surrendered yesterday afternoon and ended a standoff that shattered the calm of a New Jersey town, the authorities said.

title: Fortis Raises Bid for Generale de Banque
description: Fortis Group said today that it was raising its bid for Generale de Banque to about $13.4 billion, topping a $12.6 billion offer from a rival bidder, ABN Amro Holding N.V.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SARAH RAMSEY
description: MILLER-Sarah Ramsey. Aug. 1, 1897-June 6, 1988. Dear Mother, I miss you every day and think of you all the time. Lots of love. Dolly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBO, FRANCIS FERENC (FRANK)
description: DOBO-Francis Ferenc (Frank). Passed away peacefully on Wednesday, June 3, succumbing in his 90th year to a protracted illness. With him at the time in his Manhattan apartment was his wife and loving companion of 56 years, Bita Dobo (nee Sulzberger). In addition, he is survived by his son Michael of Culver City, CA. Memorial Service is pending.

title: Nomo Joins the Mets And Draws a Crowd
description: Hideo Nomo's first official duty as a Met took place atop the third-base dugout at Fenway Park tonight, where he sat with his legs dangling while more than 100 reporters, photographers and camera operators crowded around the steps. It was a strange scene, made stranger by the Red Sox fans who barely uttered a word, but it was also a glimpse at what Nomomania can mean for the Mets.

title: Finances Worry Neutrino Researchers
description: As Japanese and American scientists basked in the glow of their monumental discovery of neutrino mass, announced here on Friday, a financial cloud that could hamper future research hung over the 120-member team today.

title: Journal; Starr's Guilt Trip
description: Now that he's on a faster track, which we can only pray will expedite the most extravagant investigation of a quickie sex act in American history, you might think that Ken Starr has at last regained his bearings. No more martyring of anybody's mother, no more posing with garbage bags in the driveway. But this week, alas, the independent counsel reverted to form by making a speech so genuinely nutty it's hard to know which is more amazing -- what he said, or the fact that his words escaped serious scrutiny by a (you choose) bored or compliant press.

title: A WORLD OF ARMS: A Deal Under Suspicion; For U.S., Gun Sales Are Good Business
description: The Solomon Islands, a tiny country in the Pacific with 400,000 people, has no army and a police force of barely a thousand (including traffic patrols). But last summer the Government purchased enough equipment to outfit a small combat unit -- assault rifles, machine guns, helmets and boots, and two small airplanes -- from an American company.

title: New Leader for Finance Inquiry
description: Attorney General Janet Reno announced today that she had named a veteran Federal prosecutor in New Hampshire to succeed Charles G. LaBella, a lawyer who is stepping down from the top job in the Justice Department's campaign finance inquiry.

title: Talks Seen on Sale of a Texas Instruments Business
description: Texas Instruments Inc., a leading producer of computer chips, is in talks to sell its memory-chip operations to Micron Technology Inc., people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Clinton Appeal to Get Hearing in June
description: Following a suggestion from the Supreme Court, a Federal appeals court today set a prompt schedule to consider the privileges asserted by the Clinton Administration to limit the testimony of four Government employees in the Lewinsky investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBARD, HARRIS T.
description: GILBARD-Harris T. Of Boca Raton, Florida and New York City, on June 3, 1998, after a courageous struggle with Lou Gehrig's disease. He is survived by his beloved and devoted wife Marion. Loving father of Dr. Robert and Bianca Gilbard, Dr. Jeffrey and Elisabeth Gilbard, Dr. Steven and Lauren Gilbard, and step-children Andrew and Cherlye Carlton, Dale Carlton, and Arnold Carlton. He was the proud grandfather of eleven grandchildren and one great grandchild. Dear brother of Lillian Gabor, Bernard and Judith Gilbard, Phyllis & Gerry Annunziato, and the late Ruth Nakrin. He will be remembered for his vision, his outstanding leadership in business, his strength of heart, his gentle qualities and love of family. ''Harris, we will remember you forever. You are our inspiration.'' Funeral Services will be held at Temple Judea, 333 Searingtown Road, Manhasset, Long Island, Monday, June 8, 12 Noon. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Dept of Neurology ALS attn: Renee Stewart, The University of Miami School of Medicine, 1150 N.W. 14th St., Suite 701, Miami, FL 33136.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAZIN, ALFRED
description: KAZIN-Alfred. Writer and teacher, died Friday, June 5, at home, surrounded by his books and his family. He is survived by his wife, Judith Dunford, his children, Michael and Cathrael, his daughter-in-law, Beth and two grandchildren, Daniel and Maia Rebecca. He is also survived by three stepchildren, Jonathan Dunford, Nathaniel Dunford, and Hilary Shanahan, as well as five stepgrandchildren. A memorial service is planned for the Fall.

title: Firefighter Is Killed Battling Blaze
description: One firefighter was killed, another critically injured and at least four others hurt last night in a five-alarm fire that consumed a city-owned apartment building in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: NOVELL PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO 10% OF ITS SHARES
description: Novell Inc. plans to buy back as much as 10 percent of its shares outstanding, or about $390 million worth, as the company, a maker of computer-network software, continues efforts to increase its profit and market value. The company, based in Provo, Utah, has about 353 million shares outstanding; it will buy back stock from time to time in the open market. The shares rose 68.75 cents yesterday, to $11.125. It is Novell's second buyback plan in two years. Novell spent $456 million to purchase 33 million shares in 1996.

title: Chiefs Extend Rison's Contract
description: Receiver Andre Rison signed a four-year contract extension with the Kansas City Chiefs that will average $3 million a year, his agent said yesterday.

title: Jobs Surged By 300,000 Last Month
description: Despite Asian tremors, stock market jitters and fears that America is running out of workers, the economy is still booming. In May, the Labor Department reported yesterday, employers added nearly 300,000 new jobs, unemployment held steady at an almost unbelievably low 4.3 percent -- the lowest rate in 28 years -- and pay continued to rise.

title: Kerr Comes Through When Jordan Can't
description: Steve Kerr was the lifesaver that Michael Jordan had been waving for in this series.

title: Op-Art
Maxtor Initial Offering
description: The Maxtor Corporation, a disk-drive maker that is a unit of Hyundai Electronics Industries of South Korea, said today that it planned to sell $575 million of its stock in an initial public offering. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Maxtor, based in Milpitas, Calif., did not specify how many shares would be sold.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We now speak about the unspeakable as though it were fruit salad.''

title: Computer System Problem Delays Hundreds of Flights
description: Hundreds of flights were delayed early this morning, some for more than an hour, as a computer system used by controllers at an air-traffic control center on Long Island crashed during a software upgrade.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an appearance by Elie Wiesel at a Holocaust studies program at Public School 111 in Manhattan misstated the school's address. It is at 53d Street, not 56th Street, between 9th and 10th Avenues. The article also misstated a comment by the program's teacher, Ellen Gallin Procida, about slavery. While she said black parents support the program, she did not say that many may consider slavery a holocaust of their own that is little appreciated by whites.

title: Alfred Kazin, the Author Who Wrote of Literature and Himself, Is Dead at 83
description: Alfred Kazin, author, critic, teacher and New York intellectual, died yesterday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan on his 83d birthday.

title: Firefighters' Brawl
description: Three years ago New York City police officers attending a convention in Washington brought shame on their city when they trashed their hotels, harassed other guests and cavorted, drunk and naked, in public. Now New York firefighters have replicated this behavior at home, staging a rampage at a restaurant in midtown Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, WALTER J.
description: BLUM-Walter J. On June 4, 1998. Former Vice President of Walter H. Blum and Sons. Beloved husband of Graceann (Nee Whelan). Devoted father of Walter, John, James, Brian, Suzanne Rahali, Elizabeth Marconi, Clairemarie Honig and Danielle Wells. Loving grandfather of Gregory, Carolyn, Walter H., Erin and Courtney. Dear brother of Ellen Casey and the late William, Arthur, George, Betty Jane McCarthy and Peggy Voglio. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach. Mass of Christian burial on Monday 9:45am at St. Francis de Sales Church, Belle Harbor, NY. Interment Calverton V.A. cemetery. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-10pm.

title: The American Century's Opening Shot
description: Centennials usually call for a lot of clanking celebration, a period souvenir or two and perhaps some minor historical revisionism. The 1898 observation, now under way in Spain, Cuba, the Philippines and the United States, is a tough one. So much was set in motion that it is difficult to contemplate how we got from there to here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUINNESS, ANNE
description: MCGUINNESS-Anne. June 5, 1998 in Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, CT. Wife of the late Peter J. McGuinness. Mother of Peter, James, John, Kathleen, and Mary. Grandmother of fourteen. Great grandmother of six. Sister of Bessie Keane of County Mayo, Ireland. Mass of Christian Burial will be held Monday 10AM at St. Matthew's Church, Norwalk. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Visiting at the Raymond Funeral Home, 5 East Wall Street, Norwalk, CT Saturday 79PM, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Contributions to Notre Dame Conv. Home, West Rocks Rd, Norwalk,, CT 06851.

title: Harryetta Peterka, Drama Teacher, 64
description: Harryetta Peterka, director of instruction of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, died on Tuesday at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. She was 64 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rising Storm in the Balkans
description: President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia is incorrigible. Forced to accept peace in Bosnia, he is now uprooting thousands of ethnic Albanians from the Serbian province of Kosovo. His military campaign, the largest since the end of the Bosnian war, threatens to ignite a wider conflict in the Balkans. America and its European allies urgently need to increase the pressure on Mr. Milosevic to desist.

title: Spending Plan Council Adopted Is Similar to Mayor's
description: Except for huge personal income tax cuts, the $34.08 billion budget that the City Council passed yesterday -- the first in the city's history that was approved without the agreement of the Mayor -- included relatively modest changes from a plan Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed only weeks ago.

title: FIRSTAR IN DEAL TO BUY UNIT OF CARGILL
description: The Firstar Corporation agreed late on Thursday to buy the Cargill Leasing Corporation, a unit of Cargill Inc., in a move to broaden the financial services it offers corporate clients. Cargill Leasing leases transportation equipment including tractor-trailers, aircraft, barges, locomotives and rail cars, as well as computers. Its assets will total $625 million in the third quarter, when the transaction is expected to be completed. For Firstar, a Milwaukee-based commercial bank, the Cargill unit will quadruple its lease-financing business, said Roger L. Fitzsimonds, chairman and chief executive of Firstar. Cargill Leasing's parent, the Minneapolis-based Cargill, is the world's largest privately held company. Firstar's stock rose 62.5 cents, to $36.25.

title: The Dead Resurrected and Truckin'
description: Some habits are hard to break. From the late 1960's to the early 1990's, the Grateful Dead were on the road almost every year, playing down-home improvisational rock for twirling, tie-dyed Dead Heads. Three years after the death of Jerry Garcia, his fellow members of the Grateful Dead are back together as the core of a new band, the Other Ones, that sets out to resurrect and extend the Dead's legacy.

title: VICOR TO BUY 2 CONCERNS OWNED BY JAPAN TOBACCO
description: The Vicor Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the principal assets of two money-losing power supply businesses owned by Japan Tobacco Inc. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Vicor, based in Andover, Mass., manufactures power systems and modular power components. It had revenue of $162 million in 1997. Japan Tobacco, based in Tokyo, is Japan's former tobacco and salt monopoly. It had sales of 3.6 trillion yen ($26 billion) in the year that ended on March 31.

title: Consumer Debt Up Again
description: Borrowing by United States consumers grew at a faster pace in April than it did in March, the Federal Reserve reported today. Borrowing rose $5.5 billion in April, to $1.250 trillion, after rising a revised $2 billion in March. Previously, the Fed had said that March borrowing was up $1 billion. Before today's report, analysts had expected an increase of $4 billion for April. Consumer credit has moderated considerably from high levels that persisted from late 1993 through most of 1996. Credit card borrowing rose $2.3 billion in April, after increasing a revised $500 million in March, previously reported as a $600 million rise.

title: Airlines Prepare to Fight Heart Attacks Aloft
description: AMONG a planeload of passengers there is almost always a doctor, nurse or medical technician, but when an airliner is at cruise altitude, the nearest equipment to diagnose or treat a heart attack is usually seven miles below.

description: MUSEUM MILE

title: May 31-June 6; Ingles, Please
description: California voters delivered a decisive blow to three decades of bilingual instruction in their public schools, voting by a 60-to-40 margin in favor of a ballot measure that said, essentially, ''No mas!'' The measure would limit instruction for non-English speakers to one year of intensive immersion. Hispanic voters opposed it by almost the opposite margin. TODD S. PURDUM

title: Nascar Drivers Trade Paint and Accusations in Richmond

title: Editorial Observer; The Politics of Embarrassment in Alabama

The main reason for that and for the state's obsessive concern with its national image is its habit of electing governors who expose the state to ridicule. George Wallace fashioned this inferiority complex into a personal political asset with his defiant cry of ''Stand Up for Alabama.'' But even the people who loved Mr. Wallace were humiliated by his ketchup-splattered shirts and masticated cigars. Yet like members of a dysfunctional family, enlightened Alabamians usually kept quiet around outsiders when it came to their feelings of shame and their secret longing for a governor who did not come across as a racist ranter or a corrupt rube.

In the old days, before the boom, stockbrokers like Dwyer didn't waste their time restraining investors. There was too much product to push. And clients needed more explanations back then -- actually, they needed it all explained. What stocks were, how bonds worked. Die-hards who wanted to track the market had to amble into a brokerage office just to catch sight of a ticker.

The Bellangers have feisty opinions about many things, they watch a lot of television (mostly public) and they read. That's how they know about the money boom, which otherwise is not a daily reality in their house. Betty, 66, is a homemaker; Paul is a retired electrician. He's 67. Their monthly income is $2,400, including Paul's Army and union pensions and both their Social Security checks. With this the Bellangers pay the bills, feed a savings account and still manage to send $300 a month to their grandson David, who's studying computers at the University of Arizona in Tucson.

To Freud, however, excessive love of money divided man from society; it indicated a sublimation of the anal drive, by which pathological adults transferred a childhood fixation on the contents of their diapers to a fixation on the contents of their wallets. title: Where Melville Paid Homage to a Mountain
description: IT'S a brave and poignant thing to dedicate a novel to a mountain. Brave to match up an imperfect, man-made creation against one of nature's masterpieces; poignant to be so disenchanted with your fellow humans that a hillside seems your one and only friend. Both qualities were evident in Herman Melville's decision in 1852 to dedicate ''Pierre,'' his seventh novel, to the mountain that dominated the view from his study window at Arrowhead, the 18th-century farmhouse in Pittsfield, Mass., he had purchased two years before. Having dedicated his previous novel, ''Moby-Dick,'' to the American writer he valued most, his Berkshire neighbor Nathaniel Hawthorne -- having found Hawthorne's famous shyness nearly impossible to crack -- Melville may well have felt that he had no one human who could understand the wild, tormented novel he had just now completed.

title: A.T.M.'s Overseas

I had no trouble in Munich last year and so planned on using a card on a trip to England a few months ago. But when I tried to make withdrawals in London, I was denied at several banks because the machine would withdraw only from my checking account. The German A.T.M.'s allowed a savings withdrawal, but I did not have this option in London. Nor could I transfer funds from savings to checking. I was forced to use a credit card for cash advances, which is considerably more expensive.

A walk through the National Portrait Gallery's current exhibition in Washington, ''Celebrity Caricature in America,'' offers overwhelming reassurance that at least one branch of my stunted family tree gracefully reached the celestial heights of the so-called high arts.

title: The Big City; A Case of Island Madness
description: For Tom Ortez, Black Friday came on Oct. 15, 1999. The Dow had already fallen 5,000 points in the preceding 10 months, but until that morning he had been able to persuade himself that the Crash of '99 was just a temporary inconvenience. He had even tried arguing that it was good for his company. ''In these uncertain times,'' he told one reporter, ''the sophisticated customer knows that a $1,100 Durata handbag is an investment that will last.''

description: CALLING this year's overseas markets volatile is a bit like saying India and Pakistan are having a neighborhood cook-off.

description: DELL-Allan. 1/7/66-6/7/97. AllieAl-we miss you, we love you. Thumbs up! Mom, Dad, Felisa and Damon, and Blake.

title: Being 13
description: 'Becoming 13'' suggests that many if not most teen-agers believe they have to be materialistic or type-A Tara Lipinskis or automatons in cliques and gangs or cyberspace addicts, in order to be somebody. Only the Iowa farm boy seems nicely balanced, i.e., connected with his family and community, while being allowed time to dillydally.

description: To the Editor:

title: May 31-June 6; A Bishop Resigns
description: After 40 years of priesthood, the Roman Catholic Bishop of Florida, Joseph Keith Symons, resigned after admitting he sexually molested five boys more than 25 years ago.

title: Lending Aid And Comfort To a Bully
description: BIOGRAPHERS end up as advocates. They can't help it. The years spent reconstructing the lives of others, seeing through their eyes, thinking their thoughts, turn the writer into a sibling by adoption, a loyal part of the family.

description: FILES are essentially long pieces of hardened steel with parallel rows of cutting teeth. They are abrading tools, used to grind away excess material and to smooth the work surface. They are differentiated by their shape and tooth configuration.

title: Flashy Plans for a Famous Address; Rockefeller Center Is Counting on Retail, and the Bull Market
description: There are more than 60 empty storefronts at Rockefeller Center these days, and the 65,000 people who work there have certainly noticed.

title: Word for Word / Rover Rage; Chomp: A Dog's Breakfast About Dog Bites
description: DOG bites man,'' the quintessential nonstory, morphed into a very newsy sports dream-come-true last week. David Cone, the New York Yankees right-hander, was nipped on the index finger of his pitching hand by his mother's dog and had to yield his turn in the pitching rotation to Orlando (El Duque) Hernandez, newly defected from Cuba. Thus a minor bite by a Jack Russell terrier named Veronica facilitated the storybook odyssey of a gifted pitcher, from ostracism in his Communist homeland to a victorious debut in Yankee Stadium on Wednesday night.

title: May 31-June 6; A Plea to Ease Sanctions
description: President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea begins a nine-day state visit to the United States this weekend, and a few days before leaving he called on Washington to ease sanctions against North Korea. It was an unusual spectacle for the South Korean President to ask his allies to lift sanctions against his mortal enemy, but Mr. Kim said engagement with North Korea was more likely to open it up and moderate its behavior. NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

title: The Nation: Fish Story; Money Politics Wasn't Defeated in California
description: MONEY is the mother's milk of politics,'' is the maxim coined by Jesse M. Unruh, the liberal Democrat who reigned as Speaker of the California State Assembly in the 1960's, and indeed, cash has always been an essential commodity in campaigns. The primary in California last week was the most expensive statewide election in American history, with $100 million spent on races for governor, United States senator and a handful of ballot propositions.

title: In China, Tomorrow Belongs To Greed
description: THE house my great-grandparents owned sits in a narrow concrete alley in Shanghai. The walls are decaying like a rotten tooth, and the door opens into a rusty kitchen. The clock in the sitting room is a relic from before Mao came to power, the light fixture dangles as a memory from earlier days. My grandparents were married in this house, now filled with dog-eared books and broken dishes. Some call it junk; I call it history.

title: The View From/Lebanon; Small Town's Big Place In Connecticut History
description: MOST Connecticut towns have their share of Colonial history, -- a native son, a historical site, the remains of an Indian settlement -- but few can boast the equivalent of Lebanon's.

title: Salvaging Holyfield Fight Will Be Complicated Matter
description: A day after his heavyweight championship fight was canceled, Evander Holyfield was relaxing in Atlanta, watching his children compete in a track meet. Meanwhile, his lawyer, Jim Thomas, and officials at Showtime and Madison Square Garden were left sifting through the rubble of a postponed boxing show that may or may not be salvageable.

title: Milking The Boom; It's Good to Be the C.E.O.
description: For the chief executives of corporate America, money has become little more than a way to keep score. After all, many of them have made more than they could ever spend, even if they had the time.

title: The Other Portfolio Risk: Foundering in a Sea of Illiquidity
description: THE bull market in stocks has been long and lovely, but even unsophisticated mutual fund investors understand the nature of market risk. If the prices of many stocks in a fund's portfolio drop, fund holders will lose, too.

title: Genetic Testing Requires A Comprehensive Program
description: Your May 3 article on genetic testing [''Genetic Tests Gaining for Adult-Onset Ills''] states that several hospitals on Long Island have genetic departments that offer testing. Individuals seeking testing have an alternative not mentioned, namely having genetic evaluation, counseling and testing through our private-practice genetics center.

title: Toughest Boards Are Biggest Stockholders
description: DIRECTORS with a lot of money tied up in the stock of the company they oversee are more likely to dismiss a poor-performing chief executive than directors who don't have much money at stake, according to a new study.

title: Q and A
description: Renting a Scooter in Rome
