description: No Lease on Life

title: Maplewood Stores Enlist Train Station Concierge
description: While New Jersey Transit's Maplewood train station may not be as plush as the Plaza Hotel, starting tomorrow it will have a concierge.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEORGE, SALLY
description: GEORGE-Sally. 31 May 1991. Missing you as ever. Wishing you were still on earth, and not only in my heart and soul. You were one of a kind-and simply, the Best. Love, Catherine

title: Of Microsoft and Market Forces
description: ''Why Microsoft Should Be Left Alone'' (Viewpoint, May 24), by Bhaskar Chakravorti, drew varied responses from readers. Mr. Chakravorti, a senior member of the global consulting practice of the Monitor Company in Cambridge, Mass., argued that technology markets require no more regulatory intervention than other markets -- and that Microsoft has endured not by crushing competition but by finding ways to make challengers' products its own. Some readers essentially agreed; some saw other issues at work in Microsoft's fight with the Government.

title: Belle Waring, John Holbo
description: Belle Buchanan Waring and John Christian Holbo, Ph.D. candidates at the University of California at Berkeley, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's grandfather Stuyvesant Wainwright 2d in Wainscott, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Reese, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Champagne Instead of Grog for Victorious Sailors
description: THE SETTING -- An afternoon party last Tuesday aboard Mariner III, which was docked at the North Cove Yacht Harbor in Battery Park City. An international crowd of sailors and corporate guests is finishing some Champagne used to toast Illbruck-Pinta, a yacht that came in first that morning in a race from Newport to Manhattan.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Search For Savin' Sam By William Carter. Longstreet, $20.

title: 'Little Meal' at the Bar Is Big Setauket Secret
description: THE new Metropolis in East Setauket (751-2200) is packing them in. Yet relatively few patrons, even those who are three and four deep at the bar on weekends, seem to be aware of the restaurant's bar menu with its easy-to-take prices. That is unfortunate since it is one of the most extensive on the Island with nine snacks, four little meals, a dessert assortment and a three-cheese combination plate. With one exception, the bar fare costs from $3 to $7, with the little meals ''for those in a hurry that just want a light meal'' (and a light check as well), are priced from $6 to $11.

title: Labor Strife Unsettles A Cemetery
description: An eight-week dispute between workers and management at Mount Hebron Cemetery has turned its normally manicured lawns into an undulating prairie.

title: The Preservation Band That Sets the Tone
description: THE architectural firm of Beyer Blinder Belle was born in the tumultuous year of 1968, with a bow to Jane Jacobs and a commitment to the maverick ideas of community-based planning and rehabilitation rather than bulldozing. Today, it finds itself where its founders never expected to be: on the inside track.

title: Anne Kraus, 73, Administrator Of Homes for Mentally Retarded
description: Anne Kraus, who was inspired by the plight of her firstborn to devote herself to those with mental retardation and other developmental disabilities, died on Monday at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in Queens. She was 73 and lived in Rego Park, Queens.

title: Being 13
description: An entire issue on turning 13 and not a single mention of one of the most traumatic events a Jewish male faces: his bar mitzvah.

title: Birthday Parties For Dogs Is Too Much
description: I liked dogs as much as anyone when I was a child, but my years as an avid walker have dimmed my admiration. I can't count the number of times I've been frightened by dogs, with no owner in sight, or the times I've been accosted on pathways in public parks by unleashed dogs. If I protest, the owner gets mad at me! Avid dog lovers are a breed in themselves.

title: VIEWPOINT; Keep a Strong Patent System
description: MUCH has been written about how the explosion of patent litigation in the last decade in the high-technology industry threatens to cripple America's most innovative companies. Critics of the patent system are quick to point out how patent infringement judgments have escalated into the hundred-million-dollar range, not to mention the lawyers' fees.

title: The Second Generation
description: DAN CHERUBIN considers himself pretty lucky. Though his father died five years ago, he still has his mother, and his other mother.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 17 about disputes over credit for movie screenplays misstated the surname of a woman who wrote a screen adaptation of the Toni Morrison novel ''Beloved.'' She is Akosua Busia, not Ufia.

title: Being 13
description: Even as ''hep an old cat'' as William Safire shouldn't try to decipher teen-age slang, until he spends some time with a teen-ager or two (On Language: ''All Phat! And a Bag of Chips'').

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 3 of the Television section today, about the World Cup soccer tournament, misstates the cable channel for ''Outside the Lines.'' It is ESPN, not ESPN2.

title: Skirts to Match
description: People are literally ordering the clothes off Paige Novick's back. ''I had a friend stitch up a skirt to go with one of my bags for the Seventh on Sixth party, and that night I had people ordering it off my body,'' said Ms. Novick, 31, explaining how her company, Frou by Paige Novick, expanded to women's wear last November. It started as a hair-accessory business four years ago and grew to include handbags two years ago.

Herman Harmelink 3d, a retired minister of the Reformed Church of America, officiated.

title: Being 13
description: Ned Vizzini's wise and witty advice in ''Teen Angst? Nah!'' concludes with the notion that ''adolescence is a time to sit back, make some friends - and maybe discover what you're good at.'' Not quite. Learning what you are good at takes some effort.

title: Samantha Warrick, James Corrigan Jr.
description: Samantha Stockton Warrick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Warrick Jr. of Rye, N.H., was married yesterday to James Nicholas Corrigan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Corrigan of Washington. Msgr. J. Joshua Mundell performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Church in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIGIOVANNI, CONSTANCE
description: DiGIOVANNI-Constance. 6/7/60-12/3/94. Dear Connie, happy birthday in heaven to my beautiful little sister, my forever friend. I miss you more than words can say. Love never dies. Donna Lee

description: THE lilacs have been glorious this year, rewarding those who have this magnificent and fragrant shrub in their gardens.

title: New Golf Courses Face Vocal Opponents
description: THE way Michael Giordano tells it, the parcel of land he owns in North Branford has lain fallow for decades since his family assembled it from discontinued farms in the late 70's and early 80's. His plan: Build the town's first daily-fee golf course there.

title: A Brand-New Stage for Shakespeare's World
description: THE painters were casting a new dye on the new doors, switching from basic white to ''some color of Shakespeare's day,'' they said in unison. If maize (a shades of gold), verdigris (the patina of copper) and marigold (gold and brown) do not figure into everyone's color vocabulary, Bonnie J. Monte may change all that.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE WAR AGAINST PARENTS

title: Fixed Matches Are Darkening Soccer's Image
description: Last November, as the United States prepared for a World Cup soccer qualifying match against El Salvador, John Harkes and Roy Wegerle, two of the team's top players, received an alarming telephone call at their hotel in Providence, R.I. The caller suggested that they could make money by throwing their game against El Salvador.

title: High School Site
description: With its enrollments growing at a steady pace, the Solomon Schechter School of Westchester has bought 23 acres in Hartsdale for a high school campus.

title: Summertime, and the Driving Is Breezy
description: SUMMER is around the corner, and the forecast, thanks to El Nino, is for a dry, sunny season -- ideal conditions for open-air motoring.

title: A Milestone for Concordia College
description: WHEN Dr. Ralph Schultz, the president of Concordia College in Bronxville, conducts works by Bach, Brahms, Mendelssohn and seven other composers along with several of his own sacred settings today at 3 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall in Manhattan, it will mark the end of an era as well as an occasion of personal significance for Dr. Schultz.

title: Delay for Saks Mall
description: Construction of a mall at the Saks Fifth Avenue site along Maple Avenue and Bloomingdale Road in White Plains is at least a year away, Alexius C. Conroy, a Greenwich developer, reported.

title: Motorcycle Mamas Are Seeing the World From a Harley
description: At first, Christina Paccione said, she was content to wrap her arms around her boyfriend's waist and ride pillion as he guided his Harley-Davidson through the city. But after six months the thrill was gone. ''I realized that I wanted more control,'' said Ms. Paccione, 47, a barber from Long Island. ''I wanted to be in the front seat.''

title: Is Headline Opera Yesterday's News?
description: THE fad for headline opera, a genre that began so promisingly in 1987 with John Adams's ''Nixon in China'' and fizzled last year with Michael Daugherty's ''Jackie O,'' seems to have passed. Breathe a sigh of relief, knowing that we have been spared operas based on O.J., Tonya and Paula.

title: The Macbeths of the Ozarks
description: ARKANSAS MISCHIEF

title: What Connecticut Gets In a Massive Transit Bill
description: LATE last month, Congress passed legislation that calls for the Federal Government to spend $203 billion on highway and mass transit projects over the next six years. The legislation will increase virtually every state's Federal aid for major transportation programs; Connecticut's share will grow by 13 percent to $408 million a year.

title: Attack of the 20-Foot Rats
description: IT is a season of discontent, at least among those who make their living on the city's streets. And many have taken to those very streets to protest: taxi drivers, disgruntled sidewalk artists and, most recently, food cart vendors, all complaining of new municipal regulations that they say will hamper their business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORCHINSKI, IRENE
description: KORCHINSKI-Irene. Suddenly in New York City May 31, 1998. Beloved sister of Alex, Ron and Ed of Canada. Burial private.

title: A Likely Challenger Is Gaining on Hollings
description: Final polls indicate that when South Carolinians vote on Tuesday for candidates to run in the fall contest for the United States Senate, Democrats will renominate the incumbent, Ernest F. Hollings, and Republicans will nominate Bob Inglis, the Congressman from the Fourth District in the state's northeastern corner. But that is not the news about this seat that is crucial to the control of the Senate.

title: Capping Off Their College Careers
description: Thousands of newly minted graduates have been sent out into the world this spring by New Jersey colleges. Here's a roundup of some recent commencements.

title: The Perils In Reporting On Rights In Colombia
description: The score of soldiers and military officers who stormed a human rights organization here recently -- holding guns to the heads of workers, forcing them to their knees and filming them -- said they had no shortage of reasons for the assault.

title: A.T.M.'s Overseas
description: Doug Rozman, a spokesman for Mastercard International, responds: The Mastercard/Cirrus network regrets the inconvenience Ms. Combes suffered in Spain. Our network has a high level of reliabiity, with more than 98 percent of the network operating at all times. But, as with any electronically based system, there may be times where a local network will malfunction.

title: Correction
description: Photographs last week accompanying an article about a proposal by a Riverhead family to use property enrolled in Suffolk County's farmland preservation program to build a golf resort were published in error. The proposal has not been approved and course construction has not begun; the photos showed work under way on an unrelated golf course project.

title: An Exhumed Body Tells Grim Tales of Apartheid
description: Before going to the cemetery, Bafana Mahlombe's family gathered in front of the police station here, laughing and joking about the 22-year-old they remembered. He had been short and muscular. He hadn't talked much.

description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

description: Jessica Lawrence duPont, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Lewars duPont of Belleair, Fla., was married yesterday to Lieut. (j.g.) Eric Christopher Thiel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Thiel of Clearwater, Fla. The Rev. David Henry, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony in the United States Naval Academy Chapel in Annapolis, Md.

title: Anna Reisman And Cary Gross
description: Dr. Anna Beth Reisman, a daughter of Martha R. Reisman of Branford, Conn., and W. Michael Reisman of Hamden, Conn., is to be married today to Dr. Cary Philip Gross, a son of Helene F. Gross of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Bernard D. Gross of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Hillel Silverman is to officiate at the home of Genevieve Murphy and Donald Axleroad, the bridegroom's aunt and uncle, in Stamford, Conn.

title: One Firefighter Is Mourned As a Second Fights for Life
description: New York mourned a dead brave firefighter, and a second fireman who was burned over 80 percent of his body lay near death yesterday as investigators focused on a mattress fire as the probable cause of a roaring, five-alarm inferno that engulfed a row of small, wood-frame houses in Brooklyn on Friday night.

title: Pedaling Back
description: The reintroduction of Schwinn's 1968 Orange Krate is good news for nostalgic grown-ups like Andrew Mer. The 35-year-old Manhattan lawyer remembers receiving a Grey Ghost (part of the Krate family) for his 8th birthday. ''The one day I lent it to my younger brother, the bike was stolen and stripped,'' he said ruefully.

title: A Soprano Does It (Precisely) Her Way
description: OH beautiful for spacious skies, and for majestic American icons like Jessye Norman, whose recital at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center today was all but sold out by press time. Ticketless fans can settle for buying CD's, of which she has made almost 70.

title: Anti-Lilco Coalition Continues Its Battle Against a New Foe
description: AT the height of their power, opponents of the Long Island Lighting Company and its once-ambitious nuclear power agenda included nearly all elected officials in Suffolk County, ad hoc anti-nuclear coalitions, environmental and civic groups, businesses, lawyers and clergy. And they won huge victories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNING, BARBARA
description: CORNING-Barbara. June 3, 1998. Beloved daughter of the late Gardner Corning and the late Charlotte Bayne Corning. Services Tuesday, June 9 at 1PM, Fifth Ave. Presbyterian Church, 5th Ave at 55th St. A reception will follow. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Womens Bible Society of New York, 360 Park Ave. South, NYC, James Lenox House, 49 East 73 St, NYC or the Fifth Ave. Presbyterian Church.

title: Spreading The Boom; Instant Gratification
description: Everyone at Polaroid remembers the day last July when the company's stock price hit $60. In the 1970's, the camera company's stock had been among the highest-flying, but those glory days were long gone. So when it soared from $50 to $60 in the space of five weeks last summer, everyone jumped to attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWY, GERHARD
description: LOWY-Gerhard. Of New York. On June 5, 1998. Cherished husband of Irma, devoted father of Frank and Ruth, grandfather of Alexander, Andrew and Evan. Contributions to the New York Public Library.

description: Yes, you may have to duck a flying cow at the latest attraction at Universal Studios Florida. In Twister . . . Ride It Out, based on the movie ''Twister,'' the cow is from a sign, however, not a farm.

title: H.M.O.'s Could Save Your Life
description: The future of health care in this country is about to be decided yet again by advertising campaigns and sob stories. Some lobbyists and public relations firms, pushing for tougher regulations, are parading patients who tearfully complain of abuse by mean-spirited, money-hungry managed-care companies. Others claim that regulation will only lead to higher premiums and more uninsured people.

title: Praise for Article On Grants to Artists
description: Thank you for writing such an informative and interesting article about the Anonymous Was a Woman grants on March 22 (''Two Women Receive Art Grants From Unknown Female Donor'').

title: Murphy Creates His Own Luck
description: About a year ago, Larry Murphy seemed near the end of a long and semidistinguished career. After modest success in Los Angeles, Washington and Minnesota in the 1980's and two Stanley Cup rings with Pittsburgh in the early 1990's, the veteran defenseman was toiling for the Toronto Maple Leafs, a team hardly in danger of qualifying for the playoffs. Even the polite fans of Maple Leaf Gardens were booing and heckling Murphy. It was as if someone had passed a law that said whatever could go wrong would go wrong. But then everything started to go right for Larry Murphy.

title: Killer to Die for Sole Murder Of His 10 That Is in Doubt
description: As long as there is a death penalty in the United States, perhaps no man would seem so ripe a candidate for execution as Henry Lee Lucas, a former drifter now on Death Row for the rape and murder of a hitchhiker 19 years ago. The victim, never identified, was known as ''Orange Socks,'' the only items of clothing left on her body when it was discovered in a culvert off a Texas freeway.

title: New Bank Replaces Old In Hub of the Bronx
description: After being empty for a year, the former Bronx headquarters of Chase Manhattan Bank, at 369 East 149th Street in the Hub district, has become the the new headquarters of New York National Bank. The Chase branch, in a 12-story building, was closed in April 1997 after Chase merged with Chemical Bank.

title: A Little Help, Here And There, Lifts Bulls
description: Over the years, Michael Jordan's congregation has listened to him without nodding off or making grocery lists. Time has passed, and a message has seeped into their souls: never give in.

title: Belmont Slows Yanks, But Hapless Marlins Can't
description: The outcome seems predestined when the Yankees are playing the Florida Marlins -- a team bidding to become one of the greatest of all time versus one of baseball's all-time embarrassments. Yesterday, the real drama came via videotape.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 4 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the theater season and the Tony Awards misspells the surname of the director of ''The Beauty Queen of Leenane,'' a nominee for best play. The director is Garry Hynes, not Hines.

description: FOR more than two decades this city has been considering, and rejecting, development proposals for Davids Island, the 78-acre abandoned Army post off its coast.

description: TILZER-Ira L. May 25, 1914June 7, 1988. A decade of missing you. Forever, you will be in our hearts. With more love than ever, Louise and Leslie

description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Buzz Words; Who's Afraid of the Islamic Bomb?
description: FOR more than two decades, the prospect that a Muslim country could possess nuclear weapons has often been summed up in two words -- ''Islamic bomb'' -- a phrase that captured the imagination of some and terrified others.

title: Exploring Campaign Fund Limit
description: SPEAKER after speaker appealed to the County Board of Legislators to move on a campaign finance proposal that would give candidates taxpayer funds for their campaigns if they agreed to limit spending and the size of contributions.

title: Next Literary Stop: Balzac Territory
description: WHEN the French writer Honore de Balzac died of caffeine poisoning in 1850 at the age of 51 -- he was said to have consumed on the order of four dozen cups of coffee a day -- he had produced more than 100 major works, predominantly novels, all in 21 years. It was not just coffee that fueled this prodigious output; it was also genius. (In a clear case of professional envy, Robert Louis Stevenson qualified the use of that word by pronouncing Balzac ''an inarticulate Shakespeare.'')

title: The New Yorkers
description: HERE BUT NOT HERE

title: Loving The Boom; The Blue-Collar Millionaire
description: As a teen-ager growing up on Long Island in the 1970's, Robert Bertuglia Jr. used to get bored fast. ''Toys, cars, girls -- I'd go through one after another,'' he says. He barely graduated from Copiague High -- ''Basically I cheated my way through.'' But what he loved, what he gave up the beach for, skipped school for, quit sports for, what filled his free time and made his mind race, what never, ever bored him was work. ''I picked up my first lawn mower at 15,'' he says in a way that makes you envision Mickey Mantle reaching for his first Louisville Slugger. He started on neighbors' lawns. Then his mother, a waitress, began driving him around town, the power mower sticking out of the trunk of their Chevy. He took $250 from his earnings and bought a '58 Studebaker pickup to haul the mower. While still in high school he hired his first workers and began doing landscaping for businesses, too.

title: The World; A Global Divide on Abortion Splits Poor From Rich
description: IT has become an article of faith among those who oppose abortion in the United States that promoting abortion anywhere else, particularly in the world's poorest countries, is tantamount to an attack on the cultures of those countries. It is a new argument from the conservative right, but it echoes charges that the radical left used to make, to the effect that family planning programs targeted at the third world were a kind of neo-imperialistic genocide.

title: The Nation: The Price of Being Lewinsky; Dream Team, Nightmare Tab
description: MONICA LEWINSKY has her new legal dream team. She will also surely have bigger bills to go along with the bigger names now defending her.

title: May 31-June 6; Seriously Settling
description: Nearly four years after Orange County, Calif., filed for bankruptcy after losing $1.6 billion on a wrong-way bet on interest rates, the affluent county is about to get a big check. It announced a $400 million settlement with Merrill Lynch & Company, the brokerage firm that sold the county speculative securities that went sour. The settlement, a record for municipal finance, heads off a scheduled September trial in a $2 billion lawsuit the county brought against the firm.

title: Liberals and Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: A Formula to Regain Vanishing Farmland
description: If I read your article ''Farmland May Yield to Fairway'' (May 31) correctly, those who sold their development rights 21 years ago can now renege on their agreement merely by substituting the same quantity of acres, without any penalty. As I understand it, they had full use of the land for the purposes they agreed to and the $385,970 they received for development rights, as well as tax reductions. Now $385,000 invested could well be worth $2 million to $10 million. And what's the value of the tax exemptions?

title: Marred Card? It May Cost You.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERKA, HARRYETTA
description: PETERKA-Harryetta. The American Academy of Dramatic Arts announces with sorrow the tragic passing of Harryetta Peterka, Director of Instruction, on Tuesday, June 2. Herself a graduate of the Academy, she was a recipient of the Jehlinger Award in 1958, the highest honor bestowed upon an Academy student. She toured as a member of the school's post-graduate performance ensemble, the Academy Repertory Company, in the 1958-59 season, playing Abigail in ''The Crucible,'' and Elizabeth I in ''Young Elizabeth.'' She began teaching at the Academy in 1964 while still acting professionally, eventually becoming Director of the Evening School, and Associate Director of the Professional Training Program, prior to being named Director of Instruction in 1992. She is survived by her beloved husband, William Damon. To her students and colleagues, Harryetta was a unique and powerful force, a friend, mentor and guiding light. Her dedication to the theatre and to all the students who pursued a life in the theatre was without limit. Her love of the craft of acting forced her to continue to educate herself and those around her, and her love and concern for her students carried on beyond their enrollment at the Academy. She will be missed, but never forgotten, and she will live on in the hearts of those whose lives she touched. A memorial service will be held in the near future.

title: More Money for Transportation
description: Late last month, Congress passed legislation that calls for the Federal Government to spend $203 billion on highway and mass transit projects over the next six years. But the legislation also includes $9.3 billion for more than 1,800 smaller projects around the country selected by members of Congress for their districts. title: The Bag Wars
description: The battle of the Hermes bag is being waged. In one corner: the Kelly bag (above, bottom left and strip near right), popularized by Grace Kelly in the 1950's; in the other: the Birkin bag (top left and strip far right), named for the singer and actress Jane Birkin, who started carrying it in the mid-80's. Both bags are custom-made by hand and cost from $5,200 to $5,700 in calf to $14,000 to $24,000 in the finest crocodile, with an 18-month wait for orders. This spring, the battle spread to the Sotheby's and William Doyle auction houses: at Doyle, a 1950's crocodile Kelly bag sold for $5,175. Why wouldn't he believe this after what he had been through, from where he had come?

title: Consumed By The Boom; All Money, All the Time
description: A few years into the current boom, I was invited by a money manager to spend a night in the Connecticut countryside. As I had passed most of that day with him in a Park Avenue office, it did not strike me as especially forward of him to invite me home. But by midnight his wife had gone to bed and it was just the two of us, alone in his living room, with the clackety-clack of the crickets and the squeakety-squeak of a corkscrew opening a bottle of wine. We had arrived at a moment of genuine financial intimacy. Money had become personal. The money manager handed me a full wineglass and said, ''I'm going to tell you about some stocks you need to buy.'' In the next two hours this man described in detail four small companies that could change my life. He had researched them fully. Each one sounded better than the last. I tried to look relaxed about the whole thing, but I did not feel relaxed. As the deals became sweeter and sweeter, I twisted with desire in my chair. At 2 in the morning, having transformed me into a greedy pretzel, the man lowered his voice. ''Mike,'' he said, ''this fifth company, it's special.'' Pause. ''This is for you and your family.'' Pause. ''Buy it, put it away and let it make you rich.'' Pause.

title: May 31-June 6; Derailing at 125 M.P.H.
description: It was Europe's worst rail crash in more than 20 years. A high-speed express train hurtling through northern Germany at 125 miles per hour piled into the concrete support of an overpass, killing at least 95 people. Officials said it was most likely a broken wheel that derailed Inter-City-Express 884, a rare example of mechanical failure in a land that prides itself on its engineering prowess.

title: Being 13
description: Reading your articles was like a trip back to the hell of middle school. I'm one of those ''Tier 3'' types who surely isn't a trendsetter and doesn't want to be a follower. I'm 15, and I will vouch that everything you wrote was true. However, I don't fit well into your photo essay. Many girls do care about wearing the right clothes and makeup. Your photos of the girls in the tanning salon, putting on makeup, trying on clothes and getting their nails done show that quite well. But some girls care about things that are more important than fitting in. I applaud your photo of the girl who scored an 800 and a 750 on the SAT's.

title: Taking On a Megastore By Carving Out a New Niche

Two years ago Staples, the megastore with more than $5 billion in annual sales, opened a back entrance to its East 34th Street store directly across the street from King. And skeptics expected the smaller store, at 14 East 33d Street, to sell its very last toner cartridge.

title: Finding Monteverdi in the Now
description: ''ARIANNA,'' which will be given its first American performance today by the Opera Theater of St. Louis, is not exactly a new work and not exactly an old one. Quite who wrote it is also in doubt. According to the title page of the score, it is a ''lost opera by Claudio Monteverdi . . . composed again by Alexander Goehr,'' the English composer who, now 65, has steadily been gaining a reputation for music at once serious and playful, beautiful and quirky, as this is.

title: Ah, So It's the Housing Market He's Sore About
description: Godzilla

title: Shrugging At The Boom; Where's The Outrage?
description: Back in the gilded age, wall street was a synonym for economic turpitude. Cartoonists for the Hearst and Pulitzer chains dipped their pens in acid before depicting a stock tycoon; the bloated plutocrat in a tight suit checkered with dollar signs, diamond stickpin gleaming from his cravat, became a turn-of-the-century cliche.

title: Being 13
description: As a teen-ager, I found your photo album intriguing -- particularly the contrast between the worlds of the kids in Edina, Minn., and the kids in downtown Los Angeles. The teen-agers in the suburbs are dwelling on new outfits and posh spring vacations, while the ''West Side Playboys'' are going through harrowing initiations and watching their fellow gang members snort a line of cocaine.

title: For Tourists, Accidental And Otherwise
description: Armchair and adventure travelers have always had plenty of vicarious options, from the books of Lawrence Durrell and Margaret Mead to television shows from National Geographic and Charles Kuralt, not to mention the Discovery Channel. But what about those who don't have the vacation time or even the inclination to canoe down the Zambezi alone or feast on yak butter in Nepal?

title: McRae Forces Balk, Run, Victory
description: Brian McRae was dancing off third base with two outs in the sixth inning today, hoping that the Mets would find some way to nudge him the remaining 90 feet to score the game's first run and hoping that he would distract the Boston pitcher Tim Wakefield enough to help make that happen. The McRae Boogie worked.

title: POSTINGS: Fannie Mae Approvals on the Internet; A Mortgage In Four Minutes
description: Mortgage approval in as little as four minutes is now available on the Internet. Dan Rawitch, chief executive officer of Finet Holdings Company, a mortgage lender in Walnut Creek, Calif., said that last month, Finet, working with Fannie Mae, the nation's largest source of residential mortgage funds, began iQualify.com (http://www.iQualify.com) -- the first on-line mortgage application service that provides Fannie Mae pre-approvals.

title: Gap Finds a New Niche: Boxer Shorts by Fax
description: SO you're sitting at your desk on Friday, and a friend calls and invites you to the Hamptons for the weekend. You have no extra clothes with you, and you can't leave your desk because you told your boss you'd have that report on her desk an hour ago. Do you stew over what kind of pal would proffer such a last-minute invitation? Or do you go to the phone and order up a wardrobe?

title: Westchester Discovers Retarded Adults in Homeless Shelters
description: The homeless shelter at the Westchester County Airport here is tidier than many of its New York City cousins, but experts still would not consider it the most congenial place for a mentally retarded person to live.

title: Record Summer Looms, In Miles and Dollars
description: Americans will be traveling more this summer, and -- in spite of lower gasoline prices -- spending more in the process, according to the Travel Industry Association of America and AAA.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: FRENCH CARIBBEAN Accor Resort Hotels has summer packages in the French West Indies starting at $745 a person, double occupancy, for a six-night stay with three nights each in Guadeloupe and St. Barts. That price includes accommodation at the 40-room Sofitel Christopher on St. Barts and the 180-room Sofitel Auberge de la Vieille Tour on Guadeloupe. Air fare between the islands, airport transfers and daily Continental breakfast are included; air fare from the United States to the islands is extra. Both hotels are air-conditioned, and both have pools. The Auberge de la Vieille Tour has a beach on the property; the Sofitel Christopher is oceanfront but not on the beach. A six-night package to St. Barts alone is $780 a person, to Guadeloupe $530. The packages are available through Dec. 15 (except for Sept. 1 to Oct. 15 at the Sofitel Christopher, when the hotel is closed). Reservations are through the tour company, American Travel Abroad: (888) 738-9922.

title: When He Speaks, Many Listen
description: ONE by one, they filed into the Union Baptist Temple in Bridgeton, offering soft hellos with the intent of whispering goodbye to Ruth Taylor, one of their very own. It was the winter of 1989 and Ruth Taylor -- who had sung in the Union choir, who had always been a rock for other families in need, who was accessible, accepted and loved -- had suffered greatly from many illnesses, including one that cost her a leg late in life.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 38 of the Arts and Leisure section today about an extensive program of public art in Berlin includes an outdated reference to a proposal by the sculptor Richard Serra and the architect Peter Eisenman for a German national memorial to Jewish Holocaust victims. After the section went to press, Mr. Serra withdrew from the project.

title: Dara Eizenman, Abraham Musher
description: Dr. Dara Robin Eizenman, a daughter of Sandra M. and David B. Eizenman of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., is to be married today to Abraham Elias Musher, the son of Ruth W. Musher and Dr. David R. Musher of New York. Rabbi Daniel Alexander is to officiate at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREVES, RENATA COLOMBO
description: TREVES-Renata Colombo. Of Palm Beach, Florida, formerly of New York, died Saturday, June 6 in New York, surrounded by her loving family. Born in Turin, Italy on September 26, 1918. Music and the arts were her life long passion. Wife of the late Peter G. Treves. Mother of Charles and Vivian. Grandmother of Janine and Marina, grandmother-in-law to Vianney Habar. Member of the New York Stock Exchange. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the Juvenile Diabetes Association and the CFIDS (Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Association). Services will be held Monday, June 8, 1 PM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65 St., New York.

title: Objects, Found and Made, Add Up to Sculpture
description: THE sculptures of Bascha Mon are energized by opposition. Ms. Mon puts disparate objects together in ways that are at once audacious and subtle, sophisticated and ingenuous, compulsive and calculated. Made of both found and created objects, they are repositories of memories: Ms. Mon's personal fixed memories, often potently intersecting with the collective memory.

title: Three Into Two Did Go
description: INTROVERTED Annabert Van Wettum met extroverted Marianne Citroen in a first-grade class in The Hague in 1931. They became best friends. When the Nazis closed their school, they were separated.

title: Inspired by Balanchine, Now an Inspiration Herself
description: SUKI SCHORER perches precariously on a ballet barre, giving her the maximum overview of her students in Studio 3 at the School of American Ballet at Lincoln Center. At 5 feet 2 inches tall, she needs the extra height to conduct a rehearsal of Balanchine's challenging ''Donizetti Variations,'' one of three ballets presented this weekend at the school's Workshop Performance at the Juilliard Theater. Her eyes dart everywhere. Cajoling, joking, demonstrating, she demands perfection, just as Balanchine, her mentor, did when she danced for the New York City Ballet from 1959 to 1971.

title: Species Counts Don't Gauge Planet's Health; Politics of Biodiversity
description: To the Editor:

title: May 31-June 6; A Zambian, Freed
description: Kenneth D. Kaunda, one of Africa's grand old men, is a free man again. After keeping the former President in jail or under house arrest for more than five months, Zambian prosecutors dropped all charges against him. Their case had always looked weak. Mr. Kaunda was originally accused of plotting a bungled coup attempt last October.

title: Gore Woos Democrats For 2000 Bid
description: THE presence of Vice President Al Gore at the recent State Democratic Convention here showed how crucial Mr. Gore considers New York to his chances of winning the Presidency in 2000, and his words showed how crucial Westchester is to his strategy of capturing New York.

title: Vintage Vermont, For Purists
description: ON Aug. 15, 1934, Laurance S. Rockefeller, son of John D. Rockefeller Jr., married Mary French, whose family had long ties to Woodstock, Vt. The couple said their vows in the stately clapboard Congregational Church that stands less than a mile from her family's estate. As a couple, the Rockefellers would spend the next six decades using their prodigious energy, their interest in history and conservation, and their considerable wealth to help make Woodstock what Mr. Rockefeller thought of as ''one of the six most beautiful towns in America.'' The couple rebuilt the famous Woodstock Inn, acquired a nearby ski slope, gave millions toward historic preservation, donated land for recreational use, established a working farm and museum on property that had been owned by Mrs. Rockefeller's grandfather, Frederick Billings, a railroad baron, and buried the power lines in the center of town. But the couple's ultimate gift to the public is a new national park -- Vermont's first.

title: Beth Leventhal, Kenneth Fromkin
description: Dr. Beth Mindy Leventhal, an internist, and Dr. Kenneth Robert Fromkin, a cardiologist, are to be married today by Rabbi Philip Berkowitz at the Pearl River (N.Y.) Hilton.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: What We Keep By Elizabeth Berg. Random House, $23.

title: Off to France: A U.S. Coach Who Speaks Spanish
description: The United States had been eliminated, 1-0, by Brazil from the 1994 World Cup, and when the Americans returned to their team hotel in southern California, forward Eric Wynalda found himself talking to the assistant coach Steve Sampson at poolside.

title: Eager Freshman's Goal: 'Internationalize' Senate
description: At Harry Knobbe's Feed Yards the other day, Senator Chuck Hagel was holding forth on the global economy, the Asian financial crisis and the International Monetary Fund with a dozen or so hog and cattle farmers.

title: Crimson Dominates With Sweep at Yale
description: Harvard's varsity heavyweight crew capped its best season since 1992 with a decisive five-boat-length victory yesterday over its archrival, Yale, in the 133d racing of America's oldest intercollegiate sporting event, the Harvard-Yale Regatta, in Gales Ferry, Conn.

title: May 31-June 6; An AIDS Vaccine Gets A Go-Ahead for Testing
description: The Food and Drug Administration gave Vaxgen Inc. of South San Francisco the green light to test its AIDS vaccine among 5,000 uninfected volunteers in this country. The same vaccine is expected to be tested among 2,500 volunteers in Thailand later this year. Health officials say a vaccine is desperately needed to stem the AIDS epidemic. But results of these trials will not be known for four years. LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

title: Casinos and Atlantic City
description: It has been 20 years since casino gambling came to Atlantic City. Has the city been helped or harmed?

title: The World: Naivete at the C.I.A.; Every Nation's Just Another U.S.
description: NICCOLO MACHIAVELLI had it right: never assume the other guy will never do something you would never do. Too bad Machiavelli never worked for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: On Top of the World
description: THE GREAT HILL STATIONS OF ASIA

title: Cheryl Sladkin, Randolph Altschuler
description: Cheryl Kim Sladkin, a dancer with the Washington Ballet Company, is to be married today to Randolph Brody Altschuler, who graduated on Thursday from the Harvard Business School. Rabbi Stuart Weinblatt is to officiate at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington.

title: For Better Earnings, Try Bigger Write-Offs
description: While the stock market ended last week on a high note, pleased with the mix of economic reports, one little-noted piece of data had ominous implications for investors.

title: Marymount President to Retire
description: LIKE Jerry Seinfeld, some people know when to step down. Earlier this spring, Sister Brigid Driscoll, who has been president of Marymount College here since 1979, announced that she would retire in June next year. It was a move that took the trustees -- and campus -- by surprise.

title: Political Memo; State Party Conventions May Be Losing Relevance
description: As the New York State Republican convention sailed toward adjournment last week, the party's five candidates for office gathered on stage, raising their arms in victory as red, white and blue balloons tumbled from the ceiling and delegates swayed to Bruce Springsteen's ''Born to Run.''

title: Black Is Back at Bethpage, A Shrine for Public Golf
description: THE Black is back. This week, the wraps come off a yearlong, $2.9 million facelift of the legendary Black Course at Bethpage State Park, which has been primped and preened in preparation for hosting the U.S. Open golf championship in 2002. But long before the professional golfers curse the knee-high fescue and bottomless bunkers, the public will get to challenge what is now the area's toughest test of the game.

title: What I Really, Really Want Is to Quit
description: When Geri Halliwell, better known as Ginger Spice, announced a week ago that she had had enough of Spice Girl-dom, holders of EMI shares worried about the impact on their record company's stock price.

title: Betsy Morgan, Chad Gifford
description: Betsy Lake Morgan was married yesterday to Clarence Hamilton Gifford 3d at the Siasconset Union Chapel on Nantucket Island. The Rev. Stephen M. Sledesky, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Refugees, Musicians and Ferries; City Doesn't Treat Ferry Like a Tourist Attraction
description: To the Editor:

title: Valentine Seethes Because Piazza Must Sit
description: Mike Piazza spoke too optimistically about possibly pinch-hitting today. His swollen left hand prevented him from even swinging a bat, while Mets Manager Bobby Valentine spoke rather angrily about Boston's Pedro Martinez for injuring Piazza with an inside fastball on Friday night.

title: Being 13
description: Why devote most of an issue to 13-year-olds? If there is any compelling reason, it is probably their spending habits, and coverage would be more effective in the Business section.

title: Coordinating Efforts For the Disabled
description: Edmund Cortez is correct in calling for extended Medicare support for individuals with developmental disabilities who want to work (''Aiding Disabled Who Want to Work,'' May 9). Some current Federal regulations penalize those who enter the workplace by removing Medicare benefits.

title: Up And Down In The Boom; The Corporate Caste System
description: A corporate headquarters is a strange kind of community--not like Scarsdale, N.Y., or the South Bronx, where neighbors are generally in the same income bracket and send thier children to the same schools. At Met Life, at Madison Avenue and 23rd Street in Manhattan, the C.E.O. is a beloved figure who strives for a relaxed atmosphere. Even so, the employees--from the security guards to the secretaries to the vice presidents--inhabit a self-imposed caste system. While employees on different rungs of the ladder certainly get along, vast differences in position, prestige and, of course, salary from boundaries that aren't easily overridden.

title: Arguments on Ethics In 'Lawyers' at Emelin
description: WHEN theatergoers exit arguing over a play instead of continuing the conversation they had before it began, it is clear they were not just killing time or nodding off between dinner and dessert.

title: Lots of New Faces, but Watch Those Legs
description: They have all converged on France, from the Indomitable Lions of Cameroon to the Bafana-Bafana of South Africa; from the newly cocky English, who missed the party last time, to the shy Japanese; from Jamaica's Reggae Boyz to Brazil's Ro-Ro Boys, as the goal scorers Romario and Ronaldo are known.

title: 32 Teams, 1 Winner (Hint: Check the Netherlands)
description: Budget travel, automatic tellers and the Internet might be making the world smaller, but the World Cup keeps getting larger. When it began in 1930, there were 13 teams entered. When it was last held in 1994 in the United States, the number of participants had grown to 24, and it is now at 32. Here is a look at the players and teams the world will be talking about for the next five weeks. The teams in each of the eight groups have been listed in order of predicted finish. Only the top two in each group advance to the second round. CHRISHOPHER CLAREY

title: Ms. Barbaris, Mr. MacTaggart
description: Christine Marie Barbaris, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry Barbaris of Sea Cliff, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Ian Barry MacTaggart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry MacTaggart of Vero Beach, Fla. The Rev. Michael J. Torpey performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Boniface Martyr Church.

title: Abigail Aaron, Peter Neave
description: Abigail Emily Aaron, the daughter of Marion N. Aaron of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Alan E. Aaron, was married yesterday to Peter Charles Neave, a son of Linda S. Neave of Rowayton, Conn., and Alexander Neave of New York. The Rev. Mitzi M. Noble, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Transfiguration in Norfolk, Conn.

title: Doing the Arithmetic of the Avenues
description: Hunting for an address on an avenue in Manhattan without knowing the cross street does not have to be difficult. Drop the last figure, divide by 2 and add or subtract as indicated below. The answer is the nearest numbered cross street. This key does not apply to Broadway below Eighth Street because of the many streets with names instead of numbers.

title: Where the Past Haunts, Berlin Embraces the New
description: THE city that Hitler adorned with muscle-bound statues by Arno Breker and where East German Communists plastered images of Marxist stalwarts is set to get a mammoth new load of officially sanctioned art. For Berlin's latest incarnation as Germany's capital, the Federal Government plans to order more than $33 million of freshly painted Neo-Expressionist canvases, cerebral conceptual installations, neon sculpture and perhaps even earthworks.

title: THE GUIDE
description: 'Romeo and Juliet,'' 1998

title: This Year, the Jet Set Is Seeking Nirvana
description: ON a sunny morning last week, Bonnie Pressman sat in her office on the 10th floor of a gleaming Fifth Avenue tower. The black-matte telephone on her desk looked big enough to route the calls of a small city, and it wouldn't stop beeping and mewling. Two assistants hovered by the door, impatient to escort her to a meeting, while the noise of a jackhammer rose from the street.

title: Furs by John Galliano, With a Deep Bow to Casanova
description: OUTSIDE the Metropolitan Club on East 60th Street last Tuesday, a line of tan and entitled-looking guests waited to be admitted to a showing of John Galliano's first fur collection.

title: Burma Road
description: THE VOICE OF HOPE

title: A New Magazine for the East End
description: AN A-LIST local magazine has come to the Hamptons. Adding an s to its name and burnish to its appearance, Hampton Country has been reborn as Hamptons Country under a new owner, M. Shanken Communications, which publishes two national life-style magazines, Wine Spectator and Cigar Aficionado, and a trade journal, Food Arts.

title: The Nation; A Breaker of Molds Now Tries to Fit In
description: ASK Newt Gingrich to name a Speaker of the House who ran for President and, ever the historian, he will immediately say Henry Clay.

title: Two Radio Pirates to Drop Anchor
description: Inspired by a growing national microbroadcasting movement and a recent conference on pirate radio, a pair of low-power, unlicensed stations are preparing to start broadcasting to East Harlem and the South Bronx. The first station, called Kids Discovery Radio, or WKDR, is expected to begin transmission by the end of June, said Pedro Angel Rivera, the station's organizer, who recently purchased its transmitter from the organizers of Radio Free Berkeley, a pirate station in California.

title: Paris
description: The World Cup of soccer, being held in France beginning Wednesday and running through July 12, is the only sports event that can dwarf the Super Bowl and challenge the Olympics for global television ratings. And in peak tourist season, an estimated 300,000 to 350,000 soccer fans will swell the ranks in Paris.

title: Thrift Meets Glitz on the Post Road
description: THE dress draped over Amy Merrill's arm carried the original department store price tag of $39.99. But the tag that mattered read $16, and that's the kind of bargain Mrs. Merrill was getting on this particular dress.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ROCKING MY LIFE AWAY

title: Air Time
description: Jill Sage, a first grader at the H. Harold Van Sant School in Marlton, thinks it would be great if she could fly. Not only that, she painted a picture called ''Wouldn't It Be Great if I Could Fly,'' shown here. And not only that, the watercolor was named the outstanding visual arts entry in a national program called Reflections, run by the National P.T.A.

title: May 31-June 6; Avast!
description: One joy of working at The New York Times is the interchange with readers -- smart, well-educated folks who care, a lot, about their newspaper's standards. But it's an endless revelation to discover what, precisely, floats their boats.

title: Currier & Ives, Popular Masters of 19th-Century Lithography
description: MENTION Currier and Ives and most people think of images of 19th-century home life -- of lovers whispering in each other's ear; elegant children holding fluffy kittens; idyllic farmhouses set in a snowy landscape.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Bill Clinton could have taken us to a different level on so many things, the issue of race, for example, but nothing's come of it. The great shame is that all our so-called moral attention is focused on alleged White House sex scandals and not on tremendous tasks like integrating the poorest families into our midst.''

title: Sold for $1, a House for Low-Income Residents Raises Ire
description: In a neighborhood with a booming real estate market, it may well be the deal of the decade: a four-story brownstone bought for just $1. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is selling the building, at 122 Hoyt Street, for less than the cost of a subway token. For the buyers, a nonprofit corporation, it is a great deal. But some neighbors are complaining it's a raw one.

title: Crimes
description: Lucas Davenport, the ''bad dog'' Minneapolis homicide detective who leaves his tooth marks all over John Sandford's police procedurals, doesn't even get his back up, in SECRET PREY (Putnam, $24.95), when the C.E.O. of a big bank is shot to death during an executive hunting trip in the Minnesota woods. Although ''evil was interesting'' to the intelligent, emotionally remote Davenport, ''he detected no evil in the killing. Spite, probably; stupidity, possibly. Greed. Anger. But not real evil.''

title: At Ease in Norfolk
description: ANY New Yorker who has passed the Empire State Building a million times without going to the top will understand how an attraction can invite neglect simply by being close at hand. Such was the state of affairs between me and Norfolk, Conn.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Weehawken's 10-Year Wallflower Lands a Tenant
description: CONSTRUCTED nearly a decade ago but never occupied, the 312,000-square-foot office building at 300 Boulevard East in Weehawken has been the Hudson County riverfront's reigning wallflower.

title: Starr Seeks Notes on Foster from Lawyer
description: Kenneth W. Starr's effort to bring White House aides and Secret Service agents before his grand jury has provided much of the recent legal drama here. But it is his pursuit of notes from a lawyer's interview with a man who has been dead nearly five years that, of all the disputes surrounding the independent counsel's investigation, could ultimately matter most to anyone who has ever consulted a lawyer about a potentially embarrassing problem.

title: Shirley Povich Dies at 92; Washington Sports Columnist
description: Shirley Povich's sports column ran in The Washington Post on Friday, which was not unusual, since his columns have appeared in The Washington Post for 74 years, or since he began working there in 1924, at age 19. Mr. Povich's column Friday, headlined ''Recent Baseball Feats Require Footnotes,'' was literary yet earthy, opinionated yet generous, topical yet filled with historical perspective, and a pleasure to read, none of which was unusual.

title: Political Calendar
description: Besides South Carolina, Maine, Virginia and North Dakota will also hold primaries on Tuesday. In Arkansas, Democrats will hold a primary runoff to elect a Senate nominee.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the New York City Council's proposed budget referred incorrectly in some copies to a speaker praising it at a news conference. He was Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, not Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Citing More Vetoes In State Budget
description: I am appalled that your article on May 3 (''Disappointment Follows Vetoes of State Spending''), which mentioned Gov. George E. Pataki's cuts to Westchester, left out entirely the outrageous cuts in the health budget.

title: Endpaper; Can I Have That in a Plain Brown Wrapper, Please?

description: To the Editor:

title: Bookend; Octavio Paz: In Defense of Poetry
description: Octavio Paz practiced poetry like a secret religion. He dwelt in its mysteries, he invoked its sacraments, he read its entrails, he inscribed its revelations. Writing was for him a primordial act, and he stared down at the blank page like an abyss until it sent him reeling over the brink of language. The poems he brought back are filled with ancient wonder and strangeness, hermetic wisdom, a dizzying sense of the sacred. They are magically uprooted from silence. Here is his eerie little poem ''Escritura'' (''Writing''): ''I draw these letters / as the day draws its images / and blows over them / and does not return.''

title: Refugees, Musicians and Ferries; Band's Skirmish Raises Question on Public Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Dazed By The Boom; Satisfaction Not Guaranteed
description: Money, like sex, can make us do things we would not do otherwise. By exposing us to moral conflict, it divides us against ourselves: one part wants money, but another part wants something else. As it becomes less and less clear what money can't buy, it becomes increasingly difficult to describe what that something else could be. Compared with the glamour of wealth, the old alternatives -- personal salvation, immortality, honor, love or even justice -- look merely pious or quaint. Now, despite differences of race or culture or gender, in the so-called free market, money has supposedly become the universal object of desire. And since we know who we are by knowing what we want, it is immensely reassuring to have sorted this out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHENHEIT, IRWIN M.
description: SHENHEIT-Irwin M. Of Maplewood, NJ in his 88th year. Died June 4, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Jeanette. Loving father of Barbara Sue. Grandfather of Laurel, Ilisa and Adam. The proud great-grandfather of Ariel. Donations in his memory to the heart fund.

title: Anne Spencer, Todd Cheema
description: Anne McLean Spencer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James A. E. Spencer of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Todd Douglas Cheema, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Inder S. Cheema of Paris. The Rev. Ronald F. Allison performed the ceremony at the Stanwich Congregational Church in Greenwich.

title: Isabel Rose, Jonathan Ezrow
description: Isabel Rose, a daughter of Susan and Elihu Rose of New York, was married last night to Jonathan Ezrow, a son of Hjordis Ezrow and Dr. Leonard Ezrow of Maplewood, N.J. Rabbi Peter J. Rubenstein officiated at the Plaza in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNSTON, CLARY
description: DUNSTON-Clary. Peacefully on June 5, 1998 at age 98. Beloved mother of Marietta Moskin and grandmother of two. She will be missed. A memorial service to be announced.

title: Park Shakespeare
description: To the Editor: Marie Winn's delightful account of Central Park (''In Just 50 Blocks, a World of Choice,'' May 17) mentions the Shakespeare statue, which was not finally dedicated until 1872, although the empty pedestal was unveiled in 1864.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Chocolate Jesus By Stephan Jaramillo. Berkley, paper, $12.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Truman Show

title: Hats Add Personality to Summer Casual
description: GIVEN all the 20th-century icons who have been resurrected and paid homage to in the name of fashion, nothing is more curious than the pedestal erected for that hapless bungler of television fame Gilligan. Or so it would appear from last summer's vogue for the fishing hat, which Bob Denver almost never took off his head in the three years that ''Gilligan's Island'' ruled the airwaves.

title: Converting to a Roth I.R.A.? First, Check the Calculator
description: ALMOST everywhere you turn, the financial services industry is offering free software to analyze whether you should convert your traditional individual retirement account to a new Roth I.R.A., which allows tax-free withdrawals.

title: Jazz's Big Man Is Stuck in a Rut
description: Scottie Pippen whispered into Karl Malone's ear as he stepped to the foul line for two crucial free throws in the final seconds of Game 1 of last season's N.B.A. finals. ''The Mailman doesn't deliver on Sundays,'' Pippen coyly told him.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARONSTEIN, HENRY
description: ARONSTEIN-Henry. Think of you always, miss you. The pain doesn't go away. Happy Birthday. Love, Margie, Susan and Jesse

title: Changing Places
description: UNDERSTANDING MEN'S PASSAGES Discovering the New Map of Men's Lives. By Gail Sheehy. 292 pp. New York: Random House. $24.

title: Grieving Seles Found Serenity on the Court
description: She uses the word ''weird'' to describe her state of mind, the heightened consciousness, the serenity. The Magyar Valley Girl is long gone, the giggle long lost or suppressed. She is now a woman, a woman in mourning, a European-American woman in black, putting her grief into her backhand.

title: Two Mansions Join the Newports Tour Loop
description: Two more historic houses are opening their doors to visitors in Newport, R.I., this summer. Both are recent acquisitions of the Preservation Society of Newport County.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about Councilman Kenneth Fisher's decision against renominating two members of Community Board 1 in Brooklyn quoted a word incorrectly in a letter to those members from Borough President Howard Golden. The letter read, ''I must inform you that Council Member Kenneth Fisher has decided not to renominate you for appointment to membership on Community Board 1''; it did not say ''not to reappoint.'' While council members nominate some community board members, the Borough President appoints all of them.

title: Corrections
description: The Vows column last Sunday, about the marriage of Rhonda M. Edwards and Henry J. Powell, misidentified the bride's hometown, where the wedding took place. It is Mount Vernon, N.Y., not New Vernon, N.J. The column also misspelled the name of the New York hotel where the couple once attended a musical performance. It is the Carlyle, not Carlisle.

title: A Wide View
description: Whether you're a sports fan stuck in the nose-bleed seats or a summer concertgoer without the energy to push to the front, Bushnell's Xtra-Wide binoculars may be the ticket.

title: Oklahoma Incumbent May Run Yet Again
description: For 14 years between 1976 and 1990, Wes Watkins represented Oklahoma's Third Congressional District, in the southeastern part of the state, as a Democrat. Then he left Capitol Hill and his party, ran two unsuccessful races for Governor as an independent, and eventually settled into a business career.

title: Gingrich Trip Showed Support for Mideast Ally
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAF, DR. ULRICH
description: NAF-Dr. Ulrich. A noted biologist and botanist died on May 1, 1998 at Montefiore Medical Center, Bronx, New York at the age of 76 after an extended illness. A resident of Riverdale, New York for over 30 years, he was born and raised in Switzerland where he served in the Swiss Army at the border with Germany during the Second World War. Dr. Naf developed his interest in nature as a boy observing and studying the play behavior of mountain goats in the Alps. He moved to the United States in the late 40's and obtained a Ph.D. in Biology from Yale University in 1953. For several years he did research at Rockefeller Institute on a variety of topics, including tumors that occurred spontaneously on hybrid tobacco plants, before joining the faculty of Manhattan College in 1962. At Manhattan College, he concentrated his research on the reproductive processes of fern plants. He retired from Manhattan College in 1981 as a Professor of Biology. Also an expert on birds and their behavior, butterflies, mammals and other natural elements, he continued this work after retirement, taking particular interest in the fauna and flora of neighboring Van Cortlandt Park, where he tracked the appearance and disappearance of various species of plants and animals. He wrote for several scholarly journals, including ''The American Journal of Botany,'' ''Science,'' and ''Nature'' and was a member of numerous environmental organizations, including the American Botanical Society and American Society of Plant Physiologists. He is survived by his sister and brother-in-law Heidi and Albert Laeuchli Naef and two brothers and sister-inlaws, Walter and Esther Naef and Robert and Christine Naef, all residing in Switzerland. Funeral arrangements were private.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; A Different Drummer
description: Laurie Gwen Shapiro's unfortunately titled but endearingly quirky first novel, THE UNEXPECTED SALAMI (Algonquin, $18.95), is a 1990's screwball comedy told in alternating chapters by two dysfunctional characters: a spoiled, neurotic, misanthropic New Yorker named Rachel Ganelli and her ''quasi boyfriend,'' Colin Dunforton, an aging Aussie bass player. While in Australia, rooming with the members of a less-than-talented band called the Tall Poppies, Rachel witnesses the apparent mob execution of the Poppies' heroin-addicted ex-drummer, Stuart, during the shooting of a rock video. When she runs back to New York to escape questioning (which would have tipped off the authorities to her long-expired visa), she is astonished to find the dead man ordering a tuna on rye at Eisenberg's Sandwich Shop. It seems the ''hit'' was staged by the band in order to boost its sagging fortunes. And the scheme works. In no time at all, Colin and the Tall Poppies have a recording contract with a major label and are booked to tour the United States. Meanwhile, Stuart, friendless and going through withdrawal, is taken in by the Ganelli family: Rachel; her brother, Frank; their Jewish mother and Italian-American dad. Shapiro captures Rachel's voice and New York attitude well, and the slightly dim Colin's travails on the concert tour are described in a dead-on, testosterone-addled style. The plot twists its way through the band's ill-fated tour, Stuart's unlikely rehab and various couplings, most of them hilariously unsuccessful. The author manages to keep her disarmingly messy plot on the rails through many fast turns, and she skillfully avoids -- if barely, at times -- having it all sound too cute, a tough task with a cast of characters so perilously sit-com ready. Despite the risks, ''The Unexpected Salami'' winds up being unexpectedly delightful. Anthony Bourdain

title: Opting Out Of The Boom; Why More Blacks Don't Invest

A tenacious businessman, he achieved what for his generation of blacks was an impressive degree of financial security.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Our Gangs
description: ''Most people don't care about us; why would they want a book about us?'' asks Scooby, one of the youths whose faces stare out from the pages of EAST SIDE STORIES: Gang Life in East LA (Power House Books, $39.95), Joseph Rodriguez's photographic exploration of violence and kinship in a community often ignored or feared by mainstream America. A few of the photographs are dark, Weegee-inspired shots of crime scenes, urban street life and funerals. But for the most part, Rodriguez's images -- once you look past the guns that often appear in the foreground -- resemble a collection of family portraits, yearbook candids and backyard snapshots (one of them even complete with a napping dog). Young gang members pose with their smiling children, or sit around the kitchen table with their mothers and sisters. Fellow gang members sit outside on the steps after school. ''East Side Stories'' is ultimately a profile of family, whether it is the nuclear family, the gang or the entire Mexican-American population in East Los Angeles. Various gangs are brought together in the book -- appropriately, because underneath the rivalries, they are all members of the same community; Rodriguez reminds us this community is also part of our country. Christina Cho

description: Catherine Eve Patterson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George D. Patterson 3d of New York, was married yesterday to Jonathan Hunter Ogilvy, a son of Dr. Heather M. Ogilvy of Portola Valley, Calif., and Dr. James A. Ogilvy of Berkeley, Calif. The Rev. Steven Crowson performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Shelter Island, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENESSEY, ZOLTAN
description: KENESSEY-Zoltan. Died on June 4, 1998 at the age of 68 after a valiant struggle with brain cancer. A brilliant and highly cultivated intellectual, he was a leader in international statistics. His career spanned the globe, from the Hungarian Statistical Office in Budapest and the United Nations in New York to the Federal Reserve in Washington and, most recently, the International Statistical Institute in the Netherlands. He will be profoundly missed by all those who knew him. His loss is deeply mourned by his loving wife Stephanie, his children Stefania and Alec, his son-in-law Andrew, and his adoring grandchildren Dora and Jordan. Funeral services are Tuesday, June 9 at 10:00 AM at the National Presbyterian Church at 4101 Nebraska Avenue, NW, in Washington, DC.

title: POSTINGS: Madison Ave. Skyline Panels Yield to Developers; A Mosaic Jazz Age Memory
description: Long after the Jazz Age skyline of slender, cloud-piercing towers in Lower Manhattan had been compromised by mammoth modern boxes, New Yorkers could still get a glimpse of that romantic silhouette in a most unlikely spot -- the corner of Madison Avenue and 47th Street.

title: So What Color T-Shirt Befits a Board Meeting?
description: Because everybody seems to know what Friday means, the problem with Casual Friday is clearly the word ''casual.'' Some people interpret the dictionary definition -- informal -- to mean going without a necktie or jacket. To others, it means torn jeans, tiny tennis skirts, flip-flops or T-shirts that say ''I'm Low on Estrogen'' or ''Got a Gun.'' Maybe things will get better when the lexicographers roll up their sleeves and provide a better definition.

title: Dr. Halvorsen, Mr. Matthews

title: Corrections

title: Corrections

description: THE UNFINISHED PRESIDENCY Jimmy Carter's Journey Beyond the White House. By Douglas Brinkley. Illustrated. 586 pp. New York: Viking. $29.95.

title: The View From/Hartsdale; Rolling Back 100 Years To Golf Club's Beginning
description: EXCEPT for the brick high-rise buildings peeking over the tree line, the scene could have been 100 years ago: soft early evening sunlight, gently sloping greens, people playing golf using hickory-shaft clubs and molded rubber-like gutta percha balls. The men were wearing knickers, knee socks and wingtip shoes; the ladies, ankle-length skirts, crisp blouses and straw boaters. At each hole, they would pause and consult a list to see what they needed -- a brassie, a spoon, a mashie, a niblick or some other club -- for a particular shot.

title: Residency Rules
description: Citing his city's charter, Mayor Ernest D. Davis of Mount Vernon said he would enforce a rule requiring officials to live in the municipality. Mayor Davis, explaining that he has been criticized for not cracking down on high-ranking officials who are nonresidents, said he had been focusing on other things during his first term in office.

title: May 31-June 6; Hold That Toast
description: A well-known Bordeaux wine chateau, Giscours, was charged by the French Government with fraudulent winemaking practices. According to indictments handed down in Bordeaux, Giscours' winemakers stretched their good stuff by using wine from a lesser region, mixing one year's wine with another's, adding sugar to boost alcoholic content and soaking wood chips in the vats to simulate aging in a barrel.

title: The World; Even the French Hate This Strike
description: TRANSPORTATION strikes are an annoying fact of life in France, yet most people sympathize with the strikers when the subways shut down or truckers block the highways. After all, truck drivers and railway workers don't make much money, and employers seldom penalize workers for not showing up during transit strikes, so it's easy to wish the strikers well.

title: IN BRIEF
description: A group of people involved in the occult who stole a skull from a crypt in Passaic County last year didn't get away with their macabre scheme, but once they were caught, police found they could be charged only with a disorderly persons charge of vandalism. Assembly Majority Leader Paul DiGaetano, Republican of Passaic, is the sponsor of a bill released unanimously by the Assembly Judiciary Committee last week that would make grave robbing, and unlawfully entering a tomb, a crime with a penalty of up to 10 years in prison and a fine of up to $150,000. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: (Even) Jazz Makes the Leap to Cyberspace
description: COMPUTERS speak in many different voices, but the one coming out of the PC on Bret Primack's desk is likely to startle even the most jaded of Web surfers. Low, amused and overcareful, it sounds suspiciously like a man who has just taken a good-size shot of heroin, and not without reason: the speaker is Charlie Parker, jazz's best-known junkie. ''I had the pleasure to meet Miles for the first time in St. Louis when he was a youngster,'' says the digitized Parker, referring to Miles Davis, the subject of www.milesdavis.com, an interactive Web site designed by Mr. Primack that opened for public viewing two weeks ago.

title: By Mayor's Calculation, A Hole in Council's Budget
description: A day after the City Council defied Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani by passing a budget without his consent, he struck back yesterday by declaring that New York would collect less money next year than the Council had assumed -- meaning the brand-new budget has a big-old hole. The move escalated a game of political brinkmanship, with higher property taxes as the stakes.

title: Would-Be Warriors of Kosovo: Fit Mainly to Die
description: A local gun merchant, his handkerchief hanging out of his green camouflage cap to keep his neck from roasting in the afternoon sun, reached into the trunk of an old black Audi where he had a pile of assault rifles.

title: G.O.P. Trickery in the House
description: Campaign finance reform has been declared dead many times by Newt Gingrich and his eager pallbearers only to rise again with more support. But with the House set to open its long-deferred debate on overhauling campaign finance laws, the Speaker has come up with another strategy to squelch reform in the form of a parliamentary rule to allow hundreds of amendments. This sneaky attempt to sow legislative chaos and run out the clock is another abuse of power by the Speaker. But advocates can win by standing up to the Georgia obstructionist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SESNON HANCOCK, MARGARET (NEE JOHNSON)
description: SESNON HANCOCK - Margaret (nee Johnson). Beloved mother of Sara Stoker Kendall of New York and Richard C. Stoker of Miami, Florida, and the late Henry Lauren Stoker, Jr., and stepmother of John Hancock, Jr., Linda Hancock Florie, Carol Hancock Chiaverini, and Richard Hancock, died June 2 in Miami Beach, Florida, after a brief illness. Born October 20, 1907, in Anson, Texas, to Mary E. Morrow Johnson and Albert W. Johnson, banker. Graduate of Juilliard School of Music. Member of the California Club, the Founders League of Los Angeles, Regent of the DAR, National Society, Magna Carta Dames, Texas Society-Colonial Dames XVII Century, Plantagenet Society, Sovereign Colonial Society - Americans of Royal Descent, Assistance League of Southern California. Deeply committed to bettering the cultural activities of the community, she was a benefactor of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the Los Angeles Museum of Natural History, Los Angeles Light Opera, International Committee of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Association, a volunteer at the Hospital of the Good Samaritan and St. James' Episcopal Church. This lovely Texas rose was not only an accomplished pianist and most gracious lady, she was a champion skeet shooter and golfer and her indomitably generous spirit will live forever in all our hearts. Margaret is also survived by her sister Audrey, her brother Albert, many loving nieces and nephews and 16 grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. The funeral service will be at St. James' Episcopal Church, Los Angeles, Friday, June 12, at 2 PM. Burial at Forest Lawn, Glendale. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to Auburn Seminary Multifaith Programs, 3041 Broadway at 121 St., New York, NY 10027.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMA, EDWARD J.
description: HERMA-Edward J. Of Lighthouse Point, FL. Passed away Friday, June 5, 1998, at The Congregational Home of Brookfield, WI, at the age of 88 years. Preceded in death by his wife Ruth and granddaughter Leigh. Dear father of Janice Herma of Boca Raton, FL, and John F. (Susan) Herma of Elm Grove, WI. Loving grandfather of Kyle and Drew. Before becoming chief executive of the far-flung global telecommunications company Cable and Wireless P.L.C. two years ago, Mr. Brown, an American, had been outside the United States only twice.

title: Evoking Nostalgia, Evolving New Sounds
description: Sometime during Andrew Hill's show at the Knitting Factory on Friday night, as part of the Texaco Jazz Festival, it became clear that he was producing the equivalent of a perfect game in baseball. Tune after tune rolled out and Mr. Hill, a major jazz pianist from the 1960's, was equaling his work for the Blue Note label of the time. The music, filled with long written passages, riffs and solos that were barely contained by the material, reached a point where its idiom wasn't important; it was music, played at an extremely high level.

That first installment of the 20th-Century Masters series attracted more attention than the rest of the hall's musical offerings combined. Not surprisingly, the series has become an anchor of the programming plans for the hall for the next few seasons.
