title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAZIN, ALFRED
description: KAZIN-Alfred. With profound sadness, the faculty, students and staff of the Graduate School and University Center of The City University of New York mourn the passing of Alfred Kazin, our great teacher and man of letters, who was Distinguished Professor Emeritus of English, as well as one the nation's most eminent literary critics. He loved literature and, above all, he loved the literary word, and he imparted this love and appreciation to generations of students and to countless readers of his own books and articles. He was a national treasure and our treasure as well. He was a proud ''walker in the city,'' and we will miss him greatly. Our deepest sympathy to his family. Frances Degen Horowitz, President

title: Report Tying Abortion To Welfare Is Rejected
description: A team of Rutgers University researchers hired by the New Jersey government to examine the effects of the state's new welfare policy found that it has contributed to an increase in abortions, but the state has rejected the findings, and asked for revisions of the report.

title: State Senator From the Bronx Withdraws Bid for U.S. House
description: Larry B. Seabrook, a State Senator from the Bronx who had long planned to oppose Representative Eliot L. Engel, a fellow Democrat, said yesterday that he would not run for Congress this year but would prepare for a Congressional campaign in two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBARD, HARRIS T.
description: GILBARD-Harris T. Beloved brother-in-law of Helen and Shelly Rodbell and cherished uncle of Hank and Gerry Alpert, Alain and Ellen Roizen, and their children David, Brooke, Erica and Remy. His gentle spirit, profound goodness and devoted caring will be greatly missed by all who had the good fortune to know him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, WILLIAM O.
description: JOHNSTON-William O. Of Henderson, KY. Died in New York City on June 4, 1998. A devout Episcopalian and founder and President of the Episcopal Churchpeople for a Free Southern Africa. He devoted his life to the struggle for freedom in Africa and to racial and social justice for all people. He will be sorely missed. A funeral service will be held at Fernwood Cemetery in Henderson on Thursday, June 11. New York memorial service to be announced. Contributions to Greenpeace in lieu of flowers.

title: Cable Difficulties May Thwart HDTV Debut
description: After more than a decade of planning, digital high-definition television broadcasts are to begin in just a few months, and so is the sale of HDTV sets.

title: Telemedicine Getting a Test in Efforts to Cut Costs of Treating Prisoners
description: Universal health care is a reality in one part of the United States: prison.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column on Friday about the novelist David Foster Wallace used his surname incorrectly at one point. He is Mr. Wallace, not Mr. Foster.

title: Editorial Observer; The Curious Parable of the Mideast Mayors
description: It is an odd conjunction of opposing political cultures. Turkey, the emblem of secular governance in the Middle East, and Iran, the heartland of Islamic fundamentalism, are both resisting powerful internal political movements by prosecuting the Mayors of their largest cities, Istanbul and Teheran.

title: Georges E. Seligmann, 102, Art Dealer
description: Georges E. Seligmann, a Manhattan dealer who sold works of art to major museums around the world, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 102.

title: Essay; No Slots for Tots
description: Confession time: at the age of 13, I was avidly watching a crap game in the stairwell of Joan of Arc Junior High in Manhattan when a monitor caught us. Penalty: no diploma or handshake from the principal at graduation. Ma gave me hell.

title: Mets Seem Out of It In Fenway Sleepwalk
description: The Mets looked like a team in a trance or a team anxious to return home after an 11-game road trip or a team that could not see very clearly because the persistent rain pelted 25 pairs of eyes. Actually, the Mets looked like all of the above and worse tonight while tumbling to the Red Sox, 5-0.

title: The awards are flowing freely, and many are going to agencies owned by Omnicom Group.
description: THE advertising awards season continues in full swing as five organizations have bestowed honors for television and radio commercials, art direction, corporate citizenship and fragrance advertising. Interestingly, many of those awards went to agencies owned by Omnicom Group.

description: KATZMAN-Sidney. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Marc and Lori, Alan and Melinda. Loving grandfather of Amanda, Eric, Bryan, Brianna and Nicole. Also survived by sister Bertha Ozer. Services today, 12 noon, at I.J. Morris Inc., 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, L.I. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Diabetes Foundation, or Temple Shalom of Westbury, 675 Brookside Court, Westbury, NY 11590.

Loving father of Scotson Lindsay (Daphne Milliken) Webbe, Richard White Webbe and Margaret Webbe (James Hodge) Colley. Cherished grandfather of Blaire Milliken, Kate Lindsay, Hope Daphne and Henry Scotson Michelson Webbe, Andrew Lodge and Emily Sears Webbe, Scotson Webbe and John Wilson Colley. title: Industry View; Cisco Systems takes on the really big boys, in a competition over new technology for routing data.
description: For most of the last decade, Cisco Systems Inc. has been steamrolling competitors in data networking. Its routers and switches dominate the Internet and corporate networks that try to get disparate sorts of computers to talk to each other.

title: A Heart of Snow and Ice Undone by Love's Fire
description: The expense of producing new full-evening story ballets these days has nearly guaranteed the demise of the genre. But American Ballet Theater persists. On Friday night, the company presented the much-anticipated New York premiere of ''The Snow Maiden'' at the Metropolitan Opera House. Was the lavish $1.2 million production worth the gamble? The answer is a slightly qualified yes.

title: Mets' Piazza Bristles At Brushback Words
description: Forget about giving Mike Piazza a bat and Pedro Martinez a baseball to settle their continuing dispute about Martinez's inside fastball that plunked Piazza in the left hand on Friday night.

description: SATTENSPIEL - Charlotte. On June 5, 1998. Beloved wife of Bertram. Loving mother of Sigmund and Abby. Adored grandmother of Dina and Karen. Dear sister of Anatol and David Linder and the late Benjamin Linder. Private services and interment were held.

description: Group A

description: Helen Carter, a singer and musician who was part of the Carter family dynasty of country-music entertainers, died on Tuesday at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville, Tenn. She was 70 and lived in Dickson, Tenn.

title: Search for Two Armed Fugitives in Utah Town Is Scaled Back
description: Police reopened this small San Juan River town to traffic from the outside this morning and said they would cut back their search for two armed fugitives who are suspects in the killing of a police officer.

description: A trend line in the World Stock Markets chart in the Money & Business section on Sunday was mislabeled. It should have said Russian Index, not German Index.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLIN, KATHRYN I. (SCANLON)
description: CARLIN-Kathryn I. (Scanlon). Age 89 years. Of Cairo, NY. Died Sunday, June 7, 1998, at Eden Park Nursing Home, Catskill, NY after a long illness. She was born in Yonkers, NY, May 12, 1909 and was the daughter of the late Edward J. and Ida (Johnstone) Scanlon. Mass of the Christian Burial will be celebrated Wednesday at the Sacred Heart Church, Cairo. Interment will take place in the Pinelawn National Cemetery next to her late husband, Dr. John J. Carlin, who predeceased her in 1968. Kay received her Ph.D. at Fordham University and also was Administrator of Fordham University. She was also a member of the Cairo Golden Age Club, a member of the Greene County Citizens Council, a member of the Advisory Board of the Office of the Aging, a member of the Health Aide Advisory Board, a member of the New York State Statewide Senior Action Council, a member of the Greene County Rivertown Senior Citizens, a member of the Greene County Board of Elections, a member of the Columbia-Greene Intercounty Board of Seniors, a member of the National Retired Teachers Association, a member of the Cairo Democratic Club, a member of the Pi Delta Kappa, and a communicant of the Sacred Heart Church of Cairo. Her brother Joseph Scanlon predeceased her. Survivors are a niece, Anita Della Fera of Jackman, ME and a nephew, Dr. Jack Scanlon of Cambridge, MD. Relatives and friends are invited to call at the Richards Funeral Home, 383 Bross St., Cairo, NY, Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

description: In the banking industry's latest megamerger, the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis and Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco plan to join forces and may announce the $34 billion deal as early as today, according to people close to both companies.

title: WORLD CUP PROFILE: FRANCE '98 -- The Master of the Quick Fix; An Enigmatic Milutinovic, an Equally Enigmatic Nigeria
description: ELINCOURT SAINTE MARGUERITE, France, June 7 -- His top goalkeeper has a broken arm. The news media are demanding his head. In recent exhibitions, his players have done nothing creative with their feet. And for democracy to overcome military rule in Nigeria, some believe, it is better for his team to fail than to succeed in the World Cup.

title: Now, a Set Of Rivalries For the Colts
description: Victory Gallop has a more important and prominent nose than Cyrano de Bergerac or Pinocchio. His narrow margin of victory in Saturday's 130th Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park not only prevented Real Quiet from capturing the Triple Crown -- and a $5 million bonus -- but it also reopened the race for championship honors among this year's talented crop of 3-year-olds.

Church, Deer Park. Entombment to follow at Pine Lawn Memorial Park.

Beloved father of Garrett Goodbody, Jr. and Ducky Goodbody Bancroft. Beloved step-father of Dr. John Woodland and Christy Krueger. Adored grandfather of Kelly and Alexander Bancroft. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Alumni Fund of Williams College, Williamstown, MA 01267 or hospice.

Should friends desire, contributions to the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

description: Two performances within the Texaco New York Jazz Festival at the Knitting Factory on Saturday night overturned convention. Charles Lloyd's quartet found mystery within comfortable parameters; Mark Dresser's trio gave architecture to the void.

description: Fire marshals spent yesterday slowly searching what was left of a row of Brooklyn buildings in search of definitive clues to what caused a five-alarm blaze that killed a fire lieutenant and left a fire captain severely burned and clinging to life, fire officials said.

title: Not Just 'Larry King Live'
description: It is hard to know what came first -- the idea of partnerships between Time-Warner's weekly magazines and Turner Broadcasting's all-news network CNN, or the idea of changing CNN's humdrum reputation.

title: Fantasies From the Northwest, With a Dose of Reality
description: When the novelist Ernest Callenbach imagined Ecotopia, he was cooking up an environmentalist's dream. His imaginary republic, formed by the secession of Northern California along with the states of Oregon and Washington, was an autonomous society free from the excesses of American expansionism. Little did he know that his concept would flourish in another realm: the West Coast underground rock scene.

title: Garment Lawsuit Plaintiff Is Dead
description: The owner of a Brooklyn sweater factory who had accused Liz Claiborne and the nation's leading garment industry union of conspiring to destroy his business has died of a heart attack at his home in Monsey, N.Y., according to his lawyers.

title: N.R.A. Tries to Improve Image, With Charlton Heston in Lead
description: Weary of perceptions that it is an extremist organization out of touch with mainstream America, the National Rifle Association is going on the offensive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEZZO, RICHARD
description: YEZZO-Richard. The Board of Governors, members and staff of the Greater New York Hospital Association deeply regret the untimely and tragic passing of Richard Yezzo. His wonderful mix of humor and compassion will be sorely missed by everyone who had the pleasure of knowing him. He will be remembered as a dedicated leader in the healthcare community and as a strong advocate for compassionate, state-ofthe-art treatment for AIDS patients. We extend our most sincere condolences to his wife Phyllis, his children, and his many friends and loved ones. Mark J. Mundy, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President Greater NY Hospital Association

title: MetroStars Are Hot, But Not Bothered
description: As the MetroStars played their third game in a week, the temperature here today was a frying-pan-hot 97 degrees, with no clouds overhead.

title: Assisted Suicide, at State Discretion
description: Attorney General Janet Reno made the right call in preserving the right of Oregon residents to seek physician-assisted suicide in that state. Last November, Thomas Constantine, the Administrator of the Federal Drug Enforcement Agency, announced that doctors in Oregon who acted under that state's assisted suicide law would be subject to severe Federal sanctions, including revocation of their right to prescribe drugs. The D.E.A. is responsible for enforcing Federal drug laws, but it has no right to substitute its own judgment for the judgment of Oregon voters, who resoundingly affirmed their support for the state's Death With Dignity Act by a 60 percent vote last November.

title: Members' Items May Be First to Be Vetoed in Budget Dispute
description: Nestled among the huge numbers in the budget passed by the City Council last week are page after page of small ones: $500 to the Actors Company Theater, $3,000 to the Brooklyn Puerto Rican Day Parade, $3,125 to the Shore Garden Club.

title: Families Bear a Bigger Share of Long-Term Care for the Frail Elderly
description: Janice Davocato's devotion to her disabled mother has wiped out her savings and turned her into a seven-day-a-week workhorse.

title: Erika Cheetham Dies at 58; An Expert on Nostradamus
description: Erika Cheetham, an English medieval scholar who made a fortune translating the predictions of the 16th-century physician and astrologer Nostradamus, who gazed not only at the stars but also, legend had it, into a brass bowl of water to see visions of the future, died on May 3 in London. She was 58.

title: Pompeii Journal; A Pagan Gem, and Next Door, the Mob's Dead Hand
description: There are two Pompeiis near the bay of Naples, and it is not always clear which is the dead city. One, crawling with tourists, guides, laborers and archeologists, hums with activity. The other, where the unemployment rate is 30 percent, has crumbling buildings, faded honky-tonk signs and stray dogs sleeping in the sun.

title: Lorne Welch, R.A.F. Pilot And Escape Artist, Dies at 81
description: Lorne Welch, a crack British glider pilot and yachtsman who played parts in two of the most storied escapes by Allied prisoners during World War II, died on May 15 at his home in Farnham, England. He was 81.

title: One Player's Rare Distinction: Two Victories Just Days Apart
description: Few players ever win two events in different locations within a span of four days, but the number has just increased. Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn., who owns three major national team titles, began last week by capturing the Reisinger Knockout Teams, the premier event of the Eastern Regional Championships. Wednesday night, at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, Manhattan, he won the annual U.J.A. Federation Charity Game, which raised more than $75,000, a record.

description: A bomb exploded this morning on a crowded railroad train in southern Pakistan, killing 23 people, and the Government immediately blamed Indian secret agents.

title: Judge Dismisses Daily News Suit
description: For The Daily News, the rainbow of new color pages is still somewhere over the rainbow, and the search for the best way to keep the color inks free of water continues, but the lawsuit that the paper's parent company filed against the company that supplied the balky newsliner presses is over.

title: France's 'Foreign Legion' Hopes Hour of Glory Has Arrived
description: PARIS  Wines and designs are not the only French products in demand as the 20th century draws to a close. French soccer talent is a popular export as well.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Shirley Povich, the Washington Post sports columnist for 74 years, misspelled the given name of the former Post publisher and chairwoman who attributed one-third of the paper's circulation to him. She is Katharine Graham, not Katherine.

title: NBC Ends Ban on 'Dirty Work' Ads
description: This weekend's update: The movie ''Dirty Work'' can buy commercials on NBC after all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASSNER, ALLAN S.
description: LASSNER-Allan S. 89. On June 6, 1998, in San Diego. Formerly of New York City, Tenafly, NJ, and Block Island, RI. Beloved father of Ellen van Hoften of La Jolla, CA, and Jane Lassner Zeitchick of Westport, CT. Loving husband of Jane and the late Elinore. Adored father-in-law of Scott and Norman. Dear grandfather of Kyle, Derek, Alex and Evan. Loving uncle of Amy and Sarah. A special man who will be missed by many.

title: Tobacco Industry Gave Big Where It Faced Attack
description: When Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida sued the tobacco industry in early 1995, he ignited a legal and political war that raged for the next three years. During the course of the lawsuit to recoup smoking-related health costs, which culminated in an $11.3 billion settlement last summer, tobacco interests poured more than $1 million into the state, most of it going to political opponents of the Governor, a Democrat.

title: When a Sport Becomes a Shirt
description: Is it real Polo or Ralph's Polo? That is the concern of the clothing company Polo Ralph Lauren, which is seeking to block Polo magazine from using the name Polo. . . . Polo Ralph Lauren started the legal wrangling last fall by sending a letter to Polo magazine, expressing concern that the revamping of the 23-year-old publication of the United States Polo Association from a narrow, horsy publication to an upscale, life style magazine would cause people to view it as a product of the luxury designer.

title: U.S. Expected To File Suit Against Intel
description: The Federal Trade Commission is expected to file a major antitrust lawsuit against the Intel Corporation on Monday, and Intel executives and lawyers, saying the very future of the company is at stake, have vowed to fight the suit vigorously.

title: Customer Gambles, Broker Loses
description: Let the seller beware. That appears to be a principal lesson in the decision of Merrill Lynch to pay $437 million to settle civil suits brought against it in the wake of the Orange County, Calif., bankruptcy.

title: Caps Waltz Into Finals, But Music Could End
description: Mixing his usual candor with a little diplomacy, Coach Ron Wilson of the Washington Capitals was evaluating how his team came to find itself in the Stanley Cup finals against the defending champion, Detroit.

title: S. J. Lanahan, 79, Authority on Tax Law
description: Samuel Jackson Lanahan, an authority on tax law, died on May 29, after suffering a pulmonary embolism at his vacation home in Dartmouth, England. He was 79 and lived in Trappe, Md.

title: Shirley Polykoff, 90, Ad Writer Whose Query Colored A Nation
description: Shirley Polykoff, the pioneering advertising woman who came up with a single double-entendre that changed the face, or rather turned the heads, of American society, died on Thursday at her home on Park Avenue. She was 90 and the author of the ''Does she . . . or doesn't she?'' slogan, which unleashed American women to choose the color of their hair.

title: Soul-Searching for TV in Los Angeles
description: Live television coverage of a man's suicide on a freeway prompted outrage among viewers here in April. It also led to an open discussion about whether it was time to rethink standards and practices in news. KNBC received 2,000 complaints, and called each of those viewers back to apologize.

description: The world's six largest accounting firms have plunged into the legal business in Europe, leaving many European lawyers fighting mad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREVES, RENATA COLOMBO
description: TREVES-Renata Colombo. Of Palm Beach, Florida, formerly of New York, died Saturday, June 6 in New York, surrounded by her loving family. Born in Turin, Italy on September 26, 1918. Music and the arts were her life long passion. Wife of the late Peter G. Treves. Mother of Charles and Vivian. Grandmother of Janine and Marina, grandmother-in-law to Vianney Habar. title: Brooklyn Girl Is Killed When Man Handles Gun
description: A 14-year-old girl was shot and killed at a friend's apartment in Brooklyn early yesterday when a pistol being handled by a man in the apartment discharged, the police said.

title: Moya Puts Final Accent Mark on the Spanish Conquest of the French Open
description: Carlos Moya flopped down, flat on his back and vulnerable for the first time after playing the leading man in a 2-hour-18-minute performance. It was a 6-3, 7-5, 6-3 mauling of his outclassed friend and opponent, Alex Corretja, that proclaimed Moya, the flashy bandanna-clad Spaniard, the latest French Open champion. Coming on the heels of Arantxa Sanchez Vicario's defeat of Monica Seles in the women's final on Saturday, Moya put the finishing touches on a Spanish sweep of this Grand Slam event's singles titles, a coup that last occurred when Sanchez Vicario and Sergi Bruguera monopolized the event in 1994.

title: Religious Leaders Urge Clinton To Press China On Persecution
description: From Tibetan Buddhists to Roman Catholics to evangelical Christians, a broad array of religious leaders is urging President Clinton to use his summit meeting later this month in Beijing to press the Chinese Government to end the repression of religious believers there.

Jorge Posada, who has gradually become the team's front-line catcher this season, sprained his right foot during batting practice before yesterday's game. At the very least, the Yankees will call up a catcher from Class AAA before starting their next series in Montreal tomorrow night.

description: The skirmishes over New York City's next budget continued yesterday as City Council leaders ventured into the labyrinthine world of property taxes to patch a $251 million hole that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had blown into their budget a day earlier.

description: For many companies, recruiting executives is like looking for needles in a haystack. The Wall Street Journal and Korn/Ferry International, a leading executive search firm, hope to use the Internet to get the needles to emerge on their own.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL DOWN 3.5 PERCENT. Oil fell on market speculation that production cuts promised last week by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico would fail to end a global glut. July contracts fell 52 cents, to $14.55 a barrel.

title: Vulnerable Intel
description: Although the Federal Trade Commission filed an antitrust lawsuit yesterday against the Intel Corporation seemingly similar to the one that the Justice Department filed against Microsoft last month, it would be a mistake to consider the two companies as posing equal threats as monopolies.

description: The producers of ''Honour,'' a four-character drama about infidelity in the pundit class that marked Jane Alexander's return to Broadway after four years as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, announced yesterday that it would close after its Sunday matinee, becoming the first casualty of the Tony Awards ceremony.

title: Strike Idles Other G.M. Plants And Workers Are Sent Home
description: With two of its factories running out of essential components, the General Motors Corporation sent 4,500 workers home today as a four-day strike at a metal stamping plant in Flint, Mich., threatened to halt vehicle production for the world's largest auto maker.

title: Protecting Collapsed Lungs
description: A collapsed lung has a random way of reopening as air presses in from a life support system, and tissue damage is more likely if the air pressure is not varied in a random pattern, scientists suggest.

title: Students Strut Their Stuff
description: The ambition and execution of the 34th Annual Workshop Performance on Saturday afternoon at the Juilliard Theater would have been impressive even if it had been the work of adult professionals. But the performers were students at the New York City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet.

description: Top executives at Siegel & Gale, the corporate identity company in New York, have agreed to buy the company from Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. for $33.8 million in cash.

title: Newark's 'Zoo Crew' Business Head Pleads Guilty in Drug Ring Case
description: The leader of what had seemed to be a civic-minded group of entrepreneurs known as the Zoo Crew pleaded guilty today to a Federal drug trafficking conspiracy charge, admitting that his clothing boutique, florist shop, carry-out restaurant and auto supply store were actually fronts for an elaborate drug distribution ring.

title: DAIMLER-BENZ AND CHRYSLER REVISE RATIO FOR STOCK SWAP
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. and the Chrysler Corporation have revised the ratio for their $39 billion stock swap to account for additional shares to be issued by both companies before the merger is completed. Chrysler shareholders will receive 0.6235 share of DaimlerChrysler for every share they hold. Daimler shareholders will receive one share in the new company, which will have 1.003 billion shares, according to a joint document that Daimler-Benz said both auto makers had filed at the United States Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday. The companies had previously put the share ratio at 0.547.

title: The End May Be in Sight In the Brawley Case
description: Alton H. Maddox Jr., the one of the three defendants in the Tawana Brawley defamation case who is representing himself, rested his case yesterday. Another defendant, C. Vernon Mason, plans to present his case with only two witnesses on Friday. Seven months after the start, jurors could hear closing arguments by late next week.

description: Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities Inc. will close its primary dealership, probably by Oct. 1, in connection with the merger of its parent, the Nationsbank Corporation, with the BankAmerica Corporation.

title: Studies Explore Love and the Sweaty T-Shirt
description: WHEN it comes to love, sex and friendship, do birds of a feather flock together? Or is it more important that opposites attract? The argument is so old that even Aristotle mentioned evidence for both sides.

The odd feature of the antitrust complaint brought yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission is that it accused Intel of victimizing putative rivals that are also customers.

title: A Taxi Commissioner Supports Fleets' Suit Against New Rules

description: Sherman Douglas, a backup point guard for the Nets, underwent successful hand surgery yesterday to repair ligament and tendon damage to the knuckle of the middle finger on his left hand.

description: Gen. Sani Abacha, who died yesterday at 54, was the seventh Nigerian officer to come to power by force since the country gained independence from Britain in 1960. But even against this background, General Abacha established a distinctive record of brutal rule.

He will be missed by the health care community and by people from all walks of life who were privileged to know him. We extend our profound sympathy to Phyllis, Nicole, Marie and his entire family. Frederic B. Powers, Chairman John R. Spicer, President Sound Shore Health System

title: No Vanilla, Please, for America's Team
description: Chan Gailey came seemingly from nowhere, an offensive coordinator from the Pittsburgh Steelers who had quietly but efficiently done his job. A man of strong character and stout religious background who in his football travels had never left a place where his return would not be welcomed. An offensive guru, an imaginative, cutting-edge offensive mind, a 46-year-old Georgian who in his football travels had been a special teams coach, a defensive coordinator, an offensive coordinator and a head coach.

title: Nabisco Plans $524 Million Reorganization
description: Nabisco announced a $524 million reorganization plan yesterday that will include factory closings and the layoffs of more than 3,000 of its 53,000 employees in an effort to pump new energy into Cheese Nips, Fig Newtons and the rest of its languishing cookie and cracker business. But Wall Street, caught off guard, knocked the price of Nabisco stock down by more than 13 percent.

Even if Nomo woke up today with the ability to speak perfect English, that would not assure that the right-hander would be any more fathomable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODZIANKO, LUBOV
description: RODZIANKO-Lubov, 95 years old. The Sovereign Order of the Orthodox Knights Hospitaller of St. John of Jerusalem notes with deep sorrow the passing of Dame Commander Grand Cross Lubov Rodzianko, LLD, June 5, 1998, in Palm Beach, Florida. Together with her late husband, Col. Paul Rodzianko III, she devoted her distinguished life trying to relieve suffering humanity, via the UN and UNESCO where she initiated and chaired several actions and committees. She received the U.S. Presidential Citation for Meritorious Personal Service. Since 1973, she devoted much of her time to reviving the Orthodox branch of the Order, drafting its by-laws, writing historical treatises, obtaining the protection of the Russian Imperial family. The Order will never forget its debt to her. We are sharing the sorrow of her son, Paul and his family, who suggested that donations in her name to the Order of St. John would be welcomed, 39 Parkway East, Mount Vernon, New York 10552. Memorial service to be held at a later date in Palm Beach. Memory eternal to a great humanitarian. Count Nicholas Bobrinskoy Grand Prior

The business had sales of 540 million marks ($305 million) in 1997, excluding the German operations, which will be retained by Pharmacia & Upjohn, the Swedish-American drug maker.

In answer to the question, ''Can good people grow tobacco?,'' the producers, Christine Fugate and Eren McGinnis, visit with four Kentucky families who bear no resemblance to the cigarette executives who have come to personify the ills of smoking: it's innocence by dissociation.

title: Theatrical Den Mother Nurtures Her Lions
description: Flora Roberts is one of the last of the red-hot play agents, a fiercely independent woman who has gone her own way in a world dominated by corporate agencies. In a career of almost 50 years, she has been a formidable talent spotter. She is artful in her choice of clients -- mostly writers, like Stephen Sondheim, Tina Howe and Alfred Uhry -- and sharp-sighted in her assessments of their strengths. She is a kind of dramaturge in the guise of an agent.

The FMC unit, Crosby Valve, has 500 employees. Of those, 375 will join Tyco, most of them at a plant in Wrentham, Mass. The other 125 will stay at an FMC plant in Texas. FMC, based in Chicago, is a maker of agricultural chemicals and machinery.

title: RENAISSANCE ENERGY IN $463 MILLION DEAL FOR PINNACLE
description: The Canadian oil company Renaissance Energy Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy Pinnacle Resources Ltd. for about $675 million (Canadian), or about $463 million (United States), in stock. Renaissance said it would offer 0.66 share for each Pinnacle share, which represents a per-share price of about $16.76 (Canadian) based on Friday's closing price. It will also assume Pinnacle's debt of about $380 million (Canadian). Pinnacle, another Canadian oil company, agreed not to encourage any competing offers and to pay Renaissance a breakup fee of $21 million (Canadian) if a better offer was recommended to shareholders. Pinnacle's shares rose $2.30 yesterday, to $15.40, and Renaissance fell $1.80, to $23.60, on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

Cheryl Hurley, President Richard Poirier, Chairman The Library of America

description: Scientists are exploring a new way to get rid of hazardous dust mites: by attacking their chemical communication system, as an alternative to the standard labor-intensive bedroom-cleaning protocol.

title: Cohen Orders Inquiry Into U.S. Nerve Gas Charges
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen has ordered an inquiry into new charges that United States forces used nerve gas against American defectors during the Vietnam War, the Pentagon said today.

title: Chinese in U.S. Tie Harassment To Clinton Trip
description: Ciping Huang was always known among her family's neighbors in the Chinese city of Hefei as a dutiful daughter. In the 13 years since she arrived in the United States, initially to study science at the University of Toledo, she returned home often, and there had never been a problem with the police during her five previous trips.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 1 about a small-town Alabama publishing couple who exposed corruption by a county sheriff misstated the sentence received by the sheriff, Roger Davis of Marengo County, for extortion. It was 27 months in prison, not 27 years, and is to be served concurrently with another 27-month sentence, for soliciting a bribe and failure to pay state income taxes.

title: Battling Sprawl, States Buy Land for Open Space
description: New Jersey and half a dozen other states are considering ambitious plans to preserve farmland and other open space to curb suburban sprawl and address mounting concern from suburban and rural residents about new development in fast-growing towns.

title: SYMBOL WITHDRAWS ITS SWEETENED OFFER FOR TELXON
description: Symbol Technologies Inc., the world's largest maker of bar-code scanners, said yesterday that it had withdrawn its sweetened bid to buy the Telxon Corporation after Telxon rejected the offer as too low. Shares of Telxon, which is based in Akron, Ohio, and is a rival maker of wireless products for transmitting bar-code data, slid $3.5625, to $32.0625. Symbol shares rose 56.25 cents, to $35.125. Symbol, based in Holtsville, N.Y., said last week that it would pay $40 in cash or as much as $42 in cash and stock for each Telxon share. It also said it could arrange financing for the purchase. Under the offer, Symbol would have bought Telxon debt that is convertible into about 4 million shares and options to buy 3.5 million shares at $16 each.

title: Policing the Firemen
description: In keeping with his campaign promises, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has given New Yorkers strict law enforcement. Ordinary citizens get ticketed for jaywalking. Taxi drivers and street vendors are under close scrutiny from the New York City Police Department. Given such enforcement policies, Mr. Giuliani and the police have been troublingly quiet about the drunken brawl staged by New York City firefighters last week at the Bryant Park Grill. The melee included between 50 and 100 uniformed firefighters who trashed the restaurant, harassed patrons, exposed themselves and fought for five hours. Despite a wealth of witnesses, the only person arrested was the restaurant's bouncer.

title: America Online to Buy Internet Chat Service for $287 Million
description: With all the frenzy over the Internet, entrepreneurs have been able to create and sell companies for huge sums without ever earning a dime. But in what may be a record of financial weightlessness, America Online said yesterday that it would pay at least $287 million for a company that has never taken in a penny in revenue and has no plans to start charging money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUMPHREYS, RONALD R.
description: HUMPHREYS-Ronald R. on Monday, June 8, 1998 of Manhattan, NY. Father of Olivia K. & Colin A. both of Bloomfield. Son of Richard and Ellen Shaddock Humphreys of Suffern, NY. Brother of Kathleen Adam of Clifton Park, NY, Nancy Zelen of Suffern, NY and Brian Humphreys of Manhattan, NY. Former husband of Carol Meyers Humphreys of Bloomfield. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from the O'Boyle Funeral Home, 309 Broad Street, Bloomfield, Thursday at 9:30 AM. The funeral mass will be offered in Immaculate Conception Church, Montclair at 10:30 AM. Friends may call Tuesday 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. For those who wish, in lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial donations be made to the Children's Brain Tumor Foundation, 274 Madison Avenue, Suite 1301, NY, NY 10016 or the State University of New York College at Oswego Athletic Association in his memory would be appreciated.

title: Utah Tries To Leave A Disaster Behind It
description: Utah Coach Jerry Sloan came strolling onto the floor as cheerful as a bluebird today. He stopped with a smile and said, ''Hello, everyone,'' with the glee of a morning show host.

title: U.S. Ally Elected to Head World Soccer Body
description: After a quarter-century of one-man rule, soccer's world governing body got a new president today. If this had been a soccer match instead of an election, the two candidates would have received at least a yellow card warning for foul play during their bitter campaigns.

title: Elusive Particles Continue to Puzzle Theorists of the Sun
description: ONE of the biggest embarrassments of 20th-century science -- the sun's refusal to emit nearly as many neutrinos as physicists say it should -- inched closer to a possible solution last week when experimenters reported strong new evidence that these weird elementary particles, long thought to be perfectly massless, may have a small amount of heft after all. If neutrinos indeed have mass, the story goes, they can change ''flavor'' on their flight from the center of the Sun, eluding the electronic snares earthlings have been setting. The neutrinos wouldn't be missing, but traveling in disguise.

title: Lott Wants Tobacco Bill Withdrawn
description: Turning up the heat in a partisan debate, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said today that the tobacco bill now before the Senate was such poor legislation that it should be withdrawn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, RHODA (NEE OLANOFF)
description: POLLACK-Rhoda (nee Olanoff). Beloved wife of Max. Dear sister of Grace Smith. Cherished aunt, teacher and friend. Miss Olanoff, George Gershwin Junior High School no. 166. Services today, 9:30AM, at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett.

title: Yzerman Is Set for Biggest Role as the Leading Man
description: After 15 seasons in the National Hockey League, most of them as captain of the Detroit Red Wings, Steve Yzerman has earned a few perks. One of them is a private hotel room on the road. So he was surprised one night this spring to discover goalie Chris Osgood in the next bed.

title: Sinn Fein Enters Campaign For New Ulster Assembly
description: The campaign for the new Northern Ireland Assembly began in earnest today as Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, abandoned its traditional policy and announced formally that it would field candidates even though the assembly is almost certain to have a Protestant unionist majority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULTAN, IDA
description: SULTAN-Ida. Age 89, died June 7, 1998. Beloved wife of Max, devoted mother of Edwin, Herbert, Barbara Balfour and Sharon Zareski. Adored sister of Irving Silverman and Beatrice Betheil. She will be profoundly missed by her grandchildren, family & friends. Services Garlick's, 1700 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, New York, today at 1:30.

title: TAG Heuer ads keep a sports theme but now feature star athletes for 'more human presence.'
description: THE Swiss company TAG Heuer A. G. is abandoning an unusually striking style of advertising in favor of a more traditional campaign that uses top athletes to sell the company's premium-priced sports watches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRENTZ, BERTRAM
description: KRENTZ-Bertram. Of Lake Worth, Florida, and Brookfield, CT, died on June 5. Beloved husband of the late Gertrude, father of Richard and Debbie, brother of Benjamin, grandfather of Alycia, Jeffrey, Shari, Cheryl and Michelle. Great grandfather of Sidney and Bethany.

title: Pentium Chip Prices Sliced 12% to 20%
description: The Intel Corporation said today that it had lowered prices on its Pentium II microprocessors for desktop computers by 12 percent to 20 percent. Intel also introduced a faster version of its low-end Celeron processor and dropped the price of the older, slower model by 32 percent.

title: Wells Fargo And Norwest Plan Merger
description: The Norwest Corporation and Wells Fargo & Company agreed to merge yesterday in a $34 billion deal, the latest in a string of blockbuster unions that have created a clear cadre of giants and a few dozen also-rans in the once-sleepy banking industry.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about the management of Internet addresses misstated the year that the suffix ''.com'' was introduced for commercial enterprises. It was 1985, not 1990.

title: Accounts
description: * Premier Parks Inc., Oklahoma City, will consolidate its 1999 national amusement parks advertising, with billings estimated at $40 million, at Ackerman McQueen, Oklahoma City, its agency of almost five years, after acquiring the Six Flags amusement parks from Time Warner Inc. Grey Advertising, New York, which recently began handling the Six Flags account, will continue work on those parks through December.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIFETZ, PEARL
description: HEIFETZ-Pearl. June 6. Beloved wife of the late pianist and composer Vladmir Heifetz. Mourned and adored by her nieces & nephews, Rachel and Yitzchak Klein, Asher and Lenore Schapiro, Rabbi Israel Poleyeff, Rosalee Schapiro and their children. The family will be receiving friends on Tuesday, June 9, from 3 PM until 9 PM at 351 West 24th St., Apt 14J, NYC. Memorial contributions may be made to United Jewish Community G'mach, C/O Klein, 473 Beach 6th St., Far Rockaway, NY 11691.

title: In a Hybrid Band, Flirting With Many Influences
description: Any quick description of Dave Douglas's show on Sunday night at the Knitting Factory's Old Office, part of the Texaco New York Jazz Festival, sounds like a parody of post-modernism: ''So the jazz trumpeter was trading four-bar solo breaks with the tabla player in the middle of a Burt Bacharach tune. . . .''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Intel Sued; U.S. Cites Harm to Computer Makers

title: A 75-Year Sentence For Robbing the Elderly
description: A man who was convicted in a string of robberies of elderly subway riders was sentenced yesterday to 75 years to life in state prison.

title: Bell Atlantic Plans A Network for Data
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the largest United States local phone company, said yesterday that it would begin building a $500 million long-distance network to carry Internet and data traffic as it awaits approval from regulators to provide the services.

title: D.M.V.'s Computer Crash Strands Thousands of Car Owners
description: A new software program installed in the computer system at the New Jersey Department of Motor Vehicles crashed after only an hour of use yesterday morning, forcing the agency's 45 field offices to turn away thousands of drivers in search of new licenses, registrations and titles, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUDACK, WILLIAM
description: SUDACK-William. On June 7, 1998 in Hallandale, Florida. Beloved and devoted husband of Lillian. Loving father of Robert. Cherished grandfather of Mark and father-in-law of Nikki. Dear uncle of Linda Sussman. Services Tuesday, 12 Noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: REVLON INC., -- New York, the maker of beauty products, said it would sell its 85 percent stake in Cosmetic Center Inc., Savage, Md., a retailer, and take a charge of $15 million in the second quarter related to the sale.

description: President Clinton asked Congress yesterday to add about $300 million to next year's Federal budget to protect Americans better from germ and chemical attacks, the White House announced.

title: Clinton Deserves Due Process, Too

title: ENVIRODYNE AGREES TO SELL PLASTICS UNIT TO SOLO CUP
description: Envirodyne Industries, a maker of plastic packaging and containers based in Oak Brook, Ill., agreed yesterday to sell its Clear Shield National unit to the Solo Cup Company for $140 million in cash as it seeks to reduce debt. Clear Shield, based in Wheeling, Ill., makes disposable plastic cutlery and drinking straws, and had sales of $85.9 million in 1997. The closely held Solo, of Highland Park, Ill., makes paper and plastic dinnerware. About 40 percent of Envirodyne's stock is owned by the Zapata Corporation, a former oil and gas company that now produces fish byproducts and has said it wants to focus on Internet-related businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARVIN, ROBERT L.
description: GARVIN-Robert L. Of Flushing, N.Y. On June 5, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Pauline. Loving father of John and the late Wes. Also survived by grandchildren Beth, Gregory, Kristen and Michael of Lindenhurst, N.Y. and Sean and Gary of Marietta, GA. Bob was truly an idealist. A memorial service will be held July 12, 1998, 5 P.M., at the Bowne Street Community Church, Flushing.

title: U.S. Backs Dividing Conrail to Increase Competition
description: The Federal Government approved a sweeping plan today to restructure the nation's rail freight system east of the Mississippi River, a move officials said would take trucks off the road, reduce air pollution and lower the cost of goods for the New York City metropolitan region and much of the rest of the nation.

title: Fight on Milk Prices Is Making Its Way to Capital
description: Do not be fooled by the virtuous grins on all those celebrities with the white mustaches. The question ''Got Milk?'' and its corollaries ''How much?'' and ''At what price?'' are fueling what economists call the most contentious, most political battle over agricultural policy in the East, if not the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, ALICE VIVIEN
description: MURPHY-Alice Vivien. In Westport, CT, June 7, 1998, formerly of New York City, wife of the late William F. Murphy and Frederick M. Singer. Mother of Francis V. Murphy of Venice, FL., John A. Murphy of Jackson, New York, Grandmother of nine and great grandmother of six. A Mass of Christian burial will take place today in Assumption Church, Westport. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Bronx High School Gets $1 Million Pledge
description: The competition among New York City's elite public high schools has always been fierce, especially when academic bragging rights have been on the line. But lately, the jousting has moved from the classroom into the fund-raising arena.

title: Mayor Wants To Privatize Pupil Reviews
description: In an ambitious effort to revamp one of the costliest items in the city school budget, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani intends to call on the Board of Education today to privatize the job of evaluating children who are referred by their teachers to special education, Board officials said yesterday.

In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Giant Steps, C/O AIND, (make checks payable to AIND), 1275 Post Road, Suite A3, Fairfield, CT., 06430.

title: With Nigeria's Military Ruler Dead, Concern Is Voiced for the Fate of His Jailed Foe
description: After the death of Nigeria's military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, the daughter of Moshood K. O. Abiola, the opposition leader who was imprisoned after being elected President in 1993, called today for the military to step aside and for her father's immediate release.

title: The Dow Shifts Gears a Bit, Rising a Modest 31.89 Points
description: Major stock market indexes rose modestly yesterday, extending their gains for a third day. Among the leaders were financial services companies, propelled by merger news, and pharmaceutical stocks, lifted by a positive outlook for new drug products.

description: Lawyers who fought the tobacco industry have found a new focus for their energies: fighting for their share of the spoils from lawsuits against the industry.

title: Reed Gets Within 7 Outs of Perfection
description: Rick Reed keeps making the art of pitching look so simple. But last night's outing was a little numbing even for him. Just about every pitch had a purpose or slithered into the strike zone. Just about every Tampa Bay batter wondered how Reed, so coolly efficient, was dominating him with pitches that looked so hittable.

title: THE N.B.A. FINALS: At Every Turn, Jazz Finds Pippen; The Bulls' Consummate Defender Picks Apart the Pick-and-Roll
description: Scottie Pippen was buzzing John Stockton like an annoying gnat in the backcourt, filling the passing lanes the way Coach Jerry Sloan wishes his players would and taking a charge from Karl Malone under the basket. On the next Utah Jazz possession, Pippen caused more havoc.

title: Lively Council Race in Newark Pits Experience Against New Blood
description: Runoff elections rarely set pulses racing. But the one being played out Tuesday in Newark's Central Ward may prove the exception.

description: VIEWPOINT Datalabs International Inc. has helped create many computer-generated models for television and the movies, including the latest version of ''Godzilla.'' Liveart98, its first product for the general public, trades the monsters for bugs.

title: Supreme Court Hears Case on Ex-White House Counsel's Notes
description: The lawyer for Vincent W. Foster Jr., the late White House aide, urged the Supreme Court today to allow him to keep secret his notes of a final meeting he and Mr. Foster had in order to preserve the sanctity of the lawyer-client privilege and more generally to encourage clients to be candid with their lawyers.

title: Commemorating a Discovery in Radio Astronomy
description: His assignment from his bosses at Bell Laboratories in 1931 was simple: Build a 100-foot-long rotating antenna to find out what was causing the static that interfered with trans-Atlantic telephone calls. His discovery was anything but simple: The static was the first evidence that stars and galaxies were emitting radio waves.

title: Cheerleaders Against Drugs
description: Manhattan is filled this week with world leaders attending a well-intentioned but misdirected United Nations conference on drugs. With drugs more plentiful and cheaper than ever worldwide, the leaders are mostly extolling failed strategies to combat the problem. Pino Arlacchi, the Italian official who heads the organization's International Drug Control Program, is promising to eliminate coca leaf and opium poppies, the basis of cocaine and heroin, in 10 years. Such claims get in the way of effective programs to reduce drug use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COIRO, ANN T.

In lieu of flowers donations may be made to American Italian Foundation for Cancer Research, 872 Madison Ave., NY NY 10021. Rest in peace.

description: In dramatic fashion, Casey Martin qualified for the United States Open today, fulfilling another dream and returning his remarkable story to the national stage.

title: New Guide Puts Most Americans on the Fat Side
description: WITH bathing suit season approaching (and already here in some parts of the country), it seems as if nearly every popular magazine in the last month or two has touted one scheme or another for shedding that winter padding and achieving a movie-star figure in eight weeks or less. Even without the beach as an incentive, millions of Americans are perpetually struggling to lose pounds, an effort that has spawned a $33 billion diet industry.

title: Arthur Gottlieb, 60, Biologist-Immunologist and Company Founder
description: A. Arthur Gottlieb, a biologist and immunologist who formed his own biotechnology company, died on Sunday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 60 and lived in New Orleans.

description: It is every director's nightmare -- bombing on Broadway. For Judy Cohen, it came true yesterday, in a manner of speaking.

description: Visx Inc. said today that it would pay Summit Technology Inc. $35 million to end a partnership and settle lawsuits between the two laser companies.

description: Many of the 200 bone-weary guerrillas had the blank, distant gaze of people who don't quite know where they are or what they are doing. Some panted and sweated in exhaustion and appeared unaccustomed to heavy physical exertion.

title: At Drug Summit, Clinton Asks Nations to Set Aside Blame
description: President Clinton said today that the debate over who bears responsibility for the world's drug problems has gone on too long and called for drug-producing and consuming countries to cooperate in stanching the supply and demand for illegal drugs.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Charged In Fatal Shooting of Girl
description: A Brooklyn man with a long criminal record was arrested on second-degree murder charges yesterday in the fatal shooting of a 14-year-old girl early Sunday, the police said.

title: What Was Your Name Again?
description: For people who think they know who they are, beware. There's a computer out there just waiting to cloak you in a new identity. Anyone with a first and last name is a target, and the more names in your household -- middle, married, hyphenated, or pets' -- the better your chances for a gala rechristening.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; While banks have been gobbling up one another, who's been eating the shareholders' premium?
description: WORD yesterday that Norwest and Wells Fargo plan to merge in a stock-for-stock transaction may have set bank stock investors' pulses racing. But for those who had hoped the most recent mega-merger would breathe a little life into bank stocks, the sector was a letdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, BARBARA FELDMAN
description: ABRAMS-Barbara Feldman. On June 2, 1998 after a gallant battle with Acute Myeloid Leukemia. Artist, sculptor, teacher & designer, she taught 20 years at Parsons School of Design. Survived by her daughters, Lauren and Emma and her husband Roy. Her interest in land preservation for all our children is to be conserved with the Barbara Abrams Feldman Childrens' Land Trust.

description: Even die-hard fashion aficionados who live in black most of the year add a touch of white in the summer. Here are some suggestions.

description: It would surely have amused Roque Dalton, inveterate bohemian and revolutionary that he was, to know that the right-wing Government in power here recently added his poetry to the school curriculum. A fierce critic of organized religion, he no doubt would also have chuckled at the notion that a Jesuit-run university was sponsoring a project to publish his complete works.

description: PARIS  The Air France pilots' strike entered its second week Monday with negotiations deadlocked and management reportedly determined to impose salary cuts.

title: Fortis Wins Bidding War For Big Belgian Bank
description: Fortis A.G. , the Dutch-Belgian banking and insurance company, beat ABN Amro Holding N.V. of the Netherlands yesterday in the takeover battle for Belgium's biggest bank, after raising its offer for Generale de Banque S.A. to $14.2 billion. Shares of Fortis fell as much as 535 Belgian francs, to 9,940 francs ($271), as analysts said the deal's price was steep.

description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had formed a real estate fund with a group of investors to buy real estate from the bank and resell it.

description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said today that the Army, Navy and Air Force would continue to train male and female recruits together but would provide stricter privacy and security in the barracks areas.

description: The United States said today that it would support a British resolution in the United Nations to authorize a NATO military intervention in the southern Serbian province of Kosovo, and that Washington would press NATO to speed up planning for such an action.

title: Bishop Quits As Mediator In Rebellion By Zapatistas
description: Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garcia, the Roman Catholic prelate who presides over an Indian-dominated diocese in southern Chiapas state, has stepped down as mediator in peace talks between the Government and the Zapatista rebels.

title: Dread Rules: An Unpopular Leader Leaves Nigerians Fearful and Divided
description: Few Nigerians are in a state of mourning over the death of Gen. Sani Abacha, a deeply unpopular leader. But while Nigeria awaits clearer signs of its political future, nearly all of the nation is in a state of dread.

title: South Korean Recovery: A Mixed but Gloomy Picture
description: Six months after Koreans elected Kim Dae Jung as President, economic pain is mounting with few signs of a turnaround in sight.

title: F.T.C. SUES INTEL, SAYING IT VIOLATED ANTITRUST LAWS
description: The Federal Trade Commission filed an antitrust suit today against the Intel Corporation, accusing the company of threatening and actually injuring three computer manufacturers, including the Compaq Computer Corporation, in an attempt to coerce them to turn over rights to patented technologies.

title: Suharto Finds Friends Are Few Now That He's Just an Ex-V.I.P.
description: Only his pet parrot still calls him ''Mr. President.''

title: LUCENT ACQUIRING SDX, A BRITISH TELEPHONE CONCERN
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the British business telephone company SDX Business Systems P.L.C. for $:124 million ($202 million). Lucent, North America's largest telecommunications equipment maker, said the acquisition involved the fast-growing European market in call centers, or automated telephone and data switching systems. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., said call center sales in Western Europe were expected to grow by more than 20 percent annually, to more than $3 billion in 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERATHY, ALBERT JOSEPH
description: GERATHY-Albert Joseph. Of Short Hills, New Jersey, Sunday, June 7, 1998. Husband of Dolores Ansbro Gerathy, father of Albert J. Gerathy, Jr., D.M.D., brother of Mrs. Theresa Hughes and Mrs. Marjorie Vosper. Funeral from Smith and Smith (Suburban) 415 Morris Avenue, Springfield, New Jersey, on Wednesday, June 10 at 10:15 AM. Funeral mass in St. Rose of Lima Church, Short Hills, at 11:15 AM. Interment St. Rose of Lima Cemetery. Friends may call Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Donations Urged to Overcome Severe Shortage of Blood
description: With less than a day's supply of blood on hand for hospitals in the New York region, health officials are urging people to donate to curb the severe shortage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLLS, KITTY
description: STOLLS-Kitty. Beloved wife of the late Kassel, devoted mother of Richard and Lynne, loving grandmother and great-grandmother of Tracy and Mark, Ken and Lena and Isabella. Dear sister of Benjamin Rosen. Services were held Monday at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: HEALTHCARE REALTY AGREES TO ACQUIRE CAPSTONE CAPITAL
description: Healthcare Realty Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Capstone Capital Corporation in a stock deal valued around $900 million, including the assumption of $268 million in debt. Stockholders of Capstone Capital, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., would receive 0.8518 share of Healthcare Realty common stock for each Capstone common share held. And holders of Capstone preferred stock would receive one share of Healthcare Realty voting preferred stock for each Capstone preferred share held. The value of the deal includes the issuance of $75 million in preferred stock. After the deal is completed, Healthcare Realty, based in Nashville, expects to have a market capitalization around $1.1 billion and will own 250 properties in 68 markets, leased to 66 health care providers.

title: Refining Entrepreneurship; Bankrupted Twice, an Oilman Takes Another Gamble
description: Rivals have tried to buy him off, creditors have gotten high-powered lawyers to try to cow him, investors have needled him about going through bankruptcy twice, his own son has accused him of being a polluter and many in the energy industry here shake their heads at the mention of his name.

title: Piazza Returns Hot: 3 Hits and a Homer
description: Mike Piazza returned to the Mets' lineup last night for the first time since Boston's Pedro Martinez hit him on the left hand with a fastball in the first inning on Friday night.

title: Samsung Curbing Output of Chips to Cut Back Inventories
description: The Samsung Electronics Company of South Korea, one of the largest semiconductor manufacturers, said today that it would suspend all production of memory chips and much of the production of nonmemory chips for a week to reduce inventory and strengthen prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINKOWITZ, MARION (NEE KORNBLAU)
description: MINKOWITZ-Marion (nee Kornblau). Age 89, of Brooklyn, NY. Died Sunday, June 7, 1998. Beloved wife of Jacob. Devoted mother of Dorothy Lewis, Martin Minkowitz & Renee Minkowitz. Mother-in-law of Lionel Lewis and Carol Ziegler. Loving grandmother of Tracey Okun, Jonathan Lewis and Stuart Minkowitz. Cherished great-grandmother of Mark and Scott Okun. She was a member of the Sisterhood of Temple Young Israel Beth-El of Boro Park; Vice President and ''Woman of the Year'' award recipient of Cancer Care; member of the Boro Park chapter of Haddasah. Funeral services 11:30 A.M., Tuesday, June 9, 1998, at Garlick Funeral Homes, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Anand Takes the High Road And Tops the Field in Madrid
description: Viswanathan Anand was originally picked by Garry Kasparov to contest a match with Vladimir Kramnik to determine who would challenge him for the world championship. Kasparov, under the aegis of his World Chess Council, which he formed with a Spanish sponsor, Luis Rentero, had decided that Anand and Kramnik were the two players closest to him in strength to justify that honor.

title: Cabby Who Fled India Finds New Struggle
description: DAY after day, the view of Balvinder Singh that people get is the back of his head. So why would anyone think he has a story to tell? But he does, like everyone else. His life has excellent, if heartbreaking, plot lines, from his flight from the 1984 pogrom of Sikhs in India to what Mr. Singh sees as the strange persecution of taxi drivers by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today.

title: ARCH COMMUNICATIONS TO REORGANIZE AND TRIM JOBS
description: Arch Communications Group Inc. said yesterday that it would revamp its business units and cut its work force of 2,800 by about 10 percent. Arch, a paging-services company, said the reorganization, which would take place in the next two years, would reduce the number of its divisions from seven to four. The units to be closed are in Portland, Ore.; Carmel, Ind., and Warrensville, Ohio. The company, based in Westborough, Mass., said the move would save it about $15 million a year, which it planned to reinvest in its sales operations. Arch said the restructuring would result in costs of about $15 million to $25 million for the second quarter.

title: Connecticut Official Wants Rate Cut From Phone Merger
description: The merger between Connecticut's primary telephone company and a Texas-based telecommunications giant should not be approved unless it includes a substantial rate reduction, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said today.

title: Report on Asian Crisis Clears Hedge Funds
description: Hedge fund managers like George Soros did not conspire to sell Asian currencies last year and touch off the capital flight that set off the economic slowdown that now grips the region, the Bank for International Settlements said today in its annual report.

title: Giuliani Vetoes $4.6 Million of Council's Allocation for Itself
description: Taking direct aim at his adversaries in the city budget battle, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani used his line-item veto power for the first time yesterday to eliminate nearly $5 million that the City Council had allocated for itself.

title: Gunman Fatally Shoots Man in a Brooklyn Park
description: Roy Fidel was talking to a few friends late Sunday night in Carroll Park, a small patch of trees and lawns in a brownstone-lined section of Brooklyn, when a green car pulled up and a man with a gun got out.

title: Irish Aircraft Lessor Trims Ties to G.E. Unit
description: GPA Group P.L.C., an Irish aircraft leasing company, said yesterday that it would seek an outside investor to take a ''significant minority stake'' as it severs a number of ties with the GE Capital Corporation unit of the General Electric Company.

title: Let the Good, and Bad, Times Roll
description: We live in easy times, according to the prevailing mood. Stocks are ascendant; crime has plummeted. If the late 1990's were a rock-and-roll show, they'd be a long, mellifluous jam by the Dave Matthews Band. Yet this pleasant haze is regularly punctuated by hard reality: teen-agers killing teen-agers, terrorists blowing up fairgrounds. If the late 1990's had a rock singer's voice, it would be the cracked, capricious wail of Dave Matthews.

title: An Auspicious Moment for Australian Designers
description: For decades, it has been the rule in Paris and Milan: if you build it, on a shoulder pad or on the bias, they will come.

title: Yen Continues Its Slide, Threatening Other Asian Markets
description: The Japanese yen weakened to 140 to the dollar for the first time in seven years yesterday, extending a yearlong decline that is now threatening the economic recovery of the emerging markets in Asia that were battered by their currency devaluations last year.

title: Korean President Sees a Western Cure for Economic Ills
description: President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea told New York business leaders yesterday that his country's once-prized economic miracle was nothing but a ''house of cards'' and that his people now needed American help to rebuild the economy in a more Western image.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILBUR, BEN E.
description: WILBUR-Ben E. Of Columbus, OH. Formerly of New Jersey. Died Friday, June 5, 1998, in Columbus. Former producer Voice of America, 1941-51; managed WOL, Washington, DC, 1951-53; director of radio/television for National Council of Churches, NYC 1953-61. Producer Sunday Radio for Norman Vincent Peale, 1962-80; instructor Morris Community College, Dover, NJ; University of Maryland, European Div. Survived by wife Doris Veronica Wilbur; son Jeffrey Z. Wilbur, San Angelo, TX; daughter Pamela Wilbur, Lubbock, TX; stepson Daniel (Mary) Fitzsimmons, Chula Vista, CA; sister Shirley (Robert) Maurath, Columbus, OH; brotherin-law Elden Sauerbrey, Dresden, OH; six grandchildren, three greatgrandchildren, many nieces and nephews.

title: CUNY Is Sued for Vote On Remedial Courses
description: In the first lawsuit aimed at preventing the City University of New York from halting remedial classes in its four-year colleges, a group of students and faculty members accused the trustees of violating New York State's open meeting law in May by removing members of the public before they voted to adopt the new remedial policy.

title: Sports of The Times; U.S. Team Is Secluded And Surly
description: FOR reading matter, Brian Maisonneuve had the latest copy of Les Pages Jaunes, a page-turner if ever there was one. His family name would indicate that he might be able to decipher the thrilling plot within, but Maisonneuve assured his visitors, ''I'm looking at the pictures.''

title: Harold Segal, World War II Hero, Dies at 77
description: Harold Segal, a Marine fighter pilot who shot down 12 Japanese planes in World War II, three of them in a single duel that ended with his being fished out of the Pacific Ocean by an American destroyer, died on Wednesday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 77.

title: The Living Are Grateful For the Dead's Legacy
description: For a band that's defunct, the Grateful Dead have been mighty busy lately. In San Francisco on Thursday night, the surviving core of the Dead introduced their new band, the Other Ones, reclaiming three decades' worth of Dead songs including, pointedly, songs by Jerry Garcia, whose death in 1995 put an end to the band. On Friday night, members of the Dead's sound crew were on the QVC cable-television shopping channel, hawking live recordings of the Dead and taking in a quick $70,000. And on Saturday night, the San Jose Stage Company in California gave the premiere of ''Cumberland Blues,'' a musical built around early-1970's songs by Garcia and Robert Hunter, the band's best lyricist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BITTER, HERBERT J.
description: BITTER-Herbert J. Born August 4, 1919, passed away June 7, 1998 in Dallas, Texas. He was President of Georgetown Marketing. Herbert was a beloved husband, devoted father, grandfather, brother, good friend and all around great guy. He is survived by wife Frieda; children, Mitchell and Rena Bitter, Eileen and Mark Rosenzweig; grandsons, Joshua and Adam Rosenzweig and sister Helen Daniels. We love you, Herb. Services will be held on Tuesday, June 9, 1998, 12 noon at Riverside Funeral Home, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Heart Association, 7320 Greenville Avenue, Dallas, TX 75231 or the American Cancer Society, 8900 Carpenter Freeway, Dallas, TX. 75247.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONENBERG, BERNARD, M.D.
description: KRONENBERG - Bernard, M.D. The officers, board and staff of the Jewish Braille Institute of America offer profound sympathy to his beloved family and also to all those whose lives were so enriched by the extraordinary medical skills and deeply sensitive personality throughout his decades of service. The visually impaired served today by the JBI throughout the United States, Israel and in many other countries are beneficiaries of Dr. Kronenberg's having been the pioneer who first added to our agency's program large print and other additional services for them. Thus, we opened the doors of Judaic heritage to thousands more of all ages. His memory endures for lasting blessing and inspiration.

title: St. John's Nears Deal With Jarvis
description: After more than four weeks of searching for a new head basketball coach, St. John's appears to be closing in on a deal with Mike Jarvis of George Washington University.

title: Partner Notification for H.I.V.
description: A bill before the New York State Senate would notify spouses, sex partners and needle-sharing partners of H.I.V.-infected people of their exposure to the virus. Notification is particularly important as AIDS and H.I.V. become more prevalent among women, minorities and the young. There are too many cases where women and their babies have become infected because husbands and boyfriends hid the truth. The bill, sponsored by Assemblywoman Nettie Mayersohn and Senator Guy Velella, and supported by the New York State Association of County Health Officials and the New York State Medical Society, would give spouses and others access to crucial information so that they can take steps to avoid infection.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Right of States to Extradite Fugitives Is Upheld
description: States have an unalterable duty to return other states' fugitives, the Supreme Court ruled today in a unanimous opinion that gave the New Mexico Supreme Court no choice but to extradite an escaped parolee whom the state court had deemed to be a ''refugee from injustice'' in the Ohio prison system.

title: Enthusiastic N.R.A. Gives Mandate to Charlton Heston
description: With a courtly bow, the actor Charlton Heston acknowledged a loud, standing ovation today by the National Rifle Association board of directors, which voted overwhelmingly to make him the N.R.A.'s 56th president.

title: Yankees Keep Eyes Ahead, Not on History
description: Like mountain climbers afraid of heights, the Yankees don't want to look down. They don't want to look around, to check out the view from their lofty perch in the standing. Joe Torre, the manager, walks out of the room if others start comparing his team's incredible record with other standards in baseball history.

title: A Composer's 60th, Quirks and All
description: Today Charles Wuorinen celebrates his 60th birthday. Two days ago the Works and Process series at the Guggenheim Museum was helping him get in the mood by presenting a short concert of his music, given by longstanding friends and other virtuosos. Many characteristic Wuorinenian qualities were prominently on display: the rhythmic dynamism, the playfulness, the solid and thoroughly traditional handling of instruments, the odd combination of the studied and the quirky.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Weekend on Friday about a pledge by American museums to search their collections for artworks taken illegally from owners in the Nazi era misstated the name of the group that announced the plan. It is the Association of Art Museum Directors, not the Association of American Art Museum Directors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMPEL, CLARISSE B.
description: KAMPEL-Clarisse B. On June 7, 1998. Adored wife of Daniel S. Kampel. Beloved aunt of John B. Ritter and Ernestine Clark, and stepmother of Stacie Soloway. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, June 8, at 7-9 PM, with services Tuesday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in her memory to The Quan Fellowship at Harvard Medical School.

title: Metro Business; Battery Park City Plans New Building
description: More than 60 developers have been invited to submit proposals for a residential building at the northern end of Battery Park City and are being encouraged to design large apartments for families, officials said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Walton Is Still Heard From the Back Seat
description: What I wouldn't have given for a few renditions of ''That's terrible!'' from Bill Walton to describe Utah's ignominious 96-54 collapse Sunday night to Chicago in Game 3 of the National Basketball Association finals.
