description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONTANA, LOUIS
description: FONTANA-Louis. On June 7, 1998. Owner of Dumont Barbar Shop (Hotel Iroquois, NYC) and ''James Dean's barber''. Beloved husband of Mary. Devoted father of Angela and Louis. Cherished grandfather of Stephanie. Funeral Thursday 1 PM from the Andrew Torregrossa and Sons Funeral Home, 345 Avenue U, Brooklyn. Visiting on Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-9PM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Tootsie Roll Stock Split
description: Tootsie Roll Industries said today that it would split its shares 2 for 1. The stock split will double the number of shares to 48 million, but halve their value. The company had 24 million shares on average, as of March 28. Shares of Tootsie Roll Industries rose $1.375, to $78.125. The new shares will be issued July 13 to shareholders of record as of June 22.

title: A Crucial Privilege Case
description: Though the Presidential inquiry by Kenneth Starr has yet to produce many answers, his hunt for evidence has raised thorny legal issues, among them the fight over attorney-client privilege heard yesterday by the Supreme Court.

title: Clinton Deserves Due Process, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: For Cancer Patients, Hope Can Add to Pain
description: WHEN William Roy Bond learned last year that he had cancer, his doctor was honest about the grim diagnosis: end-stage lung cancer that had spread to the liver, stomach and pancreas. The doctor assumed that the diagnosis spoke for itself, that Mr. Bond would understand that treatment was futile, recalled his wife, Helen. ''But he didn't hear it,'' she said. ''My husband said he wanted chemotherapy.''

title: British Cast Spotlight on Misconduct in Scientific Research
description: LITTLE can rival the misery of a medical researcher who discovers that a co-author has committed scientific misconduct. One who feels that most keenly is Dr. Cameron Bowie, emeritus director of public health in Somerset, England.

title: Stabilizing the Ruble
description: To the Editor:

title: Water World: Love of Plumbing
description: A $5 billion water tunnel stretching 64 miles: they said it couldn't be done.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: M.C.'s Impudence Is No 'Cabaret' Act

title: KERR-MCGEE SELLING COAL MINES FOR $600 MILLION
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its coal mining operations in two deals for a total of $600 million. Kerr-McGee, an energy company, said the decision was part of a strategy to concentrate on its oil and natural-gas exploration and production business and its titanium-dioxide business. Under one deal, Kerr-McGee will sell its Jacobs Ranch Mine in Wyoming to the Kennecott Energy Company, a Gillette, Wyo., unit of the British mining giant Rio Tinto P.L.C. In the other deal, Kerr-McGee will sell its Galatia Mine in Illinois to the closely held American Coal Company. Shares of Kerr-McGee, based in Oklahoma City, fell $1.8125 yesterday, to $61.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMS, DAWN WESTON
description: TOMS-Dawn Weston. Nicholas R. H. Toms announces the death of his beloved wife Dawn Weston Toms of cancer Sunday, June 7, 1998 at their home in Manhattan. Mrs. Toms a resident of NYC and Montauk, Long Island was born in Matatiele, South Africa on May 2, 1946. Her work as a Director of an European-based international real estate firm brought her to the United States where she has lived continuously since 1969. In addition to her work, Mrs. Toms was a passionate gardener and talented decorator, possessing an exceptional sense of color which marked all her creative projects with distinction. In addition to her husband, Mrs. Toms is survived by her mother, Dorothy van Eeden, of Capetown, South Africa, a brother of Trevor Hodd of Springbok, South Africa and many devoted friends. The funeral service will be held on Thursday, June 11 at 2 P.M., at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and 52nd Street in NYC. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, gifts be directed in Mrs. Tom's name to the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Institute, P.O. Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day yesterday about plans by Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities Inc. to close its primary dealership unit misstated one result. The closing will free about $9 billion of capital that had been earmarked for trading; it will not directly save $9 billion.

title: Hard to Be His Instruments
description: The drummer Han Bennink broke the skin of his snare drum because he hit it so hard, and then he stood up and played a pipe in the wall. He knocked the new snare drum over by accident, and played it on the floor. He played the floor itself, too, and put towels over his drums and whacked them all. He put the case covers of his drums on the drums and played them, and stuck a drumstick in his mouth and tapped on that, changing the pitch of the sound. On the surface, Mr. Bennink was performing a theater piece; beyond it was a deep musicality that the show couldn't hide.

title: The Minimalist; Burger With No Need of Ketchup
description: THERE were several things that inspired me to create a salmon burger. I knew it would taste good, which is really reason enough. And I figured people would be unlikely to cover it with ketchup, another plus. Then there's the fact that salmon is sold everywhere, and when on sale, it's not much more expensive than ground meat. Finally, the oils contained in salmon are actually supposed to have some health benefits -- at least according to the current wisdom -- thanks to its high percentage of omega-3 fatty acids.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Building Owners Are Cool to New Power Suppliers
description: Building owners and managers in New York City were free to choose their electric power suppliers for the first time at the start of this month, but the reaction of some major commercial property companies so far is: no big deal.

title: Amex Agrees to a Combination With the Philadelphia Exchange
description: The American Stock Exchange and the Philadelphia Stock Exchange agreed to a merger late yesterday that would create an options trading powerhouse to rival the giant Chicago Board Options Exchange.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: From Palau to Kyrgyzstan, Leaders Agree: The Scourge Is Drugs
description: Palau's President describes his nation as an island paradise, with the world's best scuba diving in pristine South Pacific waters, abundant seafood, safe streets and a growing economy.

title: Q & A / Muchtar Pakpahan : 'Suharto Pulls the Strings'
description: Muchtar Pakpahan, founder of Indonesia's first independent labor union, SBSI, in 1992, was imprisoned by the Suharto government for "subversive activities" in 1996. After Mr. Suharto stepped down on May 21, Mr. Pakpahan was one of the first political prisoners to be released. The 45-year-old activist from Sumatra was invited by the World Confederation of Labor to attend the annual assembly of the International Labor Organization in Geneva this week. He discussed his country's problems and prospects with Robert Kroon for the IHT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MARTIN
description: STONE-Martin. Of Pound Ridge, New York, on June 7, 1998 in Washington, D.C. Beloved father of Judith Ain (Ross) and Richard Stone (Shirley). Loving grandfather of Jeremy and Jennifer Ain, and Deirdre and Elizabeth Stone. A special person who touched so many lives with his warmth, intellect and engaging personality. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him.

title: Marketers sweat a bit as 'Godzilla' disappoints at the box office. Will product tie-ins follow suit?
description: WITH ''Godzilla'' turning out to be more of a limping lizard than a leaping lizard at the box office, the scores of promotional, licensing and merchandising partners that anticipated the film would be a summer blockbuster must now hope that size won't matter after all.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the death of Gen. Sani Abacha, the Nigerian leader, misidentified his predecessor. General Abacha took over in 1993 by unseating President Ernest Shonekan, an unelected civilian leader for two and a half months, not Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, who had installed Mr. Shonekan.

title: Dieter Roth, Reclusive Artist And Tireless Provocateur, 68
description: Dieter Roth, a prolific, notoriously irascible, reclusive and eccentric German-born artist-provocateur who built a formidable reputation in Europe but remained something of a mystery in America, in part because he permitted his work to be exhibited here even more rarely than there, died on Saturday in Basel, Switzerland, where he had a home. He was 68.

title: ARTS IN AMERICA: The Proust of the Prairie Gallops On; A Decade After His Death, Louis L'Amour Remains a Publisher's Dream
description: If you saw Maggie Rock in a movie, or read about it in a novel by Louis L'Amour, you would recognize it as the kind of craggy butte where hostile Indians might gather before descending on a wagon train in the valley below. But late one recent afternoon, there were just a couple of casual explorers on the ridge, one of them Kathy L'Amour, the novelist's widow, who goes up there a lot.

title: Calendar
description: South African Wine Tasting

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PHARMERICA INC., Tampa, Fla., agreed to acquire National Institutional Pharmaceutical Services Inc., Owings Mills, Md., a unit of Integrated Health Services Inc., for undisclosed terms.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS, REBOUNDS SLIGHTLY. The yen reached 141 to the dollar before rebounding on fear the Group of Seven nations would bolster Japan's currency. In New York, the dollar cost 140.30 yen, down from 140.71.

title: Baltimore Journal; As City Buffs Its Image, It Keeps a Place for Hons
description: The crowd grew quiet, knowing a solemn moment was finally at hand. Pamela Foresman stepped forward. These were her final minutes as Baltimore's Best Hon, the title she won at the Cafe Hon last year.

title: Modern Power In Rituals Of Africa
description: Ronald K. Brown can be depended on for powerful, stylish modern dance choreography. Rokiya Kone and her Jeune Ballet d'Afrique Noire, based in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, are new to New York City. But Ms. Kone's gifts were clear in ''Destiny/ Dakan/Destin,'' a world premiere and collaboration with Mr. Brown that was presented on Sunday afternoon at Aaron Davis Hall at City College.

title: Clinton Rejects Pleas to Avoid Tiananmen Ceremony
description: President Clinton rejected appeals today that he avoid an official welcoming ceremony in Tiananmen Square in Beijing when he visits China this month, saying that he could not dictate to China's leaders how he should be received in their country.

title: At St. John's, a New Era Requires a Big Name
description: There was a split second of hesitation on the other end of the line. Eric Barkley, the all-America guard who will attend St. John's in September, learned that he might be the linchpin for a new coach's championship aspirations.

title: Under it All, The Band's Pleasures
description: Sonic Youth is proud of its high-flown side. As the band started a three-night stand at Irving Plaza on Monday night, Kim Gordon sang lines like ''the radical beacon, the preverbal season/the abstract poetics, immediate treason,'' from ''The Ineffable Me.'' Sonic Youth is renowned for its precisely retuned guitars, which defy the conventions of well-tempered music, and for its continuing explorations of finely calibrated dissonance and noise.

title: House to Vote Today on Legislation for Bankruptcy Overhaul
description: The House is preparing to vote on Wednesday on the first major overhaul of the bankruptcy system in two decades, legislation that could allow the credit and banking industries to reap billions of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNAFEL, SUSAN
description: KNAFEL-Susan. The Board and staff of the New York Association for New Americans, Inc., mourn the passing of Susan Knafel, for many years a member of our Board of Directors. During that time, Susan was actively engaged in NYANA's casework, employment & training and health care committees. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Laura G. Ross, President Mark Handelman, Executive VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, BENJAMIN T.
description: WEINBERG-Benjamin T. Died on June 9, 1998. The lifelong Brooklyn resident was 94. For over 50 years he owned and operated Richard's Jewelers on Lexington Avenue in New York and was active in the New York Jewelers Benevolent Association. His wife of 64 years, Helen Younger Weinberg died in 1991. He is survived by his son, Richard and daughter-in-law Rita of Boynton Beach, FL.; his daughter Marjorie and son-in-law Arthur Kaufman of East Stroudsburg, Pa.; grandchildren Amy, Cindy, Susan, Paul and Donna; and great-grandchildren Michael, Michele, Rachel and Jessica. Services Thursday, June 11 at 10am at Kirschenbaum/ Garlick, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, New York. Interment at Beth Moses cemetery.

title: Despite Loss, Capitals Like Chances
description: The Washington Capitals seemed upbeat and encouraged tonight. Their coach, Ron Wilson, talked as if he couldn't wait to start Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals.

title: School-Prayer Fallacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Convertibles Ordered to Compensate 780 Customers After Complaints Pile Up
description: Jennifer Convertibles Inc., one of the largest chains of furniture stores in the New York region, has been ordered to compensate more than 700 customers after what Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco said was a flood of complaints since 1995.

title: Seeing Threat to Casinos, Tribes March on the Capitol
description: In an intensifying battle between California's American Indians and its Governor, more than 100 tribal leaders traveled here this week to try to halt what they call a threat to the survival of their reservations: state action to rein in their casinos.

title: BUICK CLASSIC
description: Ernie Els said yesterday that he would love to three-peat and win his third straight title in the Buick Classic, which starts tomorrow at Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y. After that, he added, it would be nice to repeat as the United States Open champion and win the event for the third time.

title: Josephine Hutchinson, 94, Movie Actress
description: Josephine Hutchinson, a stage and film actress who gained prominence in the 1930's and early 40's, died on June 4 at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 94.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA S.
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara S. Happy birthday, Bobs. Gone a year but you're still with me constantly. My one in a million sis. Johnnie

title: Miller and Fassel Meet at Camp and Call a Truce of Sorts
description: Giants linebacker Corey Miller arrived at Giants Stadium for the team's passing camp today, one day later than Coach Jim Fassel had been expecting him.

title: Nigeria's Moment of Truth
description: Five years ago when my father, Moshood Abiola, was elected President of Nigeria, I did not expect that the military would arrest him on false charges of treason and put him in prison. Nor did I expect that my mother, Kudirat Abiola, who fought for his release, would be gunned down three years later. Such political violence against a woman was unprecedented.

title: BASEBALL: While Nomo Struggles, Hernandez Takes Control; Newest Starting Pitcher Surprises Even the Yanks With His Mastery
description: When the Yankees signed Orlando Hernandez in March, they knew he was brave enough to board a leaky boat. They knew he had the determination to defect from Cuba. They knew he possessed a strange delivery that often changed from one pitch to the next.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 27 about Jermal Kirnon, an 11-year-old Bronx boy who was returned to foster parents who had beaten him, misstated the birth month of the couple's daughter, Angelique. It was September 1997, not March.

title: It's a Mall . . . It's an Airport; . . . It's Both: The Latest Trend in Terminals
description: It is not easy to squeeze into a dressing room with two pieces of carry-on luggage and a laptop to try on a pair of jeans. And the sight of three airline captains hovering over a table of pink lingerie at Victoria's Secret still draws a second glance.

title: Tougher Rules Proposed On Money Laundering
description: A package of bills was introduced yesterday to increase penalties for money laundering and impose new reporting requirements on banks and check-cashing businesses to help track illegal profits.

title: Under Heston, Same Old N.R.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Signing Bonus Now a Fixture Farther Down the Job Ladder
description: Unable to hire enough teachers, the Dallas school board voted last month to lure them with $1,500 signing bonuses. Corporate recruiters paid out much larger bonuses -- averaging $17,500 -- to Cornell's business school graduates. Even Burger King has got into the bonus game, offering $5,000 in some cities to hire away restaurant managers from rival fast-food chains.

title: First Bosnia, Now Kosovo
description: The last war in the Balkans lasted four years and took more than 200,000 lives before President Clinton and NATO finally intervened. Under the impetus of NATO air strikes, the United States and its envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, brought the warring Bosnians together at Dayton, Ohio, and hammered out a peace.

title: Swiss-Japanese Alliance Said to Be on Track
description: Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd. and the Swiss Bank Corporation, which is merging with Union Bank of Switzerland to form the world's second-largest bank, dismissed speculation yesterday that their alliance in Japan was in trouble. The deputy president of Long-Term Credit Bank, Masami Suda, said at a news conference that a rumor the business alliance with Swiss Bank might be dissolved was ''absolutely groundless.'' Mr. Suda's comments helped the shares, which had plunged, to recover to 167 yen at the close, down 14 yen, or 7.7 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, CATHERINE MEREDITH
description: BROWN - Catherine Meredith. June 3, 1998. Wife of the late John Mason Brown; mother of Preston and Meredith Brown, grandfather of Mason Barnard Brown, John Preston Brown, and Catherine St. George Brown. A Memorial Service will be conducted at Calvary Church, Stonington CT, Saturday, June 27 at 11:15 A.M. Memorial gifts may be made to Episcopal Charities, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10025.

title: Boeing to Increase Cuts in 747 Production
description: The Boeing Company announced yesterday that weakening demand in Asia would force it to cut production of its wide-body jets even deeper than the company had previously indicated, resulting in further job cuts.

title: 225 Years of the Royal Swedish Ballet
description: As King Carl XVI Gustaf and Queen Silvia of Sweden rode out from their palace in an open carriage on Saturday to greet a populace celebrating the King's 25-year reign, the clouds lifted. The sun shone not only on the plumed helmets of the King's horse guard, riding with sabers drawn, but also on the nearby Royal Opera, which, with its ballet company, was founded by King Gustav III in 1773.

title: A Bit of Lisbon In the Meadowlands
description: BENFICA 3, METROSTARS 1

title: NBC Buying A Portal To the Internet
description: Venturing into the most competitive area of the Internet, NBC said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a controlling stake in Snap, an upstart search and directory service, from its creator, Cnet Inc. The television network said it was also buying a nearly 5 percent stake in Cnet itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, SAUL DAVID
description: ASTOR-Saul David. On June 8, 1998. Beloved husband of Patricia, loving father of Andrew and Lauren, adoring grandfather of Brett, Eric and Kate. Devoted brother of Martin and the late Edith. Services Wednesday, June 10, at 1 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Children's Defense Fund, 25 E Street NW, Washington, DC 20001.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review yesterday about a workshop performance by students from the School of American Ballet at the Juilliard Theater on Saturday misstated the surname of the school's director of security, who read a poem at the end of the program. He is Carlton Shaw, not Smith.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, MARC
description: MURPHY-Marc. On June 4, 1998. Beloved son of the late Catherine and James, loving brother of Laurel, dear nephew of Adele DeBellis. Interment Friday, June 12, 10:30 AM St. John's Cemetery. Memorial service 3:30 PM Sat, June 20, at the Church of St. Luke in the Field, 487 Hudson St. In lieu of flowers, donations to the AIDS Project of St. Luke or the St. Luke Chapel Fund. For information call Nucciarone Funeral Home, 212-254-3007.

title: Moscow Statisticians Accused of Aiding Tax Evasion
description: The Yeltsin Government began its long-overdue fight against tax evasion today by arresting the country's top statisticians and accusing them of manipulating data to help Russian companies avoid taxes.

title: Yeltsin Plans Personal Bid To Defuse Kosovo Crisis
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, seeking to forestall a NATO military incursion in the Serbian province of Kosovo, promised today to undertake a personal diplomatic effort with the Serbian leadership in an effort to defuse the violence there.

title: Judge to Limit Witnesses in Microsoft Suit
description: Trying to avert a lengthy proceeding, a Federal judge said today that he planned to limit the number of witnesses the Microsoft Corporation and the Government may call during the September trial for the antitrust suits filed by the Justice Department and 20 states.

title: Devotion and Virtuosity In the Cantorial Tradition
description: To commemorate the 50th anniversary of the founding of the Cantors Assembly, nearly two dozen cantors from synagogues across the country took to the stage of Carnegie Hall on Monday evening and performed classic settings of prayers from the Sabbath and holiday services. That the concert had a celebratory quality was not surprising: the assembly's aim was to put its most virtuosic members in the spotlight and to honor the compositions of several generations of cantors.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Personal Health column in Science Times yesterday, about new weight guidelines, misstated an alternate formula for computing body mass. The formula, which was given correctly in a chart, entails squaring height, not weight.

title: Spanish Utility Shares Post a Big Drop
description: The shares of Endesa S.A., Spain's largest power company, posted their biggest one-day drop in more than two years yesterday as new shares in Spain's largest state asset sale ever flooded the market, and individual investors sold their shares to profit from a discount during the sale. Shares in Endesa dropped 170 pesetas, or 5 percent, to 3,275. More than 35 million shares traded yesterday, almost nine times the average daily volume for 1998.

title: Bid to Expand Javits Center Loses Ground
description: State officials are scrambling to salvage a $750 million plan to expand the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on the West Side of Manhattan, which has collided with the Giuliani administration's proposal to build a stadium for the New York Yankees and a developer's efforts to erect a sprawling apartment complex.

title: Prosecutor in Louima Case Will Resign
description: In a decision that surprised legal observers and led to speculation about its timing, the lead Federal prosecutor in the Abner Louima case said yesterday that she would resign and return to her former job at a private law firm in Manhattan.

title: NETWORK ASSOCIATES TO ACQUIRE DR. SOLOMON'S
description: Network Associates agreed yesterday to acquire Dr. Solomon's Group P.L.C., the British maker of antivirus software, for $642 million in stock. Network Associates, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it would offer 0.82875 share of its common stock for each American depository receipt of Dr. Solomon's. The stock of Net Associates rose $1.875 a share yesterday, to $43.875. Dr. Solomon's American depository receipts rose $3.375 each, to $35.50. Network Associates, whose flagship product is the McAfee Virus Scan software, said it would take a one-time charge in the third quarter to pay for the acquisition.

title: Ex-Argentine Junta Leader Held in 70's Kidnappings
description: Former President Jorge Rafael Videla, who had previously been pardoned for his role in the disappearances of thousands of political dissidents from 1976 to 1983, was detained today and could face charges of child kidnapping, the Government announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDDY, WILLIAM F.
description: LUDDY-William F. On June 8, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Virginia. Loving father of Jeanne VanDuzer, Thomas, Brian, David, James and the late William F. Luddy. Also survived by five grandchildren. Reposing at the McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains on Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, 10AM, Our Lady of Sorrows Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: About New York; Cash Squeeze Makes It Hard To Save Lives
description: JOE PEREZ'S pulse quickens when the phone rings inside his storefront office at the Bedford-Stuyvesant Volunteer Ambulance Corps. The adrenaline rush psyches him up to respond to a cardiac call or some other code-red emergency. It also fuels his response to the corps's lingering code green, a lack of funds that has left these trailblazers having to perform triage on their bills.

title: Liberties; Feathered and Tarred
description: Monica Lewinsky's glamour shots in Vanity Fair are pornography.

title: WET SEAL TO BUY 83 BRITCHES GREAT OUTDOOR STORES
description: Wet Seal Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase about 83 Britches Great Outdoor stores for an undisclosed amount. Wet Seal, a retailer of casual apparel and accessories, said it planned to turn most of the Britches stores into Arden B. stores and the rest into Wet Seal, Contempo Casuals and Limbo Lounge stores. Excluding the Britches deal, Wet Seal said it planned to open 75 stores in 1998. Wet Seal, based in Foothill Ranch, Calif., had 1997 sales of $412.5 million. It owns 411 stores in 42 states and Puerto Rico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSSIN, HARRIET
description: KOSSIN-Harriet, 67. On June 8, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Bill Kossin. Dear mother of Ruth Queen, loving sister of Helen Bass and Marion Vaccarella, and adored grandmother of William & Peter Queen. Funeral Services will be Wednesday, June 10, 1998, 9:30 AM, from the Bloomfield Cooper Jewish Chapels, 44 Wilson Avenue, Manalapan, New Jersey, with the burial following at the King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXMAN, ARTHUR
description: WAXMAN-Arthur. On June 9, 1998. Beloved husband and father. Services Thursday, 12 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Air France Pilots Not Budging : World Cup Is On, As Is Labor Unrest
description: PARIS  The World Cup soccer tournament officially opened in France on Tuesday night amid a wave of labor unrest as specific groups of workers used the world's biggest sporting event as a lever to get higher pay, bonuses or improved conditions.

title: Now Boarding: The Turbot, A True Fish Out of Water
description: EVERY two or three weeks in a refrigerated warehouse at Charles de Gaulle Airport outside Paris, a man in a white laboratory coat lifts live turbot out of a cold seawater tank and lays them, one by one, into dry styrofoam boxes. The fish lie almost completely still, but they are very much alive.

title: Retail's Knotty Knockoff Problem Goes to Court
description: When a Paris court ordered Ralph Lauren to stop selling knockoffs of Yves Saint Laurent's tuxedo dresses in 1994, the message was clear: fashion, at least in France, can be subject to protection from the scheming scissors of competitors. But here in the United States, should a simple blue-and-white-striped shirt enjoy similar sanctuary?

title: Woman, 43, Faces Charges In Fatal Fire In Queens
description: Police detectives accused a 43-year-old woman of second-degree murder and arson yesterday, saying she set a fire that killed one person and injured nine others on Monday at an overcrowded home in Queens. City officials also cited the home's owner for illegally subdividing the two-family residence into six apartments.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Blue-Chip Rally Fades, But Internet Shares Gain

title: Programming Is Blamed In Computer Failure
description: A programming error by engineers who were attempting to upgrade the State Division of Motor Vehicles computer system was responsible for the shutdown of computers in the agency's 45 field offices and 4 regional service centers on Monday, officials said yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Public Ambition of A Private Firm
description: As the partners of Goldman, Sachs & Company debate whether to turn Wall Street's premier private investment bank into a public company, they might mull over this paradox: They are earning record profits advising clients to do deals they themselves would never do.

title: Maine Holds Its Primary Among Modest Spenders
description: Maine's primary today could be considered a breath of cool, fresh political air after the overheated spending of California's election last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRENIER, JANE V.
description: GRENIER-Jane V. On Sunday, June 7, 1998, of Potomac, MD, and formerly of New York City. Beloved wife of the late Edward J. Grenier, mother of Edward J. Grenier, Jr., also survived by three grandchildren, Tori Eklund, Edward Grenier III, Peter C. Grenier, and three great-grandchildren, Sara and Kristen Eklund, and Sydney Grenier. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday, June 10 from 6 to 9 P.M. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at St. John The Evangelist Catholic Church, First Avenue at 55th Street, NYC 10022, on Thursday June 11th at 10 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Saint John The Evangelist Church or The Montgomery Hospice Society, 1450 Research Boulevard, Suite 310, Rockville, MD 20850.

title: Many Internet Shares Rally, but Major Indexes Are Mixed
description: A three-day rally in stocks fizzled yesterday and left major market indexes mixed, illustrating Wall Street's renewed concerns about the corporate earnings outlook and some wariness about the near-term prospect for interest rates.

title: Drug Regulators Make Push To Rein In Herbal Remedies
description: Here at the base of the Rocky Mountains, in a region that is the heart of the nation's herbal and vitamin industry, a stainless steel contraption was hard at work on a recent morning, spitting out clear plastic capsules at the rate of 90,000 an hour. Each contained precisely 600 milligrams of a fine, brick-colored powder that Federal health officials are trying to ban.

title: $1 Million Gift for New Charity Case: the Viagra-Needy
description: Alan C. Greenberg bettered his own life by becoming rich on Wall Street, and yesterday he gave away $1 million of that money to better the lives of other aging men in a very specific way: He will pay for Viagra prescriptions for people who cannot afford them.

title: In Bilingual-Schooling Setback, Educators See Another Swing of Pendulum
description: With the defeat of bilingual schooling in California, educators around the country are examining that program's ill-fated path and drawing parallels to the outcome of other educational innovations of recent decades.

title: Angst, Guilt, Lust and Loneliness
description: ''I'm a New Yorker; fear's my life,'' sings the battle-scarred support-group attendee in ''Rent.'' Free-floating anxiety may well be the birthright of every son and daughter of the five boroughs, but everyone knows that in this perilous age, it's parents who have first dibs on fretting.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR AT 7-YEAR LOW. Sugar fell 3.9 percent to the weakest level since April 1991 on fear that a record harvest and weakened demand in Asia will create a global glut. July contracts fell 0.31 cent, to 7.55 cents a pound.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Playing Yourself

description: To the Editor:

title: Partisan Counting
description: To the Editor:

title: Rescuers Claw Through Mountain of Grain
description: While anxious family members waited and prayed, dozens of rescue workers desperately dug through tons of grain and debris today in search of four men who were trapped after an explosion at one of the world's largest grain elevators near this Midwestern city.

title: The Chef
description: WHEN I was a kid, I was forbidden to drink alcohol but was allowed to eat Mon Cheri, a chocolate-cherry candy that tasted boozy and made me feel like a grown-up. This cherry-chocolate tart, with its cherries poached in port, is definitely not kid stuff, but it was inspired by those foil-wrapped candies of childhood.

title: Trying to Cut Special Education Rolls
description: In proposing an overhaul of the $2.5 billion special-education system in the city's schools, the Mayor and the Schools Chancellor said yesterday that they were seeking to reverse what they described as alarming growth in the number of children consigned to expensive, segregated classrooms.

title: New York Pizza, the Real Thing, Makes a Comeback
description: NEW YORK pizza is a phrase synonymous with pizza greatness, yet for years New Yorkers could find the genuine article in only a few isolated spots. Now pizza lovers can rejoice: the true New York pizza is back in town.

title: Pursuing A Woman, A Fortune And God
description: The play, all too fittingly, is about a crucifixion of sorts. And when it opened on Broadway late in 1964, many critics and theatergoers felt they had been handed a custom-made hammer and set of nails to use on its author. Edward Albee, at that moment, was still garlanded in the success of 1962's ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,'' and he had been thrust onto cultural heights that have not been visited since by an American playwright. The successor to Williams and Miller, he was being called; the future of the country's theater.

title: Philadelphia Mayor Gives N.R.A. a Challenge
description: Pushing his figurative poker chips into the pot, Mayor Edward G. Rendell called the National Rifle Association's hand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREGEL, ALEXANDER
description: PREGEL-Alexander. Died June 6, 1998 at age 91 in Sarasota, Florida. Survived by his wife, Ellie; son, Robert; grandson, Richard and great grandson, Alexander. Contributions to: Hospice of Southwest Florida, 5955 Rand Boulevard, Sarasota, FL. 34238.

title: The Pitfalls Of Global Justice
description: The United States has a penchant these days for joining international negotiations that spin out of control. We went to Kyoto to talk about climate change and discovered we couldn't sign the treaty. We went to Ottawa to talk about land mines and found our military problems ignored by other states.

title: Remaking Special Education
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew will be judged in no small measure on what he does to repair special education, the troubled program for disabled children that eats up a quarter of New York City's education budget, graduates few of its students and has come under Federal scrutiny for potential violations of civil rights laws. Dr. Crew acquired an important tool in this fight last year, when the State Legislature enhanced his powers to seize control of failing schools and hold principals accountable for school performance. He now intends to restructure the special-education bureaucracy itself, an unwieldy system-within-a-system that currently runs itself, accountable to almost no one.

title: COMPUTONE IN DEAL TO ENTER COMMUNICATIONS SERVICES
description: The Computone Corporation, a maker of computer hardware and software, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Ladia L.L.C., a closely held long-distance wholesale telephone and data carrier, for stock worth more than $61 million, based on Monday's closing price. The Computone Corporation, based in Alpharetta, Ga., makes computer connectivity hardware and software. The company said it wanted Ladia to help it enter the communications services market. Under the agreement, Computone will pay up to 8.5 million common shares for the Boston-based Ladia. Shares of Computone dropped 31.25 cents to close at $6.875. The combined company will be renamed Ladia Communications Technologies Inc.

title: Under Heston, Same Old N.R.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Score Behind Closed Doors
description: The United States, which has struggled to find the net in recent warmup matches, put away four goals against a French second-division club yesterday in St. Jean D'Ardieres, France.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBORD, RABBI RUWIN JONA
description: WEISBORD-Rabbi Ruwin Jona. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the beloved father of its Rebetzen Yocheved Schacter and father-in-law of Rabbi Jacob J. Schacter. May his entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Samuel Goldman, President Arthur G. Degen, Ch. of the Board Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: DLJ MERCHANT BANKING PARTNERS RAISES BID FOR INSILCO
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc.'s merchant banking unit raised its bid yesterday for the Insilco Corporation, an industrial parts maker, to $455 million from $437 million. Donaldson, Lufkin's new offer of $45 a share, up from its $44.50 offer made in March, follows the award of a $36 million verdict in a suit that an Insilco unit, Taylor Publishing, won against Jostens Inc. DLJ Merchant Banking Partners II agreed to buy 90 percent of Insilco, based in Dublin, Ohio, for cash, some stock and assumed debt. Insilco shareholders will receive $43.48 cash and 0.03378 share of retained stock under the terms of the new offer. Insilco's stock rose 56.25 cents, to $44.25. Shares of Donaldson, which is owned by the Equitable Companies, rose $1.125, to $48.

title: Alice Waters Negotiates For Restaurant in Louvre
description: MON Dieu! The mother of modern American cooking has been asked to open a restaurant at the temple of French culture in Paris.

title: Off the Menu
description: Chefs on the Move

title: North Korea Rebukes Japan by Canceling a Visit by Women
description: North Korea today called off a planned visit by Japanese-born women to Japan, in a sign of steadily worsening relations between the two countries.

title: Acquisitions By Three Companies
description: Three agency companies have made acquisitions for undisclosed financial terms.

title: BANKAMERICA PLACES ITS MUTUAL FUNDS UNIT ON SALE
description: The BankAmerica Corporation put its Robertson Stephens Investment Management mutual funds unit up for sale yesterday as the parent company, the largest West Coast bank, prepares to merge with the Nationsbank Corporation. The decision comes less than two weeks after the San Francisco-based bank agreed to sell its investment banking unit to the BankBoston Corporation. Robertson Stephens Investment Management, which manages about $4 billion of assets, would fetch about $150 million in a sale, analysts said. BankAmerica said a sale of the Robertson Stephens unit would not affect other parts of the bank's money-management business.

title: Wine Talk; Chateau Scandal Leaves Bordeaux Uneasy
description: WINE scandals are few and far between in Bordeaux, but when they occur, as in the current crisis involving Chateau Giscours, they become major events, not just in France but worldwide.

title: In Drug Arrest, Police Failed to Tell Child Agency They Were Moving Children
description: The police acknowledged yesterday that they had failed to notify New York City's child welfare agency so that it could arrange care for two young boys who the Government said were being used as drug couriers by their father.

title: The Pop Life; Eclecticism Personified
description: Before speaking a word of greeting, Keigo Oyamada runs around the offices of Trattoria Records, handing out elaborately packaged CD's of cutting-edge Japanese rock bands, obscure English girl groups, French chansons sung by Japanese vocalists and soccer anthem compilations. Trattoria may be one of the most eclectic and interesting boutique labels affiliated with a major record company (Polystar), and not only does Mr. Oyamada help run it, he is also its best-selling act, Cornelius (named after the chimpanzee from ''Planet of the Apes''). He is on his first world tour and performs in Manhattan tomorrow night at Shine, at 380 Canal Street in Chinatown.

title: NEW NIGERIA CHIEF PLEDGES A RETURN TO CIVILIAN RULE
description: Nigeria's new military leader said today that he would turn over power to an elected civilian government by Oct. 1.

title: Nigeria's Opportunity
description: The death this week of Sani Abacha, the corrupt and abusive Nigerian military dictator, is an opportunity for an African giant to begin to lift itself from poverty, fear and decay. General Abacha so discredited military rule that in recent months even many officers began to join ordinary Nigerians in clamoring for a civilian government. Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar, who has taken over the Government, was one of those officers. He should put those ideas into practice.

title: Critic's Notebook; A New Spago Points the Way
description: WHEN Wolfgang Puck opened Spago in West Hollywood in early 1982, he changed American restaurants. He did not do it by serving California cuisine or putting caviar on pizza; in fact, he didn't do it with the food at all.

title: Balkans Revisited
description: The last war in the Balkans lasted four years before President Clinton and NATO intervened. But now another part of the Balkans is aflame, and once again world powers are floundering in an effort to pressure Yugoslavia and contain the conflict.

title: A Big Bank Merger, Again
description: The wave of giant bank mergers, which continued this week with the Norwest Corporation's planned $34 billion takeover of Wells Fargo, has mixed implications for the nation's financial system and the civic well-being of many communities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LELCHUCK, LOUIS, DR.
description: LELCHUCK-Louis, Dr. Husband of Tia. Father of Claire Hawkins and Ellen Robinson. Brother of Sarah (Ned) Harris. Services in Cleveland, Ohio.

title: ULTRAMAR TO CUT 466 JOBS AND SELL OR SHUT 14% OF STORES
description: The Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corporation said yesterday that it planned to eliminate 466 jobs and sell or close 14 percent of its stores in a move to cut costs and increase profitability. The revamping will reduce costs and raise earnings before interest and taxes by $100 million in 1999 and $124 million in 2000, the company said. The San Antonio-based Ultramar, which owns about 2,200 gasoline or convenience merchandise stores in the United States, said it already had sold 29 stores in Tennessee, Arkansas and Mississippi. Ultramar employs about 23,000 people. Shares of Ultramar rose 18.75 cents, to $31.75.

title: $25 and Under; Crepes: A Taste of France, Now in New York Again
description: WHEN I think of crepes, I remember the bonnets and peasant aprons the waitresses used to wear at a French restaurant on Long Island I went to as a child. The menu was predictable: crocks of thick onion soup topped with melted cheese and a slice of bread; then savory crepes, stuffed with meat and cheese, which I endured to get to the dessert crepes, served with ice cream or chocolate mousse on top. Even the name of the restaurant, La Crepe, testified to the enticing allure of these French pancakes.

title: Smokers and Shooters First
description: The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, has been carving out some interesting political territory for the Republicans. In recent days he has denounced legislation aimed at curbing teen-age smoking and suggested that the best response to school shootings was more guns. When both parties are supposed to be pursuing the women's vote, it is unusual to see a politician promote a survival-of-the-fittest theory of child-rearing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEIRNE, MICHAEL E.
description: BEIRNE-Michael E. On June 9, 1998. It is with deep sadness and heavy heart that the family announce Mike's death at his home in Rockville Centre, LI. Michael was a 30 year veteran on Wall Street, where he enjoyed a wonderful and respected reputation as a successful corporate bond broker. He retired in June of 1991 as President and Chief Executive Officer of Fundamental Corporate Bond Brokers, Inc. Mike lost the battle, but never his will or spirit to brain cancer. He is survived by his beloved and devoted wife Edna; his most cherished children, Leslie, Michael and Dianna, and his adored grandson Ethan. He was a loving son of Margaret and Edward M.. Loving brother, brotherin-law and uncle. A true friend to many. Farewell my love. Friends may call at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 20 Lincoln Avenue, Rockville Centre on Wednesday, 7-9 PM and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday, 10 AM at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Mercy Hospice, or the Organ Fund of Church of the Ascension, Rockville Centre.

title: Journal; Bob Hope Lives
description: Contrary to published reports, the Internet didn't kill Bob Hope. The real culprit was Congress, whose members took to eulogizing the still-living comic from the floor last Friday on the basis of an advance obituary accidentally posted on an Associated Press web site. Had anyone in the House actually looked at the computer printout that cued the funeral oratory, he would have seen a patently dummy news story shot through with long strings of xxxxxxxxx as space holders. But why let the facts ruin a touching impromptu memorial service being beamed by C-Span to the voters back home?

title: Thyssen Krupp Weighs Expansion in Belgium
description: Thyssen Krupp Stahl A.G., Europe's largest flat-steel maker, said yesterday that it was considering taking a stake in the Belgian steel company Cockerill Sambre S.A. The French company Usinor S.A., Europe's No. 2 steelmaker, said it was also studying making a bid.

title: INSIDE
description: A Revealing Russian Scandal

title: U.S. and Industry Discuss Data Encryption
description: Leading computing executives, including Microsoft's chief executive, William H. Gates, huddled for two hours today with Attorney General Janet Reno and the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to discuss disagreements between the industry and the Government over data scrambling.

title: Business Travel; Even with many big cities like Chicago adding to capacity, hotel rooms can still be hard to get.
description: HOTEL room rates are expected to rise slightly this year, even though occupancy rates will decline slightly, but travelers should not be lulled into thinking they need not book well in advance. With the economy still chugging along, rooms will continue to be hard to come by in New York, Boston, San Francisco, Chicago and other business cities.

title: It's a New York Pitch: Foreign Dignitaries
description: The United Nations is in New York, so why shouldn't the city's baseball teams look like a United Nations of players? The pitching staffs, in particular, are taking on that look.

description: ANNIS-Abner. We extend our sympathy to Rick Annis on the death of his father Abner. A loving father and grandfather, he will be remembered for his warmth and wit and unswerving loyalty to the Rangers. Sincere condolences from the Friends and Colleagues of Rick Annis.

description: Following is an excerpt from a 250-word declaration on family life adopted today by the Southern Baptist Convention:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, SIDNEY
description: MEYER-Sidney. June 8. Age 92. Husband of Laurann Herbert, the late Katherine Scully, and the late Evelyn Breslaw. Father of Lynn & Stephen. Father-in-law of Arnold Perlmutter. Brother of Constance Sadek, Theodore Meyer; and the late Helen Sloan, Rita Kilstein and Roy Meyer. Grandfather of Evan Slavitt, Sarah Bryce, Joshua Slavitt, & Justine Meyer. Stepgrandfather of Bernard Perlmutter and Joseph Perlmutter. Great-grandfather of Isaac, Hannah, Tamar, Elena, Nina, Sam & Shoshana. Step great-grandfather of Leah, Daniel and David. title: METAMOR IN $250 MILLION DEAL WITH CORPORATE SERVICES
description: Metamor Worldwide Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Corestaff Services unit to the Corporate Services Group P.L.C. for $250 million. The London-based Corporate Services operates more than 370 branch offices in Britain and France and provides contract staffing services. It had revenue of $720 million in 1997. The Houston-based Corestaff operates more than 100 branch offices that provide office support, light industrial and specialized services. Metamor, also based in Houston, offers information technology and staffing services. Shares of Metamor rose $1.3125, to $33.

title: Ex-Treasurer of Drew U. Admits to Embezzling
description: A former treasurer of Drew University pleaded guilty yesterday to embezzling $1.4 million from 1989 to 1997 to finance a life of luxury, prosecutors said.

title: In Jakarta, Reports Of Numerous Rapes Of Chinese in Riots
description: In addition to the looting and arson that was largely aimed at Chinese neighborhoods in three days of rioting in Jakarta last month, human rights and women's aid groups have begun to document what they say appears to have been an organized campaign of assaults, gang rapes and killings of ethnic Chinese women.

title: For a Month, Soccer Is Life; In Queens, World Cup Opens Frenzy of Futbol and Pride
description: At least once a year, Juan Ospina finds himself driving 24 hours nonstop just to watch a soccer match. He sometimes takes off from work to head to one of the Queens bars that broadcast games from South America. And in case there was any doubt of his devotion, he has been known to shave the name of his native country, Colombia, onto the back of his head and paint the colors of the Colombian flag across his face.

title: London Journal; Old-Style Power Struggle Brings Abbey Up to Date
description: Time moves slowly at Westminster Abbey, a church of high Anglican solemnity whose first inhabitant, King Edward the Confessor, has been resting in his tomb there for 900 years.

He will be sadly missed by many. He was active in charities in Palm Beach and New York. A member of Temple Emanu-El in Palm Beach. Funeral service in Florida on Wednesday and 1:30 PM Thursday, June 11, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Contributions to cancer research in his memory may be sent to ICA/USA, 230 Royal Palm Way, Palm Beach, FL 33480.

title: Voucher Program for Inner-City Children

The businessmen said they were trying to prod failing public schools into improving by subjecting them to market forces.

title: STAR TELECOMMUNICATIONS TO BUY PT-1 FOR $591 MILLION
description: Star Telecommunications Inc., a long-distance telephone company, agreed yesterday to buy PT-1 Communications Inc., a New York-based prepaid calling card company, for about $591 million in stock to increase its sales to commercial and residential customers. Star Telecommunications, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., will issue 21 million shares to the closely held PT-1's shareholders. Before trading was halted yesterday, Star's shares traded at $28.125. The acquisition will more than double Star's revenue and increase its sales to commercial and residential customers. Now, 90 percent of its traffic is to other telecommunications companies that resell its services.

title: A Newcomer Is the Winner In Newark's Runoff Election
description: A 29-year-old Rhodes scholar and newcomer to Newark upset the four-term Councilman in the city's Central Ward today in a runoff election that most said touched on some deep discontent with established politicians and mobilized long-discouraged voters.

title: Magazines, Magazines
description: For months people inside and outside CBS News have been poking and prying and practically listening at keyholes for gossip about whether a second weekly edition of ''60 Minutes'' will be authorized. The move is opposed by the producer and correspondents of the Sunday night program but supported by Leslie Moonves and Mel Karmazin, the top executives at the network, who hope the clout of the ''60 Minutes'' name will bring in millions of viewers another night of the week.

title: Sports of The Times; For Mets, a New Face With the Old Chant
description: WHEN the ''Let's Go, Mets'' chant was heard in recent years, it too often was a waste of loyal lungs. Most of those Mets teams usually didn't go anywhere except down to the dungeons of the National League East.

title: Jittery Brazilians Confident They Can Cast Fans' Worries Aside
description: The World Cup is starting Wednesday and Brazil is like a pot ready to boil over, a Brazilian journalist told Coach Mario Zagallo today. Could the coach offer some reassuring words to the people back home, something that would turn the heat down to a simmer?

Through three games, NBC's 17.0 rating is the highest in history, 5 percent above the 16.2 for the first three games of the 1993 finals. In Chicago, the game earned a 44.8 rating and a 66 share, while the Salt Lake City market produced a 41.1 rating and a 66 share.

title: Newark Police Accused of Stealing Guns
description: In seeking safer streets, police departments across the country have increasingly asked citizens to turn in guns in exchange for cash or gift certificates, no questions asked. But in Newark, officials said today, the city's gun buy-back program earlier this year took an unfortunate twist: Fancy weapons were pocketed by some officers in the Police Department's East District.

description: The guest speaker at George Washington High School in Washington Heights yesterday was not quite a local boy made good. Leonel Fernandez Reyna regretted to report that he had grown up a few neighborhoods south and attended rival Louis D. Brandeis High School.

title: Of Life, and Death, Behind Bars
description: No stereotypes about prison life intrude on the candor and intimacy of ''The Farm: Angola, U.S.A.,'' a discreetly searing documentary that shared top honors at this year's Sundance Film Festival and opens at the Film Forum today. With extraordinary tact and acuity, the filmmakers Jonathan Stack, Liz Garbus and Wilbert Rideau, who is an inmate, explore the world inside a vast maximum security prison and consider the coping mechanisms that make up everyday life there. The place is the Louisiana State Penitentiary at Angola, a former slave plantation named for its African population. Prisoners, 85 percent of whom will die at Angola, do field work for as little as 4 cents an hour.

title: Budget Deadlock May Cause Some Property Tax Increases
description: The political deadlock over the shape of the city's next budget could cause owners of single-, two- and three-family houses to pay about $50 more in taxes in the next fiscal year. And the Council and the Mayor's Office blamed each other yesterday for the increase.

title: National Origins: Glennville, Georgia; A Georgia Onion as Sweet as a Peach
description: In springtime, you know you're in Vidalia country without reading the signs. As soon as you leave the piney woods of Fort Stewart, the Army base where American troops trained for the Persian Gulf war, you come upon an amazing sight: row after row of burlap bags stretching across the sandy fields as far as the eye can see, full of onions drying in the Georgia sun.

title: Tottenville Wins in P.S.A.L.
description: Tottenville of Staten Island won its fourth Public Schools Athletic League Class A baseball title in the 1990's and its sixth over all yesterday with a 10-1 victory over Lehman of the Bronx before a crowd of about 3,000 at Yankee Stadium.

title: Restaurants; A Seafood Bargain and No Need to Shout

She scooped an oyster off her plate and added, ''All I ever seem to manage is a seat out here in the bar.'' ''I reserved three weeks ago,'' I replied, soon following the hostess into the cheerful dining room.

title: Correction

Some classroom teachers and principals see them as unproductive clock-watchers who play cards all day, perform a few tasks, then go home promptly when the last school bell rings. They average only an evaluation or two a week.

Mrs. Toms a resident of NYC and Montauk, Long Island was born in Matatiele, South Africa on May 2, 1946. Her work as a Director of an European-based international real estate firm brought her to the United States where she has lived continuously since 1969. In addition to her work, Mrs. Toms was a passionate gardener and talented decorator, possessing an exceptional sense of color which marked all her creative projects with distinction. In addition to her husband, Mrs. Toms is survived by her mother, Dorothy van Eeden, of Capetown, South Africa, a brother of Trevor Hodd of Springbok, South Africa and many devoted friends. The funeral service will be held Thursday, June 11 at 2 P.M., at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53 Street in New York City. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, gifts be directed in Mrs. Tom's name to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Institute, P.O. Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Personal Shopper; Witty Trompe L'Oeil
description: A SMILE. It's the only possible response to trompe l'oeil designs and photo images on shower curtains, bed sheets, even end tables. The designs are contemporary sisters to those by Piero Fornasetti, the Milanese decorative master of trompe l'oeil. Renewed interest in his work (which peaked in the 1950's) was apparent at the May 16 auction of 203 of his designs at Christie's in Los Angeles; the bureaus, dinner plates, magazine racks and hand-painted bathroom fixtures sold for record-breaking prices -- sometimes five times the estimates. Fornasetti transferred engravings that tricked the eye and tickled the imagination.
