description: Customs agents have seized more than 1,300 pounds of cocaine after smugglers tried to bring it into the United States secreted in specially made fiberglass barrels at the center of tightly wound, one-ton rolls of brown wrapping paper.

title: Plutonium Traces Found In Sediment at Lab
description: Officials at Brookhaven National Laboratory said yesterday that they had detected low levels of plutonium in Peconic River sediments on the laboratory's grounds and in the river bed a mile from the lab's eastern border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOFSKY, LEO
description: SOLOFSKY-Leo. Of Fort Lauderdale, FL., formerly of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, passed away on Wednesday, June 10. Beloved husband of Martha. Cherished father of Michele, Fran, Steven, Alan & Joel. Beloved grandfather of Michael, Alyssa, Amy, Melanie, Robyn, Jamie, Shannon, Nicole & Natalie. Dear brother of Morris and Mary. He will be sadly missed by his dearest friends of 68 years, Lil & Sid Kisin. Services Thursday, 12 noon at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Marshall Green Dies at 82; Longtime Diplomat in Asia
description: Marshall Green, who was the State Department's leading expert on East Asia and served as Ambassador to Indonesia during the violent uprising in the 1960's that brought President Suharto to power, died on Saturday. He was 82 and lived in Washington.

title: House and Senate Negotiators Agree on Education Tax Credits
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a final bill to provide tax breaks to parents who save for elementary and secondary school costs, including private school tuition, a proposal that President Clinton has threatened to veto.

title: Japanese Seem Ready to Let Banks Fail
description: Six months after it retreated from closing weak banks or allowing them to fail, the Japanese Government is once again inclined to administer such shock therapy as a cure for the nation's sick financial system.

title: Mayor Cuts Budget $196 Million, But Council Vows to Reject Move
description: Wielding a rarely used power of his office, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani vetoed more than $196 million from the city budget yesterday, asserting that the money -- from $727 for the Staten Island Historical Society to $10 million for legal aid -- represented the reckless spending of a City Council confused in a season of budget surplus and political ambition.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Queen Retains Star Appeal

title: Doughnut-Shop Holdups, And a Mr. Duncan Is Held
description: The homonym was not lost on the Police Department: The man arrested Tuesday night in the robbery of eight Dunkin' Donuts shops in Manhattan over the last two months was named Douglas Duncan.

title: Lufthansa President Named Chief of Marketing at Delta
description: Frederick W. Reid, the president of Lufthansa German Airlines, will join Delta Air Lines as marketing chief, the latest in a series of top personnel changes by Leo F. Mullin, Delta's new chairman and chief executive.

title: Currents; SHAPING SPACE -- The Play of Light and Shadow
description: For homeowners who want to create translucence at a window, consider Robert Irwin's installation, ''Prologue: Times 183 '' at the Dia Center for the Arts. Mr. Irwin stapled a fine white scrim to the edges of the walls, so that the boundaries between the walls, ceiling and floor were blurred. In the home, designers say that a similar effect can be achieved by wrapping scrim around a thin frame and attaching it to one wall with a piano hinge and to the opposite wall with a concealed latch. Dia is at 548 West 22d Street; the show runs through Sunday.

title: Paying a Price for Principles
description: The Christian political activists who helped sweep Ronald Reagan and George Bush to the White House in the 1980's are now threatening to do the same for the Democrats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, DANIEL L.
description: HOPKINS-Daniel L., 50. Of New York on Saturday, June 6, 1998. He was the son of Orville L. Hopkins and the late Helen Hopkins Fontal. Brother of Janice (Phil) Dick Joyce of Pittsburgh, PA. Uncle of Elizabeth L. and Perry J. Dick III of Shadyside, PA. For information, Paul L. Henney Memorial Chapel Inc, 5570 Library Road, Bethel Park, PA. 15102. 412-835-1312.

title: DVD-Video Is Late to Bloom
description: CHRISTIAN HENNINGS is enthusiastic about his DVD movie player and the disks that go with it, but it remains to be seen if the technology mainstream will move in the same direction.

title: St. John's and Jarvis Near an Agreement
description: After several days of intense and sometimes acrimonious negotiations, St. John's appeared on the verge of reaching agreement with Mike Jarvis, its No. 1 choice to be the new head basketball coach, despite several remaining sticking points.

title: Hernandez Keeps Hitters Guessing
description: The Yankees pay Mike Borzello to sit behind home plate at every game with a radar gun and write down the speed and type of every pitch thrown. In his own way, he's an expert on pitching, but Borzello met his match Tuesday night. There were times he had no idea what Orlando Hernandez was throwing.

title: 3 New Victims Raise Toll at Kansas Grain Elevator to 5
description: For all the poetry of Kansas wheat fields swaying in the breeze, the laborers who worked inside the big DeBruce Grain Inc. elevator knew that the work could be dreary, dirty and low-paying, jobs often done by Mexican immigrants.

title: Ex-Advertising Manager Missing Near State Park
description: A 41-year-old former advertising manager for Mother Earth News disappeared a week ago after parking his car near the Appalachian Trail in Fahnstock State Park in Putnam County, the New York State police said yesterday.

title: Agency Sues T.W.A. Over Sexual Harassment Charges
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued Trans World Airlines yesterday, saying the company failed to intervene after three female employees accused three high-level managers of engaging in unwanted touching, using crude language and demanding sexual favors.

title: Hot-Handed Westwood A Threat at Westchester
description: By anyone's standards, Lee Westwood is having a special year.

title: Scientists Decode the DNA Of Germ Responsible for TB
description: Scientists have broken the code of the tuberculosis bacterium, a germ that kills more people in the world than any other infectious agent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MENOWITZ, SOPHIE
description: MENOWITZ-Sophie. (1914-1979). Gone but not forgotten these many years. We think of you always. Love from your family who meant so much to you.

title: Public Eye; Going All Out to Offer A Good Night's Sleep
description: AT the Waldorf-Astoria and other Hilton hotels, special Sleep-Tight Rooms have been designed in consultation with the National Sleep Foundation. A survey of international business travelers by Hilton and the sleep foundation in 1997 found that outside noise and, more important, noise from neighbors were most often cited as keeping travelers up at night.

title: ABC stays with old yellow, but it's in an 'evolved' form.
description: NO need to wonder where the yellow went, to paraphrase the old Pepsodent toothpaste jingle. ABC is bringing back for a second season an irreverent, yellow-tinted campaign that satirically salutes those intermingled twinges of guilt and pleasure felt by most Americans as they watch television.

title: Vallone Introduces Bill to Put Stadium Issue Before Voters
description: Following through on a pledge that has contributed significantly to his current budget battle with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, introduced a bill yesterday that would put a referendum about the future of Yankee Stadium on the November ballot.

title: I.M.F. Presses The Russians To Speed Fiscal Reform
description: The International Monetary Fund has told the Russian Government that it needs to slash its budget deficit and overhaul its antiquated tax system if it wants to qualify for billions of dollars in additional loans, senior Russian officials said today.

title: Cutting Health Costs Isn't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMMERDAHL, JENS M.
description: ROMMERDAHL-Jens M. A Memorial Service will be held at the Zion Lutheran Church, Saddle River, N.J. at 2PM, Saturday, June 13, 1998. Jens Rommerdahl was the General Manager of New York Marine Terminals, Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. He is survived by his wife Carla and the families of his sons Kurt and Lance. He received honors from Queen Margrethe II of Denmark for service to the Danish community in New York. He received honors presented by Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands for service to the Dutch Navy. He was awarded the Ellis Island Medal of Honor awarded to non-native American citizens for outstanding citizenship. He graduated Cum Laude from New York University.

title: A Creative Corporate Attempt to Tame Air Fares
description: In one of the first attempts by major companies to counter the high air fares charged by the major airlines, the Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation are near an agreement to pay a monthly fee for five years to Pro Air, a start-up airline based in Detroit, in exchange for unlimited passage on the carrier for their employees.

title: Keyboard Is No Cure-All; Clinton's Platitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracking Child Abuse Abroad
description: On the 50th anniversary of the United Nations Convention of the Rights of the Child, the lot of many of the world's children is far from happy. That is the message of Kate Blewett and Brian Woods, who traveled 70,000 miles and visited 21 countries to track down abuses of the young in Russia and Ghana, Greece and Togo, Central America and the United Arab Emirates. ''Innocents Lost'' is a harsh sequel to their 1996 investigation, ''The Dying Rooms,'' which exposed the mistreatment of baby girls in Chinese orphanages.

title: Keyboard Is No Cure-All
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENMAN, HENRY (HANK)
description: EISENMAN-Henry (Hank). The Board of Governors, members and staff of Greater New York Hospital Association mourn the loss of Hank Eisenman, beloved father of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dana Eisenman Sherwin. Mr. Eisenman was a major contributor to New York's health care industry, having served as an executive at Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield for many years. A man of warmth and intellect, he will be missed by many. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire Eisenman and Sherwin families. Mark J. Mundy, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President Greater NY Hospital Association

title: FAMILY RESTAURANTS TO ACQUIRE IACOCCA'S KOO KOO ROO
description: Koo Koo Roo Inc., a chicken restaurant chain headed by Lee A. Iacocca and based in Los Angeles, agreed yesterday to be bought by Family Restaurants Inc., the owner of Chi-Chi's and El Torito Mexican restaurants, in a stock swap valued at about $143 million based on Tuesday's closing stock price. Koo Koo Roo said its shareholders would swap each of their shares for one in the new combined company. Family Restaurants is controlled by the financiers Leon Black and Leonard Green. Mr. Iacocca took charge of Koo Koo Roo in April with the aim of turning it around after 18 straight quarters of losses. Shares of Koo Koo Roo fell 43.75 cents yesterday, to $2.4375, in Nasdaq trading. The company has just under 50 million shares outstanding.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: HOW LONG WILL THEY GO? -- Just when it seemed safe to buy a new computer, along comes another prediction of an imminent plunge in PC prices. Last week, Ziff-Davis Market Intelligence predicted a new shift downward. By the middle of next month, the report said, the prices of computers selling for $1,000 will drop to $700 or $800. And the price of a decent 17-inch color monitor will fall to about $350.

title: Bridge; One Stayman Steps Down, And Another Is a Winner
description: A long and successful run -- perhaps the longest in the history of bridge administration -- came to an end last week. Josephine Stayman, invariably known as Tubby, resigned after 34 years in charge of the annual U.J.A.-Federation Charity Game, the world's most successful such effort. Her final production a week ago generated more than $75,000, yet another record in the series. Her efficient deputy, Marci Miron, will be in charge in the future.

title: Currents; LIKE LOUVERS IN MINIATURE -- In the Eye of the Beholder: The Angle Is All
description: Now you don't see it; now you do. At Pleats Please: Issey Miyake, a new clothing store that opened last month on Wooster Street, the exterior windows, above, are blurry from a distance and become clear only close up. This alluring tease is made possible by a new film developed by the Sumitomo Chemical Company in Tokyo. The polymer resin film, which is applied to glass, has a microscopic structure that looks like miniature louvers.

title: Time to Muscle State Polluters
description: In late 1996, a fed-up Carol Browner fined Smithfield Foods $125 million for dumping hog wastes into a Virginia river. It was the biggest penalty ever levied by an administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and Smithfield was not the only target. It was also a rebuke to Virginia, which had failed to control Smithfield's behavior, and a warning to all other states that were not enforcing Federal environmental laws.

title: Cuts Are Possible in an On-Line Plan for Schools and Libraries
description: Facing intense bipartisan criticism on Capitol Hill, William E. Kennard, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, offered today to scale back a plan to connect schools and libraries to the Internet and said his agency would make a final decision by Friday.

title: Air France Pilots Settle Strike, Accepting 7-Year Pay Freeze
description: Air France began limping back toward normal operations today after pilots accepted a seven-year pay freeze, ending a strike that had grounded most flights since the beginning of the month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIZMAN, MARGARET S.
description: REIZMAN-Margaret S. On June 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Clarice Rosenstock. Cherished grandmother of Joan, Kathie and Richard. Loving great-grandmother of seven. Private services were held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, CATHERINE
description: PERRY-Catherine. Died June 8 at age 75. Long time resident of East 21st Street. Loved cats. Memorial service today at 6:30 PM Epiphany Church, 375 2nd Ave at 22nd St.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Mutual Admiration

title: FIRST SIERRA IN $91.2 MILLION DEAL FOR OLIVER-ALLEN
description: First Sierra Financial Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the Oliver-Allen Corporation, a computer-leasing company based in Larkspur, Calif., for $91.2 million in stock. First Sierra, which is based in Houston, is a financial and technology services company. Oliver-Allen, with assets of $179 million as of Dec. 31, specializes in leasing information-technology equipment. Under the agreement, First Sierra will issue the equivalent of 3.8 million shares in stock and options. Shares of First Sierra were up 62.5 cents at $24.625 in Nasdaq trading.

title: A New Stadium? Let's Vote on It
description: To the Editor:

title: The Silicon Valley Gang; An Influential Industry With Lots of Money Is Getting Its Way on Capitol Hill
description: The topic may have been an arcane change to the securities laws, but there was the sound of old-fashioned melodrama today in a hearing room on Capitol Hill.

title: Games Add Fun to Summer Math Practice
description: AS summer approaches and the school year ends, my students are anticipating their time away from school. While they may miss their friends, it would be rare for any child to spend the summer months dreaming about math class.

title: My Own Personal Antitrust Action
description: AS a child, I liked to rip off mattress tags, the kind that threatened prosecution to anyone who removed them. So I was excited to learn a few days ago about a simple shareware program that allows a computer user to deface the Windows operating system in much the same way.

title: Damage Awards Bill Has New Backer
description: A far-reaching measure that would set nationwide limits on damages awarded in court for faulty products received a significant boost today as a leading Senate opponent said he would now support a version of the law proposed by the Clinton Administration.

title: Federal Nuclear Agency Says Reactor Is Improved
description: Two months after the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission fined Public Service Electric & Gas Company $55,000 for violations at its Hope Creek nuclear reactor, the commission said yesterday that operations at the reactor have improved significantly.

title: NIMBUS IN TALKS TO BE BOUGHT FOR $246 MILLION
description: Nimbus CD International Inc., a maker of compact disks, said yesterday that it was in talks with an undisclosed suitor that might acquire the company for $11.50 a share, or about $246 million. Nimbus shares fell 50 cents, to $10.875, in Nasdaq trading. The shares had risen to $12 before trading was halted for the news. In response to inquiries prompted by an increase in trading of its shares, the company issued a statement saying that it was ''in discussions for the sale of the company.'' Nimbus, which is based in Charlottesville, Va., makes optical disks such as CD's and DVD's that are used to store information digitally. Its shares, first sold to the public in October 1995 at $7 each, reached a high of $18.25 in May 1996.

title: Show House Report; Inspired Improvisation in a Harlem Debut
description: AS every voyeur clutching a ticket and a dream knows, designer show houses are typically celebrations of the perfection that money can buy. More often than not in these open-to-the-public alliances of charity fund-raising and design-industry public relations, sumptuous taffetas shadow windows, kitchen cabinets flaunt labor-intensive hand-painted finishes, and there is always a room where the cost of one antique would finance an Ivy League education.

title: Fearing a Run on $4 Day Passes, M.T.A. May Sell Them Only at Tourist Spots
description: Fearing that the planned one-day, unlimited bus and subway Metrocard is priced so low that it could be a big money-loser, city transit officials want to sell the $4 pass only at hotels and other tourist spots, according to an official who has worked on developing the passes.

title: Essex County Plans Vote On Funds for Open Space
description: As Gov. Christine Todd Whitman asked Essex County officials yesterday to support a tax increase to preserve undeveloped land, the county announced that it would hold a referendum in November on whether to set aside a portion of property taxes for its own open-space fund.

title: Math Drills That Imitate Video Games
description: MATH MUNCHERS DELUXE

title: Advertisers Shift Compensation Method
description: A majority of American advertisers have shifted from compensating their agencies based on the traditional billings method, according to a study conducted by the Association of National Advertisers.

title: 6 Drivers Charged in Theft Ring at United Parcel Service
description: Six drivers for the United Parcel Service were charged yesterday with participation in a theft ring that Federal prosecutors said stole more than $175,000 in jewelry, computers and other goods from delivery trucks and the service's midtown distribution center.

title: One Prince's Cause Is Another Man's Castle
description: IT was not the kind of headline that Charles, the Prince of Wales, was used to in the British press. ''The Prince Has Got It Right,'' trumpeted The Independent.

title: Cutting Health Costs Isn't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: TECH DATA SELLS COMPUTER WHOLESALER FOR $100 MILLION
description: The computer-distribution giant Ingram Micro Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Tech Data Corporation's majority interest in Macrotron A.G., a German computer wholesaler, for $100 million in cash. Ingram, based in Santa Ana, Calif., is the world's biggest distributor of personal computers and accessory products, with full-year sales of $16.6 billion. Tech Data, in Clearwater, Fla., is the world's No. 2 computer distributor, with annual sales of $7.1 billion. It acquired Macrotron last year. Macrotron has annual sales of $1.2 billion. Tech Data shares fell 75 cents, to $37, in Nasdaq trading, and Ingram slipped 25 cents, to $39.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Greenspan Finds Economy Is Extraordinarily Sound

title: Leaping Centuries in Single Step, a Minimalist Goes Digital
description: TRAINED the old-fashioned way in her native Copenhagen to photograph without light meters and to make her own emulsions in the darkroom, Marianne Engberg is cheerfully nonchalant about the lengths she goes to in pursuit of her art. She takes black-and-white photographs with pinhole cameras, equipment so primitive that she has made the ones she uses out of Quaker Oats boxes and black masking tape. The speed of the pinhole is so slow that she thinks nothing of waiting out exposure times ranging from 7 to 90 minutes.

title: WISCONSIN COURT UPHOLDS VOUCHERS IN CHURCH SCHOOLS
description: In the most significant legal decision yet on the growing use of school vouchers, the Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the City of Milwaukee could spend taxpayer money to send pupils to parochial or other religious schools.

title: Currents; GILT BY ASSOCIATION -- Frames by Stanford White
description: The architect Stanford White designed picture frames, too. ''He felt he was the most qualified to finish the details of his rooms,'' said Robyn Pocker, the president of J. Pocker & Son, a Manhattan frame gallery, which has just introduced six frames based on White's designs from the 1890's to 1906, complete with pierced grillwork and acanthus leaves.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL FALLS 2.9 PERCENT. Oil dropped after Iran joined other producers in pledging only modest cutbacks in output, reinforcing a view that supplies will remain plentiful. July contracts fell 40 cents a barrel, to $13.45.

title: A New Stadium? Let's Vote on It
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Helmsley Sells Stake In Property Company
description: Leona Helmsley said yesterday that she sold her stake in Investment Properties Associates, a commercial real estate partnership, to a group led by Scoggin Capital Management for more than $100 million.

title: Toronto Journal; It's Everything Castro Promised, on Lake Ontario
description: Each stroll in the neighborhood opens new worlds for Guillermo Sambra. He gawks at the shoes and radios in Toronto's store windows and shakes his head in disbelief at the gleaming new cars that actually stop to let him cross the street.

title: Currents; 45-ACRE TERMINAL -- Your Flight Is at Gate 2,001
description: Whatever happened to ''Small Is Beautiful''? From the Big Bang Decade that has brought the world supersize fries and the remake of ''Godzilla'' now comes the Mother of All Airports.

title: Making the Move From Wall to Web
description: THE class nerd memorized it. The chemistry teacher knelt before it. And you -- you kind of liked the colors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPELL, DANIEL T.
description: APPELL-Daniel T. Of Lexington, MA, formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Died Sunday, June 7, at the age of 98, in Lexington, MA. Beloved father of Jane Appell of Lincoln, MA. Grandfather of two. Loving uncle, granduncle & great-granduncle, especially loved by grandniece and great-grandniece. Memorial service to be held Sunday, June 21, 2 PM, at Brookhaven, 1010 Waltham Street, Lexington, MA. Friends & family are invited to the home of Jane Appell and Steven Shapse, from 3:30 to 9 PM, following the service. Donations to be made to Hospice Care, Inc., 41 Montvale Avenue, Stoneham, MA 02180, or the American Diabetes Association, 2 Mount Royal Avenue, Marlborough, MA 01752.

title: Focusing on Computer User's Eyestrain
description: For many people, working in front of a computer monitor means aching eyes, blurred vision and even migraines. Eye and vision problems are fast overtaking sore wrists and hands as one of the most frequently reported health-related complaints among the ever-growing numbers of people who spend time peering at a computer screen.

title: AIDS Bill Has Flaws
description: To the Editor:

title: A Feminist Look at Sophocles
description: The theater company Voice and Vision, now in its eighth year, is committed to developing works by and about women and girls. The strength of this commitment is clear from the latest theater work the company has commissioned, ''Jocasta,'' which uses opera, dance and the spoken word to tell the story of Oedipus from the imagined perspective of Jocasta.

title: House Approves Legislation To Curb Laws on Bankruptcy
description: The House today passed far-reaching legislation to tighten the bankruptcy laws for the first time in a generation in an effort to discourage the growing practice of consumers' declaring personal bankruptcy to erase their debts.

title: Metro Business; Change at Rainbow Room
description: The family that owns Harry Cipriani, the restaurant in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel on Fifth Avenue, will take over the Rainbow Room on Jan. 1, the company that manages Rockefeller Center said yesterday.

title: A Juror Explains Her Tortuous Path to Voting for a Death Sentence
description: There had been three days of arguing and occasional shouting, three days in which the 12 jurors in the Brooklyn murder trial of Darrel K. Harris had agonized over the death penalty. By Friday, 10 jurors wanted a death sentence. Eleanore L. Walker, a registered nurse, was one of two who did not.

title: Long-Term Interest Rates Fall to 5.7%
description: Long-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday, as the Asian financial crisis and continuing problems in Russia apparently sent more foreigners to the haven of the American bond market.

title: Capitals Stand Behind Hunter's Rugged Ways
description: Dale Hunter has only been playing in the National Hockey League for 18 years, so he did not see what all the fuss was about. But his Washington Capitals teammates read a larger meaning into his mugging of Steve Yzerman, the Detroit Red Wings' captain, during Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Piazza Is Proving That He's More Than a Hitter
description: It would not seem that a player of Mike Piazza's stature would need to be reinvented. Yet since joining the Mets on May 22, Piazza is happily using the change of scenery to also change the perception of who and what he is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNAFEL, SUSAN
description: KNAFEL-Susan. In sorrow and appreciation for a dear friend of our family. We will miss her warmth and humor. We send our deepest condolences to Sidney, Doug and Andy. Meile, Peter, Stuart and Michael Rockefeller.

title: Aiming for Public's Heart and Dollars
description: A team-by-team look at the 10-team league that opens with four games tonight. Records are for last season.

title: A Long Way From Simplicity
description: To the Editor:

title: Qualms on Politics Are Thinning Field For Top CUNY Job
description: Five months after a search committee began looking for a new chancellor of the City University of New York, strong candidates have declined even to consider the job because of the divisive political battles surrounding the institution -- leaving a pool of early contenders that some of its trustees call unimpressive.

title: Lott Unable to Step Aside
description: Senator Trent Lott is not voting on tobacco issues because of family ties to a lawyer in the settlement, but he says he can't recuse himself from being the majority leader. Page A26.

title: Town Expresses Sadness And Horror Over Slaying
description: The courthouse square in this East Texas town seemed eerily quiet on this sweltering day. Few people milled about, and those who did seemed hesitant to talk to outsiders about the horrible crime that had brought a swarm of television trucks to the town and would bring the Rev. Jesse Jackson this afternoon.

title: Offensive By Serbia Puts Allies In War Room
description: Serbia has used military warplanes in addition to army troops and special police units in its attacks on ethnic Albanian villages in Kosovo province over the last two weeks, a senior United States official involved in monitoring the situation there said today.

title: Excerpts From the Congress Testimony by Greenspan
description: Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress:

title: Families Joined or Divided by Silence; Film Shed Light on Emotional Issues of the Deaf
description: A fierce thunderstorm rips through the night and wakens the little girl at the beginning of ''Beyond Silence,'' a new movie by the German director Caroline Link about the hearing child of two deaf parents. Night noises are the child's noises, heard only by the children of the deaf while their parents sleep on. The little girl runs to wake her mother and father, seeking comfort. ''Lightning is loud,'' the father says, in sign language. ''Lightning is silent, like the moon,'' the little girl responds.

title: 'Anne Frank' Is to Close
description: ''The Diary of Anne Frank,'' an adaptation by Wendy Kesselman of the 1955 drama by Frances Goodrich and Albert Hackett, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street, Manhattan. The play, directed by James Lapine and starring Linda Lavin, Nathalie Paulding and George Hearn, will have run for 221 regular performances and had 16 previews.

title: Sports of The Times; World's Team Kicks Off World Cup
description: THE No. 13 Metro train was bobbing up and down from the sheer brute rhythm of hundreds of Scots jumping in place, singing utterly salacious lyrics to familiar tunes. You wouldn't believe what they did to Ronaldo to the tune of ''Walking in a Winter Wonderland.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFITH, RICHARD RANDOLPH
description: GRIFFITH-Richard Randolph. On June 10, 1998. Beloved and loving husband of Lucille. Amazing father of Val, Randy, Kerri, Kim, Meg, Chris, Elizabeth, Carl, and Marion. Grandfather of Polly and Josh. Professor Emeritus C.W. Post Campus/LIU. Malory Expert and piano man, who will be missed by friends, family, colleagues and thousands of students. Memorial service on Thursday, June 18th at 2 P.M. at The Chapel at C.W. Post Campus, Brookville.

title: A Long Way From Simplicity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHAN, MARY ARNOLD SYKES
description: CAHAN-Mary Arnold Sykes. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, Inc., in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Mary Arnold Sykes Cahan, mother of our dear friend and colleague Anthony Cahan, MD, Physician-In-Charge of the Robert and Helen Appel Comprehensive Breast Service at Beth Israel Medical Center-North Division. To Tony, the entire Cahan family and all of his mother's loved ones, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Continuum Health Partners, Inc. and Beth Israel Medical Center. Matthew E. Fink, MD, President and CEO, Beth Israel Medical Center Ruth E. Hennessey, Vice Pres. Operations, North Division

title: Council Backs Over-Age Police Recruits by Overriding Veto
description: The City Council voted overwhelmingly yesterday to override Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's veto of a bill that would allow 40 candidates to enter the Police Academy although they exceed the age limit of 34 for recruits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELBRAUN, PHYLLIS
description: HELBRAUN-Phyllis, 76. Of brain cancer, on June 9. Indefatigable advocate for the needs of children and families. Founder and director for twenty years of the Rockland Council for Young Children. Beloved wife of Morton, adored mother of Madeline, Jennifer, Elizabeth and David. Devoted sister of Laurance, Harriet, Herbert and Joan. Funeral services Friday, June 12, 12:15 PM at Temple Beth El, Viola Road, Spring Valley. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Child Care Resources of Rockland, 185 North Main Street, Spring Valley, New York 10977.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Mathematics to Madness, and Back
description: A BEAUTIFUL MINDBy Sylvia NasarSimon & Schuster. 459 pages. $25.

title: 'Fiber' That's the Fabric of Life
description: Nearly two decades ago, Blondell Cummings created an epochal solo, called ''Chicken Soup,'' that explored black family life through the metaphors of the kitchen, the kitchen table and food. Now Philadanco, also known as the Philadelphia Dance Company, has brought us Ms. Cummings's new ''100 Percent Cotton Natural Fiber,'' presented on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Fat Substitute May Cause Disease, a Top Researcher Says
description: One of the leading researchers in the field of nutrition and degenerative diseases said today that long-term use of a new fat substitute, already available nationwide in potato chips, might cause thousands of additional cases of cancer and heart disease.

title: Going Out, Without Leaving Home
description: IT'S Saturday night in the big city. After weeks of busy schedules, a loving couple has set these hours aside for some overdue quality time, in the form of a cozy evening at home.

title: International Effort Is Pledged to Curb Demand for Illegal Drugs
description: The General Assembly concluded a special session on the world drug problem today with the 150 participating nations promising to work to reduce their appetites for illegal drugs within the next five years.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of Linda McCartney on April 20 misstated her college background. She attended only the University of Arizona, not Sarah Lawrence College as well. The obituary also misstated the given name of her first husband in some copies. He was Melvin See, not Bob. The errors were pointed out in E-mail received from a reader yesterday.

title: Economic Slump in Asia Spurs Sharp Drop in Dow
description: Stocks fell yesterday on concern that Asia's economic slump is causing companies that do business there to report disappointing earnings.

title: I.M.F. Gives Russians Its Conditions for Aid
description: The International Monetary Fund has told the Russian Government that it needs to slash its budget deficit and overhaul its tax system if it wants to qualify for billions of dollars in extra loans, senior Russian officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAVIO, LIONELLO
description: GAVIO-Lionello. Passed away on May 13, 1998 in Langhorne, PA. of complications following bypass surgery. Italian Travel Commissioner. R. 1986. Memorial mass at Our Lady of Pompeii, 25 Carmine St, June 13, 11 am

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Fed Chief Calls the Economy One of the Best He Has Seen
description: With a mixture of pride and puzzlement, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, declared the economy to be in extraordinarily good shape today and signaled to investors that he saw no immediate need to strike against inflation by raising interest rates.

title: Honoring a Legacy of Quiet Heroism
description: There was familiar pageantry today, a sea of dark suits and white gloves as thousands of somber firefighters paid homage to a fallen colleague. Then, after a procession of drummers in green kilts, a lone bagpiper marked the passing of Lieut. James W. Blackmore, a New York City firefighter who died on Friday trying to rescue a missing woman who, unknown to him, had already escaped a burning house.

title: I.B.M. to Expand Custom Chip Business
description: Taking aim at the booming wireless communications market, the International Business Machines Corporation said today that it would spend more than $100 million to expand its custom chip business.

title: Christian Group Feels Net Filter's Wrath
description: CONCERNED that children have easy access to pornography and other inappropriate material on the Internet, the American Family Association, a conservative, Christian group, has been a vocal supporter of filtering products, software meant to cordon off the nastier corners of cyberspace from users, especially young children.

title: The Game of Budget Gotcha
description: City Hall these days has the feel of a student government convention, with grown politicians scrambling to reread the New York City Charter in search of new and unimagined ways to check or ultimately checkmate the opposition. What has provoked this extreme case of governmental gamesmanship is this year's budget process. While it is generally a sleepy debate between the Mayor and the City Council, this year the two sides have been walloping each other with parliamentary brickbats. This sudden vigor would be terrific sport, except that it involves $34 billion of the public's money.

title: Agassi and Courier On U.S. Team
description: Deciding that loyalty may be the best policy when it comes to selecting a Davis Cup team, Tom Gullikson, the United States captain, announced yesterday that his players for the quarterfinal against Belgium July 17-19 would be a mirror image of the veteran squad that squeaked past Russia, 3-2, in the opening round at Atlanta.

title: Malone Harassed, Stockton Human
description: The famed tandem entered the interview room tonight the way they always do, walking side by side, as if hooked together. This is how John Stockton and Karl Malone function.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MARTIN
description: STONE-Martin. The remarkable Martin Stone died on Sunday, June 7, 1998. He led the most distinguished, diverse and dynamic life. His interests were broad and deep, and he brought his keen wit, intelligence and informed wisdom to all he considered and undertook. The gamut of his key involvements ranged from serving as attorney for the Lend-Lease Administration and helping to launch the G.I. Bill of Rights during the Roosevelt Administration to his Peabody Awards for ''The Author Meets the Critics,'' and ''Howdy Doody.'' He was a charter member of The New 42nd Board of Trustees and was invaluable in helping to guide the direction and pro-active decisions of the Board. We will miss him, his sage advice, his eloquence and his grace. All of our heartfelt condolences to Angela and to Martin's family. The Board and Staff of The New 42nd St. Marian S. Heiskell, Chairman Cora Cahan, President

title: Suit Against MCI In Internet Unit Sale
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit seeking to require MCI Communications to comply with a $625 million agreement to sell its wholesale Internet business to Cable and Wireless.

title: Currents; 30'S LUXURY -- When Bakelite Was a Miracle
description: Plastic is not always banal. In the 1930's, it was a luxury material, used in the interior of Radio City Music Hall and in a Lucite bedroom suite for Helena Rubinstein.

title: In the Headlights: P.D.A.'s and Virtual Pets
description: THE Georgia World Congress Center in Atlanta contains 35 football fields' worth of exhibition space. During the Electronic Entertainment Expo in May, it contained the equivalent of 35 football fields filled with video games -- PC games, console games and handheld games -- peripherals and accessories of all descriptions, as well as thousands of developers, software publishers, retailers, investors and journalists.

title: Cutting Health Costs Isn't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS WATCH; In a Boston Museum, Fish Don't Need Any Water to Swim
description: The six-year-old Computer Museum in Boston will open a giant virtual aquarium on Friday that will let visitors create and program their own fish and then watch them interact. The exhibit, developed with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Laboratory and Nearlife of Cambridge, Mass., will show how patterns arise through simple interactions and rules.

title: Inquiry Has No Suspects In Cafe Brawl
description: A police investigation into a brawl by firefighters at a restaurant in Bryant Park last week appeared to have stalled yesterday, with Police Commissioner Howard Safir saying that witnesses had been unable to identify any suspects.

title: Solving the Maze Challenge
description: NUMBER MAZE CHALLENGE

title: INSIDE
description: Vote on Bankruptcy Law

title: It's Showtime for the Sisters of the N.B.A.
description: The Women's National Basketball Association, a sister of the N.B.A. and a beneficiary of the N.B.A.'s marketing clout, begins its second season with four games tonight. One of those games -- the New York Liberty at the Cleveland Rockers -- will be televised nationally by the Lifetime cable network.

title: Brazil Does the Job With a Little Help From Its Opponent
description: Brazil's coach, Mario Zagallo, said he would know in the first match whether he might have only great players or a great team. The fans had already made up their minds. When Zagallo was introduced today, he was booed. But his team did what a defending champion must do in the opener of the World Cup. It survived, even if it took Scotland's putting a goal into its own net to provide a 2-1 victory for Brazil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAGLIANO, FRANCES
description: GAGLIANO-Frances. On June 9, 1998. Dedicated school teacher for over forty years, NYC Board of Ed., dear aunt of many nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grandnephews. Loved by her students and respected by her peers. Visiting Friday 2-4, 7-9, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, 9 A.M., St. Anselm's Church.

title: INTEGRATED HEALTH TO SELL 11 NURSING HOMES IN 5 STATES
description: Integrated Health Services Inc. said it would sell 11 nursing homes -- four in Montana, two in Colorado, one in Wyoming, three in Iowa and one in Missouri -- for $60 million as it works to reduce its $3.3 billion debt. The homes, which will be sold to private companies, are ''in states or markets that we do not believe are central for us to continue an operation there,'' said Marc Levin, executive vice president for investor relations. Integrated Health, which is based in Owings Mills, Md., recently sold 44 facilities for $371 million to Monarch Properties Inc., a newly formed real estate investment trust that filed for public offering in April. The companies are closely affiliated.

title: Kazakhs Raise Curtain on Remote New Capital, but Many Ask Why
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan  Free hands were hard to find in Kazakhstan's new capital on Wednesday, in the hours before it was officially offered to the nation by President Nursultan Nazarbayev.

title: Essay; Stop the 'Incoming!'
description: For years, when hawkish Republicans uttered the phrase ''missile defense,'' dovish Democrats would respond with a derisive Bronx cheer: ''Star Wars! Pie in the sky! Cost too much and would never work!''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NATIONAL VISION ASSOCIATES LTD., Lawrenceville, Ga., an optical company, agreed to acquire the closely held Frame-n-Lens Optical Inc., Fullerton, Calif., for about $37 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: IMC GLOBAL CONSIDERS SALE OF ITS AGRIBUSINESS UNIT
description: The fertilizer company IMC Global of Northbrook, Ill., said it was ''exploring strategic options'' for and might decide to sell its IMC Agribusiness retail and wholesale distribution unit. IMC Agribusiness, based in Collinsville, Ill., has about 2,000 employees at more than 240 sites in the Midwest and Southeast. It sells crop nutrients, seed and crop protection products to farmers and had sales of $873 million in 1997. Last week, IMC Global completed a sale of its consumer lawn and garden and professional products businesses. Its stock fell $2.125 a share yesterday, to $30.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXWELL, RHODA
description: MAXWELL-Rhoda. On June 9, 1998. Survived by her devoted son Douglas, her brother Sanford Granowitz and sister-in-law Fern Granowitz and numerous nieces and nephews. In lieu of a funeral, a memorial service will be arranged at a time & date to be announced. Any gifts or donations may be made to New York University School of Law, Manuel Maxwell Fund, or to The Parker Jewish Geriatric Center.

title: Compaq Discloses Management Team
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation disclosed the management team that will lead the company after its $9 billion acquisition of the Digital Equipment Corporation. It also said Digital's chairman and chief executive, Robert B. Palmer, would leave at the end of July.

title: Rodman Helps Put the Bulls A Game Away
description: Dennis Rodman grabbed the basketball and would not let Karl Malone take it away from him. He flung his elbows and smiled for effect with 43.8 seconds left. He wrestled. He rebounded. They won.

title: Aegon Is Selling Investment Banking Unit
description: Aegon N.V., one of the largest Dutch insurance companies, said yesterday that it would sell Bank Labouchere N.V., its investment banking arm, to the Dutch broker Amsterdam Options Traders N.V. Aegon said the two companies would be merged to create Bank AOT Labouchere, which would be the fourth-largest Dutch bank.

title: Shoot First, E-Mail Photos to Grandma Later
description: THE first digital cameras aimed at consumers were interesting computer peripherals that captured pictures on a sliver of silicon instead of film. Beyond some simple business applications that required instant electronic publishing, like making computer records of dented fenders, new home listings or smiling employees of the month, the first digital cameras were no match for even a simple point-and-shoot disposable camera.

title: G.M. to Develop Pickup Truck With Isuzu
description: The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest auto maker, said yesterday that it would develop a pickup truck with Isuzu Motors Ltd. of Japan for sale in the United States, Europe and Brazil. Isuzu, which is 37.5 percent owned by General Motors, will supply the chassis -- which includes the engine, axle and frame -- for the one-ton pickup truck, Isuzu's president, Kazuhira Seki, said. The agreement could grow to include sport utility vehicles, said Toru Kajiyama, an Isuzu managing director.

title: Old Teams, New Teams, Leiter Can Stop Them
description: Even with the significant addition of Mike Piazza to the lineup, pitching and defense are what have won games for the Mets the majority of the time this season. And for a staff that was criticized before the season for lacking a front-line starter, Al Leiter certainly has pitched like an ace.

title: Economic Scene; Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.
description: IF the war on drugs is indeed a battle of good versus evil, then Satan is gaining some impressive allies. An open letter to the United Nations Secretary General, on the occasion of the General Assembly's special session on drugs, asserts that ''the global war on drugs is now causing more harm than drug abuse itself.'' Among the signers of the letter were Javier Perez de Cuellar, the former Secretary General; Robert Strauss, the Democratic Party's lobbyist-lawyer; George Shultz, the former secretary of everything to Republican presidents, and even Walter Cronkite.

title: Harry, A Man Of Many Parts
description: Pete, Bob and Mary walk into a bar. ''You can't run around with primates all your life,'' says Pete (Sean Weil), objecting to Mary's plan to adopt an ape. Mary (Eva Patton) wants Pete and Bob (Lars Hanson) to be the ape's co-godfathers.

title: A Long Way From Simplicity
description: To the Editor:

title: Rocky Start for Merged Power Company
description: The first 13 days of corporate marriage between the Long Island Lighting Company and the Brooklyn Union Gas holding company has turned into a stormy honeymoon, with both sides fighting over their prenuptial agreement and vying for control of their partnership.

title: HEICO TO BUY JET ENGINE PARTS COMPANY FOR $41 MILLION
description: The Heico Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy McClain International, a privately held jet-engine parts company, for $41 million in cash and the company's headquarters for an additional $2.5 million. McClain, which is based in Atlanta, had revenue of $11 million in 1997. Heico, a maker of aircraft engine parts based in Hollywood, Fla., had revenue of $63.7 million last year. It said last week that it had agreed to buy a controlling stake in the French aviation company Teleflex Lionel-Dupont for $63 million in stock and the Miami-based PTM International for $15 million in cash.

title: Tom Dent, 66, Civil Rights Campaigner and Poet
description: Tom Dent, a civil rights campaigner who went on to become a writer of prose and poetry, died on Saturday at a hospital in New Orleans. He was 66 and lived in New Orleans.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Small and Wide-Shade Tree

title: Cigarette Maker Is Liable in Smoker's Death
description: In a major defeat for cigarette makers that could affect the course of Federal tobacco legislation, a Florida jury yesterday found the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation liable for a smoker's death and ordered the company to pay about $1 million in compensatory and punitive damages.

title: Trahan, Burden Gets Maryland Account
description: The Maryland Department of Business and Economic Development said yesterday that it had named Trahan, Burden & Charles to promote Maryland tourism as well as Maryland as a business location. The five-year contract, with total billings estimated at $35 million, had been handled by the Baltimore office of W. B. Doner & Company.

title: SoHo Site Specific: On the Roof
description: The traffic on West Broadway in SoHo came to a standstill on Sunday evening as a flatbed truck carrying what looked like a translucent water tower inched its way toward a 250-ton crane waiting at the corner of Grand Street.

title: Number Play for the Young
description: STICKYBEAR'S MATH SPLASH

title: Excerpts From Ruling on Use of Education Money
description: Following are excerpts from the decision issued yesterday by the Wisconsin Supreme Court on the Milwaukee Parental Choice Program allowing the city to use public money to send children to parochial or other religious schools. The text was obtained from the Web site of The Milwaukee Journal.

title: Complaints Against Police in '98 Grow 20%
description: Civilian complaints against New York City police officers went up by 20 percent during the first five months of the year, according to statistics released yesterday by the Civilian Complaint Review Board.

title: Mary Arnold Cahan, Museum Associate, 71
description: Mary Arnold Cahan, a New York socialite who helped organize annual benefits for the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on Tuesday in her home on the East Side of Manhattan. She was 71.

title: Metro Business; Insignia to Buy Company
description: The Insignia Financial Group announced yesterday that its commercial real estate services unit, Insignia/ESG, had agreed to acquire the commercial real estate businesses of the Jackson-Cross Company, one of the country's oldest commercial real estate services firms and the market leader in the greater Philadelphia region.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DE SILVA, GIL
description: De SILVA-Gil. June 11, 1997. Gilbey, a year ago your life was cut short and many hearts were broken. A beautiful & courageous soul, you'll be remembered always, with love, by all those you loved. Your friend forever, Michael Sieradzki

title: Ban Cars, Not Carts, On New York Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: SECURITY CAPITAL TO BUY BELGIAN PARKING COMPANY
description: Security Capital Group Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Bernheim-Comofi of Belgium, a parking garage company that controls more than 100,000 parking spaces throughout Europe, for 8.22 billion Belgian francs ($225 million). The purchase comes as more United States companies are looking to Europe for opportunities. Security Capital, which is based in Chicago, set up a $1.5 billion fund in April to invest in properties and companies on the Continent. The company is one of the largest real estate investors in the nation and controls about $20 billion in real estate through controlling stakes in 16 companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, DOROTHY STEINFELD
description: HOFFMAN - Dorothy Steinfeld. June 9, 1998. Loving wife of Myron B., devoted mother of Michael and Jill Shore. Devoted mother-in-law of Allan E. Shore, Jr. Loving grandmother of Jennifer, Christopher, Matthew & Sarah. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, June 11, 3-5PM and 7-9PM. Service Friday, 9:45AM at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Lilco 'Golden Parachute' Woven in Advance
description: Even as he was leading one of the most troubled utility companies in the United States, William J. Catacosinos was working on another task: laying the foundation for a lucrative departure from the utility, the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Hardly a Pocket Calculator: Kraftwerk's Studio Goes on Tour
description: Concert audiences in Japan have a reputation as quiet spectators who mystify Western musicians by hardly even clapping between songs. But when the German electronic-pop pioneers Kraftwerk performed three concerts at the Akasaka Blitz for a sold-out crowd of 2,500 people a night, the response was deafening.

title: Ban Cars, Not Carts, On New York Streets
description: To the Editor:

description: Quilt Artists, Plus One

title: Wolters Kluwer to Buy Plenum Publishing
description: Wolters Kluwer N.V., the big Dutch publisher, said yesterday that it would buy the Plenum Publishing Corporation of New York for $258 million in cash to bolster its research-oriented scientific publishing unit. The offer equals $73.50 a share for Plenum, publisher of The Journal of Abnormal Child Psychology.

title: State Street Unit Expands
description: The mutual fund company State Street Global Advisors said today that it had acquired a majority interest in Boston Capital Management Inc., owner of the Russian mutual fund Pallada Asset Management. Terms were not disclosed. State Street Global Advisors is a unit of the State Street Corporation, a financial-services holding company based in Boston. State Street Global Advisors has tax-exempt assets under management of $334.4 billion. State Street said that in addition to domestic funds, Pallada would manage assets for foreign investors.

title: Chinese Remove Book on Clinton's Indiscretions From Stores
description: In a seeming attempt to spare President Clinton embarrassment on his state visit, officials ordered bookstores this week to remove from their shelves a popular new book that details the sex scandals surrounding the American leader.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENSON, EMANUEL
description: LEVENSON-Emanuel. Today we mark the passing of a great musician, teacher and friend, Emanuel Levenson. What he gave to us could not have been bought for all the money in the world. He steadfastly served beauty and truth. He was a bright and brilliant link in a chain of illuminated souls working together for the upliftment of humanity. He achieved neither fame nor fortune in this world; he lived ethically and without compromise. The legacy of his teaching is a pure and living thing, excellent and perfect in its way.

title: NEWS WATCH; Nader Weighs In on Microsoft, Calling for the Return of OS/2
description: As part of a year-old crusade against Microsoft's dominance, the longtime consumer advocate Ralph Nader has written to the chairman of International Business Machines, Louis V. Gerstner, to say he thinks I.B.M. should make public the source code for its moribund OS/2 operating system.

title: In Support of Apartheid: Poison Whisky and Sterilization
description: Screwdrivers held tiny poison-filled cylinders, rings had spring-loaded compartments hiding deadly powders, vials of whisky were laced with the toxic herbicide paraquat, even peppermints were spiked with botulism.

title: The Red Wings' Tough Guy Enjoys an Unlikely Renaissance
description: Joe Kocur's face didn't make the cover of Rolling Stone, but it takes up about half of page 101 of the current issue.

title: A Cocktail of Chemicals to Treat Cancer Has Canada in a Stir
description: The visit this week of an 85-year-old doctor from Italy who claims to have successfully treated thousands of cancer patients with a cocktail of vitamins and hormones has set off a debate within Canada's universal health care system about patients' rights and alternative treatments.

title: Language Called Java Transcends Barriers
description: IT'S a familiar name with many meanings -- an ancient kingdom in what is now Indonesia, slang for a cup of coffee and one of the most important developments in the short life span of the Internet. Java, a programming language for applications used on networks, is being heralded, at least by Scott McNealy, chairman of Sun Microsystems, which developed and licenses Java as the next great thing, ready to change the nature of computing. Not everyone is quite as optimistic, but Java's growth and success so far is clear.

title: A New Stadium? Let's Vote on It
description: To the Editor:

title: Unfazed by New Theories on Child Welfare
description: LIKE breezes off the Hudson River a few feet away, new theories and fads in child welfare tend to blow through the rolling campus of Leake and Watts Services every few decades, ruffling the paperwork. Families should be preserved at all cost. No, abusive families must be split up. Neglected children should live together in a bucolic country setting. No, they should stay in the neighborhood where they grew up.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHEPPARD, DR. H.L. (SHEP)
description: SHEPPARD-Dr. H.L. (Shep). June 11, 1992. An unforgetable man to be remembered forever, by all who knew and loved him.

title: Indonesian Leader Softens Stand on the Status of East Timor
description: For the first time in 20 years, the Government has signaled its willingness to address one of the sorest points in Indonesia's international relations: the status of East Timor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIVEN, PHYLLIS CASSEDY
description: GIVEN-Phyllis Cassedy. On June 10, 1998, she is survived by her husband, Dr. William P., her children, Dr. William P. Jr, Robert M., and Phyllis Townsend Weaver. Memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 13 at 11 A.M. at Saint James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave at 71 Street. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory can be made to The Neighborhood Coalition For The Homeless.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASAROLI, CARDINAL AGOSTINO
description: CASAROLI - Cardinal Agostino. Appeal of Conscience Foundation mourns the death of Cardinal Casaroli, a past recipient of its World Statesman Award. His vision and wisdom made a lasting contribution to religious freedom and human rights. Rabbi Arthur Schneier, President Reverend Joseph A. O'Hare, S.J. Dr. David H.C. Read, Vice Pres.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

description: ROSENBLATT-E.G. Our hearts are greatly saddened by the loss of our dear uncle Manny, the patriarch of our family. He was a man of great generosity who cared for his family, Israel and the support of many worthwhile causes. He will be sorely missed. Linda & Ira Panzier Vicki & Michael Gross & Family Samantha & Ron Panzier Lois & Eric Lustig Rachel & Michael Lustig & Family Robin & Avi Schreiber & Family

description: Manhattan

title: Yankees Face Life Without Williams
description: The Yankees have won without Derek Jeter. They have won without Tino Martinez and Mariano Rivera and Chili Davis. Now they will have to try to win without Bernie Williams.

title: Two Big Nursing Home Operators Reach Agreement to Merge
description: The Health Care and Retirement Corporation and Manor Care Inc. agreed to merge yesterday in a stock swap valued at about $2.45 billion, creating one of the nation's largest operators of nursing homes.

title: Lewinsky Immunity Deal Is Said to Be Preferred by Both Sides
description: As they renewed their negotiations over a possible immunity agreement, prosecutors and the lawyers for Monica S. Lewinsky have two things in common: each side wants evidence from the other and each side would prefer an immunity deal to an indictment, lawyers and others involved in the inquiry said today.

title: Sports of The Times; Chicago's Big Three Becomes Gang of Four
description: IN whatever dimension Dennis Rodman operates, there is a God, a poetic flavor to the chaos. In Michael Jordan's, the universal truth is that no matter what leap of faith he makes, he ultimately lands right on his feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE CARDENAS, PIEDAD M.
description: de CARDENAS-Piedad M. On June 7, 1998. Beloved mother of Harry, George and Alan Romney, loving grandmother of Vanessa and Alexandra. Memorial mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84 St, Sat, June 13, 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAVITZ, SELMA
description: SHAVITZ-Selma. The Jewish Community Relations Council of New York mourns the passing of a dear friend and loyal supporter. Her dedication to so many Jewish causes will be sorely missed. May her loved ones be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Martin S. Begun, President Michael S. Miller, Exec VP

title: NEWS WATCH; Questions About Sex on Line Raise Questions About Survey
description: A survey of more than 9,000 MSNBC.com readers about their on-line sexual habits has generated skepticism about the study's scientific soundness.

title: Mr. Catacosinos Cashes In
description: For years the Long Island Lighting Company, or Lilco, has been very unpopular on Long Island. People resented its rates -- the highest in the nation -- and politicians found it easier to run against it than against each other.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an open letter to the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, asserting that the global war on drugs is causing more harm than drug abuse itself, misspelled the surname of the organizer of the letter. He is Ethan Nadelmann, not Nadlemann.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about the popularity of visits to India by high-profile people from the worlds of fashion, entertainment and society referred incorrectly to the Indian guru Sai Baba. He did not die in 1982. He is 71, has devotees worldwide and lives mainly at Prasanthi Nilayam, a large ashram in South India near the town of Puttaparthi, where he was born.

title: Judge Dismisses Lawyer for Defendant in Racial Beating Case
description: Noting that the defendant owed more than $73,000 in legal fees and had no way to pay, a judge today dismissed the lawyer for a white man from Queens who was charged with the near-fatal beating of a black man outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub two years ago.

title: Speed Limits On Modems
description: Q. I own a 56 K modem. The manual says the highest speed the modem can legally attain is 53 kilobits per second because of speed limits. What are these limits?

title: Trolls Help Dress Up Math
description: MATH BLASTER: AGES 6 TO 9

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The role of the Mayor and the Governor and the trustees would seem to be more robust than one would expect, and that diminishes the role of the chancellor. I have a different kind of board that lets me be president. If I succeed, they pat me on the head. If I don't, they kick me in the pants. But they are not constantly pulling up the plant to see how the roots are doing.''

title: BAY VIEW CAPITAL TO BUY PSB LENDING FOR $153 MILLION
description: The Bay View Capital Corporation, a savings institution in San Mateo, Calif., agreed to acquire the PSB Lending Corporation, a home equity lender in Carlsbad, Calif., for $153 million in stock and cash plus as much as $147 million from future profits. PSB, a unit of the Dallas-based Pacific Southwest Bank, specializes in the highly leveraged home equity loan -- a loan that is a high percentage of the value of the borrower's home. Bay View will pay $100 million in stock and $53 million in cash to Pacific Southwest Bank. The additional payments will be spread over seven years if PSB meets profit targets. Bay View shares fell 62.50 cents, to $30.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Design Notebook; Fountain Fantasies, From Cascades to Curbs
description: MOTHS are attracted to flames; humans to fountains. Whether they are towering plumes ingeniously engineered to rise Excalibur-like from a becalmed lake or monumental gushes churning through some mythological deity, fountains are irresistible messengers.

title: Linebacker Signs
description: The Miami Dolphins signed the free agent linebacker Robert Jones to a one-year contract yesterday, eight days after he was released by the St. Louis Rams in a salary cap move. Jones, 29, led the Rams with 115 tackles last season.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Attempted Killing Links Turkish Army, the Kurds and Politics
description: Even after Turkey's most prominent rights advocate, Akin Birdal, was released from a hospital this week, questions about who was behind the attempt to kill him remain unanswered.

title: With Asia's Economies Shrinking, Women Are Being Squeezed Out
description: As the South Korean economy boomed, so did Son Kyoung Suk's career. As a clothing designer at Shinsegae Department Store, she was steadily given more responsibility and promoted to become a buyer, a job usually reserved for men.

title: Currents; THE NEW CUBISM -- Making Art Out of Necessity
description: Construction sites are usually ugly. But the Brooklyn Museum of Art's third-floor Beaux-Arts Court, though filled with scaffolding, has been turned into a light show and a photographic gallery.

title: Class Convenes On the Course
description: Twelve-year-old Jason Diaz had taken three ferocious swings and hit nothing but air on the practice range at the Westchester Country Club here. But then the advice he had been receiving from Ben Hoffhine, an assistant professional at the club, finally registered, and Jason, swinging easier, laced a tee shot right down the middle.

title: Making Books; Art of Foreplay At the Table
description: The oldest ceremonial in book publishing is the publishing lunch. It may date back to the 15th century when, myth has it, Johann Gutenberg bought a chunk of bratwurst for an author's agent. And it has reeled on through mead and the three-martini lunch to today's meal of choice, grilled fish and iced tea. So in the bubbling pot of the present book world, the question is: Are these lunches (down to about two hours from the three of not too long ago) still useful? Or are they merely for preening?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNAU, ELIZABETH
description: LUNAU-Elizabeth, 87. Beloved mother of Dominique Avery and grandmother of Carola Morrone of Simsbury, CT, died June 5 at her home in Manhattan. She was the daughter of Ludwig Marum, a minister in the Weimar government who was taken prisoner by the Nazis in 1933 and killed a year later. Elizabeth passed her exams to become a lawyer three days before Hitler's government barred Jews from practicing law. She fled Germany in 1936 and joined her mother, sister and brother in France, where they were put in concentration camps. Her sister died in a camp in Poland. Elizabeth was eventually released and made her way to New York in 1941. She supported herself and her daughter by working as a maid, eventually becoming executive housekeeper at a number of Manhattan hotels. To keep the memory of her family alive, Elizabeth published two books in German, a collection of her father's writings and one of her relatives' letters during World War II, which was also published in French. She travelled to Germany frequently to speak to young people about the Holocaust. A Memorial service will be held Sunday at 11 A.M. at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her name to the Leo Baeck Institute, 129 East 73rd Street, New York, New York 10021.

description: Deciding that escapist romance for the Treadmill Generation has to be a workout in its own right, Ivan Reitman's ''Six Days, Seven Nights'' puts its stars through the wringer. Not even in action pictures do muscles often matter the way they do here. Marooned on a breathtaking desert island, Anne Heche and Harrison Ford share both amorous stirrings and personal training, doing enough climbing, hauling and flexing to shame anybody (i.e., you there, loafing in the audience) who is merely killing time in the dark. Among the numerous homages in a film that yearns for little distractions is the ''From Here to Eternity'' surf kiss with a new twist: hiking boots.

title: Romance and Grit on a Wartime English Farm
description: Movies that remember the home front during World War II -- especially those made in England -- exert an almost irresistible nostalgic tug. The image of the British populace, bravely sacrificing together while under siege from Hitler's bombs, conjures the nobler side of human nature. And the romances that bloom between soldiers facing death and women tending the home fires acquire a star-crossed, now-or-never edge of desperate longing. It takes a war to remind us just how much fonder the heart can grow when it beats for an absent lover.

title: Breaching the Church-State Wall

Although a few recent United States Supreme Court decisions have relaxed strictures against using public money to support certain activities in parochial schools, those cases have dealt with tangential and very limited benefits to the church-sponsored institutions. No appellate court, including the Supreme Court, has ever allowed the huge transfer of taxpayer money that the Wisconsin voucher program will put into parochial school coffers.

title: Jaded Artist and Ingenue In an Arty Spider Web

Interested in the collision between naturalistic, highly personal photography and cool commerce, she makes her film's main character a once-celebrated photographer named Lucy Berliner, who is played by Ally Sheedy in a fierce, tricky performance that is the film's strongest element. Spooked by fame, Lucy long ago retreated from the art world to live a reclusive, druggy life in an apartment that has become a louche mecca for her lesbian friends.

That number is down from the 6.8 million shares Hagler Bailly said it would issue when the two companies signed a nonbinding merger agreement in March. But Hagler's stock price has risen in the last three months and at yesterday's closing price of $28.125, up 12.5 cents, the deal is now worth $185.6 million. Hagler Bailly, based in Arlington, Va., is a consulting firm that specializes in the energy, utility and environmental industries. Putnam Hayes, based in Cambridge, Mass., is an economic and management consulting firm.

Come prepared for a mixed bag. At its best, his art combines strange wit with a hangdog humanity that is endearing, clever and funny.

title: Mixing Melodies From the Page With Tunes From the Head
description: One of the many strains running through this year's Texaco New York Jazz Festival has been the desire to integrate free improvisation and composition. It's an old concern, and some people do it better than others. On Tuesday night Myra Melford, the pianist playing at the Knitting Factory, structured her loose pieces with bits of strong writing.
