description: A Hearst Unveils

title: Slaying of a Gadfly Regional Editor Makes Moscow Take Notice
description: For several years Moscow-based journalist rights groups have pressed the Government to help Larisa Yudina, a newspaper editor in the southern region of Kalmykia who suffered repeated harassment by local authorities, in clear violation of Russia's press law.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page summary in some editions yesterday about the Chicago Bulls' victory over the Utah Jazz in Game 4 of the basketball finals misstated the point total for Michael Jordan. It was 34, not 36.

title: Sports of The Times; Love Gives Els Referral For Therapist
description: IN the PGA Tour's fitness trailer before his round yesterday morning, Davis Love 3d noticed that Ernie Els was stretched out on a table. And as they and Frank Nobilo played their first nine holes in the Buick Classic, Love knew that the world's No. 1-ranked golfer wasn't himself.

title: HOME VIDEO
description: Maneuvers At the Games

title: California's Answer to Impressionism
description: There are two immediate points to be made about the show ''All Things Bright and Beautiful'' at the National Academy Museum: It will satiate you with lush California scenery, and it will tell you more than you want to know about the insipid regional school known as California Impressionism. In full stride from around the turn of the century to the mid-1920's, the artists of this group produced sun-drenched treescapes, rockscapes, seascapes, mountain scapes, flowerscapes and views of run-down old mission buildings, with little evidence in their work of people or urban squalor.

title: Danish Banks Plan To Form Big Lender
description: BG Bank A/S and Realkredit Danmark A/S announced plans yesterday to form Denmark's largest lender by assets in a merger worth at least 12.8 billion kroner ($1.9 billion). Investors will swap each BG Bank share for one in Kapital Holding A/S, a new holding company with assets of 530 billion kroner. Realkredit Danmark, owned by an association of mortgage borrowers, will hold 55 percent of the entity, while BG Bank will provide the chief executive. BG Bank's shares jumped 30 kroner yesterday, to 430.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOSE, MARGARET V.S.
description: VOSE-Margaret V.S. 85. Of Westport, CT., and wife of the late Charles B. Vose, died Monday, June 8. Mrs. Vose, daughter of the late James Frederick and Emily Vance Simpson, was a graduate of Kemper Hall, Kenosha, and the University of Wisconsin. She was past-president of the Women's Board of the Norwalk Hospital and a member of the Westport and Sasqua Garden Clubs. She served as a member of the Board of Directors of the Nature Center for Environmental Activities and the Altar Guild of Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, both in Westport. Survived by her son, James B. Vose of Fairfield, CT; daughter, Margaret V.V. Armao of NYC and two grandchildren. Memorial service 11:30 AM at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 75 Church Lane, Westport.

title: Name Game: The More The Merrier
description: What's in a name? A lot if it's early American furniture. Two names are even better: when the name of the furniture maker and the patron for whom the furniture was made are both known, it can greatly increase the value of a piece.

title: Police Effort To Speed 911 Lagging Badly
description: The Police Department's attempt to speed its officers' response to emergency calls by upgrading the city's new 911 system is nearly three years behind schedule, and, with no completion date in sight, the city is on the verge of canceling the $17 million project, city officials said.

title: Council Postpones Vote on Overriding Giuliani's $196 Million in Budget Cuts
description: Just hours before staging another demonstration of its newfound political resolve, the City Council postponed plans yesterday to override a series of vetoes by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani that cut $196 million from the city's recently adopted $34 billion budget.

title: Pakistan, Facing Sanctions, Urges Citizens to Cut Back
description: With the economy facing sanctions because of the Government's nuclear tests, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif called on Pakistanis today to tighten their belts.

title: W.N.B.A.: ROUNDUP; Liberty Opens Season With Loss at Cleveland
description: ROCKERS 78, LIBERTY 71

title: British Cellist's Challenge: A Pair of Russian Sonatas
description: The British cellist Kathryn Price, who gave her New York debut recital at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday, is a fine young player, attentive and in control. In a long evening, maybe five notes suffered from split or imperfect tone, and there was not a phrase that was allowed to come across without being thought through. Tuning, too, was exact throughout -- even, or especially, when she chose a slight deflection to accord with how the music was going at that point. And all her discipline expressed itself as engaged determination. These were pieces she wanted to make into music, and did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMPEL, CLARISSE B.
description: KAMPEL-Clarisse B. Harvard Medical School expresses deepest regret for the loss of Clarisse Kampel. Mrs. Kampel and her husband Daniel Kampel have been exemplary supporters of the Stuart H.Q. and Victoria Quan Fellowship Fund in Neurobiology through their leadership and their philanthropy. Her legacy will continue in perpetuity.

title: Sending Up Fashion, Sex, Art and His Own Sheepish Persona
description: It happened the other day that I was walking through the Charles Ray exhibition at the Whitney at the same time as a couple of hardy older women (not the type of ladies who lunch), and they looked as if they had wandered by mistake from the Andrew Wyeth show downstairs, unsure of what they had stumbled onto.

title: Lois/USA Forms Health Care Unit
description: Lois/USA Inc. in New York has formed Lois/Health Care, which will operate as part of the Lois/EJL New York agency and specialize in health-related accounts.

title: DANAHER AGREES TO ACQUIRE GERMAN EQUIPMENT MAKER
description: The Danaher Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Dr. Bruno Lange G.m.b.H., a German maker of equipment to monitor air and water quality. Terms were not disclosed. Danaher, based in Washington, makes tools, components and process controls. It had revenue of $2.05 billion last year. Dr. Bruno Lange has annual revenue of $60 million. Danaher's shares fell 62.5 cents each yesterday, to $36.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Michael L. Pollock, 61, an Expert on Exercise
description: Michael L. Pollock, perhaps the nation's most respected expert on how much and how hard adults should exercise, died last Friday at age 61. He suffered a stroke that afternoon at the annual meeting of the American College of Sports Medicine in Orlando, Fla., and died that night, according to the organization.

title: W.N.B.A.: ROUNDUP
description: Sting 83, Mystics 57

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYMONS, EMILY
description: SYMONS-Emily. Died June 10. Devoted wife to the late Dr. Max Symons and wonderful mother to David, mother-in-law to Irene, grandmother to Stuart, his wife Caryn and to Matthew, greatgrandmother of Scott Austin. Sister of the late Mortimer Silvey. Sister-in-law to Diane Silvey. All of us and cousins, nieces, nephews and friends will miss her. Funeral services today at 10 AM at Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. Shiva will be observed at her son's home. Memorial contributions may be made to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VITAGLIANO, KATHRYN NESS
description: VITAGLIANO-Kathryn Ness. On June 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Giuseppe. Loving mother of Maria Teresa and grandmother of Katrina and Eleanor. Services at Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Ave at 91 St, Saturday, June 13th, 11AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Department of Human Genetics, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, 1250 1st Av, Rm 917, NY NY 10021.

title: Murdoch Sets TV Guide Sale For $2 Billion
description: In a deal that brings together the nation's top-selling weekly magazine with the leading provider of on-screen television listings, the News Corporation agreed yesterday to sell TV Guide to United Video Satellite Group Inc. for $2 billion in cash and stock.

title: Foe of Nigeria's Military Fears It Will Rule On
description: His greatest fear, said Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian Nobel laureate and ardent foe of military rule, is that with the death of one tyrant, the world will not press for the entire junta to step aside.

title: She's Poor, Homely and Bent on Revenge
description: Some stories are so long and so elaborate that they could never be comfortably squeezed into a 108-minute movie, no matter how judicious the editing. Take the new film version of Balzac's novel ''Cousin Bette,'' a mid-19th-century French antecedent of ''The Bonfire of the Vanities.'' Even though the film, set in 1840's Paris, dispenses with some of the novel's characters and subplots, it feels as rushed, overstuffed and devoid of texture as Brian DePalma's hopelessly stunted screen adaptation of ''Bonfire.''

title: Candice Bergen vs. Murphy Brown
description: By and large, the world views of television sitcom actors are best left to fluffy features in the entertainment section. But in a society where intellectuals regard pop culture as a passable approximation of political reality, surely Candice Bergen's remarks marking the end of her once controversial show, ''Murphy Brown,'' are noteworthy.

title: Rechecking a Writer's Facts, A Magazine Uncovers Fiction
description: There was the article last February about the three twentysomething White House interns sitting hunched over vodka martinis in a Washington bar, ''feverishly speculating about the details of President Clinton's sex life.''

title: Baggio's Kick Saves Italians From Upset by Chile
description: Two formerly exiled forces collided today, releasing pent-up energy and expectations on the second day of the 1998 World Cup.

title: Sarkis Soultanian, 57, Chairman Of Company That Monitors Bills
description: Sarkis Soultanian, who rose to become chairman and chief executive of a company he first joined as an office boy, died on June 5 at his home in Franklin Lakes, N.J., of complications from a heart attack. He was 57.

title: Observer; Up There In High Dudgeon
description: The trial lawyers who whipped Big Bad Tobacco are now trying to collect fees that run into billions of dollars. This has produced the usual outcries from people who hate to see anybody wallow in money, especially when the anybody is a lawyer.

title: SIERRA HEALTH TO ACQUIRE KAISER OPERATIONS IN TEXAS
description: Sierra Health Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Kaiser Permanente's operations in Texas for about $129 million. The deal consists of Kaiser Foundation Health Plan of Texas, a managed health care plan, and Permanente Medical Association of Texas, a 150-physician medical group. Sierra Health, a managed health care company based in Las Vegas, Nev., said the purchase price consisted of $51.5 million for the 123,000-member Kaiser Foundation, and $7.5 million for the Permanente Medical Association, as well as $70 million for the organizations' office equipment, real estate and eight medical and office complexes.

title: Yanks Lose As Pettitte Exits With Hip Pain
description: Andy Pettitte stood on the mound in the seventh inning tonight and assured Joe Torre that he was fine, that the discomfort in his left hip that bothered him in the sixth inning had disappeared.

description: What is your exact height and weight? Anyone who even thinks of tacking an extra half-inch onto one or shaving a pound or two from the other can imagine the temptation felt by scientists when they make measurements that affect a favorite theory.

description: To the Editor:

title: Parallel Lives, Frozen By a Lost Loved One
description: Love, fear and revulsion are some of the feelings movies are particularly adept at conjuring, but grief is much more elusive because it's so private. How do you evoke the inner life of a solitary mourner mutely contemplating the world from behind an emotional shroud? ''When I Close My Eyes,'' the feature film debut of the Japanese director Shunji Iwai, offers an intriguing narrative platform from which to experience the sadness of its bereft central character, Hiroko Watanabe (Miho Nakayama).

title: Debate Over the Census Focuses On How to Define 'Enumeration'
description: The dispute over whether the Census Bureau will statistically sample neighborhoods and estimate the population in 2000 moved today from the House of Representatives to the Federal courts, where arguments in this dispute over numbers centered on the definition of words.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIDLER, JEAN
description: FIDLER-Jean. Wife of the late Sam, mother of Howard & the late Martin, mother-in-law of Judy & Andree, sister of Sylvia Kaufman, sister-in-law of Ben, grandmother of Beth Rakin, Peter, Amy Kalt and David, great-grandmother of Michael, Joshua, Martin, Cary, Matthew and Jared, aunt of Alan. Graveside service 1 PM, Sunday, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Sweeping Turkish Stories In a Century of Change
description: Hugely ambitious and blessed with a versatile, richly talented cast, an excellent new play called ''Pera Palas'' arrived last night to engage the mind and grip the emotions.

title: NATO TO CONDUCT LARGE MANEUVERS TO WARN OFF SERBS
description: NATO defense ministers commissioned contingency plans today for bombing Serbian targets in Kosovo and said they would stage a large-scale military exercise at Serbia's doorstep as early as next week to give the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, a taste of the power that could be turned on him if he persists in attacks on the province.

title: Armstrong Wins In Comeback Race
description: Lance Armstrong won the opening stage of the Tour of Luxembourg yesterday, his first international race since coming back from testicular cancer.

title: If It's the Last Dance, Bulls Have the Right Floor
description: There is a certain series-ending feel about Friday night. If the cast of stars and oddball sidekicks who have made up the Bulls' dramatic run must fade to black, this is where they want to let go of their gilded era. In the warmth of their own sound stage.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Don't go to Donguri.

title: Asian Crisis Lifts Bonds But Not Stocks
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday even as Government bond yields fell to their lowest level in more than 20 years.

title: Monitoring Of Drug Tests Is Faulted
description: Federal investigators told a Congressional panel today that the system for policing tests of new drugs and medical devices needed changes to protect the interests of patients participating in such experiments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBB, JAMES R.
description: GIBB-James R., 52, a long-time activist and former president of Front Runners New York, the gay and lesbian running club, died June 7 at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. The immediate cause of death was septicemia. Jim was active from 1991 with Front Runners New York, among the largest gay & lesbian athletic groups in the nation. In 1995, he was elected that group's Vice President and was elected Front Runner President in 1996. Jim was also an early leader of Body Positive, the advocacy group for persons with HIV. A 1967 graduate of Dartmouth, Jim later served as a Peace Corps volunteer in the Philippines. At the time of his death, Jim was Senior Editor of HBO's Program Guide, a post he had held for the last fifteen years. He is survived by his father, Donald of Poway, CA., a brother Raymond, a nephew and numerous close friends & colleagues. A memorial service will be held on July 18 at 2:30 PM at Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 73rd and Broadway. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Jim's name may be made to Front Runners Charitable Foundation, Box 87, Ansonia Station, New York, New York 10023.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMMERDAHL, JENS M.
description: ROMMERDAHL-Jens M. A Memorial Service will be held at the Zion Lutheran Church, Saddle River, N.J. at 2PM, Saturday, June 13, 1998. Jens Rommerdahl was the General Manager of New York Marine Terminals, Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. He is survived by his wife Carla and the families of his sons Kurt and Lance. He received honors from Queen Margrethe II of Denmark for service to the Danish community in New York. He received honors presented by Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands for service to the Dutch Navy. He was awarded the Ellis Island Medal of Honor awarded to non-native American citizens for outstanding citizenship. He graduated Cum Laude from New York University.

title: President Promoted At Unit of Omnicom
description: Thomas L. Harrison, 50, president of the Diversified Agency Services division of Omnicom Group in New York, is being promoted to chairman and chief executive. John Wren, 46, will relinquish those duties and continue as chairman and chief executive of Omnicom. Mr. Harrison joined the division in 1992. It is composed of agencies that specialize in public relations, direct response, sales promotion, medical communications and recruitment advertising.

title: Songwriters' Hall of Fame Ushers Simon, Outsider, In
description: After a hard year of watching his musical, ''The Capeman,'' struggle on Broadway, Paul Simon was happy to be getting an award when the Songwriters' Hall of Fame held its 29th annual induction on Wednesday night at the Sheraton New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHAN, MARY (SISI)
description: CAHAN-Mary (Sisi). Sisi made magnificent public occasions because she imbued each with personality and individualism. One will remember forever her great dinners; one will remember her forever. Richard Martin The Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: Hockey Shots Being Taken From Different Approaches
description: Whose hockey would you rather watch? Fox's or CBC's? The heretic's broadcast or the traditionalist's? While most of us cannot view the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's telecasts, a few cognoscenti of the purist persuasion have written or called to say CBC produces hockey games the way it should be done.

title: Summer Theater: Out of Doors and Off the Wall
description: ''Julius Caesar'' makes no mention of a wino. A Poet, yes; a Soothsayer, of course. But there is no reference in Shakespeare to a tipsy guy in soiled clothes who heckles Cassius and wheezes during Marc Antony's funeral oration.

description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's address yesterday at the National Geographic Society in Washington, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAVEN, WILLIAM M.
description: CRAVEN-William M., 70. Of Montague Center, MA. He was formerly associated with the New York Telephone Co in Watertown, NY. He was a retired Vice President of Institutional Sales for Paine Webber, in Springfield, MA. Survived by his wife, Barbara Sheehan Craven. Funeral Saturday, 10:00AM, St. James Church.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about negotiations for Alice Waters, the chef and owner of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., to open a restaurant at the Louvre in Paris misspelled the surname of the well-known baker whom Ms. Waters expects to advise her there. He is Lionel Poilane, not Pouillon.

title: Schools Get Guidelines On Applying 'Megan's Law'
description: New Jersey's Attorney General issued revised guidelines on ''Megan's Law'' today, including the first rules on school officials' roles in issuing alerts about paroled sex offenders living or working near schools.

title: NATO Action in Kosovo Would Face New Pitfalls
description: Three years ago, NATO jets pounded Bosnian Serb separatists into submission, bombarding their heavy weapons, ammunition depots, supply routes and lines of communication until their leaders agreed to make peace with Bosnia's Muslims and Croats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAVNEH, ANNA
description: YAVNEH-Anna, 93. Died June 5. Matriarch of Northern Galilee Pioneers of Palestine; champion of Israeli statehood, passionately devoted to her extended family & her Jewish heritage. Her generosity and indomitable Sabra spirit were the hallmarks and legacy of her life. Widow of renowned Cantor Zalmon Yavneh. Survived by children Emanuel, Murray, Nina Steinberg, Cyrus; sister Molly Fox; ten grandchildren; ten great grandchildren. Pre-deceased by son Raphael. Services were held. Memorial contributions to Project in Yavniel, Israel, (C/O Yavneh, 100 West 76th Street, New York, New York 10023).

title: Curbs on Lawyer Fees In Tobacco Suits Fail
description: One of the few critical issues remaining in the comprehensive tobacco legislation before the Senate, limits in the fees that lawyers could collect from successful lawsuits against tobacco companies, failed to be approved for the second time in a month. The measure, which would limit lawyers to fees of $1,000 an hour, failed on a vote of 50 to 45.

title: ITT FLUID TECHNOLOGY TO BUY MARINE PRODUCTS MAKER
description: The ITT Fluid Technology Corporation, the world's largest pump producer, agreed yesterday to buy the marine products maker Rule Industries from Kennametal Inc. for an undisclosed amount. Rule Industries, a unit of Kennametal's Greenfield Industries subsidiary, makes marine and accessory products for the recreational and small commercial boat markets. Rule has annual sales of about $25 million, while ITT Industries of White Plains, the parent of ITT Fluid Technology, had 1997 sales of $8.6 billion.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Matisse and Balthus

title: Stock Mutual Fund Purchases Reduced
description: Investors reduced their stock mutual fund purchases by about 23 percent in May, a fund company trade group reported yesterday.

title: $34 Million Settles Suit For Women At Auto Plant
description: In the largest sexual harassment settlement ever negotiated by the Federal Government, the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation's American subsidiary agreed today to pay $34 million to end a Government lawsuit charging that hundreds of female workers at its automobile assembly plant in Normal, Ill., had been sexually harassed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE CARDENAS, PIEDAD M.
description: de CARDENAS-Piedad M. On June 7, 1998. Beloved mother of Harry, George and Alan Romney, loving grandmother of Vanessa and Alexandra. Loving mother-inlaw of Susi. In Memorial mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84 St, Sat, June 13, 11 AM.

title: 6,000 G.M. WORKERS AT MICHIGAN PLANT JOIN AUTO STRIKE
description: Nearly 6,000 workers went on strike this evening at a General Motors factory in Flint, Mich., joining fellow strikers at a nearby G.M. plant in an increasingly bitter fight that could close virtually all of the company's North American assembly plants within days.

title: An Artist Reflected in the Faces and Works of His Famous Colleagues
description: Were they ever that young? There's Willem de Kooning sitting on the floor, propped up against a bed with his feet crossed and knees clasped, with a black knit cap and a stunned, starry-eyed expression. Next to him on the floor is Franz Kline, a laughing walrus. In another picture Mark Rothko worries. There is Alexander Calder posing with a smoking cigarette, smiling slightly with dirty teeth. In another shot Jackson Pollock stands in a field, plump and wholesome in a ribbed T-shirt with a hawk on his wrist.

title: Birthday Candles? This Family's Into Fireworks
description: Prosperous Philippe (Wladimir Yordanoff) arrives at his family's modest little restaurant fresh from a television appearance about which he has been nervous. So he fishes for compliments in the shark-infested waters of a family gathering. ''It's a stupid detail, but you stuttered at one point,'' points out Betty (Agnes Jaoui), his rebellious and outspoken sister. Then Philippe's domineering mother (Claire Maurier) and dim, dainty wife (Catherine Frot) voice their unhelpful opinions about Philippe's necktie.

description: Judging strictly by the number of restaurants, Italian may be the most popular cuisine in New York. Some seem stamped from a mold, offering the same menus and the same dishes. Others, like these 12 restaurants, are more distinctive. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Duke Energy Acquisition
description: The Duke Energy Corporation, an electric utility, purchased two Louisiana natural gas-processing plants and related pipeline systems today from Dynegy Inc., increasing its ability to process gas and liquids for shipment to other parts of the country. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Duke's shares rose $1.1875 each, to $62. Dynegy fell 18.75 cents, to $14.0625.

title: Lawyer to Study Lilco Chief's Pay Package
description: Despite Gov. George E. Pataki's demand for his ouster, William J. Catacosinos is still gripping the chairman's reins at the new Marketspan Corporation. Today he presided over the company's first meeting of its board of directors.

title: F.A.A. Investigates DC-9 Upkeep by Northwest
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating accusations that Northwest Airlines improperly maintained its DC-9 aircraft and that the F.A.A.'s own principal maintenance inspector in Minneapolis did not oversee the airline properly, Federal officials said.

title: Teheran Mayor's Trial Begins and the Strains Are Showing
description: The start of a public trial of the Mayor of Teheran appears to have turned up the political temperature in Iran at a time when strains between conservatives and moderates there are on increasingly vivid display.

title: Oxford Health Cuts Back Its Medicare Plans
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said today that it had stopped marketing and most enrollment in its Medicare plans after a Federal review that criticized the company.

title: Japan Credit Bank To Review Some Lending
description: Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd. said yesterday that it had started to review its lending to 2,500 companies, one-third of its total client base, with the possibility that the loans may be eliminated. The review will be finished by March 2000. ''We expect our clients to be around 5,000 over the next two years after the review,'' a bank official said.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; 50 Years of the 2CV's Joie de Vivre
description: THE Citroen 2CV, affectionately known the world over as the Deux Chevaux -- for two horsepower -- turns 50 this month. Although the eccentric little car has not been built since 1990, French devotees recently marked its birthday with a parade on the Champs Elysees, and a smaller celebration is planned next week in Massachusetts. Like the Model T Ford and the original Volkswagen, two other cars designed as basic transportation for common people, the 2CV has transcended its humble origins to become a 20th-century icon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOWSHOWITZ, LIBBY
description: MOWSHOWITZ-Libby. Z'l. Hillcrest Jewish Center mourns the passing of our beloved Rebbitzen emeritus. She devoted her life and was dedicated to the Jewish world and will be sorely missed. All the arms of the synagogue were touched by her guidance as were all the synagogue members for decades. May her loved ones be comforted amongst the mourns of Zion and Jerusalem. Geoffrey Botnick, Rabbi Martin Resnick, President

description: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee accused the Clinton Administration today of shielding China from sanctions that could block Chinese companies from launching American satellites.

description: For New York City parents, the neighborhood playground is an oasis, a place for children to run, climb, swing and shout that transcends the harried congestion of urban life.

description: OIL AT LOWEST IN 10 YEARS. Oil declined again on fear of a protracted global glut and insufficient OPEC cuts. July contracts fell 73 cents, or 5.4 percent, to $12.75 a barrel, the weakest since October 1988.

description: After warning last month that its revenues would fall below Wall Street's expectations, the National Semiconductor Corporation today reported a fourth-quarter loss that equaled analysts' revised estimates. National said orders continued to decline in the quarter, but that the rate of decrease had slowed during May.

description: Four Atlantic City casino workers, including two executives, were arrested on Federal charges yesterday after they agreed to launder tens of thousands of dollars for undercover investigators, who described the money as illegal drug proceeds, Federal and state law enforcement officials said.

description: Ernie Els's attempt to win a third consecutive Buick Classic at the Westchester Country Club ended abruptly today when back spasms forced him to withdraw after nine holes.

description: Indonesia's powerful military affirmed its backing today for the reform movement that is spreading new freedoms through the country, but warned that it would crack down if protests got out of hand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOON, WILLIAM FRANKLIN
description: MOON-William Franklin. The Faculty and Staff of Columbia School of Public Health mourn the loss of William Franklin Moon, brother of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. Joyce Moon-Howard, Assistant Professor in the Division of Sociomedical Sciences. Mr. Moon, 46, died on June 8, 1998 at his home in Uniondale, NY of respiratory complications associated with his long term battle with Multiple Sclerosis (MS.) He had a promising career in the media broacasting before contracting the disease in the early 1980's. Born in Cleveland, Ohio, he was awarded a Jennings Scholarship and attended Ohio University where he received his Bachelor's Degree and pursued graduate work in Communications. He will be greatly missed and we send our sincere condolences to his parents, William and Ruth Moon of Cleveland, Ohio, loving sisters, Majorie Moon, Joyce Moon-Howard, and Madonna Moon, and godsons Jabari and Jason Tawiah of San Leandro, California and a host of relatives and friends. A memorial service will be held in Cleveland, Ohio. Allan Rosenfeld, MD, Dean Cheryl Healton, Dr. P.H., Head, Division of Sociomedical Sciences Columbia School of Public Health

description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN PLUMMETS. Japan's currency reached a nearly eight-year low after remarks by Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin were taken to mean it would fall further. In New York, the dollar rose to 143.79 yen from 141.43.

title: Sailor Victorious in Gay Case of On-Line Privacy
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: I.N.S. Moves to Deport Persistent Illegal Immigrant a 2d Time
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has begun deportation proceedings -- again -- against a Chinese man who has tried twice in the last five years to sneak into the United States aboard smuggling ships that ran aground, the man's lawyers said today.

title: On My Mind; Pointing The Finger
description: The three-day meeting on fighting drugs was one of the more useful United Nations conferences in decades. It was well led by Pino Arlacchi, the Italian Mafia-buster, drew chiefs of state and narcotics specialists from every part of the world, and wound up with a plan to eliminate the growing of illegal heroin and cocaine in 10 years -- certainly difficult but certainly doable.

title: Misplaced Trust In Missile Defenses
description: To the Editor:

title: Graf Advances To Quarterfinals
description: Steffi Graf took just one hour to beat Kristie Boogert, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday and advance to the quarterfinals of the D.F.S. Classic in Birmingham, England.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''America thought Korea was a problem, but Japan is like a bomb a hundred times more powerful than Korea.''

title: A Lone Desert Wanderer Befriended by a Leopard
description: Cultures clash and man and animal achieve transcendent communion in the fever dream that is ''Passion in the Desert.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: IRON MOUNTAIN INC., Boston, a records- management company, said it would buy National Underground Storage Inc., Boyers, Pa., for undisclosed terms.

title: Eritrea-Ethiopia War: Unwanted but Unchecked
description: The undeclared war between Eritrea and Ethiopia is a bewildering study in contradictions. It is a war that both heads of state maintain they do not want, set off by a minor land dispute both sides agree could easily be settled by historians and cartographical experts.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Robert Irwin

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Wednesday listing political prisoners in Nigeria misspelled the surname of a former head of state who is being held. He is Olusegun Obasanjo, not Obosanjo.

title: 'Good and Evil,' but Always Charming
description: The genius of Savannah lies in its contradictions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, DANIEL G.
description: LEVINE-Daniel G. Congregation Ohab Zedek of Belle Harbor and the Yeshiva of Belle Harbor mourn the passing of our esteemed member of the Board of Governors, beloved husband of Fay and loving father of Gail and Howard. May the bereaved family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob Reiner, Rabbi Stanley Liker, Mendy Bauman, Presidium Dr. Jorge Farber, Chairman of the Board, Yeshiva of Belle Harbor

title: Catherine Cookson, 91, Prolific British Author
description: Dame Catherine Cookson, a determined dockside waif who spun the dross of a squalid childhood into gold as one of Britain's most prolific and best-read novelists, died yesterday at her home in a Newcastle suburb. She was 91 and the author of more than 90 novels with a combined distribution of more than 100 million copies.

title: Residential Real Estate; West Side Co-op Converts to a Condo
description: Seeking to make apartments in their building more attractive to prospective purchasers and to ease their own monthly payments, shareholders in a nine-story co-op at 30 West 90th Street have converted the building to a condominium. The 47-unit building, which was converted from a rental to a co-op in 1985, is the first in New York City to switch from a co-op to a condominium form of ownership, according to real-estate lawyers.

title: No Timetable for Hundley
description: Before the Mets traded for Mike Piazza on May 22 and installed him as their No. 1 catcher, General Manager Steve Phillips was optimistic that Todd Hundley could return around or even before the All-Star Game break, July 6-8. As Hundley continues to rehabilitate from his elbow surgery in Port St. Lucie, Fla., however, Phillips refuses to set any kind of timetable for his return.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Wings of the Dove

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Steven Evans

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: David Goldes

title: In a Commencement Setting, Jarvis Joins St. John's
description: Alumni Hall was decorated for a special occasion, with carpeting and flowers adorning the basketball court. The decorations were for the commencement ceremony to come, but yesterday, in a small room just off the court, the festivities involved relieved St. John's officials and the new coach they hired to run the men's basketball program. After an exhausting search and drawn-out negotiations, St. John's introduced Mike Jarvis yesterday as its coach.

title: Weary of Gun Violence, Chicago Considers Suit
description: In the face of the persistent threat of gun violence, Mayor Richard M. Daley is considering filing a lawsuit against the makers, marketers and sellers as a way to stop the flow of illegal guns into the city.

title: Grand Jury Hears Critic of a Clinton Accuser
description: The Federal grand jury investigating the Lewinsky matter heard today from Julie Hiatt Steele, the former friend of Kathleen E. Willey, the woman who went on national television to accuse President Clinton of groping her in the Oval Office nearly five years ago.

title: New Chips Threaten Microsoft as Well as Intel
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINERFELD, JOSEPH B.
description: HINERFELD-Joseph B. Longtime resident of Pound Ridge, NY. Died June 10, 1998. Born in Scranton, PA March 8, 1902. He was the last of seven siblings. He will be missed by his nieces and nephews and many friends throughout the U.S.

title: Pataki Revisits Death Penalty, Seeking a Broader Law
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, who was elected four years ago after pledging to reinstate the death penalty, rekindled the issue today, introducing legislation intended to strengthen the capital punishment law that he signed after he took office.

title: Starr's Tactics Endanger Us All
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Spending Limit Is Rejected
description: In the first of what is likely to be a summer of votes on campaign finance, the House today by a vote of 345 to 29 rejected a proposed constitutional amendment that would have given Congress and the states authority to set campaign spending limits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSUKAMOTO, KOICHI
description: TSUKAMOTO - Koichi. Astute businessman and inborn connoisseur and scholar, Koichi Tsukamoto was not only Chairman of Wacoal, but President of the unequalled Kyoto Costume Institute. It was an honor to know and to have the privilege to work with a man of such greatness, one who understood in every way, commercially and intellectually, that clothing defines culture. Richard Martin The Metropolitant Museum of Art

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Workers at a Second Plant Go On Strike Against G.M.

title: Citing 'Constructive Engagement,' He Acts to Counter Critics in Congress : Clinton Widens Defense of China Visit
description: WASHINGTON  President Bill Clinton issued an impassioned defense of his policy of "constructive engagement" with China on Thursday, clearly hoping to prevent congressional criticism from overshadowing the first trip by a U.S. president to China in this decade.

title: Starr's Tactics Endanger Us All; Questions on Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Held in Standoff Is Also Accused of Rape
description: A 34-year-old man who barricaded himself in his apartment and then fired at the police during a 15-hour standoff Monday night had become violent because his uncle had questioned him about a sexual assault on a 13-year-old girl, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABAT, SARAH NEE SCHNEIDER
description: BABAT-Sarah nee Schneider. Passed away June 11th. Wife of the late Julius. Devoted mother of Arlene Jacoby, Dr. Chester (Doris) Babat, Norman (Ruth) Babat. Loving grandmother of Douglas and Karin Jacoby, Dr. Nina (Dr. Steven) Kessel, Jennifer Babat and Marc Babat. Services private.

title: Construction Workers Report Yellow Tongues
description: Fourteen construction workers who are renovating the Carl J. Olsen Water Treatment Plant have reported suffering from an unexplained ailment that led to nausea and dizziness and caused their tongues to turn yellow, Federal workplace safety officials said yesterday.

title: A Drama Built More on Character Than Dancing
description: Lar Lubovitch's ''Othello'' gives the ballet stage a whole new look. George Tsypin's sets for the three-act dance, performed by American Ballet Theater on Wednesday afternoon and evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, create a towering landscape of ornate cathedral and palace interiors and a dock with a huge, full-masted ship pulling in. Accomplished in part by projections and Pat Collins's dramatic lighting, the look is Broadway musical in an era of mobile chandeliers and helicopters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OROSZ, EDITH
description: OROSZ-Edith, 84. On June 2, 1998 in Coral Springs, FL. Beloved wife of the late Eugene Orosz, mother of Les & Ted, loving grandmother of Michael, Paul, Elizabeth, Brooke and Jeremy. Also survived by brothers Jack, Zalman and Paul Agran. Burial was June 4, 1998. She was a tireless fundraiser for Hadassah. Contributions can be made in her name to Kew Gardens Hadassah, 84-29 Lefferts Blvd, Kew Gardens, NY 11415.

title: The New Magic Show, and Something Blue (a Pup)
description: On Monday night, Jay Leno twitted Harrison Ford about not liking to appear on talk shows, trotted out a clip of the struggling young Ford on an episode of ''Ironside'' and (getting to the point) showed a scene from Mr. Ford's new movie, ''Six Days, Seven Nights.''

title: Sir David English, a Top Editor On Fleet Street, Is Dead at 67
description: Sir David English, widely considered one of Britain's most astute journalists, who transformed the struggling Daily Mail into a highly influential tabloid and redefined Fleet Street standards for editing and reporting, died Wednesday at St. Thomas's Hospital in London. He was 67 and had suffered a stroke the night before.

title: A Costly Sting in Mexico
description: In less than a month the Clinton Administration has shifted from boasting to backtracking about its big drug-money-laundering sting in Mexico. More than 150 suspected drug traffickers and their alleged banker confederates were arrested, but Washington, inexcusably, failed to obtain Mexico's approval for undercover operations carried out on Mexican soil. That failure has turned a law enforcement coup into a diplomatic fiasco, with the Administration now trying to repair the damage to drug enforcement efforts.

title: Court Invalidates Law Restricting Park to Residents of a New Jersey Borough
description: A State Superior Court judge in Paterson, N.J., ruled yesterday that an ordinance in a Passaic County borough that limits the use of a public park to residents was unconstitutional, a ruling that could affect other cases involving who can use public spaces.

title: Religious Right's Tactician on Wider Crusade
description: In his tidy corner office in this northern suburb of Atlanta, Ralph Reed sits atop a fault line.

title: Coaching Choices Down to Two
description: Long Island University apparently has whittled its search for a basketball coach to Miami of Ohio's Ray Martin and Rutgers's Rob Lanier, assistant coaches who have never been head coaches at the collegiate level. John Suarez, the athletic director, is expected to make a decision after the weekend.

title: A Discrepancy Over Retarded In Shelters
description: One week after 26 retarded adults were found to be living in homeless shelters and the state claimed that the problem was confined to Westchester County, a state legislator produced a list today that he said showed that 138 retarded adults statewide are living in shelters or are otherwise homeless.

title: Factory Chief Faces Charges Of Labor Abuse
description: Over the last two years, 100 Chinese immigrants toiling in a small garment factory in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn produced as many as 30,000 pieces of girls' sportswear a week for a Manhattan-based clothes manufacturer, workers said. They routinely logged 12-hour shifts, seven days a week, and in a handful of cases worked 24-hour shifts filling orders from the manufacturer, Street Beat Sportswear.

title: Gifts to Modern, For All to Share
description: For most of his 91 years, Philip Johnson has been an important figure at the Museum of Modern Art. He has been a member of its curatorial staff, the institution's official architect, and a trustee since 1957. He has also been a consistently generous donor, giving the museum seminal paintings, drawings and sculpture by modern masters like Andy Warhol, Jasper Johns, Franz Kline and Mark Rothko. Mr. Johnson has also contributed mightily to the Modern's design collection, adding furniture and objects by architects like Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Marcel Breuer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STONE, MARTIN
description: STONE-Martin. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, June 21 at 11 A.M., at The Northern Westchester Center for the Arts, 272 North Bedford Road, Mount Kisco, New York.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jorge Pardo

title: Prosperous Times, Except for the Young
description: I once wrote an article about a young drug dealer in New Haven. Afterward, he and I kept in touch. In the mid-1990's, when a police crackdown temporarily suppressed the New Haven drug trade, he told me, ''People are scared now, so they're just getting, like, jobs.'' His tone was pitying, appalled. Jobs were apparently only for the truly desperate.

title: Yeltsin Invites Milosevic for a Slav-to-Slav Talk
description: In an attempt to head off possible NATO military action in the Kosovo crisis, President Boris N. Yeltsin has invited President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia for talks in Moscow. The talks are scheduled for Monday or Tuesday.

title: Readying the Slingshot for a Modern Goliath
description: DAVID BOIES is the former Cravath, Swaine & Moore superstar trial lawyer in the cheap suits and stretch limousines who has defended some of the biggest legal game of the last 30 years: I.B.M. in its 13-year fight with the Government, CBS in the libel suit brought by Gen. William C. Westmoreland, and the nation's failed savings-and-loans against Michael R. Milken. Now he is the Government's chief lawyer in the snazziest antitrust lawsuit of the 1990's: United States v. Microsoft.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the awarding of punitive damages in a cigarette lawsuit misstated restrictions on such suits in some tobacco bills pending in Congress. Those bills would bar the awarding of punitive damages and class-action lawsuits. They would not bar all tobacco lawsuits.

title: Marlins Green Enough To Keep Mets Rolling
description: For four innings tonight, the story line was not only straightforward, it was also rather compelling. One day after Al Leiter had earned his seventh victory and demonstrated again why the Mets sent four minor leaguers to Florida for him during the off season, one of those minor leaguers showed the Mets why he was the main portion of the asking price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, EMANUEL G.
description: ROSENBLATT-Emanuel G. The Board of Trustees of Strang Cancer Prevention Center notes with sorrow the passing of its esteemed Trustee Emeritus, Emanuel G. Rosenblatt. Mr. Rosenblatt's long service and generous support will be remembered with respect and gratitude. Julian H. Robertson, Jr, Chairman Michael P. Osborne, MD, President/CEO Daniel G. Miller, MD, President-Emeritus

title: Sampson Criticizes Germany
description: Four days before his team's World Cup opener, Coach Steve Sampson criticized his German counterpart, Berti Vogts, for not respecting the Americans.

title: Trawler Is Held in Immigrant Smuggling
description: A fishing vessel registered in Venezuela has been impounded by the United States Coast Guard in connection with the smuggling of 23 Chinese men who landed on the shore of an affluent seaside town in New Jersey two weeks ago, Federal authorities said last night.

title: Paula Jones's Lawyers Begged Her to Settle
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones pleaded with her last summer not to reject a proposed settlement of her sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton, warning that she was risking ''devastation'' in pursuing a claim that would sully her reputation, ultimately fail and ''snatch defeat from the jaws of victory.''

title: Why Cole Porter, Born 107 Years Ago, Lives On
description: It usually takes a centennial for a Broadway composer to be accorded the kind of attention that was lavished on Cole Porter at Town Hall on Tuesday evening on the 107th anniversary of his birth. But to his most ardent fans, Porter, who died in 1964, wasn't just a great theater composer but a kindred spirit with special knowledge about the ecstasy and absurdity of romantic love. For those admirers, an annual consultation with the oracle is a required rite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMOWITZ, SYLVIA
description: SIMOWITZ-Sylvia. On June 10, 1998. Beloved Sister, Aunt, and Great Aunt. We will miss you. Florence & Jules Nestle & family

title: Boldon Feuding With Federation
description: Ato Boldon, the world 200-meter champion, feeling unappreciated by track and field officials in his native Trinidad and Tobago, said yesterday he planned to skip this summer's Commonwealth Games in Kuala Lampur, Malaysia, and the World Cup in Johannesburg, South Africa.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Drawing on Native America With a Modernist's Spirit
description: Composers often become fascinated by literary figures or musical traditions outside the classical mainstream, and when they do, they invariably find ways to work these interests into their compositions. Dvorak's and Bartok's use of folk music and David Del Tredici's string of works inspired by Lewis Carroll come immediately to mind.

title: Thanks, Boss, For All Your Help
description: TRY as he may, this benighted taxpayer cannot for the life of him figure out why New York City's leaders have let their budget -- our budget -- be taken hostage by George M. Steinbrenner 3d of Tampa, Fla.

title: A.I.G. Forms Alliance With Insurer in Taiwan
description: American International Group, the largest publicly held insurer in the United States, said it had formed an alliance with the Fubon Insurance Company, Taiwan's largest property and casualty insurer. A.I.G. already owns at least 1.8 percent of Fubon and operates one of Taiwan's largest life insurers, the Nan Shan Life Insurance Company. The Fubon alliance involves American International Underwriters, A.I.G.'s overseas property and casualty unit.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR WEAKENS AGAIN. Sugar fell 3.4 percent, to the lowest since November 1987, on new estimates of a record global crop this year. July contracts fell 0.26 cent, to 7.45 cents a pound. Sugar has fallen 39 percent since Jan. 1.

title: More Guns, More Chaos; Vigilante City
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Defeat Is Back To Haunt The Serbs
description: NATO's coming show of strength in Albania and Macedonia is clearly meant to represent its resolve to stop the Yugoslav crackdown on separatists in Kosovo. Then there is the military exercise's code name, announced today: ''Operation Determined Falcon.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DELPHI FINANCIAL GROUP INC., Wilmington, Del., agreed to buy Matrix Absence Management Inc., San Jose, Calif., a privately held company that provides disability services to employers, for a undisclosed combination of stock, cash and notes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAISEL, JOAN (NEE EPSTEIN
description: MAISEL-Joan (nee Epstein). Beloved wife and best friend of Howard. Devoted mother of Miriam, Jennifer, David and Lynn. Doting grandmother of Jessie. Dear sister of Herbert and Susan, Natalie and the late Sidney. So full of grace, so fair of face, she was our treasure and our life. She lit up every room she walked into with her radiant smile, her great warmth and her kindness. You will live on in our hearts forever. Funeral services on Sunday, June 14 at 12:30 PM, Boulevard-Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: Lengthening the Road To November 2000
description: The primary and caucus season for the Presidential election of 2000 is still the better part of 20 months away. But the gathering of a dozen Republican wannabes in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, this weekend for one of those hey-look-me-over affairs -- no straw poll, just speaking and schmoozing -- is proof positive that the race is well under way.

title: Sports of The Times; Americans About to Face A Field of Hard Knocks
description: CLAUDIO REYNA always thought you played soccer. His father had been a professional in Argentina and he is a professional in the United States, and soccer is, at its core, a game.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  INNISS, CHARLES E.
description: INNISS-Charles E. June 13, 1935January 30, 1997. Happy Birthday beloved husband, brother, uncle and friend. Remembering you on your Birthday, Marjorie.

title: Giuliani's Press Aide to Step Down
description: Colleen Roche, the press secretary to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, announced yesterday that she planned to resign but would remain for several months while she finds another job.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAC LEAN, SEAN
description: Mac Lean-Sean. 6/13/96. Love you and miss you. Your sister Monika

title: Advocates of School Vouchers Heartened by Ruling
description: Emboldened by a Wisconsin Supreme Court decision this week permitting the use of taxpayer money to pay religious school tuition, advocates for the use of school vouchers in the New York area say they believe they now have fresh ammunition to press their cause.

title: Recruiting Station to Get That Times Square Look
description: In keeping with the neon-infused rejuvenation of the area, the famous armed forces recruiting station at the crossroads of Times Square will be replaced with a flashier recruiting center just in time for New Year's Eve.

title: Caring for a Reborn Great Lawn; Keeper of the Park's Play Space Wants It Used Gently
description: One sunny morning earlier this week, a well-dressed couple stood on the edge of the newly restored Great Lawn in Central Park, the lush bluegrass tickling their ankles. They had rolled aside the four-foot-high fence to enter.

title: Lure of Bright Lights And Big, Barry-less City
description: The nation's capital is filled with former legislators who never went back home after retiring or being turned out of office. Seduced by the city's power, majesty and easy money in law and lobbying, many find it hard to return to the place they once represented.

title: World News Briefs; U.S. Endorses Treaty On Child Labor Abuses
description: Labor Secretary Alexis Herman gave the Clinton Administration's support this week to a proposed treaty to outlaw the most exploitative forms of child labor.

title: Bill to Speed Divorce Approved by Assembly
description: A bill that would allow married couples to cite irreconcilable differences as a reason for divorce passed the State Assembly on Thursday.

title: Beliefs
description: Criticism was quick in coming after the Southern Baptist Convention, at its annual meeting in Salt Lake City this week, added to the denomination's basic statement of beliefs a declaration that ''a wife is to submit herself graciously to the servant leadership of her husband.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, LESTER
description: SACKS-Lester. Of Clifton, NJ, on Friday, June 12, 1998. He was 82. Beloved husband of Anita (nee Weinstein). Devoted father of Gary of New York City & Dr. Ronald of Norwitch, New York. Loving father-in-law of Fannie. Loving grandfather of Ellie. Services will be held at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 66 Howe Avenue, Passaic, New Jersey, on Sunday at 11AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGER, VAN VECHTEN
description: BURGER-Van Vechten. Husband of the late Rosalie Evans Burger. Father of Beverly Alexandre, the late Evan Donaldson and Van Vechten Burger Jr. He also leaves nine grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held July 1 at Trinity St. John's Church, Hewlett, NY. Contributions may be sent to the Hill School, Pottstown, PA, Yale University or the Evan B. Donaldson Adoption Institute, NYC.

title: Glenn Is Ready to Say Goodbye to All That
description: Senator John Glenn, the merriest commuter on Capitol Hill, was talking of the spaceship he will soon be riding and the joy of weightlessness, which for him is rivaled by the delight of never again having to engage in political fund-raising, the bane of his earthly existence these past 24 years.

title: Divergent Views of Motive in Tarrytown Killings
description: During the four hours that Anthony Ambrosovich, a retired police officer, held 100 police officers at bay outside his home here, he tried to make a female officer understand why he would murder a wife he seemed to dote on and a daughter he seemed to love.

title: 3 Disciplined By Fire Dept. In Cafe Brawl
description: The Fire Department, frustrated in its investigation of a drunken brawl among its members at a midtown restaurant last week, fired one firefighter and suspended two others without pay yesterday because, investigators say, they were involved in or witnessed the fight and are telling less than they know.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''At a time when the Mayor is screaming and yelling about pork in city government and trying to cut city services that keep libraries and day care centers open, it seems bizarre to me that the city would be putting nearly $16 million into a rented space that the city doesn't even own.''

title: Dow Up 23.17 As Late Rally Salvages Prices
description: The stock market continued to cascade yesterday, falling sharply for the fourth consecutive session on renewed concerns about Asia's economic woes, before a rally late in the day pushed prices higher.

title: Poetic Journeys Through Life
description: One work in the American Chamber Opera's double bill at the Theater of the Riverside Church does much, if not everything, right. ''My Year, My Life,'' by Douglas Anderson, the company's executive director, was presumably tailor-made for the forces at hand, and it presents an English text with great clarity.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK GAINS. The mark rose on speculation that the I.M.F., which has lent Russia $670 million to pay urgent debts, would grant further aid to Germany's biggest trading partner. The dollar fell to 1.8056 marks from 1.8087.

title: Dozens Hurt on Wall St. In Electrical Fire
description: An electrical fire in the basement of a Wall Street office building late yesterday morning injured 16 firefighters and 28 civilians and clogged the streets of the financial district with emergency vehicles for hours, the authorities said.

title: Rutgers Dean Is Dismissed As $4 Million Gift Is Lost
description: In the brouhaha since the dismissal of the dean of the Rutgers Law School in Newark earlier this week, the central question has become: Who lost Bernard S. Yudowitz and his promise of a $4 million donation?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, BEATRICE, M.D. (NEE SCHNUR
description: SLATER-Beatrice, M.D. (nee Schnur). Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Nurturing mother of Judith Geller and David. Loving and energetic grandmother of Debby Cuneo, Susan Lockwood and B.J. Funeral service Sunday 12:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers please make donations to Hadassah, 50 West 58 Street, NYC. Shiva will be at 351 W.24th St. NYC, Sunday, Monday and Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINSETH, MIRIAM B.
description: FEINSETH-Miriam B. Passed away on June 11, 1998. Beloved mother of Debra Bodner and Ivan Feinseth, sister of Seymour Betman and mother-in-law of Andy Bodner. Director of Advertising and Communications for Hunter Douglas and a longtime member of the International Furnishings and Design Association, Miriam resided in Fort Lee, N.J. She was a congregant of the Fort Lee Jewish Community Center. Services to be held Sunday, June 14th at 1 PM. Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Ave., Maplewood, N.J. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the American Cancer Society or the Hackensack Hospice Program in Hackensack, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, BETTY P.
description: SIMON-Betty P., 82. Of Westchester. Formerly of NYC. Wife of the late Hubert K. Simon. Mother of Molly Katz of Westport, CT; Steven C. Simon of CA. Brother of Charles Chuckrow of CA. Grandmother of four and great-grandmother of one. Services Sunday 2 PM in the Harding Funeral Home, 210 Post Road East, Wesport, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to Domestic Violence Crisis Center, 5 Eversley Avenue, Norwalk, CT. 06851.

title: Armed Gang Raids Perfume Scion's Home : Robbers Shoot Guerlain
description: PARIS  Jean-Paul Guerlain, one of the most celebrated "noses" in the French perfume industry and a scion of the famous fragrance family, was wounded during a robbery early Friday after an armed invasion of his home.

title: Mayor Ignores Council Over Property Tax
description: The Giuliani administration announced yesterday that it was ignoring property tax rates set by the City Council this week, and had begun sending bills to the city's 900,000 property owners at the old rate.

title: As G.M. Idles Plants, Talks Make Progress
description: Strikes at two General Motors parts factories forced the auto maker to close some of its most profitable assembly plants today, increasing the number of temporarily laid-off workers to 50,900. But tensions started to ease in the dispute as negotiators began making slow progress.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOHN, NAOMI
description: SOHN-Naomi. Your loss has left a tremendous void in my life. I need you, I miss you, I love you, I'll never forget you. Rest in peace on your birthday. Aunt Carol

title: Burton's Pontiac Wins the Pole
description: Ward Burton turned a lap of 39.656 seconds as he drove his Pontiac to the front of the field at Michigan Speedway yesterday, winning the pole for tomorrow's Miller Lite 400 in Brooklyn, Mich., with a one-lap speed of 181.611 miles an hour.

title: No Escaping Motherhood on Campaign Trail
description: Even in the friendly crowd at an afternoon coffee, where three generations of women were gathered around a silver punch bowl, talking politics in between bites of ham roll, the Senate candidate Blanche Lambert Lincoln heard the usual question: ''Do you see hubby and the babies at all?''

title: Journal; Class Of '98
description: The last term of high school, as I remember it from the first time around, is one steady flooring of the accelerator pedal. Grades don't count, exams don't count, the college that's accepted you can't change its mind.

title: Malone Puts Celebration of Dynasty on Ice
description: Karl Malone squared up on the left baseline, peeked over Dennis Rodman and released one of those career-defining shots with 53.3 seconds left. Until that moment tonight in Game 5, his torturous experience in the N.B.A. finals -- every misfire, loose rebound and lost game -- was magnified and standing in the 12 feet between him and the rim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBBS, DR. STANLEY L.
description: GIBBS-Dr. Stanley L. On June 11, 1998 of Glen Cove, Long Island. Beloved husband of Emily. Devoted father of Dr. Alan and Wendy, Dr. Eric and Sabrina, and Betsy. title: Merger Speculation Lifts Shares of SmithKline
description: Shares in SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. jumped yesterday as speculation gathered speed about a revival of merger talks with its pharmaceutical rival, Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. SmithKline's American depository receipts rose $2.25, to $60.875.

title: Cost of Hotel Rooms Soars in Manhattan
description: The hotel market in Manhattan, the most expensive in the country and coming off a record year in 1997, grew even more costly in this year's first quarter, with the average price of a night's stay creeping closer to $200. The market has become so expensive that in the last 18 months, five hotels -- the Lowell, the St. Regis and the Carlyle, as well as the Pierre and the Four Seasons --began charging an average daily rate of $500.

title: Vice Principal Gets Jail Term For Operating Slot Machines
description: The vice principal of a Brooklyn middle school who amassed $2.5 million from a network of illegal Joker Poker gambling machines in poor neighborhoods that he obsessively tended for 10 years was sentenced in Federal court yesterday to 15 months in prison.

title: Beginning With Chickens and Ending With Eggs
description: That husky warble, those hairy legs! He absolutely is Lady Bracknell.

title: Manhattan Hotel Rates Head for the Sky
description: Looking for a hotel room in Manhattan? You have plenty of options.

title: Sentence Is 3 Life Terms For Killing Rampage
description: A 33-year-old maintenance worker who murdered his former girlfriend, best friend and mother within six hours in 1995 was sentenced yesterday to three consecutive life terms in prison, prosecutors said.

title: Beating Defendant Vows To Go Without Lawyer
description: Rejecting a judge's offer to provide him a court-appointed lawyer, Austin Offen said yesterday that he would defend himself in his retrial on charges that he attempted to murder a Long Island man during a racially charged brawl outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub two years ago.

title: Lois Mailou Jones, 92, Painter and Teacher
description: Lois Mailou Jones, an American painter and an art teacher for almost a half century at Howard University in Washington, died at her home in Washington on Tuesday. She was 92.

title: Moscow Jobs Beckon, but Let the Migrant Beware
description: After working five weeks as an illegal laborer on a Moscow construction site, Ivan, a Ukrainian crane operator, was heading home to Kiev last October with his hard-earned wages carefully hidden where the Moscow police could not find them.

title: Mexican Shootout Leaves Bullet Holes and Bitterness
description: The stucco walls of the two-room schoolhouse are gouged with hundreds of bullet holes and stained with patterns of dried blood: a handprint that slides downward, a broad wash that spills into a thick puddle on the floor.

title: Venturing Out To the Limits Of Partnering
description: Peter Martins has had a long fascination with ballet partnering. In his ''River of Light,'' presented by the New York City Ballet in its world premiere on Thursday night at the New York State Theater, Mr. Martins continues his exploration of what partnering can mean in ballet of the late 20th century.

title: Key Industrial Countries Demand Serbs Halt Offensive in Kosovo
description: Reinforcing the NATO alliance's threat of military action to stop the violence in Kosovo, the United States, Russia and six other major industrial democracies meeting here today demanded a halt to Serbian attacks on ethnic Albanian civilians in the province.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Old Drugs, New Labels; Brand Name Generics and Other Linguistic Anomalies
description: What's in a name? Increasingly for makers of generic drugs, everything -- a seemingly odd state of affairs for an industry whose stock in trade is cheap no-name knockoffs of brands that have lost their patents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOWSHOWITZ, LIBBY (NEE POLACHEK
description: MOWSHOWITZ-Libby (nee Polachek), of Jamaica, N.Y. Passed away June 11, 1998. Widow of the eminent Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz; daughter of Rabbi Solomon Polachek, renowned head of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Rabbinical Academy of Yeshiva University (''the Meitchiter Illui''); sister to Dr. Harry Polachek of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. and Dr. Abraham Polachek of Jerusalem; mother of Sylvia Orenstein (wife of Rabbi Jehiel Orenstein) of South Orange, N.J. and Dr. Solomon Mowshowitz (husband of Dr. Deborah Mowshowitz, of New York, N.Y.; grandmother of Aviva Orenstein, Dr. Raphael Orenstein (husband of Dr. Susan Orenstein), Rabbi Debra Orenstein, Zvi Mowshowitz and Avi Mowshowitz; great-grandmother of Michael, David and Benjamin Greenberg and Elliot Orenstein. Funeral services are to be held at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills, New York, on Sunday, June 14 at 12 noon. May her soul be bound up in the Bond of Life.

title: Bronx Politics Is Complicated As Politician Pledges to Run
description: Two weeks after he dropped out of the State Senate race in the Bronx, Pedro Espada Jr. said yesterday that he had changed his mind and would run in the Democratic primary to regain the seat he once held.

title: Youths' 'Tainted' Testimony Is Barred in Day Care Retrial
description: Handing a major victory to the defense in one of the country's longest-running day-care sexual abuse cases, a Massachusetts judge ruled today that the children in the case had been so manipulated in interviews with investigators that their testimony was ''forever tainted.''

title: CITRIX SYSTEMS IN ACCORD TO ACQUIRE ALL APM SHARES
description: Citrix Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire all outstanding shares of the privately held APM Ltd., based in Cambridge, England, in a cash transaction valued at about $40 million. Citrix said it expected to record a charge for in-process research and development of about $33 million related to the acquisition, which is expected to close by the end of June. Both companies' boards have approved the acquisition and more than 50 percent of Citrix shareholders have agreed to accept the offer. APM Ltd. is a Java consulting company. Citrix makes network products that enable desktop computers to operate from software installed on a central server.

title: Lurching Into Comedy With a Heart Attack
description: If you thought the Asian economy was bad, try assessing the state of film comedy on the basis of ''Dirty Work.'' Phrases like terminally stupid and brain dead leap readily to mind.

description: DRANGEL-Mildred. Beloved sister of Irwin, cherished aunt of Sheryl and Chip Kaye, and of Jason and Jessica, devoted greataunt of Nicole and Tyler. Services Sunday 11:15AM at The Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUDOFF, LEON
description: YUDOFF-Leon. Age 95. Passed away peacefully in his home in North Miami Beach, Florida on Thursday, June 11, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Anna Yudoff. Cherished father of Zena Wiener and Paul Yudoff. Adored grandfather of Jenny and Gabe Wiener and David and Jason Yudoff. He emigrated to this country in 1923 and was deeply grateful to be an American citizen. Leon devoted his life not only to his family and friends, but to the many passions he held so dear: his heritage, the United Jewish Appeal, the State of Israel, music and the arts. His love of life and great wisdom will live on forever in those fortunate enough to have known him. Funeral services Sunday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Beating a Dead Mule, Partly in Fun
description: They die from asphyxiation, rabies, drowning and falling off cliffs. They are hit by trains, worked to death, hanged, stabbed, shot and, in one Cormac McCarthy novel, decapitated by an irate opera singer.

title: Seizure of Ship Helps Officials Trace Route of Illegal Immigrants
description: With the seizure of a freighter that is suspected of smuggling Asian immigrants into the Bahamas this week, Federal officials said they were beginning to piece together the circuitous journey of 23 Chinese men who illegally landed on a New Jersey beach two weeks ago.

title: John Nassikas, 81, Who Led Deregulation of Natural Gas
description: John N. Nassikas, who as the chairman of the Federal Power Commission from 1969 to 1975 began deregulation of the natural gas industry and the shift away from using natural gas to generate electricity, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 81.

title: DAVEL COMMUNICATIONS TO ADD PHONETEL TECHNOLOGIES
description: Davel Communications Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Phonetel Technologies Inc., a competing operator of pay telephones, for $49.3 million in stock. Davel, based in Tampa, Fla., operates 40,000 pay telephones in 36 states. Phonetel, with headquarters in Cleveland, operates 45,000 pay phones in 42 states. Under the agreement, Phonetel shareholders will receive $3.08 in Davel stock for each of the 16 million Phonetel shares outstanding. The shares of Phonetel rose 62.5 cents, or 33 percent, to $2.50. Davel said the combination of the companies would result in significant cost savings from lower line and transmission costs, lower field operating costs and elimination of redundant general and administrative expenses.

title: SEAGRAM AIMS TO RAISE $3.6 BILLION IN TROPICANA SALE
description: The Seagram Company filed yesterday to sell its entire Tropicana juice business to the public, raising as much as $3.6 billion to help finance Seagram's expansion of its music operations. A Seagram unit will sell 95.1 percent of the common stock in Tropicana Products Inc. through an initial public offering, according to a registration statement filed with the S.E.C. The unit will sell the other 4.9 percent if underwriters need additional shares to meet excess orders. Seagram announced on May 21 that it would sell Tropicana. The announcement came at the same time Seagram said it would acquire Polygram N.V. from Royal Philips Electronics N.V. Seagram is paying $10.6 billion in cash and stock for Polygram, one of the world's largest music companies.

title: Opposition Rally in Nigeria Is Answered With Tear Gas
description: In the first showdown between Nigeria's new military leadership and promoters of democracy, hundreds of protesters braved a powerful deployment of the police and soldiers in Lagos today to mount a demonstration at a downtown market.

title: Sports of The Times; It's As Much Pippen's Fight As Jordan's
description: A YEAR ago on a Friday night with a familiar feel, Scottie Pippen stole the ball, secured title No. 5 and was acknowledged by Michael Jordan in a poignant most valuable player moment.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Weekend yesterday about the Songwriters' Hall of Fame induction ceremony misstated the honor given to Paul Simon. He received the Johnny Mercer Award; he was already in the Hall of Fame.

title: Surplus of Starters Puts Mendoza in Bullpen
description: Rain washed out the scheduled game between the Yankees and the Cleveland Indians last night at Yankee Stadium, but it could not mute the machinations of a team trying not to lose a step in its march to become the biggest winner in baseball history.

title: The City That Always Sleeps
description: When a mature horse lies down in a pasture to sleep, you know that it is comfortable in its surroundings. The same is true when a New Yorker dozes in public -- on one of the green chairs in Bryant Park, on the steps of the Met, on a hillock in Central Park, or anywhere else, for that matter. Some New Yorkers manage to nod off discreetly, almost warily, at lunchtime in the open air, as though they had just tipped their heads back to get some sun on the wattles. Others sleep with rhetorical abandon -- with a budget of gurgles and starts and impromptu ratchetings from the throat. But discreet and indiscreet alike have managed to let down their guard, to rely, something like a horse, on the attention of the herd that surrounds them.

title: Leo Buscaglia, TV Advocate Of Love's Power, Dies at 74
description: Leo Buscaglia, the bearded self-help author and cuddly television guru who preached love with such single-minded fervor that he seemed unable to stop until he had hugged everyone in sight, died yesterday at his home in Lake Tahoe, Nev. He was 74 and known variously as Dr. Love, the Love Merchant and the Hug Doctor.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: About New York; Boys Into Men As Death Hits Class of 1998
description: ABOVE the bronze entrance doors of a gracefully curved Art Deco building on the Grand Concourse are the words ''Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School for Boys.'' They are a reminder that although the students graduate as Hayesmen, a group as proud and persistent as the Marines, they enter as children.

title: THOMAS H. LEE BUYOUT FIRM IS ADDING 30% OF COTT
description: The buyout firm Thomas H. Lee Company agreed yesterday to acquire a 30 percent interest in the Cott Corporation, a Canadian soft-drink maker, for $110 million. Lee, based in Boston, is a private equity firm. Cott, based in Toronto, supplies private-label soft drinks to retailers. Lee will buy 10 million Cott shares from the Pencer family for $70 million. It will also receive an option to buy 5 million additional Cott shares in the next four years. Lee will also purchase $40 million of convertible preferred Cott shares from the company.

title: Producer Prices Rose in May Because of Higher Drug Costs
description: Prices paid to producers rose during May for the second consecutive month, but the increase reflected record growth in the cost of prescription drugs, and analysts continued to forecast a low inflation rate for the year.

title: TELESPECTRUM WORLDWIDE TO PURCHASE CRW FINANCIAL
description: Telespectrum Worldwide Inc., a telemarketing and customer-service company, said yesteday that it planned to buy CRW Financial Inc., which provides cash to casino customers through wire transfers and credit-card advances, for about $39 million in stock. CRW is Telespectrum's largest shareholder, with a 28 percent stake. The agreement values CRW at $6.03 a share. CRW shares rose 62.5 cents, to $5.625, in Nasdaq trading, and Telespectrum rose 12.5 cents, to $8.625. Under a nonbinding agreement, Telespectrum would issue 0.709 share for each share of CRW. Telespectrum expects to issue about 4.6 million shares for the transaction. Both companies are based in King of Prussia, Pa.

title: Rejuvenated French Loom As a Threat
description: Though the French were the driving force behind the creation of soccer's World Cup, they have never managed to reach the final of the event that Jules Rimet and Henri Delaunay helped to launch in 1930.

title: Endgame in Albany
description: The pre-election stupor that has afflicted New York's State Legislature in recent months now means that Albany has only a few days left to wrestle with some of the most crucial issues on this year's agenda. Here is an abbreviated list of important matters that need immediate attention.

title: BCE OF CANADA SELLS 14.25% BRITISH CABLE STAKE
description: BCE Inc., the Canadian telecommunications company, said yesterday that it had sold its 14.25 percent stake in Cable and Wireless Communications P.L.C. of Britain for $:975.2 million ($1.59 billion), in a move to exit the British cable television industry. BCI Telecom Holding Inc., a BCE unit, said last month that it planned to sell its 212-million-share stake in Cable and Wireless and use the proceeds to pay down debt. Cable and Wireless is majority owned by the British telecommunications company Cable and Wireless P.L.C., which has said it may raise its 53 percent stake in the company.

title: Silver Charm Comes Back as Heavy Favorite
description: One week after the Triple Crown series ended in a classic finish in the Belmont Stakes, older horses will follow the 3-year-olds into the spotlight today: Silver Charm returns to action at Churchill Downs in the $750,000 Stephen Foster Handicap, and Ordway and Behrens are among a field of 13 in the $300,000 Brooklyn Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: Pakistani Rebuff for India, But Talks May Be Closer
description: An Indian proposal for talks with Pakistan later this month on ways of lessening tensions in the subcontinent was quickly rejected by Pakistan today, but the exchange appeared to have moved both Governments closer to direct negotiations over the crisis set off by the nuclear tests that both conducted last month.

title: Americans Take Top Scores In 13th Worldwide Contest
description: Players from the United States won most of the honors in the 13th Worldwide Bridge Contest a week ago. The World Bridge Federation reported that the best score in the world was achieved by Ray Bohne of Monterey, Calif., and James Coventry of Salinas, Calif.
