title: Intel Inside . . . Target Range
description: With its antitrust lawsuit against Intel, the maker of chips for nearly all personal computers, the Clinton Administration took another step this week to enforce old rules in a new arena. Like the Justice Department's suit against Microsoft last month, the Federal Trade Commission's action challenges Intel's conduct as a monopoly in a fast-changing business. In both cases, the Government argues correctly that the law prevents a monopoly from using its dominant position to muscle competitors, even when competitors are also customers. But whereas the Microsoft suit could reshape the computing industry, the Intel suit seeks a modest outcome unlikely to hurt the company or transform the industry.

title: Einstein and the Spy
description: To the Editor:

title: Reluctant Threat: West's Kosovo Policy Hinges on the Use of Force
description: The United States and its allies remain reluctant to use force against the Yugoslav Army, despite NATO's decision on Thursday to put on a display of air power in countries bordering the Serbian province of Kosovo, officials of the United States and other NATO member-nations said today.

title: ADVANCED TISSUE SCIENCES' SHARES PLUMMET BY 44%
description: The shares of Advanced Tissue Sciences Inc. fell 44 percent yesterday after regulators ordered the company to conduct a new clinical trial before granting approval of its new Dermagraft skin-replacement product. Advanced Tissue shares fell $3.125, to $3.9375, in Nasdaq trading of 7.4 million shares. Dermagraft is Advanced Tissue's bid to enter the growing wound-healing market, which analysts estimate could reach $1 billion. Advanced Tissue must now apply again for United States Food and Drug Administration approval to use Dermagraft to treat diabetic foot ulcers, a process that could take two years.

title: Korean Stocks Tumble 8.1% In Recond One-Day Plunge
description: Investors stampeded out of the Korean stock market today, sending it back to the 11-year lows hit last month when worries about the pace of economic changes and labor unrest hurt share prices.

title: Hundley's Overture Puts Mets in a Squeeze Play
description: Todd Hundley, whose return date from elbow surgery is still uncertain and whose future with the Mets is equally unclear, has informed the team that he wants a no-trade clause if he is going to prepare to do anything but catch this season.

title: How to Make Government Comprehensible
description: The drive announced last week by Vice President Al Gore to make ''plain language'' the rule in the Federal Government is well intentioned but toothless.

description: Hammond Innes, the author of ''The Wreck of the Mary Deare'' and more than 30 other novels of adventure and suspense, died on Wednesday in Kersey, England. He was 84.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the possible health risks of olestra, the new fat substitute, referred incompletely to the position of a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee. While it appears that olestra will remain on the market, Dr. Alan Rulis, director of the office of premarket approval in the Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition, said in an interview: ''I don't want to prejudge the issue. It is far from settled, but we have not seen real documented consensus agreement about the benefits of carotenoids. The regulatory status of olestra will be status quo.''

title: City's Plans for Governors I. Include Housing and Casino
description: The Giuliani administration plans to release two reports next week sketching out redevelopment proposals for Governors Island, including housing, schools, parks, a new hotel -- and a casino that would provide millions of dollars to finance the plan.

title: Jazz Stays Alive
description: The Utah Jazz stunned Michael Jordan, the Bulls and the rest of the basketball world with an 83-81 victory in Chicago in Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals last night, preventing Chicago from capturing its sixth championship in the last eight years. The Bulls still lead the series, 3 games to 2. Game 6 will be played tomorrow night in Salt Lake City.

title: U.S. Triple Damage Claim Against City and State Is Ruled Out
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the United States Government may not sue the city or state under a special whistleblower law in which it was seeking to recover triple damages for money that the Government said was fraudulently obtained for foster care.

title: G.O.P., Its Eyes On High Court, Blocks a Judge
description: Judge Sonia Sotomayor seemed like a trouble-free choice when President Clinton nominated her to an appeals court post a year ago. Hers was an appealing story: a child from the Bronx housing projects who went on to graduate summa cum laude from Princeton and become editor of the Yale Law Journal and then a Federal prosecutor.

description: More G.M. Plants Are Idled

title: Reports Show Chinese Military Used American-Made Satellites
description: For the past two years, China's military has relied on American-made satellites sold for civilian purposes to transmit messages to its far-flung army garrisons, according to highly classified intelligence reports.

title: It Takes 2 to Merge but One Firm to Give Advice
description: In the cozy world of corporate finance, bankers and lawyers are finding themselves straddling both sides of merger negotiations these days in what some critics say is a risky move for companies and their shareholders.

title: Goldman Partners Meet on Firm's Future
description: The partners of Goldman, Sachs & Company met at a suburban New York conference center yesterday to consider a proposal to turn the firm, Wall Street's last major private partnership, into a public company.

title: A Life Marked by Troubles, but Not by Hatred
description: From the shade of his porch across the street, Grover Thomas could watch the steady stream of people, black and white, bearing casseroles and baked chicken and other peace offerings today to the family of James Byrd Jr., who was killed this week in one of the South's most grotesque racial murders in many years.

title: World News Briefs; Volkswagen Faces Suit Over Jewish Slave Labor
description: A week after it bought Rolls-Royce, and just as it adds Lamborghini sports cars to its automotive stable, Volkswagen is facing a lawsuit seeking payment of wages to Jewish slave laborers forced to work for the company during World War II.

title: Preparing for Worst, Giuliani Is to Build Blastproof Shelter
description: Having tamed squeegee men and cabbies, murderers and muggers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is now bracing for a whole other order of urban treachery and cataclysm by building a $15.1 million emergency control center for his administration -- bulletproofed, hardened to withstand bombs and hurricanes and equipped with food and beds for at least 30 members of his inner circle.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEEDS, MORTON
description: LEEDS-Morton. June 13, 1984. ''...to reach the port of heaven, we must sail sometimes with the wind and sometimes against it, but we must sail, and not drift, nor lie at anchor''.

title: Radio Quiz Rewards Its Erudite Listeners
description: There are not many places where you can win a gift set of Torah cards or a teeth cleaning just for knowing a few things about Benjamin Franklin. ''Good Question,'' a new call-in radio quiz program on historical figures, is just such a place.

title: The Libraries: Another Kind Of War Victim
description: ''What is more important in a library than anything else -- than everything else -- is the fact that it exists,'' wrote Archibald MacLeish, the poet and a former Librarian of Congress. But across Bosnia-Herzegovina, ethnic nationalists twisted this injunction by bombing and burning libraries, archives and other cultural institutions during the recent war there in an effort to erase records of the common heritage that Muslim, Serbian and Croatian cultures have shared since the 16th century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGELFANGER, NETTIE
description: VOGELFANGER-Nettie. On June 11, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Salomon, loving mother of Martin & Ruby, Elliot and Roz of Houston, Texas. Cherished grandmother of Nina and Arnold Lehman, Naomi and Marshall Jaffe, Tamar and Trevor Morris and Jules Vogel. Great-grandmother of Jonathan, Ellen, Carolyn, Stephen, Richard, Gregory, Henry and Phillip. Service on Sunday at 12:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Budget Is Cut for a Plan to Put Schools and Libraries On Line
description: The Federal Communications Commission decided yesterday to reduce by more than 40 percent the budget of a plan to connect schools and libraries to the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDEN, GLORIA
description: HARDEN-Gloria. Of New York City and Chestertown, MD. Died June 10, 1998. Born in Little Rock, AK, she was an honors graduate of Little Rock High School, Little Rock Junior College, and Marymount College in Manhattan. She was Vice President at Chase Manhattan Bank, serving on the Chairman's Executive Staff. Later she founded and then was President of Alliance Management Systems in New York City. She is survived by her sisters, Elizabeth Noblitt, Dorothy Lewis, and Carra Harden, nieces and nephews, and was preceded in death by her sister Amy Vidnovic and parents Ernest and Ruth Harden. Memorial Service, Saturday at 2PM at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28 St., New York City. She will be buried in Little Rock on Monday.

title: Woman's Body Is Found In Attic of Church
description: A worker fixing a leaky roof discovered a woman's decomposed body yesterday afternoon in the attic of a church on East 29th Street in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Our Towns column on Thursday misstated the title of a song recorded by the singer Jimmy Roselli. It is ''Mala Femmina.'' (''Bad Woman'' is the translation.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAFORGIA, FELICE, DR.
description: LAFORGIA-Felice, Dr. On May 29, 1998, in Naples, Italy. Beloved husband of the late Michela (nee Coppola). Beloved father of Vincenza, Elena & Guiseppe. Loving son of the late Cav. Joseph and the late Vincenza. Cherished brother of Frank & Marie Antonia Connolly. Devoted grandfather of five. Dear father-in-law of Fulvio Conte & Dr. Luigi Irace. Cherished brother-in-law of Josephine and Jim. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Memorial Mass will be held on June 29th at 8PM at St. Dominic's RC Church, 2001 Bay Ridge Pkwy. Interment was in Toritto Bari, Italy.

title: Foreign Affairs; Trash The I.M.F.!
description: Recently several prominent former officials and economists have called for abolishing the International Monetary Fund. Congress is also holding back its next deposit to the fund, $18 billion, because a Republican Congressman, Chris Smith, won't allow the U.S. contribution to be made unless the Clinton Administration drops support for any worldwide family-planning program that includes abortions. Since all these smart people seem to think the world doesn't need the I.M.F., I say junk the place. Here's what the world would look like a year later.

title: In Age of Scandal, Reporters Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japanese Economy Weaker Than Believed, Data Show

title: Talking, Not Shouting, About Race
description: Tomorrow will be the first anniversary of President Clinton's announcement of a national Initiative on Race. When the President chose me and the other members of the advisory board a year ago, I was struck not only by how enormous our task was, but also by its historic implications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERRY, ELENA HOWELL
description: TERRY-Elena Howell. Of Castine, ME, and Kennett Square, PA, died June 6, 1998 at York Hospital in Maine of a stroke. She was born January 18, 1914 in NYC to Helen A. Littell and Thomas A. Howell, Jr. and is a direct descendant of one of the founding families of South Hampton, LI, NY. A graduate of Miss Porter's School and Temple University School of Horticulture, she was an active member in the Garden Club of America, a National Chairman of its Horticultural Committee and a judge at the Philadelphia Flower Show. She was married to Wyllys Terry Jr. and is survived by her sons, Wyllys Terry III of Wayland, MA, James T. Terry II, Cambridge, MD, and Michael H. Terry, Fort Lauderdale, FL. Grandchildren Wyllys Chip Terry, Cambridge, MA, Lyon Terry, Seattle, WA, and Tiffany Terry, San Francisco, CA, and sister Elizabeth L. Childs, York Harbor, ME. Memorials to Miss Porter's School, Farmington, CT, or Bagaduce Ambulance Corp, P.O. Box 522, Castine, ME, 04421.

title: WORLD CUP: ROUNDUP
description: Paraguay 0, Bulgaria 0

title: New Slant On the 60's: The Past Made New; Experts Are Reassessing a Tumultuous Decade
description: Here's the wallet-size version of the sixties:

title: Lewinsky Inquiry Is Said to Focus on Clinton Aide's Talks With Potential Witnesses
description: Prosecutors looking into President Clinton's relationship with a former White House intern are investigating contacts between one of his senior aides and potential witnesses shortly after the investigation began, according to lawyers who have read a sealed legal opinion describing the contacts.

title: Again, New Hampshire Daunts the Democrats
description: New Hampshire can be a tough place for Democrats, given that they have long been outnumbered there by Republicans. Yet back in 1996, by aggressively raising money and recruiting strong candidates, the party had an unusually good run, helping President Clinton to a solid victory, electing Jeanne Shaheen as Governor and giving a scare to the Republican incumbents in all three Congressional contests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NARINS, FRANCES KROSS
description: NARINS-Frances Kross. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Frances Kross Narins and extends its heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. David L. Rudnick, President Robert S. Puder, Secretary

title: Insuring, Not Investing
description: To the Editor:

title: One Title Dimmed, Another Anticipated
description: Detroit and its Red Wings waited 42 years to celebrate, but their party lasted only six days. It ended with a terrifying limousine crash one year ago -- on Friday, June 13 -- that left two men with serious brain damage.

title: Judge's Excerpt From Interview
description: Judge Isaac Borenstein read the following excerpt from an interview to show how insistent investigators were with children in the Fells Acres case. His excerpt began with a girl saying, ''They did not take my picture.''

title: Carr Changes Role From Sub to Savior
description: Antoine Carr stood before a flood of camera lights in a pair of sunglasses that had wide camouflage-coated plastic rims. And yet, tonight was the first time Carr had been visible in these National Basketball Association finals.

title: Interleague Attendance Down
description: Last season, the first for interleague play, attendance was 21 percent greater than for other games. The increase for the first phase of interleague games this season was 15 percent.

title: Samsung to Cut Output At Korean Chip Plants
description: The Samsung Electronics Company, the world's largest memory-chip manufacturer, said yesterday that its Korean plants would probably shut down for a week next month in addition to a week already set for this month. The cut in production is intended to increase the price of the company's mainstay 16-megabit dynamic random access memory chips.

title: Lauca Ene Journal; A Bolivian Legislator Who Just Says 'Yes' to Coca
description: Like congressmen all over the world, Evo Morales hugs babies and makes fist-thumping speeches. But that's where the similarities end. For starters, this Congressman chews coca leaves in public.

title: From Stylist to Socialite; Hairdressers and makeup artists as social darlings, invited everywhere. (Off duty, of course.)
description: STEVEN DILLON, a hairstylist at the high-end Brad Johns salon on Fifth Avenue, who tends to the manes of Natasha Richardson and young society swans like Carolina Herrera Jr., has found himself at the center of a social whirl.

title: Longo Turns Into Lone Rider of France
description: Many people in cycling think Jeannie Longo is the best female bicycle rider ever. But not many like her. They say Longo is self-centered and selfish, anti-establishment, anti-everything and anti-everyone.

title: Jordan Seeking Relaxation
description: Michael Jordan recalled being one of the last players to board the team plane in 1993. The Chicago Bulls were off to Phoenix for a Game 6 they had not envisioned after failing to clinch their third straight title at home.

title: Assault Rifles: Dirt Cheap. . .and Legal!
description: As a police officer who can buy almost any type of weapon, even I have to fill out the notorious A.T.F. form 4473 when I show proper identification, like my police ID and driver's license (''Assault Rifles: Dirt Cheap. . .and Legal!'' by David C. Anderson, May 24). As for purchases from private collections, this is a new one on me. You cannot sell to another person without going through a licensed dealer. I have been attending gun shows in New York State for more than 10 years and have yet to see anyone buy what the ''gun grabbers'' call an ''assault rifle.''

title: Attachment Theory: The Ultimate Experiment
description: Twice in the article Talbot makes unsupported accusations against feminists. When she says, ''Feminists have long criticized attachment theory as a sentimental scheme for shooing mothers back home,'' I would like to know who are these feminists, exactly? And when she writes, ''From . . .some feminists, you hear the steely insistence that child care is just fine for every child, thank you very much, and don't go singing the praises of maternal love like some besotted Irish tenor,'' I am positively offended.

title: Defeat Deferred, but Jazz Isn't Smiling Yet
description: Sometimes the crust on America's apple pie team gets hard. For all the Utah Jazz players' square appeal, they have a crotchety side that pops up from time to time.

title: Emily Hall, James Miller
description: Emily Bancroft Hall, a daughter of Dr. Cynthia S. Rankin of Lower Waterford, Vt., and John L. Hall 2d of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to James Scott Miller, a son of Robin A. Cohen of Saratoga, Calif., and the late Glenn E. Miller. The Rev. Roddy O'Neil Cleary, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Old Round Church in Richmond, Vt.

title: She'll Always Have Dublin
description: IT was Bloomsday, 1970. Dublin was minding its own business, apparently unconcerned that June 16 was a high holy day to Joyce scholars. So I was alone for most of the day, rarely encountering other fanatical readers of James Joyce. I carried my well-worn copy of ''Ulysses,'' which I had already read at least three times in my young life, and a map of Dublin.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; It's No Way to Finance Elections
description: The Suffolk County Legislature's call for a referendum [to be put on the ballot in November] seeking a property tax check-off to finance elections for county office is a feeble attempt at local election finance reform and has all the markings of leaving the foxes in charge of the chicken coop. There is nothing wrong with asking for voters' approval before lawmakers can put their hands in taxpayers' pockets, but it smacks of disengenuousness to disguise this effort as real election finance reform.

title: The Big City; Two-Bedroom Quandary
description: To bribe or not to bribe? That is the question if you want a good deal on a New York apartment, and the answer is usually yes. But a friend of mine, new to the city and to the intricate morality of rent control, is struggling with her conscience, not to mention her wallet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLOMB, MIRA I.
description: GOLOMB-Mira I. Died June 11, 1998. The Golomb Cousins Club records with sorrow the first loss of a charter member. Beloved sister of Barry and Adeline Golomb and Sarai and Sam Zitter, she is also survived by many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and a grandnephew. Funeral services will be at Mt. Sinai Memorial Chapel, 454 Cranbury Rd, E. Brunswick, NJ, at noon today.

title: Did He Love Her? Oh, Yes
description: WATCHING the early scenes of ''The Thorn Birds,'' when Father Ralph de Bricassart was too young and dashing for his own good, it's hard to believe that Richard Chamberlain was 48 at the time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGER, VAN VECHTEN
description: BURGER-Van Vechten. Husband of the late Rosalie Evans Burger. Father of Beverly Alexandre, the late Evan Donaldson and Van Vechten Burger Jr. He also leaves nine grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held July 1 at Trinity St. John's Church, Hewlett, NY. Contributions may be sent to the Hill School, Pottstown, PA, Yale University or the Evan B. Donaldson Adoption Institute, NYC.

title: Habitats/75 Livingston Street; Scaling the Heights Of Brooklyn Heights
description: THE penthouse at Heights 75 wasn't much to look at when Kevin Steffens and Doug Dorsett first saw it. The apartment had been empty for several years, and the ceilings and walls had extensive water damage. Holes were everywhere. The floors had begun to buckle. The kitchen area had been scavenged for parts. There was no water or electricity, and during restoration work on the facade, the apartment had been used as a work area.

title: Ms. Lautenbach, Dr. Murphy
description: Sherry Lynn Lautenbach, a daughter of Cindy and Ned Lautenbach of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Robert Murphy, the son of Maureen Murphy of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., and Robert T. Murphy of Hackensack, N.J. Msgr. Pierre Botton performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Church in Westport, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTIK, HARRY
description: KUTIK-Harry. Of Tenafly, NJ, on June 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Carol C. (nee McDonald). Devoted father of Robert Mark, Ronald Steven and David Alan. Dear brother of Phillip and Minnie Malmad. Loving grandfather of Sara O'Connell Kutik, Gabriel McDonald Kutik, Tobias Kutik, Andrea Kutik, Lauren Elizabeth Kutik, Jenny Claire Kutik and Sean McGarr. Services Gutterman-Musicant (corner Passaic & Park Sts.), Hackensack, NJ today at 1:30 PM. Contributions to Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Assoc., 75-20 Astoria Blvd., Jackson Hts., NY 11370.

title: Where, oh Where . . .
description: In ''Loving and Losing a Pet,'' the story is related of a child, told that his dog is now with God, who replies, ''What is God going to do with a dead dog?'' Owning a pet, say the authors, Michael Stern and Susan Cropper, puts people in touch with the rewards of attachment and the wonders of life, but also with the inevitability of death. Dr. Stern is a clinical psychologist who practices in Haworth and New York City, and Dr. Cropper is a home-visiting veterinarian based in Wycoff. Their book is an intelligent owner's manual, weighted as much toward issues like choosing a pet and using a vet as toward making the tough decision to end a pet's life. The book is especially good on the relationship between pets and the elderly, and pets and children. You'd expect as much from a book that includes dogs named Pooky and Pepper in the acknowledgments. The book, published by Jason Aronson in Northvale, costs $25 and is available at bookstores or by calling (800) 782-0015.

title: Beaches and Pools Open
description: Westchester pools and beaches have officially opened for the season on a full-time schedule: from 10 A.M. to 6:30 P.M. daily through Labor Day, except for Spruce Lake Beach in North Salem, which is open only on weekends and holidays.

title: A Summer Vine Yields a Sweet Reward in Fall
description: WHEN I lived in an apartment with a balcony, friends used to admire the vine I had growing there each summer in an old apple crate. Its shiny leaves cascaded over the balcony's edge, and it always looked fresh, healthy and a little bit tropical.

title: Ms. Alexander and Mr. Sears
description: Katherine Dawson Alexander, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Alexander of Groton, Mass., was married there yesterday to Nathaniel Roy Sears, a son of Mrs. A. J. Donelson Morrow of Lamy, N.M., and Richard C. Sears of Snedens Landing, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas N. Oates, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Parish Church.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1999 Porsche 911; A Lightning Bolt, Now Water-Cooled
description: PORSCHE 911's have always been superior sports cars despite their quirks, with capable handling and rocket-like speed. This year, as Porsche marks the 50th anniversary of its first car, it has reinvented itself by remaking its 34-year-old flagship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, DANIEL
description: LEVINE-Daniel. It is with great sadness that we extend our condolences to Gail Cohen, wife of our esteemed colleague Burton Cohen, her mother Faye, and her brother and sister-in-law Howard and Susan, on the loss of their beloved husband and father. Daniel Levine was a special man. He was kind, compassionate and wise. Beloved by all, it was a privilege to have known him. We feel enriched that he touched our lives. Doctors and Staff Daniel Maklansky, M.D. Howard B. Grunther, M.D. Jerold D. Kurzban, M.D. Jerald Zimmer, M.D. Alain D. Hyman, M.D. Barry D. Berson, M.D.

title: An Old Favorite by Mozart in a New Location
description: BY signing a lease with the McCarter Theater in Princeton, the Opera Festival of New Jersey has acquired the use of an orchestra pit, a computer-based box office, and location, location, location, all of which have helped the company quintuple its subscriptions and ticket sales this year.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Dollywood Has Become Wetter and Wilder
description: Dolly Parton's entertainment and amusement park, Dollywood, opened this spring for its 13th season with a new ride and a new show.

title: Tuberculosis DNA Is Decoded
description: For a really scary disease, forget Ebola and other plagues. Tuberculosis, contained at present by antibiotics, may not be kept at bay for long. The bacterium, which is easily inhaled, already infects much of the world's population and kills three million people a year in the less developed world.

title: Betsy Kane, Douglas LeBlanc
description: Elizabeth Ann Kane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Kane of Barnstable, Mass., was married yesterday to Douglas John LeBlanc, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger H. LeBlanc of Salem, Mass. The Rev. Russ Savage performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of Barnstable.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: OUT OF LEFT FIELD

title: Legislative Session Ending Quietly, Stilled by Election-Year Inertia
description: This week, just days before the end of the 1998 legislative session, State Senator Nicholas A. Spano strolled through the lobby outside the Senate chamber, chatting quietly with a few colleagues and lobbyists.

title: Corrections
description: An illustration with the Capitalist column on May 31, about the book-publishing business, carried an erroneous credit. The artist was Christian Clayton.

title: Nation of Caregivers Needs Greater Foresight; Depression Is Common
description: To the Editor:

title: Something Showy
description: Getting the bride to the church is high fantasy, with two white horses drawing a fairy princess coach or matching limousines with an escort of matching silver motorcycles. The customized limousine is so important that it serves as a backdrop for wedding portraits. Rigid rules have given way to personal expressions of style and fun. Guests on the church steps blow bubbles instead of throwing rice. Groomsmen display a peacock style in a green derby and shirt, a shocking pink suit, a zoot suit.

title: Judy Garland As a Force Of Nature
description: DIVAS are the tornadoes of the performing arts.

title: Fortepiano Gets a Test: Beethoven
description: THE Beethoven piano sonatas are often compared to Mount Everest: after conquering other peaks, one proves one's ultimate mettle by performing all 32 sonatas in a cycle. The task seems made for a solitary trekker. So the real oddity in the latest recorded Beethoven cycle (Claves 50-9707; 10 CD's) is not that it uses period pianos -- others have done so -- but that it is played by a collective. What's more, the collective consists mostly of relative unknowns.

title: Taking a Close-Up of Photography, a Longer View of Sculpture
description: TWO current offerings in Stamford are the very definition of diverse. A photography show at PMW Gallery is intimate and demands close-up viewing, while an extravaganza of a sculpture show is so large that a big swatch of the city is its showing place.

title: Yeshivish at Yale
description: Although the Yale Five's commitment to their religious convictions is admirable, their insistence on being cloistered from the temptations of secular life is hardly courageous. Most of the Old Testament is devoted to stories of men and women whose faith never wavered in the face of death, disaster or imprisonment. Faith that fears the more modest challenges of living in campus housing seems rather timid by comparison.

title: U.S. Tour Companies Venture to Iran
description: Iran is gradually opening to American visitors. There are no diplomatic relations between the United States and Iran, and a trade embargo is in force, so the State Department continues to warn against travel there, although the warning was softened on April 2. But travel there is not illegal and three companies are offering tours: Absolute Asia of New York; Distant Horizons of Long Beach, Calif., and Geographic Expeditions of San Francisco. All trips touch Ishfahan, whose Royal Square contains materpieces of 17th-century Islamic architecture, particularly the Imam Mosque.

title: Greece Seeks the Rewards of 'Club Med'
description: TWO years ago, shrewd European speculators reaped huge profits on a brilliantly contrary bet. Not only would the euro become a reality, they reasoned, but its biggest beneficiaries would be the European Union's poorer and more inflation-prone countries: Italy, Spain and Portugal.

title: Sports of The Times; Sensing Something Special, a Celebration Is Delayed
description: THE statue stood so tall, so proud, so reassuring for those who came to worship as if it were a shrine. No doubt in its eyes. No fear. No reason not to believe that the night would be everything it was supposed to be. The guardian of the United Center, the messiah of professional sports, would make the photo a timepiece to savor.

title: Access Rights in Peril On Certain Waterways
description: Unknown to most anglers, the right to fish hundreds of miles of waterways within New York State has hung precariously in the balance for more than a year, following a court decision that greatly limits where the public can cast a line.

title: Celeste DiPasqua And Robert Kane
description: Celeste Marie DiPasqua, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred DiPasqua of Saddle River, N.J., is to be married today to Robert John Kane, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Kane of Hackensack, N.J. The Rev. Jerry Hahn is to perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River.

title: Silver Charm Finishes Short At the Scene of Derby Glory
description: Some of the stars of the 3-year-old racing class of 1997 returned to the stage yesterday and did not exactly prosper. Silver Charm, who won the Kentucky Derby and Preakness a year ago, was outrun by Awesome Again in the Stephen Foster Handicap at Churchill Downs. And at Belmont Park, both Ordway and Behrens ran out of the money while Subordination was driving through the mud to win the Brooklyn Handicap.

title: Q and A
description: Romanov Funeral

title: Word for Word/Therapy; You Are Getting Very Confused: Psychologists' Split Decisions
description: YOU take it all with a grain of salt when you read your daily horoscope or the advice columns. But advice dispensed on the couch by a trained psychologist should carry more weight, right? Sure, but watch it: Even therapists with the best credentials can be all over the map.

title: Washington Talk; Tobacco Bill in Senate Is Rough Draft
description: The anti-smoking bill now before the Senate has strayed far afield.

title: Sometimes 3 Managers Are Better Than One
description: ONE hot industry trend -- some would say fad -- is the concentrated fund: an offering that holds 30 or so stocks instead of the typical 100 or more. Another is the so-called all-star fund, in which several high-profile managers each run a slice of a portfolio.

title: An Attack He Cannot Remember, a Memory Problem He Cannot Forget
description: For too long, Kaushal Sharan's mornings have begun in the basement of a storefront in Richmond Hill, Queens. There, in a Hindu monastery of sorts, known as an ashram, where Mr. Sharan has a subterranean room, he has started his days with yoga three times a week. Every other day, he has jogged around the Aqueduct Race Track nearby. And day after monotonous day, he has pored over his books and notes, preparing for an examination required to practice medicine in this country.

title: Wear It or Frame It
description: Richard Karnatz is an artist who may not have made it into the Whitney Museum of American Art, but at least his barbecue aprons are in the Whitney Museum's Store. Printed with 1950's images of what he calls ''fashion girls,'' his four cotton-duck aprons cost $40 each at the Whitney, Madison Avenue at 74th Street. ''I started the business by making a new apron for myself to wear in my print shop,'' said Mr. Karnatz, a fine-arts printer who owns Bent Fish Editions in Manhattan. ''All my clients wanted them, so I started giving them out as promotional gifts -- even to potential clients like Chuck Close.'' Mr. Karnatz's own silk-screened artworks are on show at Bendix Diner (First Avenue at 10th Street).

title: Flowery Greeters
description: When Steven Spielberg and Donna Karan arrive at their East Hampton, N.Y., retreats, after a long week in the film and fashion trenches, they want to relax in rooms made welcoming by fresh-cut flowers. But they're not in the mood to stop first at the village florist, then mess with vases and unwieldy delphiniums. Enter Paul Goerz, who precedes them home on Friday afternoons and fills rooms with delicate and romantic floral arrangements. (Mr. Spielberg likes all white; Ms. Karan prefers colorful, theatrical displays.) Mr. Goerz's business, A New Leaf, (516) 329-2646, charges $150 a room. He's one of the new florists making house calls in the Hamptons, where the notion of flowers used to be limited to telegraphed carnations or zinnias from a farm stand.

title: Homeless Shelters Suffer As Welfare Rolls Decline
description: The sharp decline in New York State's welfare rolls has created an unexpected crisis for financially struggling homeless shelters in New York City's suburbs and upstate communities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, IRENE ANN
description: GIBSON-Irene Ann, Ph.D. On June 9, at home in her 93rd year. Born in Oswego, NY, Ms. Gibson received her degree from Columbia University Teachers College and was a long time supervisor with the NYC Board of Education. A student and collector of American Indian culture and artifacts she lived in Boulder, CO for a number of years, and served in the U.S. Navy during World War II. She was a 40 year resident of Stuyvesant Town and parishoner of Immaculate Conception Church (414 East 14th St., NYC 10009) where gifts in her memory may be sent. A memorial is being planned.

title: Space Aged
description: ''One of the neat things about being a commander,'' says Lieut. Col. Curtis L. Brown Jr., ''is when you take rookies into space and you see their face after the main engine shutdown and you're in orbit. You never forget that.'' In October, if all goes as planned, Colonel Brown will fly his fifth shuttle mission with one crew member who may have that same look, not from the novelty of the experience but from distant memory.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Housing Developers Look Inland From Riverfront
description: WHILE housing is sprouting like wildflowers along the Hudson River coastline, it is also taking shape on interior streets in some waterfront communities.

title: Little Cars With Dash, Classic and Racing
description: EVEN before opening, ''The Art of the Automotive Model'' at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center (on view through July 12), generated interest from California, the Midwest, England, France, Japan and elsewhere around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADLER, HANNAH LUSTGARTEN
description: NADLER - Hannah Lustgarten. Age 88. Devoted wife of the late Murray Nadler. Hannah will be dearly missed by her daughters Anne Grosser and Henriet Cohen; grandchildren Derek, Allison, Jetha and Zachary; sons-in-law Marty Cohen and Bill Grosser; and by her family and many friends who cherished her deep loyalty, sense of humor, elegance and caring ways. Funeral at Riverside-Nassau North, Great Neck, 1:30 PM, Sunday, June 14. Donations to Mitzvah-Temple Israel of Great Neck, R.E.A.P., Planned Parenthood or American Cancer Society.

description: To the Editor:

description: GHOST COUNTRY

description: To the Editor:

title: In Turkey, Press's Lot Includes Jail Time
description: A couple of dozen of Ragip Duran's friends arranged a farewell dinner for him on Thursday night at a restaurant in Istanbul's artistic Asmalimescit quarter. Spirits were high, jokes and stories were told, and much Turkish food was washed down with much beer, wine and raki, the potent anise-flavored national drink.

title: Taking Tours
description: To the Editor: As convenient as group tours are in handling the red tape of foreign countries and achieving excellent air and land travel, I shall never forget:

title: In Highland Park, Lessons in History, Computer Science and Friendship
description: The students are 7 years old, 8 if they're really getting up there. The people they set out to interview have been around considerably longer.

title: Reinforcing Diplomacy on Kosovo
description: The mock air attacks NATO plans to carry out tomorrow in the Balkans are a timely and reasonable response to the growing military violence being orchestrated by Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, in the Serbian province of Kosovo. As seen with Iraq earlier this year, diplomacy backed with a show of force can move a leader with a history of failing to respond to gentler forms of international persuasion.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: MESSAGE IN A BOTTLE By Nicholas Sparks. Warner, $20.

title: The Sales Roll On
description: Hey dude, skateboarding's back. The National Sporting Goods Association says skateboarding eclipsed mountain biking and golf last year to become this country's fastest growing activity for which you need sports equipment. Hurt in recent years by in-line skating, skateboarding recovered strongly, with 6.3 million skaters lurching through streets and parks last year, a 35.8 percent increase over the year before.

title: An American Original Under Europe's Influence
description: THERE are rare artists who jealously hoard their best efforts; posthumously, their estates reveal them to have been their own most discerning collectors. But this is a luxury most artists can ill afford. Every sale is a godsend, and with luck, the better the painting, the quicker it goes out the door.

title: Does Shakespeare Really Need B12 Shots?
description: THERE probably isn't a scholar or critic in the world who would rate ''Henry VIII'' as one of Shakespeare's great history plays. It possesses no grandly iconic heroes or villains of diabolic ambitions. It contains no patches of soaring verse and commemorates no single splendid event that forever changed the course of the British monarchy. It is essentially a patched-together propaganda piece.

title: John H. Richardson, 84, C.I.A. Station Chief in Saigon in Early '60s
description: John H. He was 84.

description: WHAT developers say will be a little bit of Scotland, or Ireland perhaps, is not so much falling from the sky as emerging from the deeply scoured earth on 151 acres of former farmland in Riverhead.

description: UNTIL a month ago Deedee Langhorn lived in a garden apartment complex on Roanoke Avenue where, she says, the presence of drugs and constant police activity made her life miserable.

title: Style; Nice 'n' Easy
description: Cocked and jaunty, the hat's a fedora with what people in the business call ''a stingy brim'' It first appeared at a time when Frank Sinatra had begun his postwar transformation from what the critic Gary Giddins describes as ''the eager balladeer'' to a swinger, that enduring emblem of late nights and lush life, of done-it-all-but-didn't-crease-the-suit. When Sinatra was dumped by Ava Gardner in the mid-50's, he seemed to abandon forever the vaguely androgynous crooner of bobby-socks fantasia, the man-boy enfolded in serge and crowned with an oily pompadour. It was then that he began paring down both his vocal and sartorial styles, eliminating embellishment, tightening up the lyric line, reshaping tempo and also ditching big-shouldered jackets and pleated trousers for a stark silhouette that he continued to work on for the next 40 years.

title: SOAPBOX; A Long Wait for Justice
description: THERE may be no one alive today who is aware of being the direct descendant of a person who was thrown to the lions by the Romans. Given enough time, even the worst tragedies are forgotten, at least as personal or family memories. While a millennium may be enough time to purge the memory of such horror, a century is not. My family still remembers the brutal murder of my great-grandfather on the shores of Verona Lake 100 years ago.

title: JUNE 7-13; A Hairdresser Strikes Oil
description: Sometimes the march of progress goes past some incongruous places, like the Alabama ditch where space agency engineers gathered to pump dirty water through a barrel partly filled with human hair.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about an extensive program of public art in Berlin misstated the setting for a proposed mural by Ellsworth Kelly. It would be in a new office building for the Bundestag, Germany's national legislature, not in the Reichstag. The Reichstag is being renovated for use by the Bundestag as its legislative chamber.

title: Bookend; Imagining Imaginary Artists
description: IT has been three months now since William Boyd's little book, ''Nat Tate: An American Artist, 1928-1960,'' was kicked off with a big art-gallery party in New York, and articles in The New York Times and The Independent of London revealing that this supposed biography of a previously unknown artist was a put-on. Three months seems to have been time enough for Nat Tate's 15 minutes to be over, but some interesting questions remain.

title: Joe Dixon, 81, A Jazz Musician
description: Joe Dixon, a clarinetist and saxophonist who played with many of the great jazz ensembles during a career that began in the 1930's and lasted about 50 years, died on May 28 at his home in Oceanside, N.Y. He was 81.

title: San Diego Mission
description: To the Editor: I find it curious that Sarah Ferrell wrote an article about touring San Diego (''Recharging in Sunny San Diego,'' May 24) and did not mention the reason for the city's original fame -- the Mission of San Diego de Alcala, the mother of all the California missions.

title: A Million-Dollar Home? Ho-Hum.
description: THE million-dollar home -- a phrase that not long ago summoned up images of mansions and perhaps even liveried servants -- has become so commonplace in the most affluent New York suburbs that in some communities more than half the homes now on the market are priced above $1 million.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 26 of the Arts and Leisure section today with a play review of ''Once in a Lifetime'' at the Atlantic Theater Company misidentifies the actress shown with Johanna Day and Larry Bryggman. She is Isabel Keating, not Cynthia Darlow.

title: THE WORLD: Camera Angles; What China Sees in Clinton
description: THE Chinese have an old saying, describing donkey dung, that pokes fun at their culture's obsession with appearances: ''Shiny on the outside, smelly within.''

title: Only Their Spirits Are High
description: LIKE thousands of high school seniors across New Jersey, Jason Kenney is looking forward to graduation -- and the partying afterward.

Loving grandfather of Theresa and Terrence. Dear brother of Maria DeFrancisci and brother-inlaw of Ignatius DeFrancisci and Rose Merritt. Devoted friend of Phyllis Seidenfrau. Survived by six fond nieces and nephews. Reposing at Farenga Bros. Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Ave., Bronx until Monday, 10:15 AM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Clare's Church at 11:15 AM.

description: WHEN asked to describe himself in one word, Donald Everett Axinn was momentarily stumped.

title: Hilltop Castles Guard the Past
description: PORTUGAL'S age of glory is written on water. Its 15th- and 16th-century explorers, trained at King Henry the Navigator's school at Sagres, carried the flag of the tiny kingdom across uncharted oceans to places as distant as Mozambique and Macao, Greenland, Brazil, Australia and India.

title: Making Juliet One of the Guys in a Macho Verona
description: IN the first pumped-up moments of ''Shakespeare's 'R&J,' '' the all-male version of ''Romeo and Juliet'' at the John Houseman Studio Theater, a slightly-built schoolboy smashes a notebook against the wall. It is an abrupt, urgent image and one that sums up the production's visceral approach, in which the famous story of star-crossed lovers has been set at a repressive boys' school.

description: Lisa Day Zonino and William Alan Woodworth were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony.

The Rev. James C. Martin performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of West Tisbury (Mass.), on Martha's Vineyard.

description: Jim Hewitt was speeding through the streets of East New York to an interview at the Urban Youth Corps when his bicycle tire caught a flat. The rest is history.

description: The plan to build a new concourse and ticketing area for Pennsylvania Station within the landmark General Post Office on Eighth Avenue moved ahead last week as state officials narrowed their negotiations to one prominent architectural and engineering team.

title: Charles Gosse 2d, Laura Radack
description: Laura Sharon Radack, a lawyer, and Charles Shailer Gosse 2d, the chief financial officer of the Dalton School in New York, were married yesterday in Little Compton, R.I. The Rev. Daniel Burke, an Episcopal priest, officiated with Rabbi Benjamin Rudavsky at the Stone House Club.

title: Young and in a Niche That the Movies Neglect
description: WENDY WASSERSTEIN was surprised when a friend mentioned that she had just accompanied 17 11-year-olds to see ''The Object of My Affection'' for a birthday party. ''At first I was taken aback,'' says Ms. Wasserstein, who wrote the screenplay for that movie, which is rated R and deals with bisexuality. ''But then I had to admit that to appeal to such young girls made me really happy.''

title: For a Danish City, A Year in a Thousand
description: In September, Roskilde, once the capital of Denmark, will proclaim itself 1,000 years old. But in the months preceding, the well-preserved medieval city -- known for its Gothic cathedral with the tombs of 38 Danish kings, the Viking Ship Museum and an area of half-timbered houses and shops -- is observing its millennial jubilee.

title: Backtalk; Weaning the World Off Michael: Not a Pretty Picture
description: When Michael leaves us, I will also miss the breathless crushes he evoked in other men. There has been nothing like it since Mickey Mantle made middle-aged men cry by showing up, for a fee, at their birthday parties. Muhammad Ali makes big boys melt with a frozen half-smile. But the Mick and Ali reached their powers long after they retired, when their fans had grown into their nostalgia years. Michael will make his fans swoon again tonight with his tongue hanging out, rising to the hoop.

title: April (May, June, Etc.) Showers Are Enough for These Flowers

title: Music Festival Opens at Caramoor
description: MUSICAL enrichment and enlightenment stem from our wish for a better world,'' says Peter Oundjian, the artistic director of Caramoor in Katonah. ''The spiritual nourishment of music is vital to our civilization.'' When Caramoor's International Music Festival opens next Saturday, several of Mr. Oundjian's innovations will be apparent. For one, vocal music has been returned to full partnership with other forms of music, with four Bel Canto at Caramoor evenings, including opening night, and on July 18, a semi-staged production of ''Lucrezia Borgia,'' the Donizetti opera that the director Will Crutchfield calls ''red-blooded, passionate, and one of the great masterpieces of the bel canto era.''

title: Solo Act, Jeep Voice As Well
description: HE is an actor, he is a director and he is a musical theater star. But don't call James Naughton a song and dance man. He'll tell you to strike the dance part, in spite of his showy Tony Award-winning performance as the shockingly contemporary lawyer, Billy Flynn who sings ''Razzle Dazzle'' in the current Broadway re-invention of ''Chicago,'' a hot and cold-blooded view of amorality, 1920's style -- and the very model of a dancing show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAISEL, JOAN (NEE EPSTEIN)

Funeral services on Sunday, June 14 at 12:30 PM, Boulevard-Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

He listed low points in his life: smoking marijuana at 13, drinking alcohol at 14, dropping out of high school, drinking before work, getting fired from job after job, being arrested for armed robbery and attempting to hang himself in jail.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Cover Story
description: For 30 years, Rolling Stone has been a barometer of popular culture and fashion. As the longest-surviving offspring of the counterculture of the 1960's and now as mainstream as Time or Newsweek, Rolling Stone has documented most of pop music's legends, often before they reached their eminence; in some cases the magazine even helped them earn such status. ROLLING STONE: The Complete Covers (Abrams, $39.95), a pantheon of many of the leading personalities in music, television, film and even politics, traces the lives and, sometimes, the demise of memorable and forgotten culture heroes. From the first issue, featuring a photograph of the young John Lennon in Richard Lester's film ''How I Won the War,'' to issue No. 773, featuring Tina Turner, Madonna and Courtney Love to illustrate three generations of ''Women of Rock,'' Rolling Stone's covers reveal the changing, and often the aging, faces of pop. The front and back covers of the book, respectively a 1978 photograph of Bob Dylan and a 1997 one of his son Jakob, underscore a somewhat disturbing (for us baby boomers) march of time as seen through the Rolling Stone lens. In addition to being a pop culture time line, this handsome book offers pithy anecdotes by Rolling Stone writers and photographers about their work, like this recollection by Annie Leibovitz about a January 1981 cover of a naked John Lennon draped in a fetal position over Yoko Ono: ''I remember arriving at the apartment that morning, Dec. 8, and John taking me aside and saying, 'Listen, I know they want to run me by myself on the cover, but I really want Yoko to be on the cover with me. It's really important.' . . . Several hours later John was murdered.'' Steven Heller

title: The View From/Litchfield; The Retreat at Lourdes, Some 40 Years Later
description: WHEN it was completed and blessed in 1958, the shrine grotto at Lourdes in Litchfield quickly drew pilgrims to its peaceful, sylvan setting. They lit candles beneath its rocky dome and walked the Stations of the Cross in a wooded hillock that echoed with birdsong and the rushing water of a nearby stream. They roamed its 150 acres but rarely encountered the 40 seminarians who lived in the big house on the hill.

title: Outdoor Chef's Secret Weapon: Marinade
description: WHEN you watch a good chef get meat or fish ready for the outdoor grill, the first thing he or she does is put together a marinade. Sometimes it is nothing more than a mixture of olive oil, garlic and herbs. But it makes quite a difference to the taste of the food being cooked.

title: Questions About Those Links Links
description: ''Duffers Need Not Apply'' (May 31), by Adam Bryant, examined a study comparing the golf handicaps of chief executives to their companies' stock market performance. The study found a pattern: that if a chief executive is a better-than-average golfer, his company is likely to deliver above-average returns to shareholders.

title: The Legacy of Lilco: No-Fault Failure
description: IN the history of bad decisions, the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station stands out, a single project that has polarized the politics of Long Island for a generation, boosted electric rates high enough to repel industry for miles around, uselessly monopolized the talents of hundreds of engineers and thousands of skilled craftsmen for more than a decade and sucked more than $5.5 billion out of the economy.

Several students gathered around each supine body. First, they ''scanned,'' sliding their outstretched hands through the air over their subjects, hunting for trouble spots.

title: Feiner Is Sued
description: Bernard J. Forrest, the Receiver of Taxes for Greenburgh, has filed a Federal lawsuit against Supervisor Paul J. Feiner and the Town of Greenburgh, claiming the Supervisor acted vindictively. In his suit in Federal District Court in White Plains on May 18, Mr. Forrest, 78, claims that Mr. Feiner tried to punish him because Mr. Forrest's wife campaigned for Susan Tolchin, who ran against Mr. Feiner in 1991.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC; Early-Music Talk Begins to Heat Up Again
description: IS it becoming fun again to argue about early music? In the 1980's the early-music movement meant controversy. Fortepianists swarmed outside the concert hall like campus radicals poised to storm the administration building. Learned commentators analyzed the movement's significance; everyone was sure it was a symptom of cultural something or other. Then in the 90's the diagnosticians turned their attention elsewhere. Richard Taruskin, the chief pundit, publicly laid down his pen. Leo Treitler, a noted musicologist, declared the death of ''early-music talk.''

title: Lorena Sayer, Graham O'Brien
description: Lorena Hope Sayer, the daughter of Ruth and John Dorsey Sayer of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Graham Patrick O'Brien, a son of Joyce and William R. title: Cigarette Maker Held Liable
description: The tobacco industry's tight door against lawsuits was jolted open when a Florida jury ordered the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company to pay $1 million to the family of a man whose death from cancer was blamed on cigarettes. The award included $450,000 in punitive damages, marking the first time a jury in a tobacco case has ordered such a penalty.

title: Show Me Where It Hurts!
description: It was a party for a fitness magazine and brett and I were drinking wine and talking about what we had done to get stories. ''I had all the hair removed from my underarms. By electrolysis. And that was before numbing creams,'' she said. A waiter came by with fresh drinks. I took one, and thought about electric needles going into underarms. ''My pain threshold is pretty high,'' Brett said. ''I go for cellulite treatments.'' We made a bet and I do not remember much after that.

title: Back to My Roots
description: William Safire's rejoinder to Stephen Sondheim's letter hardly qualified as deconstruction (On Language: ''Back to My Roots,'' May 24). I would have chosen simpler terms of literary criticism, like ''explication'' or ''close reading,'' to describe Safire's very traditional approach here. Whatever you call it, his painstaking study of Sondheim's words backfired. Not only did it not undercut Sondheim's intention (to criticize Safire's monotonous attacks on Bill Clinton), it lent sharpness to Sondheim's pen.

title: After 15 Years in Court, Workers' Lawsuit Against Trump Faces Yet Another Delay
description: Eighteen years ago, Wojciech Kozak helped build Trump Tower, the skyscraper jewel in Donald J. Trump's real-estate empire. Today, Mr. Kozak recalls that time with nightmare memories of backbreaking 12-hour shifts and of being cheated with 200 other undocumented Polish immigrants out of meager wages and fringe benefits.

title: Volunteers Sought
description: Save the Sound, a regional nonprofit group with offices in Connecticut and New York, is seeking volunteers to test water quality along the Long Island Sound shoreline this summer. All data collected by volunteers are collated in a yearly report and distributed to more than 300 groups, government agencies and individuals.

title: Editorial Observer; At a Gathering in Walden Woods
description: Somehow a visit to Walden Pond doesn't really resolve the image of Henry Thoreau. What it does instead is clarify the contradictions, the disparities from which that image is shaped. The light rising from the surface of the pond on a June afternoon reflects indiscriminately on the objects around it. The same was true of Thoreau's mind, no matter how ill-assorted the objects he wrote about might have been. What harmony there is in Thoreau's thinking, I believe, came from the collision and eventual abrasion of dissimilar ideas, the struggle, as he might have put it, between the acorn and the chestnut obeying their own laws.

title: Move to Ban Laser Pointers For Minors
description: A STUDENT in the seventh grade at Scarsdale Middle School, sitting in his English class, was recently struck in the eye by the beam from a classmate's laser pointer, and it was more than a day before his vision returned to normal. A police officer in Peekskill had a moment of panic when a laser pointer was shined on him and he thought it was a weapon-sighting device; luckily he did not pull a weapon to defend himself. And there have been reports, outside of Westchester, of a new game: shining laser pointers into the eyes of motorists.

title: Boces Head Resigns Post
description: In a surprising move, Dr. Vincent Beni announced last Monday his resignation as Superintendent of the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services. Dr. Beni, who has served for four years, follows Dr. Dudley Hare, who resigned as Superintendent of the Putnam-Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services six weeks ago.

title: Bahia Makes Room for A Candomble Pantheon
description: A CENTURY ago, the African-rooted religion of Candomble was an unspoken secret in Bahia and its capital, Salvador. Today, the former mystery is a matter of public pride, and now it has its own monument. Eight towering statues of orixas, the deities of Candomble, were dedicated in April in the Dique do Tororo, a lake in the center of downtown Salvador.

The designer's six-year-old firm, Aero Studios, has decorated houses for Ralph Lauren (a former employer), and designed commercial interiors for Giorgio Armani, the restaurateur Ken Aretsky and the upscale bath store Waterworks, to name a few A-list clients. title: A Marine-Themed World's Fair
description: EVER since Britain and France began holding universal exhibitions in the late 19th century to boast of their power and prowess, world's fairs have had a political agenda. So Portugal can be forgiven for looking beyond education and entertainment in organizing its first international fair, Expo '98, which opened in Lisbon on May 22 and runs through Sept. 30. Quite simply, it wants the world to take note that Portugal, a tiny backward dictatorship 25 years ago, is now a modern, self-confident democracy. And it wants to remind us that this country, too, has a glorious past.

description: Free Choices

title: Margaret Kannan, Alexander Peters
description: Margaret Morrison Kannan and Alexander Robin Peters were married last evening at the bridegroom's home in Amagansett, N.Y. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, the dean emeritus of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, officiated. Rabbi Joseph H. Gelberman took part in the ceremony.

title: Food With Flair
description: TIM SCHAFER'S CUISINE is a narrow, fun-filled space in which you can eat contemporary dishes that are as ebullient as the chef and his well-trained assistants.

title: Freer and Fresher, An Old Form Catches Fire
description: IT was not a dream. Late one night last month, at Tunnel, a club in lower Manhattan, the deejay threw a curve. For several hours a group of young men and women had been gyrating to hip-hop, house and techno music when, out of the blue, a passionate song sung by Alejandro Sanz filled the room. Without missing a beat, the dancers' posture changed. They lifted their chests, placed their hands on their waists and prepared for a fiery flamenco. Then, fingers clicking, hips swiveling, feet pounding, they had a go at it. They sizzled. And why not? Flamenco is hot.

title: Swallowing Hard
description: BITTER PILLS Inside the Hazardous World of Legal Drugs. By Stephen Fried. 417 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $24.95.

title: Bench Marks
description: EQUAL JUSTICE UNDER LAW

title: Ruling on On-Line Privacy
description: It was not the retirement that Master Chief Petty Officer Timothy R. McVeigh had wanted. But after America Online violated its in-house rules and disclosed to a military investigator that the sailor had posted an electronic message describing himself as gay, Mr. McVeigh said he was left with little choice but to go.

title: Spared Tornado, County Still Ready
description: ON the recent night that a tornado roared through upstate Mechanicville and funnel clouds whirled over northern Westchester, Yorktown braced for the worst. The town was in a tornado's path, radio and television bulletins warned, and Capt. Richard Strauss of the Lake Mohegan Fire District, which serves parts of Yorktown and Cortlandt, readied emergency services.

title: Bickering In the Clubhouse; Lawsuits Against Golfing Giant Disrupt a Manicured Kingdom
description: THAT makes a perfect country club? It should be ''a haven of refuge'' dedicated to ''the genuine care and comfort of our members,'' said Robert H. Dedman Sr., founder and chairman of Club Corporation International, a leading operator of country clubs and other such genteel gathering spots.

title: Bridal Statistics
description: Just in time for the June onslaught of dyed-to-match shoes, a paperback of frank statistics on how people meet, marry and survive the first year of nuptial bliss is arriving in bookstores. Based on a survey of 3,876 Americans who have been married an average of 9.6 months, ''Just Married'' (Andrews McMeel Publishing, $8.95) by Barry Sinrod and Marlo Grey offers amusing and sometimes surprising data. Contrary to the belief that holding out on the sexual front guarantees a mate, 17 percent of the respondents chose to consummate their marriage on the first date. The spouses who say ''I love you'' least often to their partners are over 40 and married for the first time. Those who say it the most are on their third marriage, or more.

title: Backtalk; 'Cool' Fads Causing Meltdown In N.H.L.
description: In the land where hockey runs through veins the way brine runs through the pipes beneath ice rinks, viewers of Molson's ''Hockey Night in Canada'' have been treated to a rather astounding beer commercial this spring. Set in an austere wood paneled boardroom, a man with a distinct accent addresses some anonymous National Hockey League executives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRATTA, M. CECILE
description: STRATTA-M. Cecile. In profound sorrow, the devoted sons of M. Cecile Stratta announce her passing on June 8, 1998. Over four decades, Cecile developed a successful and renowned foreign language translation and interpreting business, through which she enjoyed assignments and experiences which extended far beyond the New York area. Cecile's incredible strength and dignity as she battled a long and difficult illness inspired all those who came in contact with her. She had an insatiable curiosity and appetite for life. Her special wisdom, endless generosity and love will be deeply missed by all who had the privilege to know her and be touched by her. Cecile will be honored in a special Celebratory Memorial Service at 3 PM, Saturday, June 20, at Christ and St. Stephens' Church, West 69th St., between Broadway and Columbus. All of Cecile's many friends and colleagues are invited to attend to remember and celebrate her very special life.

title: In Annecy, Beguiling Accents
description: THE town of Annecy, on the French side of the Alps about 25 miles south of Geneva, is set on a translucent glacial lake. Surrounded by mountains, its air is pure and invigorating. Skiers come in winter, hikers in spring and summer. When not engaged in more strenuous activity, they stroll through the old quarters of Annecy, or window-shop under the arcades or along the quays lining the canals. Or they visit other towns and villages bordering the nine-mile Lac d'Annecy.

title: Runoffs Put Newcomers In City Council Seats
description: Seven of the 15 municipal council spots that were decided by runoff elections Tuesday in Newark, Trenton and Bayonne will be filled by newcomers. A newcomer also won a seat in Trenton, but the outcome may be subject to a recount. The runoffs were held for contests in which no candidate was able to win a majority of the vote in nonpartisan municipal elections May 12.

title: Snob Appeal In the Soap Dish
description: AFTER putting the finishing touches on a recent makeover of my bathroom, I stepped back and marveled at the spanking white tiles, sparkling fixtures and plush, cream-colored towels. Suddenly, the sight of a bar of pink Dove in my new porcelain soap dish jarred me. The supermarket staple was dreadfully out of place in my new sanctum of personal hygiene.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: EXHIBITION

title: Early Music, Truly Old-Fashioned at Last?
description: IF two new CD's by the English violinist Andrew Manze are any indication, early music may finally be shedding one of classical music's most venerable but useless assumptions. To wit, the funny notion abroad among classical-music reviewers that the best thing a performer can do is disappear.

title: 'In a Barren Land'
description: To the Editor:

title: Look Who's Leading the Country
description: THE conspiracy theorists have it all wrong. The United States Government is not run by Freemasons. Or by the Pope or Jewish bankers.

title: Mrs. Murchison Saunders, Mr. Wilcox
description: Coke Anne Murchison Saunders and George Jarvis Geer Wilcox Jr. were married yesterday aboard the ketch Aliento in Gardiners Bay off Long Island. The Rev. George A. Wilson, a Presbyterian minister and the Aliento's owner, officiated.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an art review last Sunday about self-portraits on display at Gallery North in Setauket misidentified the painter. He is Stan Brodsky; Don Resnick's paintings are also on display at the Setauket gallery.

title: Rhonda Roper And Jeffrey Shear
description: Rhonda Wynne Roper, an associate costume designer for ''Another World,'' the soap opera on NBC-TV, is to be married today to Jeffrey Mark Shear, a deputy assistant commissioner of the New York City Finance Department. Rabbi Charles Agin is to officiate at the Swan Club in Glenwood Landing, N.Y.

title: Yeshivish at Yale
description: The Yale Five take my breath away. They may be the first group of Jews actually to endeavor to renegotiate the terms on which Jews have traditionally operated among non-Jews. For the most part, they have either been loyal to their identity and opted for marginalization or assimilated, in order to become successful. This arrangement is not good enough for these Jews -- they want it all. Bravo!

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: Inhi Kim, David Kelley Jr.
description: Inhi Clara Kim, a graphic designer, and David Byron Kelley Jr., a freelance art director for films and videos, were married yesterday in the Rose Garden at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Frank Hall, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: New Problem With the Press: Attitude in Print
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathryn Lynch and Peter Moore
description: AS his friends tell it, Peter Moore has never been the sort of guy to pamper his girlfriends in the obvious ways -- like picking them up in a limousine, or even in a car. For as long as anyone can remember, he has traveled everywhere by bicycle.

title: Nation of Caregivers Needs Greater Foresight; Bankrupting Ourselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Golfers Play Catch-Up on the Course
description: AFTER watching Chris Gross of New Canaan High School and Paul Piro of Stamford High hit their opening tee shots about 180 yards onto the fairway at the 105-year-old Country Club of New Canaan recently, Carlton Edwards stepped up to the tee knowing he could not possibly duplicate those drives. And he did not, slicing into the woods just to the right of the tee.

title: Heather Johnson and John Sargent
description: Heather Eileen LaGrange Johnson, the daughter of Brenda and J. Howard Johnson of New York, was married yesterday to John Harrison Sargent, a son of Helen and P. Thomas Sargent of Westlake Village, Calif. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Kemper-Dreman High Return Equity Fund
description: THE ugly, the down and out, the beaten up -- these are the stocks that David N. Dreman, the value investor, loves.

description: Here's a bold and exciting idea in local news: artificial insemination of the anchor.

title: Will It Still Pay to Rally Around a Flag?
description: KISS the European country funds goodbye.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Reed Makes An Impression On Leyland
description: Jim Leyland, who will select the National League pitchers for the All-Star Game, pondered the notion of Rick Reed as an All-Star candidate tonight.

title: Tomiko Brown And Daniel Nagin
description: Tomiko S. Brown, a daughter of Lillie and Willie Brown of Greenwood, S.C., was married last evening to Daniel Lewis Nagin, a son of Sherrie and Lawrence Nagin of Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi Reeve Brenner performed the ceremony with the Rev. John Vaughn, an American Baptist minister, at Riverside Church in New York.

title: Emily Bowen, Etan Cohen
description: Emily Jean Bowen and Etan Jacob Cohen are to be married today in Montclair, N.J., at the home of Marjorie Horowitz, the bride's grandmother. Rabbi Meir Sendor is to officiate.

title: Boilermaker to Expand, And Hire, Locally
description: A. L. Eastmond & Sons, a manufacturer of industrial boilers and steel storage tanks, plans to expand its 73-year-old, family-run business at 1175 Leggett Avenue in Hunts Point in the Bronx.

title: Swallowing Hard
description: BITTER PILLS Inside the Hazardous World of Legal Drugs. By Stephen Fried. 417 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $24.95.

title: The Eurail Pass Idea Takes to the Skies
description: If you used a Eurail Pass in college, you might now want to try the Eurair Pass. A California company of the same name started the system in April, and it works like this: Americans or anyone with permanent residency in the United States can contact Eurair Pass or a travel agent to buy coupons good for any of 10 European airlines that connect 50 cities in 18 countries. Each coupon, representing one flight, costs $90 (not including airport taxes, which vary by country), and travelers must buy at least three.

title: POSTINGS: Ex-Citibank at Canal St. to House Stores; An Old Bank On Broadway Is Going Retail
description: A former Citibank branch has been gutted to make way for 12,000 square feet of retail space on two floors at 415 Broadway, on a triangle bounded on the other two sides by Canal and Lispenard Streets on the outskirts of Chinatown.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's nice to be able to fix broken things, and there are a lot of broken things in California. I certainly fixed bilingual education. I fixed it but good.''

title: Our Towns; An Artist Sees Fame Vanish, Fast as It Came
description: THE night his first solo exhibit opened in New York, Don DeNarie was as jumpy as a rabbit. People wearing black clothes and sophisticated smiles were strolling the little Gershwin Gallery on East 27th Street oohing and aahing over paintings he had made while he was still living in his car. It was too much.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST HARLEM; Off the Streets, Into the Air
description: When Crystal Hill, 9, sits on the trapeze that hangs 14 feet above the gym floor she feels as if she is floating on air. Below, some 300 students watch with amazement as she swings and flips on the thin rod.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, JUDY C.
description: ROSENTHAL-Judy C. It is written in stone ''Beloved and devoted daughter. We miss her strength, wisdom, wit and compassion.'' Mom

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: SINGERS AND THE SONG II

title: Whipping Rains Clog Traffic and Disrupt Subways
description: A combination of turbulent winds and low-hanging moisture brought a whipping rainfall yesterday, causing mudslides in the subway tunnels, flooding on the highways and long flight delays at most metropolitan airports.

title: In Face-Off Of Faiths, Kindness Is Winner
description: In a college neighborhood east of the historic Mormon Temple here this week, four young Southern Baptist men and women bowed their heads with Clint Roberts, whose T-shirt asks, ''What's more important than eternal life?''

title: Inching Forward on Emissions Curbs
description: Six months ago, in a sleepless, adrenaline-fueled rush of last-minute dealing in Kyoto, Japan, delegates from around the world agreed for the first time to make specific, legally binding reductions in industrialized countries' emissions of heat-trapping gases believed to affect Earth's climate.

title: Jane Randel, Charles Kliment
description: Jane Ann Randel, a daughter of Elaine and Kenneth Randel of Southbury, Conn., is to be married today to Charles Karel Kliment, the son of Daniela and Charles Kliment of Princeton, N.J. Susan Spielberg, a justice of the peace and a Jewish congregant, will perform a ceremony in the Jewish tradition at 70 Hillside, a historic house in Waterbury, Conn.

title: Molten Delirium
description: On the hunt for a special and much-appreciated house gift, one that will keep the invitations rolling in? Consider a jar of truffle sauce from Charbonnel et Walker, the London chocolatier established in 1875 and a fixture of the luxury row of Bond Street. Until recently, only those jetting back and forth to Britain could enjoy the decadent chocolate sauces in flavors like Cognac and Grand Marnier. But since September, Bergdorf Goodman has carried them in its specialty-foods department for $20 a jar. Drambo Villar, a sales associate, said they are hard to keep on the shelves. ''We've had great success with Europeans and the traveling types who know the brand,'' he said. ''It's an insider thing right now.''

title: Questions About Those Links Links
description: ''Duffers Need Not Apply'' (May 31), by Adam Bryant, examined a study comparing the golf handicaps of chief executives to their companies' stock market performance. The study found a pattern: that if a chief executive is a better-than-average golfer, his company is likely to deliver above-average returns to shareholders.

title: Maria Florez, Algirdas Lukosevicius
description: Maria Beatriz Florez, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ramon Florez of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to Dr. Algirdas Jonas Lukosevicius, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Antanas Lukosevicius of Woodhaven, Queens. Bishop Paul A. Baltakis, the Bishop for Lithuanian Roman Catholics living outside Lithuania, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. Peter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELLA ROCCA, DOMINICK
description: DELLA ROCCA - Dominick. Shocked at the sudden passing of ''Dom'' Della Rocca, a giant of a man. His energy, drive and committment to the unfortunate and underprivileged children of the State and City of New York is legendary. His charm, enthusiasm, unselfishness and dedication will be missed by all of the Mayors of the State of New York and by our family who loved him dearly. Maxine, Tad, Marge, Matt and Jerome Belson

title: Land Swapping For Development
description: Re: ''Farmland May Yield to Fairway'' (May 31):
