description: Shocking development at Coors Field:

title: Yeshivish at Yale
description: While I am sympathetic to the desire of the ''Yale Five'' to avoid the worst excesses of dorm life, I find their approach to the problem deeply troubling (''Yeshivish at Yale,'' by Samuel G. Freedman, May 24). More and more, we as a society are rejecting all solutions to conflict except two: violence and the courts.

title: Pacific Aquarium Ready To Open in Long Beach
description: A new aquarium focusing on the Pacific Ocean is to open on Saturday in Long Beach, Calif. The Long Beach Aquarium of the Pacific will have three permanent galleries of exhibits on marine life from Southern California and Baja, the Northern Pacific and the Tropical Pacific.

title: Moscow Aims at Tax Evasion
description: Getting a handle on Russia's economic activity is notoriously difficult because businesses routinely under-report their production to minimize taxes. The Government of Boris N. Yeltsin took a first step toward improving official economic estimates by arresting the country's top statisticians and accusing them of manipulating data to help Russian companies avoid taxes.

title: A Couple's Largesse Benefits Englewood Hospital
description: The entrepreneur Russell Berrie is no stranger to Englewood Hospital and Medical Center. It's where the two youngest of his six children were born, and Mr. Berrie, who has lived in Englewood for 33 years, has been a patient there himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUDOFF, LEON
description: YUDOFF-Leon. Age 95. Passed away peacefully in his home in North Miami Beach, Florida on Thursday, June 11, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Anna Yudoff. Cherished father of Zena Wiener and Paul Yudoff. Adored grandfather of Jenny and Gabe Wiener and David and Jason Yudoff. He emigrated to this country in 1923 and was deeply grateful to be an American citizen. Leon devoted his life not only to his family and friends, but to the many passions he held so dear: his heritage, the United Jewish Appeal, the State of Israel, music and the arts. His love of life and great wisdom will live on forever in those fortunate enough to have known him. Funeral services Sunday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Executive Director Leaves The Emelin in Mamaroneck
description: THE unexpected exit of David Watson as executive director of the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck, effective Friday, may not be a major hindrance to the state of professional theater in Westchester. But it does not help.

title: In Ulster, a Feeling That Peace Has a Chance
description: On the Shankill Road, in the heart of Protestant West Belfast, Penny Purdy tucked her three small children into the back of her small red car the other day, fussing with them and warning them to behave. A few hundred yards from her car, a Catholic bomber killed 10 Protestants and himself in a fish shop in 1993.

title: Eleni Demetriou, John Passalaris
description: Eleni Maria Demetriou, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Demetriou of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. John Dimitrios Passalaris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Passalaris of New Hyde Park, N.Y. The Rev. Dimitrios Antokas performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in Westfield, N.J.

title: Rock Kings, Drag Queens: A Common Strut
description: IT wasn't so long ago that rock-and-roll, symbolized by the primitive, strutting, priapic dance of a surly young man and his guitar, seemed to be an entrenched staple of American culture. In the 1970's and 80's heyday of the hard-rock ''hair band,'' it was easy to imagine an endless stream of sinewy guitar heroes with flowing tresses and bulging crotches passing the Dionysian torch from generation to generation until civilization finally exploded in an apocalyptic blitz of screeching feedback. An immersion in the arena-rock experience, with its beer-guzzling, drug-taking and gladiatorial rowdiness, was a rite of passage for every red-blooded American teen-age boy.

title: Interesting Offerings From the Caribbean
description: THE inexpensive, interesting ethnic food at Negril Palm in Baldwin makes it a quintessential a la carte restaurant. This cool Caribbean corner, owned by Jean Woodbine, its Jamaican chef, is a tropical green spot of palm plants and thatched roof with an erstatz palm tree at its center. It serves lively, authentic island dishes like curried goat ($8.95), chicken ($8.50) or shrimp ($12.95), oxtail and beans ($8.95), jerk ($9.00) and stewed chicken ($8.50), escabeche of fish ($12.95) and sweet potato or corn meal pudding (both $3.50).

title: Questions About Those Links Links
description: ''Duffers Need Not Apply'' (May 31), by Adam Bryant, examined a study comparing the golf handicaps of chief executives to their companies' stock market performance. The study found a pattern: that if a chief executive is a better-than-average golfer, his company is likely to deliver above-average returns to shareholders.

title: BUSINESS BEST SELLERS
description: HARD COVER

title: Charles Disch, 96, a Druggist And Island Curmudgeon, Dies
description: Charles Disch, who dispensed strong bitter medicine and good-natured vitriol during more than 60 years as the Shelter Island druggist and resident curmudgeon, died on May 31 at a mainland nursing home in Greenport, N.Y. He was 96.

title: With This Legislation, I Thee Wed
description: MARRIAGE, a cursory glance at the encyclopedia tells us, didn't used to be just a simple exchange of overpriced jewelry; it was once a pact between clan leaders. ''Apart from the case of wife stealing,'' Britannica says, ''no female member could be parted from her clan without the cooperation of her chief, and no male member could take a wife without the cooperation of his chief.''

title: Shropshire's Rolling Green Carpet
description: WHENEVER my husband, John, and I mentioned to our London friends that we were planning a trip to Shropshire, the response was invariably an incredulous ''Where?'' We quickly got the idea that this quiet agricultural region on the Welsh border was not the most fashionable place to spend a summer vacation.

title: In America; Hidden Agendas
description: The Governor of Wisconsin, Tommy G. Thompson, is expected to sign a bill on Tuesday that would permit the state to take into custody pregnant women who exhibit a serious and habitual ''lack of self-control'' in the use of alcohol or drugs.

title: THE NATION: The Liberal Myth; Whining and Dining Out As Hollywood Conservatives
description: IF you want to know what is wrong with the movie business, just ask Lionel Chetwynd. Mr. Chetwynd has written the scripts for more than a dozen successful movies and says he has been frustrated in his efforts to take his career a step higher. The problem is not quality, he argued -- his films like ''The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz'' and ''Kissinger and Nixon'' have won widespread praise.

title: THE NATION: Oh, THAT George Bush; Wins of the Father Are Visited on the Son
description: MORE than two years before Election Day, polls say a Republican front-runner in the 2000 Presidential race has already emerged. He is a one-term Governor who has never run for national office but has, according to one recent poll, already overtaken Vice President Al Gore, the popular Democrat who has been running for the White House for 20 years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GITTELSON, NETTIE
description: GITTELSON-Nettie. Born NYC June 10, 1898. Devoted wife of Dr. Moses. Loving mom, mom-in-law, grandma and great-grandma. Happy 100th. Arthur, Stanley, Roger

title: Abraham Lincoln, Deadbeat
description: House Republicans last week excoriated their fellow Americans as a bunch of deadbeats casually running up debts and then disingenuously pleading bankruptcy to wipe their slates clean.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: A Board's Liability In a Lawsuit
description: SERIOUS concern arose in New York's co-op and condominium community last September after a Criminal Court judge in Brooklyn ruled that board members could be held personally liable for criminal charges brought against the co-op.

title: Yanks' Homework Adds Up With Top Draft Pick
description: Last year, the Yankees negotiated with their first-round pick, Tyrell Godwin, for more than three months before he rejected their offer of $1.9 million and went to college. Drafting in the same position in the first round this year -- 24th over all -- the Yankees selected Andy Brown, a prep outfielder, and Brown agreed to sign for $1.05 million on Friday, less than two weeks after the draft.

title: THE NATION: And the Survey Says...; Colleges Seek Glory In the Polling Game
description: THEY do not have the academic cachet of a Harvard, nor will they forever be identified with winning one for the Gipper like Notre Dame. But many unsung schools, including those with tongue-curling names like Quinnipiac College, have discovered a sly way to get themselves better known.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Scotch Plains, N.J.; A Town That Harkens to Simpler Times
description: THE three-block downtown of this community, along Park Avenue and Front and East Second Streets, seems to reach back to simpler times. Its 75 businesses include half a dozen antiques stores, two hobby shops, gift shops, a model-train store, a comic-book store, two shoe-repair shops, a doll hospital and a silversmith. Nearly all are housed in small 19th-century structures.

title: PRO BASKETBALL; Swoopes and Comets Spoil Liberty's Return
description: It was a day made for Teresa Weatherspoon. A day all about confidence and attitude; a day when Weatherspoon and her Liberty teammates could waltz into the Compaq Center and steal the day away from the Houston Comets.

title: No More Taxi Tips From Dr. Ruth
description: Listen up, New York taxi passengers. Soon, you're not going to have Dr. Ruth Westheimer to remind you to buckle up or take your possessions. Or Joan Rivers, Jackie Mason, Eartha Kitt or any of the rest of them. In this, the city of constant change, they're about to get the boot.

title: STARR ADMITS ROLE IN LEAKS TO PRESS
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating President Clinton, has acknowledged in a magazine interview that he and his aides have given information on the Monica Lewinsky matter to reporters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRAGUE, WILLIAM DOUGLAS
description: SPRAGUE-William Douglas. Age 84, beloved husband for 59 years of Helen (nee Mims), dear father of William Douglas Sprague, Jr. (Marilyn) of Devon, PA, Madelon Sprague of Twinsburg, OH., Marianne Paul of Aurora, OH., grandfather of Kathy Paul, Doug Sprague, Rob Paul, Andy Paul, Anne Sprague and Rob Sprague. Passed away on June 3, 1998. Doug Sprague was born in Springfield, Ohio and graduated from the U. of Wisconsin, Madison with a BBA. He earned his Master's in Tax at NYU and then received the Elijah Watt Sells Award in 1938 for achieving the second highest score on the CPA exam. He spent his career with Arthur Andersen, LLP, becoming a partner in 1950 and later Managing Partner of the New York office. He was President of the New York State Society of CPA's and an Executive Director of the Financial Accounting Standards Advisory Council from 1978-1983. He was President of the National Association of State Boards of Accountancy and received the William H. Van Rensselaer Public Service Award from NASBA in 1993. Private burial will be in the family cemetery in Plattsburg, Ohio. A Memorial Service will be held at All Souls Unitarian Church in New York City on Sunday, June 28, 1998 at 1:30 P.M. Contributions may be made to All Souls Church. For information call Stroud-Lawrence Funeral Home, Chagrin Falls, (440) 247-7575.

title: Waaay Up There: The New Upper Deck at Jones Beach
description: FROM the top row of the Jones Beach Theater, John and Sharon Fougner had a spectacular view of the full moon. To the east, the couple from East Williston could look along the barrier island chain to Robert Moses State Park, on the western tip of Fire Island. Zachs Bay and the Atlantic Ocean loomed in front of them. The lights of South Shore communities twinkled to the north.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: MESSAGE IN A BOTTLE By Nicholas Sparks. Warner, $20.

title: Assault Rifles: Dirt Cheap. . .and Legal!
description: Anderson's article is chilling, and more alarming than anything I have read documenting easy access to murderous weapons. Perhaps the coincidence of the article with the tragedy in Springfield, Ore., will awaken people to the need for some common-sense regulation of guns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYNARD, PAUL
description: MAYNARD-Paul. The Aaron Copland School of Music at Queens College deeply mourns the death of its distinguished faculty member, professor emeritus Paul Maynard, extraordinary musician, harpsichordist, organist and conductor. Coming to the College from a long professional career as keyboard player and conductor of the pioneer American early music ensemble New York Pro Musica, Professor Maynard was for many years the conductor of the Queens College Choir, Vocal Ensemble, and Collegium Musicum. His great artistry and insightful teaching will be long remembered by faculty and generations of students. Raymond Erickson, Dean of Arts and Humanities Hubert S. Howe, Jr., Director Faculty, Staff and Students

title: Geep Keogh and Anne Todd
description: Anne Caraway Todd, the daughter of Judge Alan Collier Todd and Mrs. Todd of Winter Park, Fla., was married there yesterday to Dr. George Paul Keogh 3d, the son of Mrs. Nicholas Noyes Solley of Washington, Conn., and the late Mr. Keogh Jr. The Rev. H. David Wilson performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church.

title: New Currency, New Opportunities
description: FROM his vantage point as the chief investment officer of Deutsche Bank, Hanspeter Ackermann sees expanding opportunities for investors in a unifying Europe. As portfolio manager of the bank's closed-end New Germany fund, a $665 million growth fund invested primarily in midsize German companies, Mr. Ackermann is deploying money to pursue some of those opportunities. And as a Swiss citizen, he sees firsthand the significance of being inside or outside the euro club. SHARON R. KING

title: Dogs on Duty, Help for the Police
description: ONE of the state's newest public memorials is also among its most unusual: A granite larger-than-life sculpture of a German shepherd standing over a crest of land in Byram Park in Greenwich, the dog's head turned sideways as if awaiting its master's command.

title: Attachment Theory: The Ultimate Experiment
description: Margaret Talbot's article about orphans adopted from eastern Europe was hauntingly sad (''Attachment Theory: The Ultimate Experiment,'' May 24). In all the years I've heard of people adopting these needy children, I imagined only happy endings. I never considered the possible lifelong trauma resulting from these children's neglected infancies.

title: Law Should Encourage Family Sites at Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: The Long-Running Musical of William Finn's Life
description: At the start of William Finn's latest musical, ''A New Brain,'' a Finn-like songwriter named Gordon Schwinn wrestles with something called the spring song for a children's TV entertainer. Minutes later, having dashed away from his piano to meet a friend for lunch, he puts down his fork, sings woozily, ''Something is. . .very. . .wrong,'' and collapses into his ziti.

The first Society president to bring professional business experience to the volunteer role, Mrs. Stevens presided over a series of successful fundraising events to celebrate The Society's tenth anniversary, initiated patient care programs, and the creation of handbooks for patients, and oversaw the hospital's Gift Shop. Nancy Stevens was an active member of the Past Presidents Committee until shortly before her death. Her wisdom, experience and good spirits will be sorely missed. Mrs. Coleman P. Burke, President The Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

Fountain, of the Fountain National Academy of Professional Embalming Skills in Springfield, Mo., will discuss ''identification of the dead'' after natural and man-made disasters. * Natural disasters have killed 181 people this year in the United States; there have been more than 600 tornadoes. * Are we in jinxed times? ''It's been a pretty good year so far, not a lot of terrorism,'' says Matthew Blais, a nuclear-terrorism expert. ''But there are a lot of crazy people out there, saving up for the big one. He was a President pining for a legacy, and race had been the special burden and pain of his South. The first romances, so called, date back to the 12th century, when the courts of an increasingly sophisticated Europe began to thrill to action-packed, heart-tugging verse-tales of a distinctly secular bent. Although the poems brought together Celtic legends, Arabic imagery and classical flights of rhetoric, they were united in a single theme: love passionate, ennobling and invariably thwarted. Sigh.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Soldier of Fortune
description: Robert Poley, the narrator of Mike Nicol's fourth novel, THE IBIS TAPESTRY (Knopf, $23), is a South African writer who makes a good living cranking out political thrillers. But while Poley's career may be going well, his personal life is deeply troubled -- so when he's sent a mysterious laptop computer containing a single file, it seems an irresistible diversion. Who is Christo Mercer, author of the file (which contains a dreamlike story about a shellshocked African tapestry maker and the violent deaths of four young girls), and why was he killed? As Poley attempts to answer these questions, he is drawn into the underground world of gunrunning, which has been made even more tumultuous by the end of apartheid. Mercer, it turns out, supplied weapons to rebels and bandits all over Africa, and was himself a soldier in some of South Africa's nastier conflicts. But he was also a poet obsessed with Elizabethan literature, particularly Christopher Marlowe's ''Tamburlaine the Great.'' Thus Poley's investigation quickly becomes an engaging mix of academic criticism and gritty detective work. Complex, colorful and intricately layered, ''The Ibis Tapestry'' plays skillfully with truth and fiction to portray the landscape of a nation undergoing revolutionary change. Cast as a collection of texts and notes for a novel, the book moves from Africa to England and points in between, breathing life into a wide range of characters directly and indirectly affected by the elusive Mr. Mercer. Erik Burns

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBO, FRANCIS
description: DOBO-Francis. His wife & loving companion of fifty-six years, Bita & his son, Michael note with great sadness the passing of Francis Ferenc (Frank) Dobo Wednesday, June 3rd in his 90th year, after a protracted illness. Born Christmas Day, 1908 in Nagykanizsa, Hungary, to Dezso Dobo, M.D., and Aranka Weiss, cherished younger brother to Istvan, Frank Dobo grew to become the epitome of a 20th Century intellectual. A nephew of the celebrated rare book dealer Gabriel Wells, he was a close, lifelong friend of the renowned Hungarian Masters of candid black & white photography, Jules Halasz (a.k.a. Brassai), and Andre Kertesz, as well as noted novelists, Henry Miller, Celine and Raymond Queneau. Frank shared their halcyon days in early 1930's Paris and, as the latter's U.S. agent, he was instrumental in bringing Queneau's novels, including his celebrated ''Zazi Dans Le Metro'' to readers worldwide. His unquenchable thirst for and consumption of contemporary literature led Frank to hold numerous affiliated vocations over the course of his long life. Commencing as a stringer for the Opera Mundi Press Service and Paul Winkler's Agence Literaire in Paris, he then journeyed to New York City where he utilised his multi-linguistic talents to produce and direct radio broadcasts for the Office of War Information, (O.W.I.), with John Houseman, among others. He went on to hold executive positions with King Features Syndicate, Latham Press, Arno Press, (a publishing subsidiary of The New York Times), Eugene Fodor's/Shell Travel Guides U.S.A. and with his esteemed associate and friend, Michael Gladstone, at The Publishing Center For Cultural Resources. A patron of The New York Public Library and a genuine world citizen who once professed no other god than Johann Sebastian BAch, Frank Dobo was an individual who truly personified the maxim, ''Less is More.'' His passing leaves an irreparable hole in the hearts of his family and friends, who will miss his enduring intellect and wit, and leaves the international literary community much the poorer. A memorial service is planned for the Fall.

title: It Just Looks Paranoid
description: Pretend for a minute that you're an alien, sent to Earth to assess its suitability for takeover. Right away you'd notice that the black earthlings and the white earthlings tend to live apart; that they both worship particularly large earthlings in open-air stadiums and that earthlings residing outside the crowded urban centers broil sacrificial meats on little outdoor altars. Eventually you'd pick up on smaller, possibly more significant things -- Sunday evening, for example, and how in many households as the hour of 9 approaches, the eating utensils are quickly and ceremoniously cleansed and stored and the younger offspring are clothed in loose-fitting cotton garments and then made to lie dormant in darkened chambers, while the elders and the proto-elders (many of them adorned with bits of metal on their teeth) drift into their communications centers, as if in answer to the eerie whistling music now emanating from their cathode-ray scopes, and for the next 60 minutes or so remain motionless, enraptured, while contemplating images of other earthlings engaged in negotiations with. . . aliens just like you, with the same long spatulate fingers, the same greenish ichor coursing through their cooling systems! In such a case, you'd probably conclude that you had arrived too late, and that the earthlings had already been colonized.

A distinguished lawyer, diplomat and economist, he worked for the United Nations and governments around the world to promote economic development. description: DELLAROCCA-Dominic. Beloved father of Shelley Aprea and Peter. Cherished grandfather of Joanna and Jacqueline. Reposing at Colonial Funeral Home, 2819 Hylan Blvd., SI, NY, Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Interment Tuesday, St. Gertrude's Cemetery, Colonnia, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINCUS, JULIA L.
description: PINCUS-Julia L. On June 13, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Lester. Loving mother of Honorable Edward K. Pincus and Elaine Sacks. Cherished grandmother of Andrea Pincus Multer, David H. Pincus and Wendy Weiss. Great-grandmother of Jake, Elisheva, Sara, Orah, Ari, Rivka, Zevi, Dani and Devora. Services Tuesday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a dispute over the number of retarded adults living in homeless shelters in New York gave conflicting figures for a state list's tally of the total. The list said there were 138 adults, not 75.

title: Sports of The Times; At the End, Jordan Lifts Bulls To Their Sixth N.B.A. Title
description: If this was the end, it looked suspiciously like the beginning. Michael Jordan against the world, a celebrated solo act. But even with his odds reduced by age, by Scottie Pippen's injured back, this wasn't the place, or the time, for Jordan to surrender pro basketball supremacy to a couple of reticent stars who only come out to play. Why? The world's most famously successful athlete willed it that way.

title: Reg Smythe, 81, British Cartoonist Who Created 'Andy Capp' Strip
description: Reg Smythe, the British cartoonist who invented the internationally popular character Andy Capp and drew comic strips about him for more than four decades, died on Saturday at his home in Hartlepool in northeastern England. He was 81.

title: Juneau Wants A Team Effort
description: In the wake of the Capitals' 2-1 loss to Detroit on Saturday night in Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals, Joe Juneau said yesterday that maximum effort was lacking from some of his teammates.

title: 2-Year Inspection Stickers For Cars Are Delayed
description: The State Department of Transportation will not begin granting two-year motor vehicle inspection stickers on July 1, as it had promised.

title: It's a Techno World, With Nothing to Fear From Gears and Switches
description: Perhaps there's nothing in the world so unfairly typecast as the machine. There's a classic perception that we turn to it in moments of paranoia, greed, envy, fear, self-aggrandizement. It's second nature: Love is human, hatred is enginelike; to become the perfect worker, to adopt a mind of gears and switches, is futile and dangerous.

title: Pippen's Pain Pushes Jordan to Greatest Feat
description: The limping Scottie Pippen worked his way through the pack surrounding a fatigued but elated Michael Jordan and embraced him with the most gingerly of hugs when it was over.

title: Jim Hearn, 77, Giants Pitcher Who Helped Win '51 Pennant
description: Jim Hearn, a right-handed pitcher who helped propel the New York Giants to victory in a dramatic 1951 National League pennant race with the Brooklyn Dodgers a year after his career was seemingly ending, died Wednesday at his winter home in Boca Grande, Fla. He was 77.

title: Compressed Data; Possible Purchase of Bay By Nortel Faces Hurdles
description: One of the more persistent financial technology stories over the last few months has been that Northern Telecom of Canada, the big maker of telephone equipment, has been in talks to acquire Bay Networks Inc., the not-as-big maker of computer networking gear.

title: New York Region Steps Up Efforts for Bilingual Classes
description: As California prepares to dismantle bilingual education for immigrant children, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are moving in the opposite direction, with plans to improve and even expand bilingual and intensive English programs in public schools.

title: Most Approve Of Microsoft, A Poll Shows
description: The Government's antitrust battle against the Microsoft Corporation has not tarnished the company's reputation as an outstanding business that makes high-quality products. But according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, a majority of Americans do think that Microsoft is a monopoly and that the Justice Department should continue to investigate the company and its business practices.

title: Bridge; Tragedy Isn't Shakespearean; But Still, the Play's the Thing
description: Tragedies are much more common at the bridge-table than they are in Shakespeare. The ultimate in this, the ''Hamlet'' of the tournament world, may be this plot line: You play a very difficult hand superbly, better than a group of world-class performers, but at the last moment, with a prize in sight for the best-played hand of the year, you pull out the wrong card and go down.

title: The Churning World of High School Fantasies
description: In ''Stupid Kids,'' a peppy little satire of high school life, the playwright John C. Russell gets the opera of adolescence to a T. ''It's only sixth period, there's still time to do what's right!'' says the hyperemotional cheerleader type who's dating the hunky greaser. ''Anything I say now,'' she exclaims in another moment of wide-eyed melodrama, ''could be a lie in half an hour!''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVEE, FRANCES
description: LEVEE-Frances. It's been five years, Grandma, and not a day goes by where I don't think of you. Michael

title: Emotional Major League Debut for Ledee
description: One nice thing about a season in which the Yankees have all but taken care of the big picture before mid-June is that their runaway success allows time for the little portraits that put a human face on what is otherwise a relentless machine.

title: The Parade of the Plastic Soldiers
description: TOY WARS

title: Hayes Wins Showdown With Furyk in Buick
description: As the pressure mounted during the final holes of the Buick Classic today, J. P. Hayes had reasons to doubt himself.

title: A seminar examines the plethora of prescription drug pitches since regulations were loosened.
description: THE proliferation of prescription drug pitches aimed directly at consumers has become one of the hottest topics in advertising. So it was not unexpected that a seminar on the subject, attended by more than 200 agency and pharmaceutical industry executives, should generate its share of Zoloft zingers, the Rx equivalents of Maalox moments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOBEL, ISADOR
description: ZOBEL-Isador. 89, passed away June 13, 1998. Survivors, children, Dr. Judith Zobel Feigin and husband Dr. Ralph D. Feigin, Joyce Zobel Opper and husband Edward Opper. Eight grandchildren; three great-grandchildren. He was an attorney and outstanding educator who for many years served as principal in several New York City schools where he introduced model educational programs that have been emulated nationally. Funeral services 1 PM, Tuesday, in Houston, TX, Levy Funeral Directors, 4525 Bissonnet, Bellaire, TX 77401. Call 713-660-6633 for information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, CATHARINE
description: STEVENS-Catharine. June 12, 1998, in Westborough, MA. Late Lt. Commander, U.S. Navy; Founder and President of Stevens Consultants Management, NYC. Survived by sisters Dorothy Hickox and George ''Petty'' Forrestall, both of MA; numerous nieces and nephews. Services at 1 PM, today, in the Forsyth Chapel of Forest Hills Cemetery, Boston. Interment in the family lot to follow. Visiting hour from 12 noon to 1 PM. Memorials to Tufts University Scholarship Fund, University Avenue, Medford, MA 02155. Call Manzi Funeral Home, Worcester, MA, 508-754-5400, for information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSHEL, IRVING
description: KUSHEL-Irving. Beloved husband to Jeanette. Adored father to Roy, Dan and Lynn. Proud grandpa to Jeremy and Jethro. Humor, selfless, integrity, menschlichkeit. Gently passed June 11.

title: Gambling Is Not a Character Flaw
description: To the Editor:

title: Woodman, Don't Spare That Tree! It Doesn't Belong in South Africa
description: ''What tree is that?'' calls Diane Sheard, environmental education officer at the Reitfontein Nature Reserve in the leafy Johannesburg suburbs.

title: Media Talk; In a Brief Episode, One More Sinatra Book for the Road
description: Between the time Frank Sinatra died on May 14 and the television specials began, American publishers revved up the presses. In death was the possibility of life: out-of-print titles resuscitated; existing books given extra sales; unpublished death-watch titles finalized for quick release.

title: Gambling Is Not a Character Flaw; Smoking Is Different
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUB, MAURIE A.
description: STRAUB-Maurie A. Died June 12, 1998. Loving husband of Billie. Devoted father of Peter. Dear brother of Robert and Janet. He will be greatly missed by his extended family and close friends. Memorial service Monday 1 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Media Talk; Just Talking: Public Broadcasting
description: For a year, Representative W. J. (Billy) Tauzin has been trumpeting his idea for how to keep money flowing to public television and radio without draining the Federal budget: a trust fund, perhaps endowed by fees charged to commercial broadcasters. But the proposal has attracted little support in Congress.

title: Media Talk; Dialing Sister Souljah at WLIB
description: Sister Souljah, the musician, writer, political activist and avowed ''outlaw,'' found herself as a guest host on the noon talk show at WLIB-AM, the black-owned station in New York City, in a week of particularly incendiary news. In New York, the family of Yusuf K. Hawkins had received a letter of apology from Keith Mondello, a member of a white gang who was recently released after eight years in prison for his role in killing the black teen-ager in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn in 1989. And in Texas, the father of one of three white men arrested in the torture-slaying of a black man apologized for his son's actions.

title: East and West in a Noisy Confluence of Cultures
description: When a subway rumbled under the Taipei Theater in the McGraw-Hill Building on the Avenue of the Americas on Friday evening, punctuating a performance by Taipei Percussion, it seemed utterly natural. If the composers had known that such a resource was available, they might have written it into a score, for they used everything else imaginable from an arsenal crammed onto the tiny stage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAND, EDYTHE
description: GRAND-Edythe. On June 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Harris Grand. Services Tuesday, June 16, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: End Court Secrecy
description: To the Editor:

title: School Ruling Shakes Milwaukee
description: It was the last week of school, and students and teachers were absorbed in final exams and celebratory field trips. The biggest local story was the invasion of 100,000 motorcycle riders for the 95th anniversary of Milwaukee's own Harley-Davidson Inc.

title: PLAN TO GO PUBLIC AT GOLDMAN, SACHS
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, Wall Street's last big private investment bank and by many measures its most successful, plans to announce today that it will end the firm's 130-year partnership by becoming a public company, according to people close to the firm.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Monday about Shirley Polykoff, the advertising woman who devised the slogan ''Does she . . . or doesn't she?'' in 1956 to advertise hair coloring products, referred incorrectly to the ownership of the advertiser, Clairol. The company was independent at the time. It was acquired in 1959 by the Bristol-Myers Company, now Bristol-Myers Squibb.

title: Microsoft Admirers Are Also Detractors
description: A majority of Americans have great admiration for the accomplishments of the Microsoft Corporation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. But 53 percent of the 1,126 adults surveyed June 7 to 9 think that Microsoft has a monopoly on computer software and many say it would be bad if it monopolized the Internet browser business. And 60 percent of those polled want the Justice Department to continue investigating the company.

title: Ferry Company Adds Two Manhattan Routes
description: New York Waterway, the private ferry company, is adding two routes to and from lower Manhattan this week, one that connects with Jersey City and another with the Gateway National Recreation Area in Sandy Hook, N.J., company officials said.

title: With a New Smart Suite, Lotus Chases Its Rivals' Success
description: This week the Lotus Development Corporation will begin shipping the Smart Suite Millennium Edition, which includes the latest version of the 1-2-3 spreadsheet program, word processing, data base, graphics and other productivity software. The question is does anyone care.

title: The Bullpen Squanders Nomo's Gem
description: On a searing subtropical afternoon, Hideo Nomo did his part. But the Mets' bullpen wasn't nearly as effective.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, KATHRYN
description: BARRY-Kathryn. Formerly of Bronxville, NY, on June 13, 1998. Wife of the late Desmond T. Barry. Mother of Kathryn Barry Dobbs, Patricia Barry Eigo, Maureen Barry Meaney and Desmond T. Barry, Jr. Grandmother of 16. Great-grandmother of 25. Calling hours at Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home in Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Monday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Tuesday, June 16, at 10 AM.

title: Baptists Are Right On Spousal Roles
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When people talk, I want to know what they're talking about. Otherwise, you're lost in your own world, one of those people saying, 'We used to do this and we used to do that.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, MICHAEL M.
description: RAND-Michael M. On June 13, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Ida K. Rand. Dear brother of Frances and brother-in-law of Ronald Leventhal. Services will be held graveside, Tuesday, June 16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENLEIGH, FRANCES N.
description: GREENLEIGH-Frances N. On June 14, 1998. Of Rockville, MD. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Greenleigh. Mother of Stephen and Judith Greenleigh and Esther Greenleigh Prince and grandmother of Joshua Prince, Andrea Jill Greenleigh and David Greenleigh. Graveside services held at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY, on Monday, June 15. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCKINLEY, SELMA ANDERSON
description: McKINLEY-Selma Anderson. Sixteen years, dearest momma. Life has never been the same. I love you always.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOWSHOWITZ, LIBBY
description: MOWSHOWITZ-Libby. We deeply mourn Libby's passing, a sister-inlaw rare beyond compare. She possessed a brilliant mind and a caring heart often expressed with a fine sense of humor. Her life was totally devoted to her husband, the eminent Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz, to her family and to the community. She served as a model and a guide to us all. We shall miss her greatly. Frieda Mowshowitz and Max Pusin

title: Toll Discounts Are Likely For Trucks on Turnpike
description: To ease rush-hour congestion and reduce truck traffic on local roads, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority is expected to offer toll discounts for trucks during off-peak hours, with the possibility of similar discounts for all motorists once the E-Z Pass toll system is installed on the turnpike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, HELEN V.
description: ROSEN-Helen V. Of New York. Died June 12, at the age of 91. Mrs. Rosen assisted her husband, the renowned ear surgeon Dr. Samuel Rosen, during his travels around the world teaching his new surgical procedure to relieve a common form of deafness. Dr. and Mrs. Rosen were honored by many countries, and, in 1971, became among the first Americans invited to visit the People's Republic of China. A lifelong progressive activist, Mrs. Rosen was one of the last and closest friends of the late singer and actor Paul Robeson and was the focus of considerable media attention in connection with this year's 100th anniversary of Mr. Robeson's birth. She was the daughter of Julia and Emmanuel VanDernoot, mother of Dr. John F. Rosen and the late Judith Ruben, grandmother of five and great-grandmother of four. Contributions in her memory can be given to the Ramapo-Anchorage Camp, PO Box 266, Rhinebeck, NY 12572. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, NATHANIEL
description: BECKER-Nathaniel. Of Hollywood, FL. Died in his 94th year, on June 13, 1998. Beloved husband for 69 years to his sweetheart and dancing partner Selma. Loving father to Harriet and Ira Teper, Joel and Dorothy Becker and Richard Becker. Cherished grandfather to Melissa Teper, Laurie Becker and Paul Berkelhammer, Wendy and Michael Zucker and Jeffrey and Joanne Levine. Loving great-grandfather to Jennie and Bryan Levine and Joshua and Sarah Zucker. Caring brother-inlaw to Pearl Kohnop. A testament to this thoughtful and generous man lives in the warm memories his many nieces, nephews, friends and acquaintances in New York and Florida will hold in their hearts. Services at I. J. Morris, Deer Park Ave, Dix Hills, NY, 12:15 PM, Monday, June 15.

title: What to Do About China
description: For more than a decade many concerned observers have warned of the dangers in reaching a one-sided rapprochement with China. Invariably, such trepidations have been minimized by ''pragmatic'' political voices, or shouted down by business leaders who were seduced by China's vast potential market only to become hostages should our policies toward that country turn more confrontational.

title: Maria Reiche, 95, Keeper of an Ancient Peruvian Puzzle, Dies
description: Maria Reiche, who spent half a century as the self-appointed guardian of an obscure pre-Incan culture's most mysterious legacy -- a vast, dazzling tableau of giant birds, animals, plants and intricate geometric patterns scratched into the stark desert floor -- died on June 8 in a hospital in Lima, Peru. She was 95 and was known as the Lady of the Lines.

title: Media Talk; Now, Three Stooges Beer
description: Do Stooges spring eternal?

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, NANCY (MRS. JOHN E.)
description: STEVENS-Nancy (Mrs. John E.). The Boards of Overseers and Managers are deeply saddened by the death of Nancy Stevens. Mrs. Stevens, in her role as president of The Society of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center from 1955-1957, developed imaginative fund-raising programs and important initiatives to enhance patient comfort. Her handiwork is still evident today. She will be missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Laurance S. Rockefeller Honorary Co-Chairman Benno C. Schmidt Honorary Co-Chairman James D. Robinson III Honorary Co-Chairman Douglas A. Warner III Chairman H. Virgil Sherrill Vice Chairman Richard L. Gelb Vice Chairman Paul A. Marks, M.D. President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: End Court Secrecy
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Federal Grants To Colleges Are Resurging
description: This year the University of West Alabama will receive a grant of $300,000 from the Department of Agriculture for research on the disposal of poultry carcasses. The University of Maine will receive $220,000, also from the Department of Agriculture, for research on low-bush blueberries.

title: Weight-Loss Drug Shows Some Success in Humans
description: A potential anti-obesity drug being developed by Amgen Inc., which made headlines a few years ago by sharply reducing body fat in mice, has now been found to contribute to weight loss in people as well, scientists reported yesterday.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week

title: A Day for Puerto Rican Flag, and Pride, to Soar
description: Despite a steady downpour, Fifth Avenue echoed with the syncopated beats of salsa, flamenco and hip-hop as hundreds of thousands of people clad in every conceivable form of their island's flag danced, cheered and sang along yesterday at the 41st annual Puerto Rican Day parade.

title: Antiquated Weapons in War Against Sprawl
description: To the Editor:

title: Christopher Shays's Moment
description: When Newt Gingrich was a little-known back-bencher in the House, he promised open and democratic procedures if the Republicans ever won control. Last week, as this page warned, the Speaker betrayed those principles and began his filibuster-by-amendment scheme to block campaign finance legislation. We raise the matter again today because it is time for reform-minded House members to revive the petition that forced Mr. Gingrich back in April to promise an honest game.

title: Helms Pulls Diplomatic Lever To Move Clinton on U.N. Bill
description: When a foreign embassy needs a favor from Congress, diplomats can appeal to no higher authority on international affairs than Senator Jesse Helms. But private audiences with the powerful North Carolina Republican, who heads the Foreign Relations Committee, and his top aides are hard to come by.

title: A New Sign in the Suburbs: Sold Out; Buyers Are Scrambling to Find Houses in a Booming Market
description: Buying a house was not how Ron Shriberg planned to spend his Sunday morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MARTIN
description: STONE-Martin. Communications visionary. He excelled at television, cable, the law and public service. But radio was his most enduring passion. He taught generations of broadcasters that a radio station could be more than a juke box and achieve a higher calling when it resembles a forum for the expression of many different viewpoints. We mourn the loss of the founding father of community radio. But we will never forget the lessons of our friend and mentor. Whitney Radio WVOX & WRTN Nancy & William O'Shaughnessy

title: U.S. Will Pay Reparations to Former Latin American Internees
description: The Federal Government has agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit filed on behalf of 1,200 Latin Americans of Japanese descent who were forcibly brought to the United States and placed in internment camps during World War II.

title: Gambling Is Not a Character Flaw; Family Entertainment
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PIKARSKY, MILTON
description: PIKARSKY-Milton 3/28/24-6/15/89. Beloved brother, a very special man, deeply loved, always remembered. Ruth

title: Paris Journal; Shaded by Gargoyles, the Exorcist of Notre Dame
description: At first sight, the exorcist of Notre Dame does not seem capable of frightening anyone, let alone the Devil. The Rev. Claude Nicolas is portly and quick-witted and has a merry laugh, a sort of Gallic Friar Tuck. But casting off demons is precisely his task as the resident exorcist of Paris' great medieval cathedral.

title: CONFERENCE OPENS ON CREATING COURT TO TRY WAR CRIMES
description: In one of the most ambitious efforts ever undertaken to extend the rule of international law, the United Nations will open a conference here on Monday to thrash out rules for an international court to prosecute crimes against humanity.

title: THIS WEEK
description: Time and Again

title: Asia's Crisis Upsets Rising Effort To Confront Blight of Sweatshops
description: Just as pressure is growing in the West against the use of sweatshops in developing countries, the Asian financial crisis is spawning such desperation that more people than ever seem willing to take grim or dangerous jobs in such factories.

title: As Martin Passes Him By, Gordon Complains of a Plot
description: As Mark Martin celebrated his victory today at Michigan Speedway, Jeff Gordon stood behind his trailer in the garage and claimed there had been a conspiracy. For the second straight week, Gordon fell victim to a strange turn of events.

title: Rhein Fire Beats Frankfurt Galaxy
description: Jim Arellanes had thrown one pass for the Rhein Fire all season. Last night he threw 18 more, three of them for touchdowns, and led the Rhein Fire to a 34-10 victory over the Frankfurt Galaxy in the fourth World Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINGER, KENNETH
description: FINGER-Kenneth. Age 40. Suddenly on June 10, 1998. Beloved husband of Susan. Adoring father of Adam. Devoted son of Chet (Hariett). Dear brother of Lauren. Predeceased by his loving mother Bernice. Services were held in Florida.

title: Water Projects' Bill Worries Even Environmentalists
description: New York City has embarked on an array of water and sewer projects whose cost will raise water bills so high over the next 10 years that even environmentalists are beginning to raise alarms.

title: New York Is Experiencing the Second-Wettest Year on Record
description: The sense of gloom, endless drizzle and inescapable dampness hanging over New York is more than a gnawing hunch. Meteorologists made it official yesterday: Figures show that New York is experiencing the second-wettest year since records were first kept in 1869. Only the first five months of 1983 were damper.

title: The Squid on Central Park West
description: Blanched in death, with a rising odor, a giant squid -- one of the best-preserved examples of this rarely seen species -- lay thawing on a plastic-sheathed workroom floor at the American Museum of Natural History last week. A worker misted its arms and tentacles with a spray bottle. Another gently turned the tip of a 20-foot tentacle to photograph the squid's suckers. A press photographer straddled the head and aimed his flash directly at the visually confusing region where head and mantle become mouth and arms.

title: This Time, Los Angeles May Lose Water War
description: ''It's not that you can't breathe,'' said Mark McCall, with gallows humor befitting a prematurely grizzled 49-year-old resident of this dusty village in the Owens Valley. ''You just don't want to.''

title: Bronx Woman Is Accused Of Beating Baby Girl
description: A 25-year-old Bronx woman has been arrested on charges that she beat her 4-month-old daughter until the baby's skull was fractured, the police said yesterday.

title: Music That Goes for the Communal Thrill
description: The drummer Bobby Previte started his set on Thursday night in the Main Space of the Knitting Factory, part of the Texaco New York Jazz Festival, with a piece that worked in canon. The band, including Wayne Horvitz on piano, Ray Anderson on trombone, Mary Ehrlich on tenor saxophone and Bob Stewart on tuba, cycled through repeated ideas, churning the music and layering glazed color on glazed color. Mr. Previte improvised within the bound horns, making his brushes produce percussive sibilants; by the end of the piece, he had entered territory that was his own.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about computer use by elderly people misstated the location of a retirement community that is installing high-speed modems. It is in Laguna Hills, Calif., not Akron, Ohio.

title: Burnett Bows Out Of Glad Account
description: Another long relationship between an advertiser and an agency is ending as the Leo Burnett USA unit of the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago has resigned the Glad brand account of the First Brands Corporation in Danbury, Conn., after working on campaigns for Glad plastic products since 1961.

title: Plain Language? No Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; Wild in the Country
description: When future archeologists dig up Albania, they will surely wonder what earthquake occurred here in the 1990's that produced the bizarre layer cake that is Albania today. They will find Communist-era concrete bunkers now decorated with ''I love Leonardo DiCaprio'' graffiti. They will find a building in Tirana still bearing the washed-out slogans of Albania's former Stalinist regime -- slogans like ''Organization is the bedrock on which the party sits'' -- overlooking a parking lot full of stolen Mercedeses. (It is said that 80 percent of the cars in Albania today were stolen from somewhere in Europe and then resold here.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINFELD, ROSE
description: WEINFELD-Rose. On June 14, 1998. Beloved mother of Ed and Deanne, David and Monica. Cherished grandmother of Scott and Ilene, Steven and Tammy, Andy and Cynthia, Sharon, Valerie, Patti and Rich, Diana and Greg. Adored great grandmother of Danny, Jack and Ross Weinfeld. Loving sister of Bernard and Sylvia Jacowitz and Claire and William Rosenblatt. Her wise counsel, sweet smile and constant support will be remembered by all who knew her. Funeral service 9:30 AM Tuesday, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave, (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREED, LARRY
description: FREED-Larry. Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, New York mourns the death of our dear friend and member and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Sheila and daughters Diana and Alicia. May God comfort and strenghten them. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster Stanley Shanies, Pres.

title: Ex-Schools Chancellor Gets a New Post
description: Anthony J. Alvarado, a former New York City Schools Chancellor who resigned amid questions of financial misconduct but later earned national distinction as the leader of an innovative Manhattan school district, announced yesterday that he would leave New York's public schools next month to become the second-in-command of the San Diego school system.

title: MATTEL AGREES TO BUY MAKER OF AMERICAN GIRL DOLLS
description: Mattel Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Pleasant Company, the maker of the American Girl line of dolls, for $700 million. Pleasant, based in Middleton, Wis., also produces books, clothing, accessories and activity products. It has annual revenue of $300 million. Mattel, based in El Segundo, Calif., makes the Barbie and Fisher-Price toy lines. It had $4.83 billion in sales in 1997. Mattel also said yesterday that it expected its earnings for the second quarter to fall short of expectations, citing a change in the buying practices of Toys ''R'' Us Inc.

title: Sports of The Times; Jordan Proves It Takes More Than Legs
description: THE pull-up jump shot, once a fundamental basketball staple, reminded us Sunday night that while Michael Jordan has dominated the Generation X 1990's, his career began in an era that looked very different from this one. When Jordan used his left shoulder and hand to force the defender Bryon Russell to move left, then backward, he was dating himself as a player who did not grow up with 24-hour cable networks, with continuous reels of 3-point shots and frantic assaults on a pliable rim.

title: Officer in Squeegee Man Shooting Has a Civilian Complaint Record
description: The New York City police officer who was charged yesterday with the off-duty shooting of a squeegee man in the Bronx on Sunday evening was removed from patrol duty earlier this year because he had accumulated an unusually high number of complaints of using excessive force against civilians, the police said.

title: The Last Skirmish For the New Jersey; Sites in State Compete for the Right To Make the Battleship a Museum
description: To devotees of naval history, America's great battleships are proud symbols of an era when hulking vessels could unnerve the most belligerent of enemies simply by bellying up to their coastlines, when global power was won at sea and diplomacy rested on the shoulders of admirals.

title: International Language of Physics Ties Physicists' Tongues
description: THE language of physics, as spoken at international conferences like the one last week where the discovery of neutrino mass was announced, is becoming difficult even for physicists to understand.

title: Sunbeam's Board, in Revolt, Ousts Job-Cutting Chairman
description: For years, Albert J. Dunlap has been one of the nation's most feared corporate executives. He downsized with a vengeance, frequently boasting of the thousands he had thrown out of work to lift a company's stock price, earning himself the nickname Chain Saw Al.

title: Hooked on Collectibles and the Bottom Line
description: FOLKS attending the Sotheby's collectors' auction on Saturday, encountering a poem written by 11-year-old Elvis Presley to a grammar-school mate (it sold for $5,500) or Ella Fitzgerald's ''Personal and Professional Card Collection'' (including Diners Club and Screen Actors Guild, it brought $600) may have wondered if there is anything in America that is not for sale.

title: DOW JONES TO INVEST $232 MILLION IN WALL STREET JOURNAL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKSON, MAX B. E.
description: CLARKSON-Max B. E., died on June 11, 1998, while vacationing with his wife Madeleine in Italy. Six days earlier they had celebrated their fiftieth wedding anniversary in the church in London, England, where they were married. He was born on October 14, 1922, in Lenzie, Scotland, and educated at Stowe School, England, and Trinity College, Toronto. After service in the Royal Canadian Navy during World War II, he earned an M.A. in English at the University of Toronto, then joined his father's printing firm, Technical Charts, Inc. in Buffalo. In 1957 the company was reorganized as Graphic Controls Corporation, with Max as President, and became a publiclyheld company in 1965. In 1962 he was the first Canadian to be elected president of the Printing Industries Association of America. Belief in the social responsibility of the corporation led him to cofound the Allentown Community Center in 1971. In 1988, after it began to provide services to people outside Allentown, it was renamed the Clarkson Center for Human Services and is now one of the largest social agencies for job training, day care, and seniors services in Western New York State. It was one of his proudest achievements. In 1975 he brought his experience in business to academia and joined the Faculty of Management, University of Toronto, as Dean (1975-80) and continued as Professor until he retired in 1988. At the Faculty he instituted and taught pioneering courses in corporate values and business ethics. In 1989 he founded the Centre for Corporate Social Performance and Ethics at the Faculty. The Centre sponsored several international conferences on the emerging field of stakeholder theory. In 1997 The Conway Chair in Business Ethics was established and the Centre was renamed the Clarkson Centre for Business Ethics. In 1971 Mr. Clarkson cofounded the Niagara Institute, where he gave seminars to leaders from all parts of Canadian society on human values in organizational life. In 1987 he helped found the Public Policy Forum in Ottawa. Mr. Clarkson's pathbreaking research and publications in the field of business ethics won him wide acclaim and invitations to many international conferences. He was awarded honorary doctorates by St. Mary's University, Halifax, and the State University of New York at Buffalo. He is survived by his wife, Madeleine Earls, son, Max Adam, daughter Helene Edith, and son-in-law Andrew Livingston, all of Toronto; one sister, Lilian de Arias of London; and four brothers, William M.E. of Buffalo, Austin E. of Toronto, Geoffrey P. E. of Pacific Palisades, California, and Stephen H.E. of Toronto. The funeral service will be held in the chapel of Trinity College, Hoskin Avenue, Toronto, at 11 a.m., Friday, June 19, 1998. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Clarkson Center for Human Services, 310 Delaware Avenue, Buffalo, NY 14202.

title: SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFIC TO BUY METALLURG FOR $300 MILLION
description: Metallurg Inc. agreed yesterday to be bought by an investor group led by Safeguard International Fund L.P. for $30 a share, or a total of about $300 million in cash. The investors also plan to assume about $150 million in debt. Safeguard International Fund is an affiliate of Safeguard Scientific Inc., based in Wayne, Pa., one of just a handful of publicly traded venture capital companies. Metallurg, formed in 1911, makes metal alloys, specialty metals and powders used in the production of steel, aluminum, titanium and other materials. Metallurg's shares rose $2.50 each, or 14 percent, to $19.75. Safeguard Scientific fell 43.75 cents, to $35.5625.

title: Michael's Last Hurrah?
description: The Chicago Bulls won their sixth basketball championship in eight years Sunday night, and once again the hard part was finding a story line that did not begin and end with Michael Jordan. There was Scottie Pippen, who basically quit during a couple of important games in years past but who this time played heroically despite injury. There was Karl Malone, a stubborn old warrior who almost carried the Utah Jazz to a seventh game by himself. There were the referees, whose odd calls near the end seemed to tilt in Jordan's favor. There was, finally, the dynastic question -- whether this was truly the end of the Bulls' great run of championships, or whether Jerry Reinsdorf, the team's owner, will cough up the $80 million necessary to keep Michael, Scottie and Phil Jackson, the coach, together.

title: Voices Sounding Like a Whole Band

McDonald & Company, also based in Cleveland, has 1,400 full-time employees and 44 offices in 11 states. With assets under management of more than $5 billion, it provides regional investment banking, brokerage and investment advisory services through its McDonald & Company Securities Inc. unit. Shares of McDonald & Company rose $2.125, to $32.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of Keycorp slipped $1.125, to $35.75, also on the Big Board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGE, AGNES M.
description: GEORGE-Agnes M., beloved wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, left this world on June 12. She died at National Healthcare Center, Panama City, FL. Born 1905 in the Bronx, New York, she was a unique and very beautiful lady. She was preceded in death by her husband, William H. George, Esq.; her parents, Mary & Robert McGeary; brother, Robert McGeary; and sister, Loretta Benson. Left to mourn her are daughters Marilyn Dobbins and husband Bobby, Gloria George, and Margaret Kilburn and husband Howard. She touched the lives of many, especially her grandchildren, Diana Sims, William Dobbins, Linda Von Tobel, and Susan Romano; and greatgrandchildren, Jennifer and Julie Sims. She is also survived by brothers Reginald and Thomas McGeary, as well as numerous nieces and nephews. She will be dearly missed by all who knew her. In her lifetime, Mrs. George attended Newtown High School in Corona, NY, and was a distinguished member of the first graduating class of St. John's University School of Law (Class of 1928). She gave up the practice of Law to raise a family, moving to Valley Stream in 1940. Gardening was a favorite pastime, as was ''the inevitable crocheting,'' and she was an avid stamp and coin collector. She hosted annual outdoor family reunion ''singalongs,'' chronicling each with a group photo. Mr. & Mrs. George were world travelers, and researched the family genealogy for eleven generations. Mrs. George was active with Court Bishop Molloy Catholic Daughters; Holy Name of Mary Rosary Society; Catholic Charities Division of Blind Services; Young at Heart; and V.I.P., for which she was piano accompanist. She was a church organist, a member of the Choral Group, and founder of the Valley Stream Creche Committee. In 1964, she spearheaded a petition to Congress to make Good Friday a National Day of Mourning. Her proudest civic accomplishment was as Founding Girl Scout Leader, Troop #

description: For the second time in less than two years, India's most famous artist, Maqbool Fida Husain, has become a target of the country's most militant Hindu activists. Early last month, members of the far-right Bajrang Dal, upset at a stylized portrait of a Hindu goddess, slipped into Mr. Husain's Bombay apartment, destroyed one painting and mauled several canvases before being arrested by the police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAFT, HELEN MARGARET, NEE GWYDIR
description: KRAFT-Helen Margaret, nee Gwydir, at home after a long illness. She was a Wellesley graduate, Class of 1948, and a long time resident of Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island. She is survived by her husband, Warren G., daughters Helen K. Buckwalter, Anne K. Thompson and sons Warren G. and John S. and nine grandchildren. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorials to the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, P.O. Box 100 (Development Office), Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. 11724, would be appreciated.

title: Science's Defining Moment
description: SCIENCE, it seems, defies description. At least that's what the American Physical Society discovered when it set out to try to define the term.

title: Annan Urges Formation of War Crimes Court
description: Warning that the eyes of past and future victims ''are fixed upon us,'' the United Nations Secretary General today urged establishment of a global war crimes court as a ''bulwark against evil.''

title: Guilty Pleas Are Expected in Office Construction Bid-Rigging
description: Five top executives and four companies in the construction industry have agreed to plead guilty to collecting kickbacks and rigging the bidding on billions of dollars in renovation work for many of the city's most powerful corporations during the 1990's, according to investigators and lawyers in the case.

title: As Japan Goes, So Goes the Neighborhood
description: As countries throughout Asia try to pick up the pieces of their economies, they are increasingly confronted with the disconcerting reality that recoveries are vulnerable to the frail Japanese economy and the downward path of the yen. What worries them is that both are completely beyond their control, and more worrying, perhaps beyond the control of the Japanese authorities.

title: A Smorgasbord Fit for a King
description: The Royal Swedish Ballet ended its 225th- anniversary festival on Saturday night here with a lively four-hour gala. During an eight-day marathon that included a delightful ''Nutcracker'' with a Swedish flavor, the company presented past and present repertory. The gala program did the same, with guest artists from France, Italy and Denmark, all countries whose dancers and ballet masters played a role in Swedish ballet history.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Friday with the continuation of a front-page article about declines in Asian economies misspelled the name of Thailand's currency in some copies. It is the baht, not the bhat.

title: By Design; Airy and Cool Crochet
description: Crocheted clothing and accessories, airy and cool-looking for summer, are part of fashion's move away from harsh minimalism.

title: Big German Bank Is Raided In a Search for Tax Cheats
description: Three hundred criminal investigators descended today on Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank, looking for evidence that bank executives helped wealthy customers illegally avoid taxes.

title: U.S. Drinking Itself Dry, Study Finds
description: AMERICANS may be literally drinking themselves into a state of dehydration, a new survey reports.

title: Disappointing Foes, Botha Will Not Testify at Inquiry Trial
description: Disappointing many South Africans who wanted to see one of apartheid's harshest leaders submit to cross-examination, lawyers for former President P. W. Botha began closing arguments in his contempt trial today without calling him or anyone else to the witness stand.

title: Turnpike Shooting Leads to Cameras in Patrol Cars
description: Responding to an outcry over the shooting of three young men by state troopers on the New Jersey Turnpike in April, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that all 245 state police cruisers that patrol New Jersey's toll roads would be equipped with video cameras.

title: Bill Seeks Certification For School Swim Classes
description: Prompted by the near-drowning of a Trenton boy in school, the Senate Education Committee approved a bill yesterday to require swimming instructors in public schools to be certified for swimming and water safety.

title: Rough Going For Maxis
description: Foul weather, broken gear and an ill skipper have interfered with the International Level Class Maxi-Yacht World Championships off Newport, R.I. But the competition continued yesterday, with Sayonara leading the four-boat fleet with two first-place finishes.

title: Judge Backs Cutler's Bid To Represent Gotti's Son
description: Bruce Cutler, the combative lawyer disqualified from defending John J. Gotti seven years ago for being too close to the mob, won a round for himself yesterday when a judge upheld his right to defend the son of the Dapper Don in a Federal racketeering case in Westchester County.

title: Flexibility and Planning Are Stressed in Chicago
description: In a small, windowless room in a welfare center on the South Side here, Elizabeth Matos is deciding what to do in the next month to progress from welfare to work.

title: Monsanto Cited In Crop Losses
description: Three Mississippi cotton farmers who planted genetically engineered seed, then watched as their cotton bolls shriveled and fell to the ground, should be paid more than $1.9 million by the Monsanto Company and two seed companies for their losses, an arbitration council of the Mississippi Department of Agriculture and Commerce ruled on Friday.

title: G.M. Closes More Plants; Talks Falter
description: General Motors' North American operations moved closer to being shut down completely today, as strikes at two Michigan parts factories forced the company to idle 13,000 more workers and partly close a host of other parts and assembly plants.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; For Sellers To Japanese, Worse Ahead
description: As the Japanese yen continued its slide toward the abyss yesterday, stock markets around the world trembled. So much for the idea that Asian problems could be contained.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRASSO, DOMINIC JOHN
description: GRASSO-Dominic John, 64. Died June 14, 1998, at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, New Brunswick, NJ, of complications following surgery for brain cancer. He was a resident of Princeton, NJ since 1979. Mr. Grasso was born in New York City and was the son of the late Mr. John D. Grasso and Mrs. Nancy Cicarelli Grasso. He attended the New York public schools, graduating from Evander Childs High School with honors. He was a graduate of Columbia College in 1955 with a B.A., and a graduate of Columbia University School of Engineering and Applied Science with a BS in 1956. He was awarded the Charles Hayden Memorial Scholarship. While there, he was a member of Phi Kappa Psi, and the Theta Tau Engineering Society. In 1963 he received a M.S. from Columbia University. In 1957 Mr. Grasso attended Naval Officers Candidate School in Newport, RI, and retired with 26 years of both active and reserve service. Stationed both at the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard and Bahrain Island in the Persian Gulf, he was attached to the Inspector of Naval Materials serving the Seventh Fleet. In 1961 he returned to the United States and remained on reserve duty, and in 1974 attained the rank of Commander, USNR. Mr. Grasso's civilian professional career after active duty in the USN began in 1961 when he joined ARCO in Philadelphia as a senior systems analyst. He later worked for Price Waterhouse & Co., Philadelphia as a Manager in Management Advisory Services. In 1969 he joined McKinsey & Co., NYC/Milan, as a Senior Manager, with engagements in the U.S. and Europe. In 1974 he was appointed Vice President & Controller for the Manufacturing Division of Melville Corp. in Nashua, NH, achieving its highest profitability to date. From 1979 until the present, Mr. Grasso worked as a consultant in strategic planning, telecommunications, and information systems for many Fortune 500 companies, government agencies, and schools of higher education. Mr. Grasso was a Registered Professional Engineer, a senior member of The American Institute of Industrial Engineers, and a member of The Wardroom Club, Boston. He was a member of Columbia University Secondary Schools Admissions Committee, and a private pilot and member of Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association. In earlier years he was an avid tennis player and skier. He is survived by his wife of 39 years, Mary Viola Grasso, a son and daughter-in-law, David J. Grasso and Lisa Hopkins Grasso of Phoenix, AZ, a daughter and son-in-law Dr. Paula Grasso Zollner and Dr. Gregory P. Zollner, two granddaughters Sarah Marie and Julia Rose Zollner, a sister Mary Saracco of New City, NY, a brother Edward J. Grasso of Chepachet, RI, and his late sister, Vincenzia Petrilli of Waterford, CT, seven nephews and 4 nieces and his childhood friend Donald Bolognese of New York City and Vermont. A funeral mass will be celebrated by Father John Zagarella on Thursday, June 18, at 11 a.m. at St. Thomas Aquinas Institute Chapel on Stockton Street at Library Place, Princeton, NJ. Burial at the Princeton Cemetery. For information, Kimble Funeral Home, 1 Hamilton Ave., Princeton. Memorial contributions may be made to the Columbia College Fund, POB 19023, NYC, 10277-0109; or The Aquinas Institute of Princeton University, Stockton Street at Library Place, Princeton, N.J., 08540.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, LARRY
description: MORRIS-Larry. On June 14, 1998 at the age of 87. Beloved husband of the late Libby. Adored father of Stephen and Marjorie. Dear father-in-law of Marlene. Loving grandfather of David, Gary, Allison and Eric. A pioneer in motion picture theatre exhibition. He will be deeply missed. Service 1:30PM Wednesday, June 17, 1998 at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

description: Stocks Fall to 3-Month Low On Growing Asian Concerns

title: Even as Stocks Plunge, Treasuries Soar to 30-Year High
description: Long-term Treasury rates fell to their lowest level in 30 years yesterday while other Government bond yields, including those that affect home mortgages, dropped sharply.

title: Q&A
description: Hot Stuff

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, EDYTHE
description: GOODMAN-Edythe. On June 15, 1998. Beloved wife of George. Loving mother of the late Harris James (Jimmy) and Nancy. Service and interment private.

title: Protecting Fetuses, Jailing Mothers
description: To the Editor:

title: TRIDEX AND SULCUS HOSPITALITY TECHNOLOGIES TO MERGE
description: The Tridex Corporation, which makes equipment used in retail sales, and the Sulcus Hospitality Technologies Corporation, which makes systems for processing data in the hospitality industry, said yesterday that they had agreed to a merger. Sulcus, based in Greensburg, Pa., serves the tourism industry. Tridex, based in Westport, Conn., provides sales and back-office management software and related services for food and specialty retailers.

title: The Eighth Roommate: A Camera
description: For children of the media age, who have grown up with MTV and ''Entertainment Tonight,'' the idea of living your life in front of a camera may not be astonishing. That's one reason MTV's cutting-edge series ''The Real World,'' which begins its seventh season tonight at 10, is central to the suddenly hot topic of how television and reality shape each other. More than ''The Truman Show,'' a wafer-thin hit movie pretending to be profound, and more than all the orchestrated ''Jerry Springer'' brawls put together, ''The Real World'' blurs the line between television and private life. More telling, it accepts that fuzzy line as a given.

title: The Rhythm And Rhyme Of Victory
description: To start with the winner after all, it was a contest -- the new heavyweight poetry champion of the world is Sherman Alexie, the 31-year-old American Indian writer from Spokane, Wash. Mr. Alexie wrested the crown from the two-time defending champ and the home-state favorite, Jimmy Santiago Baca, on Saturday night here, before a crowd of 700 whooping literati.

title: In Beijing Students' Worldview, Jordan Rules
description: It was class time at Beijing University, but at 10 this morning seven guys in shorts and T-shirts crowded around a color TV in dorm room 511, a spare cement cubicle decorated with three metal bunkbeds and yesterday's laundry. Nine student ''shareholders'' had bought the TV last month in anticipation of just such an occasion, and now hoots and jeers filled the air.

title: UNITRODE BALKS AT BID FOR BENCHMARQ MICROELECTRONICS
description: The shares of the Unitrode Corporation and Benchmarq Microelectronics Inc. moved in opposite directions yesterday after Unitrode's board withdrew a recommendation that shareholders approve a $135 million acquisition of Benchmarq. Unitrode's stock gained $1.3125, or 11 percent, to $12.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange, while shares of Benchmarq plunged $5.375, or 38 percent, to $8.625, in Nasdaq trading. Benchmarq, a maker of battery management products based in Dallas, also predicted second-quarter income from operations of 5 cents to 9 cents a share, citing revenue and margin declines. A consensus of three analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation had estimated the company's second-quarter earnings at 14 cents a share.

title: Mr. Starr Keeps Talking
description: If the art of public relations were a handgun, Kenneth Starr would have been footless long ago. The independent counsel has a perverse gift for talking when he should remain silent and for saying all the wrong things when he opens his mouth. An interview in which he confessed to giving information to reporters is the latest of Mr. Starr's golden bloopers. The interviewer, Steven Brill of Brill's Content magazine, argues that Mr. Starr broke the law against disclosure of grand jury information, and the White House weighed in with its usual pitch for investigating Mr. Starr rather than President Clinton.

title: $100 Million in Legal Services Funding Is Placed in Doubt by a Supreme Court Ruling
description: A sharply divided Supreme Court today cast constitutional doubt on state programs that generate $100 million a year for legal services for poor people by pooling the interest on some of the money that clients deposit for brief periods with their lawyers.

title: TULTEX TO SELL LOGOATHLETIC UNIT TO INVESTOR GROUP
description: The Tultex Corporation, an athletic apparel maker, agreed yesterday to sell its Logoathletic Inc. and Logoathletic/Headware Inc. units to a group including Puma A.G. of Germany for $96.5 million in cash and notes. The buyout, by a group formed by Logoathletic's founder, Tom Shine, and a senior executive, Michael R. Kistler, and including Puma, unidentified professional athletes and others, will help alleviate some of Tultex's debt. Puma, the world's sixth-largest sporting goods maker, is in the midst of a five-year, multimillion-mark investment program to gain ground lost to Nike Inc., Reebok International Ltd. and Adidas A.G. Logoathletic makes sportswear under license from professional and collegiate sports leagues.

title: Woman Is Killed Trying To Halt Her Rolling Car
description: A woman whose car began rolling down a hill in Millburn with a group of neighborhood children inside was killed yesterday when she tried to stop the car and slipped beneath it.

title: Shirov to Face Kasparov In October Title Match
description: Alexei Shirov, a Spanish (formerly Latvian) grandmaster, has become Garry Kasparov's challenger in a world title match planned for October. The 25-year-old Shirov defeated Vladimir Kramnik, a Russian grandmaster, in the World Chess Council candidates match, held from May 24 to June 5, in Cazorla (Jaen), Spain.

title: The Good Book of Few Answers
description: The Southern Baptist Convention in Salt Lake City adopted a declaration last week intended to reinforce traditional Christian family values. Based on the Epistle to the Ephesians, a text that may or may not have been written by Saint Paul, it asserts that ''a wife is to submit graciously to the servant leadership of her husband even as the church willingly submits to the headship of Christ.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Does Yzerman Rate the M.V.P. Award?
description: The pre-game conversations had a post-game tone. With the Detroit Red Wings leading the Washington Capitals by three games to none in the Stanley Cup finals, the questions were less about Tuesday's Game 4 than about what might happen if Detroit captures its second consecutive championship.

title: Chanal Journal; Helmet Instead of a Miter for the Bishop of Chiapas
description: When Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garcia comes to this town, he wears a metal helmet as protection against bullets and he walks surrounded by burly bodyguards.

title: Dynasties of a Different Day
description: Never in the 51 years of the National Basketball Association has there been a dynasty to compare with Bill Russell's Celtics. Unless it is Michael Jordan's Bulls.

description: SCHOEN-Leah Temma.
