Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Principal David N. Kahn, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: The Agenda: Musicians for Tibet
description: The Tibetan Freedom Concerts came to the capital determined to get the attention of politicians before President Clinton's visit to China later this month. The Milarepa Foundation, which expects to realize about $1 million from the concerts at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium here, followed the concerts with a rally the next day at the Capitol urging Mr. Clinton to press China to negotiate with the Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled leader.

description: The Johnnie Walker Man

title: Record Rating For Bulls-Jazz
description: Game 6 of the National Basketball Association finals generated a 23.0 overnight Nielsen rating for NBC, guaranteeing that the Chicago Bulls-Utah Jazz series will be the highest-rated ever for the sport. It was 14 percent above Game 6 a year ago, when the Bulls also beat the Jazz to win the N.B.A. title.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVEDOFF, MARY
description: SAVEDOFF-Mary, 85. Of Hallandale, FL., on June 14. Loving and devoted mother of Ted, Charles & the late Stephen. Cherished grandmother of Ellen, Marci, Jason & Luke. Beloved aunt. A great friend to many people. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hospice By The Sea, Boca Raton, FL. 561-395-5031.

title: The Magic Of a Voice, The Unity Of Peoples
description: In the midst of summer festivals focused on political issues (the Tibet Festival, held simultaneously in Washington) alternative culture (the late, lost Lollapalooza), a specific gender (Lilith Fair) and varying genres (Ozzfest, Smokin' Grooves), the Guinness Fleadh (pronounced flah) is a festival focused on music. Yet this stout-sponsored event, which this past weekend visited Randalls Island for the second time, still realized an agenda of its own. Its 60-plus acts coalesced around two romantic notions of popular music's power: its ability to elevate solitary voices and its magical way of bonding communities, both onstage and in the audience.

title: ACQUISITION TO BROADEN NETMANAGE'S SOFTWARE LINES
description: Netmanage Inc., a maker of networking software, said yesterday that it would acquire FTP Software Inc. for about $77.4 million. The acquisition will allow Netmanage to offer a broader range of computer-linking products. Netmanage will exchange 0.73 of each of its shares for each FTP share, valuing FTP at $2.27 a share, based on Netmanage's closing price on Friday. Netmanage, based in Cupertino, Calif., fell 18.75 cents, to $2.9375, while FTP, based in North Andover, Mass., fell 18.75 cents, to $1.8125. The acquisition adds FTP's World Wide Web, computer server and other networking products to the linking software for corporate mainframes and midrange and Unix computers now offered by Netmanage.

description: The stock of Broderbund Software Inc. fell 15 percent yesterday after the producer of software for homes and small business said it could lose as much as $3.3 million in its third quarter.

description: The Yankees insisted that the bad blood with the Baltimore Orioles no longer existed, that they had no intention of retaliating for the pitch Armando Benitez hit Tino Martinez with last month.

title: Lucio Costa Is Dead at 96; Planned Futuristic Brasilia
description: Lucio Costa, the architect and urban planner whose vision of man living in harmony with his tropical surroundings carried Brazilian architecture into the modern age, died on Saturday at his home here. He was 96.

Those duties had been handled by Ogilvy & Mather New York, part of WPP Group P.L.C. The creative and media planning duties on the account, with billings estimated at $10 million to $11 million, remain at Fitzgerald & Co., Atlanta.

title: White House And Starr Are Warned About Leaks
description: A Federal district judge sternly admonished the White House and the office of the Whitewater independent counsel today not to disclose material related to the investigation of President Clinton and a former White House intern, lawyers familiar with the inquiry said.

title: Auschwitz Synagogue to Reopen, Bringing 'Hopes of the Future'
description: Until the Nazis marched in, the Polish town of Oswiecim, which was named Auschwitz by the Germans, had 12 synagogues. All but one were destroyed by the Nazis as they built the concentration camps of Auschwitz and Birkenau. Somehow, one small house of worship remained standing, and after the war it was converted into a carpet warehouse.

title: HEALTH WATCH; Hope and Heart
description: DISEASE is depressing; depression complicates recovery from disease. That vicious circle has proved especially intractable for older people who have severe coronary problems, compounded by the fact that the main class of antidepressant drugs used in the last 20 years often made heart conditions worse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITMORE, EDWARD KNIGHT
description: WHITMORE-Edward Knight. On June 12, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Virginia R. Whitmore. Devoted father of Joy W. Goldstein and Ned Whitmore. He also leaves six grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. May his love of life live on forever in the hearts of those who cherished his memory. Memorial service on Friday, June 19, at 11 AM, All Saints Episcopal Church, Bay Head, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in his name for the memorial fund of All Saints Church, Lake Ave, Bay Head, New Jersey 08742.

title: Assembly Democrats File Suit Challenging Vetoes by Pataki
description: Setting the stage for a constitutional showdown, the Democrats who control the State Assembly filed a lawsuit today challenging Gov. George E. Pataki's decision to veto dozens of items from the budget that the Legislature enacted two months ago.

title: In Booming Economy, Poor Still Struggle to Pay the Rent
description: Despite the economy's robust growth, low-income families continue to face record-level problems in the most basic of economic transactions: paying the rent.

title: Performing Arts Center Gets $2.5 Million Grant
description: A Newark-based foundation has voted to give $2.5 million to the New Jersey Performing Arts Center to increase its arts education and outreach programs and for general support.

title: Attack in Bronx Linked To a Serial Rapist
description: A 22-year-old woman who was raped in a Bronx building early Sunday is believed to have been attacked by a rapist who is responsible for 38 sexual assaults in the Bronx and northern Manhattan in four years, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISTFIELD, LEONARD M.
description: LISTFIELD-Leonard M. Died in London on June 11, 1998. Loving husband to Helen for forty-seven years. Devoted father to Andrew and Emily. Cherished father-in-law to George. Adoring and adored granddaddy to Sasha. He will be deeply missed for his wit, wisdom, humor and loyalty by friends and family. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Saint Thomas Hospital, Mead Ward, Lambeth Palace Road, London SE1, 7EH, C/O Dr. Richard Leach.

description: GARF-Vivian. On June 14, 1998. Beloved wife of Jerry, loving mother of Larry, Wendy, and Peter. Cherished grandmother, dear sister of Dorothy Rosner. Services Wednesday, June 17, 11:30AM ''Boulevard - Riverside Chapel'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Ziff-Davis is pushing its 24-hour cable television network on computing in a three-front campaign.
description: ZIFF-DAVIS, the high-technology media and marketing company, has introduced a 24-hour cable television network focused on computing and the Internet and is counting on a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign to put it on the map.

title: Offering a Cheaper Ride to Orbit From the Middle of the Ocean
description: EVER since 1926, when Dr. Robert H. Goddard, working in Auburn, Mass., fired the world's first successful liquid-fueled rocket, the field has developed along the same general lines. Increasingly big and powerful vehicles have blasted off from dry land.

title: Jazz Winners for All Tastes
description: For a new awards program, jazz's major players -- and its major nonmusician supporters -- delivered their soliloquies on the stage of Alice Tully Hall last night. It was the first annual Jazz Awards, produced by Knit Media and benefiting two organizations supporting destitute musicians, Musicares and the Jazz Foundation of America. Between presentations there were performances by Joe Henderson, Alice and Ravi Coltrane, Geri Allen and others. Eric Bogosian was the master of ceremonies.

title: Jenny Craig Narrows Its Review
description: Jenny Craig Inc. in La Jolla, Calif., which operates weight-loss programs, has narrowed a review for the creative and media parts of its domestic account to six agencies and two media services. Billings are estimated at $40 million.

title: Jets Sign Draft Pick
description: The Jets, who drafted a league-high 12 players, signed their second player from that big crop yesterday. He is Lawrence Hart, a tight end from Southern University and the last player they selected. Previously, the Jets signed a sixth-round pick, Charis Brazzell, a receiver from Angelo State. GERALD ESKENAZI

title: Note to Readers: IHT Begins Printing A Joint-Venture Supplement in Italy
description: Beginning today, a four-page supplement of Italian news in English will be included with all copies the International Herald Tribune distributes in Italy.

title: Proposal Ties Car Insurance To Mileage
description: Seizing on an issue that dominated last year's gubernatorial race in New Jersey, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross released a plan today to lower auto insurance rates in New York, including a proposal for pay-by-the-mile premiums.

title: U.S. Starts Out Awed and Finishes Dominated
description: After four years of undeniable improvement, of encouraging results against top teams in lesser tournaments, the United States learned a sober lesson today in a 2-0 loss to Germany in the World Cup. When it counts, the Americans' third-level ability has still not caught up with its first-level ambition.

title: Adrift in Japan's Sea of Unknown Intentions
description: For the last 10 months the Clinton Administration has warned that a full-blown recession in Japan could prove the time bomb of the Asian crisis, setting off a sharp fall of the yen and, in turn, a second wave of the economic contagion that is spreading to investors around the globe.

title: If Lehman Keeps Knocking on the Door, He Is Confident It Will Open
description: A few days after last year's United States Open, Tom Lehman recalls, he went to a driving range and angrily hit golf balls as hard as he could for several hours. Who could blame him? For the third consecutive year, Lehman had held or shared the lead after three rounds of the Open, yet he failed to win it. In 1995, he finished third. In 1996, he finished tied for second. And last year, Lehman was third again.

title: Risks of World Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor in Baltimore on Stadium Research
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has said his heart wants to keep the New York Yankees in the Bronx although a move to Manhattan might be more lucrative, visited Oriole Park at Camden Yards here today to see how a baseball stadium can fit into a downtown.

title: RITE OF PASSAGE: A special report.; Those Seductive Snake Eyes: Tales of Growing Up Gambling
description: Like a first kiss, getting the car keys for the first time or walking into a bar and buying a first drink, gambling has become a rite of passage for young people on their way to adulthood.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL AT 12-YEAR LOW. Crude oil fell 8.2 percent, to the lowest level since 1986, after a United Nations inspector said Iraq sanctions might soon end, which could increase a supply glut. July contracts fell $1.03, to $11.56 a barrel.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Russia Scolds U.S. General, Saying It Was Misled Over Timing of NATO Air Exercise
description: In a blunt dressing down, Russia's Defense Minister told the top United States military commander today that Moscow had been misled over the timing of NATO's air exercises in the Balkans.

title: Fans Set Off Another Day of Violence
description: Hooliganism, soccer's recurring headache, turned Marseilles into a city of tear gas for the second consecutive day today as a World Cup game between England and Tunisia was overshadowed by clashes that took place outside the stadium.

title: A Ballerina's Farewell, With Typical Flair
description: Nichol Hlinka gave her final performance with the New York City Ballet on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater, dancing two works by George Balanchine that showed off her special gifts.

title: Did Augustus Take the Waters Here? Ruins Hint 'Yes'
description: GREAT as he loomed in the heyday of Rome, the Emperor Augustus was frail of body and suffered a lifetime of infirmities. In 23 B. C., according to a contemporary account, he almost died of ''an abscessed liver'' and presumably would have if not for the restorative power of cold baths in mineral springs. Word of the Emperor's cure touched off one of antiquity's more enduring health fads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINS, LEO M.
description: WEINS-Leo M. Beloved husband of Margaret and loving brother of John. Leo M. Weins, who was born on September 2, 1912, in Racine, Wisconsin, died on June 12, 1998. President of The H.W. Wilson Company (1967-1995), Mr. Weins pursued his education at Loyola University in Chicago (1935-1936), the University of Chicago (1937-1938) and Northwestern University (1946-1947). From 1935 to 1946 he worked as an accountant at a subsidiary of the Peabody Coal Company of Chicago. His education and career were interrupted by a three-year stint in the United States Army during World War II (1943-1946); he served for two years in the South Pacific, as a master sergeant in the anti-aircraft artillery. In 1946 Mr. Weins became chief accountant at the American Library Association headquarters in Chicago. In 1952 he became the ALA's comptroller and chief of administrative services, a position that gave him a special appreciation of the library industry. In 1957 he joined The H.W. Wilson Company, a world renowned publisher of reference materials, as controller and chief of business services. In 1963 Mr. Weins was elected a vice-president, and in 1967 he was elected president and treasurer. He held the positions of president and treasurer for 28 years, during which he also served as president of The H.W. Wilson Foundation. He retired in 1995 but continued to serve on the Board of Directors. Mr. Weins has also served on the board of directors of Choice (1963-1970; 1977-1981), as a trustee and treasurer of the New York Metropolitan Reference and Research Library Agency (1979-1983), as a trustee of the Dollar Drydock Savings Bank of New York (1969-1984), and a trustee on the Board of the Maritime College at Fort Schuyler Foundation, Inc. (1981-1989). Memorial Mass will be Tuesday 2PM at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 1 W. 53rd St., NYC.

title: Lott Says Homosexuality Is a Sin and Compares It to Alcoholism
description: In an interview about his personal beliefs, Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, told a conservative talk show host today that homosexuality is a sin and then compared it to such personal problems as alcoholism, kleptomania and ''sex addiction.''

title: Cart Problems Bedevil Martin
description: When the United States Open begins on Thursday, Casey Martin may be more worried about his cart than his golf game.

title: Like Church, With Funk and Disco
description: On Friday night, with a summer storm battering the roof and rainwater gathering around its shoes, the audience at the Hudson Tent for the Texaco New York Jazz Festival had its emotions stirred up. And with cellos and violins blending with saxophones and trumpets, accordion and blues singing, the music onstage was fittingly expressive, mixing funeral parlor, dance hall and church.

title: Fake Beanie Babies Lead to Import Charges
description: A stationery store owner from Ridgewood, N.J., was charged yesterday with illegally importing 6,500 counterfeit Beanie Babies from China and conspiring to sell the popular stuffed animals for as much as $1,500 each, Federal authorities in Manhattan said.

title: The Proof Is in the Neutrino
description: This month, a team of physicists working deep inside a Japanese mine shaft announced that the neutrino, perhaps the most mysterious particle in the universe, does indeed have mass. Although fellow experimenters applauded the discovery and the press reported it enthusiastically, the most joyous response came from theoretical physicists who devote much of their lives to conjuring up explanations of the universe and then must wait for experimenters to prove them true.

title: Mark Morris Helps Tease Louis XV
description: Was Mark Morris a ballet master at some Baroque court in a previous life? The American choreographer, who has already staged several Baroque operas and masques, has now created a zany yet touching production of a neglected French masterpiece, ''Platee,'' Jean-Philippe Rameau's parody of the tragic Baroque operas of his day, including his own. Through this story of a self-deluded amphibian swamp creature, Platee, who believes she has been chosen by Jupiter to be his new wife, Rameau even took some pokes at Louis XV and his entourage at Versailles, where the work was first presented in 1745.

title: Cornerback Lincoln Joins the Giants
description: The Giants signed the free-agent defensive back Jeremy Lincoln yesterday to back up cornerbacks Jason Sehorn and Phillippi Sparks. Lincoln, 29, will assume the role filled in recent seasons by Thomas Randolph, whom the Giants lost to free agency last winter.

title: Shhh! Can't You See the Celebration?
description: ''Thou shalt be silent when the celebrating begins,'' is a commandment for broadcasters calling title games. The pictures tell the story, so shut up. Don't narrate the hugs. There will be lots of time to talk later.

title: Hard Times for Gorillas

A civil war in their home nation, Congo, has left many guns in the hands of poachers, and people are encroaching on the gorillas' forests. A recent survey of the gorilla territory, which spans about 35,000 square miles, found that most of the animals are holding their own for now, but their survival is becoming more precarious.

title: Document Describes Poor Communication in Military Before Ski Lift Incident
description: Four months before a Marine jet hit a ski lift cable in the Italian alps, communication of safety information between the Marines and the Air Force was so poor that a Marine plane once came nose to nose with two Air Force fighters flying the same route, according to an internal Marine memorandum introduced in legal proceedings here today.

title: Mall Planned for New Jersey, With a Lure for New Yorkers
description: An Ohio developer announced yesterday that his company had secured $163 million in bank loans to build one of the largest malls in the New York City metropolitan area: a shopping and entertainment complex that would rise on 110 acres near Newark International Airport, with a view of the Manhattan skyline.

title: Goldman Goes for a Bit of Gusto; A Bold Agenda, but Only Compared With a Cautious Past
description: On the day that Goldman, Sachs & Company announced its plans to go public, Jon S. Corzine and Henry M. Paulson Jr. might have been expected to relax, even exult a little. After all, they have succeeded where at least two generations of Goldman leaders repeatedly failed, persuading a famously feisty but publicity-shy partnership to dissolve itself and embrace what it had long shunned -- a brave new world of expansion, acquisitions, stock options and shareholder meetings.

Unemployment here reached 4.2 percent from March through May, the highest rate in 15 years. And the stock market plunged 5.7 percent today to its lowest closing level since Jan. 30, 1995.

description: Hire the best, and pay them less.

title: Prosecutors Charge Bias In Screening Of Jurors

Livoti, a former New York City police officer who is charged with violating the civil rights of a man who died after being choked during a 1994 arrest.

title: State Proposal Seeks to Raise Requirements for Teachers to Retain State Licenses
description: After deliberating for more than two years on how to raise the bar for public-school teachers in New York, state education officials have settled on a proposal that cracks down on college teaching programs and requires all new teachers to enroll in college courses or professional development seminars every five years in order to retain their state teaching licenses.

title: DOW TUMBLES 207 IN GLOBAL DECLINE
description: Renewed fears that Asia's economic crisis will stall growth in the profits of American companies sent United States' stocks plunging yesterday, the worst in a string of recent selloffs that has now erased the gains of the last three months for the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Gaining Weight on Sugar-Free, Fat-Free Diets

title: Speedier Inspections in Iraq
description: It was startling to hear Richard Butler, the chief United Nations weapons inspector for Iraq, declare yesterday that a more cooperative attitude in Baghdad may now make it possible to conclude the search for concealed biological and chemical weapons and prohibited missiles in just a few more months. Mr. Butler is not known for optimistic forecasts about Iraqi behavior, and Baghdad seldom cooperates for very long.

title: Tuscaloosa Journal; Shrine to the Coach Who Made Alabama Proud
description: The bronze bust of Paul William (Bear) Bryant that glares from the museum's entrance is about five times life-size, and still might not be quite big enough.

description: Disabled state prisoners are covered by the Federal law that prohibits discrimination against people with disabilities, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL SNAPS BACK. Crude oil rebounded from 12-year lows after OPEC producers agreed to make further output reductions to help shrink a global oversupply. July contracts rose 42 cents, or 3.6 percent, to $11.98 a barrel.

title: General Managers Move to Open Up Game
description: The National Hockey League's general managers today adopted recommendations designed to increase offensive production, cut down on undetected fouls and reduce confusion and debate about goal-crease interference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOWSHOWITZ, LIBBY
description: MOWSHOWITZ-Libby. Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary mourn the passing of a deeply cherished friend, the beloved wife of the late Rabbi Dr. Israel Mowshowitz, an esteemed alumnus and inspired worker on behalf of his alma mater. title: A Long, Hot Fiscal Year Is Anticipated

But because of the overheated political atmosphere in City Hall this year, the fight over the budget will continue for several months and perhaps for the entire next fiscal year, officials predict.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTELL, PENELOPE

On June 13 Penelope Williams Littell, loving mother of Eliakim Littell, beloved wife of the late Blaine Littell, devoted stepmother of Philip Littell, Peter Littell and Anita Repp, adored mother-in-law to Catherine Deathe, died in Westerly, Rhode Island hospital. She is also survived by 7 grandchildren. She died of complications from breast cancer. Born on May 23, 1940 in Nottingham, England, Penelope began her pursuit of artistic creations in the visual arts in her teens. She married Blaine in 1965 and gave birth to her son Kim in 1966. During the 1970's through to the early 1990's she split her time between Cambridge and Tyringham, Mass. She became an American citizen in 1992. A funeral service for Penelope will be held in Tyringham's Union Church on Saturday, June 20, beginning at 12 noon.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN REBOUNDS. Japan's currency jumped 2 percent on views that the central bank was trying to raise its value by buying yen and selling dollars. In New York, the dollar fell to 143.47 yen from an eight-year high of 146.15 Monday.

title: New Proposals to Help Make Up for Lost Taxes
description: A proposal to tax commuters to make up for lost revenues in towns with large numbers of tax-exempt buildings was among several recommendations to help cut property taxes released yesterday by the New Jersey State League of Municipalities.

title: Business Travel; U S Airways' low-fare Metro Jet service is an effort to beat Southwest Airlines at its own game.
description: WITH the introduction earlier this month of Metro Jet, a low-fare service, U S Airways is trying to beat Southwest Airlines at its own game. Metro Jet is competing with Southwest on routes between Baltimore and four cities: Cleveland; Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Manchester, N.H., and Providence, R.I. None of the routes overlap with U S Airways' regular service.

title: HEINZ TO BUY COLLEGE INN BROTH UNIT FROM NABISCO
description: The H. J. Heinz Company agreed yesterday to buy the College Inn line of canned broth from the Nabisco Holdings Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. College Inn, which has about $50 million in annual sales, is profitable, but Nabisco said it had decided to sell the unit because it did not fit into the company's plan to focus on snack foods such as Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers. Heinz, which also makes supermarket-brand soups that have increased in market share over the last four years, is seeking to add businesses that fit well with its other food lines, which include ketchup, Earth's Best baby food, Ore-Ida frozen potato products and Star-Kist tuna. Nabisco, based in Parsippany, N.J., is 80.5 percent owned by the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAILE, CHRISTOPHER
description: HAILE-Christopher, artist; 50; son of Lucia Haile of Sag Harbor, Long Island, and his late father, Shirley Haile of Carmel, California, died peacefully on June 15 at his summer studio in North Adams, Massachusetts of complications from juvenile diabetes. He leaves his mother, brothers Duncan of New Milford, Conn, and Roger of Mebane, North Carolina, as well as a large family of aunts, cousins, nephews, nieces, his stepmother, many friends and devoted collectors of his paintings, drawings, sculptures, prints and environmental pieces. In accordance with his stated wishes, there will be no funeral service. He will be buried in Oakland Cemetery in Sag Harbor at a date to be determined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INGOGLIA, FRANK
description: INGOGLIA-Frank, age 91. A gentleman with many friends. Died peacefully at home in Forest Hills Gardens, NY on Flag Day morning, June 14. A graduate of the Fawcett School of Design and the Art Students League, he began a 70 year career in art. As a commercial artist, his illustrations appeared in major magazines and newspapers of the day. Later, as a portraitist, he was represented by Portraits, Inc. and his paintings hang in private collections and galleries throughout the country, including the U.S. Army Chief of Staff Gallery in the Pentagon. After overcoming a long childhood illness, he turned to sports and became a champion fencer. He competed for the New York Athletic Club and was a member of the United States fencing team for the 1936 Olympics. His wife of 49 years, Danis Gerdes Ingoglia, died in 1982. He is survived by his daughter, Gina Ingoglia Weiner and son-in-law, Earl D. Weiner of Brooklyn Heights, NY; sister Dorothy Ingoglia Gatto; grandson, John Barlow Weiner; granddaughter, Melissa Danis Balmain Weiner; and grandson-in-law, William J. FitzPatrick. Memorial services on Friday, June 19th at 3:00PM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills Gardens. Instead of flowers, please make a donation to a charity or organization of your choosing.

title: Security Rules Sought For State Workers
description: Three months after a state employee shot and killed four co-workers at state lottery headquarters, Gov. John G. Rowland proposed yesterday that state employees be barred from carrying weapons to work and that the state begin disciplining state employees who threaten co-workers.

description: A Federal jury has rejected claims by nine people that they suffered injuries from using computer keyboards made by the Digital Equipment Corporation.

But even as it was winning admirers, it was causing a rift between the Academie Francaise, the guardians of the French language, who defined it as a flan, and the Limousins, who insisted it was a cake. The Limousins prevailed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELWEROWICZ, ORCHON, HELENA

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times yesterday with an article about the amount of exercise needed to burn off calories in various foods misstated the number burned per minute of running. It is 19.4 calories, not 11.2.

title: Goals Are Set for Iraq, but U.N. Aides Remain Wary
description: Officials here cautioned today that although the chief United Nations arms inspector succeeded over the weekend in setting a list of immediate goals for Iraq to meet before an eight-year embargo on oil sales could be lifted, other more difficult issues remained.

title: Virgin's Chief Battling Law On Ownership Of U.S. Airlines
description: Richard Branson, the British entrepreneur whose Virgin Group's holdings range from airlines and high-speed trains to retail stores and soft drinks, was close to a deal to start a new low-cost airline at New York's Kennedy International Airport earlier this month but backed away because of Federal restrictions that prevent foreigners from controlling domestic airlines.

The acquired operation has annual sales of about $110 million and an annual production capacity of 170,000 metric tons of carbon black, a rubber toughening agent.

title: Vincent P. Healey, 80, Antisubmarine Specialist
description: Rear Adm. Vincent Patrick Healey, a retired antisubmarine specialist who as a young gunnery officer saw naval combat from the Philippines to Iwo Jima to Japan itself in World War II, died on May 30 at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 80 and lived in Arlington, Va.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARFMAN, MORTY
description: WARFMAN-Morty. Against all odds you persevered. We could always count on your loyalty and friendship. We will miss you. Bernie and Barbara Zimberg

title: DOMTAR TO BUY PAPER AND WOOD UNITS FOR $545 MILLION
description: George Weston Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its E. B. Eddy paper and wood products subsidiaries to Domtar Inc. for about $803 million (Canadian), or $545.3 million (United States). George Weston, a food processing and distribution company based in Toronto, said the price consisted of $435 million (Canadian) in cash and about $368 million in Domtar treasury shares. Domtar, the Montreal-based forest products company, said the acquired companies had 1997 sales of about $1 billion (Canadian). After the purchase, Domtar will have about 8,000 employees, up from 4,700. The company had 1997 sales of $1.93 billion (Canadian).

title: Temptation; In Shades of Pale Pastel, Designer Eggs With Taste
description: GO to the Union Square Greenmarket very early on a Wednesday or Saturday morning. Go to the Windfall Farms stand and ask for a carton of ''the eggs.'' They sell out fast, usually by mid-morning, and you have to know they're there -- out of sight, in the truck.

title: To Go; Grown-Up Adventures in Carryout
description: VERBENA, Diane Forley's pretty little restaurant, has a genteel quality that almost dares you to break a plate or spill some wine. But her inventive cooking can make you delight in feeling civilized. Now she has brought her light touch to carryout with VERBENA FOODS , just a narrow counter with a few simple tables and an entrance around the block from the restaurant.

title: His Last Harangue; After 30 Years as a Legislative Gadfly, Leichter Is Bowing Out
description: It is the time of year when Franz S. Leichter's colleagues in the State Senate ardently wish that he would disappear.

title: MILOSEVIC PLEDGES STEPS TO HOLD OFF ATTACK FROM NATO
description: President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia promised today to make concessions over Kosovo to forestall military action by the West. But he failed to meet one key demand: the withdrawal of Serbian security forces accused of attacking ethnic Albanians in the province.

title: In Drive for Unity, Hyundai Founder Takes Cattle to North Korea
description: In an exercise that the United States military patroling between North and South Korea dubbed ''Operation Rawhide,'' the founder of the giant Hyundai conglomerate drove 500 head of cattle across the border to the North today in an effort to aid reconciliation on the divided peninsula.

title: Fifth Time for Double Sweep
description: By winning the Stanley Cup in a four-game sweep for the second consecutive year, the Detroit Red Wings matched an accomplishment of only four other teams since the inception of the four-of-seven-game format in the championship round in 1939.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Friday reported settlements by the Navy and America Online with a highly decorated sailor who was investigated by the Navy after he posted a computer message, under an anonymous E-mail address, in which he described himself as gay.

title: Writer Accuses The Producers Of 'Truman'
description: A Greenwich Village playwright says the similarities are just too uncanny. In the summer of 1992, ''Frank's Life,'' an Off Off Broadway play written by Mark Dunn, portrayed the plight of an orphaned boy adopted by a television network and unwittingly made the focus of a television soap opera.

title: Biggest One-Day Setback For Treasuries in 2 Months
description: Giving back much of its previous day's gains, the Treasury market yesterday posted one of its biggest one-day losses in nearly two months.

title: Russia, Between a Dream and a Nightmare
description: Both the greatest opportunity and the greatest danger for the United States internationally may well still lie in Russia. If we do not soon seize the opportunity, the danger will increase -- and could present us with the most serious threat to basic global stability since the end of the cold war.

title: Critics Don't Want to 'Isolate' China; Protocol vs. Principle
description: To the Editor:

title: A Grocery Shopper's Escape From New York
description: I HAVE just returned from the ballet. Not the one starring Darci Kistler at Lincoln Center, the one starring me at Gristede's. My co-star was the pathetic excuse for a cart that refused to dance along.

title: NTL TO BUY COMTEL FOR $898 MILLION IN STOCK AND CASH
description: NTL Inc., a communications company based in New York, said it had agreed to buy Comtel, the British cable unit of KPN Koninklyke PTT Nederland N.V., the dominant Dutch phone and post company, for $:550 million ($898 million) in stock and cash, allowing it to maintain third place in the British cable market. The purchase comes after NTL's agreement to pay $997 million in stock and assumed debt to buy Comcast UK Cable Partners. With both purchases, NTL will increase the number of homes that can receive its cable networks to 4.3 million, from 2.09 million.

title: Tartan Army Finds Voice in Nick of Time
description: Scotland's ''tartan army'' came back from certain elimination today to keep its World Cup chances alive with a 1-1 draw against a ragged Norwegian team.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: A Turkey's Freezer Life

title: Restaurants; Proof That the Thin Do, in Fact, Eat
description: IF you are over 30, weigh more than 105 pounds, favor bright colors or bite your fingernails, Bond Street could do you damage. No matter how confident you may be in the real world, it is hard to face an entire universe of thin, young, beautiful people dressed in black without wondering what you are doing there. Especially when you watch their chopsticks flash through the perfumed air to pick up bits of ''hot eel dice.''

title: Study Finds Pain Of Oldest Is Ignored In Nursing Homes
description: Researchers studying elderly cancer patients in nursing homes have found that many are severely undertreated for their pain and more than a quarter of those who complain of pain -- especially blacks and the oldest of the old -- are not given any pain medication, even aspirin.

title: Senate Panel Ponders Long-Term Effect of Mergers
description: Confronted with a merger wave that is reshaping industries like banking, communications and military contracting, the Senate Judiciary Committee began debating today whether the trend was going too far and putting workers, consumers and the economy's long-term health at risk.

title: Liberties; Monica And Me
description: Never mind Steven Brill.

title: Political Briefing; Best Signature of All? Perot's on a Check
description: Almost from the day it was founded, Ross Perot's Reform Party has been complaining about the difficulty that third parties have in gaining official recognition and getting on state and Federal ballots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DITCHEK, HENRY
description: DITCHEK-Henry. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Alan S. Roth, President

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: China's Oppressive Silence
description: There is a disturbing quality to China's preparations for next week's visit by President Clinton. Chinese leaders are so eager to project a sanitized picture of political harmony to a global television audience that they have been harassing democratic dissidents, preventing Chinese-Americans from visiting their families back home and blocking distribution of a book featuring American journalistic accounts of President Clinton's alleged sexual indiscretions.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: No Writer's Block, But Writer's Itch

title: Carving a Path Of Innovations; Live and Electronic Music Blend in a Varied Career
description: Mimi Goese lives in one of those old New York City apartments whose rooms are so tiny that they feel like a complex of cages. Yet Ms. Goese, a 38-year-old performing artist, has transformed this standard walk-up into enchanted chambers.

title: PEPSICO TO SELL POLISH CHOCOLATE AND COOKIE BUSINESS
description: Pepsico Inc. said that it would sell its E. Wedel S.A. chocolate and cookie business in Poland and invest the proceeds in its sodas and snacks business there. Pepsico first bought a 40 percent stake in Wedel in 1991 for $58 million. It said in November that it wanted to take Wedel private to strengthen its control in an expanding market. The move is part of the company's strategy to focus Pepsico on selling Pepsi and Mountain Dew sodas as well as Doritos and Lays snacks. In October, the company spun off its Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut restaurant operations. A number of Polish and multinational companies have expressed an interest in Wedel, Pepsico said, but it did not name them.

title: 'X-Files' Movie Seeks New Fans
description: David Duchovny believed that he was taking part in a first when he filmed the ''X-Files'' movie last summer: starring in a big-budget Hollywood film, playing the same character he plays in a continuing television series.

title: Williams, A Youth Confined
description: ''Now is the time to make a break get away -- away.'' The words, hopeful and desperate, appear in the private journal of the 27-year-old Thomas Lanier Williams 3d, who was soon to adopt the first name of Tennessee. Williams was then living, most unhappily, with his parents in St. Louis. His older sister, Rose, who people said might as well be his twin, had recently been institutionalized for mental illness, and the young man found himself ''pinning pictures of wild birds on my lavatory screen.'' The idea of flight, of escape, saturated a life that was becoming more and more claustrophobic.

title: N.H.L. Sweepers: Another Title for Red Wings
description: First, his Detroit Red Wings teammates placed the Stanley Cup -- 35 inches tall, 35 pounds, its base filled with 2,225 names, including his own -- on his knee. Then they got behind Vladimir Konstantinov's wheelchair and gave it a gentle push to begin a slow parade of triumph across the ice before thousands of cheering fans.

title: Massachusetts High Court Backs Freeing Au Pair in Baby's Death
description: Massachusetts' highest court upheld a reduced sentence for the British au pair Louise Woodward today in a 4-to-3 decision that effectively ended a criminal case followed by millions on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Utility Halts Excavation After Workers Fall Ill
description: The Middlesex Water Company has suspended excavation work on a $30 million expansion of its treatment plant to prevent the spread of a mysterious ailment that has stricken workers, the company said yesterday.

title: Police Chief Considered For Transportation Post
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is considering appointing Wilbur L. Chapman, the Chief of Patrol for the New York Police Department, as his next transportation commissioner, an administration official said yesterday.

title: Serb's Promises Are Just a First Step, U.S. Says
description: The United States and its allies said today that pledges by the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, did not go far enough to meet the demands of the West that he end his crackdown in Kosovo, and that planning for possible NATO military intervention was continuing.

title: The Bunker Is Not a Laughing Matter
description: Given Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's talent for making enemies -- as in hot dog vendors, jaywalkers and taxi drivers -- it is hard to resist poking fun at his latest plan for a $15 million bunker, or ''crisis center,'' as the Mayor's supporters prefer to call it. Despite the merriment this inspires in the city's journalists and talk-show hosts, the Mayor's proposal makes sense. Crisis experts have said for some time that New York City desperately needs a modernized command center to cope with sudden emergencies ranging from blackouts to floods or riots and even biological or chemical terrorism.

title: Food Stuff
description: Ripe, Red, Luscious And at the Greenmarkets

title: INSIDE
description: Fuel Cell Will Power a House

title: Rapp Collins Forms Alliance
description: Rapp Collins Worldwide in New York, the direct marketing unit of Omnicom Group, said yesterday that it had formed an alliance with Customer Management Group in Boston, a consulting company that specializes in customer profitablity management. Customer Management, with 10 employees, works for clients including Houghton Mifflin; it will continue to operate under present management. Rapp Collins, with 2,400 employees, has billings estimated at $1.78 billion from clients like the Mercedes-Benz of North America unit of Daimler-Benz A.G.

title: Sips; Labels for Rhone Wines Communicate in Braille
description: IF there are bumps on the label, it must be Chapoutier. Reasoning that blind customers want the same information that other wine lovers look for on a bottle, Michel Chapoutier, a well-known maker and shipper of Rhone wines, has put Braille labels on all his premium wines, including appellations like Hermitage, Crozes-Hermitage, Condrieu, St.-Joseph, Cote Rotie and Chateauneuf-du-Pape. That adds up to nearly two million bottles each year.

title: Merrill Lynch Fails to Close Jury Records
description: Merrill Lynch & Company lost its appeal today to prevent the release of thousands of pages of potentially embarrassing transcripts from a grand jury investigation into its role in the 1994 bankruptcy of Orange County.

title: About New York; Sorry, Mayor, It's the Law: Chaos Rules
description: MICHIO KAKU has good news for hapless hot-dog vendors, street artists and cabbies frazzled by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's quest to quell urban entropy. The Mayor's zeal for near-absolute order is against the law.

title: People
description: * David J. Pecker, president and chief executive at Hachette Filipacchi Magazines, New York, part of Lagardere SCA, was named to the additional position of chief executive at Grolier Inc., also owned by Lagardere, succeeding Arnaud Lagardere, who continues as general manager and chief executive at Lagardere.

title: Telecom Italia Names A Director General
description: Telecom Italia named Massimo Sarmi yesterday to replace the director general, Vito Gamberale, signaling a victory for the chairman, Gian Mario Rossignolo, in resolving a management conflict that has threatened his stewardship of the world's sixth-largest phone company.

title: A Janacek Reprise At Glyndebourne
description: Britain is wet. The uncloned sheep on the hills and meadows around the garden do not seem to mind, but chalky mud from the paths of Glyndebourne clings to the black shoes of the gentlemen in evening clothes at 4 in the afternoon, and ladies pick up their long skirts to run from the next shower.

title: White House Sees Bank Bill Being Put Off Till Next Year
description: The Clinton Administration today all but doomed efforts to update the nation's financial services law this year, saying that it would not budge from its opposition to the bill passed last month by the House and that it wanted to start over next year.

title: Misguided City Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Will Miss Out on Big Payday at Goldman, Sachs
description: Bankers call it ''yesterday's trade'' -- the one buy or sell order that might have made an easy million had it only been executed. For retired, resigned and might-have-been partners of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the announcement on Monday that the private investment bank would go public was the ultimate missed opportunity.

title: After Unrest, The Fans Are Quiet
description: There were no bottles and cans hissing menacingly through the air outside the Stade Velodrome today. No clashes between the fans of England, the fans of Tunisia and no thrill-seeking local teen-agers on the Prado Beach.

title: North Korea Plans to Continue Developing and Selling Missiles
description: North Korea declared today that it would continue to develop missiles and sell them abroad, rejecting United States suggestions that it curb its missile program.

title: 14 Sanitation Workers Charged With Bribery
description: Fourteen Brooklyn sanitation workers were arrested yesterday on charges that they solicited and collected bribes to haul commercial waste illegally, city officials said.

title: The Ambitious Ronaldo Finally Finds the Net
description: Ronaldo keeps falling behind his quota of goals for this World Cup, but now it is official that he will have at least two more games in which to increase his output.

title: Lafayette, Zagat Is Here, and Paris Hardly Shrugs
description: Zagat Survey's first Paris Restaurant Guide has arrived at newsstands and bookstores here, introducing French readers to the novel idea that customers can rate restaurants just as well as Michelin and Gault Millau inspectors.

title: Happiness Is to Fly And Swing And Slam
description: When the members of De la Guarda aren't hanging around, they're yelling and bouncing off the wall. Literally. Most of De la Guarda's ''Villa Villa,'' which opened yesterday at the Daryl Roth Theater on Union Square (20 Union Square East, at 15th Street), takes place with the performers overhead, swinging from the ceiling while harnessed to long tethers. First they appear as speeding shadows behind a ceiling scrim, like celestial messengers whizzing across a fluorescent firmament. Then dangling heads break through from above, and the true mayhem begins.

title: Group Bidding for Browns Hires Shula
description: Don Shula, a Cleveland native, would hire the coach and general manager of the new Browns if the investment group he is part of wins its bid for the National Football League expansion franchise, he said at a news conference yesterday.

title: Rabbi Hillel Fine, 77, Expert on Languages
description: Rabbi Hillel A. Fine, an educator, expert in Semitic languages and, most recently, director of the New Orleans Hillel Foundation, died of a heart attack on May 25 in New York City. He was 77 and had lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan since his retirement in 1986.

title: Fans Bid the Bulls Hail (and Farewell?)
description: Chicago threw a bittersweet celebration today, with 300,000 fans filling Grant Park to thank the Chicago Bulls for winning their sixth National Basketball Association championship on Sunday but fearing that it was a goodbye party. The Bulls may have been the only team to hold a public victory celebration without any player saying, ''We're going to try to do it again next year!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, EDYTHE
description: GOODMAN-Edythe. On June 15, 1998. Beloved wife of George. Loving mother of the late Harris James (Jimmy) and Nancy. Service and interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANKENSHIP, ALBERT
description: BLANKENSHIP-Albert, age 83, died in Farmington, CT. on Saturday, June 13, 1998. Albert and his wife Janet moved from Florida in 1995 to be near family. Albert was the son of Dr. Walter D. and Winifred B. Blankenship. Born in Lancaster, PA, he graduated from Franklin and Marshall College in 1935. He earned a doctorate in psychology at Columbia in 1940. Al was a pioneer in market research. He was author or co-author of nine books and many papers, including the critically acclaimed 1992 book, ''State of the Art Marketing Research'', co-authored with George Breen. He held positions with major advertising agencies, client companies, and research firms, most notably as Director of Consumer Research at N.W. Ayer & Son, Vice President of Research at Ted Bates and Company, Young & Rubicam Inc, Director of Market Research at Carter-Wallace, and Vice President of Canadian Facts. He taught market research at Temple University, New York University, and Bowling Green State University. A Rockefeller Fellow, Al was also a Fellow of the Professional Marketing Research Society (Canada), the American Psychological Association, and the Royal Statistical Society (UK), and a life member of the Market Research Council. He was past (national) SecretaryTreasurer of the American Marketing Association, and served on SCORE's national board. In 1997 the Professional Marketing Research Society (Canada) funded an annual scholarship named ''The Blankenship Research Award'' for his contributions to market research. Last month he was inducted into the Marketing Research Hall of Fame, joining such luminaries as George Gallup and W. Edwards Deming. He is survived by his wife, two sons, a daughter, a sister, and their families.

title: Major Indexes Up Slightly As Investors Hunt Bargains
description: Major stock market indexes were modestly higher yesterday as investors looked for bargains but shunned many multinational companies with exposure to Asian markets. Instead, they sought technology issues, which have been battered recently by some of the same concerns that are now hurting the conglomerates.

title: Culture as a Dream Without Escape
description: SYMPTOMS OF CULTURE

title: Political Briefing; Virginia Tobacco Ties G.O.P. and Labor
description: Tobacco makes strange political bedfellows.

title: U.S. Firm's German Deal
description: A fund managed by the New York buyout firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc. has completed the purchase of a 65 percent stake in Thyssen Schulte Bautechnik, a German building-materials wholesaler, for 425 million marks ($234 million), a person involved in the transaction said yesterday. Such a deal would be Clayton, Dubilier's first private equity investment in Europe. The firm recently announced plans to open a London office that will serve as its European headquarters.

title: Voters Pick the 100 Best American Movies
description: The American Film Institute announced the winners last night in a contest for the 100 best American films of all time. And the winner was . . . the perennial favorite, ''Citizen Kane,'' Orson Welles's 1941 classic film about the rise and fall of a media titan, made when Welles was only 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LOUIS
description: LEVINE-Louis. Died on June 13, 1998 at age 95 in his home in Palm Beach, FL. Loving husband of the late Mae Bruckman Levine for 61 years. Cherished by his daughter, Susan Raanan, and beloved by his grandchildren Matthew and Victoria and his son-in-law Robert Fleischer. A gentle and sensitive man of considerable artistic talent. We will miss you very much.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELTCHEK, EDITH Z.
description: WELTCHEK-Edith Z. Born March 18, 1933 in Boston, MA. Died June 14, 1998 at home in East Hampton, NY. Daughter of Minnie Zanditon and the late Sydney Zanditon. She died surrounded by her loved ones, her husband Paul, children Nancy Ferris, Ann Wolf and Peter Weltchek; grandchildren Daisy, Henry & Benjamin Wolf, Susannah and Amelia Ferris, and sons-in-law Mathew Wolf and Henry Ferris. Funeral private. Memorial Service 1 PM Sunday, June 21 at Williams Funeral Home, 99 Newtown Lane, East Hampton, NY. Family will be receiving at home in East Hampton evenings June 18th through June 20th. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Breast Cancer Vaccine Research Fund, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAPIN, ELIZABETH STEINWAY
description: CHAPIN - Elizabeth Steinway. Wonderful Betty left us five years ago today. We all cherish and believe in the old Danish expression that ''no one ever dies who lives in hearts left behind.'' Schuyler, Henry and Betsy, Ted and Joanna, Sam and Caroline, Miles and Jennie.

title: Pfizer to Sell Stent Business for $2.1 Billion
description: Pfizer Inc. announced yesterday that it would sell its cardiovascular devices unit to the Boston Scientific Corporation for $2.1 billion in cash.

title: A Vision of Russia's Future: Art vs. Despotism
description: Toward the end of his tour of Russian culture, James H. Billington suggests that Russia's future will be decided by a clash between art and despotism. That conventional coda does not do justice to the more complex if less wishful history that he tells, which demonstrates that art can be in the service of despotism as well as at war with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSKIND, JESSE
description: SUSSKIND-Jesse. On June 14, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Frances Sokolski. Beloved father of Jane and Stephan, brother of Pearl Rice and the late Blanche Laurie. Adoring grandfather of Pamela Narins. Larger than life, a man of vigor, intelligence and humor, he never lost joy in simply being alive, and lived gallantly and with courage into his 90's. Private services at the Riverside.

title: Bermuda Insurer to Buy Tarquin of Britain
description: Ace Ltd., an insurance holding company based in Bermuda, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Tarquin Ltd. of Britain for about $503 million in stock, based on Monday's closing price.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, LARRY
description: MORRIS-Larry. On June 14, 1998 at the age of 86. Beloved husband of the late Libby. Adored father of Stephen and Marjorie. Dear father-in-law of Marlene. Loving grandfather of David, Gary, Allison and Eric. A pioneer in motion picture theatre exhibition. He will be deeply missed. Service 1:30PM Wednesday, June 17, 1998 at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: Closing Off Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, RICHARD L.
description: ROSENTHAL-Richard L. Of Stamford, CT. Loving husband of Hinda Gould Rosenthal. Devoted father of Jamie Wolf and Rick Rosenthal. Father-in-law of David Wolf & Nancy Stephens Rosenthal. Adoring grandfather of Kate Wolf, Noah, Mick and Jane Rosenthal. Brother of Herbert C. Rosenthal of Santa Barbara, Ca. Died at home on June 13. Mr. Rosenthal was chairman of Assets Administration and Management, and chairman of the Richard and Hinda Rosenthal Foundation which encourages achievement and excellence in the arts, social sciences and medicine. He was also Chairman of the Stamford Center for the Arts. He was the Founder and CEO of Citizens Utilities and President of Utilities and Industries Corporation. His vitality and acumen were an inspiration to the many whose lives he touched. His loyalty, encouragement and devotion to his friends and family will continue to enrich our lives. Services will be private. A memorial to celebrate his life will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Richard and Hinda Rosenthal Foundation.

title: Fuel Cell Will Supply All Power to a Test House
description: For the first time, an energy technology called a fuel cell will supply all the power to a suburban house, another sign that the innovation is on the verge of breakthrough as an economical alternative to traditional energy sources.

title: Still Time to Overhaul the Courts
description: New York's Legislature may close down for the season this week, and slink home after having done virtually nothing but pass fiscally dangerous tax cuts. However, there is still time to change things. A breakthrough plan to reorganize the state's inefficient and complicated court system can be approved if only Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver summons the will to do it.

title: Political Briefing; Governor's Book At Issue in Arkansas
description: There is nothing new about political candidates writing books about themselves or public issues or both, and then having their selectively crafted works hit stores just as the campaign season heats up. Most of the tomes are then routinely greeted for what they are -- self-serving political advertisements.

title: CALENDAR
description: Twilight in Hollywood

title: Richard L. Rosenthal, a Utilities Entrepreneur, Is Dead at 82
description: Richard L. Rosenthal, who took control of a small troubled company called Citizens Utilities after World War II and built it into a powerhouse of profit that made millionaires of many investors who stuck with him until he retired in 1989, died on Saturday. He was 82 years old.

title: With a Bronx Cheer, Grammys Go to Los Angeles in '99
description: With a playful but pointed rebuke to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the head of the organization that runs the Grammy Awards announced today that next year's event would be held in Los Angeles, at the Shrine Auditorium.

title: U.S. Is Strong at Second-Guessing Itself
description: A day after a humbling 2-0 loss to Germany in the World Cup, the United States began looking toward Sunday's match with Iran while contemplating new personnel and a new attitude.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALERSTEIN, MIRIAM
description: WALERSTEIN-Miriam. June 15, 1998. Miriam was a valiant and remarkable woman who was devoted to her family, her late husband Harold, children Ronald and Jordan, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Donations in her memory may be made to The Jeffrey David Walerstein Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUELLER, GILBERT
description: MUELLER-Gilbert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Gilbert Mueller, associated with The Times from 1948, until retiring in 1981.

title: Teen-Ager Is Killed in Shooting in Manhattan
description: A gunman wielding a sawed-off shotgun fatally shot a teen-ager in Chelsea last night, then brandished his weapon at an undercover police officer before dashing into a housing project, the police said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AGCO CORP., Duluth, Ga., a farm machinery company, agreed to acquire the Spra-Coupe line of crop sprayers from the Ingersoll-Rand Co. for an undisclosed amount.

title: Harsh Penalty Sought For Stanton by Orioles
description: The American League will presumably make a decision later this week on whether or not to suspend Mike Stanton for hitting Baltimore's Eric Davis with a pitch Monday night. But the Yankee relief pitcher is already saying that if he is penalized, with a suspension or a fine, he will appeal.

title: Police Union Weighs Paying Legal Bills for Officer in Shooting of Squeegee Man
description: Appearing to distance itself from the officer charged in the shooting of a squeegee man on Sunday, officials of the city's police union said yesterday that they were weighing whether to continue paying his legal bills.

title: U.S. Argues That Livoti Violated Rights
description: A Federal prosecutor in Manhattan told a jury yesterday that Anthony Baez died one winter's night in 1994 outside his parents' home in the Bronx after he was intentionally choked during an arrest by a New York City police officer, Francis X. Livoti.

title: Shots Fired At the House Of a Rapist
description: Two weeks after neighbors and and officials were notified under New Jersey's ''Megan's Law'' that a convicted rapist lived in their town, five shots were fired early today into a two-story house where the paroled man lives.

title: Sapporo Journal; Hokkaido Catches Cold: Will All of Japan Sneeze?
description: Kimihiko Shimada's footsteps echo against the marble floors as he crosses the hall of the Therme International Hotel, a grand resort with everything from fake palm trees reaching up 11 stories to a roller coaster water slide.

title: By the Book; Desserts That Could Be by Armani
description: IN their homes, Italians refuse to budge on the issue of desserts. The guiding principle is so brilliantly simple: whatever follows a meal should be pure, fresh and, preferably, seasonal -- an aid to digestion, an inducement to further conversation. It's an Armani way of eating: the elegance of restraint.

title: Barney's Heirs To Step Down As Co-Chiefs
description: Bob and Gene Pressman, the grandsons of the founder of Barney's Inc., the luxury fashion retailer, will step down as co-chief executives as early as this week as part of the company's plan to emerge from bankruptcy.

title: The Transformation Of Captain Yzerman
description: During the course of the Stanley Cup finals, Brendan Shanahan said that hockey teams -- like pets with their owners -- begin to resemble their leader over time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTBERG, EUGENE J.
description: LUSTBERG-Eugene J. A man whose life was dominated by his love for his family and friends, and his devotion to his work at Dazian. His wife, Lila, his children, Kay and Michael Goldbeck, Regina and Stuart Lustberg and grandchildren Joseph, Ethan, Zachary, Sara and David will forever be grateful for the gift of having him in our lives. Services 12PM on Thursday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The World Beckons, and One More Chinese Chef Leaves America
description: DURING a banquet of whole shark fin, abalone with goose web and fish maw, scallops and sea conch in brandy sauce, and minced lobster in lettuce cups, Ken Hom, the man who tried to put a wok in every American home, was supposed to discuss the reasons Americans aren't interested in Chinese haute cuisine.

title: Affidavit Says CUNY Spied on Students
description: After a surveillance camera was discovered earlier this month at City College of New York -- concealed in a smoke detector outside a student meeting room -- cries of Big Brother tactics were heard around the campus: the college had strayed into invasion of privacy and was trying to silence dissent.

title: Two CUNY Colleges in Queens Plan to Merge
description: Into the swirl of proposals about how the City University of New York should be transformed comes one more: a plan to merge Queens College and Queensborough Community College to create a bigger, more comprehensive university, akin to the Albany or Stony Brook campuses of the State University of New York, with its own doctoral programs and more generous funding.

title: How Senate Voted On Lawyers' Fees
description: Following is the 49-to-48 roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today to limit lawyers' fees in lawsuits against cigarette makers in an amendment to tobacco legislation sponsored by Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington. Forty-five Republicans and 4 Democrats voted yes. Forty Democrats and 8 Republicans voted no. One Democrat and one Republican voted ''present'' and one Republican was absent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EISENSTEIN, ENID ROSALINDE
description: EISENSTEIN-Enid Rosalinde. June 17, 1953--May 12, 1977 Beloved Daughter Without you No rose can grow; No leaf be green If never seen Your sweetest face; No bird have grace Or pow'r to sing Or anything Be kind or fair, And you nowhere. Rebe Eisenstein, loving family and friends

title: Charming Shoppes Chooses Doner
description: Charming Shoppes Inc. in Philadelphia has named W. B. Doner & Company in Southfield, Mich., to handle advertising for its Fashion Bug retail chain, with billings estimated at $10 million. The account had been divided between Earle Palmer Brown in Philadelphia, for creative, and the Media Edge in New York, part of Young & Rubicam Inc., for media. Doner, which had participated in a previous review in November for the creative part of the Fashion Bug account, was selected without another review.

title: Justice Thomas Declines to Drop Speech to Bar
description: The afternoon of July 29 in Memphis could prove an exquisitely interesting if awkward moment; Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court has told the National Bar Association that he intends to deliver a luncheon speech at its annual convention even though he received a subsequent letter from some members withdrawing the invitation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURGER, ETHEL
description: HAMBURGER-Ethel. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Ethel Hamburger and extends its heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. David L. Rudnick, President Robert S. Puder, Secretary

description: Movies perform all sorts of back flips to shock people these days, which makes an early scene in the documentary ''Gerrie and Louise'' notable for its understated horror. The film's central figure, Gerrie Hugo, once a commander of a South African hit squad, is discussing torture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KYLE, DANA ROOSEVELT
description: KYLE-Dana Roosevelt. Aged 40. Died June 14, Sedona, Arizona. Memorial Services Saturday, June 20, 1PM, Aspen Community Church, Aspen, Colorado. Contributions: Nature Conservancy, 1244 Pine, Boulder, Colorado 80302.

description: Very New York

title: The Impresario Plays With the Performers
description: It was a strange but telling way to open this year's JVC Jazz Festival: George Wein, the festival's founder and producer, came out and spent the first half of the concert, a tribute to Fats Waller, playing piano and singing. The performance, on Monday at the Kaye Playhouse, was discomforting because of the brazenness of Mr. Wein's handling of his power -- he is at best a mildly able pianist and singer -- and it pointed out a reason for the festival's precipitate decline. Run as a fief, the festival has become an adjunct to his taste.

title: Rojas Still Struggling to Find Form
description: The Mets' pitching coach, Bob Apodaca, bristled when asked whether the team had been hiding Mel Rojas in its bullpen at times this season to keep Rojas from hurting the team's chances late in close games.

title: Mines on the Road to Reform
description: After months of false starts, the House today embarks on a path that could lead to genuine campaign finance reform. Newt Gingrich and other foes of change have lined the road with mines and booby traps, but if reformers counterattack with discipline and force they can quickly gain the upper hand. The Shays-Meehan bill, which would ban unlimited ''soft money'' donations to parties and impose other sensible fund-raising limits, is close to commanding a majority. Supporters need to show right away that they have the votes to reject dozens of amendments that the Speaker and other obstructionists will try to put forward to stymie the process.

title: G.M.'s Plant in Brazil Raises Fears Closer to Home
description: The strikes now crippling General Motors, while partly about short-term job security and workplace safety disputes, reflect a larger struggle over how far G.M. will go in adopting at home the manufacturing techniques it is introducing abroad.

title: An Overshadowed Altruist Sees the Light
description: MEET Paul Soros, the invisible Soros. He is 71, the older brother of George, the 67-year-old financier-philanthropist famous for giving away nearly $2 billion. Big brother says little brother got all the attention when they were children -- ''that's always what the older one feels.'' It hasn't changed today, unless you know that Paul Soros made his own fortune, separate from George, building the world's largest industrial ports.

title: $25 and Under; In the East Village, Bistro Food With Indian Accents
description: IN a world where culinary borders have posed no obstacles for experimental chefs, it's hard to fathom why Indian and Western kitchens have taken so long to reach over. Chefs, too, must have been wondering, because they are now rushing to the simple but appetizing idea of blending Indian and Western ingredients and techniques.

title: China Frets About Yen, Fanning Talk of Its Own Devaluation
description: As if the falling yen were not causing enough heartache in Asia, investors here and abroad are now fretting about another potential crisis: the devaluation of the Chinese currency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, WILLIAM S.
description: STEIN-William S. June 15, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Eleanor; loving father of Nancy MacMillan and her husband Duncan; cherished grandfather of Alissa and Kevin. Devoted brother of the late James and the late Richard. Contributions in his memory may be made to Lenox Hill HospitalVolunteer Office, 100 East 77 Street, NYC 10021. Funeral private.

title: Martin Is Cleared to Use a Golf Cart for the U.S. Open
description: The United States Golf Association will allow Casey Martin to use a regular golf cart this week at the United States Open.

title: Mastering the Art of the Perfectly Grilled Fish
description: GRILLING a whole fish is to outdoor cookery what a triple axel is to figure skating: the apex of the skill pyramid, daunting enough to turn back many challengers. As such, accomplishing it provides a sense of mastery.

description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation and its machinists' union, the carrier's largest employee group, signed a tentative labor contract agreement today after nearly two years of negotiations.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Japan's New 'Temp' Workers; Rethinking Lifetime Jobs and Their Underpinnings
description: This spring, Suguru Takamatsu, one of 814 new employees of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, took his destiny into his own hands.

title: For Nigeria's Leader, Offense Is the Best Defense
description: From the moment Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar was selected last week to succeed the late ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, Nigerians began speculating whether a reformist era might be at hand after years of ruinous dictatorship. After all, General Abubakar was long reputed to be a prim professional among Nigeria's politicized and immensely rich generals.

description: To the Editor:

title: Doubling 'Moneyline'
description: Trying to build audiences by capitalizing on one of its better-known names, the Cable News Network is expected to announce today that the financial news program ''Moneyline With Lou Dobbs'' will be expanded to one hour from a half-hour, starting next week, and will change its name to reflect a broader approach.

title: Metro Business; Job Creation Continues
description: New Jersey's labor market continued to expand last month, with the creation of 10,200 new jobs and a dip in the unemployment rate to 5.0 percent, from 5.1 percent in April, the State Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: Ponson No Longer Unknown to Yanks
description: Sidney Ponson ascended the mound for Baltimore tonight practically unknown outside of his homeland of Aruba, a young pitcher looking for his first major league victory. Now he is the primary reason the Yankees are in their first mini-slump in more than than two months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTIS, RALPH V.O.
description: CURTIS-Ralph V.O., 83. Of Stillwater, N.J., died on June 16, 1998. Husband of Beatrice Curtis. Brother of A. Dudley and Elizabeth Stradtman. Uncle of four. Retired attorney/partner, Mendes & Mount, NYC. Visitation, Thursday, 7 to 9 P.M., with VFW services, 8PM, at Smith-McCracken Funeral Home, Newton, NJ. Donations to Karen Ann Quinlan Hospice, 99 Sparta Ave, Newton, N.J. 07860.

title: Beet Pancakes (Hold the Syrup)
description: ALTHOUGH sweetness is not an unfamiliar sensation at the dinner table, no so-called savory food gives quite the experience of the beet, whose intensity is incomparable. This has typically led cooks to counter its sweetness with acidity or other sharp flavors, a natural inclination that has given us beets with vinegar, beets with sour cream, beets with lemon, vinaigrette, ginger, and so on.

title: Judge Rebuffs Drug Agency on Effort to Ban Diet Supplement
description: The Food and Drug Administration today lost the first round of its legal battle with the manufacturer of Cholestin, an herbal remedy being marketed as a dietary supplement to reduce cholesterol but which the agency is trying to declare an illegal drug.

title: OUTDOOR ADVERTISER BUYING DAME MEDIA, A BROADCASTER
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc. of San Antonio, the outdoor advertising company, agreed to acquire Dame Media Inc., a closely held broadcasting company, for $85 million in stock and assumed debt. Dame Media, based in Harrisburg, Pa., operates stations in New York and Pennsylvania. This is the latest media acquisition for Clear Channel, which now owns 219 radio stations and 18 television stations in 48 markets in addition to its 88,000 outdoor advertising displays in 31 markets. Clear Channel shares rose $1.6875, to $102.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLEISNER, KARLA
description: SCHLEISNER-Karla. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Karla Schleisner, associated with The Times from 1974, until retiring in 1986.

title: Doctor-Owned Managed Care Plan Collapses
description: In a sobering blow to the many doctors who want to recapture control of their patients' care, the California Medical Association is shutting down the managed care company that it and 7,500 of its member physicians created to take on the state's big health maintenance organizations.

title: Dining in the West With an Eastern Approach
description: I WILL never forget that narrow storefront on East Broadway in Chinatown, where many years ago a Chinese business acquaintance of my husband's once took us to dinner. There were little pans of dried seafood in the window. The dishes were plastic, the napkins paper, and the food, including my first taste of Shanghai soup dumplings, was delicious.

title: Sony and Lowe End Relationship
description: The Sony Electronics unit of the Sony Corporation of America and Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York said yesterday that they would part company after more than three years. Billings on the account were estimated at $35 million to $50 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNBLATT, OSCAR
description: KORNBLATT-Oscar. A 17 year resident of Shelter Island, New York died June 15 at his home. A nonreligious gathering will be held Thursday, June 18 at 3PM, Shelter Island Funeral Home (phone 516749-3119). Born January 2, 1920 in Manhattan to Rose Gutterman Kornblatt and Harry (Herschel) Kornblatt. Oscar founded SnoHaus Ski Shops in 1959. He served with decorations in W.W. II. We loved him for his sense of humor, the relish he brought to life, & his unique intelligence. His survivors include Helen Krizek Kornblatt, his wife of 27 years; Helene Kornblatt, Neil Kornblatt & Susan Idell, his children; Sylvia Alpert, the children's mother; sister Sylvia Silver and brother Jack Kornblatt; and grandchildren Adam Hirsch, Julia and Monica Kornblatt, and Elena & Michael Idell. His brother Lou preceded him in death. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, Attn: Tribute Committe, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place SW, Washington, D.C. 20024.

title: Networks Cheered by Sales Of 1998-99 Commercial Time
description: That loud sound you may have heard in recent days was a collective sigh emanating from the top executives of the four major broadcast television networks, who have been able to sell about as much advance commercial time for the 1998-99 prime-time season as they did for 1997-98.

title: Wine Talk; The Other Bordeaux, Where Bargains Exist
description: DON'T give up on Bordeaux. Prices are going through the roof and in recent weeks there has been some unpleasantness at one of the chateaus, Giscours, over alleged shortcuts in the winemaking. But keep in mind that there are two Bordeaux.

title: COX BUYS CABLE TV SYSTEMS IN ARIZONA FROM TCI
description: Cox Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired cable television systems in Tucson, Sierra Vista and parts of Pima County, Ariz., from TCI Communications Inc., part of the TCI Group of Tele-Communications Inc. of Englewood, Colo. Terms were not disclosed. The systems have 115,000 customers, Cox said. Cox, based in Atlanta, has interests in international and domestic cable distribution systems, programming networks and telecommunications technology.

title: Critic's Notebook; Of Sculpture and the Past Revivified
description: The announcement said simply, ''Ellsworth Kelly: Sculpture for a Large Wall, 1957,'' a title that didn't prepare me for a reunion with an old friend. But there it was, alarmingly visible through the window of the Matthew Marks Gallery at 522 West 22d Street in Chelsea: the portal to the city of my youth. The piece, an immense aluminum construction created by Mr. Kelly for the Transportation Building in downtown Philadelphia, which remains on view through Saturday, has been a joy of the spring season.

title: John Gutmann, 93, Painter Who Became a Photographer
description: John Gutmann, a painter who left Germany in 1933 and reinvented himself as an optimistic photographic chronicler of Depression-era America, died on Friday at his home in San Francisco. He was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCSWEENEY, EDWARD F. III (DOOLEY)
description: McSWEENEY-Edward F. III (Dooley). Seven years have rolled by and somehow you seem to continue to touch the lives of the legion of friends you left behind. Ryan has learned the ''business of the business'' while Goldstein has become a Joycean Scholar of his usual evangelical intensity. Berg and Gardner found themselves spending the first hour of a recent dinner on ''Dooley Stories.'' Some of us are catching the scent of something called ''roses'' .... which causes you to be missed all the more. Thanks for the memories babycakes. See ya! Your pal, JPK.

description: In another vote on campaign finance, the House tonight resoundingly rejected a measure that was widely considered one of the main threats to a bipartisan bill to ban unregulated campaign contributions.
