description: ROSENTHAL-Richard L. The faculty and staff of NYU School of Medicine and Medical Center mourn the passing of a loyal and visionary philanthropist, Richard L. Rosenthal. He was a longtime supporter of the University and the School of Medicine through the Richard and Hinda Rosenthal Foundation which encourages achievement and excellence in the arts, social sciences and medicine. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Hinda and to all the members of the Rosenthal family. E. John Rosenwald, Jr., Chairman, Board of Trustees, NYU Medical Center Noel L. title: Mets' Rojas Is Undone By Expos Left and Right
description: The rule of thumb in baseball is that right-handed hitters should have more trouble with right-handed pitchers than when lefties are on the mound. But these days, that rule doesn't apply when the right-handed reliever Mel Rojas is pitching for the Mets.

title: In 'Kudzu,' The South Learns About Itself
description: Not everyone who lives in the South, who was born in the lee of a kudzu-ensnarled water tower on a road where filling stations advertise barbecue and worms in the same breath and the hard-headed mechanic works only on American cars, actually loves the South.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, CATHERINE OLIVE LAUREL (COWEN)
description: MURPHY-Catherine Olive Laurel (Cowen), 79, of Truro, MA., in Hyannis, MA., on Thursday, June 11th, 1998. Wife of the late Adrian M. Murphy. Mother of Serre A. Murphy of Rockledge, Florida. Step-mother of Lydia Savage of Near Pineswick, Gloucester, England. Aunt of Robert Stephens of Tyngsboro, MA. Grandmother of Brendan Murphy, Laura Savage, Rebecca Savage, and Belinda Savage. A Funeral service will be held in Christian Union Church, Truro, MA., Wednesday, June 17, 1998 at 2:00 P.M. Friends may call at Nickerson Funeral Home, Main Street, Wellfleet, MA., Tuesday, June 16, 1998 from 7:00 to 9:00 PM and at the church from 1:00 to 2:00 PM on Wednesday. Interment will be in Congregational Cemetery, Truro. Donations in her memory may be made to the charity of one's choice.

Mr. Lyskanycz had been a managing partner at Ogilvy & Mather Chicago, part of WPP Group P.L.C.

Cherished grandfather of Lori, Wendy, Alejandro, Douglas, Adam and Gracie. Loving friend of Eva Yurman. Services Thursday, 1 PM, at Gutterman's Inc., 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Though His Bill Is Dead, McCain May Be Enlivened
description: The death of tobacco legislation in the Senate today was a stinging disappointment for Senator John McCain of Arizona, yet it might burnish his image as a Republican maverick.

title: Study Sees High Revenue in a Governors Island Casino
description: A new study commissioned by the Mayor's office to look at the future of Governors Island has concluded that high-class gambling casino would provide the most revenue of any development option being considered -- more than enough to meet the expense of preserving the historic northern part of the island.

title: LASALLE AND JONES LANG WOOTTON IN MERGER TALKS
description: LaSalle Partners Inc., a Chicago-based real estate company, said yesterday that it was in talks with Jones Lang Wootton, a privately owned British real estate company, that might lead to a merger. The London-based Jones Lang Wootton, which has 4,000 employees in 33 countries, said LaSalle shares would be issued if a transaction was completed. LaSalle also said it was in negotiations with the Lend Lease Corporation, an Australian investment and fund management company, to buy Compass Management and Leasing Inc., its Atlanta-based property management unit, as well as Lend Lease's United States retail management business. LaSalle's shares fell $5.75, to $40.

title: Thousands Lose Power In Severe Thunderstorms
description: A series of severe thunderstorms struck northern New Jersey, New York City and Long Island last night, knocking out power to more than 8,000 customers and delaying flights at two of the region's major airports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, NINA S.
description: ALTMAN-Nina S. On June 17th. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Altman. Loving mother of Jane Altman Rubin and Susan Altman Miller. Devoted grandmother of J. Bradford Miller, Bennett Altman Miller, Theodore Wyatt Miller and Jordan Bernard Rubin. Funeral on Friday, June 19, at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, New York, at 9:30 A.M. Burial at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings, New York.

title: A Universal Quest for Bargains; Japanese Flock to Outlet Center in the Hudson Valley
description: Machiko Takenaka, 25, a self-described ''office lady'' from Tokyo, was on a whirlwind tour of New York City. The day before, she had seen ''Cats.'' She was bound for a Mets game in the afternoon. But on this lovely spring morning, she had carved out time for that supreme Japanese-tourist pastime: shopping. Gucci, Max Mara and Anne Klein were just a few of the stores on her itinerary.

title: CALL-NET RAISES FONOROLA BID TO $67 (CANADIAN) A SHARE
description: Call-Net Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it had increased its unsolicited bid to acquire the long-distance carrier Fonorola Inc. to $67 (Canadian) a share, a total of $1.78 billion (Canadian), or $1.21 billion (United States), in cash and nonvoting shares. Last month, Call-Net offered $60 (Canadian) a share, or $1.6 billion (Canadian). Call-Net is 25 percent owned by the Sprint Corporation of Kansas City, Mo. Call-Net, based in Toronto, provides long-distance service under the Sprint Canada brand name. Fonorola is assembling a fiber optic network across North America.

title: Prudential Bill Raises Concern For Consumers
description: With billions of dollars at stake and after little debate, New Jersey lawmakers are poised to adopt legislation governing the reorganization of the Prudential Insurance Company of America that consumer advocates say contains troubling loopholes that could shortchange nearly 11 million policyholders.

title: Accepting for 'Citizen Kane'...
description: Critics say the American Film Institute's much-publicized list of the 100 best American movies of all time is simply a marketing device for studios with a lot of old videos to sell. If so, it is a pretty good one. It was hard to watch the three-hour CBS countdown of the golden hundred Tuesday evening without making mental notes of things to rent during the next rainy season. ''The Grapes of Wrath'' seems to be aging very well.

title: Economic Scene; Will Japan try to inflate its way out of its economic morass?
description: WITH Japan now officially in recession and the yen sagging to an eight-year low, the Clinton Administration has finally intervened to prop up the beleaguered Japanese currency. No one is claiming that the intervention is more than a palliative. One way or another Japan must jump-start its long-sputtering economy.

title: U.S. Says It Told Russia 2 Days Before Balkan Aerial Maneuvers
description: Top NATO officials formally notified Russia about Monday's aerial military exercises in the Balkans two days before they took place, Western officials said today, although Russian officials have complained they were left in the dark.

description: LUSTBERG-Eugene. Dazian Fabrics mourns the loss of their longtime Secretary, Treasurer and CFO, Eugene Lustberg. He will be remembered for his devoted service and leadership. We wish to express our deepest sympathy to his wife, Lila, children, Kay and Stuart and family.

title: A Daughter Gathers Swatches of Memory
description: I thought I saw my father at the Lathrop furniture store the other day. He was standing by the Chiclets dispenser, looking out over an endless sea of walnut rockers and lampshades swaddled in crisp plastic wrappers. He was carrying his decrepit leather sample case under his arm, so bursting with fabric swatches he could barely keep it together with a piece of string.

title: Better to Light One Candle

But there are hazards: in cooperation with the Consumer Product Safety Commission, the Conros Corporation of Toronto has recalled 30,000 fuel canisters for its Summer Lights outdoor bamboo torches. The plastic canisters can cause the bamboo poles to ignite.

title: Jack Biblo, Used Bookseller For Half a Century, Dies at 91
description: Jack Biblo, a bookish sort of man who spent a musty half century on Manhattan's Book Row as the founding proprietor of the Biblo & Tannen used, er antiquarian, bookstore on Fourth Avenue, then retired at 73 to open a smaller store around the corner from his home in Brooklyn Heights, died on June 5 at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 91 and until a couple of years ago had been active at the Biblo bookstore on Hicks Street.

title: South Korea May Look For Tobacco Investors
description: South Korea said yesterday that it might sell a 25 percent stake in its $3 billion cigarette monopoly to foreign investors, a possibility that is drawing interest from Rothmans UK Holdings P.L.C. of Britain and from other tobacco companies. The Government, which owns 37.3 percent of the Korea Tobacco and Ginseng Company, plans to sell stakes in several companies to attract foreign capital and help pull the country out of its first recession since 1980.

description: Last Thursday, Robert E. Rubin, the Secretary of the Treasury, made comments to Congress that currency traders took as a green light to sell billions more yen, driving the currency to nearly an eight-year low.

title: Vietnam the Way It Wasn't

This was the case last week, when Time magazine and Cable News Network's ''Newsstand'' asserted that in September 1970, United States Special Forces used sarin, a lethal nerve gas, on a Laotian village believed to be harboring American soldiers who had defected.

description: The Australian conductor Sir Charles Mackerras has accepted an appointment as music director of the Orchestra of St. Luke's, effective Sept. 1. The announcement was made yesterday by Marianne C. Lockwood, the president and executive director of the New York-based chamber orchestra. Mr. Mackerras, who has been a frequent guest conductor with St. Luke's, has signed a three-year contract and will conduct his first concert as music director on Jan. 28, 1999, at Carnegie Hall, as part of the orchestra's yearlong Haydn festival.

title: Hundley and Mets Near a No-Trade Clause
description: Early today, the Mets' co-owner Fred Wilpon had again stressed the organization's desire to keep both Todd Hundley and Mike Piazza happy. It could soon be a case of one down, one to go, as it appears General Manager Steve Phillips is close to an agreement with Hundley on a no-trade clause that could run up to the All-Star Game break in 1999.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about two Queens colleges of the City University of New York referred incorrectly to the status of a proposal to merge them. It has been submitted to CUNY officials, not approved.

The Zamboni Model 100 Ice Rink Resurfacing Machine will soon be offered for $9,995 at Sportsite.com, say officials at the site (www.sportsite.com). A warning: The tractor's not included.

title: William Schwann, 85, Founder Of the Noted Record Catalogue
description: William Schwann, an organist, musicologist and publisher who started a record catalogue in 1949 that became an indispensable resource for browsers, collectors, musicians, critics and record company executives, died on June 7 at the Lahey Clinic in Burlington, Mass. He was 85.

title: In America; Sci-Fi In the Sky
description: The Mayor will probably go one for two. A new stadium for the Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan will never happen. But Rudolph Giuliani will probably get his skybox bunker, the overpriced emergency command center on the 23d floor of a World Trade Center building.

title: A.M.A. Retains Chief Despite Sunbeam Furor
description: Delegates to the American Medical Association voted today to retain their current leadership, rejecting a presidential candidate who was critical of a failed deal to allow the commercial use of the A.M.A.'s name.

title: Joint Efforts to Prop Up Yen Cause a Selloff in Treasuries
description: Intervention by the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan yesterday on behalf of the yen sent the dollar plunging and caused the second consecutive sharp selloff in the Treasury market. The strong gains in many Asian stock markets also stemmed the flight into Treasuries.

title: How the Senate Voted on Cloture
description: Following is the 53-to-46 roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today effectively killing the tobacco bill. A 'yes' vote was to keep the bill on the Senate floor; a 'no' was to send it back to the Senate Commerce Committee. Those favoring further debate needed 60 votes. Forty-two Democrats and 11 Republicans voted 'yes.' Three Democrats and 43 Republicans voted 'no.' One Republican was absent.

title: Strong Foursome Defeated In International Team Trials
description: One of the country's strongest teams was defeated yesterday in the International Team Trials in Tunica, Miss. Steve Robinson of Arlington, Va.; Peter Boyd of Silver Spring, Md.; Ed Manfield of Hyattsville, Md., and Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif., lost by 33 imps to Brian Gunnell of Jacksonville, Fla.; Kyle Larsen of San Francisco; Billy Miller of Las Vegas, and Curtis Cheek of Huntsville, Ala.

title: Francis Lee, Combat Cameraman, 85
description: Francis Lee, a combat cameraman who documented the D-Day invasion of Normandy in 1944 and was a member of an avant-garde film movement, died on May 29 at a nursing home in Manhattan. He was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Wartime Nightmare Is Still Alive in a Small French Town
description: At first it looks like hundreds of other small towns lost in the French countryside, with its two friendly cafes, its flower boxes and its proud little City Hall. But the streets are straighter and the facades are cleaner, and many buildings lie in ruins.

title: Bowman's Toughness Spurred Wings to Title
description: Two days before the Stanley Cup finals began, Coach Scotty Bowman brought his Detroit Red Wings onto the ice at Joe Louis Arena early on a Sunday morning. Game 1 was still more than 48 hours away, and it could have been a sloppy, unfocused practice. Gathering his mostly veteran champions in a circle at center ice, Bowman began to bark instructions out for a new drill. Everyone, even in the seats, could hear every word. But in their totality, the instructions were disjointed and made little sense. Confused, the players tried the new drill and messed it up.

title: Investigator Is Named In Greenwich Murder
description: The state has appointed a one-man investigative grand jury to look again into the murder of a Greenwich teen-ager nearly 23 years ago, a state official close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: The Web Reflects a Wider World
description: FOR Becky Juarez, a chatty teen-ager who recently graduated from high school, the Internet is a juicy electronic grapevine virtually crammed with information she wants, like gossip about her favorite movie stars, no-nonsense descriptions of courses offered by the college she plans to attend in the fall and tidbits about bittersweet teen-age life, exchanged in scads of E-mail messages and in on-line chat rooms.

title: Death of the Tobacco Bill
description: By killing tobacco control legislation that would have helped curb teen-age smoking, the Republicans in the Senate have shown that they simply cannot wean themselves from tobacco money. The bill that would have raised cigarette prices and increased Federal authority to regulate tobacco ads was approved by the Senate Commerce Committee 19 to 1. But during four weeks of debate Republicans demanded one amendment after another, threatening to kill the bill at every turn. They succeeded in larding it with unrelated elements such as a tax cut for married couples, new anti-drug programs and a cap on attorneys' fees for lawyers who sue the tobacco industry.

title: New Conservative News Site Will Fill a Void, Founder Says
description: Convinced that the Clinton White House is awash in scandals that national television networks have ignored, L. Brent Bozell 3d, chairman of Media Research Center, a conservative watchdog group in Alexandria, Va., this week opened his own news operation on the Net.

Stern, the New York City Commissioner of Parks and Recreation, told the estimated crowd of 15,000 people who turned out on Tuesday night for this summer's first free performance of the Met in the Parks series on the Great Lawn in Central Park. ''So be good to it. Don't step too hard. Don't leave anything on it.''

title: Ex-Sparring Partner Confident vs. Jones
description: Lou Del Valle believes the 30 rounds he logged as a sparring partner for Roy Jones Jr. should help him defeat Jones in their coming bout to unify the light-heavyweight title. Del Valle (27-1, 19 knockouts), the World Boxing Association champion, taped the training sessions and studies them at his Bronx home. But Jones has warned Del Valle not to put so much stock in footage.

description: The Coventry Industries Corporation of Boca Raton, Fla., which had sales of $4.65 million for the year ended last June, agreed yesterday to acquire Communicare P.E.O. for more than $50 million to expand its employee staffing services. Coventry also said it terminated its letter of intent to acquire Kiwi International Holdings Inc., a low-fare airline, as the two companies could not reach an agreement. Communicare P.E.O., a three-year-old subsidiary of the closely held Communicare Health Services, a Cincinnati-based health services company, is projected to have annual revenue of $105 million.

description: Russia's new national security adviser, the thoughtful academician Andrei Kokoshin, is in town to reassure the Clinton Administration it should not worry about Moscow's technology exports to Iran.

title: On the Salsa Circuit, an Improviser With an Elastic Tempo
description: D'Mingo, a 24-year-old singer who is beginning to work regularly on the New York salsa circuit, played a set at the Copacabana on Friday night. He's an improviser, and during his tune ''No Me Mientas Mas,'' the chorus sang ''Tu eres una mentirosa'' (''You're a liar''). In between the bursts of choral sound, he rhymed three or four words at a time, making the tempo elastic with melodic repetitions that never repeated exactly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARDINALI, MARY T. (NEE RUSSO)
description: CARDINALI-Mary T. (nee Russo). On June 16, 1998. Wife of the late Louis. Cherished mother of Barbara. Loving mother-in-law and confidante of Morton Toffler. Dear step-grandmother of Elise and Hilton. Beloved sister of Josephine Swanson, fond aunt of Edwin and Roger Swanson, and Rudolph and Robert Russo. Pre-deceased by sisters Pasqualina Frazette, Rose Romano & brother Michael Russo. A lifelong resident of Greenwich Village, Mary was a lovely, energetic, enthusiastic, vibrant woman, affectionately referred to by some friends as the ''Flower Lady'' since her husband was the owner of a well known, long established Village flower shop on Bleecker Street. Courageous in the face of daunting obstacles, thereby heightening her sensitivity to the pain in others, she left priceless legacies of love, compassion, caring words and actions, all done with a gentle heart. She demonstrated these acts many, many times, always ready to help another, whether family, friend, or even stranger. If she could help, she would. Honest, faithful & wise, she would listen intently &, most important, without criticism, before giving counsel. Mary had dark, sparkling eyes, with a true zest for living, & a spontaneous, genuine, sunny smile, radiating joy, warmth and merriment, which proved to be healing to others. She brought light to many with her generosity of spirit. We were so blessed to have known her, and it was our privilege to be her daughter and son-in-law. She will be forever cherished in our memories, and we will continue to be enriched by her inspiration in our lives. Memories are the treasures of the heart and balm for the soul. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, NYC, Friday, June 19, 2-5 & 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass Saturday at 9:30 A.M., Our Lady of Pompeii RC Church. Interment in Calvary Cemetery, Queens, New York.

title: India Defense Chief Calls U.S. Hypocritical
description: India's Defense Minister said today that President Clinton should explain why the United States believes that it can ''trust China with nuclear weapons'' while imposing economic sanctions on India for seeking a nuclear deterrent against threats from its nuclear-armed neighbors, China and Pakistan.

title: Stocks Rally After Moves To Bolster Yen
description: The stock market staged a powerful rally yesterday after the United States and Japan bought yen to bolster the sagging currency, which has threatened to plunge Asia into a deeper economic crisis.

title: Arts in America; A Wagnerian Match: Grand Opera and Grand Canyon
description: Seven thousand feet up and a basso rumble from the Grand Canyon is not a place Franz Ehgartner expected to find himself. A retired pharmacist from Graz, Austria, Mr. Ehgartner had been to the United States only once, last year, to see the Wagner ''Ring'' Cycle at the Metropolitan Opera in New York. But here he was on his 80th birthday at Ardrey Auditorium on the campus of Northern Arizona University, between Act I and Act II of ''Gotterdammerung,'' the final opera of the ''Ring,'' presented by the Arizona Opera Company.

description: President Clinton has decided to name Richard C. Holbrooke as the American representative at the United Nations, replacing Bill Richardson, who will become Secretary of Energy, senior Administration officials said today.

description: MOST software packages offer their users the chance to use compression to save disk space and make downloads faster. But what is compression? It's a shorthand system that computers use to save space. In other words, it's like lingo, buzzwords or telegramspeak -- short abbreviations people adopt to save words.

In the past five months, she has conducted 44 opinion polls on questions ranging from the political (''Should President Clinton be impeached?'') to the personal (''Which smell do you prefer in a lover?'') to the philosophical (''How often do you behave according to your ideals?''). So far her polls have prompted more than 2,000 responses.

description: The state would sell the rights to $2 billion in uncollected income taxes and other debt under a bill to be considered today by the Assembly that is backed by the State Treasury Department.

title: Japanese Lender Denies Reports of Problems
description: The Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, the nation's second-largest credit bank, has dismissed rumors that it had severe financial problems as ''groundless talk.'' Long-Term Credit Bank's shares closed down 30 yen, or 19.6 percent, yesterday, at 123 yen.

title: A Strong International Court
description: After decades of discussion and years of long and fractious planning meetings, a permanent international criminal court to try the likes of Pol Pot and Saddam Hussein is close to becoming a reality. This week in Rome, representatives of 156 nations gathered to write rules for a court, which will take the form of a treaty for nations to ratify. They should not waste this opportunity to put international muscle behind their rhetoric on punishing international crimes. They should design an effective and independent court, and not give in to nations such as the United States that want to cripple it.

title: Clues Found to Why Chest Blows Kill
description: Matthew Messing was playing hockey in Quincy, Mass., one evening in 1995 when an opponent checked him in the chest with a routine bump. Sixteen-year-old Matthew had taken plenty of such blows before, but after this one, he collapsed on the ice and died instantly of heart failure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULVEY, JOHN FRANCIS
description: MULVEY-John Francis. At age 91, died Tuesday, in Little Falls, NY. Born in New Haven, CT, he was a former thirty-five year resident of Pelham Manor, NY and retired to Bolton, CT. John was a graduate of Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, Class of 1928 and Fordham Law School. He was a former trial attorney and partner with the law firm of Engel, Judge and Miller and retired in 1975. Mr. Mulvey was a Past President of the Bronx Bar Association, former Trustee and Mayor of Pelham Manor and Past President of the Pelham Country Club. He was the husband of fifty-five years of the late Estelle Sisk Mulvey, who died on Feb. 28, 1992, and is survived by three children, Katherine Mulvey Schuler, John Sisk Mulvey and Peter Sisk Mulvey; six grandchildren, and his brother, Honorable Harold M. Mulvey of New Haven, CT. Funeral service will be on Saturday at 10:15 from the John F. Tierney Funeral Home, 219 West Center Street, Manchester, CT, followed by a Mass of Christian Burial at 11:00 at St. Maurice Church, Bolton, CT with burial in Bolton Center Cemetery. Family and friends may call at the funeral home on Friday from 6-8.

title: Getting Ready for Windows 98, Microsoft Adds Tech Support
description: For months, Microsoft has billed Windows 98 as a move toward software simplicity and automated technical support, but the company doesn't seem to believe its own claims. In anticipation of the operating system's arrival on retailers' shelves next week, Microsoft has increased its technical support staff by 400, to more than 1,000.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: TIGHT SECURITY -- A new $49 security system from Securewin for desktop and laptop machines, introduced this week at PC Expo, restricts access to applications, prevents tampering with files and blocks children's access to Internet sites. A boot-lock feature prevents a stolen computer from being used. Now all the folks at Securewin need to do is throw a GPS receiver into the package so it can be tracked down.

title: Study Pokes Holes in Theory Of How Women Use the Net
description: The conventional wisdom regarding women and their Internet habits has them logging on to shop and schmooze. But a paper released today by Vanderbilt University's Project 2000, an electronic commerce program at the Owen Graduate School of Management, questions those and other assumptions about what women do on line.

title: At a Tribute to Herb Ellis, A Contrast With Old Heroes

Their Queen's English is a language of quiet, rapid, single-note lines in a watery tone, and two baseball teams full of them played at the Kaye Playhouse during a JVC Jazz Festival tribute to Mr. Ellis on Tuesday night.

title: STAFFING PROVIDERS TO MERGE IN $85 MILLION STOCK DEAL
description: The Data Processing Resources Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Systems and Programming Consultants Inc. for $85 million in stock. Systems and Programming, based in Charlotte, N.C., is an information technology staffing company with eight offices in the Southeast. Data Processing Resources, based in Newport Beach, Calif., provides information technology staffing services through 21 offices. For the nine months ended April 30, it had revenue of $146 million. Shares of Data Processing Resources were up $1.25 yesterday, to $32.625, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Public Eye; More Than Just Money
description: ABOUT a month ago, as preparations began for printing the 10 billion new euro banknotes that will replace the currencies of most European nations by 2002, a French anti-counterfeiting hologram vanished. The disappearance, which could prompt changes in the design, occurred on a flight from France to Germany, where it was to be tested by a printer in Nuremberg. Officials speculated that it had been stolen by well-informed thieves who understood what the device was.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS TO BUY HAVAS TRAVEL BUSINESS
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Havas Voyages, France's biggest travel agency, for about 1 billion French francs ($166 million) from Havas S.A. Havas and the New York-based American Express have operated a joint business travel venture in France for two years. For Havas, the sale is part of an effort to focus on publishing and multimedia under pressure from Vivendi S.A., which is buying Havas. Eric Licoys, president of Havas S.A., would not give a definitive price for the sale, saying it was ''about 1 billion francs.'' American Express's shares rose $3.5625 each, to $104.9325.

description: As he prepares to begin defense of his men's Wimbledon title next week, Pete Sampras, a four-time Wimbledon champion who has not won a Grand Slam event since winning there a year ago, admitted yesterday that neither his preparation nor his attitude had been letter perfect.

title: Amid Asian Crisis, Mahathir Holds On
description: KUALA LUMPUR  East Asia's upheaval has already toppled governments in Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia, and the question now being asked with increasing frequency in Malaysia is whether Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad will also have to take responsibility for a looming recession and hand over power.

title: Corrections

title: Bank Purchase in Nevada
description: Colonial Bancgroup, a bank in Alabama, agreed today to acquire Interwest Bancorp, based in Reno, for an undisclosed amount in stock, more than doubling its assets in Nevada. The transaction will bring Colonial's assets in Nevada to about $248 million and add four bank branches and four mortgage lending offices.

title: Suspect in Shooting Is Found in Chelsea
description: A suspect in the fatal shooting of a teen-ager in Chelsea Tuesday night was found hiding in an apartment in a nearby housing project early yesterday and was arrested, the police said.

title: At PC Expo, a Continuing Trend Toward the Tiny
description: IN this age of consumer convenience and ease of use, the name of the game is miniaturization. Both the appeal, and some of the limits, of miniaturization were abundantly evident this week in the cavernous Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York, where PC Expo, the largest computer trade show on the East Coast, opened on Tuesday and closes today.

title: When Volumes Cross the Sea
description: Do books travel across borders and leap oceans? The Harvill Press in London publishes only foreign books that have been translated into English. Or nearly so. Some were originally written in American, and a very few books were by English authors. But page after page of Harvill's glossy catalogues list books that were translated from the Italian, the French, the Russian, the Swedish, the German, the Serbo-Croatian. And on and on, a sort of atlas of the world's composition, mostly literary fiction.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 11 about a fight against cellular telephone towers in Vermont referred incompletely to a structure in the town of Charlotte. While the tower now includes a cellular antenna, it was built as a radio tower and also supports a radio antenna and an antenna for the local fire and rescue station. A cellular industry group reported the omission to The Times in March, but its request for a correction went astray through an editing lapse.

title: SENATE DROPS TOBACCO BILL WITH '98 REVIVAL UNLIKELY; CLINTON LASHES OUT AT G.O.P.
description: The Senate today jettisoned broad legislation meant to discourage teen-agers from smoking, the most ambitious and contentious measure before Congress, and left almost no hope that it could be revived this year.

title: Executive Changes
description: METROPOLITAN LIFE INSURANCE CO., New York, named Jon F. Danski senior vice president and corporate controller, succeeding Fred Hauser, who retired last year. Mr. Danski will run Met Life's corporate controller's department in Tampa, Fla., dividing time between Tampa and New York. He will report to Stewart G. Nagler, the chief financial officer.

title: West Bank Palestinian Killed; 2 Troubled Israeli Youths Held
description: Two Israeli teen-agers living in a hostel for troubled youths in a Jewish settlement near Hebron were jailed today after a Palestinian farmer was killed on a West Bank roadside when they hit him with a wooden pole from a passing van.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 9 about defects in the pollution control systems of Hondas misstated the amount of additional hydrocarbons that the Government predicted would be emitted without corrective action. It was 8,000 tons of hydrocarbons, not eight million tons.

title: Martin Stone, 83, Radio Pioneer And Producer of 'Howdy Doody'
description: Martin Stone, a longtime broadcasting executive and entertainment lawyer who was the producer of ''Howdy Doody'' and the founder of a suburban radio network, died on June 7 in Washington, where he was attending the graduation of a grandchild. He was 83 and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Sunbeam Ousts a Top Associate of Dunlap
description: The Sunbeam Corporation today dismissed its vice chairman and chief financial officer, Russell Kersh, a longtime aide to its ousted chairman, Albert J. Dunlap.

description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia appointed Anatoly B. Chubais today as his special representative to negotiate with the International Monetary Fund, which is sending a team to Russia on Monday to discuss the possibility of a new multibillion-dollar loan to help stabilize the country's financial markets.

title: L. L. Bean Picks Mullen Advertising
description: L. L. Bean Inc. said yesterday that it had named Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass., to handle its account, which had been handled for almost five years by Bronner Slosberg Humphrey in Boston. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Aide Faces Sex Charge In Case Involving Student
description: A 23-year-old clerical aide at a Manhattan high school was arrested yesterday on charges that he had sex with a 15-year-old student in a school stairwell, school officials said.

title: Virtual-Classes Trend Alarms Professors
description: ABOUT 850 professors at the University of Washington have signed an open letter to Gov. Gary Locke to say they are worried about the enthusiasm he and one of his advisers are showing for instruction via CD-ROM's and the Internet.

title: Defense Rests in Brawley Case, And a Courtroom Begins to Exhale
description: After seven months, more than two dozen witnesses and the last-minute appearance of a television celebrity, testimony concluded today in the Tawana Brawley defamation lawsuit.

title: Woman Found Fatally Stabbed In Her Apartment in Westchester
description: A woman was found fatally stabbed yesterday in her apartment in Hastings-on Hudson, a town in Westchester County, the police said.

title: Drug Policy Official Warns Panel of Effort to Legalize Drugs
description: The White House's top drug policy official today accused critics of the nation's zero-tolerance drug laws of pursuing an agenda to legalize drugs from marijuana to heroin and cocaine.

description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright called on Iran yesterday to join the United States in drawing up ''a road map leading to normal relations.'' description: SHERRY TURKLE began to study the interaction of humans with computers in the late 1970's. Her first book on the topic, ''The Second Self: Computers and the Human Spirit,'' was published in 1984.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, EDWIN J.
description: CAREY-Edwin J. Age 74 of Wyckoff died Wednesday, June 17, 1998 at New York University Hospital. Born in New York he was a resident of Wyckoff since 1960. He attended Manhattan College from 1941-1943 and received an LL.B in 1951 from St. John's University Law School. He was admitted to practice before the Supreme Court of the U.S., the U.S. District Courts for the Southern and Eastern districts of N.Y. and the N.Y. State Court of Appeals. Mr. Carey was a partner at the law firm of Hill, Rivkins and Hayden LLP before his retirement in 1988. He was a member of the Maritime Law Association of the U.S. and served as President from 1972-1974. He was also a Titular Member of the Comite Maritime International. He was an avid golfer and a member of Arcola Country Club, Paramus. A parishioner of St. Elizabeth R.C. Church, where he served as a former Lector and coach of the Boy's CYO Basketball Team. He was a WWII Army veteran. Surviving are his wife Marian (nee Burke) Carey, a daughter, Brianne Wright of Allendale, a son, Christopher of New Orleans. Also surviving are four grandchildren, Christopher, Brigid, Colleen, and Katherine. Funeral services Saturday 10:15AM from the Vander Plaat Funeral Home 257 Godwin Ave, Wyckoff, NJ. Funeral Mass 11AM St. Elizabeth's RC Church 700 Wyckoff Ave, Wyckoff, NJ. Interment Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah. Visiting Friday 2-4 and 7-9 at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home 257 Godwin Avenue, Wyckoff, NJ.

description: As one of the most sluggish legislative sessions in memory drew toward a close today, lawmakers remained deeply divided on a host of major issues, from changing parole rules to creating charter schools to expanding health care for poor children.

title: Dousing the Glow Of TV's First Family; Time for the Truth About Ozzie and Harriet
description: Ozzie and Harriet. They were America's ideal fantasy couple in the 1950's. He was a bit goofy, never seemed to have a job and was always puttering around the two-story Colonial house. She was an all-purpose Mom who happily wore aprons most of the time and never seemed to leave the kitchen. Their sons, David and Ricky, were virtuous and good-looking, two boys whose toughest problems seemed to be getting a date for the high school prom and asking Dad for the keys to the car.

title: World Dance Festival At Connecticut College

Other groups will include the Afro-Brazilian Ago Bahia Dance Company, the Khmer Performing Arts Ensemble and Les Guirivoires from the Ivory Coast.

title: California Regent's New Focus: Ethnic Studies
description: The University of California regent who led the effort to eliminate affirmative action at the state's public universities expressed serious qualms today about ethnic studies programs and suggested that he might try to curtail them.

title: Flawed Approaches to Parole Reform
description: The death of Jenna Grieshaber, allegedly at the hands of a paroled felon, and the recent killing of a New York City police officer, Anthony Mosomillo, by a man wanted for a parole violation have fueled efforts to restrict parole in New York State. So, too, has election-year politics. The State Senate, with Gov. George Pataki's backing, has passed a bill to end parole for first-time violent offenders. Not to be outdone, the Assembly last week also approved a bill to end parole. Neither bill deals with the broader problems in the state's sentencing structure, of which parole is only a part. But the Assembly's measure is somewhat less objectionable because it makes some effort to rehabilitate inmates as well as lengthen sentences.

title: Ex-Lawmaker Arraigned in Campaign Use of Medicaid Funds
description: Pedro Espada Jr., a former State Senator who built a health clinic in the Bronx into a powerful political empire, was arraigned yesterday along with two of his employees on charges that they illegally diverted $221,000 in Medicaid funds to the failed 1996 re-election campaigns of Mr. Espada and his son, Pedro Gautier Espada, then an Assemblyman.

title: 2 Associations To Join Operations

title: AHL SERVICES TO BUY MINNESOTA MARKETING COMPANY

In 1997 revenues were were about $80 million for Gage and $276 million for AHL, which is based in Atlanta.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER TO BUY MEAD DISTRIBUTION UNIT
description: The International Paper Company, the forest-products giant, agreed yesterday to acquire the Mead Corporation's Zellerbach distribution business for $263 million. Zellerbach, based in Miamisburg, Ohio, has 2,000 employees and annual sales of $1.6 billion. It operates more than 30 primary distribution centers across the country and more than 40 stores serving small printers. International Paper will fold Zellerbach into its Xpedx distribution unit, based in Covington, Ky. Both companies distribute printing, packaging and industrial supplies and equipment.

description: The Lyondell Petrochemical Company agreed yesterday to buy the ARCO Chemical Company from the Atlantic Richfield Company for $5.6 billion in cash, a deal that would triple Lyondell's size and make it a major provider of chemicals used in everyday products such as plastics, detergents and paints.

title: A Sprint to the Finish And to the Next Event
description: It has all happened so fast for Marion Jones.

title: Triumphal Songs of Loss and Loneliness
description: Sooner or later, all pleasures fade. The party ends; infatuation gives way to familiarity; age takes its toll. And Jarvis Cocker, the singer and lyricist for the English band Pulp, is obsessed with that inevitable decline.

title: Corrections
description: An erroneous roll-call tabulation appeared yesterday under a heading about the Senate vote that effectively killed the tobacco bill. The listing reflected the vote on whether to send the bill back to the Senate Commerce Committee. The vote on cloture, in which the Senate decided by 57 to 42 against cutting off debate, is printed today on page A24.

title: A Potentially Costly Victory For France
description: If you glanced quickly at the field at the end of tonight's game, there appeared to be little reason for any French person to complain.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Draeger's, a supermarket in San Mateo, Calif., incorrectly translated the name of its restaurant. Viognier is a French grape variety; it does not mean ''great variety'' in French.

description: THE best time to buy a new car is August or September, right? Perhaps not this year: The end-of-the-model-year clearance may have already begun.

title: Corrections
description: The main front-page article in Circuits on Thursday, about technical advances in personal computers, misstated the price of the Microsoft Natural Keyboard Elite. It is $64, not $46.

title: Of Faustian Wonders And a Mythic Queens
description: The affectless precision of Hal Hartley's previous work is absolutely no preparation for the brilliance and deep resonance of his ''Henry Fool.'' Here is a great American film that's no more likely than ''Nashville'' to turn up on the American Film Institute's Top 100 hit parade (where ''Rocky'' outranks ''The Searchers'') but will linger where it matters: in the hearts and minds of viewers receptive to its epic vision.

title: Top Fillies To Square Off
description: The best fillies in the East -- including last year's champion and two with five-race winning streaks -- will compete at Belmont Park tomorrow in the Hempstead Handicap, running a mile and one-sixteenth for a purse of $250,000.

description: Shirley Goldfarb

title: A Dream World of Painting, Yielding Its Secrets Slowly
description: When Pierre Bonnard died in 1947, at 79, Cahiers d'Art published an editorial by Christian Zervos, one of Picasso's mouthpieces. Picasso had called Bonnard a piddler, saying: ''Don't talk to me about Bonnard. That's not painting, what he does.'' And worse: ''He is not really a modern painter.''

We extend our heartfelt condolences to Paul, Janice, and James. Jack Hausman, Founder Leo Hausman, President UCP/NYC Inc.

title: Girl Is Sexually Assaulted In Newark Public Library
description: For the second time in little more than a month, a 16-year-old girl was raped in the main branch of Newark's public library, the police and library officials said yesterday.

title: Industrial Bank of Japan Reduces Three Stakes
description: Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd. has sold a significant portion of the shares it held in the Nomura Securities Company, the Nikko Securities Company and the Daiwa Securities Company, the bank said yesterday. Industrial Bank of Japan is no longer among the top 10 shareholders in Japan's three largest brokerage firms, Nikkei English News said. The bank, Japan's largest long-term credit bank, now holds 20 million shares in each of the three firms, the news agency said.

title: How to Balance Church and State?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Tells Iraq Secrecy May Imperil Deal on Sanctions
description: The chief United Nations arms inspector for Iraq said today that a plan for ending sanctions that he and the Iraqis agreed to last weekend would collapse if the Iraqis withheld documents or other evidence, something they threatened to do even while the talks were in progress.

title: Tobacco Bill's Death Is Likely to Prompt Litigation Landslide
description: For months, cigarette industry executives have said they would rather fight every lawsuit filed against them than support Federal legislation like the $516 billion tobacco bill introduced by Senator John McCain of Arizona. With the collapse of the McCain bill on Wednesday, they may soon get plenty of practice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALCA, ALFRED
description: PALCA-Alfred. Age 78, died Thursday, June 18, 1998. Husband of Doris. Father of Joseph and Margaret. Father-in-law of Paul Kalin and Kathy Hudson. Brother of Rosalinde Leader. Grandfather of Julie, Katie, Sam and Jacob. Friends are welcome at 175 Riverside Drive, Apartment 8H from 2-5 P.M., Sunday, June 21.

title: NEW YORK ENLISTS PRIVATE SCHOOLS
description: With less than three months left before 14,000 4-year-olds are supposed to begin new pre-kindergarten classes established by the state, New York City's overcrowded public school system is planning to enroll a third of those children in private and parochial preschools.

title: House Subcommittee Votes to Kill the Endowment for the Arts
description: In what has become an annual ritual for the Republicans in control of Congress, a House subcommittee voted today to kill the National Endowment for the Arts, but the Senate was expected to revive it.

title: At Rally, Hospital Workers Vow to Strike to Protect Jobs
description: An estimated 13,000 members of the largest union representing New York City hospital workers rallied along Broadway in midtown Manhattan yesterday afternoon, vowing to strike if 35 private hospitals do not offer them a satisfactory contract by June 30.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN'S GAIN ERODES. Japan's currency fell on a lack of further intervention by Washington and Tokyo central banks, which had sent the yen's value up 5.2 percent Wednesday. In New York, the dollar rose to 137.83 yen from 136.37.

title: A Media Specialist Is Leaving Salomon
description: Frank D. Yeary, head of the media and telecommunications investment banking group at Salomon Smith Barney, is joining Carlyle Group.

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP
description: FRIENDLY'S CLASSIC

title: SBARRO SHARES FALL AFTER FAMILY WITHDRAWS OFFER
description: The shares of Sbarro Inc. fell 8 percent yesterday after the company, the fifth-largest United States pizza-restaurant chain, said its chairman, Mario Sbarro, and his family had withdrawn an offer to buy the company for $28.50 a share, or $380 million. Sbarro fell $2.4375 a share, to $26.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Sbarro and its investment banker will consider other alternatives, the company said. The withdrawal comes five months after the founding family, including three members who are top executives at the company, said it would buy the 13.3 million shares, or 65 percent, of Sbarro that it does not already own. The company, based in Commack, N.Y., also said payment of its regular dividend would remain suspended.

title: TV Weekend; Fairy-Tale Family's Grim Chapters
description: Though it was commonly referred to as ''Ozzie and Harriet,'' the full title gives the game away. ''The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet'' posited everyday family life as a dynamic, exciting activity, and the show went a long way toward convincing 1950's middle America that was true.

title: Wild, Brutal Adolescents As Angels Among Sharks
description: French legend has it that the two spurs of rock jutting ominously from the sea in the ''bay of angels,'' near Nice, are shaped like the fins of ''angel sharks'' that once upon a time devoured the bodies of invaders shipwrecked while navigating the area's treacherous waters. In Manuel Pradal's visually gorgeous film, ''Marie Baie des Anges,'' those rocks and the pearly waters surrounding them become a potent metaphor for the savagery of teen-age sexual rites.

title: Young Giselle, Buoyant as a Child, With a Mature Albrecht
description: Ashley Tuttle and Angel Corella are gifted young technicians and intelligent performers with a lot of individual presence. Ms. Tuttle seems very worldly, however, for the innocent Giselle, and Mr. Corella too merry an innocent for the caddish Albrecht. But their performance in ''Giselle,'' presented by American Ballet Theater on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, was a triumph, as was another New York role debut by Sara Mau as Myrta on Wednesday afternoon.

title: Shooting Death of Livery Driver A Teen-Age Prank, Police Say
description: They were four teen-agers, most of them from prestigious schools, who the police say had a sudden idea to rob a car service driver for thrills. But something went wrong: a gun discharged and the driver was killed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, SELMA N.
description: FINKEL-Selma N. Beloved wife of Eugene, loving mother of Nancy and Robert, cherished grandmother of Jordan, Jeremy, Bryan, Courtney, and Shannon. Graveside services at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, New York, Sunday at 10:30 A.M.

title: The Diplomatic Shuffle
description: Richard Holbrooke is living proof that you do not have to win friends to influence people. The most undiplomatic of diplomats, he is nevertheless persuasive enough to be a good choice for the post of Washington's representative to the United Nations. The man he replaces, Bill Richardson, is his stylistic opposite, an Olympic-class schmoozer. He, in turn, knows Washington and the relevant issues well enough to make a solid Energy Secretary.

title: Mayor's Bunker Is Bunk; Fending Off Cabdrivers
description: To the Editor:

title: Acton Hired As Assistant
description: The Rangers hired Keith Acton as an assistant coach yesterday, reuniting him with Coach John Muckler and two former teammates, Wayne Gretzky and Jeff Beukeboom.

title: Linden to Lead Players Association
description: Trevor Linden, the Islanders' captain, was elected president of the National Hockey League Players Association yesterday, replacing Phoenix Coyotes right wing Mike Gartner.

title: Rescue Effort Puts a Satellite In Viable Orbit
description: An unusual effort to salvage an errant communications satellite by slinging it around the Moon has succeeded in restoring the spacecraft to a ''commercially viable'' orbit around Earth, the satellite's manufacturer said today.

title: Opel to Turn Profit As Sales Remain Level
description: Adam Opel A.G., the German unit of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that it would return to profit in 1998 as personnel costs drop and sales remain level. Opel, which reported a loss of 228 million marks ($128 million) last year because of a one-time 560-million-mark charge for a job-cutting plan, said sales in the first five months fell 8.7 percent. The company expects increased output of its new best-selling Astra introduced in March to result in full-year sales unchanged at about 30 billion marks.

title: Creative Director At Bates Worldwide
description: Bates Worldwide in New York, part of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C., has named its first worldwide creative director since Bill Backer retired in 1993.

title: Bodger Traded
description: The Devils traded the veteran defenseman Doug Bodger to Los Angeles yesterday in exchange for a fourth round pick in this month's draft.

title: San Francisco Sitcom: Coffee and Kierkegaard
description: It's not an encouraging sign when a movie whose center of gravity is a San Francisco coffeehouse called the Cafe Blue Eyes plays Frank Sinatra Jr. on the soundtrack instead of the real thing. And that's not the only element that rings false in ''Dream for an Insomniac,'' the much-too-cute feature film debut of Tiffanie DeBartolo, which opens today at the Criterion.

title: Centennial Weekend; Where to See the Fireworks
description: As darkness falls over New York City tomorrow night, fireworks will light up a 24-mile swath across the five boroughs, thanks to the New York City 100: Greater New York Centennial Celebration. The Gruccis, whose family first came to New York through Ellis Island in 1870, will use a computerized firing system to synchronize the pyrotechnics from each of the boroughs. Each borough has organized its own festivities leading up to the fireworks. Here are the five sites and what is scheduled, all in celebration of the 1898 consolidation of the five boroughs into a single city. The fireworks begin at 9:30 P.M.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japanese Pledge on Banks Raises Hopes for Overhaul

title: Selling Spy Satellites to China
description: Evidence keeps mounting that the Chinese Army is exploiting flawed American export controls to acquire sophisticated satellite communications technology for military and intelligence use. The Pentagon and State Department are now questioning the pending sale of a Hughes communications satellite whose upgraded design would let Chinese authorities eavesdrop on mobile telephone conversations at home and abroad. President Clinton should suspend this sale and the licensing of any more satellite deals with China until export control rules are tightened. In particular, he needs to put the State and Defense Departments back in charge of export approvals and diminish the role of the Commerce Department.

title: Police Agree to New Policy on Sex Charges
description: Bowing to pressure from Federal prosecutors, the New York City Police Department has agreed to overhaul its system for investigating sexual harassment complaints and sex-discrimination charges within the department.

title: An Administration Report Finds Urban Improvement, but Hardly Fat City
description: A study of American cities by the Clinton Administration says the strong national economy has left most of them in their best financial shape in decades.

title: Squeegee Man Gives Account Of Shooting by Police Officer
description: From his bed in Lincoln Hospital, the squeegee man who the police say was shot by an off-duty officer in the Bronx on Sunday said in an interview that the officer flew into a rage and shot him in the chest at point-blank range even after he offered to remove the soap he had poured onto the windshield of the officer's car.

title: Plan to Sell Puerto Rico Phone Company Leads to Strike
description: More than 6,000 telephone workers went on an island-wide strike today to try to stop the sale of a controlling stake of the government-owned Puerto Rico Telephone Company to a consortium led by the GTE Corporation.

title: Boston Columnist Is Ousted For Fabricated Articles
description: A columnist at The Boston Globe, a Pulitzer Prize finalist, fabricated people and quotations in four of her columns this year, and the newspaper has asked for her resignation, The Globe announced yesterday.

title: For a Hollywood Institution, Just Desserts
description: In times of rapid change and shifting trends and enthusiasms, the passing of institutions goes unrecorded all too often. By the time anyone can react, the wrecker's ball has swung or the doors have closed and the furnishings have been sold off here and there. Cultural anthropology and archeology are left the poorer.

description: McMAHON-Theresa. On June 17th, 1998. Beloved sister of Mary Curran, Josephine Sheridan and Eileen Frawley. Friends may call Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 St. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10 AM, St. Monica's R.C. Church, 413 East 79 Street, NYC.

description: Every Friday afternoon, dozens of late-model cars pull up to the iron gate of the three-year-old 21st-Century Experimental School, one of several new private schools here.

title: Russia Announces Intent to Ask I.M.F. for 10 to 15 Billion More
description: The Russian Government announced today that it would seek $10 billion to $15 billion in additional assistance from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Gates Part of Group Buying Hotel Company
description: A consortium of American investors, including William H. Gates of the Microsoft Corporation, said today that it had agreed to acquire the British luxury hotel company Cliveden P.L.C. for $:42.8 million, or $71.1 million.

description: In percent

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Amex-Nasdaq Merger Faces Another Critic
description: Just when it looked as if the proposed merger between the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq Stock Market had won the dissidents over, another critic has popped up. And this one is bringing the specter of antitrust into the merger.

title: Whitman Eyes Alternatives to Increasing Gas Tax
description: Faced with growing opposition from lawmakers over her plan to raise the gasoline tax to pay for preserving 1 million acres of farmland and undeveloped land over the next 10 years, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that she was considering other ways to finance the program.

title: Rebels in Kosovo Striking Back Against Yugoslav Forces
description: After taking losses in their fight with the Yugoslav military and bolstered by a huge infusion of weapons and fighters from Albania, separatist rebels in Kosovo Province have begun to hit back in recent days, Western diplomats say.

title: SOUTHERN SELLS STAKE IN BRITISH UTILITY TO PP&L
description: Southern Energy Inc. has sold an additional 26 percent interest in its British-based SWEB Holdings, the parent company of South Western Electricity, for $170 million to PP&L Global. PP&L Global, a subsidiary of PP&L Resources, based in Allentown, Pa., initially purchased a 25 percent stake in SWEB Holdings in 1996. Yesterday's transaction will increase PP&L's economic interest in SWEB Holdings to 51 percent. Southern Energy will continue to hold a majority of the voting shares in SWEB Holdings and will retain a majority of the board, and SWEB's senior management team will remain in place. SWEB, based in Bristol, England, provides electricity to more than 1.3 million customers in southwestern England.

title: Assembly Passes Prudential Bill
description: In less than a minute, the New Jersey Assembly passed legislation today that would enable the Prudential Insurance Company of America to convert from a mutual company, owned by policyholders, to a publicly traded one.

title: Observer; What! No Buster Keaton?
description: To whip up some chatter about movies, the American Film Institute polled 1,500 ''prominent'' Americans to select the 100 best American films of all time, and the results are in. So let's chatter:

title: Man in the News: William Blaine Richardson; Derring-Do at Energy
description: As a Congressman and later as the Clinton Administration's chief delegate to the United Nations, Bill Richardson displayed a flair for missions that required a sense of derring-do, like the time he persuaded officials in Pyongyang to release an American who had stolen into North Korea to convert all its citizens to Christianity.

title: Disney Joins Rush to Build Web Gateways
description: The Walt Disney Company joined the nation's biggest media and technology companies yesterday with its own effort to control where people go in cyberspace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINDECKER, ERNA
description: STEINDECKER-Erna. Beloved wife of the late Charles, devoted and adored mother of Liliane, John and Rebecca, Oliver and Elaine, respected grand mother of Anne and Karen, James, Jeremy and Michelle, Jessica and Alisha, loved great grandmother, cherished sister of Els Bendheim and Herman Salomon. A dignified and special lady-she will be greatly missed. Funeral service at the Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., in New York, Friday, 10 AM.

description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: Indonesia's new President, B. J. Habibie, has appointed as a senior military adviser a retired army general who was ordered by a United States court to pay millions of dollars in damages for his involvement in a 1991 massacre in which 270 people were estimated to have been killed.

title: Forrest H. Kirkpatrick, Consultant, 92
description: Forrest Hunter Kirkpatrick, a retired educator, corporate executive and management consultant on personnel administration and industrial relations, died on May 31 at the Ohio Valley Medical Center in Wheeling, W. Va. He was 92 and lived in Wheeling.

title: A Romp Through the Valley of Death
description: When it comes to considering their own mortality, there's no people like show people. In the movie ''All That Jazz,'' you may recall, the director and choreographer Bob Fosse turned his alter ego's expiring moments into a splashy production number set to the tune of ''Bye Bye Love.'' Now William Finn, the composer of the wonderful ''Falsetto'' musicals, translates his life-threatening experiences on the operating table into an evening of song and dance called ''A New Brain.'' Kander and Ebb got it wrong, it seems; it's death that's the cabaret.

title: She's Engaged, He Doesn't Date and He Disapproves of Her (but Guess What?)
description: When a male character in Christopher Scott Cherot's witty screwball comedy ''Hav Plenty'' asks a woman he has just met, ''What's your first impression?'' she retorts, ''I'll let you know when you impress me.'' The movie, an up-to-the-minute examination of the mating habits of well-heeled young black professionals in New York City, is packed with such snappy exchanges among competitive, upwardly mobile characters who, despite their vanity and self-absorption, are disarming in the vulnerability that occasionally leaks through the cracks of their brittle exteriors.

title: Magazines Revise Their Mastheads
description: Several magazines have made top executive changes.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINNEHAN, CLAIRE G.
description: LINNEHAN-Claire G. On June 15, 1998. Loving wife of John J. Linnehan, devoted mother of Seana Linnehan Wood and her husband Roger H. Wood of New York, NY, an attorney Courtney C. Linnehan of Boston, MA. Visiting hours at the C. Frank Linnehan & Son Funeral Home, 129 Kenoza Ave., Haverhill, MA Friday 2-4 and 79PM. Concelebrated Funeral Mass on Saturday June 20th at 11AM in St. John the Baptist Church, Haverhill, MA. Contributions to the American Cancer Society.

title: Reformers Scare the Speaker
description: House Speaker Newt Gingrich and his allies did all they could this week to bury campaign finance reform. But after two days of skirmishing, Christopher Shays of Connecticut extracted a promise from Republican leaders yesterday to vote on the Shays-Meehan bill to outlaw ''soft money'' before the end of summer. That promise strengthens the chance of reform and also challenges Republicans from the metropolitan area to get on board.

title: Tobacco Stocks Recoup After Legislation Fizzles
description: Tobacco stocks rebounded yesterday, the day after the latest version of a tobacco-settlement bill was stubbed out like, well, a cigarette.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Under the Hood: Computer Nerds?
description: AUTO MAKERS and their dealers are facing a severe shortage of automobile service technicians -- they used to be called ''mechanics'' before computer chips took over most of a car's functions. While the auto companies are recruiting newcomers, they are also looking for ways to help current workers do their jobs more efficiently and precisely.

title: Kenneth Starr Stretches the Rules
description: What are we to make of Steven Brill's article contending that Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel, and his deputy, Jackie Bennett, may have leaked grand jury information about their investigation of President Clinton?

title: First Choice Holidays To Acquire Unijet
description: First Choice Holidays P.L.C., Britain's third-largest package tour operator, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Unijet, a British travel and airline company, for $:110 million ($183.7 million) in cash and stock. Under the terms of the deal, First Choice will offer 277 First Choice shares plus $:1,453 in cash for every 100 Unijet shares.

description: Saying it wanted to end ''the scandal of poverty pay,'' the Labor Government announced plans today to establish a national minimum wage for the first time in British history.

title: Melvin Barnet, 83, Times Editor Fired After Charge of Communism
description: Melvin L. Barnet, who was among several editors and reporters questioned by a Congressional committee investigating Communist affiliations in the news business in the 1950's and who was dismissed by The New York Times after invoking the Fifth Amendment, died on Wednesday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 83 and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: 15,000 World Cup Tickets Reported Stolen
description: An American tour company said today that 15,000 World Cup tickets were stolen from its Paris office this morning, the latest twist in the uproar over the sale of tickets for the monthlong tournament.

title: Train Slams Into Truck in Indiana, Killing 3
description: Three people were killed and five injured this morning when a Chicago-bound commuter train struck a tractor-trailer that was stuck at a crossing.

title: L. Edwin Smart, 74, a Former T.W.A. Chairman
description: L. Edwin Smart, a former chairman and chief executive of Trans World Airlines, died June 1 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York. He was 74 and lived in New York.

description: EASTBOURNE

title: SHAREHOLDER GROUP OFFERS BUYOUT TO STOP NICHOLS SALE
description: A dissident shareholder group that controls about 14 percent of the J. C. Nichols Company has offered to buy the rest of the company for $70 a share in cash, according to a regulatory filing. The group, led by Stephen Feinberg, opposes Nichols's plan to be acquired by Highwoods Properties Inc. It made the buyout offer in a letter dated Wednesday to the Nichols board. The letter was included in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. J. C. Nichols shares rose $1 to close at $65, giving the company a current market capitalization of $300 million. In business since 1905, Nichols is based in Kansas City, Mo., and owns office buildings, apartment buildings, and retail and industrial properties in the Kansas City area. In December, Highwoods, based in Raleigh, N.C., had agreed to buy Nichols's shares for $65 each.

title: A Vivaldi Rarity Whose Music Overcomes Its Musty Plot
description: Music has had little trouble keeping Vivaldi's instrumental works alive. ''The Seasons,'' deserving better, has become the stuff of elevators. The other concertos, and they number in the hundreds, ring with energy and dramatic turns of phrase, though admittedly it is sometimes easy to mistake one for another. The cogniscenti of this particular generation tend to mock Vivaldi, but he will survive them as he has their predecessors.

title: Home Video; Full Grab Bag Of Varied Titles
description: When a biological weapon called Trixie gets loose in little Evans City, the Army sends a large contingent to seal off the town and prevent anyone from leaving. Trixie either kills people or turns them into homicidal maniacs, which makes for a busy time for soldiers in gas masks and for citizens, whose terror and outrage aren't eased by the fact that the Army decides not to tell them what is going on.

title: From White Plaster Figures to Wider Themes
description: The mournful tableaux of white plaster figures fitted into diners, subway cars or telephone booths produced by George Segal in the 1960's earned him a permanent niche in the history of Pop Art. But he was not content to confine his vision to that genre, and in later years he tackled other worlds and bigger themes.

description: New York City is celebrating the 100th anniversary of its consolidation with a weekend of activities, from fireworks to walking tours, and free music from the classics to classic rock. A pullout guide.

description: The Liberty got everything it wanted last night in Sacramento against the Monarchs: defense, confidence, redemption and, ultimately, its first victory of the W.N.B.A. season.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MULLIN, THOMAS J.
description: MULLIN-Thomas J. Today, June 19, 1998 is the 730th day that I've had to endure the unfortunate fact that you are no longer a part of this journey called life. However, you are and will always be a part of me and the legacy that I'm trying hard to create for myself. I continue to mourn for you and the happy ending that you wanted for us. For you were the laughter in my heart and the substance of my soul, how very lucky was I to have shared your life, happiness and love. Hopefully one day soon the pain of losing you, and all that you shared and gave to me will subside. Until that time, I will continue to kiss you tenderly in my dreams, hold you in my arms and love your forever.... Your Loving Fiance, Naomi

title: 'Katya,' 'Faust' and 'Don Pasquale' in St. Louis
description: The Opera Theater of St. Louis has grown remarkably since Richard Gaddes founded it in 1976 as a Midwestern oasis of contemporary works, operatic rarities and standard repertory, performed in English by young singers at the beginning of their careers. The festival's budget was $139,000 that first season; in recent years, it has hovered around $5 million. Today, the directorial reins are held by a triumvirate -- Charles MacKay, general director; Colin Graham, artistic director, and Stephen Lord, music director -- but the original vision has remained largely intact.

title: Accepting Challenges To Make a Difference

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, LUKE JOSEPH
description: TAYLOR-Luke Joseph, June 17, 1998. This unique and sensitive spirit was taken suddenly from a bewilderingly large and loyal circle of family and friends. Given a second chance at life Luke showed by his tenacity, humor and comforting presence what it means to be human. His appetite for knowledge, his ability to see through sham and cant, his carefully crafted prose and generous instincts will always inspire all those he loved and touched. We love you, Luke. Your father and mother J. Gary Taylor and Mary Ann Quinson, step parents Pat Taylor and Bruno Quinson. Your brothers Geoffrey, Adam and Joshua. Step brothers and sisters Tim, Chris, Peggy, Wendy and Janet and their families. Nephews and nieces James Giles, John Christian and Alexandra. Uncles and aunts Peter Taylor, Hadley Fisk, Vivien Malloy, Ed Goodman, Pam Lichty and their families. Luke was the grandson of the late Nena Manach, and Andrew Goodman, and Margaret Clark. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Thomas More Church, 65 East 89 Street, Saturday, June 20, 11AM. Interment New Marborough, Mass. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Public Library.

title: PURCHASE OF SEQUENTIA TO EXPAND CRANE PLASTIC UNIT
description: The Crane Company, the largest United States distributor of doors, windows and millwork, said it had agreed to acquire the closely held Sequentia Inc. for $125 million to expand its reinforced plastic-panel products unit. Sequentia makes fiberglass-reinforced plastic panels for use with construction and building products. The company, based in Strongsville, Ohio, has plants in Grand Junction, Tenn., and in Houston and is expected to have 1998 sales of $85 million, Crane said. Crane, which is based in Stamford, Conn., said it would integrate Sequentia into its Kemlite unit, which sells reinforced plastic-panel products to the transportation and recreational vehicle markets.

description: One of the JVC Jazz Festival's regular miracles has been completely underwhelming programming that transcends itself and produces exceptional concerts.

title: Corrections

title: Every Currency Crumbles
description: Currencies, being made of paper, are highly flammable, and governments are forever trying to put out the fires. Thus a half decade before the bonfire of the baht, the rupiah and the yen, there was the conflagration of the markka, the lira and the pound. The dollar, today's global standard of value, was smoldering ominously as recently as 1992.

description: Fast Cheap and Out of Control

title: Officer Accused in 1994 Death Was Labeled Violent in 1991

title: Pedestrian Barricades Outlast the Critics
description: IN 1972, Claus Reinisch had an idea for improving the traffic flow in mid-Manhattan: confine pedestrians to one side of the street when crossing major avenues. For example, they would have to stick to the north side to get across southbound Fifth Avenue. That way, he said, cars would have an easier time turning into the avenue from side streets, and the backup of crosstown traffic would be reduced.

description: Ynez Johnston

title: A Warrior, She Takes on Huns and Stereotypes
description: Disney takes a sledgehammer to the subject of gender stereotyping in ''Mulan,'' a film that not only breaks the cross-dressing barrier but also ratchets up the violence level for children's animation. ''Sign me up for the next war!'' exclaims the heroine's grandmother, in a show of what does not precisely qualify as progress for women. And for all its supposed daring in presenting a bold female warrior, ''Mulan'' takes no steps forward when it comes to Disney's animation renaissance. This is the most inert and formulaic of recent Disney animated films, right down to the clowning sidekicks and would-be ''Under the Sea'' production number. This time there's a big musical sequence about basic training.

title: Dauntless Heroines and Pouting Princes in a Garden of Delights
description: India has produced countless styles of manuscript painting. Among the most poetic, and certainly the most popular outside of India itself, are those that emerged in the 17th century in the Hindu Rajput kingdoms nestled in the remote mountain valleys of the Himalayan foothills.

title: New York Girding for Grim Fear: Deadly Germ Attack by Terrorists
description: New York City, long viewed as one of the world's most attractive targets for terrorists, has quietly undertaken an ambitious effort to counter attacks carried out with deadly chemicals or germs, according to city officials.

title: From Mental Illness to Yale to Murder Charge
description: For more than a decade, Michael B. Laudor had wrestled with the demons of schizophrenia, managing to eke out startling victories over the delusions and hallucinations, like a degree from Yale Law School and more than $2.1 million in book and movie contracts for his life story.

title: Need Good Wood? A Batmaker Tries Maple
description: Joe Carter was standing behind the plate at Camden Yards in Baltimore last month, sermonizing about his bat. Carter, nearly reverential, told how it was more durable, how it allowed him to whip through the strike zone faster and how other major leaguers will ultimately want one.

title: House to Consider 258 Campaign Amendments
description: With Democrats maintaining that the Republican leadership was once again trying to delay any final vote on campaign finance, the House voted today to open the debate to a blizzard of amendments.

title: Administration Details Defense Of Controls on Satellite Exports
description: The Clinton Administration mounted the most detailed defense of its satellite export control policy today. Three top officials said that China's military had not benefited from transfers of sensitive American technology and that safeguards were in place to prevent any such leakage.

title: Death of a Spiritualist Is Ruled a Suicide
description: The death two months ago of Frederick P. Lenz, a New Age spiritual guru turned author and computer programmer, was a suicide by drowning, the Suffolk County Medical Examiner ruled yesterday.

description: SEID-Charles K., Jr. (Bud), husband of Barbara (nee Klepper). Father of Bradford and Charles III. Brother of Florence Harff. Kind and caring, a true gentleman, graced with rare integrity, quiet dignity, and a wonderful dry, quick wit. We will love him forever. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 11 A.M., on Friday.

title: John J. Cardinal Carberry, 93; Led Archdiocese of St. Louis
description: John Joseph Cardinal Carberry, who was a canon lawyer active in the Roman Catholic Church's affairs and who led the Archdiocese of St. Louis for 11 years, died on Wednesday at St. Agnes Home in Kirkwood, Mo. He was 93.

title: More Welfare Recipients Going to Work, Study Finds
description: Millions of people have left the welfare rolls since Congress overhauled the Federal program two years ago, but what happened to them has been a puzzle for policy makers. Now, the most comprehensive study of the new system says more and more are going to work.

title: A Recorder of History Manufactured It, Too
description: Mathew Brady was the most famous American photographer of his day and is still one of the best known of ours, and yet in a peculiar way he is not well known. The outline of his life is clear enough, but so few personal documents survive that he might as well have carried on his correspondence by E-mail. His very birth date was uncertain, perhaps even to himself. At an advanced age he reluctantly told an interviewer he was born ''near 1823 or '24.'' Death being one of the few certainties in the lives of the famous, we know he died in 1896.

description: The Islanders last night traded goaltender Eric Fichaud to Edmonton for left wing Mike Watt. The Islanders did not want to lose Fichaud in next Friday's expansion draft.

description: WATTS INDUSTRIES, North Andover, Mass., a maker of valves used in plumbing and heating, agreed to buy Hoke Inc., Cresskill, N.J., a company that also makes valves. The terms were not disclosed.

There were to be no more secret meetings between the Capitol's power brokers to decide the outcome of major legislation. Public business was now to be done in public. And rank-and-file members of the Legislature suddenly mattered.

description: Amid a surging demand to produce films in New York City, the Giuliani administration has promised a pair of young entrepreneurs a lease to build a major Hollywood-style movie studio in the Brooklyn Navy Yard -- provided they can obtain $190 million in financing by December.

title: Painting a Dark Time in the Colors of Hope
description: THERE is a watercolor, painted with her happy blues and reds and a touch of leaf green (in her work, one often finds leaf green), that the artist Nelly S. Toll made as an 8-year-old child in wartime Poland. It depicts a little girl with a red ribbon in her hair brushing her big, docile shepherd dog in a large wash basin, while her mother prepares food in their enormous kitchen.

description: The South Korean Government officially decreed 55 troubled companies nonviable today, signaling their likely demise in hopes of accelerating the revamping of the economy and ailing financial system.
