title: A Ballet Whose Finale Is a Rousing Shipwreck
description: The world will come crashing down in a huge shipwreck at approximately 10:30 tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House, where American Ballet Theater is performing. It is not that Ballet Theater has bowed to popular taste and created a dance version of ''Titanic.'' Instead, it has resurrected ''Le Corsaire,'' a seldom-seen, three-act Russian ballet that ends with the spectacular sinking of a ship. The company will perform the ballet tonight for the first time, and then tomorrow afternoon and evening.

title: Recalled Heart Drug Poses Risk Even After Patients Stop Using It
description: Ten days after the Food and Drug Administration took the heart medication Posicor off the market, a new warning has been issued about the drug. A team of doctors in Oregon has reported that four patients who stopped taking Posicor went into shock after switching to other drugs, and that one died as a result.

description: Finding that young surgeons at New York University Medical Center were working far more hours than the law allows -- in some cases up to 130 hours a week -- state health officials fined the hospital $16,000 yesterday.

title: In the Dark, 'X' Resembles A Conspiracy
description: Conspiracy theorists, consider this: What if the hush-hush atmosphere and Internet mania surrounding the first ''X-Files'' feature film were part of a giant plot to hide the uneventfulness of one more summertime sci-fi fizzle? It's as possible as much of what ''The X-Files'' has to offer. If devotees of the television series come to the film with enough baggage for a six-week safari, perhaps they can deepen the experience of watching a middling, unfocused action-adventure with brand-name appeal. But there's a catch: this film isn't tailor-made for true X-fanatics, because the material has been so broadened to accommodate the uninitiated. Trust no one who dreams up an action sequence in Antarctica for the big screen.

title: Chiding G.O.P., D'Amato Pushes for Vote on Gay Nominee for Envoy
description: In an unusually sharp rebuke of his party leader, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato today urged the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, to allow a vote on the nomination of James C. Hormel as ambassador to Luxembourg.

description: In a few weeks Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto will face nationwide elections as he presides over the worst recession in more than 50 years, a limp stock market and the highest unemployment rate since records began to be kept.

description: Stocks retreated slightly yesterday from Wednesday's powerful rally, as optimism over a possible turnaround in Asia waned.

title: SUMMIT TO ACQUIRE NSS BANCORP OF CONNECTICUT
description: Summit Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire NSS Bancorp Inc., a Connecticut savings bank, for $139.6 million in stock. Summit will issue 1.232 shares for each share of NSS, valuing each at $58.83. NSS, based in Norwalk, Conn., operates eight branches in southern Connecticut and has assets of $669 million. Summit, based in Princeton, N.J., is a bank holding company with $30.6 billion in assets and more than 430 offices in New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania. Shares of NSS jumped $9.375 yesterday, or 20 percent, to $55.25, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Summit were down $1, to $46.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Centennial Weekend

Centennial Weekend, the apex of the yearlong New York City 100: Greater New York Centennial Celebration, will salute the city on land (with parades, street fairs, walking tours and exhibitions), at sea (a harbor festival on the Hudson River with everything from ferryboats to kayaks) and in the air (simultaneous fireworks in the five boroughs on Saturday night, bursting over 24 miles of sky).

description: The music of Brazil is a tuneful affirmation of the beauties of cultural interchange. Ever since foreigners started showing up in South America, Brazilians have borrowed and transformed the music that showed up with them. This weekend, and in the days that follow, New Yorkers have a chance to hear the results of four decades of Brazilian musical alchemy, with two festivals creating the most concentrated Brazilian invasion in at least a decade.

title: Peggy Guggenheim, Celebrity. Oh Yes, Collector.

title: Centennial Weekend; A Centennial Serenade to New York
description: New York's music is the world's music, the sound of every group to arrive since the Dutch were met by the Indians. To commemorate the centennial of the annexation of Brooklyn and the consolidation of the five boroughs into one city, the musical celebration this weekend will be as varied, scattered and unpredictable as the city itself. From brass bands to Central American punta music to jazz, oldies and alternative rock, the centennial program offers glimpses of New York's many musical worlds. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, MURRAY
description: GRANT-Murray. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, its Men's Club and Couples Club mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member Zachary Grant, and extend heartfelt condolences to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Daly Shows Maturity By Not Using His Driver
description: Before John Daly teed off today, he made an important decision. He left his driver in his bag.

title: Picture Perfect, Stewart in Front
description: On a day when it was difficult to birdie any holes, Payne Stewart did some special things today in the first round of the United States Open. He birdied the final three holes. He made just one bogey on the picturesque but lethal Lake course at the Olympic Club, a place that left many competitors complaining, cursing, and putting some strange numbers on their scorecards.

title: Texas Instruments to Eliminate 3,500 Jobs
description: The cutbacks coursing through the chip industry reached Texas Instruments Inc. today as the company announced plans to eliminate 3,500 jobs, or 8 percent of its work force. The company cited both the recent sale of several divisions and a weak, glutted market for chips, especially in Asia.

title: United Grounds Its 777's
description: United Airlines grounded all 33 of its Boeing 777 airplanes today because it could not load new software into the planes' navigation computers, the airline said.

title: 2 Brokerage Firms Post Strong Quarterly Profits
description: A surge in companies issuing stock for the first time and a raging pace of corporate takeovers powered robust second-quarter earnings at two leading brokerage firms.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about digital watches misstated the name of the company that manufactures Beepwear and misidentified one of the partners in the company. The company is Beepwear Paging Products; MTX is its former name. Along with Motorola, the partner is Timex, not Swatch.

title: INSIDE
description: Falsehoods at Boston Globe

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the retirement of James O. Freedman as president of Dartmouth College referred incorrectly to the James Joyce book he received as a gift. It is ''Finnegans Wake''; Joyce omitted the apostrophe for the sake of a wordplay, ''Wake'' serving as both noun and verb.

title: GIAT of France to Cut 3,000 to 4,000 Jobs
description: GIAT Industries, the French loss-ridden state-owned arms maker, will eliminate 3,000 to 4,000 jobs, or as much as 38 percent of its work force, the French Defense Minister, Alain Richard, said yesterday. Mr. Richard said the job cuts would be part of a reorganization plan to be announced at the beginning of July that will include the closing of several GIAT manufacturing sites.

title: Sports of The Times; It Is Time to Wave a Yellow Card at England
description: THERE are three good reasons for despising the thugs, the mostly English thugs, who ran wild in Marseilles the other day -- and who are lying in wait to do it again.

title: An Ethereal Siren in the Eyes of Her Fans
description: The audience squealed with pleasure every time Stevie Nicks twirled in the spotlight at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night. Wearing long Renaissance-princess dresses of velvet and sequins, stroking the ribbons that dangled from her microphone and changing shawls with nearly every song -- gold for ''Gold Dust Woman,'' white for the ''white-winged dove'' of ''Nightbird'' -- Ms. Nicks was still, for her fans, the otherworldly siren who sang ''Rhiannon'' with Fleetwood Mac in the 1970's. A less worshipful listener heard something else: a singer with an out-of-tune croak enthusiastically working her way through two decades' of dewy-eyed narcissism.

title: El Duque a Gamer? Yanks Know It
description: Failing to see anything else that they could exploit in Orlando Hernandez, the Indians noticed the Yankees pitcher wriggling his fingers in his glove with runners on base tonight. Mike Hargrove, the Cleveland manager, twice argued vehemently that this was a balk, accomplishing nothing other than to convince the veteran David Cone that they were just trying to unnerve the defector from Cuba.

title: McCall Forms Investor Coalition To Press Fight Over Lilco Payouts
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall has organized a coalition of major stockholders in the Marketspan Corporation seeking to remove its chairman, Dr. William J. Catacosinos, because of the growing controversy over his compensation.

title: Emily Whaley, Charleston Gardener and Writer, Dies at 87
description: Emily Whaley, a South Carolina woman with a green thumb and such an eye for color that she helped show flowering Charleston there was bloom beyond azaleas and camellias and turned her backyard into one of the nation's most acclaimed private gardens, died on Monday at her summer home in Flat Rock, N.C. She was 87 and had become something of celebrity since the publication of a memoir, ''Mrs. Whaley and her Charleston Garden,'' last year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, HENRY
description: FELDMAN-Henry. June 19, 1998. Happy Birthday, dearest. We love you and miss you more each year. Your wife Helen and son Leonard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEYTON, ALLEGRA MARGARET
description: PEYTON-Allegra Margaret. Age 27. Beloved daughter of Maggi Peyton and the late J. Randolph Peyton, Sr. Cherished sister of J. Randolph Peyton, Jr., and Sean Peyton and dear sister-in-law of Cheryl Peyton and aunt of Albert Cassidy Peyton. Visitation Sunday June 21, 2-4PM and 7-9PM, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 81 St. & Madison Avenue. Funeral Mass, Monday, June 22, 9:30 A.M., St. Francis de Sales, 135 East 96 St. (bet Park and Lexington Aves). In lieu of flowers the family requests contributions be made to the Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 East 91st Street, New York, NY 10128.

title: Cemetery Is to Replace Money From Trust Funds
description: Woodlawn Cemetery, the resting place of Herman Melville, Fiorello H. La Guardia, Miles Davis and Harry Helmsley, has agreed to repay $6.9 million that its managers borrowed from special trust funds dedicated to the perpetual upkeep of gravesites and mausoleums, the State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, said yesterday.

title: How to Balance Church and State?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHORR, DAVID
description: SHORR-David. You are always in our minds. Wish you were here. Bailey is your new granddaughter. Love, Barbara

title: A Novelty for China: Owning a Home
description: The Government has formally spelled out its radical new housing policy, under which the hallowed right of workers to virtually cost-free apartments will end this year.

title: Shanghai Halts Shipment of Opera Sets for Lincoln Center Festival
description: Chinese authorities in Shanghai yesterday detained the shipment of sets and equipment for a classic Chinese opera that is scheduled to be the centerpiece of next month's Lincoln Center Festival, threatening to disrupt the festival and start an international incident.

title: The Next Big Wave
description: He wears his hair to his shoulders. He proposed to his wife in the Pacific Ocean surf, holding her with one hand and his surfboard with the other. Even into last year, Frankie Hejduk struggled to determine whether his profession would be surfing or soccer.

title: Europe Is Said To Approve MCI's Merger
description: After more than a month of negotiations, European antitrust regulators today tentatively approved Worldcom Inc.'s $37 billion takeover of the MCI Communications Corporation after the two companies agreed to concessions in the sale of MCI's Internet holdings, industry executives involved in the negotiations said.

title: 'Dark' Is Closing
description: ''Wait Until Dark,'' a revival of Frederick Knott's 1966 drama starring Marisa Tomei and Quentin Tarantino, is to close after the matinee on Sunday, June 28, at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, Manhattan. The play, directed by Leonard Foglia, will have run for 97 regular performances and 12 previews.

title: SCHIZOPHRENIA DRUG FAILS TO GET F.D.A. APPROVAL
description: Pfizer Inc., maker of the impotence treatment pill Viagra, said yesterday that its schizophrenia drug Zeldox had failed to get marketing approval from the Food and Drug Administration. Pfizer, one of the world's largest drug makers, with $9.2 billion in 1997 drug sales, said it would meet with F.D.A. officials to discuss the decision. The initial decision on the drug comes as a blow to Pfizer, as Zeldox was expected to be a powerful entry in the multibillion-dollar market for psychotherapies. Shares of the New York-based Pfizer fell $2.875 each, to $111.50. Schizophrenia affects between two million and three million Americans, normally striking people between the ages of 15 and 30.

title: Text of Resolution On Removal of Guns
description: Following is a resolution that was passed on Thursday by the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), calling on the denomination's 2.6 million members to try to remove guns from their homes and communities. The resolution was approved by a vote of 393 to 120 at the church's annual General Assembly in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Negotiators in Congress Narrow Differences on I.R.S. Overhaul
description: Congress moved closer today to final passage of legislation that would overhaul the Internal Revenue Service, as House and Senate negotiators resolved many of the differences in the details of their bills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICKARD, NORA C
description: PICKARD-Nora C. On June 18, 1998, of Little Neck, N.Y. Wife of Thomas J. Pickard. Mother of Thomas J. Jr., Brian J., Maureen A., and Shelia M. Pickard and MaryEllen Scala. Sister of James and John Heaney, Rita Whalen & the late Eileen Rooney. Also survived by 6 grandchildren. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Blvd, Little Neck, NY on Sat. & Sun., 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered in St. Anastasia R.C. Church, Mon. at 10:45 AM. Interment in Oneonta, N.Y.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If a strict vegetarian diet is part of someone's long-term culture, the kids grow fine, though not as big. But for those who became vegans recently, I can't say it's dangerous, but there are risks.''

title: Judge Faults Taxi Board On Meeting
description: A State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan said yesterday that the Taxi and Limousine Commission apparently violated the state's open meetings law when it met in private May 28 shortly before approving most of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's strict package of taxi safety rules, according to lawyers for both the city and an industry group suing to overturn the rules.

title: Perfect Start Turns Sour for Reed
description: Eleven days ago, when the Mets' Rick Reed took the pitcher's mound at Shea Stadium in the seventh inning, he glanced at the immense scoreboard beyond the right-center-field wall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, DORIS
description: FRIEDMAN-Doris. Beloved wife of Henry. Devoted mother of Carol Ann Siegel, Peter Friedman, Mark Friedman. Dear sister of Beula Dember, Rhoda Dember, Felice Young. Adored grandmother of Ben, Jocelyn, Daniel & Sadie. Received a B.A. at Queens College with honors. Services Sunday, 12:30 at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard & 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Mr. Heston, the Police Are Not the Enemy
description: Charlton Heston, the new president of the National Rifle Association, may get his wish. Edward Rendell, Mayor of Philadelphia, and Mr. Heston agreed this week to work together to seek Federal money for a crackdown on gun violence. If successful, the N.R.A. will test its so-called crime-fighting plans in Philadelphia.

title: Greek and Turkish Jets Lead New Round of Cyprus Tension
description: Greece and Turkey are at odds again over the divided island of Cyprus, with Greek planes landing on the island and Turkish planes screeching overhead in retaliation.

title: Gunmen Kill 25 Hindus in Kashmir Attacks
description: In one of the worst attacks on Hindu civilians in nine years of war in Kashmir, 25 men taking part in wedding parties were killed today by gunmen armed with automatic weapons.

title: XTRA TO BE ACQUIRED FOR $976 MILLION IN CASH
description: The Xtra Corporation agreed yesterday to be acquired for $65 a share in cash, or a total of $976 million. The buyers will also assume debt that raises their total obligations to $1.9 billion. Xtra, a transportation-equipment leasing company, being acquired by Apollo Management IV L.P., a New York-based buyout group, and Interpool Inc., a Princeton, N.J., equipment leasing company. Apollo and Interpool, through its investment affiliate Atlas Capital Partners L.L.C., will own about 90 percent of Xtra, and existing shareholders will retain a 10 percent stake. After the deal, Xtra will no longer be publicly traded. The shares of Xtra, which is based in Boston, soared 32 percent, gaining $14.9375 each, to $61, on the Big Board

title: The Underachieving Legislature
description: New York's State Legislature has done an excellent job of reducing expectations. When the lawmakers closed up shop and went home yesterday, relief that they had done so few things that were terrible overcame some of the disappointment over their failure to do much that was good.

title: Aching Godina Still Expects Oomph in His Throw
description: Just think how far John Godina would propel the shot and the discus if he were healthy.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY
description: BIG TOBACCO WON'T QUIT

title: Sports of The Times; Cavalcade Of Coaches Ends at L.I.U.
description: LONG ISLAND UNIVERSITY became the final New York City program to name a head basketball coach yesterday. In the elegant Great Hall of the former Paramount theater on the school's Brooklyn campus, L.I.U. introduced Ray Martin as the successor to Ray Haskins.

title: International Briefs; S.& P. Gives Junk Rating To Mitsubishi's Debt
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation's long-term debt was downgraded to ''junk,'' or noninvestment, grade by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. S.& P. lowered the debt rating three notches to ''BBpi'' from ''BBBpi.'' A BB rating indicates Mitsubishi ''faces major ongoing uncertainties which could lead to inadequate capacity to meet its financial commitments.''

title: The Lack of Truth Brings a Bounty of Consequences
description: In December, Patricia Smith was on top of this town, her center-parted braids and half-smile dominating the cover of Boston magazine's issue on the city's most intriguing women.

title: U.S. Rests Case in 1994 Choke-Hold Death
description: The Government rested its case yesterday in the trial of Francis X. Livoti, the former New York City police officer accused in the 1994 choking death of Anthony Baez.

title: Wild Outing by Cone Spoils Jeter's Return
description: Playing shortstop for the Yankees is the dream that has driven Derek Jeter since the fourth grade, a goal he realized when he turned 21. And yet, playing shortstop for the Yankees felt foreign to him tonight, when he returned to the lineup after missing 15 days with an injury.

title: Therapists' Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: MISSILES AND SPACE UNIT TO CUT OVER 2,000 JOBS
description: Lockheed Martin Missiles and Space said yesterday that it would cut 2,000 to 2,500 jobs by the end of the year, primarily at its San Francisco Bay Area operation. The company, which manufactures space and military systems, said it expected 1,000 to 1,500 of the cuts to be involuntary layoffs and the rest to come through attrition and offers of early retirement. Lockheed Martin Missiles, a unit of the Lockheed Martin Corporation, the military and aerospace giant, , blamed a recent loss of business contracts and a delay in major orders for the layoffs. The parent company, Lockheed Martin, based in Bethesda, Md., had 1997 sales of $28.06 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, ANNA
description: GREENWALD - Anna. Beloved wife of Sandor, devoted mother of Myrna and Edward Weisselberg, & Rochelle Greenwald, cherished grandmother of Deborah, Joanne, Michael, Dianne & Joseph. Loving great-grandmother & dear sister. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 312 Coney Island Avenue (at Prospect Park), Brooklyn, on Sunday at 12 noon.

title: Saying Parole Was Promised, Amy Fisher Seeks a Trial
description: When Amy Fisher agreed to plead guilty to the 1992 shooting of Mary Jo Buttafuoco, she said, she believed she had a promise from the Nassau County District Attorney to help her win early parole and entry into a work-release program. Now she says the District Attorney, Denis E. Dillon, has broken that promise and she wants to vacate her guilty plea and proceed to a trial, even though she has spent more than five and a half years in prison.

title: Repairman Is Injured In Fall From Ride
description: A 29-year-old repairman working atop a new ride at Coney Island fell to the ground and his right foot was nearly severed after his safety harness failed late yesterday, city officials said.

title: Rhythmical Wins Welcome Stake
description: With Nona Garson of Lebanon, N.J., aboard, Rhythmical jumped all 16 fences on the course in 81.13 seconds yesterday to win the $25,000 Welcome Stake at the United States Equestrian Team Festival of Champions in Gladstone, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AVERILL, BRETT
description: AVERILL-Brett July 23, 1957-June 20, 1995. My darling Brett, for now and forever, I'll always love you. Bill

title: Mexican Charges Filed Over I.B.M. Contract
description: The authorities here have charged 3 executives of IBM de Mexico and 22 current and former Mexico City officials with conspiracy in connection with the acquisition without competitive bidding of a $28 million computer system that the city says has never worked.

title: The Overweight Majority
description: In a world that supposedly increasingly celebrates diversity, there is one constant and obvious personal trait that marks complete social unacceptability: obesity. Unlike any other physical attribute that differs from the ideal norm, being overweight is an immediate flashing light that connotes reduced desirability. You never know right away if the person you're dating is a potential Son of Sam or Lizzie Borden. But if you spot flabby arms, that's a dead giveaway for lack of self-esteem and fear of intimacy.

title: Presbyterians Urged to Get Rid of Guns
description: In a strikingly strong statement on individual responsibility and guns, the top policy-making body of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) has passed a resolution calling on the denomination's 2.6 million members to begin removing handguns and assault weapons from their homes.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a film review in Weekend yesterday about ''The X Files'' misstated the surname of the starring actress at one point. She is Gillian Anderson, as noted earlier in the review, not Armstrong.

title: Which Bush Leads Polls?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALCA, ALFRED
description: PALCA-Alfred. Age 78, died Thursday, June 18, 1998. Husband of Doris. Father of Joseph and Margaret. Father-in-law of Paul Kalin and Kathy Hudson. Brother of Rosalinde Leader. Grandfather of Julie, Katie, Sam and Jacob. Friends are welcome at 175 Riverside Drive, Apartment 8H from 2-5 P.M., Sunday, June 21.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, LILLIAN
description: HOFFMAN-Lillian on June 18, 1998. Wife of the late Irving, devoted mother to Lori, Rick, and Janice, grandmother of Alana and Kylie, sister of Seymour Schlaefer, and devoted friend to many. After a full and productive life, her counsel, compassion and love will be sorely missed. Services Sunday at 3PM at Lewis Suburban Chapel, Dover, NJ.

title: Lopez Is Ready For N.B.A. Draft
description: To prepare for next Wednesday's National Basketball Association draft, Felipe Lopez hired a shooting instructor and put himself through vigorous workouts. But perhaps the finest tutelage that Lopez, the former St. John's guard, received came from the workouts he was put through by 10 N.B.A. teams. In them, he learned as much about the professional game as the teams learned about him.

title: Girls' Team Runs Fifth Fastest Time
description: Collinwood of Cleveland registered the fifth fastest time ever in the United States in winning the girls' sprint medley relay in 3 minutes 57.01 seconds tonight at the Foot Locker national scholastic track and field championships at the North Carolina State University Field in Raleigh.

title: Finding the Mystery in the Mundane
description: The title character in ''Lillian'' fits no one's ideas of a woman of mystery. Her English accent is unmistakably middle-class; her gestures are small and rather prim; her lips are often pursed into the expression of someone savoring the vestiges of that morning's mouthwash. There is certainly no air of concealment in the way she talks about her life. And though you don't know what she's wearing, you can be sure it's not a Garbo-style cloche and sunglasses.

title: Democrat Cites Early Suspicion Over Donations
description: Not long after Johnny Chung and his checkbook were welcomed into Democratic fund-raising circles, some senior party officials worried that he posed a potential problem.

title: Patrol Chief to Head Transportation Agency
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani named Wilbur L. Chapman, the Chief of Patrol for the New York Police Department, as Transportation Commissioner yesterday. The job has been vacant since Christopher R. Lynn resigned in December.

title: U.S. Permits Deaf Mexicans, Forced to Peddle, to Remain
description: The 49 deaf Mexican men and women whose ordeal as virtual slaves in a quiet Queens neighborhood shocked New York and attracted national attention last year will be allowed to stay in the United States, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Carlos Castaneda, Mystical and Mysterious Writer, Dies
description: Carlos Castaneda, whose best-selling explorations of mystical and pharmacological frontiers helped to define the psychological landscape of the 1960's, died two months ago just as privately and secretly as he had lived, associates revealed this week. Befitting a man who made an esthetic out of mystery, even his age is uncertain, but he was believed to be 72.

title: What to Read? Ask a Computer; New Strategy for Selling Books Makes Many Experts Uneasy
description: Clerking at a New Haven book shop one afternoon 15 years ago, a novelist named Kitty Florey watched two regular customers approach the display racks, their faces furrowed with consternation. ''I get tired of these after a while,'' one said, indicating a stack of best sellers, ''but I don't know what else to read.'' Ms. Florey bounded across the Oriental rugs to propose a few titles by Anne Tyler and Barbara Kingsolver. Her manager, just a pace behind, suggested Ms. Florey's own latest book.

title: Religion Journal; Art That Speaks of Reconciliation
description: The last time Pope John Paul II visited the New York area, in October 1995, he stayed less than a week and drew 125,000 people to an open-air Mass in Central Park.

title: Russia Isn't Likely to Receive More Funds Now, I.M.F. Says
description: The International Monetary Fund warned Russia today that it does not plan to provide the $10 billion to $15 billion in additional assistance that the Kremlin is seeking.

title: Retro-Frivolity, Even a Dance Tune
description: In their 1980's heyday, the B-52's and the Pretenders were both considered new wave rock, which shows how vague a category can be. The two bands, which began a summer tour together on Thursday night at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., shared an era but not a sensibility. The B-52's turned a few campy jokes into a fountainhead of giddy party songs; the Pretenders chronicle Chrissie Hynde's shifting attitudes, from tough-talking rocker to affectionate wife and mother.

title: Zero Is the Verdict in $2 Billion Koch Family Feud
description: One of the longest and nastiest family disputes ended today, sort of, as a working-class jury blocked efforts by William Koch, one of the nation's richest men, to get $2 billion from two of his brothers who were accused by Mr. Koch of cheating in a business deal more than a decade ago.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Father Knows Best, With Help: Kiss the Baby and Wife
description: Advice to mothers is as plentiful as air. There are hundreds of books and thousands of old wives' tales. On top of that is the daily unsolicited advice that mothers get from friends, relatives, even strangers on the street.

title: Miami Wrestling With Corruption of Officials
description: Bribery. Kickbacks. Voter fraud. Cover-up. Miami is engulfed in a series of high-profile investigations of public corruption so pervasive that it is often mentioned in the same breath as the New York of Tammany Hall and Chicago in the heyday of the Daley Democratic machine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISEN, HANNAH
description: EISEN-Hannah. On June 19, 1998. Beloved wife of Benjamin. Devoted mother of Linda. Funeral services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITTER, HARVEY
description: GITTER-Harvey. Beloved husband and friend of Corinne (nee Brilliant). Father of Andrea and Jeffry Gitter. Father-in-law of Stephan Fox. Beloved grandfather of Ashley Gitter and Maya GitterFox. Beloved brother, brother-inlaw and uncle. Graveside services at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y. Sunday, 11AM. We'll miss you, Poppyseed.

title: Liberty Loses Again
description: The Liberty's trip to nowhere ended in Inglewood, Calif., last night, with a 78-75 loss to Los Angeles at the Great Western Forum.

title: When Dad Is Addicted
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Executives Are Convicted in a Fuel-Tax Scheme
description: Four fuel company executives were convicted today for their roles in a scheme that cheated the Federal and state governments out of more than $140 million in fuel taxes.

title: As Crisis Deepens, U.S. and European Firms Move In : West Snaps Up Asian Businesses
description: SINGAPORE  As East Asia's financial and economic crisis deepens, Western companies are buying Asian businesses at a record rate to increase their strategic presence in the region and outflank rivals, especially from Japan, executives and analysts say.

title: Clinton Urged to Meet Top China Dissident
description: A group of 55 democracy advocates from around China called on President Clinton today to meet with a prominent Beijing dissident during his visit to China next week as a visible symbol of commitment to human rights.

title: U.S. Starts to Dust Off a Dark Spot in History for All to See
description: The stone sentry posts stand empty and silent at Manzanar, their graceful pagoda shapes a haunting reminder in the desolate high desert here on the eastern slope of the Sierra Nevada. In World War II, this lonely stretch of scrub off Highway 395 was the largest community between Los Angeles and Reno.

title: Jane Austen? Love Her! Don DeLillo? Love Him! But No Poets?
description: The New York Times asked Melissa Fay Greene, Stanley Crouch and Elmore Leonard to rate the computer-generated book recommendations offered by Amazon.com's Bookmatcher. The Bookmatcher quiz first asked the authors how frequently they read different literary genres, like classics and science fiction. Then they were asked to rate 20 different books ''Bad!'' to ''Loved It!'' (In general, Bookmatcher was more interested in opinions about John Grisham than Tolstoy.) Despite their different responses, all three authors found Jane Austen and ''Underworld,'' by Don DeLillo on their lists.

title: From a Promising Path To a Charge of Murder
description: As he left his Queens home on Tuesday night, Tae Wook Yoon walked by a letter in the living room accepting him into a military academy, and his dream of becoming a law enforcement agent still seemed a possibility.

title: CUNY Board Nominee Confirmed by Senate
description: In a move that may strengthen the hand of Gov. George E. Pataki with the City University of New York, the State Senate has confirmed the Governor's nominee for the 15-member board of trustees. The approval this week of the candidate, Kathleen M. Pesile of Staten Island, takes effect immediately. The term of Ms. Pesile, a financial consultant, teacher and CUNY alumna, expires in 2004.

title: TV News Magazines Hard, Medium and Lite
description: ''CNN Newsstand,'' the new prime-time cable series, opened on a controversial note last week with allegations that the United States used nerve gas against American defectors during the Vietnam War. The network's chief military analyst, Maj. Gen. Perry Smith, retired, resigned in protest (''sleazy journalism'' he called it) but the report prompted Defense Secretary William S. Cohen to order a fresh inquiry.

title: International Briefs; China's Bank Regulation Is Criticized by Moody's
description: Arbitrary and unpredictable regulation by Chinese banking authorities poses a great risk to outsiders, Moody's Investors Service said this week in a report, warning that recent actions by the authorities ''highlight the almost total lack of transparency in the real regulation -- such that it is -- of Chinese financial institutions.''

title: NEW RULES SOUGHT FOR CONTRACTORS
description: Having declared victory in campaigns against corruption at garbage-carting companies and in the Fulton Fish Market, the Giuliani administration now has its sights on another target: New York City's giant $24 billion construction industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINDECKER, ERNA
description: STEINDECKER-Erna. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Els Bendheim and the Steindecker family on the loss of their beloved Erna. To anyone who had the good fortune of knowing her, she was a source of happiness and joy. Mrs. Steindecker was a righteous woman who personified the qualities of elegance, grace and extraordinary dignity. Throughout her life she exemplifed the values of intergrity, kindness and modesty and was ever-faithful to the legacy of the Bendheim-Salomon-Steindecker families' devotion to Am Yisrael, Torat Yisrael and Eretz Yisrael. May the family have warm and loving memories of a very special and caring wife, mother and grandmother. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Lee Weinbach, President, National Women's Division Sidney Adler, Treasurer Stuart Tauber, Executive Director

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a roll-call tabulation on Thursday about the Senate vote that sent the tobacco bill back to the Senate Commerce Committee misstated the party affiliation for Tom Harkin of Iowa. He is a Democrat.

title: Many Insurers Are Deciding Not to Cover Cost of Viagra
description: Some of the nation's biggest health insurers have decided not to pay for Viagra, the new male impotence drug, under their prescription drug plans. They said that providing the recommended 6 to 12 pills per month would be too expensive, adding hundreds of millions of dollars to annual costs.

title: Pushed by U.S., Colombia Plans New Chemical Attack on Coca
description: Bowing to demands from Washington, the Government has agreed to test a chemical to kill coca crops, even though the manufacturer has publicly warned against its use in Colombia.

title: INSIDE
description: Takeover of MCI Advances

title: Hundley's No-Trade Clause Represents a Compromise
description: In the last month, Todd Hundley has lost his catching job to Mike Piazza, been asked to learn a new position, nearly completed his rehabilitation from elbow surgery and read that some in Mets management are concerned about his work and drinking habits.

title: Baptists' Marital Edict Ignores Today's Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Let Russia Know It Has U.S. Support; Democratic Soul Mates
description: To the Editor:

title: International Briefs; Banco Bilbao Buys Stake In Chile's Banco BHIF
description: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya S.A., Spain's second-largest bank, said yesterday that it would spend $350 million to buy a controlling stake in Banco BHIF, Chile's seventh-largest bank, as it shifts its Latin American expansion to the region's southern reaches. The purchase will give Banco Bilbao a foothold in the region's most developed banking market and a presence in one of the few Latin American nations where Banco Bilbao does not do business.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, a front-page picture on Wednesday showing a church choir in Nanjing, China, was printed in mirror image. The choir leader actually stood at the right, and the characters behind the choir and beneath the cross said, ''Emmanuel,'' or ''God with us.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, JAMES
description: WALLACH-James. Suddenly on June 19, 1998. Loving husband of Mary J. Wallach, devoted father of Andrew M. and Scott S. Son of Miriam & Ira D. Wallach. Brother of Sue W. Wachenheim, Kenneth L. Wallach, and Kate W. Cassidy. Chairman & Chief Executive Officer of Central National Gottesman Inc. Services on Monday, June 22 at 11:00 A.M. at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York. Please omit flowers. Contributions may be sent to Bates College or Prep for Prep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, LUKE JOSEPH
description: TAYLOR-Luke Joseph, June 17, 1998. This unique and sensitive spirit was taken suddenly from a bewilderingly large and loyal circle of family and friends. Given a second chance at life Luke showed by his tenacity, humor and comforting presence what it means to be human. His appetite for knowledge, his ability to see through sham and cant, his carefully crafted prose and generous instincts will always inspire all those he loved and touched. We love you, Luke. Your father and mother J. Gary Taylor and Mary Ann Quinson, step parents Pat Taylor and Bruno Quinson. Your brothers Geoffrey, Adam and Joshua. Step brothers and sisters Tim, Chris, Peggy, Wendy and Janet and their families. Nephews and nieces James Giles, John Christian and Alexandra. Uncles and aunts Peter Taylor, Hadley Fisk, Vivien Malloy, Ed Goodman, Pam Lichty and their families. Luke was the grandson of the late Nena Manach, and Andrew Goodman, and Margaret Clark. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Thomas More Church, 65 East 89 Street, on Saturday, June 20th, at 11 A.M. Interment New Marborough, Mass. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Public Library.

title: Let Russia Know It Has U.S. Support; Devolution No. 2
description: To the Editor:

title: Expand the Javits Center
description: New York City's attraction as a site for trade shows and conventions has been one of the key elements in its economic growth. That makes it hard to understand why Mayor Rudolph Giuliani seems so indifferent to the fact that the Jacob Javits Convention Center is too small to accommodate the nation's largest trade shows, and growing less competitive every year. New York has long since fallen out of the top 10 when it comes to available exhibition space. It will drop further as other cities expand their facilities.

title: Astra to Buy Out Merck in Venture
description: Astra A.B., the Swedish pharmaceuticals giant, announced yesterday that it would buy Merck & Company's half of their American joint venture.

title: Healing With the Power Of Horses; Therapists Use Riding To Help Treat Disabilities
description: Guiding a chestnut gelding as it stepped carefully over obstacles in a ring in Huntington, N.Y., Tricia Schrader could have been any novice rider preparing for her first competition. She sat erect. She seemed confident, in control. Not until she spoke did her disabilities become apparent.

title: Silver Charm Joins the Fray For a Gold Cup Showdown
description: The long-awaited confrontation between two heralded horses became a reality yesterday when Hollywood Park got word that Bob Baffert was sending Silver Charm, winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness last year, to face Skip Away in the $1 million Hollywood Gold Cup next Sunday.

title: Microsoft Takes on Strunk and White
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN REBOUNDS. The yen rallied ahead of a weekend Group of Seven meeting in Tokyo to address Japan's economic problems. In New York, the dollar fell to 136.10 yen from 137.83, and fell 8.62 yen, or 5.9 percent, for the week.

title: French Premier Says West Faces Quandary on Kosovo
description: Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France said today that the West faced a serious quandary in the southern Serb province of Kosovo by trying to stop the violence there without appearing to side with the ethnic Albanians who are fighting for independence.

title: VALHI PURCHASES A 43.8% STAKE IN TREMONT
description: Valhi Inc., a holding company with stakes in chemical, waste management and metal parts companies, said yesterday that it had bought 43.8 percent of the Tremont Corporation from the parent of both companies for about $165 million, raising its ownership in the fourth-largest maker of white pigments. Valhi paid $56 a share for 2.9 million Tremont shares from the closely held Contran Corporation, which owns 93 percent of the Dallas-based Valhi. The purchase increases Valhi's stake in NL Industries, the fourth-largest maker of titanium dioxide, from 57 percent to 75 percent because of the Denver-based Tremont's stake in NL. The Texas billionaire Harold C. Simmons owns controlling stakes in Contran, Valhi, NL Industries and Tremont.

title: Journal; The Fire Next Time
description: New Yorkers can't stop howling about Rudolph Giuliani's proposed $15 million bulletproof bunker, but let's give the Mayor a break. Perhaps he is afraid of Pat Robertson, who this month warned that terrorist bombs, earthquakes, tornadoes and ''possibly a meteor'' could strike Orlando, Fla., in biblical vengeance for ''Gay Days'' at Disney World. There are more gay people in New York than in Orlando, and Mr. Giuliani has recently endorsed domestic-partnership rights for them. Who knows what havoc Reverend Pat might cook up in response? In 1985, when he prayed on TV for Hurricane Gloria to spare his headquarters in Virginia Beach, Va., the storm diverted to Fire Island, where, as the writer Christopher Buckley astutely noted, it wiped out Calvin Klein's summer house instead.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MERCANTILE BANCORP, St. Louis, agreed to acquire Bruno Stolze & Co., St. Louis, a discount brokerage firm, expanding into the retail securities market. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Steven Brill Strikes a Nerve in the News Media
description: If Steven Brill had simply written an opinion column for his new magazine, condemning the news media for their conduct in the coverage of the Monica S. Lewinsky investigation, Washington might have been able to ignore it. If all he had done was to get Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, to admit leaking information to reporters, the storm might have passed after a brief downpour of headlines.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of the Arts section on Thursday about the opening of the Caramoor Music Festival tonight in Katonah, N.Y., included an outdated reference to the soloist. She is the soprano June Anderson; the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne canceled her appearance after the program was printed.

title: Catholic Bishops Seek Restraint From the Entertainment Industry
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops issued an appeal yesterday to the entertainment industry and the Government to reduce the public portrayal of sex and excessive violence.

title: Baptists' Marital Edict Ignores Today's Reality; Food Laws Expired
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: AIDS Groups Stunned by Vote for Partner Notification
description: Advocates for H.I.V.-positive people in New York yesterday heard with disbelief the news that the State Legislature had passed a bill requiring that the names of infected people be reported to the state and mandating that government workers contact the sexual partners of those people.

title: Campbell Is a Candidate for a Top Job in the N.H.L.
description: Four months after being dismissed as coach of the Rangers, Colin Campbell is a top candidate for one of the most difficult jobs in the National Hockey League -- senior vice president and director of hockey operations.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 9 about Harold Segal, a fighter pilot decorated for his defense of American bombers against the Japanese in World War II, misidentified the Manhattan Borough President who was among those honoring Mr. Segal on his return to New York in 1944. He was Edgar J. Nathan Jr., not Edgar Harvey Jr.

title: JOINT VENTURE WITH REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES IS PLANNED
description: The Ford Motor Company took a big step yesterday into the car dealership business, announcing that it would set up a joint venture with Republic Industries and Ford dealers in Rochester that would own all of the Ford dealerships in the city. Republic has become the nation's largest retailer of cars by buying nearly 300 dealerships over the last year and a half. The transaction calls for the creation of a new company that would own all eight Ford dealerships in Rochester plus one of the city's three Lincoln-Mercury dealerships. The new company would be owned by the dealerships' current owners plus Ford and Republic.

title: Albany Passes A Bill to Speed School Voting
description: In its rush to adjourn for the year, the State Legislature passed a bill that would overhaul school board elections in New York City, replacing paper ballots with voting machines and simplifying a system of weighted voting.

title: Pope in Austria to Heal a Troubled Church
description: Pope John Paul II arrived in Austria today on a mission to grapple with two of the most troubling problems of his papacy in the Western world -- bitter divisions inside the ranks of the Roman Catholic Church, and the alienation and indifference of the prosperous society around it.

title: Microsoft Takes on Strunk and White
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Denies It Intends to Rescue Two Banks
description: As a high-level United States delegation pressed Japanese leaders today to strengthen the economy and tackle bad loan problems, news reports appeared that the Government might rescue two major banks by merging them.

title: Corrections
description: An essay in Science Times on Tuesday about the confusing language of physics at international conferences misattributed a comment about professors' making better speakers than graduate students. It was from Dr. Sheldon Glashow of Harvard, not Dr. Maurice Goldhaber, former director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Long Island.

title: G.M. Chief Urges Strike's End as 23d Plant Is Shut
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation called today for a speedy resolution of the two-week strike that has shut down virtually all of the car maker's North American assembly plants and has idled more than 100,000 workers.

title: Dick Gibson, Jazz Producer And Fan, 72
description: Dick Gibson, a longtime jazz aficionado and the producer of what he called an annual jazz party in Colorado, died at the Red Rocks Health Center hospice in Denver on Wednesday. He was 72 and lived in Denver.

title: Report Says Dead Child Had Suffered All His Life
description: An 11-year-old boy who died at a psychiatric hospital while being restrained had suffered his entire life, both because of a mother who verbally and physically abused him and because of a state agency that did not take him away soon enough, according to a report issued today by a state oversight panel.

title: The Dream Is Enough For L.I.U.'s New Coach
description: When Ray Martin received the telephone call informing him that he would be Long Island University's next basketball coach, he screamed. But during yesterday's news conference at L.I.U., Martin was a man of muted expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNSBERG, SHELDON
description: GUNSBERG-Sheldon. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Film Society of Lincoln Center note with profound sorrow the death of our Vice Chairman and beloved friend. Sheldon Gunsberg was among the founders of the Film Society in 1968. As an officer of the Walter Reade Foundation, he implemented the naming gift which launched our theater and worked devotedly with our staff and architects for nearly a decade, during all stages of the planning and building process. His support and enthusiasm were unstinting-his integrity and understanding of the true purpose of our organization made him an invaluable Board member and an indispensable sounding board for our staff. Our sense of loss is overwhelming and we send heartfelt condolences to his wife Lois and all the members of his especially loving family. Roy Furman, Chairman Irwin W. Young, President Joanne Koch, Exec. Dir.

title: International Briefs; Bertelsmann to Buy Out Its Partner in Book Clubs
description: Bertelsmann A.G., Germany's largest media company, said yesterday that it would buy Reed Elsevier P.L.C.'s 50 percent stake in their joint venture BCA, giving it total ownership of the operation, which is Britain's largest group of book clubs. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Microsoft Takes on Strunk and White
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSS, ARTHUR BRUCE
description: ROSS-Arthur Bruce. Artie, you do not depart from us. Love, B., C. and D.

title: Milutinovic Leads Another Team to 2d Round
description: Before these World Cup finals began, Bora Milutinovic was close to losing his job for the second time in a year. Today, Milutinovic, the cosmopolitan Yugoslav, became the first man to lead four different teams into the World Cup's second round.

title: Perez Gets Record In CityHawks' Loss
description: The CityHawks suffered a 53-43 loss to the Grand Rapids Rampage last night at Madison Square Garden to spoil a milestone game for quarterback Mike Perez.

title: Rome Journal; Insulting Ads: 'Guy Thing,' or Satire?
description: Soccer is usually the great unifier, the one hallowed passion that brings warring Italians together. When the first matches of the World Cup began last week, even the irreconcilable Italian Parliament agreed to hold sessions in the morning, which by odd coincidence leaves their afternoons free to watch the matches.

title: Victim in a Stabbing Saw Only the Best in Her Schizophrenic Fiance
description: On a summer night in 1995, there was a lively backyard party in New Rochelle, with music and hanging lanterns, and among the guests were Caroline Costello and Michael Laudor, who whirled around the flagstone patio with the grace of professional dancers.

title: McDonald's Burger War Salvo; Is 'Made for You' the Way Folks Want to Have It?
description: O.K., so McDonald's has a taste problem. The company says a solution is in the works. The only question is whether people will notice it.

title: MIDLAND, A CANADIAN BROKER, IS NEARING TAKEOVER
description: The stock of Midland Walwyn Inc. rose yesterday for a fourth day on renewed speculation that the concern, Canada's last major independent brokerage firm, is close to accepting a takeover offer. Midland's stock rose $1.25 (Canadian), to $27.25, in Toronto trading. The stock has risen 19 percent in the last four days, giving the company a market value of about $1 billion (Canadian). Analysts said Merrill Lynch was the most likely buyer for Midland, which has 170 branches and 1,800 employees.

title: Toro to Close a Factory
description: The Toro Company, the maker of lawn mowers, snowblowers and other outdoor products, plans to close its factory in Sardis, Miss., and sell its recycling equipment unit to cut costs and improve efficiency. Toro said it would take a $3 million charge in the third quarter, which will end on Aug. 1, to close the plant, where 115 employees make Lawn-Boy mowers and Toro snowthrowers. The financial impact of the sale has not been determined.

title: Let Russia Know It Has U.S. Support
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED DOMINION REALTY IN $51 MILLION EXPANSION
description: United Dominion Realty Trust Inc. said yesterday that it had purchased two apartment communities in Phoenix and land in Orlando, Fla., for a total of $51 million. United Dominion Realty, based in Richmond, is a real estate investment trust that owns more than 71,000 apartment units in 15 Sun Belt states. In Phoenix, United Dominion acquired the 856-unit Rancho Mirage complex and the 330-unit Woodland Park apartment community, both on the city's north side. The company also said it had bought 18.3 acres in Orlando and had begun construction of an $18.6 million, 292-unit apartment community to be called Ashton at Waterford Lakes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, HENRY E
description: MAYER-Henry E. United Jewish Appeal, Israel Education Fund mourns the death of Henry Mayer. A great lover of Israel, a donor that has built the Misgav Region, a devoted Jew and a friend of the United Jewish Appeal, Israel Education Fund. Condolences to his wife Lori and their family. Jane Sherman, President Yitzchak Shavit, Vice President Eliezer Shavit, Chairman

title: Type of Gun Identified In Vigilante Incident
description: Ballistics tests have determined that a single .45-caliber weapon was used Tuesday to shoot at a house in Linden that was occupied by a convicted sex offender who had been identified under ''Megan's Law,'' the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINN, S. STEPHEN
description: LINN-S. Stephen. On June 18, 1998 at the age of 77. Beloved husband of Lillian. Adored father of Susan, Bruce and Karen. Brother of Albert and adoring grandfather of Jeffrey, Jamie and Jennifer. With a remarkable mind and an indomitable spirit, he lived his life fully and brought joy to ours.

title: Foreign Affairs; Both Sides Now
description: I came here expecting to hear all about how the Indian nuclear test was meant to cope with the Pakistani threat. What I heard instead was Indians from across the political spectrum insisting that their nuclear sound and light show on May 11 was actually meant to signal America and China that India views their emerging ''alliance'' with great concern and will not let these two powers carve up Asia without regard to India.

title: About New York; Open-Air Sculpture With a ZIP Code
description: THE postman never rings twice when he gets to Ezra Shales's house on a half-empty strip of Beach 43d Street in Edgemere, Queens. A double take is more likely. There is no bell; nor for that matter, any doors, walls or people. Just a bright yellow mailbox set into the sandy dirt by the cracked sidewalk.

title: Bridge; Cayne and Nickell Squads Lead in Championship Trials
description: Four of the country's best teams battled yesterday in Tunica, Miss., in the semifinals of the International Team Trials. At stake is the right to be one of two teams that will represent the United States in the next Bermuda Bowl world championship in Bermuda in January 2000.

title: Microsoft Takes on Strunk and White
description: To the Editor:

title: Time for Action in Japan
description: International financial officials are meeting in Tokyo with a sense of urgency that has been lacking for most of this decade as Japan refused to deal with its banking crisis. Now Japan has promised prompt action, and has earmarked money to do the job. What is unclear is whether the Japanese authorities are able to act decisively.

title: Politics or No, Brazil Plans to Sell Telebras
description: Amid fierce election-year politics, the Brazilian Government has announced plans to go ahead late next month with the breakup and sale of Telebras, the giant Brazilian telephone holding company.

title: From Arms Proliferation to Protocol, Clinton Crams to Learn About China
description: Among the learned volumes and fat briefing books on China piled by President Clinton's bedside to prepare him for his trip next week is a videocassette of ''The Gate of Heavenly Peace,'' a gripping three-hour documentary about the Tiananmen Square demonstrations of June 1989.

title: Medicare Officials to Limit Distribution of New Guide
description: In an abrupt change of plans, Clinton Administration officials said today that they would restrict the initial distribution of a new consumer guide on the Medicare program because they feared that millions of elderly people would be utterly confused by its description of new health insurance options.

title: Casey Martin Makes the Cut
description: Casey Martin felt that making the cut at the United States Open made a strong statement about his golf game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLENS, ROSLYN (BREITMAN)
description: WILLENS-Roslyn (Breitman). Widow of the late Jules, died June 17 1998. Bronx born and co-founder co-operator of Manhattan's popular Caffe Cielo. She was among the first woman salespersons in the highly competitive garment industry. Your pals and patrons adore you Roz-and ever will. Funeral service 11AM, Sunday, June 21, Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.

title: Stewart Halfway Home, but Putts Getting Slippery
description: Payne Stewart escaped the United States Open today with a one-stroke lead, but nobody escaped the Olympic Club's wrath.

title: G.O.P. LEADERSHIP IN HOUSE REBUFFED ON ELECTION FUNDS
description: A majority of the House, including 65 Republicans, voted today to protect a bipartisan campaign finance bill from the first Republican leadership effort to water it down by amendment.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks End Volatile Week Lower in Waves of Selling

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, THELMA
description: FINKEL-Thelma. The Department of Dentistry of Peninsula Hospial Center notes with profound sorrow the passing of Thelma Finkel, beloved wife of Dr. Eugene Finkel, a member of our department. Our sincerest condolences to Dr. Finkel and his family.

title: Editorial Observer; Machismo Gives Good New Laws a Black Eye
description: In March, Daniel Ortega's 30-year-old stepdaughter, Zoilamerica Narvaez, stunned Nicaragua with her charges that the former President had been sexually abusing her since she was a child. Her detailed and anguished story, which Mr. Ortega denies, has dominated Nicaragua's news and gossip. Mr. Ortega will probably not face trial, as a judge ruled this week that he has parliamentary immunity. But more surprising, the charges have sparked no broader discussion on sexual abuse. Last month Mr. Ortega was re-elected, nearly unanimously, as head of the Sandinista Front, in a convention where the charges were never mentioned.

title: Buffett Takes General Re Into His Fold
description: Warren E. Buffett added to his vast financial empire yesterday, agreeing to buy the largest United States insurance company that specializes in covering the risks of other insurers for $21.7 billion in stock.

title: Rain Hinders 2d Round
description: The first-round leader Heather Daly-Donofrio and the second-day upstart Marilyn Lovander were tied for the lead near the midway point of the storm-marred LPGA Friendly's Classic yesterday in Agawam.

title: 'Triple Witching' and Japan Worries Send Dow Lower
description: Stock prices fell again yesterday as Wall Street closed out a volatile week just the way it began: with waves of large-scale selling.

title: Therapists' Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Charged in Rape Of Girl at Library
description: A Parsippany man who had once been convicted of a sex crime was arrested last night and charged with raping a 16-year-old girl in the main branch of the Newark Public Library, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTTER, SANDRA
description: ROTTER-Sandra. Our partners and entire staff at Herzfeld & Rubin, P.C. join Sandy's husband Irv and her children Abby and Melissa, her parents and the other members of her family and friends in mourning the untimely death of this gifted and courageous lawyer and colleague. Her faith, warmth and friendship inspire us and will long be remembered. Herbert Rubin, President

title: In Shanghai, Fine Points Are Crucial
description: When the Lincoln Center Festival announced that it was presenting a production of the classic Chinese opera ''The Peony Pavilion'' as its centerpiece next month, many wondered whether so arcane an offering could capture the attention of even a few hundred theatergoers in New York. Now, as the sets, props and costumes remain tied up in Shanghai, the production is the center of an international incident involving diplomats from at least three countries.

title: The U. A.W. 's Big Mistake
description: In shutting down General Motors once again, the United Automobile Workers has shown that it will not allow the car company to do what is necessary to survive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEYMAN, AUGUSTA BROWN
description: HEYMAN-Augusta Brown. On June 18, 1998. Devoted and beloved wife of the late Edward Heyman. Beloved cousin and friend to Bobrick, Gerstley, Israel, Swillinger and Waldman families. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Monday, 11 AM.

title: Embarrassment Of Critics: Raters Rated
description: These should be the best of times for critics. The arts in America are exploding, culture has been democratized and just about anything can be called ''art.''

title: Final Advice From Dr. Spock: Eat Only All Your Vegetables
description: The late Dr. Benjamin Spock, arguably the most influential pediatrician of all time, has left children and their parents with a surprising and rather demanding legacy: advice that they stick to a vegetarian diet devoid of all dairy products after the age of 2.

title: International Briefs; Iberia Order With Airbus Gives Boeing a Setback
description: Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana S.A., the Spanish national airline, said yesterday that it had signed a contract to buy up to 76 aircraft from Airbus Industrie for as much as 400 billion pesetas ($2.63 billion). Airbus said this was the largest aircraft order it had ever received from a European carrier.

title: Big Board Posts 2.3% Rise In Uncovered Short Sales
description: On the smaller American Stock Exchange, short interest rose 3.7 percent, to 196.5 million shares as of June 15 from 189.5 million shares, the exchange reported.

title: Swiss Banks Make Offer On Nazi Loot
description: Switzerland's three biggest commercial banks today offered $600 million to settle claims from Holocaust victims who have charged that their families' assets were stolen.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN SURGES. Corn prices rose 3 percent on concerns that hot weather forecast for the Midwest, following heavy rains earlier this month, might reduce yields. The July contract rose 8 cents, to $2.535 a bushel.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day on Monday and a heading in the Business Digest about proposed accounting rules on financial derivatives misstated the stance of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. While he has indicated support for the Financial Accounting Standards Board, which made the proposal, he has opposed the rules; he did not endorse them.

title: Rid Homes of Guns, Presbyterians Urged
description: The top policy-making body of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) passed a resolution calling on the denomination's members to begin removing handguns and assault weapons from their homes. Several major Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish organizations favor restrictions on handguns and assault weapons, but Presbyterian officials said their resolution took a different tack in asking for individual action by church members, rather than seeking a purely legislative remedy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMAGNA, VICTOR A.
description: ROMAGNA-Victor A. On June 12, at home in Annapolis, Md. Survived by his wife, Louise; children, Lenore Alexander, Lisa Frappaolo, and Marion Jones; brother, Leonard, and four grandchildren. Memorial service at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, July 10, 10:30 AM, Port Washington, New York. Memorial contributions to Hospice of the Chesapeake, 8424 Veterans Highway, Millersville, MD 21108, or The Herreshoff Marine Museum, America's Cup Hall of Fame, P.O. Box 450, Bristol, R.I. 02809.

title: Baptists' Marital Edict Ignores Today's Reality; Dangerous Submission
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Kuchar Can't Win It. Or Can He?
description: IT can't happen. The 98th United States Open here at Olympic can't be won by an amateur golfer, if only because an amateur golfer hasn't won the Open since 1933. But if Matt Kuchar is still under par after the final round on Sunday, his 20th birthday, well, maybe, just maybe, an amateur could win.

title: Tiny Windows, On the Past, Shutters Open
description: SOMETIMES groundbreaking inventions come along when the world is not quite ready for them, and then they languish awhile.

title: Time for Your Close-Up
description: ENGLEWOOD is the Hollywood of the Garden State, a town replete with show-business heavyweights. But don't expect to see flesh-and-blood stars strutting down Palisades Avenue. Most of Englewood's celebrities are not ambulatory. They are houses, made of brick and mortar.

title: 7 Dead as Bus Driver On Last Run Crashes
description: A Greyhound driver making his last run before retirement was killed yesterday along with his wife and and an 8-year-old boy he planned to adopt, as well as four other passengers, when their bus hit a parked truck beside the rain-slicked Pennsylvania Turnpike and pushed it into another truck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUENEBAUM, THOMAS
description: GRUENEBAUM-Thomas. An international artist living in San Miguel and Santiago de Queretaro, Mexico, on May 28th at age 63 of a heart attack. In addition to his wife, Marilyn, he is survived by his mother, Corina, sister, Mary Weiss of Palm Beach, and five children, Alicia Hammang, Arturo Gruenebaum, Joslyn Cooke, Mary Phillips, and Suzanne Miller, and six grandchildren. He had just completed an exhibition of his work at the Museo de Arte in Queretaro.

title: New Jersey Women, Keep Your Paraphernalia
description: To the Editor:

title: Starr Is Said to Be Insistent About a Guilty Plea From Lewinsky
description: Lawyers for Monica S. Lewinsky have been told that she must agree to plead guilty to some offense to reach an agreement with Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel who is investigating her relationship with President Clinton, said a person with knowledge of the investigation.

title: A Fort Girds for Civilian Life, With Snags
description: Historic Fort Totten, a military base decommissioned in 1995, is on the brink of a new life. The panel charting its redevelopment released a final plan this spring that includes a waterfront esplanade, city parkland, housing for nonprofit agencies, a Fire Department training academy and a Civil War museum.

title: CUTTINGS; Pruning in Shorts and T-Shirt Weather
description: GRANDPA never lied. When he said, ''Pruning trees in the summer is bad, especially with fruit trees, because they might bleed to death,'' he was just repeating an heirloom fallacy.

title: In Geneva, a Makeshift Opera House Comes to Stay
description: WHILE other cities have lost their beloved 19th-century opera houses in the wave of overgrown performing-arts centers, the board of the opera company here bucked the tide. At the same time that it took necessary steps to preserve the Grand Theatre, Geneva's elegant opera house from 1882, it developed a second house in many ways as good as the old one, and for that matter, almost as old.

title: For Infertility Treatments, Now You're Covered, Now You're Not
description: IT took Carla and Bruce P. three and a half gut-wrenching years of invasive medical treatments and more than $40,000 of their savings before Carla got pregnant in April. That makes them part of a small but growing population that beat what the New York State Task Force on Life and the Law recognizes as the ''disease'' of infertility.

description: REMEMBER Abraham Maslow, the humanistic psychologist from Psych 101?

title: Strings to Moscow Severed, a Company Is Free to Be Itself
description: THE last time the Virsky Ukrainian National Dance Company visited New York, in 1988, Ukraine was part of the Soviet Union and the troupe was beholden to its Moscow sponsors. That is, it was strongly encouraged to perform Russian dances along with Ukrainian ones.

title: Genes Are Easy, Money Is Hard
description: CYNTHIA K. FRENCH was a typical entrepreneur, as passionate as she was broke. She even researched loan sharks as she sought money for the biotechnology company she was sure would find treatments for reproductive diseases.

title: Victor Romagna, 80, America's Cup Sailor
description: Victor Romagna, an outspoken force in America's Cup yacht racing for a quarter of a century, died on June 12 at his home in Annapolis, Md. He was 80.

title: Women and Sex: On This Topic, Science Blushes
description: DR. JULIA HEIMAN, a psychologist who directs the reproductive and sexual medicine clinic at the University of Washington, wanted to know whether women become sexually excited by talk of love and romance, or are they turned on by explicit talk of sex itself?

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Volvo C70; Aiming High, Volvo Throws a Curve
description: YOU see the reaction again and again when driving Volvo's new C70 coupe. When you double-park at the dry cleaners, pull into a parking garage, approach a toll booth, people glance quickly, then do a double-take. They are puzzled.

title: Orange Inspection Stickers Come to the Rescue
description: Last fall, the Division of Motor Vehicles opened test lanes for a new, more stringent emissions test in Trenton and Wayne. Drivers who passed were rewarded with a green inspection sticker good for two years rather than one. But the yearly inspection stickers that expired in 1997 were also green, and police officers have been stopping drivers with green stickers.

title: Diplomacy And Urgency As the U.S. Faces Iran
description: It is great that the Clinton Administration wants to reconcile with Iran, Alexi Lalas said. He and his American teammates will shake hands with Iran's players before Sunday's game and exchange jerseys afterward. But this is the World Cup, and politics must take a backseat to soccer, he said. Ultimately, it is more urgent to win the game than to win new friends.

title: Seeking a Consensus On Fire Island Matters
description: In his May 31 letter, Alan Brockman, president of the Fire Island Pines Property Owners' Association (of which I am also a member), implies that his environmental views reflect all of his neighbors', but I and most of the people with whom I speak disagree with many of the statements he makes.

title: Heather Hough, Steven Brownlie
description: Heather Linscott Hough, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Hough of Roanoke, Va., was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Steven Thomas Brownlie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Brownlie of Spring, Tex. The Rev. Frank E. Allen, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: A Flutter
description: Fashion is beginning to resemble Victorian fairy paintings. Butterflies embroidered in Asia are fluttering whimsically all over daytime sweaters and evening dresses. Three-dimensional silk butterflies have alighted on gossamer net evening dresses, as well as on hair and shoes. Even some New York City buses are painted all over with butterflies advertising the New York Zoological Society's Butterfly Zone at the Bronx Zoo.

title: 5 Attractions for Summer Joy Riding
description: SUMMERTIME blockbusters are not confined to movie theaters. To entice repeat visits, amusement parks spend millions of dollars on new thrill rides. This year, according to Amusement Business, which tracks the $8 billion industry, is a record one for roller coaster construction, with nearly 80 being built worldwide.

title: Valerie Gorge, John Rogers Jr.
description: Valerie Anne Geraldine Gorge and John Stratford Rogers Jr. were married on Friday at City Hall of the Ninth Arrondissement in Paris by Vincent Reina, the first assistant to the Mayor there. Yesterday, the Rev. David Wood, an American Baptist minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the American Church in Paris.

title: The Daily Obstacle Course
description: THE mushrooms growing out of the living room wall in Marcia Tepler's apartment on West 86th Street are small and dark, but her husband, Ike, could not resist cackling, ''If you bring spinach, I will make you an excellent salad.'' This is the real estate version of gallows humor.

title: Amy Ruger, Andrew Whiteley
description: Amy Thompson Ruger, a daughter of Mrs. L. Christian Michelsen of New York and the late James Thompson Ruger, was married yesterday to Andrew Stratford Whiteley, a son of Mrs. Robert E. Deeley of Dorset, Vt., and George Carpenter Whiteley 3d of New York.

description: There is a certain irony in the fact that a campus where Skull and Bones can practice such exclusivity cannot make its peace with a religious need for an exclusivity of its own.

title: 'I Am Not in a Good Place,' Michelangelo Wrote. 'And I Am No Painter.'
description: For four years, Michelangelo mounted a curved, stepped scaffold of his own design in the Vatican and went to work on the ceiling 50 feet above the floor of the Sistine Chapel. It was not his favorite thing to do. ''My brush is above my head and drips paint on my face,'' he wrote. ''I am bent like a bow and my back aches. Dear friend, rescue me now. I am not in a good place. And I am no painter.''

title: On Resort Shores, It's People vs. Plovers
description: FROM his vantage point along Dune Road in the Village of West Hampton Dunes, Lawrence M. Houghton has been watching through binoculars as a crisis unfolds.

title: A Good Villain Can Help Sales of Diet Books, Too
description: THERE'S nothing more predictable about the success of a popular diet book than the needle on the scale -- pounds fall and sales rise along with the notoriety of a faddish new villain of fat or some pound-melting gimmick.

title: Touting East Hampton's 350th, Graciously
description: SUZANNE STEELE says her family has been in East Hampton as long as there has been an East Hampton. ''And on both sides,'' she said. ''Some people can claim one side of their family goes way back, but with me it's both.''

title: Boarding Passes Becoming Relics
description: ADVANCE boarding passes are becoming relics. Tim Smith, a spokesman for American Airlines, which stopped issuing them June 1, said they actually became useless almost two years ago, after the July 1996 explosion aboard a Trans World Airlines plane off Long Island. The Government quickly tightened security regulations then, and all passengers are now required to go to an airport counter to present photo identification before boarding any flight.

title: Newport
description: As if just waking from one of its historic slumbers, the city of Newport has recently emerged from a recession that seemed to hang on longer than elsewhere in New England. But now the feeling of vitality is everywhere -- from the fresh paint on 18th-century houses to the flower boxes on storefronts; from new restaurants downtown to the yachts large and small in Newport Harbor.

title: A Thriving Texas Track Offers Something for Everyone
description: Jerry Jeff Walker has wailed beer-soaked ballads in the paddock garden. Thousands of children have been encouraged to wander through the petting zoo and family playground. And on Friday night, Lone Star Park at Grand Prairie played host to 12 of the nation's top riders in an unusual competition called the all-star jockey championship.

title: College Efforts To Lure the Best Set Others Back
description: Colleges are spending more on scholarships to attract top students and, as a result, they have less to spend on many needy applicants, admissions officers and administrators say.

title: Commuting Over the River and Through the Bay
description: MONDAY morning is Monday morning, no matter how you get to work: commuters on autopilot, with a death grip on briefcases, coffee cups and newspapers.

description: FUNDS are closing at a record rate this year. But according to a new report issued by the Kobren Insight Group, a lot more of them ought to be slamming their doors.

description: A NEW tie, some after-shave, lunch or dinner out: the typical trappings of appreciation for many fathers on Father's Day. More than a Hallmark card occasion, however, on this Father's Day, many fathers want the peace of mind that comes with quality child care.

title: Gauging the Risk Factors in the Search for a Perfect Face
description: IT has never been easier, or more tempting, to have cosmetic surgery and other beauty-enhancing procedures than now. More cosmetic surgeons and ''esthetic'' dentists are setting up shop as baby boomers are looking longer in the mirror and seeing sags, wrinkles and discolored teeth.

title: SOAPBOX; Waste Land
description: THE City of New York giveth and it taketh away -- sometimes the same day. One afternoon last fall I received two official documents from the city. One was a check for jury duty: $82.50 for three days' work. That was about $400 short of the freelance fact-checking income I had sacrificed to do my duty, but I'm all for justice. Besides, $82.50 to a freelancer is, well, $82.50 I didn't have before.

description: Marianne Means and James J. Kilpatrick, the Washington columnists, were married on Friday by Judge Christine Miller in her chambers at the United States Court of Federal Claims in Washington.
