description: Lorraine Denise Morrissey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Morrissey of Holtsville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Carswell Rush Berlin, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. F. Henry Berlin Jr. The Rev. Paul F. Wancura performed the ceremony at Caroline Episcopal Church in Setauket, N.Y.

title: Charmian Ling, Robert Gilmartin
description: Charmian Avril Junmai Ling and Robert John Gilmartin are to be married today. The Rev. Vernon C. Nichols is to perform the ceremony at the Fourth Universalist Society in Manhattan.

title: Desperately Seeking Solitude; The Wanted Fish That Went Free
description: It looked for a minute as if John Siuro would lose. Then he jerked his fishing rod backward and started reeling in the tense line. His two friends peered into the East River. A gleaming, silver-scaled fish emerged from the water, its thrashing tail flinging droplets through the air.

title: In the Region/Long Island; A Different Approach to Attached Condo Housing
description: A BELLMORE developer has come up with a new concept for a condominium development: attached houses that have only one floor, rather than the usual two-story homes.

title: Our Common Cradle
description: AFRICA A Biography of the Continent. By John Reader. Illustrated. 801 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: Hartford Symphony Moves Outdoors
description: THE Hartford Symphony's summer home is the Talcott Mountain Music Festival, with the first of four concerts on the grounds of Hartford Life in Simsbury set for Thursday evening at 8. With Apo Hsu (music director of the Springfield Symphony in Missouri) as guest conductor, the program sparkles with such popular showpieces as Sibelius's ''Finlandia'' and Tchaikovsky's ''Capriccio Italien,'' but it also features a pair of concertos -- Liszt's First and Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' -- tackled by the pianist Jeffrey Siegel.

title: A Site That Gets Lots of, Well, Hits
description: The Yankees have the best record in baseball, winning three out of four games so far this season. But Paul Gomez, a veteran Yankee fan, takes the long view. ''In my lifetime,'' he said, ''I've had my ups and downs with the team.'' Mr. Gomez turned 18 last week.

title: Yin and Yang; In Asia, America's Foe Is Also Friend
description: AS President Clinton crams for his trip to China this week, he must be yearning for those simpler days, not so long ago, when it was much easier to explain to Americans the distinction between friends and foes in Asia.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Pulp Fiction
description: Both the bullets and the gags fly fast and furious in Steve Aylett's hyperkinetically violent, hilarious time-traveling crime caper, SLAUGHTERMATIC (Four Walls Eight Windows, paper, $13.95). They strike targets both innocent and guilty: corrupt police officers, slimy lawyers, brutal hit men, computer hackers and that most hapless of modern comic figures, the mime. The slightly futuristic scene of this comic mayhem is Beerlight, a techno-Hobbesian city where life is nasty, brutish, short and wired, and where crime is ''the new and only art form.'' One of its up-and-coming masters is Dante Cubit, who, with his jittery pill-fueled partner, the Entropy Kid, executes an ingenious heist. Dante reprograms a bank vault time lock designed to send would-be robbers 20 minutes into the future, where they are already handcuffed and in police custody. Instead, he sends himself 20 minutes into the past and into the locked vault, which he will open when the Entropy Kid and the ''real time'' version of himself enter the bank again. The plan is for Dante to shoot his doppelganger -- but Dante Two survives, prompting an intense ''menhunt'' by Beerlight's brutal police, an opportunistic lawyer, a romantically motivated hit man and Rosa Control, Dante's well-armed girlfriend. The chase culminates in a surreal and potentially catastrophic encounter between the two Dantes. While the body count is high, the tone is anything but grim, thanks to Aylett's wickedly funny commentary on this bullet-riddled, nihilistic metropolis and its inhabitants. But be warned: the mime doesn't survive. Michael Porter

title: Children's Books
description: GO AND COME BACK

title: Ringo Outdistances His Past, Finally
description: FOR a musician who was once part of the most influential band in pop, spending more than a decade rekindling a career must be an intensely frustrating business. But listening to ''Vertical Man,'' Ringo Starr's 12th post-Beatles studio album, one has to admire the cheerful industriousness with which he has tried to recapture the success of his early hits ''Ringo'' (1973) and ''Good Night Vienna'' (1974). His last effort, ''Time Takes Time,'' released six years ago, should have done the trick: it was bright, energetic and pleasantly Beatlesque, but it disappeared without hitting the charts.

title: Mets Give Sierra Minor League Pact
description: The Mets announced yesterday that they had signed the 32-year-old outfielder Ruben Sierra to a minor league contract and that he would join the Class AAA Norfolk team in Pawtucket, R.I., for tomorrow's game.

title: Desperately Seeking Solitude; No Sweat? Who Says? A Ritz of the Shvitz

A visit there offers a different kind of escape, a voyage to an era when the Lower East Side bustled with peddlers and Yiddish-speaking immigrants.

title: In N.B.A. Quest, Dobbs Ferry Star Is Starting Over
description: THE dream for Mark Blount, the former Dobbs Ferry High School basketball star, had always been to make it to the National Basketball Association as fast as possible. There he would find the riches, fame and acclaim that as a seven-footer with talent, he felt he was entitled to. But in his haste to suit up with elite players, Blount failed to realize that his skills were not fully developed and his penchant for the fast life was sapping his energy.

title: Making the Case for Prokofiev As a Heavyweight Contender
description: TODAY, as composers are being told to be more popular, Sergei Prokofiev may re-emerge as a role model for the young and ambitious. The composer of the ''Classical'' Symphony, ''Peter and the Wolf,'' ''Lieutenant Kije'' and ''Romeo and Juliet'' knew a thing or two about popularity. His innate sense of how to please an audience brought him early fame and allowed his music to reach millions for whom classical music, let alone most of its 20th-century varieties, was a closed book.

title: Taking Care Of Those The Good Times Have Skipped
description: A HOMELESS woman who slept for four nights in the front portico of Union Baptist Church in Mystic opened the community's eyes to a story behind the headlines hailing economic prosperity: The good times are leaving many people in eastern Connecticut behind.

title: Desperately Seeking Solitude; An Ocean Voyage Without the High Seas
description: Martin Rosenfeld, 82, drives each morning to Canarsie Pier where he does his squats and push-ups among the seagulls with a view few health clubs could rival. Murray Epstein, 75, has come every day for 30 years, to lounge on folding chairs with ''the boys'' and shoot the breeze or play pinochle. John Melecio and his wife, Lisa, are also regulars, but they come to catch dinner. One recent Tuesday, it was bluefish.

title: Prague: The Immersion Course
description: OUTSIDE the window, the sun was smiling on one of the world's most beautiful cities. It was early September in Prague, a warm and pleasant Wednesday morning. No doubt, Old Town Square was filled with tourists snapping pictures. The outdoor cafes would be crowded with people sipping coffee, waiting for the Town Hall's 15th-century Astronomical Clock to reveal, every hour on the hour, a little tableau of a skeletal Death ringing a bell as 12 medieval carved apostles emerged from two windows.

description: ONE of the things you discover when you're about to turn 50 is that your friends and family expect you to face the occasion in a socially correct kind of way. A stiff upper lip, a leavening of wry humor, some jokes about not being over the hill yet, a modicum of reflective wisdom (but no real complaints) -- and there, you're 50, the world smiles in approval. That wasn't so hard, was it?

Ms. Tuck studies meditation in a private group, not at the Los Angeles Baba Center. The article also misidentified the Indian ashram she plans to visit in November. It is an ashram run by followers of the late guru Meher Baba near the city of Ahmadnagar, not the ashram of the guru Sai Baba, near Puttaparthi in South India.

title: Desperately Seeking Solitude; Distant Skyscrapers Cut at Their Crowns
description: Throgs Neck is a mile-long finger of land so narrow it gives the impression of being afloat on Long Island Sound. On one end is the close-knit, private community of Silver Beach, which resembles a fishing village with its picturesque wooden bungalows along narrow lanes. Out on the point of the peninsula, beneath the towering Throgs Neck Bridge, is the State University of New York Maritime College and the massive 19th-century Fort Schuyler, with its vast museum of maritime history.

I had to have my battery recharged at truck stops twice before I finally rolled into town late at night. Shaken, I left my car in the parking lot of a mechanic I'd never met.

title: Desperately Seeking Solitude; Prayer Flags Aflutter At a Tibetan Outpost
description: Jacqueline Norma Klauber had a lifelong interest in Tibet, but she never stepped foot in the Himalayas. Instead, she brought the region to her. The result is the Jacques Marchais Museum of Tibetan Art, designed by Ms. Klauber and completed in 1947 on one of the highest points along the Eastern Seaboard. Tucked away in the Staten Island neighborhood of Richmondtown, the museum seeks to recreate the feel of a Tibetan monastery. It is built into a hillside and stands about 240 feet above sea level. The terrace commands a sweeping view of lush treetops to the east. Prayer flags flutter in the breeze, and red carp swim beneath lilypads in a garden pond.

title: The Mix-It, Match-It Theory of Management
description: Spend a few minutes in the management section of your local bookstore, and you will quickly find that the book jackets and titles start to blur. What's a manager in search of a little wisdom to do? Reading them all is not a realistic option. A better solution might be to cash in on what you already know and write a book yourself.

title: Pollution Dangers Of Golf Courses and Farms
description: Re: ''Farmland May Yield to Fairway'' (May 31), it is a fact that many years of exposure to chemicals used in farming have left some parts of Long Island in pretty bad shape. It will be a lot more complicated when all the proposed golf courses are up and running and they must be kept forever green. The amounts of pollution will be greater because you will not have all those nice healthy-looking fruits and vegetables to retain some of the poison and pass them on to the consumer. This time the chemicals will be sprayed on a non-edible monoculture and from there to the soil and water. So unless both farming and/or golf courses are maintained under organic standards, we have a no-win situation.

Rogers Whiffenpoof Leadership Award (Yale University) c/o Jim Rogers, 54 Rosebrook Rd., New Canaan, CT 06840.

title: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men
description: WESTERN thought about sex -- from the story of Eve to Aristotle's belief that girl babies arise from cooler sperm -- has been tainted by the notion that the female is a kind of imperfect or unfinished male. title: Crime

title: Culture Zone; Crossing The Great Divide
description: ''Where are you from?'' It's a pretty familiar question, an icebreaker of sorts, meant to elicit a simple response and to keep the conversation driving toward commonality and connection. Unless, of course, where you're from conflicts with what you look like. Then the question is more pointed -- coded -- a falsely casual way of asking not who but what you are. And for a growing number of people living in America's post-integration miasma, What am I? is the question that's being asked, debated, turned over, chewed upon and spat back out again.

title: Children's Books; I Was a Gorilla's Bunkmate
description: Atsuko Morozumi's MY FRIEND GORILLA (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $15; ages 3 to 5) is an elegant and charming picture book about friendship and tolerance. Morozumi's spare text and her luscious pictures will move just about any preschooler from giggles to sadness to a measure of understanding about how good friends are always a part of us. Adults may get teary-eyed. When a gorilla comes to live with the zookeeper's family, the zookeeper's son is at first scared of the huge creature who sleeps on his bottom bunk. But the gorilla is nice, and soon the boy has a new friend. Together boy and gorilla go to the park, read books and dream in the trees. The gorilla even goes to the boy's birthday party, where he is the largest guest. Then the cold weather comes, and it is time for the gorilla to go back to Africa. The boy cries when he says goodbye. He stays sad until a letter comes one day with a picture of the gorilla in the African jungle. The gorilla has a baby on his back! He looks happy, and so the boy is happy too. ''I still remember him,'' the boy says on the last page, gazing out his window, looking past the gorilla's photograph on the sill. Thumbtacked to the wall is a picture the boy has drawn of himself and his friend, holding hands. Everyone will adore the illustrations; the best is of the gorilla sitting at the boy's birthday table alongside nonchalant little girls in party dresses. Friends, of course, don't have to look at all like us. Elisabeth Bumiller

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZKOPF, FRANCINE. DR.
description: SCHWARZKOPF-Francine. Dr. Francine Schwarzkopf, chemist, 83, of esophageal cancer, at home, peacefully on Friday, June 19, surrounded by those she loved. Born in 1915 in Vienna, she spent most of her youth in Antwerp, Belgium, until her family fled to America in 1940. She and her husband, the late Dr. Otto Schwarzkopf founded the Schwarzkopf Microanalytic Laboratories in Queens in 1953. She was a 50 year member of the American Chemical Society. Francine enjoyed hiking, the fine arts, and spending time with family and friends. She touched the lives of all who knew her and will be greatly missed. She leaves a son, Marcel Daniel Schwarzkopf of Yardley, PA, and his wife, Amy Lowenstein; a sister-in-law, Mary Freeman Blankstein of St. Petersburg, FL, widow of Francine's twin brother Joseph; a niece, Margo Blankstein Muller of NYC; a nephew, Philip Blankstein of Kennesaw, GA, his wife Tracie and their four children; a niece, Anne-Marie Levine and her son David Levine of NYC; and cousins Dr. Vera Price of San Francisco, Evan Price and his wife Amy and son Will of San Francisco, and Dr. Lisa Price of Cambridge, MA. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers friends may donate to her favorite charities: Choice in Dying and the International Rescue Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLEISNER, KARLA MIRJAM
description: SCHLEISNER-Karla Mirjam. Beloved aunt of Mark Schleisner and Susan Hurwitz, cherished greataunt of Philip and Rachel Hurwitz, beloved first cousin of Ze'ev Schleisner and Nana Wilinsky. Born November 4, 1924 in Hanover, Germany, died June 4, 1998 in Englewood, New Jersey, after a valiant 12-year battle with cancer. A Kindertransport refugee from the Holocaust, Karla honored herself, and the memory of family members who perished, by devoting her life to helping others. She became a registered nurse and midwife while living in England, and continued her profession in the New York/New Jersey region. From 1974 until she retired from nursing in 1986, she was assigned as head nurse at the Carlstadt, New Jersey branch of The New York Times. She spent her retirement as a tireless volunteer for a nursing organization, judicial mediation service, and Meals on Wheels. She will be sorely missed by family and friends around the world. Memorial contributions may be made to her favorite charity, Kosher Meals on Wheels, (Attention: B. Berman), UJA, 111 Kinderkanack Road, River Edge, New Jersey 07661.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, NORMAN
description: WHITE-Norman. The Board, Staff and Volunteers of the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center mourn the passing of our dear friend Norman White. Norman had the foresight, determination, and commitment to be a guiding force during the Lesbian & Gay Community Services Center's formative years. Norman's generous spirit led him to serve on the Center's Board of Directors from 1985 through 1987. Even before his term on the Board and continuing until his passing, Norman was always a role model and a leader, volunteering extensively and giving generously. Norman was a true gentleman. His perseverance and courage as he faced his struggle with HIV and AIDS are an inspiration to all of us. Our deep sympathy goes to his devoted lover John Cunningham, and to his loving niece and her husband Sarah and Juergen Vogt. Everyone at the Center misses Norman more than words can say. We are forever indebted to him for being a beacon of kindness, courage and hope that lights our path to a brighter future for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people. Judith E. Turkel, Esq President Richard D. Burns, Esq Executive Director Lesbian & Gay Community Services Center

title: Putting a Different Face on a Timeless Classic
description: IS Bonnie J. Monte's premiere production at the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's welcome new theater an accidental act of re-invention? Or is it a brave new version of a classic pageant?

title: Children and Firearms
description: Legislation to strengthen penalties for selling guns to children and for using children to sell illegal firearms has passed the State Assembly and Senate and is on its way to the Governor's office, Assemblywoman Audrey G. Hochberg of Scarsdale, a sponsor of the legislation, said last week. ''The proposed law adds to the arsenal of crime-fighting measures we have,'' she said. ''The volume of guns on the street contributes to the number of crimes and level of violence.''

title: D. I. Axelrod, 87, Plant Evolution Expert, Dies
description: Dr. Daniel I. Axelrod, a paleoecologist at the University of California at Davis who reconstructed the ancient landscapes of the West by examining plant fossils, died on June 2 at his home in Davis. He was 87.

title: A Man and His Monument, Lost and Found
description: John Fitch, the 18th-century silversmith, patriot, soldier, gun trader, real estate speculator and inventor, considered to be the first person, in the 1780's, to harness steam to the job of powering a boats, was a man whose fortunes seesawed between prominence and obscurity. Fitch took his own life in 1798, penniless and surpassed by savvier and and better-financed steamboat entrepreneurs like Robert Fulton. Perhaps it is fitting that a stone monument to Fitch in Trenton, where he lived and worked in the years before the Revolutionary War, should have a similarly topsy-turvy fate. In 1921, a boulder was dredged from the Delaware River and dedicated to Fitch, near the site in Trenton where his steamboat docked on trips from Philadelphia. In 1963 the monument seemingly disappeared, coincidentally during improvements to John Fitch Parkway in Trenton, now simply known as Route 29. The monument was eventually found in a pile of weeds nearby. Last month, with a new plaque in place, it was rededicated at Mercer County Waterfront Park, next to the Katmandu nightclub and near where it originally stood.

title: Brian Wilson Is Back. That Is, He's Back Again.
description: ''WHAT street do you live on in West Hollywood?'' Brian Wilson asks.

title: Voice on Phone Is Not Human, But It's Helpful
description: Later this year, many callers wanting flight information from United Airlines will speak not to a person but to a computer that acts like one. It will ask when and where the caller wants to travel, look up flight schedules and converse using synthesized speech.

title: Doubly Proud: Twins at Top of the Class
description: SHORTLY after Judith A. Lewis arrived at Half Hollow Hills High School West last February to see her son Darren receive a $3,000 European American Bank/News 12 scholarship, the principal, James J. LoFrese, called her aside.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an art review of the Maurice Prendergast exhibition at the Montclair Art Museum misidentified the painting shown. It was ''Summer Hotel Maine,'' circa 1914-15, not ''St.-Malo.''

title: A Collision Over School Principal
description: The superintendent of Community School District 6, Anthony Amato, sat stone-faced Thursday night as about 40 parents and children from Public School 176 let him have it. Suddenly, what had been a routine local school board meeting in Inwood became a stirring protest. ''How can you expect our school to meet the standards of the district without leadership?'' shouted a parent, Janett Canela. ''We need your support.'' Then she and the others stormed out.

title: An Atom's-Eye View of AIDS
description: Scientists have obtained an atom-level picture, reconstructed by computer from X-ray data, of the first contact made between an AIDS virus and the human cell it infects. The picture portrays the daunting strength of the virus's several defenses against the immune system. It also defines points of vulnerability against which new drugs and vaccines might be designed.

title: Teen-Agers Learning to Say No
description: TEEN-AGE pregnancy is an integral part of the loop of urban poverty: it is caused by, and in turn causes, many of the other problems that prevent young people -- especially young women -- from realizing the full potential of their lives.

title: Records Show Lilco Payout Was No Secret
description: When Gov. George E. Pataki angrily disclosed a $42 million payment to the chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company earlier this month, he denounced it as ''an extraordinary secret act of greed.''

title: Lott's Comments Highlight Divisions of G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/Westchester; More Golf Courses Coming, 3, Maybe 4, From Trump
description: SINCE entering the Westchester County market in 1995, Donald J. Trump has proposed three golf-course projects. He now may make a fourth proposal, for property he recently purchased along the border with Putnam County.

title: Behind the Buzz on Designer Estrogens, Questions Linger
description: YOU might not realize it, but you have already heard a lot about designer estrogens. Think tamoxifen. Think raloxifene. These two new drugs, now making headlines that suggest they may prevent breast cancer, are the early ripples in what could be a tidal wave of synthetic hormones in the next few years.

title: The 'News' That's Fit To Mint
description: In a city littered with free newspapers, The Rotten Apple's front page often gets a second glance. ''UN Inspectors Make Scary Find'' blared the page 1 headline of last week's issue. ''Top-Secret Yanni CD Factory Discovered in 'Sensitive' Iraqi Site.'' The article, which features a photograph of a man wearing protective gear and holding aloft several of the Greek pop musician's compact discs, reports that a cache of ''deadly Yanni products'' have been unearthed by weapons inspectors. ''Also discovered were Boombox Bombs designed to play Yanni music at high volume after making contact with the ground,'' the article says. ''All workers in the plant were wearing earplugs, except for Kurdish 'test subjects' that appeared to be vacuous shells of humanity.''

title: For Corporate Rebels, Short-Sleeved Shirts
description: THE short-sleeved dress shirt conjures an image of pale crew-cut men, circa 1965, feeding punch cards into a mainframe computer the size of a studio apartment. But these days, when the high school computer nerd has probably become one of the richest men in the United States, the look has a quirky appeal.

title: The Nation; Watching Watchdogs Watching Watchdogs
description: MIDWAY through a news story about Steven Brill's arrival as the newest major-domo in the booming industry of media criticism, Howard Kurtz, a respected practitioner himself for The Washington Post, suddenly found it necessary to open parentheses confessionally in noting: ''The founder of Brill's Content (to which this reporter is to be an occasional contributor) could not be reached for comment.''

title: Figures Are Released On Jail Injury Claims
description: IN the latest salvo of an increasingly heated labor dispute between the county and correction officers at the County Jail here, the Spano administration claimed last week that every day last year an average of 120 of the 779 correction officers were unable to work because of injury.

description: SINGER-Robert. Of Cleveland, OH. Formerly of Great Neck, NY. Died on June 19, 1998. Beloved husband of Maxine (Berger). title: A New, if Not Improved, Use of Stereotypes
description: WELCOME to ''Meantime.'' The title of Mike Leigh's scathingly funny early-80's assault on Thatcherism might just as well describe our own age. We live in a time when bullies are in fashion and creative work that addresses social injustice or the validity of someone else's suffering is likely to meet with braying accusations of ''victim art'' and ''political correctness.'' Some filmmakers accommodate themselves to such a climate by deploying, with a wink and a naughty grin, the sort of stereotypes that began to disappear from movies 30 years ago and that to some of us at least, can't be redeemed by any amount of post-modernist irony or neo-noir chic.

Mitchell of Riverview, New Brunswick. The Rev. Peter Larsen, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y.

title: Pittsburgh Is Showcase For Women In Policing
description: A small placard hangs on a wall in Comdr. Maurita J. Bryant's office so that she can always see it from behind her desk. It reads, ''Of course women don't work as hard as men; they do it right the first time.''

title: Learning To Live With Volatility
description: FEARSOME volatility? Here's a pair of fund managers who have lived and breathed it for years. Kevin Landis and Kendrick Kam founded an investment club -- the Winners' Circle -- in 1987, venturing into the stock market about a week before the October crash.

title: In the Workplace, a Step Toward Sensible Shoes
description: American women are surrendering stature in the work place, much to the benefit of their feet. According to a national telephone survey of 500 women conducted in May by the American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society, a nonprofit organization of orthopedic surgeons that promotes foot and ankle care, 24 percent of working women wear high heels on the job, down from 37 percent in 1990.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNOLO, DOMENICA. ''DIMI'' (NEE LEUZZI)
description: DONNOLO - Domenica. ''Dimi'' (nee Leuzzi). Dimi was born on June 9, 1919 and died June 20, 1998 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of the late Vincent. She is survived by her sister Immaculate Mandragona, four daughters: Suzanne, Christine, Claire and Felicia Shuff and her husband Marc: and two sons Philip and Daniel and his wife Candace. Her four grandsons: Michael and Joshua Donnolo and Ian and Adam Shuff were her special love and brought much joy to her life and were a special comfort to her illness. She was a graduate of Pratt Institute and a loyal volunteer at the Metropolitan Opera Guild Education Office. Her friends will remember her countless performances in musicals at St. Ephrem's Players Guild, the Ridge Chorale and with The Jeff Samaha Singers. For years she had a one woman musical revue and sang for seniors in nursing homes throughout Brooklyn. She was an artist and took great pleasure in painting the flower of remembrance-the pansy. We will miss her every day for the rest of our lives but will cherish our memories of a mother, grandmother, sister, aunt and friend of selfless, abounding love and devotion. Reposing at Ralph Aievoli & Son, Inc., 1275 65 Street, Brooklyn, New York. Visiting hours Sunday, 7-9:30 PM, Monday and Tuesday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday St. Ephrem R.C. Church, 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers donations in Domenica's name to BRAVO or the Brooklyn Hospice.

Browse the shelves: along with the ingredients for Southern staples like corn bread and fried chicken stretches a range of pig parts from head to foot, including brains and fatty ham hocks and tails. Pork chitlins for frying are available in 10-pound buckets; fatback by the slab. Fatty beef parts are popular, too. Lard flies off the shelves in eight-pound cans.

description: The Institute of Medicine's food and nutrition board, a Federal agency that determines the amount of nutrients you need, is revising its guidelines. Here are new recommended daily intakes for two vitamins and one mineral:

The association represents 14,000 museums and individual museum officials.

description: JASON CLARK, a former computer consultant, joined the Microsoft Corporation's help desk last year, purely to get into the company. Now, he loves it. ''You play with technology and solve problems, but you don't work 70-hour weeks like the people in development,'' he said.

Surrounded by his mother, three sisters and a brother, he explained in his singsong voice how he had terrified some of the participants in a first-aid course he had taken by reacting with passionate alarm toward a doll that was supposedly choking and its inflatable mother.

Much of that increase can be attributed to the growing number of cruise ship passengers, including 700,000 in 1997. But tourism officials in Jamaica fear that the recent pervasive harassment of visitors, which Prime Minister Percival J. Patterson called the single biggest problem facing the island's tourist industry, could put an end to a profitable source of income.

description: A young woman whose body was found in the East River 14 years ago is believed to have been killed by a couple who were angered when she refused to work for them as a prostitute, the police said yesterday.

Yet the East Coast city dweller has a lumpectomy, removal of just a part of her breast, while the entire breast of the rural woman is surgically removed. Why did the treatments differ?

This same house has been the site of many ambitious restaurants for more than 10 years. MacKenzie's Old Ale House was the most recent. But Monetti's has enough going for it -- in looks, menu (mostly Italian), prices (low to moderate) and staff (uniformly good natured and enthusiastic) -- to break the high mortality trend.

title: Heartfelt
description: Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who helped save nearly 100,000 Jews from Nazi concentration camps, has been much remarked on and written about in the United States, but there is little in the way of three-dimensional tribute to him. Now, in Smith Field Park in Parsippany, there stands a 13-foot bronze sculpture to honor Wallenberg: ''Courage and Compassion,'' created by Edward M. Adams, a sculptor and painter who works in Lambertville. He explains the form as ''inspired by the sight of tree limbs bending in the cold of winter.'' The trees, naked and waiting for spring, are like the Jews of wartime Europe, he says, waiting for signs of hope. The twisted metal took on the form of a heart, which can be seen as either broken or healing. Mr. Adams was selected for the monument by a committee formed in Parsippany in 1989 to honor Wallenberg. An earlier commissioned sculpture of Oskar Schindler by Mr. Adams, now on display at Kean College in Union, will eventually reside in the Holocaust Museum in Washington.

title: Bronxville's History Preserved in New Book

George Armstrong Custer, built two stately homes in Bronxville's Lawrence Park planned community before making her last stand in Manhattan.

Still, Batsheva Greer's attempt to justify her distinction between the social and the academic experience -- ''when something is said in a classroom, you can listen and write notes and it doesn't make an impression'' -- makes me wonder what she's going to get even from the education she says she wants.

title: Suriname's Example
description: The world's forests have been under siege since the turn of the century, but this year has been calamitous. In Canada, Brazil, Mexico, Central America, Africa and Indonesia, fires have destroyed nearly 40 million forested acres, an area as large as New York State. The easy explanation is El Nino, a perverse weather system that has flooded some regions but left others bone dry. But the main culprit, as always, is human activity, chiefly logging, mining and agriculture, which dries out the forest by stripping it bare of trees, leaving even humid tropical rain forests vulnerable to fire. For that reason, the fires are likely to reoccur, with or without El Nino, unless something is done to curb mankind's insatiable appetite for wood.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Little People
description: Victorian fairy painting might sound like just the thing to send you nodding off to never-never land. However, VICTORIAN FAIRY PAINTING (Merrell Holberton/University of Washington, $40), a collection of essays on fairies in Victorian music, literature, ballet, theater and book illustration, is as powerful an inducement to fancy as the opium that inspired a number of the paintings. Victorians were haunted by the fairies of Shakespeare's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' and of European folklore (rediscovered by the Romantics) largely because fairyland offered a warped mirror in which their era's concerns could be reflected. Rural superstitions about an uninhibited tiny people, over whom flowers towered and gravity's laws held no sway, provided a charming antidote to unsettling advances in scientific understanding and industrialization. For artists and writers, the imagination's powers were vindicated by the notion of a kingdom that only the inner eye could see (though misguided attempts were made to verify fairyland through the new eye of photography). Nearly every British painter of the period attempted descriptions of this fantastic landscape and its inhabitants. Some, like J. M. W. Turner, were merely dabbling (a fairy band appears almost as an afterthought near the bottom of his ''Queen Mab's Cave''). Others, like Richard Dadd, a schizophrenic institutionalized after killing his father, found a subject matter well suited to psychedelic extremes of proportion and detail. Dadd's dark, closely observed masterpieces realize the potential of a genre that was for some artists merely an excuse to drape nymphs in gossamer. The best of these paintings belie the insipidity of later, more familiar renderings of fairyland. Like the Victorian era itself, they are far more complicated and ambiguous than is commonly remembered. Sarah Harrison Smith

title: Word & Image; Nuclear Reactions

Like most American reporters and editors, I have been a mostly silent partner in my country's utopian but arrogant diplomacy to limit membership in the nuclear club. We have conferred special status and prestige on nations that know how to blow up the world and let American, British, Russian, Chinese and French officials strut importantly in international forums because they had the bomb. And yet we conspired in the pretense that other nations could not be trusted with atomic arsenals.

He'd pour salad dressing on her lovingly prepared lemon chicken or meatloaf. title: GUN HAPPY
description: Gun-rights forces in Utah are fighting a proposed ban on visitors carrying concealed weapons into, of all places, the grounds of the state mental hospital in Provo. The topic is in the air because Utah loosened its concealed-weapons law in 1995, making it legal for almost anyone (convicted felons are one exception) to pack heat. The change set off a legislative debate, still unresolved, about whether people with permits can be forced to disarm before entering troublesome areas like bars, churches and schools. Elwood P. Powell, chairman of the Utah Shooting Sports Council, admits it makes sense to ban weapons in a few patient wards at the hospital, but he doesn't want regulation going too far. ''Hell, if you can't exercise your right to self-defense,'' he says, ''you are no better off than a Holocaust victim.''

title: With the Spare, Sinewy Grace of an Athlete

The elegance of his work is ascetic as well as esthetic. It has everything to do with integrity and nothing to do with airs. Mr. Vinoly's new Princeton University Stadium, now nearing completion for an official opening in September, would make a great location for a fashion shoot. But the fashions would have to be of a kind worn by those who understand the beauty of service to an ideal.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALFANDRE, DR. JULIAN E.
description: ALFANDRE-Dr. Julian E. June 21, 1940-September 8, 1997. At all times, the abyss created by your tragic death resonates. But, especially at this moment, absent on your birthday and Father's Day, your incisive brilliance, integrity, sagacity, unique wit and boundless love is recalled. We long continuously for that wonderful, infectious laughter you always elicited and the profoundly informed wisdom which so animated your too short life. The world of your treasured offspring in the still early hours of morning, is lived with the inimical pain of missing you. Each day, each small right of passage, victory, celebration, is diminished by this ineffable void. So extraordinarily connected to you, and dependent upon your examplary character and singularity were they. Yet, ever punctuated with deepest pride in their cherished Dad, they are living their lives with enormous courage, benevolence, meritorious works and good humor. Surely, this is your imprimatur, and in your honor. On behalf of Rachel, Jimmy & David, Natalie

title: Copious Chinese Cuisine at Bargain Prices

In fact, most Americans probably sampled their first Chinese food at modest storefront spots like this one. They offered inexpensive flavorful fare tailored to American tastes. Over the years they have supplemented their fried rice, egg rolls, lobster Cantonese, egg foo young and chow mein when challenged by Chinese regional cuisines billed as authentic. More recently, the honest little neighborhood eateries have increasingly found themselves competing with elaborate Chinese palaces with piano players, glittering chandeliers, exotic Asian decor and prices rivaling those at fancy French restaurants.

title: Artistic Route Through Romania

title: A Signal to Teheran?

The offer came in a speech by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright almost two decades after Iran's Islamic revolution took American diplomats hostage and made a breakup with Washington inevitable. Exactly why the Administration decided to make the gesture now was not disclosed. But the United States, stunned by nuclear bomb tests in India and then Pakistan, and losing its foothold on Iraqi sanctions, may have noticed that it has no leverage in Iran, another potential nuclear nation.

We asked retailers and designers to tell us their favorites for fall 1998, then compared them with our own. The results were surprising: never once was there total agreement, and even the instance of two alike out of three was remarkably low. Which just goes to show that there is more than one way to look at what's happening in fashion now, that there is plenty of room for different interests and different points of view.

He neglects to add, however, that as much as those lenders were seduced by Asian markets, they were also seduced by their own greed and appetite for risk. No one forced them to invest in Asia, despite well-known opacity in Asian accounting practices; they could have demanded greater disclosure and contractual safeguards, as lenders often do, or simply put their money in safer (but lower-returning) investments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYNARD, PAUL
description: MAYNARD-Paul. Died on June 10, 1998, age 74. Much loved by family, by colleauges and by generations of students whom he inspired to the same high standards he demanded of himself. At Yale where he studied organ and theory, he was first introduced to early music in Paul Hindemith's legendary collegium. For many years thereafter, he was the keyboard player of the New York Pro Musica, the pioneer American early music ensemble whose many tours and recordings first brought the beauty of this music to audiences world wide. His prize winning solo recordings of French and English harpsicord and organ music were among the achievements of those years. In 1964 he came to Queens College to establish and direct an early music program. Many gifted young musicians who first encountered this music in the Vocal Ensemble and instrumental Collegium under Paul Maynard have carried the vitality and richness of his performing tradition into their own professional lives. In 1970 he took a leave from the college to direct Pro Musica. Among the events of his two years as director were the International Josquin Festival of 1971 (the only American ensemble to take part) and the ''Founding Artists'' series during the Kennedy Center's opening year in which they were the sole early music ensemble. The integrity and sensitivity of his work with the talented professionals of Pro Musica were at the service of the students upon his return to the college, inspiring the student groups to peak after peak of achievement. His own solo harpsicord and organ perfomrmances of Bach as well as his work with the students reflected his intensity, humility and passionate love for all music. His musical credo is best stated in his introduction to the ''Anthology of Early Renaissance Music'' (co-authored with Noah Greenberg): ''The greatest creative musicians of all periods are on the same level and the performance of all of their music deserves the very best we can give.'' He did, and he remains a beacon for all who were fortunate enough to work with him and hear his music making. He is survived by his wife of 28 years, Drora Pershing, two sons, David of Ballston Spa, NY, and Philip of Ridley Park, PA, three step-children, Stephen Pershing of Alexandria, VA, Jonathan Pershing of Kensington, MD, and Ruth Pershing of Chapel Hill, NC, two grandchildren and three stepgrandchildren. A memorial gathering will be held on Saturday, June 27, at 3 PM, at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64 St, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Paul Maynard Scholarship Fund, Aaron Copland School of Music, Queens College, Flushing, NY 11367.

title: Attachment Theory: The Ultimate Experiment

They may have had to undergo many physical procedures, repeated losses, emotional upheavals, as well as the financial drain associated with the treatment of infertility. Often, adoption is seen as the last hope in the struggle to become parents. They may be worried that, after so many failures, they will fail at this as well.

title: THE FAITH IS RIGHT
description: Frustrated by flat church attendance, Anglican priests in Britain are studying game-show and soap-opera techniques to boost their market share. In new one-day seminars offered by the Litchfield diocese, vicars watch TV clips to learn how to make sermons more effective, lively and with-it. (Typical tip: Pounding the lectern is out.) Traditionalists scorn the sold-out seminars, but 40 graduates say they work. ''This is not about gimmicks,'' says Mark East, a vicar in Litchfield, ''it's about making a point of contact.'' East put his training to use a few Sundays ago. Taking a page from ''The Price Is Right,'' he picked parishoners to stroll down the aisle and guess the value of a few household items. Why? ''To get them thinking of the price that God paid on the cross.''

title: con.com
description: Steve Castillo is about as locked-down as they come. An inmate at the Pelican Bay State Prison in Northern California, he has spent the past four years in maximum-security confinement because prison authorities have judged him to be ''a gang associate.'' Graham Noyes, his San Francisco lawyer, thinks the perpetual confinement is a bit much, so he's turning Castillo's plight into a cause. This being the 90's and all, one of his tools is a Web site, Virtual S.H.U. (ncal.verio.com/lazlo), which provides a virtual tour of Pelican Bay's darkest innards. (The home page is pictured below left.) Prison-oriented sites like this are increasingly common; almost always maintained by sympathetic outsiders or prison buffs, they can be serious, silly, rah-rah, grotesque and, of course, scary. Here's a look.

title: All the Town's a Stage
description: THE train south from Wilson Station in Prague last July took a leisurely two and half hours to reach Cesky Budejovice through rolling countryside and rusty, well-gardened stations scattered with poppies, cornflowers and yellow mullein spikes. Before the First World War, this was the Emperor Franz Joseph Railway between Prague and Vienna; but for most of the last 50 years Southern Bohemia was contained on three sides by the Iron Curtain, and on the way to nowhere. Little seems to have changed since the young hero of Hrabal's ''Closely Watched Trains'' (1965) combined sexual opportunism in the stationmaster's office with blowing up Nazi arms convoys near the end of the Second World War. Housing blocks and bad manners in certain hotels aside, there are few immediate signs that a People's Republic has passed this way.

title: FEELING OFF KEY
description: * Today, Ithaca College in upstate New York winds up ''The Healthy Musician,'' a three-day confab for health-care pros who treat musicians' ailments. * A 1713 treatise, ''Diseases of Tradesmen,'' lists afflictions like ''rupture of the groin'' and ''pulsations of the brain.'' * The modern ''Textbook of Performing Arts Medicine'' discusses ''Las Vegas Voice'' (strained vocal cords from working smoky rooms) and ''Fiddler's Neck'' (a skin condition caused by the friction of chinning a violin). * In a survey of 2,212 orchestra players, 39 percent reported psychological problems. Most frequent malady: stage fright. * Information-age musicians face a new peril. ''When we see repetitive stress injury, we have to ask if it's the instrument or something else,'' says Nick Quarrier, director of the Ithaca meeting. Like what? ''The computer.''

As I return to sing with our beloved Chorus tomorrow, to celebrate your life, Gary Miller's final concert, David Friedman's commission in memory of Peter Monette, and the lives of others too soon gone: Mark Fuschetti, Gary Olde, many others. title: BOOKEND; The Passion Artist: Recalling John Hawkes
description: The day after Frank Sinatra died in California at 82, a no less distinctive American voice -- in certain quarters even more prized, though in the nature of things less widely known -- was stilled in Providence, R.I. With the death at 72 of John Hawkes -- fiction writer, fiction mentor and fiction live reader extraordinaire -- we lost one of the steadily brightest (and paradoxically darkest) lights of American letters through our century's second half, a navigation star for scores of apprentice writers however different their own literary course, and as spellbinding a public reader of his own work as I have ever heard. Passion was this writer's subject, even when manifested by nonhuman characters (the narrator-protagonist of his novel ''Sweet William'' is a horse; the deuteragonist of ''The Frog'' is a very French amphibian); impassioned was his manner as author, teacher, reader and friend. He was, to echo another of his titles, truly a Passion Artist: for five decades one of our most original literary imaginations and masterly prose stylists.

title: New Horizons For Frequent Fliers
description: Trans World Airlines has begun a new frequent-flier program, called Aviators, to replace its Frequent Flight Bonus program. Mileage from the old program has been transferred to Aviators. The new program offers benefits based on money spent as well as miles flown, quicker access to higher program levels and changes in award levels. Members are awarded one bonus Aviator mile for each dollar spent on full fares in first class, business or coach. Flights between cities less than 750 miles apart require only 15,000 miles for coach or 30,000 miles for first class. Longer domestic flights cost 25,000 miles for a coach ticket and 40,000 miles for first class. More information: (800) 325-4815.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNOLO, DOMENICA. ''DIMI'' (NEE LEUZZI)
description: DONNOLO - Domenica. ''Dimi'' (nee Leuzzi). Dimi was born on June 9, 1919 and died June 20, 1998 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of the late Vincent. She is survived by her sister Immaculate Mandragona, four daughters: Suzanne, Christine, Claire and Felicia Shuff and her husband Marc: and two sons Philip and Daniel and his wife Candace. Her four grandsons: Michael and Joshua Donnolo and Ian and Adam Shuff were her special love and brought much joy to her life and were a special comfort to her illness. She was a graduate of Pratt Institute and a loyal volunteer at the Metropolitan Opera Guild Education Office. Her friends will remember her countless performances in musicals at St. Ephrem's Players Guild, the Ridge Chorale and with The Jeff Samaha Singers. For years she had a one woman musical revue and sang for seniors in nursing homes throughout Brooklyn. She was an artist and took great pleasure in painting the flower of remembrance-the pansy. We will miss her every day for the rest of our lives but will cherish our memories of a mother, grandmother, sister, aunt and friend of selfless, abounding love and devotion. Reposing at Ralph Aievoli & Son, Inc., 1275 65 Street, Brooklyn, New York. Visiting hours Sunday, 7-9:30 PM, Monday and Tuesday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday St. Ephrem R.C. Church, 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers donations in Domenica's name to BRAVO or the Brooklyn Hospice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZKOPF, FRANCINE. DR.
description: SCHWARZKOPF-Francine. Dr. Francine Schwarzkopf, chemist, 83, of esophageal cancer, at home, peacefully on Friday, June 19, surrounded by those she loved. Born in 1915 in Vienna, she spent most of her youth in Antwerp, Belgium, until her family fled to America in 1940. She and her husband, the late Dr. Otto Schwarzkopf founded the Schwarzkopf Microanalytic Laboratories in Queens in 1953. She was a 50 year member of the American Chemical Society. Francine enjoyed hiking, the fine arts, and spending time with family and friends. She touched the lives of all who knew her and will be greatly missed. She leaves a son, Marcel Daniel Schwarzkopf of Yardley, PA, and his wife, Amy Lowenstein; a sister-in-law, Mary Freeman Blankstein of St. Petersburg, FL, widow of Francine's twin brother Joseph; a niece, Margo Blankstein Muller of NYC; a nephew, Philip Blankstein of Kennesaw, GA, his wife Tracie and their four children; a niece, Anne-Marie Levine and her son David Levine of NYC; and cousins Dr. Vera Price of San Francisco, Evan Price and his wife Amy and son Will of San Francisco, and Dr. Lisa Price of Cambridge, MA. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers friends may donate to her favorite charities: Choice in Dying and the International Rescue Committee.

title: Ex-Lawmaker Says Charges Won't Slow His Election Bid
description: While an indictment might typically signal the downturn of a politician's prospects, Pedro Espada Jr., a former State Senator from the Bronx, says that his campaign to regain his old job in Albany will only be energized following his arraignment on charges of Medicaid fraud.

description: TAYLOR-Telford. A memorial gathering will be held on Friday, June 26, at 3 PM, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

title: Political Briefing; An Endorsement, Of Sorts, for Gore
description: Even as the dues-spending fight was ending in Nevada, it was picking up momentum in New Jersey, where last Monday Mr. Gore showed up in Elizabeth to help labor leaders raise money for the struggle. But that's not the news from that event.

title: 2 Big Clients Consolidate Accounts
description: Two advertisers have consolidated accounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINDECKER, ERNA
description: STEINDECKER - Erna. Adored matriarch of the Steindecker family, sister to the late Robert and Theo E. Salomon, Els Bendheim, and Professor Herman P. Salomon.

title: I.B.M. Begins Making Fast, Cheaper Chip
description: Without fanfare but with potentially far-reaching significance for the semiconductor industry, I.B.M. has begun the industry's first large-scale production of a type of chip that may reduce prices and improve performance and portability for cellular phones and other wireless communications devices.

title: Hospital Labor Pact Tightens Job Security
description: Thirty-five private hospitals and nursing homes in New York City reached a tentative agreement yesterday that provides far-reaching job-security provisions for 50,000 workers despite wrenching upheaval in the city's health-care industry.

title: Errant Bounces and Serendipity Give Germany a Draw
description: When it ended, with Jurgen Klinsmann on a stretcher and Lothar Matthaus in the record books, the Germans were the happier team. Not because they had beaten Yugoslavia, but because they had done what German teams have always done: rousted themselves from a funk and rallied, scoring two goals in the final 16 minutes today to salvage a 2-2 draw and preserve their share of first place in Group F.

title: Inconsistency at I.N.S. Complicates Refugees' Asylum Quest
description: They are both students from Congo who fled to the United States, certain they would have been killed in the political turmoil at home. Bakam Mimpongo, 21, was caught at Kennedy International Airport, trying to enter with fake papers. Bisinwa Borumbi, 22, stowed away in a cargo ship and was seized in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: Compressed Data; Copyright Treaty Raises Concerns on Research
description: Legislation intended to strengthen international copyright protections in cyberspace has run into an unexpected enemy: some of the nation's best computer security experts.

title: It's a Major Metal Band, and Even the Furniture Isn't Safe
description: It's hard not to resort to metaphor in describing a Slayer concert, because what you're confronted with is both kinetically massive and uniform, blank, detailless.

title: Janzen Roars Back To Edge Stewart
description: A few moments after realizing he had won the United States Open today, Lee Janzen put a towel over his face and wept. The last four days at the Olympic Club had been a roller coaster of emotions, grueling and relentlessly challenging, played on a course so difficult that nobody finished under par.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRINKHOUSE, MICHAEL F.
description: DRINKHOUSE-Michael F. Died Tuesday, June 16, 1998, at Summit Rehabilitation Center in Monroe, LA, after a prolonged illness. He was born in NYC, the son of Eve and Julius. Michael was self employed from an early age, when he opend the Picadilly Spa restaurant. He then went on to open and operate a chain of restaurants in New York which included the Fleetwood Grill, Churchills South and North, The Frontenac, the Olde Homestead, the Blue Ribbon, Shines, the Assembly, Manny Wolf's and others. Michael was an avid horseman all of his life. He establsihed the Somerset Farms Racing and Breeding entity in Mt. Kisco, NY, and continued to breed and race thoroughbred horses all over Amreica after his move to Ocala, FL, in 1977. In addition to his restaurant and horse racing activities, he was a real estate developer and investor, as well as a financial analyst, consultant and advisor. Michael is survived by his wife Sally, a daughter Eva Marie, a son Ronald Stephen, and by three grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. A son John died in Vietnam serving his country. There will be a private memorial service at Lake Bruin, LA, for the family.

title: Caramoor Conductors Put Bel Canto First
description: In a profession in which ego plays a significant and undoubtedly essential role, the conductors at the Caramoor International Music Festival here seem a surprisingly selfless lot.

title: Forget the Tape Measure, Indians Need an Odometer
description: Chad Curtis is the star in all the videotaped highlights of tonight's Yankees game. He will be the guy at the bottom of your screen, leaping futilely at home runs screaming 30 or 40 feet over his head, over and over and over again.

title: Who Is That Marked Man? It's Sampras at Wimbledon
description: They have put down new outdoor carpeting on the Center Court since Pete Sampras won the Wimbledon title last year, an ambitious bit of redecorating not tried here for the past 30 years. For Sampras and for Wimbledon, change is rarely a welcome commodity. But since he will be getting a toehold on the usual rugged blend of natural rye and fescue that he has trampled all four times he has won this championship, the innovation should not prove too unsettling for Sampras. He has more pressing problems to deal with than the greenery.

title: Corrections
description: A Man in the News article on Friday about Richard C. Holbrooke, who was appointed United Nations delegate, misspelled the surname of Britain's delegate. He is Sir John Weston, not Westin.

title: Zimbabwe Squatters: Land Claims on White Farms
description: ''Be very careful, please,'' said Richard Magorimbo Madzorera, crouching low to slip through the sharp, rusty fence without touching it. ''We don't want to damage the farmer's wire.''

title: New Suitor May Bid
description: J. Bruce Llewellyn, chairman of the Philadelphia Coca-Cola Bottling Co., plans to make a bid to buy the National Football League's Minnesota Vikings.

title: State Teaching Quietly in Religious Schools
description: A year after the United States Supreme Court ruled that public school teachers in New York City could hold remedial and other supplementary classes inside religious schools, rather than in oversize vans off the school grounds, school and union officials say there have been no complaints from those teachers.

title: Jousting in Iran
description: In a blow to Iran's reform-minded President, Mohammed Khatami, the Parliament voted to dismiss a close ally from the Cabinet. Page A9.

title: It Might Have Been Saturday Afternoon at the Orpheum
description: It seemed perfectly proper for American Ballet Theater to present ''Le Corsaire'' on Saturday afternoon, for this new production of a 19th-century classic resembles the old serials that used to be shown at movie matinees on Saturdays. Like those films, it is one adventure after another. Since this is a ballet, though, the adventures are punctuated by virtuosic variations, and the thrills took place at the Metropolitan Opera House and not at a movie palace.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the releases of major economic indicators this week.

title: Stop Playing by China's Rules
description: In defending his China policy, President Clinton says America faces a stark choice: engage China as his Administration has done or isolate it. But that is a false choice.

title: A Lament Preserved, but Accompanied by Parody
description: Revisiting works of the past can be a thankless job for a composer, because listeners tend to regard an earlier composer's thought process as sacrosanct and a later composer's additions as intrusive. It was not always thus: Mozart reorchestrated Handel's ''Messiah,'' and Liszt and Busoni expanded on works by Schubert and Bach without causing an outcry. But Mahler's Bach orchestrations raise eyebrows, and earnest completions of scores by Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert and Mahler have generated reams of critical debate (or, in some cases, yawns of indifference).

title: A Kinder, Smarter Tax System for Kansas
description: The new way that taxes are collected in this Midwest state capital may offer taxpayers everywhere a glimpse of what the future may be like in dealing with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: As Centenarians Thrive, 'Old' Is Redefined
description: Lynn Adler, an advocate for the aging who enjoys the company of people who have made it to their 100th birthday, gave a party recently for her centenarian friends. Nine of them showed up.

title: Church Blesses Union of 2 Men in Adoption Case
description: In an Episcopal ceremony symbolically set on Father's Day, two gay men whose lawsuit paved the way for other unmarried couples in the state to adopt children jointly were united today in what the church called a holy union as friends, relatives and television cameras looked on.

title: Compressed Data; Small Start-Up to Offer First HDTV Broadcasts
description: After years of high-profile planning for high-definition television, the first regularly scheduled national HDTV broadcasts will be by a company with a decidedly low profile.

description: EVANS-Marybeth G. (nee Kelly) of N.Y., N.Y. Formerly of Washington, D.C. On June 20, 1998. Beloved wife of Michael E. Evans. Loving daughter of John J. and Rosemary (nee Tepedino) Kelly of Dumont, N.J. Dear sister of Lisa G. McNamara of North Caldwell, N.J. and Julieann G. Kelly of Dumont, N.J. Church, Central Avenue, North Caldwell, N.J., where at 10:00 AM a Mass of Christian Burial will be offered. Friends may call Monday, 7-9 PM, Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Alfred Palca, 78, Screenwriter Blacklisted After Basketball Film
description: Alfred Palca, a blacklisted writer whose film ''Go, Man, Go!,'' about the Harlem Globetrotters, became a classic among basketball fans, died on Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Absolutely Unfabulous but Muddling Through
description: In the past year, viewers have been identifying with people made of construction paper, colored ink or computer keystrokes. Fox's hit ''King of the Hill,'' about a suburban family in Texas, and Comedy Central's ''South Park,'' the M-rated phenomenon about grammar-school boys, have made animated comedies a major prime-time trend and have shown how easy it is to see ourselves in cartoons. With so little realism on the surface, animated characters can sneak up and irreverently hit plenty of nerves. The dunderheaded fathers of ''The Simpsons'' or ''King of the Hill,'' much less the boys of ''South Park,'' would never get on the air if they were breathing actors.

title: A commercial code revision tries to take on the task of legislating the Internet.
description: IN a climate where any regulation of the Internet in its commercial infancy is considered high treason, many law experts are dismayed at the tidal wave of restrictive legislation -- governing everything from software filters to digital copyrights and public domain information -- being drafted and enacted by states and the Federal Government.

title: A Happy Marriage of Mime and Movement
description: The beauty of the performance given by Susan Jaffe, Ethan Stiefel and Andrei Dokukin in ''Giselle'' on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House lay in their attention to Romantic ballet's first principle.

title: Edward Eliscu, 96, Songwriter and Playwright
description: Edward Eliscu, a lyricist who wrote the words for ''Without a Song,'' ''Orchids in the Moonlight'' and dozens of other popular songs, died on Thursday at his home in Newtown, Conn. He was 96.

title: Reinterpreted Chinese Opera Remains Grounded by Politics
description: A battle over artistic freedom, and over local turf, appears likely to spoil plans by a Chinese opera troupe to perform a special rendition of the classic ''Peony Pavilion'' as a centerpiece of the Lincoln Center Festival next month.

description: To all the world, this would seem to be Representative Christopher Shays's moment in the sun.

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Starr Aide Seen as 'Attack Dog' or Tough Lawyer
description: After her testimony in the grand jury room, Gloria Cabe was left with a memory of such prosecutorial zeal in the performance of Jackie M. Bennett Jr. that four years later she still finds it chilling for its unfettered aggressiveness.

title: London Journal; William, a Shy Conquerer, Pursued by Groupies
description: He is a fan of pop music and fast food, an avid swimmer and tennis player, he prefers action adventure books to novels and even likes the swallow tail coat, starched collar and striped trousers he must wear at Eton.

title: Florida Keys Restricting Use Of Noisy Personal Watercraft
description: Surrounded by a forest of West Indian hardwood and exquisitely blue waterways, Juanita Greene's efficiency cottage in Key Largo seemed an idyllic place in which to pass her retirement years.

description: ZINDER-Samuel. The Commmunity Synagogue of Port Washington, NY, mourns the loss of its longtime esteemed member and past officer. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Maxine, his children and grandchildren. Jane M. Broido, President Jeffrey K. Salkin, Rabbi

description: To the Editor:

title: Skip Away Better
description: Skip Away, who developed a slight swelling in his legs over the weekend, was reported to be much improved yesterday. But his trainer, Sonny Hine, said he would wait until his star horse worked out tomorrow before clearing him to travel to California to race Silver Charm and Gentlemen next Sunday in the $1million Hollywood Gold Cup.

title: Political Briefing; POLITICAL CALENDAR
description: Primaries will be held in Utah tomorrow and there will also be primary runoffs in Mississippi, New Mexico and South Carolina.

title: Stop Squabbling, Pope Tells Austria's Divided Bishops as He Ends His Visit
description: Seeking to restore discipline to Austria's deeply divided Roman Catholic Church, Pope John Paul II instructed the country's bishops today to stop their public bickering. Without unity, the Pope warned, ''the teachings of Christ dissolves into many individual voices,'' adding, ''In the place of harmony comes noisy confusion.''

title: Japanese Yen Weakens a Bit Against Dollar, but Stocks Rise
description: Just two days before President Clinton departs for China, financial markets in Asia reacted cautiously today to the weekend's political and diplomatic efforts to stabilize the Japanese yen and other Asia currencies.

title: Adventure of Pirates, Pashas and Virtuosos
description: Too many cooks usually spoil the bouillabaisse and borscht. But ''Le Corsaire,'' an adventure yarn of a 19th-century French-Russian ballet, turned into an overnight hit for American Ballet Theater, thanks to a felicitous gaggle of producers and coaches from two continents.

title: Contract Offers Job Security For 50,000 In Hospitals
description: Thirty-five private hospitals and nursing homes in New York City reached a tentative agreement yesterday that provides far-reaching job-security provisions for 50,000 workers despite the wrenching upheaval in the city's health-care industry.

title: Montgomerie Upbeat Despite Difficult Week
description: It was a disappointing tournament for Colin Montgomerie, who was heckled by fans throughout the week. Montgomerie finished at 11 over par, though he did shoot a 69 today. However, Montgomerie had another unpleasant exchange with a fan during today's round.

title: Consultants Blame Media For Problems of Politicians
description: As politicians moan about interminable fund-raising demands to pay for brutal attack commercials, consultants who run many of their campaigns and make many of the advertisements say it is not their fault, and they suggest that if anyone is to blame for public despair about the system, it is the news media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, JAMES GAMBLE
description: ROGERS-James Gamble. Age 89. Died peacefully at home June 19, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Henrietta O. Rogers. Devoted father of Patsy Rogers, Kathie McQuarrie, James G. Rogers III and father-in-law of Maureen Rogers. Adored grandfather of Michael and Mollie McQuarrie, Amy, Kate and Jamie Rogers. Rogers Whiffenpoof Leadership Award (Yale University) c/o Jim Rogers, 54 Rosebrook Rd., New Canaan, CT 06840.

title: Remembering McCartney
description: A memorial service for Linda McCartney, the wife of Sir Paul McCartney, the former Beatle, is scheduled for 8:30 tonight in the nave of Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 120th Street in Morningside Heights. Ms. McCartney, who grew up in Scarsdale, N.Y., died on April 17 at age 56.

title: A Late Bloom
description: Warm reports about Prince Charles have begun to blossom on both sides of the Atlantic this summer. Some -- little green fingerlings of fact, like his contribution of a watercolor he painted of Hong Kong harbor to an auction at the New York Academy of Art -- gently suggest a creative spirit, a charitable heart. But there are big flattering images of princely purpose ripening into color, too.

title: Media Talk; If NBC Sells Videos, Diller Could Be a Logical Partner
description: Will Barry Diller start making infomercials for NBC? Now that NBC has begun -- or at least tiptoed -- into the business of selling videocassettes directly to consumers, it might want an outside company to produce them.

title: Koven Takes Third
description: The defending single sculls world champion Jamie Koven finished third in the petite final of the men's single sculls competition yesterday at the world cup stop in Hazewinkel, Belgium.

title: Political Briefing; Both Sides Blinked In Nevada Showdown
description: There's a new twist in the struggle over whether unions should be able to spend members' dues on political causes without first getting written permission.

title: Cayne's Team Leads Nickell's At International Team Trials
description: The final of the International Team Trials began yesterday in Tunica, Miss., and after 30 deals of a scheduled 120, the team headed by Jim Cayne of Manhattan led by 21 imps against a group headed by Nick Nickell of Manhattan. At stake is the right to be one of two teams to represent the United States in the next Bermuda Bowl world championship, scheduled in Bermuda in January 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGNANI, LILLIAN
description: MAGNANI-Lillian. Died June 19, 1998 in Sidney, NY. She was born in NYC to Silvio and Delibra Bochetti. She is survived by Peter and Dorothy Magnani and Rita and Morgan Magnani Daly. Contributions made to Lighthouse Inc., Low Vision Clinic, 111 E. 59 St., NY NY 10022. For more information, call C.H. Landers, Sidney, NY.

title: Coming Series Have That October Feel
description: Two weeks ago, even two days ago, many of the Yankees played down the games they would play in the next seven days: four against the Atlanta Braves, who have the best record in the National League, and three against the Mets. But on the eve of the coming series, emotions have begun to surface.

title: Jackson Tells Bulls He Won't Return as Coach
description: Phil Jackson has officially told the Chicago Bulls that he will step down as head coach, the first step in what could become the dismantling of the National Basketball Association's reigning dynasty.

title: Liberty's Aggressive Play Wins Over Utah
description: The first time that Kym Hampton took the ball to the basket, determined to challenge the Utah Starzz's 7-foot-2-inch center, Margo Dydek, Hampton admitted she was as frightened and curious to see the result as the 15,754 fans at Madison Square Garden.

title: Echoes of El Salvador in Colombia
description: Washington's growing involvement in a brutal Latin American guerrilla war echoes the opening stages of American intervention in the conflict in El Salvador in the 1980's. Diana Jean Schemo and Tim Golden reported in The Times earlier this month that much of the aid the Pentagon is giving Colombia's military to fight cocaine is being used instead to fight guerrillas. American special-forces trainers now work in Colombia, teaching the military such skills as jungle maneuvering and psychological operations. While the level of support is far below American aid to the Salvadoran military in the 1980's, the Administration is unwisely considering an increase.

title: Enmity Past, U.S. Meets Iran And Suffers Bitter 2-1 Defeat
description: The Iranian players shook hands with the Americans before tonight's game, handed them white flowers symbolizing peace and even posed together for a picture. But friendship extended only so far. There was a soccer game to win, and not only did Iran prevail, 2-1, but this historic victory also knocked the United States out of contention in the World Cup.

title: Gun Industry and Mayors, Sometimes at Odds, Become Partners Against Crime
description: Against the vivid backdrop of recent fatal school shootings, elected officials across the country for the first time are coordinating efforts, sometimes with unlikely partners, to reduce the incidents of gun violence.

title: Another Mets Victory, But Little to Celebrate
description: Reggie Jackson was a player who knew how to stir up a laugh with his one-liners as well as he could shake up a game with his bat. He once demonstrated that agility with one quip after a game in which he struck out four consecutive times, but won it with a grand slam in his final at-bat.

title: Desormeaux Wins
description: The Queen's Plate at Woodbine, Canada's premier race, was won yesterday by Archers Bay, ridden by Kent Desormeaux, who also won the Kentucky Derby in May aboard Real Quiet. The 3-year-old colt, trained by Todd Pletcher, outran the favorite, Brite Adam., who had defeated him in the Plate Trial three weeks ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEITZER MARSHALL, IRENE
description: SEITZER MARSHALL-Irene. Beloved wife of Joseph Marshall, mother of two loving children, Carol Seitzer and Glenn Marron, and proud grandmother of Dylan Marron. Funeral service Monday, 1:45. For information call I. J. Morris, Dix Hills, 516-499-6060.

title: Iraq Insists It's Being Candid With U.N. Arms Inspectors
description: Iraq has criticized a United Nations report that said it is still hiding details about its program to develop weapons of mass destruction.

title: Man Accused of Killing 2 Others in Robberies
description: Manhattan prosecutors have charged a Brazilian man who was living in New York with killing two men in separate robberies last year.

title: Arch Communications Pursues Paging Rival
description: Arch Communications Group, the third-largest United States paging company, said today that it was in talks to buy a rival, the Mobilemedia Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy protection more than a year ago.

title: Amid Dodger Talk, Mets Fall to Mussina
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine was not around long enough to see Brian McRae and Butch Huskey rifle back-to-back, second-inning home runs off Mike Mussina at Camden Yards tonight. Or, for that matter, to see the Orioles respond with shots by Rafael Palmeiro and Cal Ripken Jr. off Bobby Jones on their way to a 7-2 victory over the Mets in which Mussina retired the last 22 Mets he faced.
