description: To the Editor:

title: 'Ballyhoo' to Close
description: ''The Last Night of Ballyhoo,'' a romantic comedy by Alfred Uhry, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street, Manhattan. The play, directed by Ron Lagomarsino and starring Kelly Bishop, Peter Michael Goetz and Joanne Camp, will have run for 23 previews and 557 regular performances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZPATRICK, ALAN RUSH
description: FITZPATRICK-Alan Rush, June 20, 1998 of Stamford, CT. Husband of Nancy Fitzpatrick and his first wife Edith Gleason Fitzpatrick. Father of Anne Gleason Fitzpatrick and Lisa Jennifer Fitzpatrick. Father in law of Christian Pittack. Also survived by two nieces. Memorial service at the Bedford Presbyterian Church, Bedford, N.Y., Tuesday, June 23 at 2PM. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MARA, JOHN M.
description: O'MARA-John M. of Norwood, NJ, formerly of Leonia, NJ, died Friday, June 19th. He was married to Elisabeth O. O'Mara for 54 years. John had four children, Kathleen of Modesto, CA, Patricia Adair of New Canaan, CT, Michael of Nantucket, MA, and Elisabeth Sutter of Milbrae, CA. He also had eight grandchildren. He graduated from Holy Cross College in 1936, attended Harvard Law School and graduated from Boston College Law School. After starting his career as a Special Agent in the F.B.I., he became chairman of the anti-crime commission in New York City. Subsequently he went to work for Webb and Knapp as a vice president of real estate. In 1966 he became Vice President of New York University in charge of real estate holdings. He retired in 1984. Donations in his memory may be sent to the John M. O'Mara Scholarship at New York University, Washington Sq. So. NY NY

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN RESUMES DECLINE. The yen fell 1.5 percent after Japan failed to propose dramatic new economic stimulants during a weekend meeting of the richest industrialized nations. The dollar rose to 138.16 yen in New York from 136.10.

title: GTECH MAY GO PRIVATE THROUGH A LEVERAGED BUYOUT
description: The Gtech Holdings Corporation, a supplier of lottery products, said yesterday that it might go private, through a leveraged buyout, in an effort to increase its shareholder value. The company also said that it was considering increasing its debt, expanding its share-buyback program and making acquisitions while concentrating on its main gaming and entertainment business. Gtech, based in West Greenwich, R.I., reported yesterday that for the first quarter, which ended on May 30, it earned $18.6 million, or 45 cents a diluted share, compared with $19.3 million, or 46 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONOWITZ, MAURICE H.
description: KRONOWITZ-Maurice H. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Wonderful father of Susan and Leonard Lyon and Ellen Kronowitz. Proud grandfather of Eric, Giles and Liz. Service Wednesday 1:45 PM at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Review/Fashion; The Long Season Called Resort
description: Now that summer is here, it's too late to buy summer clothes. Anyone with a yen for a pair of white pants had to shop for them while the weather was cold. Tough luck if you've waited until now. Go into just about any fashion store in June, and you'll find the remnants of warm-weather clothes that have already been marked down to make room for the first wave of fall styles.

title: Bay View Moves to Delay PSB Acquisition
description: The Bay View Capital Corporation, a California savings and loan institution, delayed its $153 million acquisition of the PSB Lending Corporation after learning that new Federal rules may prohibit the transaction.

title: By Design; Keeping a Cool Head
description: For summer, hairstyles should be no fuss, easy and casual, to withstand heat and humidity, especially if you spend a lot of time outdoors. Hair that's long, and of one length, can be pulled back into a pony tail or pinned into a French twist. Short hair dries quickly and bares the neck to breezes, winning it fans this summer like Marla Maples of the formerly long blond tresses.

title: SOFTWARE SELLERS TO BE LINKED AS STERLING BUYS SYNON
description: Sterling Software Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Synon Inc. for $79 million in stock. Sterling Software, based in Dallas, provides software and services for applications management, systems management and Federal systems. It had revenue of $489 million in the year that ended on Sept. 30. Synon, based in Larkspur, Calif., provides AS/400 application development products. It had revenue of $79 million in 1997. Shares of Sterling Software were up $1.3125 yesterday at $27.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BACHMANN, EMILE
description: BACHMANN-Emile. Although one year gone, you live ever in my heart. All my love, your daughter Karen.

Funeral services at 1 p.m. Wednesday, June 24, at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons. title: The Good Guys Muff It
description: Who deserves blame for the Senate's decision to jettison the anti-smoking bill, at least for this year? When the legislation was tabled last week, President Clinton pointed at the tobacco companies and their advertising blitz. But at least part of the fault lies with the anti-smoking lobby, which overreached in its punitive demands.

title: Humorless Film Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Serial Rapist Sought For Attacks in 2 Counties
description: A serial rapist displaying a badge has been attacking women at gunpoint with increasing frequency and violence in Camden and Burlington Counties, authorities said yesterday.

title: North Korea Sub Is Snagged Off South
description: SEOUL  A North Korean midget submarine was snared in the nets of a fishing boat in South Korean waters and was towed into port by the South Korean Navy on Monday in an incident that could complicate efforts to improve relations between the two Koreas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERENBERG, ROSE
description: BERENBERG-Rose. Died May 18, 1998. Loving mother of Barry; cherished grandmother of Jon & James. Shiva was held by son.

title: Town's Fish Logo Becomes A Battleground on Religion
description: Eight years ago, on a whim, Marilyn Shexsnayder entered the contest to design a logo for her hometown. She was a stockbroker, not an artist. But using her colored pencils and her computer she drew an outstretched hand, a family of four in silhouette, and, to portray the centrality of religion in this old railroad town with more than 25 churches and about 8,000 people, she sketched the simple fish that she had regarded from childhood as a universal symbol of faith.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the appointment of a former Russian official to negotiate with the fund misspelled his surname at two points in some copies. He is Anatoly B. Chubais, not Chubias.

title: 7 Strokes Off the Lead After 3 Holes, Janzen Shows His Mettle in Last Round
description: For the second time in his career, and in admirable fashion, Lee Janzen displayed the qualities it takes to win a United States Open.

title: G.M. to Expand Investment In Building Trucks in China
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would invest $100 million in a joint venture with a Chinese company to make pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles in northeastern China.

title: Man in the News: Andres Pastrana; 'Stoolpigeon' to President
description: Four years ago Andres Pastrana could not walk into a movie theater here without facing a torrent of insults, the most frequent of which was ''stoolpigeon.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, ELI
description: GOTTLIEB-Eli, died on June 20, 1998. Beloved husband of Roslyn, devoted father of Larry (Mindy) and Marcee Knee (Ken) and adored grandfather of Matthew, Jared, Samara, David, Keith and Aaron. Services were held Monday, June 22, 1998. Shiva being observed at his home.

title: Pulsipher Rejoins Mets and Takes Seat in Bullpen
description: Bill Pulsipher awoke this morning expecting to pitch in Pawtucket, R.I., tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLON, OTTO
description: ALLON-Otto. It is with heartfelt sorrow that we note the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Otto Allon. Otto was of that rare breed of master surgeons who excelled brilliantly in his specialty while living life to the fullest. His friendship and sense of humor will be missed by all who had the good fortune to have known him. Our heart goes out to his wife Clara, his son Daniel, and his grandsons. Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Berson Dr. and Mrs. Max Felton

title: Scientists are Disputing The Fate of the Grizzly
description: A NEW report by two respected wildlife biologists warns that the number of grizzly bears in and around Yellowstone National Park may be much lower than previous estimates.

title: Apartheid Inquiry Will Hear Widow of Mozambique's President
description: Graca Machel, the widow of President Samora Machel of Mozambique and now President Nelson Mandela's companion, is to testify on Tuesday about the circumstances surrounding her husband's death in 1986, officials of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission said today. She is to testify behind closed doors.

title: Science Watch; A Study in Contradictions
description: Contradictions, at least of the intellectual kind, are better tolerated by Chinese than by Americans, according to a study by Kaiping Peng, a former Beijing scholar who is now a psychologist at the University of California at Berkeley. In a family conflict, Chinese are more likely to urge disputing parties to agree, without apportionment of blame, whereas Americans tend first to decide which party is right and then insist the other capitulate.

title: Schumer Racing D'Amato for Campaign Cash
description: During his nearly two decades in Washington, Representative Charles E. Schumer has become one of the most unblushingly tenacious fund-raisers in politics. He has built a roster of wealthy Wall Streeters, courted and cajoled the faithful in Brooklyn and beyond, and spent hours on the phone seeking donors with a well-buffed sales pitch. Now his investment is paying off.

title: Protesting Big Shadow at Grand Central
description: Sighs do matter.

title: Three Faces of the Ferry
description: Where else in the city can weary commuters rest, tourists sightsee and local people sit and think, cooled by the breeze? The Staten Island Ferry has been going back and forth from the tip of Manhattan to St. George for 188 years, carrying Wall Street lawyers, homeless people, poets like the late Allen Ginsberg, who included it in ''Howl,'' and musicians, who are barred from playing but still try to sneak in a few tunes on weekends.

title: Legislators and Whitman Agree on Budget
description: Republican legislative leaders and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman agreed on the broad outlines of a new $18.2 billion state budget today that would increase spending by more than $1 billion for public schools, state colleges, open space preservation and a handful of other programs.

title: Science Watch; The Evolutionary Scale
description: Those scales on the dinosaur's hide may have metamorphosed into feathers, as evolution, with its customary economy in making old structures serve new ends, crafted the bird. But from what existing structures did evolution create something so special as the scales on a butterfly's wing?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROEN, IRENE STERN
description: KROEN-Irene Stern. On Saturday, June 20, 1998. Mother of Marian and Sheryl. Sister of Doris Levine. Mother-in-law of Peter Hirschfeld.

title: Seoul Seizes Suspected Sub From North
description: South Korean military forces seized a suspected North Korean submarine on Monday night after the sub became entangled in fishing nets in South Korean waters, immediately raising tensions between the countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCHENBAUM, SIDNEY
description: KIRSCHENBAUM - Sidney. Be loved husband, father, grandfather, great grandfather. Services at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, 10A.M. today.

title: Richter and Gilmour Among Players Available for Draft
description: When the Nashville Predators stock their expansion team with a draft of National Hockey League players on Friday, they can start with veteran stars such as Mike Richter of the Rangers, Doug Gilmour of the Devils and Brett Hull of the St. Louis Blues.

title: WHITE HOUSE ADDS BROAD PROTECTION IN MEDICARE RULES
description: The Clinton Administration ordered sweeping protections for Medicare beneficiaries today, requiring health plans to guarantee access to specialists, to keep medical records confidential and to provide interpreters when needed.

title: Elevating Vox Pop In Fact And Tune
description: ''People on the hill, can you hear this?'' cried Eddie Vedder as the strains of a Pearl Jam ballad settled in the Montana evening air during the first show of the band's summer tour here. ''If you can hear this, stand up and move.''

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Saturday about the confirmation of Kathleen M. Pes ile as a trustee of the City University of New York misstated the number of trustees. It is 17, not 15.

title: Miller Brewing Sues 2 Former Agencies
description: The Miller Brewing Company has sued two former agencies, Bates USA and Zenith Media Services, both of New York.

title: Britain Lowers Gay Consent Age, Creating Single Standard
description: The British House of Commons voted overwhelmingly tonight to lower the age of consent for homosexuals to 16, easily overcoming objections from leaders of the Church of England.

title: Dodgers' Shake-Up Brings Reemergence of Lasorda
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers, noted for continuity when owned by the O'Malley family, have continued their ferocious makeover following the takeover by the Fox Group, firing General Manager Fred Claire and Manager Bill Russell.

title: Cache of Chemicals Is Found in Bronx House
description: Police officers responding to a report of a burglary in the Bronx yesterday afternoon discovered several boxes of rare chemicals, some of which were radioactive and flammable, the authorities said.

title: It's a Three-Legged Race to Decipher the Human Genome
description: NO one would ever invite the human genome to a party. It is long winded, highly repetitive and frustratingly full of intriguing stories that it has no idea how to tell in an organized way.

title: Clinton Is Pressed On 'One China' Policy
description: China's Foreign Minister today called on President Clinton to make a public statement during his state visit this week restating American opposition to any move by Taiwan toward independence.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Narrow the Uses of Forfeiture
description: The Supreme Court struck today for the first time against the Federal Government's aggressive use of forfeiture, ruling that a forfeiture intended as punishment is unconstitutional if the amount seized is ''grossly disproportional'' to the gravity of the offense.

title: 50 Years Later, Lanza Booms Forth; The Mystique of a Tenor Better Known in Movies Than in Opera
description: A month before Hollywood discovered him, diverting his singing career and the course of music history, a 26-year-old tenor named Mario Lanza stopped here for an open-air concert with his newly formed Bel Canto Trio. Showered with bravos and raucous whistles, Lanza was pronounced a sensation, ''born to sing.''

title: People
description: * Melissa Pordy was named senior vice president and print services director at Zenith Media Services, a joint venture of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C. and Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., succeeding Amy Andrews, who left. Ms. Pordy had been vice president and associate media director at Hill, Holliday/Altschiller, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: West Bank Arabs Scrape By as They Lose Housing
description: On a sunbaked hill outside Hebron, a Palestinian family lives in a tent beside the rubble of its house, which has been demolished for the third time, after Israeli authorities denied the family a building permit.

title: 5 Badly Burned As Blast Rips Queens Shop
description: A volatile chemical that officials said was improperly stored in an illegal furniture factory in Queens exploded yesterday, leaving seven people injured, including at least two teen-agers who may have been working there in violation of Federal regulations, the authorities said.

description: All year, legislators, lobbyists and advocates complained about how little seemed to be getting done here.

But Gene Budig, the American League president, intends to hold the hearing sooner, according to others familiar with the discussions.

title: Cleaning Up Construction
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has moved with impressive success against organized crime in industries that few experts thought could be cleaned up. He now wants to eliminate bribery, shakedowns and bid-rigging in New York City's construction industry by setting up a powerful new commission to deny licenses to unworthy companies. This is a noble objective, but his task may be much more difficult than his earlier challenges to the Fulton Fish Market and the commercial garbage haulers.

title: Foreign Affairs; What Goes Around . . .
description: The folks in Dasna village, north of New Delhi, have never heard of Alan Greenspan. They do not own shares on the Bombay Stock Exchange. And they are confident India will do just fine, thank you, despite the economic sanctions imposed by the U.S. on it and Pakistan for their nuclear tests.

description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Approves Bill To Mandate Mediation
description: In an effort to encourage families to resolve disputes outside the courtroom, the State Senate approved a bill yesterday that would require people seeking divorce, child support or custody of children to meet with a mediator before clashing in court.

title: Driver's Licenses Could Become Smart Cards
description: Standard driver's licenses would be replaced by an electronic card that could store information including insurance records and credit card accounts under a bill approved by committees in the Senate and Assembly yesterday.

title: Charter Panel Ponders Nonpartisan Voting
description: While the City Hall spotlight has focused primarily on the budgetary battle between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council in recent weeks, a dozen private citizens selected by the Mayor have been quietly developing a series of proposals that could transform New York City government and politics.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cisco Systems Is Giving Up Partner Hunt
description: Cisco Systems Inc., acknowledging that it has tried and failed to forge partnerships with Lucent Technologies Inc. and Northern Telecom of Canada, now intends to continue alone in defending its leadership in the increasingly competitive market for advanced data networking equipment.

title: The Dow Extends Its Losses As It Ends the Day Off 1.74
description: A 50-point gain in the Dow Jones industrial average evaporated in the last 30 minutes of trading yesterday, pushing the gauge lower and extending its losses for a third consecutive session.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPMAN, JEAN
description: LIPMAN-Jean. The Board of Trustees and professional staff of the Museum of American Folk Art record with profound sorrow the death of their esteemed friend and colleague, Jean Lipman, who served with distinction as a Trustee of the Museum during its formative years and provided wise and discerning counsel as Trustee Emerita for more than twenty years. One of the last of the pioneering collector-scholars who gave shape to the emerging field of American folk art at mid-century, she helped establish its importance to American life and culture through her many published essays and books. With her late husband, Howard, she was a major donor to the Museum's permanent collection and will be remembered by us with gratitude and affection for her principled commitment to excellence, the generosity of her spirit and the warmth of her encouragement. To Peter and Beverly Lipman and the rest of Jean Lipman's family goes this sincere expression of our deepest sympathy. Ralph O. Esmerian, President, Board of Trustees Gerard C. Wertkin, Director

description: The tradition of unaccompanied part singing (that is, singing by groups of four to six vocalists, one per part) has a rich history, stretching from Renaissance madrigalists to barbershop quartets. Accompanied singing groups, even brilliant ones like the Andrews Sisters or the Beach Boys, represent an offshoot of the pure thing.

title: Moog Decides To Call It Quits
description: Canadiens goalie Andy Moog retired yesterday, walking away from a contract that would have paid him $1.5 million next season. The 38-year-old Moog became Montreal's top goalie in the playoffs, helping the Canadiens gain a first-round upset victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins before losing the conference semifinals to the Buffalo Sabres.

description: The Navy is not asking for a new helicopter carrier, but Trent Lott wants it to have one.

title: Foreigners to Be Allowed Stake in Korea Telecom
description: South Korea said yesterday that it would sell as much as a third of the Korea Telecom Company, its biggest telephone company, to foreign investors in a share sale that could raise $2.4 billion to help finance the country's economic recovery. The Government will allow foreign investors to buy as much as 33 percent of the state-run Korea Telecom in July or August, several months earlier than planned, said Cho Kyung Shik, an official at the Information and Communications Ministry.

title: Restaurant Bars Included In New Smoking Ban

description: The European Union agreed today to approve Worldcom Inc.'s proposed $43.7 billion purchase of the MCI Communications Corporation, the No. 2 United States long-distance company, after MCI said it would sell its Internet business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARELLI, MARIA NAROBE
description: MARELLI-Maria Narobe, 93, of Lawrence, Kansas, died on Saturday, June 20, 1998 at the home of her caregiver in Lecompton, Kansas. She had lived in Lawrence since 1980 after moving from New York City. Ms. Marelli was born on May 5, 1905 in Trieste, Italy. She attended the King and Emperor Franz Joseph School in Austria and the Sorbonne in Paris, France, where she studied sociology, psychology and nursing. She was fluent in several languages. In 1939 she became a governess in Genoa, Italy. During WWII, she worked for the Red Cross translating official edicts and papers for the government. Ms. Marelli moved to America in 1948 and became a U.S. citizen in 1957. She worked as a governess for several families until her retirement, at which time she travelled extensively around the world. She continued her education at the University of Kansas studying art history, religion, philosophy, political science, French Literature, and Russian. She tutored many University of Kansas students in French and Italian. Although Ms. Marelli never had children of her own, she leaves behind loved ones, including Cristina Biaggi and Marina Harrison, Palisades, New York; Gianni Biaggi, Lausanne Switzerland; Purnima Dillsaver, Harriman, New York; Shirley Dinkel and Jennifer Jones, Lecompton, Kansas; two nephews in Yugoslavia and many friends around the world. Private services are planned and the family suggest memorial contributions to the Haskell Indian Nation University Endowment Association which may be made c/o Warren McElwain Mortuary, 120 West 13th Street, Lawrence, Kansas 66044.

title: Science Watch; Eyes See, Brain Decides

Those incoming images are deconstructed at the retina, extensively processed and then reconstituted somewhere in the brain. Psychologists at the Institute of Neurology in London have explored one of the higher-level stages of processing by sitting subjects in a brain-scanning machine and showing different images to the left and right eye in such a way that neither eye could see the image shown to the other.

title: New Agency Monitors Japan's Finance Industry
description: Japan's new financial watchdog agency started operations yesterday, taking over supervision of the nation's banks, brokerage firms and insurance companies. The Government set up the agency amid public criticism that previous regulators had abused their control of financial institutions.

title: Prime Minister Urges Peru To Pardon U.S. Woman
description: The new Prime Minister of Peru has startled United States officials by publicly saying that Lori Helene Berenson, a New Yorker jailed for life on charges of terrorism, should be freed from her cell and expelled.

title: Banning Guns Won't Stop Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: The Zapruder Film
description: In August, Abraham Zapruder's 26-second home movie recording of the assassination of President Kennedy will become government property, in accordance with an Assassination Records Collection Act. First, however, there is the matter of compensating the Zapruder family. (Mr. Zapruder died in 1970.) The actual 8-millimeter film has been in the National Archives since 1978, and there it will stay. What is being negotiated now is the sale of the exclusive rights the Zapruder family maintains. They would like $18.5 million. The Justice Department would like to spend much less.

title: Judge Allows Hoffa to Stay in Union Race
description: A Federal judge yesterday upheld a Federal monitor's decision in April not to disqualify James P. Hoffa from running for the teamsters' presidency, although the judge criticized some of Mr. Hoffa's behavior in the 1996 election as ''disturbing.''

title: Accounts
description: * Seattle Seahawks to Publicis, Seattle, part of Publicis S.A., to handle advertising for the National Football League team, previously handled in-house. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: A Skirt From Petrus, Curtains From Clicquot
description: WINE has always been the first love of Valentino Monticello, a sommelier at Harry's Bar in London. But art and music follow soon after, and Mr. Monticello has found a way to combine these passions. Using wine labels, he makes collages that depict opera scenes involving wine.

title: Arbitration Rules Relaxed At Brokers
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that brokerage industry employees would no longer be required to arbitrate claims of employment discrimination before industry panels.

title: GAINS TAX BREAK APPEARS AT HAND
description: Congressional leaders agreed today on a plan to give investors a break on capital gains taxes, attaching the measure to an overhaul of the Internal Revenue Service that appears headed toward speedy final passage.

title: DRAKE'S, THE MAKER OF YODELS AND RING DINGS, TO BE SOLD
description: The Interstate Bakeries Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Drake's, the maker of Yodels and Ring Dings. The seller is Culinar Inc., a baking concern based in Montreal. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Drake's, based in Wayne, N.J., makes packaged cakes and has annual sales of about $115 million. Interstate, based in Kansas City, Mo., makes and sells breads, rolls, snack cakes and sweet goods under the Wonder, Hostess and other brand names. For the nine months ended on March 7, it had sales of $2.5 billion.

title: Stockbroker Admits He Stole From Clients
description: A Monmouth County stockbroker admitted yesterday to stealing $2 million from a client who is in her 80's to pay for a lavish lifestyle and to finance what turned out to be bad investments, the authorities said.

title: SALOMON BUYS MORGAN'S AUSTRALIAN INVESTMENT UNIT
description: Salomon Smith Barney Inc. has become the latest United States investment bank to increase its operations in the rapidly expanding fund-management industry in Australia, buying the local investment operations of J. P. Morgan & Company. Salomon Smith Barney, a unit of Travelers Group, did not disclose what it paid for J. P. Morgan Investment Management Australia Ltd., which has about $4.8 billion in funds under management. Australia is the fifth-largest pension fund market in the world. Salomon Smith Barney estimates the local investment market will grow by 22 percent a year for the next four years, then slow to 16 percent, fueled by compulsory retirement contribution laws introduced in 1992.

title: AT&T IS NEAR DEAL FOR NO. 2 COMPANY IN CABLE TV IN U.S.
description: The AT&T Corporation is close to an agreement to acquire the nation's second-largest cable television operator in a deal that could sharply expand AT&T's ability to provide Internet access and local telephone service.

title: Chinese Agog at Clinton, a Hero (Like Nixon)
description: In his global vision, it seems, Bill Clinton ranks right up there with Richard M. Nixon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAUGH, ALEXANDER P.
description: WAUGH-Alexander P. Of Chatham, New Jersey, at home on June 21, 1998. Husband of Jean Martin Waugh, father of the late Joseph M. Waugh, Margaret Waugh Howie, Alexander P. Waugh, Jr. and Catherine Waugh Gilbert, seven grandchildren and one great-grandson. Memorial Mass at St. Mary's Abbey Church (Delbarton School), 230 Mendham Road, Morristown, NJ 07960-5089 on Saturday, June 28, 1998 at 10:30AM. Visiting in the Farmer Funeral Home, 45 Roseland Avenue, (at Eagle Rock Avenue) Roseland, NJ on Thursday 7-9PM and Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, kindly consider donations to St. Mary's Abbey Library Fund.

title: Steinbrenner Focuses On October, Not Mets
description: George Steinbrenner, the ultracompetitive principal owner of the Yankees, said yesterday that his team's three-game series against the Mets next weekend really wasn't that big a deal.

title: Italian Brio and Memorable Service in the Village
description: SAUTEED spinach with garlic sounds like a simple dish, yet much can go wrong. The greens, if handled improperly, can be gritty or watery. The cook must be quick and deft, removing the spinach from the fire as it wilts, before it becomes sodden and acrid. And the garlic must not be overcooked, or its bitterness will ruin everything. Then, the spinach must be served immediately, at its peak.

title: MANAGERS OF INDIANA TRUCKING COMPANY TO LEAD BUYOUT
description: Celadon Group Inc., a trucking company that specializes in shipments between the United States, Canada and Mexico, agreed yesterday to a management-led buyout for cash, stock and assumed debt. Odyssey Investment Partners L.L.C., a new $680 million investment fund based in New York, will pay Celadon shareholders $20 a share in cash. It will join with Celadon managers in buying the trucking company, based in Indianapolis, and taking it private. Shares of Celadon rose $4.3125, to $18.9375, in Nasdaq trading. The cash portion of the transaction totals $154 million based on the company's 7.7 million outstanding shares. The remainder of the purchase price will include assumed debt and the retirement of outstanding stock options.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATERS, NORMAN D.
description: WATERS-Norman D. On June 23, 1998, of Rye, NY, beloved husband of Elaine L. Loving father of Elizabeth W. Haron, and L. Sanford Waters. Dear grandfather of five grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Funeral service will be held Thursday 10 A.M. at The WIlliam H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye, New York 10580. Interment Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Pssst, Says Prosecutor to Reporter; I'm All Ears, Is the Reply
description: It is one of the least talked about corners of journalism: the relationship of reporters and their prosecution sources. But the debate in recent days over how much and what kind of information the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr gave reporters about his investigation of President Clinton has put an uncomfortable spotlight on the ties between journalists and prosecutors, ties that often lead to information and sometimes to misinformation.

title: Corrections
description: A report in Sunday Styles this week about the wedding of Pamela Ann Giddon and Roger Mitchell Freedman referred incorrectly to the bride's father, A. Arthur Giddon. He is not ''the late''; a retired lawyer, he lives in West Hartford, Conn., with his wife, Harriet Giddon.

title: Maureen O'Sullivan, Movie Tarzan's 'Jane,' Dies at 87
description: Maureen O'Sullivan, a leading Hollywood actress in the 1930's and early 40's best known for playing Jane to Johnny Weissmuller's Tarzan in the series of popular jungle adventure movies, died yesterday at the Scottsdale Memorial Hospital in Scottsdale, Ariz. She was 87. Ms. O'Sullivan, who was the mother of the actress Mia Farrow, had homes in Phoenix and Grantham, N.H.

title: California Tries to Tame an Italian Grape
description: EUROPEAN winemakers like to say that grape vines must suffer to make good wine. Which may explain why, in northern Italy, the best sangiovese grapes are the result of a protracted struggle between the vines and the hardscrabble Tuscan hills.

title: House Bill Protects Internet From New Taxes
description: Hoping to throw cold water on the frenzy to tax the Internet, the House today passed a bill that would bar state and local governments from imposing new Internet taxes for three years.

title: Woolmark Is Name For 2 Wool Groups
description: Two organizations that promote and market wool apparel -- the International Wool Secretariat in Melbourne, Australia, and its American unit, the Wool Bureau in New York -- are changing their names to the Woolmark Company. The Woolmark symbol identifies clothing made from 100 percent wool. Advertising about the name change is scheduled to appear in September issues of magazines; it will be created by Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO in London.

title: If Only We All Spoke Two Languages
description: Ever since I came to settle in the United States 18 years ago, I have hoped that this nation might someday become truly multilingual, with everyone here speaking at least two languages.

title: There's Still No Vanilla In a Finley Encounter
description: Much attention has been given to Karen Finley's body, or at least to what she does with it in public places. In her new performance piece, ''The Return of the Chocolate-Smeared Woman,'' now at the Flea Theater in TriBeCa, every inch of that body is visible. And yes, it is again lathered up in some chocolatey substance (you can tell that it's chocolate by the smell), a not-so-sentimental nod to the routine that made her a figure of angry debate on the floor of the United States Senate eight years ago.

title: Billion here, billion there, and soon your estimate on 1998 U.S. ad spending reaches $200.3 billion.
description: REMEMBER the disk jockeys on the old Top 40 radio stations who shouted, ''And the hits just keep on coming!''? Well, the rosy predictions for domestic advertising spending just keep on coming from a leading industry forecaster.

title: Hundley to Take Next Step
description: Todd Hundley will bat in a game situation on Wednesday night for the first time since last September, the Mets said today. Hundley, who since last September has had reconstructive elbow surgery and arthroscopic shoulder surgery, will play in Port St. Lucie, Fla. He took batting practice there yesterday for the second consecutive day, the final prerequisite to a rehabilitation stint. Manager Bobby Valentine said he expected Hundley to play for both Class A St. Lucie and for Class AAA Norfolk before he rejoins the Mets within the next three weeks. General Manager Steve Phillips said Hundley's ''swinging health is not an issue.''

title: Johnson's 27 Lead Liberty In Victory Over Rockers
description: For parts of last night's game at Madison Square Garden, it seemed as if Vickie Johnson were the only player on the floor for the Liberty. In the lane or way outside, Johnson was everywhere last night while her teammates were nowhere to be found.

title: Break on Estate Taxes
description: A powerful Congressman has used his influence to keep a tax break for the wealthy that no one had intended to be in the law in the first place. The beneficiaries are the heirs of a few hundred people each year who leave estates worth more than $17 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHANZER, MARTIN
description: SCHANZER-Martin. Past President of the Dental Laboratory Association of New York. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Devoted father of Joanne and Leonard Krauss, Michael and Leanne Schanzer. Adored grandfather of Teri, Eric and Dana Feuerstein, Justin, Jared and Logan. Devoted brother to Barbara Carney. Services at Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., 12 noon, Wednesday.

title: King Defense Tries To Get Evidence
description: The defense in Don King's Federal insurance fraud retrial sought to prove yesterday that the Lloyd's of London syndicate that paid the promoter $671,000 to settle a claim for a canceled Julio Cesar Chavez fight in 1991 had offered to swap evidence that could acquit King's company for the same $671,000.

title: 3 Radio Free Asia Journalists Are Barred : Clinton Assails China Over Rescinded Visas
description: WASHINGTON  President Bill Clinton, seeking to fend off pressure from congressional critics of his China visit, denounced Beijing on Tuesday for denying visas to three journalists who had planned to cover the trip for Radio Free Asia, which is funded by the U.S. government. He said the move was "highly objectionable."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, RUTH
description: FRIEDMAN-Ruth. On June 23, 1998. Beloved mother of Linda Rice. Cherished aunt, great aunt and friend to many. We will all miss her. Services Wednesday, 9:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Eat, Drink, Aunt, Niece
description: IN the photograph on the jacket of ''Every Grain of Rice'' (Clarkson N. Potter, $25), Annabel Low and Ellen Blonder resemble the striking daughters in ''Eat, Drink, Man, Woman,'' Ang Lee's film about the supreme relevance of food in Chinese life. Their new book, a family memoir and cookbook, makes the comparison even stronger.

title: So Emotional, So Thoughtful
description: The singer Ruben Blades, who performed as part of the JVC Jazz Festival at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, has had one of the odder careers in music, moving from the position of office boy at Fania records in New York to Panamanian presidential candidate. Along the way he made some of New York salsa's most important records, as a singer with Willie Colon and, on his own, recordings that took on the Americas as their subject and delved into politics and culture with long narrative works that made pop music profoundly literate. Where most pop and dance music articulate little and suggest plenty, Mr. Blades articulated everything and suggested it as well.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Quick Wit? How About Hyperquick?
description: Reno makes you glad to be a New Yorker. She has had it with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who ''thinks he's in Athens and he's fighting Troy.'' (If you want the place where you live and work to be calmer and cleaner, Reno suggests, move to Wisconsin.) She is thankful that so many Muslims live in the city, because alternate-side-of-the-street parking is now suspended on their holidays. She's totally baffled by the supposed appeal of spending weekends at a country house. (If everybody goes to bed at 9, how much fun can they really be having?) She wishes Donald Trump would move to Malibu, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINSKY, RUTH
description: MINSKY - Ruth. The Village Temple mourns the passing of one of our long-time members, Mrs. Ruth Minsky, 95 years old. With her husband, Morton, a Founding Member of the Temple, and one of the famous Minsky Brothers, Ruth was an active and beloved congregant. She will be remembered for her vibrance and elegance. Funeral Monday June 29th at The Village Temple, 33 East 12th Street, NYC, at 12 noon. Rabbi Dennis N. Math Joan Brancaccio, Sheryl Harawitz, Co-Presidents

title: Mayors Ask for Right To Impose New Taxes
description: A coalition of urban mayors told a state commission yesterday that cities should be able to impose new taxes to help reduce property taxes.

title: Spanish Ex-Premier Denies Role in Terror
description: Former Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez repeated under oath in the Supreme Court here today what he has said for years: he never ordered his Socialist Government to conduct illegal counter-terrorism against armed Basque separatists in the 1980's.

title: Crew Forbids Use of School By Hasidim
description: Amid a brewing controversy with religious and racial undertones, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has overturned a decision by a school district official that would have turned a Queens elementary school into a temporary hotel Friday night for an estimated 1,000 Hasidic Jews.

title: Playing Out the Draft
description: Today's N.B.A. draft is slim on impact players, long on people you've never heard of and doesn't have a consensus No. 1 pick. Here's a look at what could happen among the lottery picks. By MIKE WISE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOKMAN, GLORIA FRANKENTHALER ROSS
description: BOOKMAN-Gloria Frankenthaler Ross. The board and staff of the National Museum of the American Indian, Smithsonian Institution, note with sadness the passing of tapestry designer Gloria F. Ross Bookman. Her dedicated work and enthusiastic support of Navajo people will be remembered always.

title: City Lacks Laws to Curb Illegal Manufacturing, Official Says
description: A day after an explosion and fire destroyed what officials called an illegal storefront furniture shop in Queens and badly burned five people, the city's Buildings Commissioner said yesterday that hundreds of illegal manufacturers were operating in New York, but that city officials lacked the power to close them quickly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANFORD, WILLIAM B.
description: SANFORD-William B. Of Bronxville, New York. On June 21, 1998. Husband of Dorothy Day Sanford. Father of William F. and Thomas D. Sanford, and Nancy S. Pierson. Brother of Lela Bremer and Philip H. Sanford. Memorial service at the Saint Paul Chapel, Columbia University, New York City, on Wednesday, July 22, 4PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Boy Scouts of America, Westchester-Putnam Council, 41 Saw Mill River Rd, Hawthorne, NY 10532 or Columbia College, New York, New York 10027.

title: Kalisz Journal; Playground Has Plenty of Ghosts to Go Around
description: A well-worn school playground, where hard sports have left more dirt than grass but that was once the site of a venerated Jewish cemetery, has prompted a bitter dispute between Jewish organizations and the Polish authorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, HERBERT L.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Herbert L. Beloved husband of Jane. Devoted father of Marilyn & Damon and Elisheva. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Corey, Glenn, Elon and Danielle. Loving great grandfather of Jessalyn, Theo Jane, Anna, & Justin. Dear brother of Bernard & Carol. Services at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street & Amsterdam Avenue, New York City, Wednesday, 12:15 PM.

title: An Empire Is Built, the Cipriani Way
description: IT was about 4 P.M. Giuseppe Cipriani had been on the go since midmorning and had not eaten any lunch. When he spied a plate of bread and salami in a kitchen at 55 Wall Street, a landmark building his company is converting into a hotel, he asked for it to be sent to his office. He munched eagerly, gulping cups of dense espresso, and asked for another serving.

title: Japan Tries to Halt Selloff in Bank's Shares
description: Japan's Finance Minister tried to calm the financial markets today and avert a further selloff in the shares of a large weak bank, as the Government moved a step closer toward establishing a system to help restructure failed banks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, TELFORD
description: TAYLOR-Telford. A memorial gathering will be held on Friday, June 26, at 3 PM, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

title: Starwood Hotels Fails to Alter Bill
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts has failed to win changes it sought in legislation that would limit the tax advantage it enjoys, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Bill Archer, said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORVIN, CHARLES (GEZA)
description: KORVIN-Charles (Geza). Hungarian born actor of New York City and Klosters, Switzerland. Died Thursday, June 18, 1998, age 90. Husband of Natasha, father of Eddie. A memorial tribute will be held this fall. Donations may be made to Amnesty International.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MARA, JOHN M.
description: O'MARA-John M. The Trustees of the Heckscher Foundation for Children mourn the passing of our beloved Board Member and friend. A long-time champion of children, his wisdom and sensitivity contributed greatly to a generation of New York City children. We shall miss him. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Betty, and his family. Virginia Sloane, President The Heckscher Foundation for Children

Memorial Service Friday, June 26 at 11 AM at Riverside Church in New York.

title: Honors
description: * American Advertising Federation, Washington, elected Richard J. Schade, vice president for Central and National field sales at NBC, Chicago, part of the General Electric Co., as chairman. Mr. Schade, who had been vice chairman, succeeds Philip Guarascio, vice president and general manager for marketing and advertising at the North American operations of the General Motors Corp., Warren, Mich. In addition, Janet L. Robinson, president and general manager at The New York Times, New York, was elected vice chairwoman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOCH, FRANK PETER III
description: ZOCH-Frank Peter III. Died suddenly of a heart attack on June 22, 1998 in San Antonio, Texas. Peter was born in Corpus Christi, Texas, June 3, 1942. Peter was preceded in death by his parents. Peter's father, Frank Peter Zoch, Jr., of Corpus Christi, Texas, was cofounder of Sedco Oil Company, a world wide oil drilling company which was later merged into Schlumberger Ltd. Peter's mother, Elizabeth Kercheville Zoch, a native of San Antonio, was very active in civic and charitable organizations in Corpus Christi. Peter graduated from the Tabor Academy in Marion, Mass. and attended the University of Texas. Peter began his business career in New York City in investment banking. He was a co-founder and President of Netter International, a diversified holding company. He remained in New York for 27 years and returned to live in the hill country of Texas in 1991. After returning, Peter divided his time between his home at Cedar Lake Ranch and Prade Ranch in Mountain Home, Texas & San Antonio, Texas. After returning to Texas, he continued his business and investment activities and recently founded Microstone Automated Building Systems, L.L.C. Peter is survived by his wife of 29 years, Marion (Mimi) Chandler Zoch; his children, Laura Frances Zoch, Rhonda Zoch Given, Frank Peter Zoch, IV, Patricia Zoch Smith, Elizabeth Chandler Zoch and Frank Morgan Zoch; his sons-in-law, Christopher Lee Given and Ryan Scott Smith; his grandchild, Grace Faye Given; his sisters, Frances Zoch Fulton and Patricia Zoch Ferguson; a brother - in - law, Joseph R. Fulton; and his sister-inlaw, Joyce Chandler King and her husband, Wayne Hamilton King, and his sister-in-law, Judy Kimble Chandler. Peter was involved in many civic organizations and charitable organizations, including The Young Presidents Organization, The World President's Organization; he was a member of the board of the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Hospital of Houston, Texas; the Board of Schreiner, College, Kerville, Texas; and the Board of the Berkshire School, Sheffield, Massachusetts. He was a former director of the Boston Celtics. He was a member of the Clove Valley Rod & Gun Club, New York; the Racquet Club of New York City, San Antonio Country Club, the Argyle Club, the Order of the Alamo, and Riverhill Country Club in Kerrville. He was a member of the First United Methodist Church in Kerville, Texas. Visitation will be at Grimes Funeral Home, 400 Earl Garrett, Kerrville, Texas, beginning at 4:00 P.M. on June 24, 1998. Services will be held at the First United Methodist Church at 11:00 A.M., on June 26, 1998. Interment will follow the ceremony at Sunset Cemetery in Mountain Home, Texas. Pallbearers are: Robert P. Ross, Walter A. Carey, Stephen Karp, David Edwards, Gus T. Canales & Stephen J. Kleberg. Honorary Pallbearers are: Richard M. Kleberg, III, Bronson VanWyck, Jean Pierre Bigotte, T. Gibbs Kane, Hank Grant, Rick Perry, Henry Parrish, Robert Donnalley, Ronald Strackbein, Barrett Townsend, Victor Neuhaus, Ahmed Hashmi, Michael Hughes, Steven Ables, Gary W. Smith, Richard F. Rogers, William Carl, Edward Hartline, Alan Lucke, Paul Dupee, David Dunn & Julian Pizana. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Hospital of Houston, the Winston School, San Antonio, a school for children with learning differences; or the Berkshire School of Sheffield, Massachusetts. For further information Peter Loring, 1101 McCullough, San Antonio, Texas, 210-227-8221.

description: MGM Grand Inc. plans to buy back up to 12 million shares, or about 20 percent of its common stock. The stock jumped $5.5625 a share today, to $32.1875. The company will acquire the shares through two tender offers of up to 6 million each. The first will start July 2 and expire July 31.

description: It is impolitic for Catholics to speculate too openly about who could be the man to succeed Pope John Paul II. But as the 78-year-old Pope's health declines, Vatican watchers cannot resist studying the roster of cardinals for the few who could be tapped.

title: TECHNE TO ACQUIRE RESEARCH-PRODUCTS UNIT OF GENZYME
description: The Techne Corporation will buy the Genzyme Corporation's research-products unit for about $65.5 million in cash, stock and royalties, making it the world's largest supplier of certain proteins and antibodies for biomedical research. Techne, based in Minneapolis, will pay Genzyme $24.8 million in cash, $17 million in stock and an estimated $23.7 million in royalties over five years, the companies said. The research-products business of Genzyme, based in Cambridge, Mass., has a line of more than 350 synthetic proteins, antibodies and research kits and will add more than 4,000 customers to Techne's 8,000. The business, a part of Genzyme's diagnostics-products unit, had about $15 million in sales last year, compared with Techne's revenue of $63.5 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about President Clinton's preparations for his trip to China included an incorrect interpretation of remarks by Robert A. Kapp, president of the United States-China Business Council. While Mr. Kapp said foreign visitors to China should be sensitive to their hosts, he did not link the observation to President Bush's 1989 visit to Beijing, in which the White House invited a prominent dissident to a banquet.

title: Kingfisher Takes Stake In French Retailer
description: he British retailer Kingfisher P.L.C. agreed yesterday to acquire a controlling interest in the French retailer BUT S.A. for $:103 million, or $172.3 million. The London-based Kingfisher, which operates retail chains in Britain and Europe, will increase its holdings in BUT to 62 percent from 26 percent -- an interest acquired mostly from the family of the company's founder, Andre Venturini, in 1996.

title: France Or U.S.? Now It's A Hard Choice
description: IT used to be that if you wanted to become a chef, you were expected to go to cooking school in Paris. There you learned classic technique, the organization of the French kitchen and discipline under the critical eye of French instructors. Words like souffle, galantine and fricassee trickled into your vocabulary, a chef's knife became an extension of your hand.

title: 100 Works for City Ballet's 50th
description: The New York City Ballet will mark its 50th anniversary with a yearlong celebration during which 100 ballets will be performed, Peter Martins, the company's ballet master in chief, announced at a news conference yesterday at the New York State Theater.

title: Political Memo; The Mussolini Of Manhattan? Giuliani Grins And Bears It
description: In satire and in protest, the Mayor of the City of New York is again being likened to some of the vilest figures in history. But this time Rudolph W. Giuliani is learning to accept it.

title: Bacteria Sicken 8 in Georgia And 4,000 in Chicago Area
description: At least eight children who played in a wading pool in northwest Atlanta were stricken by a potentially lethal strain of E. coli bacteria, state and local health officials reported today.

title: Excerpts From Appeals Court Ruling on Microsoft
description: Following are excerpts from the decision by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia overturning the injunction against the Microsoft Corporation. Judges A. Raymond Randolph and Stephen F. Williams found for the company; Judge Patricia M. Wald dissented in part.

title: Chinese Cracking Down On the Pirating of CD's
description: Accustomed to putting its best face forward for an important guest, China is cleaning itself up for President Clinton's arrival on Thursday.

title: Kellogg, in Slump, Names New President
description: The Kellogg Company today chose a 23-year veteran, Carlos Gutierrez, as its president and chief operating officer, positioning him to take over the world's largest cereal company as it struggles to stem a slide in market share.

title: Braves Have Figured Out How to Beat Hernandez
description: Orlando Hernandez lingered on the Yankees' bench after he was knocked out in the fourth inning last night, angry at himself. ''This shouldn't be happening,'' he hissed to catcher Jorge Posada.

title: Hingis Begins Title Defense by Beating the Rain
description: No sooner had Wimbledon's ever-harried officials chased away the field mouse that took up residence in a corner of Center Court on opening day than they had to deal with a more familiar enemy on Day 2: rain. Unlike the rodent, the rain refused to decamp, and the result was that only 14 of today's 70 matches were completed, 15 were left unfinished tonight, and Martina Hingis had to begin her title defense with the court, and her Wimbledon-white outfit, coated by a fine mist.

title: A Disputed Call Helps Chile End Frustration
description: When Chile had survived a contentious 1-1 draw with Cameroon today and advanced to the second round of the World Cup, its players removed their jerseys and tossed them into the crowd, shedding their shirts and 36 years of unfulfillment and humiliation in soccer's world championship.

description: A Mediterranean Accent For Wall Streeters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, MARION PENDLETON
description: PRATT-Marion Pendleton. On June 22, 1998 in Stamford, CT. We deeply mourn the loss of our mother, mother-in-law and grandmother. We will miss her wisdom, love and humor. James H. and Louise V. North Susan P. Bradley (nee Pratt) Hollister, Benjamin and Christopher North Kaolin Davis

description: Parakeet on Park

title: China Cancels 3 Visas Issued To Radio Free Asia Reporters
description: On the eve of a state visit the White House has billed as a chance to encourage greater openness by the Chinese Government, China has canceled visas for three journalists from Radio Free Asia who had planned to cover President Clinton's trip this week.

title: CBS and Molinari Going Separate Ways
description: It was either CBS News's experiment with creating an anchorwoman from a Congresswoman, or Susan Molinari's experiment with transforming herself from a Republican Party star into a television star, but from either perspective, the experiment failed.

title: MEDPARTNERS TO EXPLORE SALE OF MANAGEMENT BUSINESS
description: Medpartners Inc. has retained Salomon Smith Barney to explore the sale of its Team Health operations, one of the nation's largest providers of hospital-based physician management services. Team Health produces more than $690 million in annual revenue. Team Health, which became part of Medpartners as a result of a merger with PPSI in 1996, manages physicians and other health care professionals. Team Health is affiliated with more than 2,100 emergency physicians and 140 radiologists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, RALPH S.
description: BROWN-Ralph S. The Dean and Faculty of Yale Law School mark with great sadness the passing of Ralph S. Brown, Simeon E. Baldwin Professor Emeritus of Law and Frank E. Taplin Professorial Lecturer, long time friend, and beloved colleague. He will be warmly remembered for over four decades of devoted teaching and service at Yale Law School; and for his scholarly contributions to the law. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. A memorial service for Professor Brown will be held at Yale on Saturday, Sept. 12, 1998 at 4:00 P.M. Memorial contributions may be made to The Ralph S. Brown Fund for Student Needs at The Yale Law School Fund, PO Box 208341, New Haven, CT. 06520-8341. Anthony T. Kronman, Dean Yale Law School

title: Social Scientist Is Nominated To Be Director of Census Bureau
description: President Clinton today nominated Kenneth Prewitt, a soft-spoken academic and former divinity student, to be Director of the Census Bureau, an agency that is being buffeted by partisan disputes over its plans for conducting the 2000 Census.

title: Huddy Joins Staff As Assistant Coach
description: Charlie Huddy, a defenseman who was on five Stanley Cup champions with the Edmonton Oilers during his 17-year career in the National Hockey League, was named an assistant coach with the Rangers yesterday.

title: Preschoolers Gain From Public-Private Tie
description: To the Editor:

title: On Camera Again, After 7 Years; Documentary's Subjects Now Speak Out as Teen-Agers
description: Lucy, voluble as always, is at boarding school these days; the pressure to become a Princetonian seems irresistible. Alexis is pretty serious about becoming a marine biologist. And Luis, no longer homeless but charismatic as ever, has left the Latin Kings gang in Milwaukee but will soon star as a gang member onstage in a Victory Memorial Church production.

title: Scientists Say Fossils From China Prove Dinosaur-to-Bird Link
description: Paleontologists examining fossils from animals bearing feathers think they have found the most persuasive evidence yet that birds evolved directly from small, meat-eating dinosaurs.

title: Peru's Leader Rejects Call to Release American
description: President Alberto K. Fujimori stood firm today against pardoning an American woman serving a life sentence for treason in Peru, despite calls for clemency or a new trial from his Prime Minister.

title: South Korea Joblessness Triples in 6 Months
description: South Korea said yesterday that a record 1.49 million people were out of work last month, triple the number six months ago, raising concern that renewed labor unrest could disrupt plans to shut down nonviable companies and prolong the country's recession. The jobless rate rose to 6.9 percent in May from 6.7 percent in April, equaling a 15-year high set in February 1983, the National Statistical Office said.

Marmon of Bethesda, Md; Nan Sabel of Waltham, Mass.; and Elise Raymond of East Hampton. Adored grandmother of Matthew and Zachary Sabel; Elizabeth Marmon and Annabelle Raymond. title: Skip Away Set to Compete in the Gold Cup
description: Skip Away's forelegs remained free of swelling after he worked out yesterday at Belmont Park, clearing the way for the champion 5-year-old horse to fly to California tomorrow to race Silver Charm and Gentlemen in Sunday's $1 million Hollywood Gold Cup.

title: THE FINE PRINT: A clear look at the 1997 tax cut; A Mistake Prevails, as Certainly as Death and Taxes
description: The tax code is chock full of benefits for the wealthy. Most of them were put in on purpose. But last year, one got in accidentally.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They send us here. They send us there. We don't know where we are going to go next.''

title: Moody's Is Pessimistic On Philippine Banking
description: The Philippine banking industry ''has now entered a difficult period of cyclical economic downturn,'' Moody's Investors Service said yesterday in a report, warning that asset quality and profitability would continue to deteriorate in the short term. Moody's said that after a ratings review of Philippine banks earlier this year that resulted in two downgrades of Philippine banks' credit ratings, it was maintaining its ''negative'' view on the sector.

title: Despite a 7-1 Prospect, the Draft Offers Slim Pickings
description: Three years ago, while sitting in his London apartment, Michael Olowokandi opened up the Peterson Guide to American Colleges and Universities, turned to the letter ''P'' and dialed the telephone number of the first school his finger came upon.

title: A Secret U.S. Device Missing After '96 China Rocket Crash
description: A secret encoded circuit board containing sensitive technology was missing from the wreckage of an American satellite aboard a Chinese rocket that exploded in 1996, and American officials said today that they suspected that the Chinese authorities took it.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Small Stocks Still Trailing In the Dust Of Bulls' Run
description: A rising tide lifts only big boats.

title: Jerusalem's Boundaries
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has chosen an awkward moment to redraw the boundaries of Jerusalem, one of the most sensitive issues in the Mideast peace talks. The point of those talks is to resolve disputed issues by negotiation and compromise, not by one side's acting on its own.

description: The Italian Parliament voted in favor of NATO expansion today, averting a political showdown that was the most serious threat to the Government's stability to date.

title: O'Donnell Is Out, and the Jets Are Talking to Testaverde
description: Neil O'Donnell's brief, bizarre run as quarterback of the Jets has ended. His agent, Leigh Steinberg, came to that conclusion tonight after receiving an unexpected phone call from Coach Bill Parcells.

title: Clinton's Challenge: Time to Deal With Asian Crisis
description: For a year the Clinton Administration has tried to minimize its direct involvement in Asia's economic crisis, pulling strings at the International Monetary Fund, sending out envoys to cajole foreign leaders and avoiding the lead role Washington took when it saved Mexico from economic implosion in 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENSTEIN, JOSEPH S.

title: Correction: A Map of Jerusalem
description: A map of Jerusalem on Monday, with an article about an Israeli Cabinet decision to expand the city, located parts of the 1949-67 Israeli-Jordanian border incorrectly. (A southwestern suburb of Jerusalem, Tsur Hadassah, is north of the border, not south.) Here is a corrected map.

title: Parts of Africa Showing H.I.V. In 1 in 4 Adults
description: In certain areas of Africa, one in four adults is infected with the virus that causes AIDS, and around the world the disease now rivals the greatest epidemics of history, according to a United Nations report issued today.

title: Amateur Division: The First Course
description: A PILE of carrots, turnips, onions, shallots, lettuce leaves and potatoes lay on a stainless steel table at the French Culinary Institute's teaching kitchen. My mission, on this first day of La Technique, the institute's basic course for amateur chefs, was to turn those vegetables into textbook examples of the basic French cuts: juliennes, paysannes, chiffonnades and the nearly invisible specks known as macedoines.

title: Without Rain, Florida Burns and Costs Mount
description: With scarce rainfall and record-breaking heat turning Florida into a tinderbox, about 258 fires were burning across the state today.

title: Glavine Puts an End To Yankee Nightmare
description: Twelve-year-old Tommy Glavine was sitting on the couch at his home in Billerica, Mass., that fateful day in 1978. Bucky Dent's playoff home run for the Yankees that buried Tommy's beloved Boston Red Sox stunned him so that he couldn't even react angrily.

title: Jean H. Lipman, 88, Authority On Folk Art and Museum Patron
description: Jean Herzberg Lipman, an arts patron, collector, author of 26 art books and longtime editor of Art in America magazine, died on Saturday at her home in Carefree, Ariz. She was 88.

title: Morocco's Shutout Is No Help
description: Morocco scored a 3-0 victory over Scotland in a gallant but unsuccessful bid to make it to the second round of the World Cup yesterday. The result in Saint-Etienne, France, left the Scots unable to make it out of the first round for the eighth time in a row.

title: Paroled Sex Offender Charged With Abusing 2 Boys in Bronx
description: A paroled sex offender who billed himself as a basketball coach was arrested yesterday on charges that he sexually abused two boys he met at shootarounds in a Bronx park, the police said.

title: Business Travel; American Express's planned bulk purchase of airline seats may be only the beginning.
description: THE planned bulk purchase of airline seats between the United States and London may be only the first in a series of such deals by American Express.

title: Panel Approves Deep Cuts in Programs Championed by Clinton
description: Setting Congress on a collision course with President Clinton, a House panel today approved a proposal to cut back the President's education initiatives as well as eliminate the annual financing for home heating subsidies for the poor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOND, SAUL
description: MOND-Saul. On June 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted brother of Gertrude Mass and the late Sophie Farfel, Morris Mond, Helen Goldstein and Anna Mond. Graveside services Thursday 11:00AM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: MICROSOFT WINNER IN APPEAL TO KEEP SOFTWARE INTACT
description: In an opinion that undercut a central argument in the Government's antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation, a Federal appeals court today struck down a lower court's ruling that had ordered the company to alter the way it sold its software for navigating the Internet.

title: Cautious Teachers Reluctantly Touch Less; A Fear of Abuse Charges Leads to Greater Restraint With Students
description: When a charter school opened last fall in Hoboken, N.J., Lydia Becker, the director, warned her small staff of teachers that they should be careful not to hug students who do not want to be hugged or otherwise touched.

title: Few Transit Changes Are Planned For Riders Drawn by New Passes
description: In 10 days, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will roll out the biggest discounts in the history of the city's subway and bus system: a package of monthly, weekly and daily passes that officials say will draw hundreds of thousands of riders to a system that is already saturated with passengers attracted by past fare deals.

title: Ruling Unlikely to Affect Windows 98 Release
description: For all the dust kicked up in the legal battle over the Microsoft Corporation's right to include Web browsing software in its Windows 95 operating system, a ruling by an appeals court today in the software giant's favor will have almost no impact on the imminent release of Windows 98, a new version that integrates the browser even more tightly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, ROSE
description: SAMUELS-Rose. June 23, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Dear mother of Elaine Harris and Flossie Samuels. Beloved sister of Dinah, Lily, Joseph and Dellie. Services today June 24.

title: Totaling the Sum of Swiss Guilt
description: As one of the lawyers hired to sue Switzerland's three largest banks for the return of assets acquired illegally from Holocaust victims, I have not commented publicly on the case, in keeping with a confidentiality agreement signed by the lawyers on both sides.

title: Garlic In Another Guise: As a Base For Soups
description: MORE and more of my friends are becoming vegetarians, and in this, the season of good vegetables and good garlic, it is a pleasure to be able to serve them delicious soups based on a meatless stock. Garlic broth is an age-old Mediterranean staple that is cheap to make and yet offers flavor and a certain body that comes from the stickiness all of us who have peeled garlic know well.

title: Alexia Is First In Slow Time
description: The maxi-yacht Alexia finished first yesterday to take line honors in what has become the slowest Newport Bermuda Race in two decades.

title: A New Tactic for Kosovo Rebels: Attacks on Isolated Serb Civilians
description: The gong of church bells summoned the Serbs up to the weed-choked cemetery, with its ancient stone crosses, marble tombs etched with the faces of the departed, crooked iron gates and gnarled trees.

title: Editorial Observer; Through the Looking Glass of Modern Music
description: Recently I walked across town to the Pierpont Morgan Library to view an exhibition of manuscripts and books by Charles Dodgson, a.k.a. Lewis Carroll, the author of ''Alice in Wonderland'' and ''Through the Looking Glass.'' What I really went to see was the colored proof sheets of Sir John Tenniel's glorious engravings, which are more closely entwined with the tales they illustrate than those by any other artist except William Blake, who illustrated his own poems. Alice, the Duchess, the Mock Turtle and the Gryphon looked much as they always have, feet firmly planted on the cross-hatchings of Wonderland, faces perplexed by the odd sobriety of the world those characters will forever inhabit.

title: 500,000 Line Up To Buy ENI Shares
description: Some 500,000 investors lined up on Monday at banks throughout Italy to purchase shares of ENI S.p.A. on the first day of the 12.8 trillion lire ($7.23 billion) offering of the state's 12.5 percent stake in ENI, the nation's biggest company. While it is not known how many shares these investors bought, if every one acquired one 500-share lot, the first day's orders alone would account for about one-quarter of ENI's entire offering of almost 1.1 billion shares, of which 750 million are reserved for retail buyers. The sale ends on Friday.

title: A Worldly Senegalese Singer Likes to Stay Home
description: This West African capital has been throbbing for years with nightclubs. Walls are pasted with concert posters, and street merchants peddling cassettes can talk knowledgeably about musicians from across the region.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about insurance coverage for Viagra misstated Medicaid policy on paying for it. Federal officials have said they expect to require Medicaid payments for Viagra, not deny them, when a doctor says the drug is medically necessary.

title: Officers Conferred After Suspect's Death
description: A New York police officer testified yesterday that he and at least a half-dozen other officers who had been present at the 1994 incident in which Officer Francis X. Livoti was accused of using a choke hold on a man who later died met at the police union's headquarters to discuss the incident before giving statements to the police or prosecutors.

title: Seamy Lowlife in Orderly Tokyo
description: It's not just true of New York, Los Angeles or Miami. Every naked city has a million squalid stories hatching under its smog. ''Junk Food,'' Masashi Yamamoto's collage of urban vignettes unfolding simultaneously over a single day insists that even nice, orderly Tokyo has a fetidly seamy lowlife.

title: Group Sickened After Hotel Lunch
description: A group of lawyers and interns from one of the city's largest corporate law firms became ill yesterday after eating tuna during lunch at the Drake Swissotel, one of the city's premier hotels.

title: Chinese Spurn Appeal To Allow Opera Tour
description: After a day of last-minute efforts to negotiate a compromise that would permit a local opera company to travel to New York City to perform a classic Chinese opera, ''The Peony Pavilion,'' as a centerpiece of the Lincoln Center Festival next month, cultural officials here continued to block the project. The director of the Shanghai Bureau of Culture insisted that the modern staging of the work was inappropriate for foreign viewers and would not be permitted to travel.

title: Woman in the News: Jane Ellen Henney; For F.D.A., an Old Hand
description: Six years ago, when Dr. David A. Kessler was new to the job of Commissioner of Food and Drugs, he flew to Kansas to ask a woman he had never met to become one of his chief deputies. Dr. Jane E. Henney, a cancer specialist who was an administrator at the University of Kansas School of Medicine, had a reputation, Dr. Kessler said, for being ''very smart, very talented, very independent-minded.''

title: Assemblyman Demands Release of Tapes Said to Implicate Bronx Democrats in Plot
description: Assemblyman Roberto Ramirez, the Bronx Democratic Party chairman, demanded yesterday that former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. release secretly recorded tapes on which Mr. Espada says Democratic officials are heard planning to undermine his campaign to recapture his seat.

title: A Clairvoyant in the Kitchen
description: IMAGINE a restaurant with a chef so prescient he can walk through the dining room and know, just by looking at his guests, what each of them is longing to eat. Aiming to please, he sends one waiter to a table saying that today's special is a salad of just-picked cherry tomatoes. Another waiter tells a startled customer that the chef has cooked the tripe and polenta he has secretly yearned for, while a third diner discovers that tonight's fish is the red snapper of his dreams.

title: Two Executives Take New Jobs
description: Two top agency executives are changing jobs.

title: Grandstanding on Taxes
description: For sheer mischief-making irresponsibility, it is hard to top the House's action last week in voting to repeal virtually the entire Federal tax code. What, you might ask, will replace it? There is no answer, except for a promise that that question will be addressed sometime in the next century.

title: Protection for Medicare Consumers
description: The Clinton Administration's new Medicare regulations will provide important consumer protections for 38 million elderly and disabled beneficiaries as more of them move into the managed-care system. Given Medicare's size and reach, these regulations could also set an operating standard for the rest of the health insurance industry.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Laundries, Coin or Not, Branch Out
description: The lifeblood tenant for a commercial broker in neighborhood shopping districts of the city is the chain retailer, perhaps a fast-food outlet or a pharmacy. When the chains are aggressively seeking additional sites, brokers make leases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, JAMES

Our sympathies are extended to his wife, Mary, and sons, Andrew and Scott, as well as his sisters, Sue Wachenheim and Kate Cassidy, and brother, Kenneth Wallach and parents, Ira and Miriam, who are dedicated supporters of UJA-Federation and many civic and educational organizations. description: PEISTER-Ellyn Tauber. On Sunday, May 24, 1998. Died peacefully in the Caribbean. Former resident of New York City and Easthampton. Her friends will miss her. Contributions may be made to The Jazz Musician's Emergency Fund, 1200 Broadway, N.Y., N.Y. 10001.

title: TIME WARNER TO ADD 9.6 MILLION SHARES TO BUYBACK PLAN
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it would increase its existing stock buyback program by 9.6 million shares. The increase -- which will take place over an unspecified time -- raises the size of the company's buyback program to a maximum 53.7 million shares, or about 9 percent of the company's outstanding shares. As of June 22, the company had repurchased 40.6 million shares at an average of $60.17 each. Time Warner had revenue of $3.1 billion in the quarter ended on March 31. Shares of the company climbed $3.3125 yesterday, to $83.25.

title: Just Passing Through the Top Job; New Breed of Chiefs Rides to the Rescue, Then Rides On
description: Help wanted: Experienced C.E.O. needed to turn around troubled company or division. Executives looking for long-term relationship, signing bonuses, guaranteed severance, an equity stake or stock options need not apply.

title: THE CHEF
description: A CHEF working in a vegetarian restaurant, as I did in my days at Greens in San Francisco, is always searching for a centerpiece for the plate, something with enough substance -- visually and in actual heft -- to pull the dish together. For me, vegetable tarts were often the answer. A wedge of tart surrounded by a multicolored salad, for instance, looks dazzling and is filling, too. Sometime in 1980, I started refining the tarts I served.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, CATHERINE
description: KENNEDY-Catherine. Age 51, died on June 23, 1998 after a long illness caused by pancreatic cancer. She was born in Wallsend, Northumberland, England on February 12, 1947. Daughter of the late James & Mary Cunningham Urwin. Educated at the University of East Anglia, she received both a B.A. (in economics, '75), and MA (economic history '77). She taught economics and did career counseling at City College of Norwich and the University of East Anglia, England. In 1967 she married Paul Kennedy, author and historian. In 1983 the Kennedy family moved to New Haven, Connecticut. Catherine Kennedy received a Master's Degree from the Yale School of Management. Concerned about a continuum of care and the lack of facilities and services for people living with HIV/AIDS, Catherine spent eight years establishing Leeway, Inc., a residential nursing home for AIDS patients. Leeway opened its doors at 40 Albert Street, in New Haven in October 1995 and since then has treated more than 157 patients. Catherine has received numerous awards including an honorary degree from Connecticut College, a distinguished service award from the Yale School of Management, and the Most Reverend Joseph F. Donnelly Memorial Award from the Archdiocese of Hartford. Mrs. Kennedy is survived by her husband Paul, her sons James, John and Matthew, her daughter-in-law Cinnamon McClinton Kennedy, sisters Josie Pegram, Susan Sharkey, brothers John and Steven Urwin and their families. Funeral Mass for family and close friends will be held at Saint Thomas More Chapel, 271 Park Street, New Haven, on Thursday, June 25th, at 11:00 A.M. A memorial service is planned to celebrate the life and achievements of Catherine Kennedy at Battell Chapel at Yale University, Thursday, July 9 at 2:00 PM. In lieu of flowers donations are requested to be sent to the Catherine Kennedy Foundation for Leeway, 40 Albert Street, New Haven, Connecticut 06511.
