title: Creation of a Shiny, Happy Band
description: In the era of the Spice Girls and the Backstreet Boys, the notion of a manufactured band -- carefully molded and shaped by record executives -- has become a repellent one. But in decades past, whether it was Motown's Berry Gordy putting the Supremes through an intensive program of dancing, singing, manners and biography adjustment or Phil Spector constructing the sound and image of bands like the Crystals and the Ronettes, acts that today would seem manufactured recorded some of the greatest songs of their era. This summer, there is a noble pop experiment taking place at Mercury Records. The band is called Swirl 360, and in many ways its aim is to make manufactured pop credible and artistically valid again.

title: Cavorting In Irish Gangland

This month Lisa Schiffren, a former Quayle speechwriter who's now a ''full-time mother of two,'' and Candice Bergen, a widowed mother, had a rematch on the editorial pages of The Times. Even as they battled, however, they agreed that two hands-on parents are better than one -- a truism now embraced by every politician in the land, from our dysfunctional chief executive on down.

title: The H.I.V. Plague
description: The latest figures on the global AIDS epidemic are frightening beyond expectations. A country-by-country analysis by the United Nations AIDS program has found that H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, is running wild through many parts of the developing world, especially the impoverished nations of Africa south of the Sahara. The virus has infected one in four adults in Botswana and Zimbabwe, and almost one in five adults in several other African countries. Most do not even know they harbor the virus, but virtually all are doomed unless modern science or their own beleaguered governments can pull off some miracle not yet in sight. As it stands now, the AIDS pandemic is destined to rival the Black Death of the Middle Ages and the influenza pandemic of 1918-1919 as a global horror.

title: Reliance Buying Processor
description: The Reliance Steel and Aluminum Company agreed today to acquire the Chatham Steel Corporation, a closely held Georgia steel processor. Terms were not disclosed. Chatham, based in Savannah, had sales of $166 million last year. Reliance Steel, based in Los Angeles, is one of several public companies snapping up smaller metals centers, which buy metals in bulk and process them to meet customer specifications.

title: Democrats in China
description: We would feel more confident about the lasting value of President Clinton's trip to China, which begins today, if we knew that someone had included among his briefing papers a summary of Ronald Reagan's extraordinary visit to the Soviet Union in 1988. Mr. Reagan used that trip to meet with prominent dissidents and speak directly to Soviet audiences about fundamental freedoms and the advantages of democracy, and there was little that his host, Mikhail Gorbachev, could do about it but grumble. Mr. Reagan knew that one of the important powers of a traveling President is the right to speak plainly in lands unaccustomed to open debate. Bill Clinton has the same luxury. The cause of human rights will be poorer if he squanders it.

And the court of public opinion will soon want proof that this enforcement of free-market capitalism will somehow make for a better digital future.

title: EATON TO CUT 200 JOBS BECAUSE OF DOWNTURN IN SALES
description: The Eaton Corporation will cut 200 jobs as part of an effort to save $60 million a year because of poor sales in its semiconductor-equipment making business. The company said it was ''no longer confident'' that earnings this year would exceed the results of a year ago because of a ''severe and prolonged downturn'' in the unit. The company cut 24 percent of the unit's work force, or 600 jobs, this year. Eaton, based in Cleveland, makes products that serve industrial, vehicle, construction and semiconductor markets. It has 49,000 employees in 26 countries and annual sales of $7.6 billion. Orders for the semiconductor capital-equipment industry are one-third less than they were six months ago, Eaton said. Its stock fell $3.4375 a share, to $78.8125.

description: Sheldon Gunsberg, a film producer and distributor who later headed the Walter Reade chain of movie theaters in New York, died last Thursday of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: Haring Site Blends the Serious and the Quirky
description: EVEN those who are not familiar with the late artist Keith Haring may get a kick out of a Web site dedicated to his work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATERS, NORMAN D.
description: WATERS-Norman D. On June 23, 1998, of Rye, NY, beloved husband of Elaine L. Loving father of Elizabeth W. Haron, and L. Sanford Waters. Dear grandfather of five grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Funeral service will be held Thursday 10 A.M. at The WIlliam H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye, New York 10580. Interment Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: WITH CABLE DEAL, AT&T MAKES MOVE TO REGAIN EMPIRE
description: The announcement yesterday that AT&T would acquire the nation's No. 2 cable television company, Tele-Communications Inc., for $31.8 billion in stock drew an initially favorable response from regulators but a concerned reaction on Wall Street.

title: Tax Cuts Won't End Japan's Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts in America; Seeking to Stretch the Boundaries of Printmaking
description: Setting up for a day in the studio behind his Cleveland Park home one recent morning, Lou Stovall, a master printmaker, plucked a jar of gray ink from a shelf where he keeps custom-blended colors. Holding the jar up for closer inspection, he gave it a gentle shake and said: ''Yes, this is it. This is a very good color for our shark.''

title: From Sand, Straw and Clay
description: Wara Juraku? Sounds like an island in the South Seas, but it's stucco. For the past 1,500 years, the walls of traditional Japanese teahouses and homes have been covered with it. The UM Corporation of Osaka, Japan, is now selling premixed bags of Wara Jaraku -- made of sand, straw and clay -- in the United States. Just add water and apply. In neutral beiges as well as red, black and olive green, the stucco costs $80 for a bag that covers 25 to 30 square feet. Available at Ex Inc., 155 East 56th Street. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: A Baton Is Passed, but the Chorus Sings On
description: THERE was a time, in the early days of the AIDS epidemic, when Gary Miller, a founder of the New York City Gay Men's Chorus, would begin rehearsals by asking if anyone needed a stool to get through. This was at Carnegie Hall. There were a lot of musicians' stools there, and still there were never enough for everyone who was sick.

title: Microsoft Alternatives
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Logo, Same as the Old
description: The Islanders' new ownership, which has said it wants to reconnect the organization to the teams' glory days, took a small but significant step toward achieving that goal yesterday by unveiling the team's new (old) home and away jerseys for next season.

title: Plan Formed To Train Prospects
description: USA Cycling announced a new program yesterday to identify and develop future champions and provide them with help from a new think tank.

title: Meetings Secretly Taped, Lawyer Testifies
description: A lawyer for a Lloyd's of London syndicate testified yesterday in Don King's insurance fraud trial that the promoter's defense team secretly taped meetings last year aimed at settling a related civil case.

title: Bridge; Most of the Victory Margin In Just One of 120 Deals
description: North America's most experienced team squeezed out a victory in the final of the International Team Trials in Tunica, Miss., on Monday night. Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Jeff Meckstroth, Eric Rodwell, Bob Hamman and Paul Soloway, all of whom have won world titles, won by just 12 imps against a fighting team headed by Jim Cayne. With 15 deals remaining in the 120-deal final, Nickell led by 37 and a stretch drive by his opponents fell just short.

title: When Medication Falters
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Toying With the Charter
description: The whole issue of dueling referendums sparked by a feud over Yankee Stadium seemed silly at first, but relatively harmless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, JOEL.
description: WEISSMAN-Joel. Beloved husband of Deborah. Son of Bernard. Brother of Diane, Steven and Kenneth. Nephew of Barbara. Services at 12 Noon, at Congregation Ahavas Achim, 216 South 1st Ave., Highland Park, New Jersey.

title: Research finds consumers worldwide belong to six basic groups that cross national lines.
description: A VENERABLE research company is offering additional evidence that consumers around the world are more similar than different, sharing attitudes and behavior that advertisers and agencies may study to create more effective sales pitches.

title: Just Watch the Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENSTEIN, JOSEPH S.
description: LOWENSTEIN-Joseph S. On June 23, 1998 after a courageous battle with cancer. Son of the late Salomon and the late Sylvia. Best friend and brother of Steve and brother-in-law of Inge. Admired uncle of David and Michael Lowenstein. Much loved nephew of Ruth Ciner. Devoted cousin of Joe Lowenstein, Jane Michaels, Liz Schott, Johnny Ciner, Jimmy and Helene Altschul. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Thursday & Friday 7-9PM. Service at Frank E. Campbell, Sunday, June 28th at 2:30PM. Interment private.

title: British G.E.-Siemens Joint Ventures to End
description: The General Electric Company P.L.C. and Siemens A.G., the two largest electronics companies in Britain and Germany, agreed yesterday to end two British-based telecommunications joint ventures in a transaction worth $:700 million ($1.17 billion) as they concentrate on different ends of the market.

title: White House Revises Policy On Contracts for Minorities
description: The White House today announced a new affirmative-action policy under which minority-owned businesses will be given an advantage when they compete for Government contracts in industries where surveys show they are underrepresented but not in industries where they seem to have a fair share of the market.

title: Tax Cuts Won't End Japan's Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Signs Crime Bill That Increases Sentences
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed into law yesterday a measure that doubles prison time and increases fines tenfold for those convicted of carrying a weapon while committing a drug offense.

title: An Opera Unvexed By Predictions of Rain Or the High Humidity
description: On Tuesday, the best source for a weather prediction in the New York region was, of all places, the Metropolitan Opera's press office. All day the weather reports on radio and television warned that thunderstorms were coming, which would have forced postponement of that night's concert performance of Rossini's ''Barbiere di Siviglia'' in Central Park, the second offering in the company's free Met in the Parks series. But the press people at the Met insisted that the rain would pass us by and the show would go on.

title: Tracing Family Trees
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Cuts Won't End Japan's Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOGILNER, LEONARD, M.D.
description: MOGILNER-Leonard, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center records with deep sorrow the death of Dr. Leonard Mogilner. Dr. Mogilner was affiliated with Maimonides Medical Center in the Pediatric Department for many years. He was loved and admired by all his patients, friends and colleagues. He will be sorely missed by all. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. Warren Wexelman, M.D., Pres. Jacob Shani, M.D., Pres. Elect David Feldman, M.D., Secretary Salvatore DeGliuomini, M.D. Treasurer

title: France Urges Allies to Define Plan for Autonomy for Kosovo
description: France called today for an international plan to restore autonomy to Kosovo Province in Serbia, with the threat of NATO military intervention if Serbian authorities did not quickly agree to negotiations.

title: Only Disconnect (For a While, Anyway)
description: EACH summer, Batya Friedman and her husband, Peter Kahn Jr., both professors at Colby College in Waterville, Me., take their daughter Zoe and move to a 670-acre outpost without electricity five hours northeast of San Francisco. They use solar power to use their computers to write, but they can get no E-mail. They can use a phone only twice a month, on trips to town.

title: Judge Rejects Proposed Pact in Sex Harassment Case
description: A Federal court judge in Manhattan unexpectedly rejected a proposed settlement of a sex discrimination case against Smith Barney Inc. yesterday, criticizing it for vagueness and questioning whether it would have sufficient financial backing.

title: Hospital Fires 4 Surgeons in Rule Dispute
description: Four senior surgeons at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx have been dismissed, in the latest and most public clash between the hospital's longtime staff and new managers who have instituted major changes there in the last year.

title: DUKE ENERGY BUYS PG&E PIPELINE IN AUSTRALIA
description: The Duke Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had bought the PG&E Corporation's gas pipeline and related assets in Australia to enter the electricity-generation and energy-trading businesses in that nation. Neither company would say how much was paid by Duke, which is based in Charlotte, N.C. The San Francisco-based PG&E bought the Queensland State Gas Pipeline from the Queensland government for $128 million in 1996. PG&E said it would sell the assets for more than it paid in Australian dollars, but it will incur a loss of about 6 United States cents a share in the second quarter because of unfavorable currency exchange rates.

title: Personal Shopper; Where the Walls Do More Than Hold Up the Ceiling
description: IT'S not just a wall, it's a canvas. And not just for paint but for marble dust, Butcher's Wax, Formica laminate and mosaic floor tiles. Texture helped make wall treatments artful at the Harlem United Show House, which is open through July 12 in the Hamilton Heights Historic District.

title: House Votes to Block F.D.A. On Approval of Abortion Pill
description: In an affirmation of its anti-abortion stance, the House voted today to block the Food and Drug Administration from approving an abortion-inducing pill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILL, SYLVIA B.
description: WILL-Sylvia B. Nee Greenstein of Westfield, formerly of Lauderhill, Florida, on Tuesday, June 23, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Eli Will, devoted mother of Joan Deutsch, dear sister of the late Dorothy Knapp, loving grandmother of two grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, New Jersey, Friday, June 26, 1998 at 1:00 PM. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge.

title: GO2NET BUYS SILICON INVESTOR FOR $35 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Go2net Inc. has bought the closely held Silicon Investor, a Web site for small investors, for $35 million in stock to broaden its audience and increase advertising revenue. Go2net, which is based in Seattle, runs Web sites with a range of features from stock investing to games. Silicon Investor, in Overland Park, Kan., offers tips and sponsors financial discussion groups on market trends, initial public offerings and mutual funds. Silicon Investor will receive 1.25 million shares of Go2net and will move to Seattle as a wholly owned subsidiary of Go2Net. The Web site will continue to be managed by the original staff.

title: Turning the Tables, Artfully
description: Tea With a Twist, shown here in a watercolor rendering, is one of 20 tabletop settings being auctioned off tonight at Christie's to benefit the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum. The winning bidder will get the table, the fringed cloth, two 1920's French bistro chairs, a spiraling epergne, vintage Fiestaware plates, a vintage Hall teapot, pastries, and six new cups and saucers, along with the rendering.

title: Ivo John Lederer, a Scholar of Eastern Europe, Is Dead at 68
description: Ivo John Lederer, a refugee in the only group of European Jews given special passage to the United States by President Roosevelt during World War II, and who went on to became a Russian and Eastern European scholar and teach generations of future American leaders, died last Thursday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Main Bursts but Art Is Safe In Modern Museum Flood
description: A burst water main in midtown Manhattan flooded the sub-basement of the Museum of Modern Art yesterday, endangering two dozen crates of artwork awaiting shipment, museum officials said. No art was damaged because the crates were stored 6 to 10 inches off the floor.

title: From Draft To Owners, A Flurry Of Events
description: Nine days after the Stanley Cup finals, the National Hockey League treadmill speeds up this week with an important owners meeting, the annual awards ceremony, the expansion draft for the Nashville team and the entry draft for 18-year-old amateurs.

title: Between Best, Yankees Still Better
description: While discussing recent baseball history this week, David Cone had nodded his head and speculated that the Braves might have been better than the Yankees in 1996. Maybe the Yankees were simply a team of destiny when they defeated Atlanta in the World Series, Cone theorized. Yeah, right.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the legislative career of Representative Christopher Shays of Connecticut referred incorrectly to his support of Richard Nixon. While Mr. Shays tells of having supported Mr. Nixon in 1960, he was 15 at the time and could not vote.

title: Liz Claiborne Wins Case In Trademark Infringement
description: Liz Claiborne Inc. has won a trademark infringement case against Mademoiselle Knitwear Inc., a Brooklyn sweater factory that is involved in a tangle of litigation with Claiborne and Unite, the garment workers' union.

title: N.R.A. Crime Fighters?
description: To the Editor:

title: Popular Target: Family Trees
description: The Web is an obvious destination for the genealogically inclined, and its popularity among family tree makers was underscored earlier this week when AT&T released the results of a survey: nearly one-third of those responding said they had used the Internet to seek family roots.

title: Arnold Receives Top Print Award
description: Arnold Communications in Boston has won the top award in the print portion of the 45th International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France, known as the Press and Poster Awards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORMAN, NEIL DAVID
description: THORMAN-Neil David. Suddenly June 22. Dearly loved and loving husband of Julie Schapiro Thorman and father of Jack. Beloved son of Edwin and Barbara Thorman. Brother of Joel and Karen. So very loved by all of the Schapiro's. We shall miss him more than we can say. Funeral service Friday, 12:30 PM, ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam. In place of flowers, please make donations to GMHC and God's Love We Deliver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, MRS. JOHN A.
description: THOMPSON-Mrs. John A. (nee Joan Hallinan). On June 23, 1998. Of New York City, NY. Former Executive Secretary for twentyfive years for Arnold H. Vollmer. Wife of the late John A. Survived by her daughter Judith Thompson, granddaughter Liz Thompson. Sister of Mr. & Mrs. Robert McElroy and their children of Flushing, New York. Sister-in-law of Mrs. Richard Hallinan, wife of the late Richard Hallinan, Vero Beach, Florida and their children. In lieu of flowers, donations to The March of Dimes in memory of Richard Hallinan, former Chairman of The March of Dimes. Visiting Friday 11:30 AM and service 12:30 PM at the Kritil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Avenue. Burial Long Island National Cemetery.

title: Palmer Still Big Name With New Jersey Fans
description: Whenever George Steinbrenner complains about Yankee Stadium, the Yankees' principal owner hints at how New Jersey will be the team's new home even though no plans exist for a ball park in the Garden State.

title: Antismoking Lobby Didn't Doom Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; Some Nerve
description: Nothing is more criminal in war than the use of poison gas. Thus it was with some horror that we read and watched the accusation by Time magazine and CNN that the United States used poison gas -- sarin, a lethal nerve gas -- in a commando raid in Laos during the Vietnam War.

title: U.S. Seeks Changes in Wetland Rules, but 2 Sides Criticize Plan
description: The Clinton Administration is proposing changes to a long-disputed system of wetland development permits, potentially opening up more wetlands to builders but also creating new restrictions that are intended to help minimize environmental damage.

title: Road To Ruin
description: King Cove, an Alaskan fishing village on the fringe of the Bering Sea, seems an unlikely place to fire the opening shots against the integrity of our nation's parks, wilderness areas and wildlife refuges. But there a new environmental war has begun.

title: Lopez of St. John's Ends Up With Grizzlies
description: For four years at St. John's University, Felipe Lopez struggled to live up to the expectations of being the national high school player of the year. Al Harrington, of St. Patrick's High School in Elizabeth, N.J., had the same expectations, but skipped college and joined Lopez as a first-round pick in the 1998 National Basketball Association draft.

title: For Pilot Fans, Lots of Bells and Whistles
description: REAL life is starting to look a lot like science fiction. With its flip top and handy size, the new Palm III personal organizer by 3Com/Palm Computing has been frequently likened to the flip-top ''communicator'' used on the original ''Star Trek'' television show. The Palm III may look like a television prop on the outside, but the adaptable little electronic organizer has lots of computing muscle on the inside.

title: Durable Goods Orders Retreated by 2.6% in May
description: Orders to United States factories for big-ticket durable goods fell sharply in May as Asia's economic crisis helped to depress orders for transportation- and electronics-related goods.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Yen Slides, U.S. Renews Pressure on Japan
description: A week after the Clinton Administration signed off on a multibillion-dollar intervention in the currency markets to support the Japanese yen, American authorities stepped up pressure on the Japanese Government today to make good on its promises of economic reform and avoid another decline in the yen's value.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, BEA
description: SNYDER-Bea. With great sadness the Board and staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. mourn the passing of Bea Snyder, a dear friend & sweet person. She was a great supporter of our programs for children, including the Meet-the-Artist School Series and Reel to Real. We extend our sympathies to her husband Harold Snyder, to her three beloved children, Beryl, Jay and Brian and their families. Beverly Sills, Chairman Nathan Leventhal, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

title: On-Line Medical Aid for China
description: Timed to coincide with President Clinton's visit to China this week, American and Chinese doctors plan to perform a live consultation over the Internet tonight to discuss two severely ill children in China. It will be the first real-time medical consultation between China and the United States over the Internet.

title: U.S. Justices to Meet With European Peers
description: Four Supreme Court Justices will lead a judicial delegation in meetings next month in Europe with judges of courts in four European countries, the Court announced today.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Dying Dill

title: Treasuries Lose Early Gains As Note Auction Falls Short
description: Treasury securities lost early gains and ended mixed yesterday, reflecting some disappointment over the results of a Government debt auction and uncertainty about Japanese financial plans.

title: Scarlett, Rhett and the Old South at Their Most Colorful; Giving New Life to a Beloved but Faded Panorama of the Civil War
description: ''Gone With the Wind'' has been released in theaters eight times since 1939, has been shown numerous times on television and has been a top rental at video stores for the last two decades.

title: Hundley 0 for 4 In a D.H. Role
description: Todd Hundley began his minor league rehabilitation assignment last night, going 0 for 4 as a designated hitter for the Mets' Class A St. Lucie team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AYRES, EDA MARIA
description: AYRES-Eda Maria, 71. Following a long illness. Beloved wife of Morgan Willcox Ayres. Loving mother of Peter Morgan Ayres, Christopher John Ayres, Leslie Ayres Seiden, Timothy Michael Ayres, John Morgan Ayres, Jacqueline Ayres Powers and David Jonathan Ayres and grandmother of 4. Visiting 3-5 and 7-9 PM Friday, Whitting Funeral Home, Inc. Glen Head, New York. Funeral service 8 PM Friday at the funeral home. Interment private. Contributions may be made to the establishment in her name of a rural health center in Rwanda, Africa to aid impoverished orphans, at Amahoro Advocacy Clinic & Shelter, 872 Massachusetts Avenue, Suite 2-2, Cambridge, MA. 02139.

title: Literary Site Offers More Than Words
description: THERE is no frigate like a book to take us lands away,'' Emily Dickinson wrote. Of course, she died in 1886, decades before anyone conceived of the Internet.

title: Silver Charm's Fever Spoils Dream Race
description: The anticipated matchup between the nation's three best older horses has been postponed yet again. Silver Charm, last year's champion 3-year-old colt and the Kentucky Derby winner, yesterday morning was declared out of Sunday's $1 million Hollywood Gold Cup because he came down with a slight fever, according to his trainer, Bob Baffert.

title: Audi Pretax Profit Grew in First Half
description: Audi A.G., the luxury car unit of Volkswagen A.G., said yesterday that its pretax profit rose significantly in the first half and sales jumped 26.6 percent on strong demand for its A6 and A8 sedans. Audi, which reported record first-half pretax profit of 498 million marks ($277 million) last year, did not say how much first-half earnings were this year. It said it expected full-year sales to rise 11.6 percent, to more than 25 billion marks, and pretax return on sales to exceed last year's 5 percent.

title: Pop Grants Unsettle British Arts
description: A number of Britain's best-known performing arts institutions are in financial crisis, and directors and producers are assailing the Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair for aggravating their plight by devoting too much of its attention to popular culture. In a debate fueled by a combustible mixture of hurt, anger and lost money, they are accusing the Government of cheating treasured British stage and concert hall traditions of funds and directing its support only to art forms that it believes have contemporary relevance, wide appeal and economic potential.

title: Knicks Part With Oakley to Get Toronto's Camby
description: The Knicks last night severed their decadelong relationship with Charles Oakley, considered the heart and soul of the team, in a trade that will send him to the Toronto Raptors for the injury-plagued, 6-foot-11-inch forward Marcus Camby, according to three officials with the teams.

title: Turf; A Timeout For Home Sales
description: THERE'S a kind of hush all over New York -- New York City's residential real estate market, that is.

title: Tough New Regents Exams Are Unveiled in New York
description: Offering the first glimpse into how dramatically they plan to raise high school standards, state education officials yesterday made public new, harder exams in English and math that are being phased in for all students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, MILDRED
description: GOLDBERG - Mildred. Beloved wife of the late Isidore (of W.H. Foods). Loving mother of Michael and the late Joseph. Mother-in-law of Marion and grandmother of Larry and Ellen. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 10:30 AM, Friday.

title: Early Reviews Look Positive; Close Scrutiny Is a Certainty
description: While Federal regulatory officials expressed initially favorable views of the AT&T Corporation's proposed acquisition of the cable television giant Tele-Communications Inc., they said today that they would closely examine the impact the deal would have on creating competition in local phone markets and increasing home access to the Internet.

title: Almond Extractor
description: It works! The Tibet Almond Stick actually makes furniture scratches disappear. It's been made since 1906 by the Zenith Chemical Works, near Chicago, whose founder discovered this cabinetmaker's secret: almonds. The potion is $4.50 at Restoration Hardware in Garden City, N.Y.; (516) 294-5388. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Relief for Tired Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AT&T-TCI Deal to Alter Communications Industry

title: As Refs Get Tougher, Everyone Else Gets Angrier
description: Joseph (Sepp) Blatter, the new president of soccer's international governing body FIFA, had a message for the referees several hours before Cameroon lost to Italy last week: they needed to get tougher.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about preparations for President Clinton's visit to Beijing misspelled the name of the state guesthouse there. It is Diaoyutai, not Daiyutai.

title: D. D. Thomas, 85; Led Effort to Build Air Traffic System
description: David Duval Thomas, a principal architect of the country's air-traffic control and safety system, died on June 17 at Inova Fairfax Hospital in Northern Virginia. He was 85 and lived in Annandale, Va.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, SUZANNE
description: LEVIN-Suzanne. Loving wife of the late Herbert. Beloved mother of Judy and Matthew. Dear sister of Lawrence Baker. Longtime friend and colleague of the staff of Pederson-Krag Center. In lieu of flowers, donations to PedersonKrag Center, Huntington, New York. Services June 26, 11:30AM at I.J. Morris, Inc., Dix Hills, NY.

title: Nasdaq Reports a 6% Rise In Uncovered Short Sales
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market rose 6 percent, to 2.09 billion shares, for the month that ended June 15, the market said. The June short positions equal 3 days of average trading volume on the Nasdaq, up from 2.46 days on May 15.

title: A Mobile-Phone Software Venture
description: Psion P.L.C., a British palmtop computer company, is joining with Nokia of Finland, Ericsson of Sweden and Motorola -- which together make 70 percent of the world's mobile phones -- to develop software for mobile phones that behave more like computers.

title: Visit to a Rising China
description: President Clinton arrives in China for a visit eagerly sought by his hosts as long-overdue recognition of the country's status. But Mr. Clinton leaves behind an America deeply uneasy about the conduct and intentions of a rising China.

title: World Cup in Morning, Victory at Night
description: MetroStars Coach Alfonso Mondelo held early-morning practices this week to allow his players to watch the World Cup in France, and it proved to be the right strategy. The MetroStars looked inspired in a 5-3 triumph over the New England Revolution tonight at Giants Stadium, in a game that marked the team's best offensive production in its three years of existence.

title: UNITRODE AGREES TO $81 MILLION DEAL WITH BENCHMARQ
description: The Unitrode Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Benchmarq Microelectronics Inc. for about $81 million, considerably less than the $145 million deal that was aborted between the two makers of semiconductors. The value of the one-for-one share swap is based on Unitrode's closing stock price on Tuesday of $11.375. Benchmarq shares rose 18 percent yesterday, gaining $1.5625 each, to $10.25. Shares of Unitrode slipped 37.5 cents, to $11. Unitrode's stock price has fallen sharply since the original deal was announced on March 2, in part because of a softness in orders. Unitrode is based in Merrimack, N.H., and Benchmarq in Dallas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEFFER, MAXINE S.
description: PFEFFER-Maxine S. It is with great sorrow that the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and its employees mourn the passing of Maxine S. Pfeffer, our friend and colleague, of cancer on June 23, 1998. Ms. Pfeffer was 37. We will miss Maxine, an Assistant United Sates Attorney, whose talents, energy and commitment to public service made us proud to be her friend and colleague for these past seven years. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her beloved husband, Khalid, their precious son, Sami, and her loving mother, Shirley. Memorial service on Friday, June 26, 1998 at 10:00AM in Courtroom 110, United States Courthouse, 40 Centre Street, New York, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to ''The Maxine Pfeffer Trust Fund for Sami Chahi,'' c/o Michael Carolan, Merrill Lynch Trust Company, 717 Fifth Avenue, 9th Floor, New York, NY 10022.

title: New Crackdown on Piracy
description: To fight software piracy, long the bane of the industry, the Software Publishers Association plans to get tough by pressing charges more often and publicizing a rogues' gallery.

title: U.N. Arms Inspector Firm on Iraq Nerve Gas but Accepts New Tests
description: The chief United Nations weapons inspector for Iraq told the Security Council today that laboratory tests left no doubt that the Iraqis had loaded deadly VX nerve agent into missile warheads, but he said he was content to go along with a Council decision to call for further tests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYON, WILLIAM W.
description: LYON-William W., died June 23rd, in Delray Beach, Fla., formerly of Scarsdale, NY, and New York City. Retired senior vice president of the Irving Trust. Survived by his wife, Nina M. Lyon; son, William W. Lyon III of Rohnert Park, Calif., and brother, Peter Lyon of Center Tuftonboro, NH.

title: Internet Venture in SoHo Runs Afoul of Fire Codes
description: Josh Harris has made a name for himself in New York City's Silicon Alley -- first by founding a new-media consulting company, then by holding large parties in a SoHo loft that evoked comparisons to Andy Warhol's Factory, and most recently by producing video programming for the Internet through a company called Pseudo Programs.

title: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE AGENDAS -- U.S. Needs Something to Show for Its Policy, While China Wants Some Respect; Clinton Needs Ways to Allay Unease in U.S. About Beijing
description: President Clinton's aerial caravan arrives here today for a visit eagerly sought by his Chinese hosts as long-overdue recognition of China's status as a major global power. But Mr. Clinton leaves behind an America deeply uneasy about the conduct and intentions of a rising China.

title: A Mistaken Microsoft Ruling
description: One month after the Justice Department filed its sweeping antitrust suit against Microsoft, a Federal appeals court has issued a deeply flawed ruling that may weaken the Government's case. The three-judge panel seemed to adopt Microsoft's arrogant claim that it has the right to incorporate its browser, or any other software, into its Windows operating system as long as doing so offers certain advantages to consumers. But if the thinking behind this decision prevails, it could permit Microsoft to use its monopoly power to crush competitors throughout the Internet. The Justice Department thus needs to mount a vigorous counterattack invoking the full force of antitrust laws.

title: Britain a Model on Phone-Cable Packages
description: The AT&T Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc. have the British cable market as a working model for their plan to combine and deliver packages of local phone, Internet and cable-television services over cable lines.

title: The Jets' Testaverde Era Begins (Well, It All Depends)
description: Bill Parcells, saying that he has learned from great sports franchises to be aggressive, officially dumped quarterback Neil O'Donnell today and signed Vinny Testaverde, but gave Glenn Foley the ''benefit of the doubt'' as the Jets' starter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HULSE, JOHN C.
description: HULSE-John C. On June 22, after a lengthy illness, at his home in Palm Beach, Florida. Talented painter & interior designer, he will be remembered with admiration and affection by his many friends and his loving son, daughter-in-law and grand-daughter, John Jr., Christina and Margo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMARI, MARINA
description: AMARI-Marina, 43. After a long and brave battle with cancer. A graduate of Columbia Univ., she was founder and President of Arethusa, Inc, a cultural organization in NYC. Arethusa sponsored Pirandello's play ''The Pleasure of Honesty'' at Clark Theatre, Lincoln Ctr. and Comedia Dell'Arte. Lecture series are ''Sicily: Crossroads of Western Civilization'' and ''The Grand Tour: Journey to Italy'' sponsored by the NY Council on the Humanities. Survived by husband, mother and two brothers. Edgar Hoover included in the show, the review referred to the former Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as the ''top G-Man and (now we know) cross-dresser.''

title: Economy in Spain Grows 0.9% in Quarter

The pace of expansion, while unchanged from the previous quarter and slightly less than expected, lifted Spain's annual growth rate to a seven-year high of 3.7 percent. Underpinning this were swelling sales of consumer products, like cars and mobile telephones, up 1.1 percent in the quarter and 3.5 percent for the year.

description: CROSSING the swimming pool with the relentlessness of a Steven Spielberg tracking shot, the boy's goggles splash bits of green and orange and purple: they are the holographic images of hungry shark mouths on the eyepieces of Speedo's new hologram goggles. The wearer can look through the goggles, but the viewer sees the shark faces or, alternately, shark eyes.

The seller was a partnership managed by the closely held O'Connor Group of New York. The properties are the Rivergate Mall and adjacent Village at Rivergate Center in Goodlettsville; Hickory Hollow Mall and the adjacent Courtyard at Hickory Hollow in the suburbs of Nashville, and Lions Head Village in west Nashville.

Management has developed an aggressive strategy, including a major capital development program to upgrade and enhance its store base, Grand Union said. The company, of Wayne, N.J., said it had obtained a $300 million line of credit from the Swiss Bank Corporation and Lehman Commercial Paper Inc.

title: The Court Vetoes Line Item
description: In a sound and much-needed decision, the Supreme Court has rejected the line item veto as a departure from the basic constitutional requirement that Presidents accept or reject bills in their entirety. The 6-to-3 decision, written by Justice John Paul Stevens, firmly cast aside Government arguments that in canceling specific lines of the budget the President was merely exercising authority delegated to him by Congress. Instead the Court found that the line item veto violates the '''presentment clause'' of Article I. That clause establishes the process by which a bill becomes law.

title: When Radical Art and Politics Marched (Briefly) Hand in Hand
description: The Great Experiment. The term is frequently applied to the modern art of Russia in the years between 1919 and 1927, when Russian Constructivism, one of the most radical manifestations of early 20th-century art, was, for all intents and purposes, the official style of the newly formed Communist Government.

title: On My Mind; Clinton Gets Results
description: After six years, President Clinton's foreign policy has brought dramatic results. It has strengthened the world's three major dictatorships, won the contempt of America's friends and enemies for its word and determination, and helped spread missile weaponry.

title: MGM Grand Picks Young & Rubicam
description: MGM Grand Inc. in Las Vegas, Nev., the hotel and casino company backed by the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, said yesterday that it had named the San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam Advertising to handle its worldwide marketing account. Billings were estimated at more than $20 million.

title: Gingrich Clarifies G.O.P. Stands on Trade
description: As President Clinton arrived in China, Representative Newt Gingrich suddenly stepped forward today to polish Republican credentials on an array of international issues, from trade relations with China to long-stalled financing for the International Monetary Fund.

title: Editorial Observer; Washington Lives in Two Different Worlds
description: At one end of Pennsylvania Avenue lies the U.S. Treasury building. At the other is the Capitol. They are not that far apart in miles, but they seem to inhabit different worlds. While the Treasury deals with the threat of financial hurricanes, the Congress legislates as if there were not a cloud in the sky.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: I should probably start by telling you that I am not a big fan of Po. So when I heard that Mario Batali, it's chef and owner, had taken over the old Coach House on Waverly Place in Greenwich Village with Joseph Bastianich (of Becco and Frico), I was not particularly impressed.

title: German Agency Sells Apartments
description: The German Transport Ministry has sold 112,600 apartments used by Deutsche Bahn A.G. rail workers to a group including WCM Beteiligungs-und Grundbesitz A.G. for 7.1 billion marks, or $3.94 billion.

title: I.M.F.'s Latest Aid Plan for Indonesia Calls for Billions More
description: The International Monetary Fund reached an agreement today that paves the way for resuming aid to Indonesia for the first time since President Suharto resigned last month, but it warned that economic conditions have worsened so quickly that the country will need billions more in emergency aid.

title: Pentagon Adviser Criticizes System of Technology Export Control
description: A senior Pentagon adviser accused the Clinton Administration today of diminishing the Pentagon's role in safeguarding sensitive American technology exports, in favor of commercial interests.

title: Aide Says He Backed Clinton On His Denials on Lewinsky
description: Sidney Blumenthal, a senior White House aide, said today that he had told a grand jury here that Mr. Clinton's private comments to him about Monica S. Lewinsky did not contradict his public denials of a sexual relationship with her.

title: L.I. Mother Is Charged In the Deaths Of 2 Children
description: Two children were found dead in their home in this Suffolk County village by the police early this morning, and their 31-year-old mother has been charged with killing them.

Mr. Taylor, who was an emeritus professor at the Columbia Law School, died in May.

description: SILBERSTEIN-Judy Sklar. On June 25, 1998, at 48 years of age. Beloved wife of Stanley. Devoted mother of Maren. Cherished daughter of Miriam and the late Albert Sklar. title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. Doubts about Japan's efforts to strengthen its banks pushed the yen back toward last week's levels, when Washington and Tokyo intervened to support the currency's value. The dollar rose to 142.30 yen from 141.25.

title: Democrats Shrug at Badillo Switch
description: The political conversion of Herman Badillo, the former United States Representative, Deputy Mayor and mayoral candidate, from Democrat to Republican was greeted yesterday largely with dispassionate shrugs from the city's Hispanic politicians, most of them Democrats, who portrayed Mr. Badillo as a political relic who was out of step with the mainstream.

title: N.H.L. Owners Add Some Balance to Offense
description: The National Hockey League began tweaking its rules today to increase the offensive balance of the game. Measures passed by the board of governors included a move of the goal line farther out from the boards; the use of two referees, instead of one, for a limited number of games; and the trimming of the goal crease by two feet on each side to allow attackers to get closer to the goal line.

Admired uncle of David and Michael Lowenstein. Much loved nephew of Ruth Ciner. Devoted cousin of Joe Lowenstein, Jane Michaels, Liz Schott, Jonny Ciner, Jimmy and Helene Altschul. description: WASHINGTON, June 25 - The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution prohibited the President from rewriting legislation by vetoing single items of spending or specific tax breaks approved by Congress.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: In ''Capital Changes,'' the Living Theater sweeps through 400 years of history on five continents in an hour and a half; in fact, the first of 21 episodes kisses off the Wars of the Roses and the Black Death in three minutes.

title: International Briefs; Lithuania Telecom Stake Sold for $510 Million
description: Telia A.B. of Sweden and the Sonera Corporation of Finland said yesterday that they would buy 60 percent of the Lithuanian state-owned telecommunications operator Lietuvos Telekomas for $510 million. Telia and Sonera, both state-owned telecommunications companies, will each pay $255 million for the stake.

title: As the Chinese See It, Taiwan Remains Most Important Issue
description: From China's point of view the most explosive issue in its relationship with the United States is Taiwan. Chinese officials consistently argue that the level of American arms sales to the island violates Washington's pledge to reduce and, ultimately, phase out such sales.

title: U.S. Allows An Exception In Supporting Loan for India
description: Yesterday, only six weeks after India conducted nuclear tests, prompting economic sanctions by the United States, the World Bank resumed its lending program to New Delhi with the endorsement of the Clinton Administration.

title: BASEBALL: Yankees and Mets Strut Into Their Showdown; Baerga's Hit In the Ninth Tops Orioles
description: With derogatory Yankee chants floating in the humid air and 35,156 fans on hand, there was a festive atmosphere at Shea Stadium last night as a prelude to this weekend's showdown with the Yankees.

title: Fear of Deportation Is Cited In Killing of Illegal Immigrant
description: An illegal immigrant who friends said was afraid to report to the police that she was being abused by her former boyfriend was found dead in the basement of her Englewood, N.J., apartment yesterday, officials said. Prosecutors said they suspect the former boyfriend, who has apparently fled the country.

title: Animals With Attitude (and Dialogue)
description: When last seen talking to the animals, Dr. Dolittle sounded like Prof. Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison starred in the 1967 musical), and his unorthodox friends were a treacly crew. That could have been the beginning and end of the doctor's film career, but the idea of a nouveau ''Dolittle'' has unexpected appeal. Chalk that up to Eddie Murphy's ability to play the straight man with hilarious aplomb, and to the director Betty Thomas's ability to turn kitsch (''The Brady Bunch Movie'') or worse (''Private Parts'') into mischievous fun. Her breezy, undemanding ''Dr. Dolittle'' is the sunniest family film so far this season.

title: BASEBALL: Yankees and Mets Strut Into Their Showdown; Warrior Wells Does It All To Blank Braves
description: In the hour after pitching his perfect game on May 17, David Wells insisted his newfound prominence in baseball history wouldn't change him. He was wrong, it seems. He has become a better pitcher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMM, MINA BURENSTEIN.
description: ROMM-Mina Burenstein. Died on June 5th at the age of 98. Wife of the late Leonard Romm, mother of the late Robert E. Romm, survived by her daughter, Cindy Romm Weeks of Westport, Connecticut, sister Joan Wetherhead, daughter-in-law Sydell Romm and granddaughters Debra Cohen and Donna Somers. Rest in peace Mommy. We love you.

title: Painful Epoch Bracketed By Optimism
description: SOME out-of-towners come to New York not for shop-and-gawk excursions but rather for lessons in life. They want to find out why crime is down, or how well the subways run, or what to do about the homeless. A few months ago, officials from post-Communist Mongolia went to Wall Street to pick up pointers on using capitalist tools.

The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved mother of Dr. William Schwartz, our esteemed vice president for academic affairs and a university professor; Tillie (and Leo) Orleck; Elaine (and Murray) Zundell; and Norman (and Cynthia) Schwartz. We express our heartfelt condolences to them and to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Foley Plays Mr. Congeniality to the Jets' Newest Quarterback
description: After Glenn Foley learned he had been anointed or at least given the ''benefit of the doubt'' in Coach Bill Parcells's words -- as the Jets' starting quarterback, he made sure to talk to the newest Jet, Vinny Testaverde.

title: Appropriating Senator Helms As a Foil and Fellow Traveler
description: By the time the documentary ''Dear Jesse'' comes to an end, one question above all seems to press for an answer: Is this film, written and directed by Tim Kirkman, likely to change any voter's mind about Jesse Helms, the conservative Republican who has represented North Carolina in the United States Senate since 1972?

title: China's Dynamism, Japan's Inertia
description: President Clinton's trip to China should put a new vision of Asia into sharp focus -- one that all but formally recognizes that the economic and geopolitical leader of the region is no longer Japan but China. It is a shift that will also have a lasting and profound impact on world financial markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, IRVING
description: LIEBERMAN-Irving. Of Bayside, NY. On June 24th at his home in Delray Beach. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Judith, Frederic and the late Roy. Dear father-in-law of Marjorie and brother of the late Roslyn Blau. Loving grandfather of Jennifer Shane, Andrew William and Anna Bess Marissa Xin Guang. Dear brother-in-law of Norma Gross, Sylvia Jaffe and the late Frances Schneider. Services will be held at 2 P.M., on Sunday at Temple Beth Sholom, 171-39 Northern Boulevard, Flushing. Esteemed teacher and advisor to many students at Martin Van Buren High School. His family and friends will miss this good, sweet man.

title: International Briefs; Pakhoed Cancels Plan For Van Ommeren Deal
description: Royal Pakhoed N.V. said yesterday that it had canceled plans to buy Royal Van Ommeren N.V. in an effort to create the world's largest oil- and chemical-shipping company, after European Union antitrust regulators demanded nearly twice the cuts in oil-storage capacity the companies had offered. Both companies' shares plunged after the the 1.35-billion-guilder ($665 million) stock-swap agreement was called off. Pakhoed fell 7 percent lower, at 70 guilders, and Van Ommeren sank 6 percent, to 85.6 guilders.

title: Justices Deal Starr a Defeat, Holding That the Attorney-Client Privilege Survives Death
description: The Supreme Court today affirmed the right of clients to take to their graves the content of their consultations with lawyers. The ruling ended the Whitewater independent counsel's quest for notes of the lawyer who represented Vincent W. Foster Jr., the deputy White House counsel who committed suicide five years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the tapestry designer Gloria F. Ross on Tuesday misstated the position of Dr. Ann Lane Hedlund at the Gloria F. Ross Center for Tapestry Studies in Tucson, Ariz. She is the center's director, not head of its board.

Funeral Mass Saturday, St. Kevin's R.C. Church at 9:45 A.M. Visiting hours Friday 2-5, 7-10 PM.

description: The President led a schoolyard discussion today in Xiahe, about 30 miles east of Xian and adjacent to the famed archeological site of the terra-cotta warriors buried in the tomb of Emperor Qin Shihuang.

title: Intel Confirms Flaw in a Chip, and Delay
description: The Intel Corporation confirmed today that a bug would delay shipments of its 450NX chip set, which is to be used with its new Xeon microprocessor in high-powered servers.

title: House Passes Bill to Revamp Tax Collection
description: By a resounding majority, the House today approved a compromise bill to revamp the Internal Revenue Service, moving the country one step closer to the biggest make-over of its tax collection system in nearly 50 years.

title: International Briefs; Daimaru to Close Stores And Quit Thai Venture
description: Daimaru Inc., a major Japanese retailer, said yesterday that it would liquidate its subsidiaries in Hong Kong and France and pull out of its department-store joint venture in Thailand as part of its effort to reorganize its operations. Daimaru said the planned liquidation and withdrawal would cause a special loss of about 14 billion yen ($99.4 million) for the current fiscal year. But proceeds from sales of real estate and securities will offset the loss, the company said.

title: Family Queried About Murder Of JonBenet
description: With the threat looming of a grand jury inquest into the murder of JonBenet Ramsey, the parents of the slain beauty princess completed three days of questioning by prosecutors here today, breaking their 14 months of official silence.

title: From Prep School to the Projects: Checking In at Age 14
description: The rich girls get your attention, as rich girls do. Lucy, Kate and Alexis, once 7-year-old classmates at the Nightingale-Bamford School in Manhattan, have gone their separate ways: to boarding school in New Jersey, to a suburban public school and to Chapin. But here they are together again at age 14, talking to the director and the cinematographer about subjects like divorce, money, religion, careers and drugs.

description: No, I am not shocked by news that writers for The Boston Globe and The New Republic have been serving up fiction dressed as fact.

Loving father of Eugene J., Jr., Sr. Margaret M., Angela M., James P., Peter C. Donovan, Marcella S. McGovern, Patricia M. Baily, Sally M. Allen and Grace M. Feighery. Funeral mass Mon., 11AM at Annunciation Church, Yonkers. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Bonn to Continue Job Programs
description: Germany is setting aside 25.3 billion marks -- $14.1 billion -- in next year's budget for job-creation programs, Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today. It is the second consecutive year that this amount is being allocated for programs aimed at reducing near-record unemployment.

title: The South In Sounds And Ideas
description: The musical fertility of the black South during the first half of the century, though it shaped the pop music of the world, has mostly fallen out of the public consciousness, at least in a direct way. But Olu Dara and Cassandra Wilson, who performed at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, went directly into the culture.

title: Utilities Urge Saving Power In Hot Midwest
description: Utilities throughout the Midwest asked millions of customers yesterday to cut the use of appliances, including air-conditioners, because of a heat wave that has resulted in a surge in demand for electricity.

title: Wimbledon Redemption Eludes Agassi Yet Again
description: It was another four seasons in one day at Wimbledon, with things a warm, bright, rainy and chilly step away from the surreal. No wonder 28-year-old Andre Agassi, dressed in a billowing white smock of Byronic vintage above black undershorts that smacked of 21st century technology, discovered himself out on Center Court locked in a May-December entanglement.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Top 100 Reasons To Quibble

title: COKE EXPECTS 2D-QUARTER BEVERAGE SALES TO RISE 10%
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it expected sales of its beverages to rise as much as 10 percent in the second quarter. Coca-Cola, which is based in Atlanta, said second-quarter case volume, an important measure of the company's underlying growth, was expected to rise up to 8 percent in the United States, up to 11 percent in both Latin America and Europe, up to 17 percent in Africa and as much as 8 percent in the Middle and Far East. Coca-Cola, the world's largest beverage company, had 1997 revenue of $18.86 billion. Its stock rose 75 cents, to $84.875.

title: Jobless Scot in Nicaragua Discovers Political Insight
description: It's hard to imagine a more unlikely visitor to Central America in wartime than George (Robert Carlyle), an unemployed Scottish bus driver who is astounded to find himself in mortal peril jouncing along a rutted mountain road in Nicaragua with a group of soldiers dressed in camouflage. It is 1987, when right-wing contras are waging a guerrilla war against the leftist Sandinista Government, and George has impulsively flown all the way from Glasgow with his Nicaraguan fiancee Carla (Oyanka Cabezas) on a risky quest that could turn out to be a wild-goose chase.

title: ADAPTEC'S PURCHASE OF A HYUNDAI UNIT IS CALLED OFF
description: Adaptec Inc. and Hyundai Electronics America yesterday scrapped Adaptec's proposed $775 million purchase of Hyundai's Symbios Inc. unit, which makes devices that connect computers to networks, in the face of opposition by the United States Federal Trade Commission. Adaptec said it expected to take a $20 million charge related to the transaction in its first quarter, which will end on Tuesday. Adaptec announced another unrelated first-quarter charge in March. Adaptec said the F.T.C. would probably oppose the purchase because the combination might have given Adaptec a monopoly in one of several technologies to move information to and from computers. Adaptec's shares rose $1.0625 yesterday, to $16.6875.

title: Residential Real Estate; TriBeCa Warehouses to Become Condominiums
description: Two rundown 19th-century warehouses in TriBeCa are to be stripped to their brick frames, joined together and turned into condominiums as part of a $30 million conversion plan that includes a rooftop addition unusual for the area. The conversion calls for the creation of 33 loft apartments within the five- and six-story buildings at 387-397 Greenwich Street, which cover nearly an entire block between Beach and North Moore Streets in the neighborhood's historic district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, PETER T.
description: JOSEPH-Peter T. Beloved husband of Wendy Evans, and loving and adoring father of Danielle and Nicholas, died on June 25, 1998 from cancer at age 47 at home. He was Chairman and CEO of Rosecliff, Inc., a merchant banking firm, Chairman of the Board of Governing Trustees of American Ballet Theatre, board member of The Second Stage Theater and Prep for Prep, and member of the Rockefeller University Council. Leading patron and collector of studio art furniture, he was the founder and owner of The Peter Joseph Gallery which exhibited studio art furniture in New York City from 1991 to 1997. He was a graduate of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University & Yale Law School. He is survived by his loving mother, Evelyn Joseph, brother Michael Joseph of Olney, IL, sisters Mary Joseph and Eleanor Joseph both of Atlanta, GA., brother Thomas Joseph and sister Evelyn Joseph both of Cincinnati, OH., sister Margaret Joseph of Nashville, TN, sister Kathleen Reinhart of Dayton, OH as well as 13 nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Sunday 2-4PM & 6-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, Monday 10AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contribtions may be sent to American Ballet Theatre, 890 Broadway, New York, NY 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEHILL, PAUL
description: FREEHILL-Paul. Suddenly on June 24th, 1998. Beloved son of Alice and James, dear brother of Laurene, Patrice, Allison, Bob, Janet, Joseph, Mary Lou, and the late Jimmy. Devoted grandson of Marion, loving uncle of Amanda, Neil, Jayne, Lynn, Jamie and Catherine. Survived by numerous aunts, uncles, in-laws, cousins, and dedicated friends. Committed and loyal employee of Audrey Cohen College. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, 81st St, Friday 2-5, and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass at St. Monica's Church, 413 East 79 St, Saturday 10AM. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. A memorial scholarship will be formed in his memory at the college.

description: Jazz history has yielded so many tales of strife-torn relationships between artists and their business associates that when performers of the stature of Joe Williams, George Shearing, Shirley Horn and Nancy Wilson gather to honor a happy long-term relationship with a manager, attention is due.

title: U.A.W. Strike Is Being Felt Far From Flint
description: Strikes at two General Motors' parts factories here, which started as local disputes over work hours and equipment investments, are producing economic effects now slowly rippling out across North America.

description: Acting on a tip, the Jersey City Police Department raided a house in Jersey City yesterday and arrested 14 people on charges of counterfeiting tens of thousands of designer watches and purses.

title: No Caps and Gowns? No Problem Here
description: Under the stained glass windows of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, students gathered yesterday morning for a singular ritual of adolescence, in which they were to listen to speeches intended to inspire, accept a rolled-up piece of parchment earned with 12 years of their sweat and ceremoniously toss their square caps up at the sky.

title: Ex-Student Is Charged With Growing Marijuana
description: A 22-year-old Vineland man who dropped out of Rutgers University in April was arrested Wednesday on a charge of growing marijuana in a fraternity house on campus, the university police said yesterday.

description: It's a Nice Song

title: Q & A / Fatos Nano : Fears of a Spillover From Kosovo's War
description: Salzburg  Prime Minister Fatos Nano of Albania is concerned that unless decisive military action is taken immediately, the Kosovo conflict could spread into a Balkan-wide problem. In Salzburg, where he was attending a regional economic conference, Mr. Nano spoke with Peter S. Green for the International Herald Tribune.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPMAN, JEAN H.
description: LIPMAN-Jean H. The employees and principals of Neuberger & Berman, LLC mourn the passing of Jean H. Lipman, wife of the late Howard Lipman, a former managing partner of Neuberger & Berman. Her commitment to the arts as a patron, collector and author will leave an everlasting mark. We extend our sincerest sympathy to her son Peter and two grandsons.

title: Image of Oak Is Chosen For Back of New Quarter
description: Connecticut's Charter Oak, the tree where Colonists hid the state charter from the British in 1687, will grace the back of at least 500 million quarters next year as part of a special program by the United States Mint. The oak was hundreds of years old when it fell during a storm in 1856.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Tuesday about an acquisition by Metro Holdings A.G. misidentified the business being acquired. Metro Holdings is acquiring a 12.5 percent stake in RSL COM Europe, not in the parent RSL Communications itself.

title: James Naughton, an Actor Singing for the Joy of It
description: At 5:30 A.M., the day after James Naughton opened in his new one-man musical revue at the Manhattan Theater Club, he was in a graveyard in Queens acting in a scene in an independent film called ''Oxygen.'' Then, after a long day's work, he raced back to the theater to give his next performance. As always, Mr. Naughton is high on energy and talent.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Achilles' Heel for Gasoline Trucks
description: GASOLINE tanker truck accidents usually kill only a few people at a time, but they can be among the best remembered and disruptive highway accidents because they can close roads for months. The reason, according to the National Transportation Safety Board, is bad design.

title: House Spending Bill Dictates Delay in Action on Climate Treaty
description: Congressional opponents of a treaty to fight the threat of global warming are using the annual spending bills now before Congress to send a blunt message to the Clinton Administration: Don't even think about how to meet the treaty's goals before it wins Senate approval.

title: Release Given To McDougal; Health Is Cited

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, JOANNE E.
description: ALLEN-Joanne E. On June 24, 1998, following a stroke, passed away in Miami Beach, FL, age 68. Joanne, wife of Skip Allen, was born in New London, CT. on July 18, 1929. She graduated from high school in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Georgetown Visitation College in Washington, D.C. In 1967, Joanne and Skip, with their six children, moved from Larchmont, NY to Miami Beach. Always active in yachting, Joanne hosted parties at their home for the Storm Trysail Club, the SORC, and held ''The Party'' annually for 500 or more friends during the Miami Boat Show. In addition, Joanne and Skip led guided cruises over to the Bahamas in the 1970s and '80s and were active supporters of Antiqua Sailing Week. Her favorite times were cruising the Exuma Cays in the Bahamas with her family and friends. Joanne and Skip spent each spring and summer in the Islands, making literally hundreds of friends throughout the chain as they cruised in their trawler, ''Press On Regardless.'' In 1972, they started Southern Boating Magazine together, a publication which has attracted a loyal and growing readership and continues to flourish after 25 years. The welcome mat was always out at the Allen's home. A warm, generous and big-hearted lady, her home was always open to all their friends which earned her the universal title, ''Mom.'' Joanne is survived and will be deeply missed by her husband, Skip, and their six children, Rick, Skip Jr., Cathryn, Jody and her husband Steve, George and Paige; their six grandchildren, Charlotte, Alexandra, Corey, Michael, Ashley and Christina; and by an incredible number of friends whom she touched during her long and full life. A memorial service will be held in Fort Lauderdale, FL., at Church by the Sea, 2700 Mayan Drive, Ft. Lauderdale, FL 33316 (just east of the 17th Street bridge), on Saturday, June 27 at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to Church by the Sea.

title: MEAD PLANS TO ELIMINATE 500 JOBS AND SELL SOME ASSETS
description: The Mead Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 500 jobs and pursue the sale of some of its assets. Mead, based in Dayton, Ohio, makes coated and specialty papers, packaging and paperboard, and school and office products. Mead said it would soon cut 250 jobs from its work force of 5,000 and would cut another 250 in the next three to five years. The company also said it would record a second-quarter pretax charge of $80 million in connection with the sale of its Zellerbach distribution business and the write-down of other assets. Mead also intends to sell Mead Ink Products, 50,000 acres of timberland, some real estate, and mill sites in three states. Mead's stock rose 56.25 cents yesterday, to 30.1875.

Level One, based in Sacramento, Calif., will issue five million shares of its common stock in exchange for Acclaim, a closely held company based in San Jose, Calif. The deal was announced after Level One's stock closed at $23.6875, down $2.5625. Level One will sell Acclaim's computer switches to its telecommunications customers, who are upgrading their networks to handle Internet traffic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DWYER, PAUL
description: O'DWYER-Paul. The officers and members of The Irish Institute of New York are profoundly saddened by the passing of our Founder, former President and Chairman of the Board of Trustees. Your extraordinary pride in your Irish heritage, your vision, enterprise, goodwill, dignity and generosity of spirit have left an enduring legacy. The vast number of artistic and historic projects benefitting from your beloved Institute, on both sides of the Atlantic, for the past 50 years are a fitting memorial to your exemplary life, none more so than the last work of scholarship to which you gave your whole hearted commitment, The New York Irish. Your longtime support for research on the history of the Irish in your adopted city helped make the recent publication of this book possible. We will always miss you and never forget your fighting spirit and enormous contribution to our Institute and to Human Rights. Kevin Morrissey, Pres.

title: The '86 Mets Live On For Man in Pinstripes
description: There was a gray Yankees uniform hanging in Darryl Strawberry's locker, a blue Yankees cap resting on the floor and several teammates sprinkled throughout the visiting clubhouse yesterday, but Strawberry plopped himself inside a baseball time capsule and went exploring. He journeyed away from the Bronx and back to Flushing. For 30 glorious and gleeful minutes, it was 1986 again.

description: KELLY-William F. Jr. On June 23rd, 1998. Beloved husband of Margaret, loving father of Margaret, William, Kevin and Kelley. Cherished grandfather of seven. Retired detective of the NYPD for twenty years and NBC for sixteen years. Dedicated member of the Knights of Columbus & the NYPD Holy Name Society. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd at 193 St. Visiting hours Thursday & Friday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Funeral Mass on Saturday 10 A.M., Holy Family RC Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Holy Family Church.

Dedicated father of Susan, Liz and Jack Priven. He leaves behind adored grandchildren Matthew and Ian, his messengers to the future. His love for his family and the state of Israel/Israel Bonds was unequaled. He will be missed. Graveside services: Sunday, 11 AM, Mount Ararat, Long Island.

title: 3 Who Urged Clinton to Meet With Democracy Groups Are Detained; U.S. Protests
description: United States officials expressed concern to the Government today over reports that several dissidents had been detained and others harassed in connection with President Clinton's visit.

title: Miscellany
description: * Link Exchange Inc., San Francisco, a Web site advertising network, acquired an on-line commerce provider, Merchant Planet, Minneapolis, and a Web site announcement services company, Submit It, Boston. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Mourning Schubert With an Oblique Simplicity
description: The Mark Morris Dance Group returned to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night with Mr. Morris's familiar staging of Purcell's mini-opera, ''Dido and Aeneas'' and the New York premiere of ''Medium.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Representative Charles E. Schumer's Senate candidacy referred imprecisely to a record set by his fund-raising. Mr. Schumer has raised more from contributors than any other challenger in Congressional history this early in a campaign, not for an entire campaign.

title: Mason Is Guilty Of 2 Misdemeanors
description: Anthony Mason pleaded guilty yesterday to two misdemeanor counts of endangering the welfare of a child in connection with an incident last February in which Mason, the Charlotte Hornets forward and former Knick, and a cousin were accused of having consensual sex with two girls at a house in Queens.

title: International Briefs; Korean Banks Set Debt Relief Plan
description: South Korean financial institutions joined forces yesterday to support cash-short companies, aiming to prevent a wave of bankruptcies that could worsen the country's recession. Korea First Bank, which is coordinating efforts among banks, said more than 230 financial companies had conditionally agreed to reschedule debt for up to six months.

title: INSIDE ART
description: By Picasso, From His Muse

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of House & Home on June 11 about the new Hong Kong International Airport misstated its dedication date. The date is July 6, not July 8.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Imaginative supplements help a pair of magazines build relationships with marketers.
description: TWO magazines are supplementing their appeals to readers and advertisers with unconventional supplements that are appearing in issues now coming out.

title: International Briefs; Publicis Predicts Profit Will Grow 10% in '98
description: Publicis S.A., Europe's second-biggest advertising company, said yesterday that its earnings and sales would grow by at least 10 percent in 1998, helped by acquisitions. ''After a positive performance in the first months of the year, we expect to see double-digit growth'' in 1998, Publicis's chairman, Maurice Levy, said at a shareholders meeting. Mr. Levy suggested that the company's earnings growth could reach 20 percent or more.

title: CAREY SAYS IT IS IN TALKS TO ACQUIRE 63 COMPANIES
description: Carey International Inc., the world's largest chauffeured-vehicle service company, said yesterday that it was in acquisition talks with 63 companies representing $420 million in annual revenue, as it continues to consolidate in a fragmented industry. Carey, which provides limousine, minibus and van services in 420 cities in 65 countries, also said that net income for the second quarter ended May 31 rose 45 percent. Carey, which is based in Washington, said it had built up its marketing and sales programs while integrating recently acquired independent operators of chauffeured-vehicle businesses. Carey rose $3 a share, to $26.25.

title: Retail Space Leased At Newark Airport
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved a 15-year lease of 71,000 square feet of retail space at Newark International Airport to a London-based airport management company.

title: 2 Idaho Indians Trace a Shared Past
description: ''Smoke Signals'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films Series. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 27. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Computer Profits Outlook Cuts 2-Week Rally's Gains
description: Stocks fell yesterday, led by Intel and Microsoft, on renewed concern about profits for the computer industry's bellwethers.

title: Man Who Hijacked Plane to Cuba in '69 Is Sentenced to 6 1/2 Years
description: The odyssey of Felix Rolando Peterson-Coplin, who hijacked a plane to Cuba three decades ago and then led an open life as a fugitive, came to an end in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday afternoon when a judge sentenced him to 6 1/2 years in prison.

title: Hasek Wins Three Awards
description: Tonight, for the second consecutive season, Dominik Hasek of the Sabres won both the Hart and Vezina trophies as the most valuable player and best goalie in the National Hockey League. He also won the Lester Pearson award, a most valuable player trophy from fellow players.

title: Alarmists Overstate China Army Buildup; Tight Control of Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: Planet Is Found Orbiting Neighbor of Sun
description: The discoveries of planets beyond the solar system, stimulating renewed speculation of other possible worlds throbbing with life, are now drawing closer in cosmic terms to the world of their discoverers.

title: Justices Uphold Decency Test in Awarding Arts Grants, Backing Subjective Judgments
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a Congressional decency test for awarding Federal arts grants but only after a majority of the Justices interpreted the 1990 law as containing only ''advisory language'' that did not actually prohibit Federal subsidies for indecent art.

title: A Field of 11 In Mother Goose
description: The leadership of this year's class of 3-year-old fillies will be on the line tomorrow when a strong field of 11 fillies meets at Belmont Park in the $200,000 Mother Goose Stakes, the middle race in the Triple Tiara series.

description: To the Editor:

title: Seller of Indian Skulls Is Sentenced and Fined
description: William Stevens, the owner of a SoHo natural history store who pleaded guilty in March to illegally selling American Indian skulls and smuggling the skulls and bones of endangered species into the country, was sentenced to 16 months in prison and fined $29,000 in Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday, officials said.

title: In Xian, 'A New Chapter in China's Story'
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's arrival remarks yesterday in China, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: Long After Pitch 162, Leiter Finds His Way
description: When Al Leiter walks to the mound at Shea Stadium tonight in the emotionally charged atmosphere of a house packed with Mets and Yankees fans, he will be excited as ever.
