description: So won't you say you love me,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYON, WILLIAM W.
description: LYON-William W., died June 23rd, in Delray Beach, Fla., formerly of Scarsdale, NY, and New York City. Retired senior vice president of the Irving Trust. Survived by his wife, Nina M. Lyon; son, William W. Lyon III of Rohnert Park, Calif., and brother, Peter Lyon of Center Tuftonboro, NH.

title: State and Hospitals Exult in Court's Decision
description: Government and hospital officials in New York State praised the Supreme Court's decision to strike down the President's line item veto power today, saying it would preserve a set of state hospital taxes that help finance health care for the poor.

title: A New Planet Almost Next Door
description: Astronomers have discovered a planet about twice the mass of Jupiter orbiting a star named Gliese 876, only 15 light-years from the Sun. The star is a red dwarf, the most common type of star in the universe, which means that planets outside the solar system may be more common than previously believed. Article, page A21.

title: Palermo Journal; The Army Is Leaving but the Mafia Probably Isn't
description: Today was supposed to be one of triumph and liberation, as thousands of Italian soldiers began pulling out of Sicily after a six-year military operation to restore order in a land virtually ruled by the Mafia.

title: From the Wry Side of American Indians' Clash With Whites
description: ''We don't serve Indians,'' a waitress said to two Indians as they sat in a diner just outside their Mesquakie settlement in Tama, Iowa. ''We don't want Indians,'' replied one of them. ''We want cheeseburgers.''

title: Police Stop Sealing Parks In Drug Raids
description: The New York City Police Department has stopped the practice of sealing parks during drug raids and keeping law-abiding citizens from leaving them. The change in policy came to light yesterday as the city settled a lawsuit brought by a professor who was briefly detained and handcuffed during a sweep in Washington Square Park last summer.

title: Sampling the State of Russian and Georgian Voices
description: Despite its title, the American Opera Company is not an actual company with a permanent house and performance staff, but a production organization. Cultural exchange is one of its stated concerns, and that appears to have been the motivation behind the curious recital the company presented on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Norman Waters, 92, Pioneer Ad Executive
description: Norman D. Waters, who owned an advertising agency bearing his name and who in 1941 produced the first fashion show broadcast on television, died Tuesday at Osborn Retirement Community in Rye, N.Y., his daughter, Elizabeth Waters Haron, said. He was 92.

title: Treasury Prices Little Changed In Light Trading as Dollar Gains
description: Treasury prices pared early losses and ended little changed yesterday, as the dollar gained in currency trading against the yen. Prices were also weakened by dealers' hedging Freddie Mac's $4 billion global bond offering yesterday.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Bathroom'

title: In Surprise Rebuff to G.O.P. Chiefs, House Panel Backs Money for Arts Endowment
description: In a surprise slap at Republican leaders, the House Appropriations Committee voted today in favor of financing the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Machines As Art, And Art As Machine
description: One good thing about ''The Art of the Motorcycle,'' opening today at the Guggenheim, is that by the time it's over everyone should finally be sick and tired of jokes about the museum as a big parking garage ramp. Frank Lloyd Wright know-it-alls, upon reading this sentence, are probably already preparing letters to the effect that the Guggenheim's design originated in a plan of Wright's during the 1920's to build a planetarium encircled by a kind of double-helix system of ramps, a ziggurat for cars.

title: Excerpts From Opinions in Ruling on the Extent of Lawyer-Client Privilege
description: Following are excerpts from today's Supreme Court decision that the lawyer-client privilege survives the death of the client. The opinion in the case, Swidler & Berlin and James Hamilton v. United States, was written by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and joined by Justices John Paul Stevens, Anthony M. Kennedy, David H. Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer. A dissenting opinion, which is also excerpted below, was filed by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor and joined by Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas.

title: Formal Visionary Of a Revolution
description: Between 1919 and 1927, Russian Constructivism, one of the most radical manifestations of early 20th-century art, was briefly the official style of the new Communist state. Avant-garde artists, subjugating personal expression to the state's utilitarian needs, designed everything from stationery to public monuments. But the experiment was short-lived, ground beneath the heel of Stalin's totalitarianism, with modernist works destroyed and artists imprisoned.

title: A Rush to Charter Revision
description: The steamy days around the Fourth of July coax most New Yorkers to slow down, to laze in the park or along the nearest shore. But Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's hastily appointed charter commission is racing recklessly ahead next week with public hearings on a new charter for New York City. This is no way to revise the bedrock document governing city affairs; it is a bad idea being carried out in a terrible hurry.

title: Sale Is Close To Completion
description: The Nets and a group of New Jersey-based businessmen are on course to complete a deal that could transfer ownership of the team by next week. But before a new ownership emerges, the Nets must overcome dissension within the ranks of the current one.

description: HELLER-Ceil. On June 25, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Devoted mother of Phillip and Michael. Cherished grandmother of Walter, William, Kevin, and Karen. Services Friday 11:30 AM at Gutterman's, Inc., 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Casino Deal With Indians In California Is Ruled Void
description: A California judge today voided a gambling agreement that had been set up by Gov. Pete Wilson without legislative approval or the support of state Indian tribes, who argued that they would lose much of their revenue because of the compact's restrictions on slot machines.

title: Not So Easy to Sell Saks Fifth Avenue
description: To the average New York shopper, Saks Fifth Avenue might seem like the ultimate acquisition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGER, SHEILA
description: LANGER-Sheila. Beloved mother of Nancy Shapiro and Robert Langer. Dear sister of Sheldon Cohen. Cherished grandmother of Rebecca, Melissa and Chelsea Shapiro and Alisa and Nicholas Langer. Service on Sunday 10 A.M., at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York. Contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10021.

title: Judge Says Case Against Brawley Advisers Should Go to Jury
description: The judge in the defamation case against Tawana Brawley's advisers ruled yesterday that the plaintiff, Steven A. Pagones, had provided enough evidence to get his case to the jury, perhaps as soon as early July.

title: COURT SPELLS OUT RULES FOR FINDING SEX HARASSMENT
description: The Supreme Court clarified the law on sexual harassment in the workplace today, making some lawsuits against employers easier to win while limiting the legal exposure of companies that have effective anti-harassment policies in place.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: UNIFORMS IN THE CLOSET
description: R. is a gay man who has thrived in the Marines. Yet he'll soon be leaving the military because the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy has created a world of fear and deceit, alienating him and his friends from fellow service members, and from gay civilians. A report by Jennifer Egan, in the Magazine.

title: England Qualifies For Round 2 With Flair
description: A revitalized England, inspired by the return of midfielder David Beckham, surged to a 2-0 victory today over Colombia and qualified for the second round of the World Cup tournament.

title: CABOT TO TAKE A $54 MILLION EARNINGS CHARGE
description: The Cabot Corporation, the largest provider of carbon black, which is used to reinforce rubber products, said yesterday that it would take a charge of about $54 million in its third quarter to reduce the value of an Indonesian plant and to reflect disappointing yields from a Pennsylvania ore recovery project. Cabot said about $38 million, or 51 cents a diluted share, of the charge was to write down the value of one of its carbon black plants in West Java, Indonesia. The Boston-based Cabot also said $16 million, or 21 cents, of the charge stemmed from a ''very disappointing'' yield at the tantalum ore project. Tantalum is used to make electronic capacitors and nuclear reactor parts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, STUART
description: WEISSMAN-Stuart. Our dearest friend. A prince amongst men. We were always so proud of you. You will never be forgotten. Honey and Norman, Dorothy and Marvin, Phyllis and Bob

title: During a Steamy Round, Palmer Walks to Work
description: It's the game, and you have to honor it, no matter how tired you are, no matter what the temperature, Arnold Palmer suggested today.

title: Getting Back to Basics, C.I.A. Is Hiring More Spies
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is beginning the largest recruitment drive for new spies in its history, in an ambitious effort to rebuild its espionage service, which has been severely damaged by spy scandals, budget cutbacks and high turnover since the end of the cold war, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWE, LOUISE P.
description: HOWE-Louise P. On June 26, 1998 of Garden City, NY. Beloved wife of the late Wallis E. (Pete) Howe. Loving Mother of Denison Scharfman, Elizabeth Shannon and the late Wallis E. Howe III. Dear grandmother of four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Memorial service Tuesday 11AM. The Cathedral of the Incarnation Garden City, New York.

title: Sunken Treasure's Sinking Fortunes; 'X' No Longer Marks the Spot For Governments or Investors
description: Mel Fisher, whose notorious optimism in the face of death, debt and doubting investors led him to the richest shipwreck in history, must wonder where the good times have gone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEFFER, MAXINE S.
description: PFEFFER-Maxine S. The partners, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison express profound sorrow at the passing of Maxine S. Pfeffer. Maxine was a former associate and beloved friend who will long be remembered for her many contributions and accomplishments. We extend our deepest sympathies and condolences to her husband, Khalid, her son, Sami, and to all the other members of her family.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a Family Court judge's finding that New York City failed to prevent a foster child from running away from a group home included an erroneous identification of the home supplied by the judge and city officials. It is a city-run home, not St. John's Residence for Boys, a private home in Queens.

title: Sports of The Times; A Sequel Worthy Of the Sandlot
description: AT about 3:30 yesterday afternoon, Manager Joe Torre led the Yankees into Shea Stadium. This was an odd scene. Normally the visiting team enters through a back entrance. Yesterday, the Yankees sauntered through the Mets bullpen in right field and walked across the outfield grass.

title: Report Card on Rudy Crew
description: New York City school bells rang at noon yesterday, tolling a two-month summer break for the 1.1 million students in what is not only the country's largest public school system but also one of its sorriest. As Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew moves into his third year on the job, this is still a system with an old physical plant and an ungainly bureaucracy. Yet it is time to recognize a few green shoots of hope in what has too long been a field of failure.

title: Lounes Matoub, 42, Is Killed; Sang to Promote Berber Cause
description: Lounes Matoub, a popular Algerian singer and Berber patriot who was kidnapped by Muslim militants in Algeria four years ago but was freed and had lived mostly in France since, was killed in an ambush near his hometown east of Algiers on Thursday. He was 42.

title: A Salute to Berra, but at Shea, Not Yankee Stadium
description: One of the most poignant moments at Shea Stadium last night came when Yogi Berra tossed out the ceremonial first pitch to a reverent standing ovation, a salute that included nearly the entire Yankee squad on the top step of the dugout.

title: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy
description: The constitutional protection against double jeopardy does not ordinarily apply to criminal sentencing, the Supreme Court ruled today in a decision that removed a legal cloud from the operation of some states' ''three strikes'' sentencing laws.

title: MORTON INTERNATIONAL TO SELL THIOKOL FORMULATED
description: Morton International Inc. agreed yesterday to sell Thiokol Formulated Products, a coatings and building-related industrial sealants product line, to the privately held Polyspec Corporation. Morton, based in Chicago, makes and markets specialty chemicals and salt. Polyspec, based in Houston, makes coatings and other chemicals used in construction. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Morton also said it was seeking a buyer for two product lines within its coatings business. The lines are in industries that have little overlap with other Morton businesses, the company said. One product line is a liquid colorant used by the plastics industry, and the other is for highway marking.

title: Norway Plans To Pay Jews $60 Million Compensation
description: Norway has proposed a $60 million payment to Norwegian Jews and international Jewish organizations as compensation for property seized during World War II, the Government announced today.

title: Japan Waits As 2 Banks Weigh Merger
description: Long-Term Credit Bank, one of Japan's biggest and weakest financial institutions, is in negotiations to merge with a smaller, stronger rival, a move that could turn the combined bank into a showcase for the Government's first blueprint to clean up the nation's bad debt.

title: No Executives on Trip, a Hint That Commercial Ties Are Maturing
description: To learn more about the state of relations between the United States and China, look at a few of the things that are not happening during President Clinton's nine-day trip to China.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the technology used by bird-watchers misidentified the equipment in a vest pocket in an illustration. The pocket held a digital mini-disk machine, not a tape recorder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPPARD, ABNER L.
description: SHEPPARD-Abner L. On June 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Sophie Virginia. Loving father of Toni and Ed Piesman. Cherished grandfather to Mary Piesman. Dear brother of Sidney Sheppard. Services on Sunday 3 PM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours Saturday 7-9 PM.

title: CBS to Sell Westinghouse Nuclear Units for $238 Million and Debts
description: The CBS Corporation will sell its Westinghouse nuclear and government services operation to a joint venture formed by the Morrison Knudsen Corporation and a British nuclear-fuel processor, the companies said yesterday.

title: City to Seek Bids for Bus Shelters
description: The Giuliani administration notified bidders yesterday that, as promised, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had canceled plans to grant a huge monopoly contract for hundreds of new bus shelters and newsstands throughout the city. Instead, the city said it would ask for new bids soon, with the possibility that more than one franchise would be awarded, to encourage design variations.

title: Unable to Collect Dues, California Bar Lays Off 450 Workers
description: With its financing slashed in a political standoff with the Governor, the State Bar of California, the main regulatory and disciplinary body for lawyers in the state, laid off hundreds of employees today and sharply curtailed its functions.

title: Corrections
description: The Antiques column in Weekend on June 19 about an auction of 20th-century art and design held on Wednesday at the William Doyle Galleries, in Manhattan, misstated the birthplace of the furniture designer Jens Risom. He is from Denmark, not Sweden.

title: Italian Insurer to Buy A Unit of Swiss Bank
description: Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. of Italy, Europe's third-largest insurer, said yesterday that it was close to buying the Swiss Bank Corporation's Banca Svizzera Italiana unit for as much as $1.3 billion in a bid to expand its money-management operations. ''We are in a good position even though the agreement hasn't been completed yet,'' a spokesman for Generali said. Swiss Bank, Switzerland's No. 3 bank, is scheduled to complete its $33 billion merger with Union Bank of Switzerland this weekend, forming Europe's biggest bank.

title: Senate Allows A Battleship To Be Moved
description: The United States Senate has approved moving the U.S.S. New Jersey from Washington State to Bayonne, clearing the way for the nation's most decorated battleship to be towed to its namesake state and refurbished as a museum.

title: Tiananmen Comment Leads to Clinton-Jiang Debate
description: President Clinton and the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, on live television, engaged in an extraodinary, and at times heated, debate today over China's human rights record.

title: Cirrus Logic and Lucent To Use ARM Processor
description: Shares of ARM Holdings P.L.C. jumped 10 percent yesterday after Cirrus Logic Inc. and Lucent Technologies Inc. said they would work with the company, a British semiconductor maker, on chips that will improve the performance of disk drives.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I told them that there's no way they can do this harmoniously. It will involve some pain.''

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA STRUCTURING CHARGE IS PLANNED
description: Scientific-Atlanta Inc. will cut 275 jobs and take a structuring charge of $60 million to $75 million, but it does not expect the expense to affect its operating earnings for the fourth quarter. The company will eliminate the jobs in October from its Atlanta operations. The company will also record a $100 million gain to adjust the value of 1.5 million shares of the Broadcom Corporation that it owns. The company expects none of the moves, including the construction of a new plant, will hurt earnings. Scientific-Atlanta's satellite services Network Operations Center and research and development operations in Melbourne, Fla., will move to Atlanta.

title: INSIDE
description: Mixed Result in Belfast Vote

title: G.O.P. Prescription
description: They gritted their teeth, but on Wednesday, with their health-care gurus lined up shoulder to shoulder, House Republicans unveiled their plan to patch up managed care with such measures as expanding a patient's ability to choose a doctor and to receive emergency care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, NATHANIEL, M.D.
description: PLOTKIN-Nathaniel, M.D. On June 26th, 1998, following a brief illness. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and compassionate, devoted physician. We will miss you deeply. Services to be held Sunday, June 28, 1998 at 1 P.M. at ''Parkside'' Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. near Avenue V (opposite King's Plaza).

title: When the Cure Becomes a Threat; Suffering in Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge; A Hand That's More Potent Than Its Meager Point Count
description: Some bridge hands have curious features that are not in the least obvious. In reading the following description of the diagramed deal, see if you can spot the oddity. It was played early this month in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Reisinger Knockout Teams. Sitting East and West were Janet and Mel Colchamiro of Merrick, N.Y., whose team reached the final.

title: Officer Is Convicted of Sexually Abusing Woman in Police Station
description: A city police officer was convicted yesterday of sexually abusing a 35-year-old woman who had been taken to the 79th Precinct station house in Brooklyn after a fight with her husband.

title: EX-OFFICER GUILTY IN CHOKING DEATH
description: Former Police Officer Francis X. Livoti, who was accused in the 1994 death of a Bronx man that ignited a passionate debate in New York City about police brutality, was convicted yesterday in Federal court of violating the man's civil rights. He faces up to 10 years in prison.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column on Thursday, about the steps that go into ''good'' publishing, misstated the given name of the editor in chief at W. W. Norton. He is Starling Lawrence, not Starr Lawrence.

title: Liberty Wins To Reach .500
description: LIBERTY 62, MONARCHS 48

title: Carpenter Crushed to Death In New Times Square Tower
description: A carpenter working on the Conde Nast skyscraper in Times Square was fatally injured yesterday morning when he was crushed by an elevator that was lowered as he worked in an elevator shaft.

title: 14-Year-Old Is Found Shot to Death at Home
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was found shot to death yesterday, lying face-down in his bedroom with a shotgun by his side and a box of ammunition nearby, the police said.

title: A Cinderella Story About Lincoln Center
description: Behind all the monumental structures at Lincoln Center is a seemingly small, unobtrusive building. On one side is the high-vaulted Metropolitan Opera House and on the other is the Vivian Beaumont Theater with neon lights billboarding its current theatrical attractions. The middle building, the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, looks like an afterthought. ''The library has long been invisible on this campus,'' says the architect James Stewart Polshek. It is, however, one of the most popular and essential elements of Lincoln Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, GIULIANA
description: FIELD-Giuliana. On January 27, 1998. In Paris, formerly of New York City, wife of Michael Field, daughter of the late Eugenie Weil of New York City & the late Nicola Tabernacolo of Milan & Bari, Italy. Known as actress in U.S. as Juliana Taberna.

title: About New York; Parents Seek Answers At M.S. 136
description: THE final seventh-grade report card Moises Ayala received yesterday from Middle School 136 in Brooklyn had enough 55's on it that it resembled a decent regional weather forecast for the fall. His mother, Marlin Mazier, did not have to look at it to know what it really predicted for September. She had decided weeks ago to yank her son from the Sunset Park school and make him repeat the seventh grade in a local parochial school.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREUND, LUCAS SAMUEL
description: FREUND-Lucas Samuel. December 5, 1981-June 27, 1997. The bird of sorrow shall forever nest in our hair. ''Unforgettable'' Grandma Arlene and Grandpa Joel

title: Field for Philosophizing and Other Dreams; Scholars Look Into Baseball and See the American Essence
description: Beyond the chalk lines that arrow into lush green outfields, beyond the packed dirt and the pristine white bases, beyond the dugouts and the scoreboards that chart wins and losses, beyond the thousands of baseball players who have lashed away at pitched balls, there is a grander Elysian field: simply, the idea and meaning of baseball.

title: Too Much Pessimism on AIDS Therapies
description: Thousands of researchers will gather in Geneva tomorrow for a weeklong conference on AIDS -- and the challenge will be not only to discuss advances in the treatment of a virus that has infected more than 30 million people worldwide, but to conquer our own pessimism as well.

title: A Clear Ruling on Harassment
description: With a pair of 7-to-2 decisions yesterday, the Supreme Court ended its term on a constructive note by strengthening the law governing sexual harassment in the workplace. The rulings, in cases from Boca Raton, Fla., and Chicago, reasonably interpreted Title VII of the Civil Rights Act to hold that an employer can be held liable for sexual misconduct by supervisors, whether or not the employer knew about it. The Court also said the employer can be liable whether or not the employee suffered adverse job consequences for refusing a supervisor's unwelcome advances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, CHESTER SYDNEY
description: FRIEDMAN-Chester Sydney. On June 26, 1998 in his 91st year. Loving husband of Rayminnie. Beloved sister of Gertrude Glaubman. Adored father of Joseph and Rita Aron. Beloved grandfather of Michael and David Friedman and Jonathan and Timothy Aron. Graveside service June 28th, 1998. Contributions to the Women's Auxiliary of Temple Emanu-El.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENSTEIN, JOSEPH S.
description: LOWENSTEIN-Joseph S. On June 23, 1998 after a courageous battle with cancer. Son of the late Salomon and the late Sylvia. Best friend and brother of Steve and brother-in-law of Inge. Admired uncle of David and Michael Lowenstein. Much loved nephew of Ruth Ciner. Devoted cousin of Joe Lowenstein, Jane Michaels, Liz Schott, Jonny Ciner, Jimmy and Helene Altschul. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Thursday & Friday 7-9PM. Service at Frank E. Campbell, Sunday, June 28th at 2:30PM. Interment private.

title: Corrections
description: The Pop Life column on June 17 about the continuing popularity of the Japanese rock star Hide, who died on May 2, misstated the title of his most recent No. 1 single. It is ''Ever Free,'' not ''Stay Free.''

title: Think Tank; A Trove of Telltale Tapes
description: One historian calls them the ''Dead Sea Scrolls of American political history.'' Another compares them to the discovery of Pompeii.

title: Political Memo; Diplomatic Chancellor Wins Little in Albany
description: Among the biggest losers in Albany this month, by his own admission, was Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew.

title: Balmy Days Give Way to Sauna's Heat Across the Northeast
description: Yesterday was the kind of day when the humid air was as palpable as a damp rag. It was the kind of day that brought to mind an expansive health club steam cabinet or, if you were a Russian immigrant lolling on the boardwalk in Brighton Beach, a banya, the rustic Russian equivalent of a sauna.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARAF, BEATRICE F.
description: BARAF-Beatrice F. Of Palm Beach, Florida. Died June 25, 1998. Wife of the late Samuel L. Baraf and the late Arthur Block. Born Brooklyn, N.Y. September 14, 1910. Beloved mother of Libby Lovett (Nelson), Charles Baraf (Jeri), Joseph Baraf, Donald Baraf (Marlena), Robert Baraf (Leslie) and Herbert Baraf (Cheryl). Beloved grandmother of Michael Lovett, Onnie Schiffmiller (Andrew), Andrew Baraf (Mayze), Susan Maness (Elliot), Josh Cender, Alison Baraf, Meredith Baraf, Arthur Baraf, Eduardo Baraf, Emily Baraf, Samantha Baraf and Zachary Baraf. Beloved great-grandmother of Jonah and Rina Schiffmiller and Hillary Maness. Beloved friend of Marie Kwalwasser and Pauline Blackwell. Services at Nassau North Chapels, North Station Plaza, Great Neck, L.I. 10AM Sunday. In lieu of flowers contributions to the charity of your choice. She lived a long exciting and fruitful life and touched the lives of many. She was an adored mother, aunt, great-aunt, grandmother and friend to many. She will be missed for years to come.

title: China's Rude Reception
description: The ceremonial part of President Clinton's welcome may be fit for an emperor, but other aspects of the Chinese Government's behavior have looked like calculated insults. By detaining several democracy advocates during the President's stop in Xian and imposing heavy surveillance on other democrats in Beijing, Chinese leaders have seriously embarrassed Mr. Clinton. He must respond personally, publicly and bluntly.

title: U.S. Bars Japanese Who Admits War Crime
description: Two years ago, when the Department of Justice created a list of suspected Japanese war criminals who would be prohibited from entering the United States, veterans and Asian-American groups were delighted. Finally, they said, people who had raped, butchered or experimented on civilians and prisoners during World War II would be treated like the ex-Nazis who faced similar prohibitions.

title: Korea Offers Financing To Industrial Groups
description: South Korea is offering trade financing to some of the nation's top industrial groups for the first time in nine years in an effort to increase exports. Export-Import Bank of Korea, a Government bank, said yesterday that it would lend $1 billion this year to the nation's 26 largest conglomerates. Companies affiliated with the top five business groups -- Hyundai, Samsung, Daewoo, LG and SK -- will remain ineligible.

title: Portrayals Of Disorder Reordered
description: Doug Elkins loves to mix things up. Over the years, he has brought various dance styles together and has borrowed movements from sports, work activities and ordinary life. Often, these combinations have been deliberately goofy.

title: Mark Harrington, 51, Leader Of the MSNBC News Station
description: Mark H. Harrington, a television news executive who managed to get MSNBC, the 24-hour news cable station, up and operating in six months and who directed the CBS News coverage of major events like Presidential conventions and the Olympics, died at his home in Manhattan on Thursday. He was 51.

title: Wide Impact Is Seen for Ruling on H.I.V.
description: Millions of Americans with conditions like diabetes, epilepsy and even infertility and alcohol addiction appear to have won important new protection against discrimination as a result of a Supreme Court ruling on Wednesday, advocates say.

title: An Ex-Officer in CNN's Nerve-Gas Report Disputes Part of It
description: A former military officer on whom the Cable News Network relied prominently for a report maintaining that nerve gas was used in an American attack during the Vietnam War has disputed key points of CNN's representation of his account.

title: ESCALADE TO SELL ITS SPORTING GOODS BUSINESS
description: Escalade Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its sporting goods equipment business to JEN Sports, a unit of the closely held Sportcraft Ltd, for $74.5 million to focus on its office and graphic arts business. Escalade, which had 1997 revenue of $91.5 million, makes basketball backboards and goals, pool tables and table tennis tables. The company employs 650 people, 400 of them in its sporting goods operations. Sportcraft, based in Mount Olive, N.J., makes darts, dart boards, table games and other sporting goods. The sale will allow Escalade to concentrate on expansion moves.

title: New Jersey Moves to Assume Daily Operation of Camden
description: In an unprecedented intervention into local affairs, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has proposed that New Jersey officials take control of virtually all of Camden's financial dealings.

title: AMP, MAKER OF ELECTRONIC DEVICES, PLANS FURLOUGHS
description: AMP Inc. said yesterday that it planned mandatory one-week furloughs for all of its United States employees and a voluntary early retirement program for some United States workers. AMP, a maker of electronic interconnection devices, said the furlough affected about 22,000 employees, and about 2,200 United States workers would be eligible for early retirement. The one-week furloughs must be taken within the period beginning July 4 and ending Aug. 15. The company attributed the the cost-cutting move to weakening sales in the Asia-Pacific region, higher pricing pressures and a strong dollar. The company has 46,500 employees in 53 countries. AMP, based in Harrisburg, Pa., had 1997 sales of $5.7 billion.

title: Marketspan Forms Panel To Deal With Lilco Furor
description: Facing a mounting array of investigations and lawsuits, Marketspan's board today appointed a special committee to deal with all litigation arising from $67 million in payments made to its executives who were at the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 11 about Marjorie Lansing, a political scientist, misstated the location of her alma mater, Florida State College for Women. The college, now known as Florida State University, is in Tallahassee, not Gainesville. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Headmaster Ousted From Harlem School He Founded
description: Thirty-two years ago, an eccentric poet named Ned O'Gorman hatched a neighborhood preschool inside a battered Harlem storefront and tended it as it grew into a private, tuition-free academy from prekindergarten through eighth grade. Since then, he has taught his charges to read Greek and perform Shakespeare, escorted some of them to exclusive prep schools and buried others in early graves.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK WEAKENS. Concerns mounted about weakness in Russia, where German banks and companies have significant investments, pressuring the mark. The dollar surged to 1.8105 marks, from 1.7992 marks on Thursday.

title: Serbian Forces Mass For Strike on Kosovo
description: Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States special envoy, ended his mission to Kosovo empty-handed and with little hope of peace in the province or even of preventing an assault that appeared immiment.

title: Journal; Thin-Skinned U.S.A.
description: A show must be censored because it is not only ''pornographic'' but presents an ethnic group as ''backward and ignorant.'' Who could be speaking? Was it the Catholic League for Religious and Civil Rights, which has campaigned against Terrence McNally's ''gay Jesus'' play, ''Corpus Christi''? Or was it the Hispanic groups that protested ''Seinfeld''? Or was it the black employees at the Library of Congress, whose protest led to the tearing down of an exhibit about slavery? Or was it the Southern Baptist Convention, which found a clergyman in purported sexual arousal in Disney's animated ''Little Mermaid''?

title: For Jasper, Just What It Didn't Want
description: Terrya Mitchell, who is black, is taking her 16-year-old daughter to Houston early Saturday morning, to go skating. Steve Seale, who is white, is leaving town before dawn, to go fishing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DWYER, PAUL
description: O'DWYER-Paul. What a privilege to have been at your side. You showed us the righteousness and joy of a life spent in the passionate pursuit of freedom, justice, equality, peace and the dignity of man. You brought Thomas Paine's ''Common Sense'' to life in Mayo, the North, Jerusalem, Johannesburg, Hattiesburg, Harrisburg and New York. Your legacy continues to multiply with each new generation inspired by your enduring advocacy, commitment and leadership. Paul Nussbaum

title: Officer Was Justified In Search, Court Rules
description: The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a Fort Lee police officer was correct in searching a man for drugs after he saw him ride a bicycle from Manhattan across the George Washington Bridge to an area known as a stop-over for drug traffic.

title: FONOROLA ADVISES HOLDERS TO ACCEPT NEW OFFER
description: Reversing its earlier stance, Fonorola Inc., Canada's fourth-biggest long-distance provider, advised its shareholders yesterday to accept Call-Net Enterprises Inc.'s sweetened takeover offer of $1.97 billion (Canadian) including debt, after failing to attract superior bids from abroad. Call-Net, the Canadian affiliate of the Sprint Corporation, will pay $67 in cash or 2.68 Call-Net nonvoting shares for each Fonorola share. The debt it is assuming totals $171 million. Fonorola, based in Montreal, will pay shareholders a 50-cent-a-share special dividend. The agreement will create Canada's second-biggest long-distance company after Bell Canada. Fonorola rose $1.20, to $67.20, on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Call-Net's class B shares rose $2.30, to $25.30.

title: Nureyev Foundation Upheld In Dispute With the Family
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan has ruled in favor of the Rudolf Nureyev Dance Foundation in Chicago in a dispute with Nureyev's family over the $7 million from the dancer's estate used to establish the foundation.

title: Panel Unimpressed by Secret Service Claim
description: A Federal appeals court today greeted with considerable skepticism the Clinton Administration's claim that Secret Service agents should not have to testify in the Lewinsky matter.

title: David Ayalon, 84, Israeli Scholar Of Muslim History and Arabic
description: David Ayalon, a scholar of Muslim history who pioneered research on the Mameluke dynasties of Egypt and compiled what is considered the most authoritative Arabic-Hebrew dictionary, died in Jerusalem on Thursday. He was 84.

description: When finance ministers and investment strategists have nightmares these days, they often involve huge financial institutions that are hardly household words in the West.

description: Despite others' projections of a hefty budget surplus next year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he planned $427 million in cuts to counteract what he called overspending by the City Council.

title: Editorial Observer; Is Viktor Orban Too Old to Lead Hungary?
description: Viktor Orban, the Prime Minister-designate of Hungary, celebrated his 35th birthday last month, and many are wondering if power has not found him too late. Across the former East Bloc some of the most dynamic, Westernized politicians are relatively youthful. The most influential are Sergei Kiriyenko, Russia's 35-year-old reformist Prime Minister, and his deputy Boris Nemtsov, 38. In American terms they are free-market Republicans on economics, liberal Democrats on social issues. Mr. Orban, whose statist politics are just the reverse, was like them once, back when he was young.

title: City Official Is Sorry for Remark Some Thought Was Anti-Semitic
description: The Commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration apologized yesterday for making an errant remark during a television interview that was construed by some viewers as anti-Semitic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZANKEL, HARRY
description: ZANKEL-Harry. Beloved husband of Hazel. Devoted father of Lewis (Sharon) and Robert (Sekai). Dear grandpa of Astara and Miriam. Caring brother of Charles, Irving and Hilda Lieberman. Retired Chairman of the NYS Unemployment Appeals Board. Funeral Sunday, 12:30 PM, at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre.

title: Money and Other Hardening Positions in Strikes at G.M.
description: Losses to the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union from strikes at two parts factories here have soared far beyond the actual money involved at the factories, making it harder with each passing day for either side to paint an eventual settlement as a victory.

title: Ulster Vote Puts Power-Sharing Pact at Risk
description: Parties committed to the Northern Ireland peace settlement emerged the winners today in the election for the new Assembly, but candidates opposed to the accord won enough seats to call into question the value of that victory.

title: Serb Buildup Seen in Kosovo as Envoys Depart in Failure
description: Serbian forces, planes and heavy weapons are massing for large-scale attacks to recapture pockets of Kosovo held by ethnic Albanian rebels and to reopen roads the separatists have blocked for weeks, Western diplomats and military officials said today.

title: The Nets' Potential Owners Considering Sites in Newark
description: A group of New Jersey businessmen that plans to buy the controlling interest in the Nets next week is still trying to determine where the team will play.

title: OFFERS FOR BRITISH REFINERY UNIT ARE UNDER STUDY
description: The Chevron Corporation, the fourth-biggest United States oil company, said yesterday that it was willing to consider offers for its mothballed British refinery unit, as a Dutch oil trader said it was in talks to buy all or part of the unit's assets. The unit, Gulf Oil Refining Ltd., consists of a refinery in Milford Haven, Wales. The Rotterdam-based Petroplus International B.V. said it was negotiating to buy all or parts of the refinery. It has been shut since December and could fetch as much as $250 million if sold in its entirety, analysts said. Tough competition and shrinking profit margins forced the San Francisco-based Chevron out of the European refining and fuel-sales business.

title: America's Queen of Salsa; Singer's Popularity Rides Waves of Immigration
description: Many Americans have never heard of her, yet she has a nonstop schedule of sold-out concerts, a Grammy on a shelf in her New Jersey home and a street named after her in Miami.

title: Citing Facts, Bush Spares Texas Inmate On Death Row
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas agreed today to save the life of one of the nation's most notorious multiple murderers rather than see him executed for a murder he may not have committed.

title: Excerpts From Decisions on Law on Sexual Harassment in Workplace
description: Following are excerpts from today's Supreme Court decisions in two sexual harassment cases, Burlington Industries v. Ellerth and Faragher v. City of Boca Raton. The opinion in the Burlington case was written by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy and that in the Boca Raton was by Justice David H. Souter. Joining them in the majorities were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Stephen G. Breyer, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Sandra Day O'Connor and John Paul Stevens. Dissenting opinions, which are also excerpted, were filed by Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas.

description: The stock market finished a strong week yesterday, as blue-chip issues rode into record territory despite longstanding fears about the economic crisis in Asia.

description: As if Alabama's Republican gubernatorial race has not been odd enough, the campaign between Gov. Fob James Jr. and Winton Blount 3d has been dominated in its final week by the possibility that it may be decided by Democrats.

description: BRAND-Herbert Edward. Age 84. Of Alexandria, VA. Formerly of Fair Lawn, N.J. On June 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Florence. Loving father of Stanley Brand & Maxine Green. Devoted brother of Frances Bush. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Peter, Stephanie and Jennifer. Adoring great grandfather of Rebecca and Ryan. Director of Public Relations of the Seafarers International Union and a variety of other positions, 19461967. Chairman of the Board Transportation Institute 19671980. Graduate of the University of Alabama. Member Navy League of the U.S. Services at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, New Jersey, 10:30AM Monday, June 29. Interment following at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, N.J. Donations to Hospice of Northern Virginia, POB 922, Falls Church, VA. 22040.

title: Girl Power (and Merchandise)
description: Scary Spice can sing. Sporty Spice can dance (or at least do high kicks). Baby Spice and Posh Spice are passable at both tasks. And competence is all the four Spice Girls need to activate the most cleverly conceived and slickly marketed pop package since Madonna showed them the blueprints.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, PETER T.
description: JOSEPH-Peter T. Beloved husband of Wendy Evans, and loving and adoring father of Danielle and Nicholas, died on June 25, 1998 from cancer at age 47 at home. He was Chairman and CEO of Rosecliff, Inc., a merchant banking firm, Chairman of the Board of Governing Trustees of American Ballet Theatre, board member of The Second Stage Theater and Prep for Prep, and member of the Rockefeller University Council. Leading patron and collector of studio art furniture, he was the founder and owner of The Peter Joseph Gallery which exhibited studio art furniture in New York City from 1991 to 1997. He was a graduate of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University & Yale Law School. He is survived by his loving mother, Evelyn Joseph, brother Michael Joseph of Olney, IL, sisters Mary Joseph and Eleanor Joseph both of Atlanta, GA., brother Thomas Joseph and sister Evelyn Joseph both of Cincinnati, OH., sister Margaret Joseph of Nashville, TN, sister Kathleen Reinhart of Dayton, OH as well as 13 nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Sunday 2-4PM & 6-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, Monday 10AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contribtions may be sent to American Ballet Theatre, 890 Broadway, New York, NY 10003.

title: Cheering Roy Goodman, for the Arts and His Art
description: Calling himself ''a most cogent argument for term limits,'' Roy M. Goodman celebrated his 30th anniverary in the State Senate at a fund-raising dinner on Thursday night that drew many arts figures sustained over the years by grants he has delivered from Albany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERDOFF, RUBIN
description: BERDOFF-Rubin. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins the physicians and staff of the Beth Israel Heart Institute in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Rubin Berdoff, father of our esteemed friend and colleague, Russell Berdoff, M.D., a member of the Beth Israel family for nearly two decades. We extend our sympathies to Dr. Berdoff, the entire Berdoff family, and all who loved him. Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President Stephen G. Baum, M.D., Chairman, Department of Medicine Thomas Killip, M.D., Director of the Beth Israel Heart Institute

title: Sub's Goal Infiltration, Seoul Says
description: South Korean Army officers said today that they had found evidence that the North Korean submarine caught this week in a fishing net had been engaged in an infiltration mission and had just picked up or dropped off spies or commandos.

title: O'Neill's Bat Salvages Torre's Experiment
description: Paul O'Neill walked across the Shea Stadium outfield alone four hours before last night's monumental matchup between the Yankees and Mets, wandering like a person who did not want to get noticed. A dozen of O'Neill's teammates had disappeared into the third base dugout, yet he crept so deliberately it was easy to overlook him.

title: Chef at Lespinasse Announces Resignation
description: Gray Kunz, the chef at Lespinasse, the luxury restaurant in the St. Regis Hotel, has announced that he is leaving the restaurant. His last day will be on July 25.

title: China Spurns A U.S. Call For Meeting Dalai Lama
description: China's senior religious official today vehemently rejected proposals, to be advanced by President Clinton during his summit meeting on Saturday, that China engage in discussions with the Dalai Lama over greater autonomy for Tibet.

title: F.B.I. Says Man Is Terrorist, but Family Sees Plot by Ex-Wife
description: In the eyes of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Hany Kiareldeen is a Palestinian terrorist who helped plot the World Trade Center bombing and planned to kill Attorney General Janet Reno.

title: DAOU SYSTEMS ADDING INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY CONCERN
description: Daou Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Resources in Healthcare Innovations, an information technology services company, for $54 million as the company, a maker of computer networks, seeks to expand the services it offers. Daou, which serves about 1,300 health care customers, said the closely held RHI installs software for information-systems companies that focus on the health care industry. RHI serves more than 150 hospitals and will add a staff of about 150, giving Daou a total of 738 employees. The San Diego-based Daou said the acquisition would allow it to offer more services to attract clients. Shares of Daou rose $2.1875, to $22.4375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLECHER, BENJAMIN
description: BLECHER-Benjamin. Of Forest Hills, NY. On Friday, June 26, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Marion (nee Goolnick). title: CONSOLIDATION CAPITAL SETS $181 MILLION IN ACQUISITIONS
description: The Consolidation Capital Corporation has agreed to acquire four electrical and mechanical contracting businesses and three janitorial service companies for a total of $181 million in cash and stock. Consolidation Capital, based in Washington, D.C., provides facilities with maintenance services, including electrical, mechanical and janitorial work. Only one of the acquisitions is already definite -- that of the Lewis Companies, a Tulsa, Okla., operator of three electrical and mechanical installation and service businesses.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT TUMBLES. Wheat prices fell on signs that Iraq had bought wheat from American rivals in the export market, suggesting that United States prices were too high. July wheat dropped 7 cents, to $2.82 a bushel.

title: Graf Loses Her Composure and Match
description: Her racquet hand turned limp as a noodle, her serve had no sting and the forehand she had always depended on to scare her challengers half silly was totally missing. Although it was cold and wet enough today to make her teeth chatter, panic had already set in and had the same effect.

title: Woman, 81, Found Slain In Bathtub in Harlem

title: Clinton, in Beijing Square, May Tread on the Ghosts
description: Tiananmen Square is the symbolic center of Communist China.

title: Decision Heartens Jones Team
description: Paula Corbin Jones's lawyers said today that the Supreme Court's decision in favor of a Chicago businesswoman would help them in their appeal to have Ms. Jones's sexual harassment suit against President Clinton reinstated.

title: 8-Fight $30 Million Deal Makes Trinidad Smile
description: Felix Trinidad, the International Boxing Federation welterweight champion, was beaming yesterday, because for the first time in a long time he felt like a star. Main Events and HBO held a news conference to announce an eight-fight $30 million deal with Trinidad, one of the best but most unheralded boxers in the most competitive division in the sport.

title: School Teaches Job Skills, Not Flower-Arranging; Principal's Foresight
description: To the Editor:

Sister of Reverend Harold F.X. O'Donnell, S.J. Friends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, New York, on Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass of Christian burial, Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Monday 10 A.M. Donations to the American Cancer Society, 2 Lion Place, White Plains, New York 10601.

title: Camby Joins Knicks, Hoping to Fit In
description: There was nothing frail in his voice -- which neither broke nor cracked -- making Marcus Camby's first major move as a Knick injury free.

title: Bolivia's Crackdown on Coca Growers Becomes Increasingly Deadly
description: Coca growers ambushed a drug-eradication team near this rebellious hamlet one day early this month, leaving one policeman dead and three wounded. The next day 600 soldiers and policemen barreled through the jungle in a show of force.

title: Leiter Exits, Bullpen Blows Up
description: Desperation. That was the only word that could describe the move Bobby Valentine was forced to make in the top of the seventh inning last night after the Mets' manager learned that his injured starter, Al Leiter, could not go on.

title: 9 North Koreans Dead in Submarine
description: SEOUL  The bodies of nine North Korean sailors and agents were discovered Friday inside a captured North Korean midget submarine, shot and killed in what South Korean officials called an apparent murder-suicide.

title: Norway Has Its Opponents Worried
description: The five Flo brothers grew up along Norway's northern fjords, playing soccer inside the house with Ping-Pong balls. The brothers divided into teams, but the only real loser was the furniture, according to midfielder Jostein Flo.

title: Beliefs
description: Doesn't Sir Sigmund Sternberg, the British businessman, Jewish philanthropist and inveterate promoter of interfaith understanding, ever get tired of receiving awards? It may not have been the most diplomatic question to ask Sir Sigmund, who was in New York for a ceremony at the United Nations honoring him for receiving the $1.23 million Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, but it also seemed unavoidable.

title: Is Irabu Tipping Pitches?
description: A day before the series was to begin, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine hinted to reporters that Hideki Irabu, the Yankees' starter last night, was tipping his pitches. In fact, both the Yankees and the Mets believe that Irabu provided clues that contributed to his beating in Cleveland last Sunday.

title: Charles Korvin, 90, Film Actor Who Played Cads
description: Charles Korvin, an actor who made a career playing gentleman thieves and philandering husbands, died on June 18 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 90 and had homes in Manhattan and Klosters, Switzerland.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: On O'Neill's Homer, Yanks Draw First Blood
description: Rivers of blue caps formed in the aisles at Shea Stadium after the eighth inning last night. They were Mets fans, defeated, depressed and departing. Above them, a mocking chorus started: ''Hey, hey, na, na, goodbye.'' The Yankee faithful serenaded their counterparts as they headed for the trains and the parkways and the bridges.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., announced plans to provide the turbines for a $1.5 billion thermal power plant to be built in China by a joint U.S.-Chinese venture.

title: New Acting Dean For Rutgers Law School
description: A professor of constitutional law at Rutgers Law School in Newark has been named acting dean, two weeks after Roger I. Abrams was ousted after mutual recriminations between him and Rutgers University President Francis L. Lawrence over who lost a $4 million gift to the school's $49 million justice center, which is under construction.

title: Television; That's E! for Entertainment (and Erotica?)
description: YOU don't have to be disgraced or disrobed to get a starring role on E! Entertainment Television. But lately it does seem to help.

title: Porn Markdown: Sex Shops Make Room for Tamer Fare
description: While the fate of the new law barring sex shops from many areas of the city is still tied up in Federal court, some adult establishments in midtown are already staging half-price sales and switching their displays and inventory to less racy material.

title: When to Retire? Planners and Workers Are on Opposite Paths
description: THEY are the boys of endless summers, measuring lives in golf putts and long winter vacations in Florida and saying daily prayers of gratitude that they had the wisdom, foresight and luck to take early retirement.

title: Mexico Squeezes Rebels, Provoking New Grief
description: The Mayor of this country town in the southern state of Chiapas should be a happy man. Instead he is in anguish.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 31 about the financial crisis in Asia misstated an amount of Korean bonds offered for sale worldwide in April. The amount was $4 billion, not $3 billion. The article also omitted the name of the company that managed the offering with Goldman, Sachs. It was Salomon Smith Barney.

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Flex Buildings for High-Tech Companies Proliferate
description: FOR three decades the 273,000-square-foot bakery and corporate office structure was a fixture on Riverview Drive in Totowa. But the bakery, where Thomas's English Muffins were once made, shut down 18 months ago and the site later was sold to new owners who plan to convert it into a high-tech building.

title: Theater; A Loony Landmark That Inspired A Seventh-Grader
description: Dinosaurs, creeping walls of ice, hunger, wars -- these are among the ingredients of the play ''The Skin of Our Teeth,'' Thornton Wilder's condensed (three acts) history of the human race. Wilder had already won a Pulitzer Prize for ''Our Town,'' when, five years later, in 1943, he won again for ''The Skin of Our Teeth.''

title: Deirdre Morton, Francis Carr Jr.
description: Deirdre Elisabeth Morton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen S. Morton of New York, was married yesterday to Francis Thomas Carr Jr., a son of Mrs. and Mrs. Carr of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Robert G. Tarche performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Richmond.

title: How Guthrie Deleted an Island
description: Staten Island gets no respect, no respect at all, many of its residents say. Never mind that the borough voted 2 to 1 to secede from New York City in 1993. The State Legislature, which rules on such declarations of independence, chose not to notice. Now Staten Island appears to have been cheated of recognition once again.

title: Small Victory for a Bicyclist
description: Roberta Fineberg hoped that the summons she got for riding her bike on the sidewalk along Court Street would serve as a legal test case in which she would emerge the winner.

title: Artifacts From a Nation as Old as It Is Young
description: EXODUS praises the first Jewish craftsman, Bezalel, who made the Ark of the Covenant, and firstborn males in artistic Jewish families are frequently given his name. It is also the name of a renowned school in Jerusalem famous for the arts and crafts produced there since it opened in 1906. To commemorate the 50th anniversary of the state of Israel, the Newark Museum has installed ''Ancient Land, New Style: Jewish Arts and Crafts From Jerusalem, 1906-1980,'' in which the history of the Bezalel School is told through more than 50 objects.

title: With Ball Fields, Battery Park City May Grow Taller
description: Take heart, downtown athletes: your temporary riverside ball fields will be temporary no longer.

title: Revving Up on Nighttime Motorcycle Noise
description: More than 120 people, mostly motorcycle fans and foes, packed a meeting of Community Board 2 on Tuesday to talk about noise; specifically, the ear-splitting, sleep-wrecking scream of altered bikes.

title: OPINION; $80 Million a Year in Traveler's Aid
description: Talk to visitors from other areas and one of the first things they say to Long Islanders is, ''The congestion on the roads, how can you stand it?''

title: Ozzy Osbourne
description: Ozzy Osbourne, 49, helped originate horror-inspired, teen-mayhem rock. He's currently on tour with ''Ozzfest '98.''

title: Sport of The Times; Liberty and the Pros Win Summitt Over
description: YOU could practically hear the gears turning in Pat Summitt's head as she and her star player, Chamique Holdsclaw, watched the New York Liberty slay yet another dragon at Madison Square Garden last week.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Sports of The Times; A Time-Study Man Monitors the World
description: MR. BLATTER is happy. Production is up. Mr. Blatter consults his clipboard and his stopwatch and his computer printouts. More fouls. Good. More yellow cards. Good. More red cards. Very good.

title: Textiles Find Previous Glory In Restoration
description: AN early afternoon sun flecked thriving strawberry plants at the side of a time-tempered door. The old door opened slowly, revealing a room dominated by an expansive wash table. Sprawled within this bath was a 19th-century Oakleaf quilt, a handsome piece, one of the 375 items handled yearly at the Textile Conservation Workshop here.

title: Talking Baseball, Talking Business
description: EVER since Andrew Rasiej became independently wealthy last year, he has devoted himself to good works. He founded Mouse, which sets up computer networks in public schools. He became president of the New York Nightlife Association. And he has attended almost every Yankee home game. How could I not want to work with a guy like that?

title: A Steady Critical Eye on Film's Shifting Currents
description: SIXTEEN years into his marathon run as the film critic for The New Republic, Stanley Kauffmann sat down in 1974 to write an essay to answer the two questions he was most often asked: How many films do you see in a week? And don't you get bored?

title: Mallets Swing Again
description: Move over, Big Bertha. This summer's swingers are grabbing croquet mallets. The genteel pastime is making a comeback. When choosing a set of painted woods, it's the dustier, the better. Players are combing antique shops for vintage sets. ''A croquet set allows this fantasy where I'm sipping iced tea on the rolling front lawn of a beautiful estate,'' said Lou Sagar, the owner of Zona at 97 Greene Street (Spring Street), which sells sets for about $200. Marcello Soriano, an owner of the Lively Set, an antique shop at 33 Bedford Street, is swamped with requests for croquet gear from those who crave a Gatsby ethos. ''A collection of croquet balls in a metal basket or a mallet hanging on the wall is an extremely popular look,'' he said.

title: The View From/Peekskill; Capturing Fireworks Show on Film in All Its Color and Glitter
description: THERE was the moment everyone had been waiting for. The sky was finally dark and into it shot a slender silver streak, high, higher, until for an instant it held perfectly still. Then it exploded into a chrysanthemum-shaped shower of red, blue and silver stars, a glittering bloom followed by a resounding boom. There was also the moment Janet Barry went to work. While everyone else greeted the start of a recent fireworks show here with relaxed applause and oohs and aahs, Ms. Barry was worrying about light measurements and shutter speeds and unrestricted views. She is a photographer of many things, but fireworks are her biggest love and her newest obsession.

title: The Rural Life; Uproar Over Quiet at the Lake
description: The lake, like thousands of others created by New York's ancient glaciers, is small and remote, a narrow valley of water less than two miles, end to end. At one time, its underground springs nurtured brook trout, and to hear the old fishermen talk, these glistening creatures tasted like no modern food, certainly not like the experimental, acid-resistant species now grown, ''neutered'' and dumped from state helicopters into the lakes below.

description: To the Editor:

description: New Haven Breweries

title: Hartford's Hard-Knock Schooling
description: FOR Robert F. Furek, if this is life in semi-retirement, what must real work be like? He attends meetings almost as a way of life, makes speeches, answers queries from newspapers and television stations. The telephone seems to be ringing all the time -- at his home in West Hartford, at his private office in a business tower in Hartford, at the city's Board of Education building nearby.

title: Radical! New York is Adventure-Sport City
description: A COUPLE of years ago, Eric Stiller, a kayaking instructor who looks like Popeye in Polartec and who once paddled halfway around Australia, was preparing to move to Seattle. Mr. Stiller, who approaches kayaking with an almost religious fervor, was giving up on New York, a city where some people's idea of an adventure sport is diving through closing subway doors.

title: Live Debate On Television Is a Rarity For Chinese
description: What is perhaps most remarkable about today's exchange between President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin is that the debate, covering sensitive topics from human rights to Tibet, was broadcast live all over China, via China Central Television-1, the Government's main television station.

title: A Stark Portrayal, Paint and Sculpture
description: A RETROSPECTIVE covering 15 years of the painting and sculpture of Tobi Kahn is a superficially obvious and easy show. But it has challenging underpinnings. Contributors to the catalogue for the traveling exhibition (titled ''Metamorphoses'' and now at the Thomas J. Walsh Gallery at Fairfield through July 16) claim rich lineages for him.

title: Again, State Frowns At Roosevelt Schools
description: The Roosevelt School District, which in 1996 became the first district in New York history to be taken over by the state, got another jolt this month when the state education commissioner told the school board to fix the worst of the district's lingering problems by mid-August, or else.

title: To Lead A Community
description: LUIS A. PEREZ drove his 1989 Honda Accord through the high iron gate of Drumthwacket in Princeton this month and felt disbelief and exhilaration as he took in the expansive lawn with sycamore, linden and beech trees leading up to the 19th-century Greek Revival mansion that serves as the Governor's official residence.

title: Monique Jethwani And Gene Keyser
description: Monique Marie Jethwani, the daughter of Joyce and Mohan Jethwani of Bayside, Queens, was married last evening to Gene Keyser, a son of Elena and Naum Keyser of Peabody, Mass. The Rev. Peter Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony with Rabbi Irwin C. Lowenheim at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y.

title: A Bigger League Is Playing to the Players
description: WALL STREET'S competitive culture has always been populated by more than a few sports fans. But now the institutions themselves -- banks, brokerage firms, money managers and mutual fund companies -- are developing a love of the game. Or, more exactly, a love of the players and their substantial paychecks.

title: Rangers and Devils Find Diversity in Draft
description: In the Canadian-dominated National Hockey League, it used to be considered exotic if a draft choice came from the United States or the Scandinavian nations. Then the scope expanded to countries of the old Soviet bloc, and it seemed natural last winter for the N.H.L. to stock the top six teams in the Nagano Olympics in Japan.

title: Walking Tours Run Out Fast
description: IF here at the brink of July you are still only dreaming about a bracing stroll in Tuscany, Ireland or perhaps Provence, it is time and possibly past time to act. Some companies report a doubling of demand for walking tours, both circular walks going out from one inn, and from inn to inn. The popularity of walking as a way to see the countryside is linked to the rise of ''soft adventure,'' walking's health benefit and the attraction of making friends on the trip.

title: Money on the Mind
description: If making big money is as important to Matthew Klam as he claims it is, I suggest that he stop whining and get himself a high-paying job while he continues to write; certainly, many before him have done so: John Grisham, Scott Turow, Michael Crichton, to name only the outrageously successful.

Brooks of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Very Rev. Robert Giannini performed the Episcopal ceremony at Oldfields, a Lilly family property that is now part of the Indianapolis Museum of Art.

description: FOR most of the 18 years since Adib Abdelshahed emigrated to New York from Egypt, he and several friends felt like nomads as they searched for a place to worship. They had two requirements: it had to be a Lutheran church and the service had to be in Arabic.

title: Political Briefing; Senator Hires Helpers For Election in 2000
description: Like most of the dozen or so Republicans and Democrats who are exploring the possibility of running for President in 2000, Senator Bob Kerrey has unpaid volunteers working and scouting for him in the early caucus and primary states, particularly Iowa and New Hampshire. And like many of the White House wannabes, Mr. Kerrey, a Nebraska Democrat, also has a political action committee, Bacpac, that helps promote favorite causes (not the least being Senator Kerrey) in significant Election 2000 states, and also helps elect like-thinking state and local officials in those states (help that presumably would be repaid in kind should the Senator ultimately run for President).

title: In This Park, the Views Span Generations
description: IN 1848, Elizabeth Cady Stanton was newly arrived in Seneca Falls, N.Y., and newly desperate. She had left an intellectually rich and materially comfortable life in Boston for a village in western New York State that was much smaller and considerably less developed.

description: It is always excruciating to play against Norway, which compacts its players in defense as if they are posing for a team picture. To prevail requires vigilance and patience and quick precision.

description: THESE are Goldilocks years for the economy, but hardly for economics. Two major assumptions about employment and growth, ideas relied upon by the Federal Reserve to determine whether the economy is too hot, have proved to be considerably less than ''just right.''

title: In Estate Planning, A Roth I.R.A. Shines
description: INVESTORS seeking to take advantage of the single most lucrative feature of the Roth individual retirement account will have to pay a substantial penalty. The ultimate one.

Miller of Greenwich, Conn. Bishop Robert A. Bryan of the Anglican Archdiocese of the North Shore of Quebec, performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Casino Boats Come to a Reluctant Freeport
description: HANDWRITTEN cards placed on the front of four slot machines reserved them for Billy Cornelli of Westbury while he waited for the 145-foot gambling boat, Royal Princess out of the Village of Freeport, to enter international waters three miles offshore. It would be another 20 minutes before the machines could legally be played.

title: A Tag-Sale Show-and-Tell
description: It's hard to avoid a yard sale on Long Island. They're everywhere, every weekend, all summer long. But are they treasure troves or trash heaps? Five reporters set out recently to answer that question. The only condition of the assignment: they could spend no more than $20. Reports on what they found are on page 9.

title: Stalking the Great Woolly
description: Suppose you are the hard-driving chief executive of the XYZ Megacorp-oration. The accelerating drumbeat of supermergers has your blood up: The headlines are full of AT&T's triumphant deal to buy Tele-Communications Inc. for $31.8 billion in stock, and every newspaper clipping from your assistant features a list of the biggest deals in history. As you scan them, M. & A. envy grips you by the throat. You slap a palm on the lacquered cherry board-room table and vow to bag the mammoth merger to beat them all.

description: BERDOFF-Rubin. On June 26, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Pauline. Loving father of Russell & father-in-law of Claire. Cherished grandfather to Alex, Matt, Elizabeth & David. Services Monday 12 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: KERN-Gladys, 89, Beloved wife of the late George I. Kern, loving mother of Abby Chinitz (Morty), Arthur (Sybil), Robert (Miriam), Donna. Sister of Blanche Siegelbaum. Grandmother of Ilene (Spencer),David, Jim (Lori), Dan, Jackie (A.C.). Great grandma of three. Rest in peace, Mother.

description: BRAUMAN-Lillian (nee Heyman). Passed away June 24 at her home in Anchorage, Alaska. She was born in Jersey City, New Jersey, February 14, 1911 and lived most of her life in the New Jersey, New York metropolitan area. She is the beloved mother of Patricia B. Wolf, mother-in-law of Aron S. Wolf, M.D., dear grandmother of Jonathan Paul Wolf, Lisa WolfWendel and Laurie Beth Wolf, and great-grandmother of Alexandre Paul Wolf. She is preceded in death by her parents Irving and Ella Y. Heyman, husband Leonard Paul Brauman, her son Paul Brauman, and her sister Adelade H. Davidson. Funeral arrangements are scheduled for Tuesday, June 30. For further information call Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Anchorage Museum Association, 121 W. Seventh Ave., Anchorage, AK 99501.

title: Dusting Off Death Row; Cellblock Is Readied for the Condemned
description: The rules that will govern Darrel K. Harris's life on death row are dizzying in their detail. Awaiting his execution at Clinton Correctional Facility here, Mr. Harris will be allowed to read the Bible, smoke cigars and wash his hands with a one-ounce bar of soap. He will not be allowed to wear his own clothes, chew gum or play a musical instrument.

title: The World; The New Fear in Israel: Next Year in Jerusalem
description: THROUGH the centuries of dispersion, Jews affirmed the faith that they would eventually return to Zion by declaring, ''Next year in Jerusalem!''
