description: Vintage movies on television this week have a something for every taste: a diva's debut, a boxing drama of exceptional integrity, an apple-pie charade about a loser and a mystical classic.

title: Scoring Jerseys
description: World Cup fever is adding color to the closets of New Yorkers. Fans are heading to the Soccer Sport Supply Company, 1745 First Avenue (near 90th Street), one of the few places where they can find the jerseys of all 32 teams in the tournament; they are $58.95 each. Teams like Brazil, Italy and the United States account for most sales, but jerseys from underdog teams with winning designs are also moving in record volume, said Jeffrey and Herman Doss, brothers and owners of the store. Among the hottest sellers: Morocco's bright red shirt with green stripe; South Africa's white, gold and green shirt, and Jamaica's gold jersey emblazoned with a crescent moon. ''The Jamaican jersey was a beautiful design and we had all the reggae boys coming in to buy it,'' Scott Davidson, a salesman, said. ''We have every ethnicity buying our shirts. You should see this place on a busy day. Everybody's ribbing each other.'' So far, no fan brawls.

title: In This District, Routine Document Is Anything But
description: The scene in front of P.S. 20 on Essex Street Tuesday night was a regular who's who of downtown radicals. The squatters, looking grungy and grumpy, were there in force, holding banners and smoking hand-rolled cigarettes. The pirates, as in radio, also made an appearance, gossiping about a crackdown on an illegal station in Philadelphia. And there was the Lower East Side Collective, a group of college-educated activists who favor khaki and mountain bikes.

title: Alexander Pregel, Uranium Dealer, Dies at 91
description: Alexander Pregel, a worldly Russian-born dealer in uranium and other radioactive elements, died on June 6 at Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 91 and lived in Sarasota.

title: The Silvermine Guild, 75 Years Later
description: A TRIO of exhibitions will celebrate Solon Borglum and the Silvermine Guild that he founded 75 years ago. Altogether they offer a feast of art and nature.

title: Classical Music; Tanglewood: How Festive A Festival?
description: THE Tanglewood Music Center in Lenox, Mass., the most prestigious summer training institute for young musicians in the United States, has just begun its 49th season, and much attention will be focused on Seiji Ozawa, who, as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, oversees artistic matters at the center. Over the last two summers, Mr. Ozawa fomented a shakeup, which provoked angry, noisy resignations from respected leaders of the center: the pianist and conductor Leon Fleisher, who had been artistic director for 12 years, and the pianist Gilbert Kalish, who had served on the faculty for nearly 30 years, the last 12 as chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, EDWARD N., MD
description: BRENNAN-Edward N., MD. On June 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Alice (nee MacHardy), father of Elizabeth of Old Greenwich, CT, Noel of New York City. and Alison Shutt of Potomac, Maryland, grandfather of Claire, Molly and Caroline. Funeral mass Monday 11:00 AM, Saint Michael's, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT.

title: Amy Batkin, Randal Knox
description: Amy Michelle Batkin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan R. Batkin of Greenwich, Conn., is to be married today to Randal Knox, the son of Rita Smith of Tappan, N.Y., and Richard Knox of Sherman Oaks, Calif. Rabbi Melvin Sirner is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: In Trenton, Votes on Stolen Pets, Divorce, Horse Racing and a Lot More
description: A busy week in the Legislature included action on a bill that would make the state Insurance Commissioner responsible for making sure that shareholders are protected during a reorganization of the Newark-based Prudential Insurance Co. of America.

title: The View From/Westport; Honor Roll Scrambles Into Place at Town Hall
description: EDWARD KEEHAN, a World War II veteran, sat at the small table in Westport's James Clinton V.F.W. Post 399 hall eating his open roast beef sandwich with gravy, beneath a framed Dec. 4, 1943, Saturday Evening Post cover illustration by the Westport artist Stevan Dohanos. The illustration showed a World War II Honor Roll of 580 residents who served in the war.

title: Laurie Katz, Andrew Braun
description: Rabbi Laurie Beth Katz and Andrew Ira Braun are to be married today at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Norman J. Cohen, the provost of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Harry and Bess at Home
description: AMID suburban sprawl and six lanes of traffic whizzing along Highway 71 just south of Kansas City, Mo., the simple sign seemed to peek out from the past. ''Truman Farm. Next Right,'' it announced. I swung off, following the ramp past the sign welcoming me to Grandview, Mo., then under the railroad overpass and up to Blue Ridge Boulevard. A strip mall on the corner offered Arby's, White Castle, Blockbuster Video and more. As I continued southwest along Blue Ridge, the unadorned backside of the Truman Corners Shopping Center was on the left, Pizza Hut on the right.

title: Amanda Ells, John Ulrich 3d
description: Amanda Lewis Ells, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Ells of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to John L. C. Ulrich 3d, the son of Mrs. Ulrich Jr. of Paoli, Pa., and the late Mr. Ulrich. The Rev. Wayne Jacobson, a Congregational minister, officiated at the Stony Creek Church of Christ in Stony Creek, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Paul Smith, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Rich Homestretch for Skip Away
description: Sonny Hine sat in the little office in Barn 1 at Belmont Park last week and reflected on the impact that Skip Away had had on his life: winning 15 races, running in the money 30 times in 33 starts and earning $8.3 million. But mostly Hine reflected on the impact that he expected Skip Away to make during the next four months as he enters the homestretch of a career with one purpose: to become the richest horse in racing history.

title: Killing of a Clubgoer Isn't Relevant to the Club
description: To the Editor:

title: Architecture; Designing Museums: Often Not a Lively Art
description: FOR some, the ''culture wars'' between liberals and conservatives have been at best a sideshow. The main event (it's been going on since the Renaissance) has been the struggle between artists and politicians. Artists understand that creativity invites destruction. Politicians prefer to snack on sweetness and light.

title: Bombshells Into Cowbells
description: Officially, the United States' bombing of Laos and Cambodia never happened. But ample evidence to the contrary was left behind. Today, more than two decades after America ended its conflict with Vietnam, unexploded B-52 bombs and thousands of dud artillery shells, napalm pods and discarded fighter-jet fuel tanks still litter the earth. Many of them have been hollowed out for new roles as garden planters, canoes, cowbells, house stilts and even jewelry.

title: COPS AND GOWNS
description: * Tomorrow, 1,042 new officers will graduate from New York's Police Academy in an 11 A.M. ceremony at Madison Square Garden. * Concession stands and food courts will be operating, but no beer will be sold. * All policemen get a $1,000 annual uniform allowance; only badges and handguns are issued by the city. * The privately owned P.A. Shop, located near the academy on East 21st Street, is a favorite stop-and-shop for the rookies. The standard nightstick, the PR24, costs $49. * Other goodies: Smith & Wesson handcuffs ($29 and up) and a breakaway clip-on tie ($3). * The favorite hangout for academy cops is the Cosmos Diner on 23d Street, which usually bakes a cake for the grads. * It's a safe dining spot. ''Overnight,'' says Mike Siderakis, who owns Cosmos with his father, Louis, ''there's always a cop car outside.''

title: Julia Hine and Neil Tardio Jr.
description: Julia Sayre Hine, the daughter of Susan J. Hine and C. Clarkson Hine of Shelter Island Heights, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Neil Joseph Tardio Jr., a son of Margaret and Neil J. Tardio of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Ella Eure-Eaton performed the ceremony at the Union Chapel in the Grove.

title: Above the Helix, an Old Library Grows Newer
description: Occupants of the 59,000 cars and trucks that descend into the Lincoln Tunnel daily may have noticed the 5,000-square-foot addition being built onto the Weehawken Library, perched on a small bluff above the tunnel's helix. ''Usually they're bumper to bumper, so they've got plenty of time to see it,'' said Mayor Richard Turner, who helped secure $2 million in local bonds, Federal grants and loans from Hudson County to double the library's size. The project is to be finished in about two months.

title: Still Life With Pickle
description: Celebrating everything from the Bonnard retrospective to wildlife to a wedding.

title: Ideas & Trends: Crash Course; Learning From the Big Booms
description: SUDDENLY, these are nervous times for prosperity fans. The stock market has the jitters; after going straight up all winter it has been stuck in place since April. The Asian economic boom, another great engine of American prosperity, is over. And the nation's economy shows signs of slowing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALLONE, MARION (DOLLY) NEE O'DONNELL
description: PALLONE-Marion (Dolly) nee O'Donnell. On June 25, 1998. Wife of Robert James Pallone. Mother of Marjorie Pallone LoBono. Mother-in-law of Joseph Anthony LoBono. Sister of Reverend Harold F.X. O'Donnell, S.J. Friends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, New York, on Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass of Christian burial, Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Monday 10 A.M. Donations to the American Cancer Society, 2 Lion Place, White Plains, New York 10601.

title: Students Make Cigar Box Violins
description: SMALL fingers gently coaxed stubborn nylon strings into place, while other craftsmen tightened wooden pegs before strumming their handmade instruments in Micah Henze's second-grade classroom at Hawthorne Pearls Elementary School here.

title: Theater With a Message, for Everyone
description: IF television is a passive activity for children, then live theater is more interactive, demanding some effort on the part of the viewer. Take that one step farther and put a bunch of children in an auditorium with the Grumbling Gryphons, a traveling theater group, and they become cast as well as audience.

title: Protecting the Flag May Be Dangerous; Fighting for Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Ferry Service Fails
description: A year-old ferry service that transported passengers from Peekskill to Bear Mountain and West Point has gone out of business because of a lack of riders.

title: An Artistic Anchor for Teen-Agers Adrift
description: Vienna Steiner-Stammen says she approached her documentary on improving children's lives through involvement in the arts with a healthy dose of skepticism. Could pursuits like glass blowing, ballet or video making help rescue young people from despair?

title: Summary of Major Actions of the 221st Session of the Legislature
description: The 221st session of the New York State Legislature ground to a close at 6:02 P.M. on June 19, not with the usual lofty declarations of achievement and unity, but with a general acknowledgment by lawmakers that, in an election year of partisan attacks and personal animus, many important issues were left unaddressed.

title: A Taxi Rider and Her Personal Commissioner
description: Ever wonder why city taxicabs have raised letter and Braille plaques inside? It's because of RoseMarie McCaffrey.

title: Money on the Mind
description: Klam runs with a circle of friends who can buy emerald-cut diamonds the size of Chiclets and spend $400 at the supermarket and $3,000 on dining-room tables; he grew up in a house with a pool, a tennis court and horses; his picture shows him wearing a St. Albans T-shirt -- all indications of either an ability to cultivate wealthy buddies or, my guess, the likelihood of some kind of inherited nest egg in his future. I don't care what his checking-account balance is this week; he has about as much business calling himself a financial flop as Marie Antoinette did calling herself a shepherdess.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A Great and Glorious Game

title: Bag-Tracking By Phone or Web
description: If your luggage was lost on a Delta Air Lines flight -- ''delayed'' is Delta's euphemism -- there is now something to do other than call an 800 number and listen to recorded messages. The airline has added a feature to its Web site that allows a traveler to learn the status of the bag search. But it can be tracked on the Web only after a passenger arriving at an airport reports the bag missing, describes it and its contents and receives an identification code for what Delta calls a property-irregularity report.

title: Caryn Lander, Joshua Lipchin
description: Caryn Gail Lander, the daughter of Roberta T. Lander of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Edward M. Lander, is to be married this evening to Joshua David Lipchin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marc J. Lipchin of Baltimore. Rabbi Alan Turetz is to officiate at the Hyatt Regency in Cambridge, Mass.

title: CLINTON IN CHINA: REACTION -- Surprising Exchange on Rights on Chinese Television; Clinton's Harsh Words On '89 Massacre Seep Into Beijing's Alleys
description: As evening fell on Yonganli Street, a crowded alleyway of small shops on the east side of town, word was filtering from one doorway to the next about what had been on television at noon: In a nationally televised news conference, President Clinton had come out and said that the Chinese Government's use of military force to suppress the 1989 Tiananmen demonstrations had been tragic and wrong.

title: $33 Million Gift for Columbia Health School Sets Record
description: Columbia University's School of Public Health will announce this week that the Mailman Foundation is giving it $33 million, the largest donation ever to a school of public health.

title: Style; The Body Is Willing
description: It's a rainy Sunday morning in Hollywood, and the Gospel aerobics class at the Crunch gym on Sunset Boulevard has just begun. ''If we ever needed the Lord before,'' sings a small choir to a class of 50 acolytes, who look as if they could use some inspiration, ''we sure do need him now.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, CHESTER SYDNEY
description: FRIEDMAN-Chester Sydney. On June 26, 1998 in his 91st year. Loving husband of Rayminnie. Beloved brother of Gertrude Glaubman. Adored father of Joseph and Rita Aron. Beloved grandfather of Michael and David Friedman and Jonathan and Timothy Aron. Graveside service June 28th, 1998. Contributions to the Women's Auxiliary of Temple Emanu-El.

title: Best Place to Live (Arbitrary Division)
description: COMPARISONS are odious,'' the British legal scholar John Fortescue wrote 500 years ago, but no one today seems to be paying attention, possibly because he wrote it in Latin. We late-20th-century types are forever comparing things, ranking them; we are obsessed with picking the 50 Most Beautiful People in the World, the 100 Greatest Movies of All Time, the Best of ZZ Top.

title: Helping Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Tackling the Issue of Bilingual Education
description: RAPHAEL S. DIAZ, who was born in the Dominican Republic and is now a school trustee here in the state's fourth-largest school system, has found himself at the heart of an intense debate over bilingual education, which is heating up here as it is in other parts of the United States. But unlike some of his fellow immigrants from South and Central America, Mr. Diaz is embracing a move to curtail, not expand, the reach of bilingual classes in this ethnically diverse city.

title: Brief Encounter
description: SHE was about 50, I would guess. Her white face, colored by sun and wind, was deeply lined and utterly unglamorous. She answered the door with a questioning smile, propping a little Indian girl on her hip while an Indian boy, slightly older, paced in front of her skirt. She seemed unafraid, though she let the screen door remain closed between us. I immediately thought of my mother, whom she didn't resemble a bit.

title: June 21-27; Taking a Stand for the Ultra-Rich
description: Representative Bill Archer has used his influence as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee to preserve an inheritance tax break for a few wealthy people that no one, not even Mr. Archer, intended to be in the law in the first place.

title: From Sauce to Soup, Ways to Use the Lemony Taste of Sorrel
description: A FEW years ago I bought a small pot of sorrel and planted it outdoors. Now it threatens to take over the garden. The leaves, which have a tart, lemony taste, are at their peak right now for eating, but when sorrel plants start to blossom later in the summer, the leaves can become very bitter.

title: Two Are Arrested In Assault Case
description: A 59-year-old black man was beaten with a wooden stick by one of two white men who accosted him on 14th Street in Manhattan on Friday night and yelled racial slurs, the police said.

title: Jersey Girl Moves to the Head of the Class
description: Jersey Girl outran the finest field of fillies gathered at any race track this year when she won the Mother Goose Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday for her second victory in the Triple Tiara series, her sixth straight anywhere, and undisputed leadership among 3-year-old fillies.

title: Companies Set To Get Tougher On Harassment
description: With the Supreme Court creating a new national policy on sexual harassment virtually overnight, many companies are moving quickly to re-examine their rules, expecting to adopt tougher measures to meet the Court's standards.

title: If You Can't Stand the Heat, Try This Advice
description: SUMMER is the time when many homeowners tackle outdoor projects like painting, masonry, roof repairs, and deck or fence construction. While the warm temperatures and bright sunshine make it convenient and even enjoyable for outdoor work, too much of a good thing can be dangerous. Overexposure to the sun can result in severe sunburn, heat exhaustion or heatstroke.

title: Mugged in Spain
description: To the Editor: We enjoyed the articles ''Spain: Vistas and Close-Ups'' (May 10), but readers ought to know that there is another side to travel in Spain, a dangerous one.

title: Q&A/Allan H. Weis; Contest Helps Internet Work for Students
description: AS someone who was involved at Ground Zero with the start of the Internet, Allan H. Weis cringes when he encounters news accounts of the bad aspects of the Web for children, including pornography and lack of content. As president and chief executive officer of the Armonk-based Advanced Network and Services and with a lot of extra money on hand, Mr. Weis and his company decided to do something to change that.

title: Tiffany Windows
description: To the Editor: Concerning the Q & A ''Tiffany in Newport'' (May 24). There are two Tiffany windows in Newport, R.I., that John Tschirch, architectural historian at the Preservation Society of Newport County, did not mention. They are to be found in the lovely Trinity Church on Spring Street.

title: June 21-27; Molinari Leaves CBS
description: Susan Molinari's bid to transform herself into the next Katie Couric fell apart, in part because she didn't want to be the next Martha Stewart. Nine months after Ms. Molinari, the former Congresswoman from Staten Island, began a new career as co-host of ''CBS News Saturday Morning,'' she and CBS News have split. Her side says CBS -- leery of criticism that a neutral news program would become a forum for a partisan politician -- tried to steer the cheery Republican into home-and-garden chat and away from important issues. Andrew Heyward, president of CBS News, said she would fare better as a political commentator, but had no such job to offer. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: Shasta Daisies: Ideal Tenants for Garden Vacancies
description: IT is said that Luther Burbank, the horticulturist and plant breeder, made 65,000 unsuccessful crosses between berry varieties before finding the one that produced a white blackberry. Except for the inherent value to botanical science, I'm not sure it was worth the trouble.

title: A Skin-Deep Beauty in Westhampton
description: ATLANTICA is gorgeous. This Westhampton Beach newcomer has leap-frogged over the competition to capture the title of best-looking restaurant in the Hamptons. Given its location on the sea side of Dune Road, diners are prepared for the splendid water views. But those enchanting ocean vistas must share bragging rights with the spectacular dining room.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-11

title: Stars in TriBeCa, Old and New
description: BOULEY BAKERY *** [rating: three stars]

title: Action at the Movie House
description: It used to be a glittering movie palace, delivering fabled Hollywood pictures to a small corner of the East Bronx. Now, the United Artists Interboro Theater, on East Tremont Avenue, is a silent, hulking wreck and neighbors want something done about it.

title: Ms. Roth, Mr. Weston
description: Katharine Kellond Roth, the daughter of Judge Jane R. Roth and Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Christopher Damme Weston, a son of Prof. Mary Ann D. Weston and Michael C. Weston of Evanston, Ill. The Rev. John W. Martiner performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del.

title: Ms. Beauchamp, Mr. Genieser
description: Christine Marie Beauchamp, a daughter of Suzanne C. Beauchamp and Dr. and Mrs. George R. Beauchamp of Dallas, was married on Friday evening to Kevin Scott Genieser, a son of Dr. Nancy B. Genieser and Werner R. Genieser of New York. The Rev. Peter S. Cooke performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Spring Lake, N.J.

title: A True Partnership
description: To the Editor:

title: Unpaid Dues At the U.N. Could Cost U.S. Its Vote
description: The United States could lose its vote in the General Assembly unless it comes up with $211 million to $241 million more than it now expects to pay in United Nations dues and assessments this year, according to a new United States Government estimate.

title: Newly Found Fungus Is Tied To Vanishing Species of Frog
description: A newly discovered fungus appears to be the cause of an epidemic among amphibians that is killing off frogs and toads of a wide variety of declining species in rain forests in Australia and Central America, according to a new report by an international team of researchers. Scientists say the new study may help solve the mystery of why amphibians are vanishing around the world, often from pristine, isolated habitats.

title: June 21-27; Schroder Replaces Smits on 'N.Y.P.D. Blue'
description: Dozens of tall, dark and handsome actors auditioned to replace tall, dark and handsome Jimmy Smits on ''N.Y.P.D. Blue,'' the ABC police drama. The winner was Rick Schroder, of the blond hair and bubbly smile, who is best remembered as Ricky Stratton from the mid-1980's NBC sitcom ''Silver Spoons.'' Now 28, Mr. Schroder will play partner to Detective Andy Sipowicz (Dennis Franz). . Steven Bochco, the executive producer, saw ''great chemistry'' between Mr. Schroder and Mr. Franz in auditions. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: Sosa and Gonzalez Pursue Their Primary Goals and Find Success
description: Together for the first three years of their professional careers, they saw their paths diverge for a decade only to merge again this year. Sammy Sosa and Juan Gonzalez play for different teams, indeed in different leagues, but they are together again in the so-far-successful pursuit of the primary goals they set last winter.

title: The Hippocratic Wars
description: On a dreary Monday several months ago, with the fog blotting out what would otherwise be a splendid view of the Chicago skyline, Dr. George Lundberg, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, stretched across the clutter in his sprawling corner office to confide his latest coup. The lead article in next week's issue, ''Fish Consumption and Risk of Sudden Cardiac Death,'' was, he murmured, ''really hot.'' A steely-eyed pathologist with a finely honed news sense, Lundberg is rarely wrong on such matters, in part because he leaves nothing to chance.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: CALAMITIES OF EXILE Three Nonfiction Novellas. By Lawrence Weschler. University of Chicago, $25.

title: Linden's a Boulevard, but Trucks Put Residents Up a Tree
description: Marcella Williams wakes up most nights to trucks rumbling past her home on Linden Boulevard. Just when she thinks the noise can get no worse, she said, the sound of rubber and metal hitting a pothole rattles her windows and her nerves.

title: Accusations of Hypocrisy On Support for Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: Erotomania
description: THE NOTEBOOKS

title: In Montauk, Gambling Gets a Limited Nod
description: EAST HAMPTON has legislated everything from when a dog can be walked on a beach to what kind of sign shop owners can put in their windows. So it came as no surprise when the town, reacting to a plan to run a high-speed ferry from Montauk to Foxwoods casino in Connecticut, imposed a temporary moratorium on new ferry service in its waters last year, claiming such operations would add to traffic congestion, among other things.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts misstated the number of managerial staff members. It is 8, not 13.

title: Keeping Faith
description: WALKING WITH THE WIND

title: For the Liberty Bell, A Move With a View
description: No tourist attraction in Philadelphia draws more people than the Liberty Bell. Last year, the National Park Service recorded 1.6 million visitors at the modest pavilion where it sits, helping make Independence National Historical Park one of the busiest park service sites.

title: In Wake of Texas Killing, Black Militants and Klan Trade Words, Not Blows
description: Despite fears of violence, a showdown between white supremacists and black militants remained relatively peaceful here on Jasper's lovely courthouse square, leaving residents feeling relieved, but used.

title: Sorenstam Shoots Record 65 and Leads Inkster by 2 Strokes
description: Annika Sorenstam plays golf with such precision and consistency that no one questioned her dominance here today when she made a bogey after 30 holes in the ShopRite L.P.G.A. Classic. The premier player in women's golf responded with three birdies on the last four holes and will have a two-shot lead over Julie Inkster going into Sunday's final day of the $1 million tournament.

title: Real Fencers Don't Use Laser Swords
description: When Luke Skywalker and Darth Vader cross (laser) swords, that's not fencing. When the Scarlet Pimpernel parries and thrusts on Broadway, that's not fencing. And when Olympic competitors duel with swords that trigger scoreboards, that's not fencing, either.

title: Pieces of Advice for Japan
description: Back in the 1980's, Japan was full of advice for the United States: Clean up the Federal deficit, a drag on the world economy. End consumers' addiction to credit cards. Try a little lean production in Detroit. Adopt strict gun-control laws. Make sure that every student can read. Let workers feel that they are part of the company, not just hired help. Oh, and start a bullet train between Boston and Washington.

title: Changes at Nathan's Go Beyond the Menu
description: NATHAN'S FAMOUS, the Westbury-based hot-dog chain whose name is as tied to Coney Island as the old Steeplechase Park, has been edging away from its amusement park roots, and as the company attempts to expand its business, Nathan's has been turning up in some unlikely places.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, PHYLLIS
description: COHN-Phyllis. On June 26, 1998. Widow of Richard E. Cohn. Survived by daughter Dorothy C. Feldman, granddaughter Fern E. Feldman, son-in-law Henry R. Feldman, grand son-in-law Scott L. Zankman, all of Seattle, WA., cousins & nieces and nephews. Memorial service to be held Monday 5 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Slumping; Sliding; Recovering
description: Two weeks ago, Tino Martinez said, he might have popped up. He might have fouled the pitch off. But when Martinez swung at a Bobby Jones curveball in the fourth inning yesterday, he might have broken out of a five-week slide.

title: Proselytizing Teacher Violated Students' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: John Kenny 3d and Heather White
description: Heather Wells White, a daughter of Virginia Towne Latimer of Satellite Beach, Fla., and Stephen Howard White of Dover, N.H., was married yesterday to John A. Kenny 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenny Jr. of Manhasset, N.Y.

title: Orchestra Gives Concerts Aboard a Floating Arts Center
description: The players arrive by gangplank, the audience stays on shore and shrieking gulls or lapping waves enhance the nautical mood. The American Wind Symphony Orchestra, founded 40 years ago by its conductor, Robert Austin Boudreau, performs aboard an extraordinary craft called Point Counterpoint II, a 195-foot, self-powered barge designed by the architect Louis I. Kahn. With a specially built stage, an art museum and a theater, the widely traveled vessel is known as a floating arts center.

title: Film; A Classic That's as Changeable as the Wind
description: ''GONE WITH THE WIND'' is still generally accepted as the most widely seen motion picture ever to come out of Hollywood. When its estimated income is adjusted to reflect the increase in ticket prices over 59 years, it is still one of the biggest-grossing movies in history, topped only by a handful of others, including the newest champion of champions, ''Titanic.''

title: Pop/Jazz; Jazz Is Not What They're Famous For
description: WILLIAM TROY was a charismatic intellectual provocateur, ideally equipped to teach English literature at the New School in the years right after World War II, when the adjunct faculty included Hannah Arrendt and Earl Bowder, leader of the American Communist Party. Though few remember Troy today, one of his students, the painter and esthetic provocateur Larry Rivers, still treasures the opening words of Troy's lecture on James Joyce: ''He wanted to be a singer, you know.''

title: Swing Time
description: SUITS ME

title: Software May Go, Microsoft Won't
description: To the Editor:

title: Money on the Mind
description: Matthew Klam had me laughing all the way through his lament (''Some of My Best Friends Are Rich''), though I think he is lamenting the wrong thing. He doesn't seem to need more money -- what he needs are new friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUX, LOUIS M.
description: LUX-Louis M. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Devoted father of Arthur and Phyllis. Loving grandfather of Alan, Danny and Steven. Adoring great-grandfather of Annelise, Andrew and Jonathan. Services private.

title: Dance; Dancer Alert: Pilobolus Holds an Open Audition
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 27, 11:30 A.M.: Forty barefoot women are lined up along the dingy walls of City Center's fourth-floor rehearsal hall, waiting to improvise a 30-second dance that could change their lives. Some look alert, some nonchalant, a few terrified. All are here in response to a terse notice posted in a handful of New York dance studios and published in the trade press: Pilobolus Dance Theater is holding open auditions, starting today.

title: Todd Schleifstein, Eliza Feuerstein
description: Eliza Carol Feuerstein, the daughter of Donald M. Feuerstein of Potomac, Md., and the late Dorothy S. Feuerstein, is to be married this afternoon to Todd Lawrence Schleifstein, a son of Sharon and Richard M. Schleifstein of Marlboro, N.J. Rabbi Kenneth Stern is to perform the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: Karen Handler, Patrick J. Ryan
description: Karen Suzanne Handler, a daughter of Gerda R. Handler and Arthur M. Handler, both of New York, was married in New York yesterday to Patrick Joseph Ryan, a son of Delia and Michael Ryan of Mallow, Ireland. Acting Justice Arlene R. Silverman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony at the Water Club.

title: From the Classroom to the Trenches for Student Archeologists
description: WORKING between the tides, teams of students and their instructors are digging along the shore of Cape May to unearth history. The teams can work some of the sites only during low tide and then must shift to other inland digs when the tide rises

He is survived by his loving mother, Evelyn Joseph, brother Michael Joseph of Olney, IL, sisters Mary Joseph and Eleanor Joseph both of Atlanta, GA., brother Thomas Joseph and sister Evelyn Joseph both of Cincinnati, OH., sister Margaret Joseph of Nashville, TN, sister Kathleen Reinhart of Dayton, OH as well as 13 nieces and nephews. title: PHOTOGRAPHER'S JOURNAL
Books in Brief: Fiction; You Say Potato, I Say Kartoffel
description: The unnamed narrator of the German novelist Uwe Timm's MIDSUMMER NIGHT (New Directions, $23.95) is a novelist with writer's block. So when he's asked to write a magazine article about potatoes, he accepts, hoping to shake his torpor. But his research trip from Munich to post-reunification Berlin, where he wants to retrieve a potato scholar's archive, is as bizarre as his subject is banal. Entering the former eastern sector, he is swindled by a hawker of fake leather jackets, abused by a cabby and given a really bad haircut. Timm's sendup of reunification is fun -- some walls, it seems, never come down -- but that's not his theme. He's more interested in exploring what happens when two opposing political cultures, both of which have stifled self-expression, are suddenly mixed. What results, if his portrait is any indication, is a restless flux -- a midsummer night's dream. This is a Berlin whose Reichstag Christo has just wrapped in a canvas cocoon and whose citizens, shaken up by the Zeitgeist, are reinventing themselves: a linguistics scholar is forging Russian Constructivist paintings; a husband has bidden goodbye to his wife and taken up with a djellaba-clad Bedouin. And as the increasingly befuddled narrator pursues his quest, the potato emerges as the symbol of this flux. How? Credit Timm's puckish conceptual artistry and his brewmeister style of letting a story ferment unhindered. ''Midsummer Night,'' as translated by Peter Tegel, is a picaresque comedy that is also, unobtrusively and astutely, a novel of ideas. Bill Christophersen

title: Studied Simplicity

Mary Steenburgen gives a pensive, biting performance as the writer who moved to a remotely rural home to find herself in the simple lives of the people around her. Dana Hill, Rip Torn, Peter Coyote and the others add to the regional color and earthiness. The pacing is leisurely, which suits a story as absorbing as this - FRIDAY at midnight on Channel 55.

title: Riverhead Golf Course Is Not a Sand Mine
description: With regard to your piece on the development of the Long Island National Golf Course [''In Riverhead, Sand Worth Its Weight in Gold,'' June 14], I take issue with your insinuation that the developers of this course are pocketing $2.4 million from the sale of material. This movement of sand and topsoil is a byproduct of the type of course that is to be built. The associated costs to move and remove material of this nature does cost money and certainly will not yield the numbers you splash across your headline.

title: Uniforms in the Closet

It is normal for a marine to change clothes before leaving the base; by shedding his ''cammies,'' R. leaves behind the obligation to salute other marines in uniform. But for R., the change is also symbolic: as a marine who is gay, he looks forward to the end of each workday as a reprieve from hiding part of himself from everyone around him.

A pacifist and conscientious objector during World War II and a crusader for environmental causes in Cornwall, where he has lived and worked for most of his life, Mr. Heron has rarely taken pointers about his art from anyone, no matter how influential. Yet that is precisely what he said the critic Clement Greenberg once proposed to him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUGER, ELIZABETH (BETTY) GILE
description: KRUGER-Elizabeth (Betty) Gile. May 26. Age 97. Born July 1, 1901 in Minneapolis, 3rd child of Sam & Mabel Gile. Graduated Cum Laude from University of Minnesota (MA in English). In 1929, moved to NYC where she began her legendary career in publishing, joining McGraw-Hill as their first, and only, editor. By 1945, her department had grown to 44 editors and she was Editor-in-Chief. Known for exacting standards, she attracted noted authors and helped McGraw Hill establish its reputation for quality. Before retiring in 1966, she trained more than 250 editors. Her definitive book, ''Gile on Style,'' was still in revision when she died. Member of Christ and St. Stephen's Church in NYC; avid swimmer, bird watcher, reader and traveler. Widow of Otto Kruger; survived by many nieces and nephews. Memorial Service July 12, St. Paul's Villa, San Diego, where she lived the last 3 years.

The aptly named Thrill Zone digital-animation attraction, at the observation level near the top of the CN Tower, is part of an $18.4 million expansion and revitalization of the 22-year-old landmark. For $12 visitors will also be able to have themselves digitally photographed in such simulated daredevil poses as hanging by their fingertips off the tower, with a 10-minute wait for the print.

title: Trying to Give Opera A Festival Like No Other
description: AMID Europe's ever more crowded calendar of summer musical happenings, the slow demise of the opera festival in this bucolic southern French city went largely unnoticed. In its heyday, in the 1950's and 60's, when it reintroduced Mozart to France, le tout Paris would flock here every July. But in recent years, even for dedicated opera lovers, Aix was increasingly overshadowed by Salzburg, Bayreuth, Glyndebourne and other festivals more offbeat, glitzy or crowd-pleasing.

''What are we going to do with the proceeds from the stock, which amounted to $325,000,'' said George C. Schmitz, a brother of the Holy Cross, a French religious order with American headquarters in New Rochelle. The answer they came up with was, ''Let's put it to use in our own communities at the disposal of nonprofit organizations working with the poor.''

title: Classical Music; Yes, Virgil, There Were Composers

Virgil Thomson called the music of George Chadwick, Edward MacDowell, John Knowles Paine, Amy Beach and other prominent turn-of-the-century Americans ''a pale copy'' of ''Continental models'' and reckoned their scale of achievement ''a sort of adolescence.'' Leonard Bernstein termed this ''the kindergarten period of American music,'' whose ''fine, academic imitations'' of European masters were actually intended to sound like Brahms and Liszt: ''the more they did, the better.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERRY, CICELY K.
description: ROSENBERRY-Cicely K. On Friday, June 26 at Norwell Knoll Nursing Home, Norwell, MA. Adored wife of the late Samuel L. Rosenberry, a former senior partner of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley and McCloy; beloved mother and true friend of Nancy R. Hoit and son-in-law Roger O. Hoit; and devoted grandmother of Roger W. Hoit and Sarah H. Whitman; and great-grandmother of Morgan and Jackson Hoit. She lived all her life in New York until the past few months and devoted her civic life to education and nursing. She was a former Chair of the Board of Trustees of Smith College, from which she graduated with honors and held an honorary degree, former trustee of Hampshire College, former President of the Board of the Spence School, former trustee of the Institute for International Education and a past President of the Junior League of New York and an Overseer of the Boston Symphony. Board member of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York for 50 years, Vice President of the Board and Chair of the Executive Committee, also former Chair of the Advisory Council for Nursing for the Department of Hospitals of NYC, the Emergency Division of the Office of Civil Defense, Vice President of the Board of Managers of the Bellevue School of Nursing and on the Advisory Council for the New York Cornell School of Nursing. Her personal life was devoted to her family and her many wonderful and loyal friends. A memorial service will be held on July 24 at 1 PM at the Church of the Holy Spirit in Orleans, MA. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 East 70 St., NY, NY 10021 and to Smith College, Office of Advancement, Alumnae House, Northampton, MA 01063.

title: Must-Hear TV

Music Choice, a cable television service that recently arrived in select neighborhoods in New York, provides customers with 24 hours of commercial-free music programming the old-fashioned way -- without pictures. With a click of the remote control, a menu appears on screen listing 31 music channels to choose from: 1970's Super Hits, Big Bands, Classical, Musica Latina, Jazz, Lite Jazz, Contemporary Christian. Subscribers of Music Choice praise it for offering song rotations, as on radio or music-television, but without commercial blocks, deejays, veejays or the need to wait to learn a song's credits. As each song plays, a simple black screen displays the title, artist, label and an 800 number to order the CD. ''It's like MTV, but you're not forced to watch hygiene-challenged rockers,'' A. J. Jacobs, a writer at Entertainment Weekly, said as he watched (oops -- listened to) ''Please Send Me Some Love'' by Dinah Washington. Mr. Jacobs ''pops it on'' when he has a friend over or is ''puttering around the house.'' Why not queue up a CD? ''I like the glow of the TV,'' he said. ''It makes me happy.''

title: Nathan Glazer Changes His Mind, Again
description: Nathan Glazer has had more second thoughts in his lifetime than most people have had thoughts. He is the most modest (and the least tendentious) of the brilliant Jewish boys who attended City College 60 years ago and later came to be known collectively as the New York Intellectuals. The City College crowd helped chart postwar America's ideological frontier; like many of his classmates, Glazer journeyed steadily rightward for decades, from Trotskyist to social democrat to neo-conservative. But lately, Glazer has begun to adopt -- though scarcely embrace -- some strikingly liberal positions. This spring, Glazer wrote in The New Republic that without affirmative action, hardly any blacks would gain admission to top colleges; and that, he argued, would ''undermine the legitimacy of American democracy.'' Glazer seemed resigned rather than enthusiastic, but it was nonetheless a startling reversal from a scholar who two decades earlier wrote ''Affirmative Discrimination,'' a stinging critique of racial (and other) preferences.

title: Classical Music; Belated Fruits of the Operatic 80's

La Scala in Milan produced the first three installments in Karlheinz Stockhausen's series of operas for the days of the week: ''Thursday,'' ''Saturday'' and ''Monday.'' Luciano Berio had two operas staged in quick succession: ''La Vera Storia'' and ''Un Re in Ascolto.'' So did Harrison Birtwistle, with ''The Mask of Orpheus'' and ''Yan Tan Tethera.'' title: AVA OUT
description: Last month the Ava Gardner Museum, in Smithfield, N.C., was flooded with calls about -- surprise -- Frank Sinatra, with whom the actress had famously split. Now it's getting kicked out of its space in an old brick building, which has been sold. Despite the indignities, Melody Godwin, the museum's ''weekday hostess,'' will proudly pack treasures like the tiny black dress Gardner wore in ''The Great Sinner'' (1949), a purple knit suit worn on ''Knots Landing'' and even the ceramic model of Ava's beloved corgi, Morgan. The museum is fielding offers from other cities that want Ava, who died in 1990. But no move is planned. ''Ava was a strong Southern woman who never forgot where she came from,'' Godwin says of the North Carolinian. ''Her place is here.''

title: Pop/Jazz; What if Woody Guthrie Had Led a Rock Band?
description: IN his 1981 history ''Deep Blues,'' the rock critic and blues scholar Robert Palmer entertains a fantasy about Robert Johnson, who is said to have traveled with a drummer and an electric guitar in the months before his death. What, Palmer wonders, if the bluesman had lived to play in John Hammond's 1938 Spirituals to Swing concert at Carnegie Hall with Count Basie, Joe Turner, Meade Lux Lewis and many others now renowned? In that seminal context, Palmer exclaims, Johnson and his band ''probably would have created Chicago blues'' -- in other words, got within spitting distance of rock-and-roll.

title: Money on the Mind
description: As students on the ''reality tour'' in Tijuana ''study their shoelaces'' with guilt, I wonder if those are shoelaces made in the very factories they feel guilty about visiting (''Let's Go on a Guilt Trip,'' by Denise Dowling). No, it is not their fault that they each ''live in an upper-middle-class family in a first-world country,'' but the privilege that comes with such a background gives them choices, something that lots of people do not have. Choices to forgo McDonald's, to not buy Smith Corona and Nike products, but instead give that money to something that is important to them. Those who are blessed with financial stability and family support have the choice to tutor kids in East L.A., help out at orphanages and soup kitchens in Tijuana or work with recent immigrants from Mexico, not just look at them from behind a fence.

title: Arts/Artifacts; For Centuries, The Garden Path Has Led to Adventure

''Verdant Riches Revealed: A Selection From the Treasures of the LuEsther T. Mertz Library at the New York Botanical Garden,'' offers a case in point. On the surface, the 80 illustrated books, neatly arranged in showcases at the Grolier Club in Manhattan, are a fine collection, featuring botanical prints and early garden designs. But to proceed along the exhibits slowly, reading the informative captions, is like traveling, first to a medical school in Salerno in 1190, on to the cargo hold of Captain Bligh's Bounty in 1792 and, eventually, to the landscape at the Royal Pavilion at Brighton in 1808.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Machine Dreams
description: Once considered a member of modernism's ''minor aristocracy,'' Fernand Leger (1881-1955) is now receiving deserved attention as a modern master -- ''the only major painter of his generation'' to take modernity itself ''as his subject,'' as Carolyn Lanchner writes in FERNAND LEGER (Museum of Modern Art/Abrams, $60), a compilation of three stimulating essays and 209 illustrations, 66 in color. Exploring the nature and effects of Leger's interactions with American patrons, artists and spaces, Lanchner, a curator at the Museum of Modern Art, argues that his art shared with popular culture the ''equation of the machine, the modern and the American.'' In cities like New York and Chicago, Leger's fascination with mass culture could find fulfillment. Jodi Hauptman, who teaches art history at the University of Delaware, further investigates Leger's notion of urban ''spectacle and speed'' as ''an art of dynamic divisionism,'' and she compares and contrasts Leger's expressions of the city with those of several contemporary artists. Matthew Affron, who teaches art history at the University of Virginia, uses Leger's own term ''new realism'' to characterize ''the new visual state imposed by the evolution of the new means of production.'' Leger intended this new realism to relate painting to the social world, primarily that of the working class; he aimed to show the beauty of the modern object to the people. The reproductions in ''Fernand Leger'' show that his art went beyond Cubist shapes, primary colors and machine imagery; his merging of Cubist stasis with undulating volume can only be called masterly. Zoe H. Rice

Three wars have been fought over Kashmir in the last 50 years. The United States and other countries can help defuse tensions, but India and Pakistan must make a new attempt to sort out their differences now that these divisions could become the pretext for a nuclear war.

More important, the entire Centrum is walkable; for example, from the museum area to the Spuistraat restaurants is not more than 20 minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLETT, ROBERT A.
description: BARTLETT-Robert A. Age 80. Died June 27, 1998, at his home in Mt. Gilead, Murrells Inlet, SC, after a long illness. Mr. Bartlett was predeceased by his wife, Lilla Rodda Bartlett, and one sister, Jane Heisinger. R.A. Bartlett, Board Chairman and CEO of the F.A. Bartlett Tree Expert Company of Stamford, CT, was born in Stamford, CT, on October 11, 1917. He was the son of the late Francis A. and Myrtle K. Bartlett. Following graduation from the Irving School, Tarrytown, NY, he attended the New York State College of Forestry at Syracuse University, later transferring to the business school at Columbia University. He joined the family business in 1937 and, a year later, was instrumental in coordinating efforts to restore damaged landscapes in the aftermath of the great 1938 hurricane. Mr. Bartlett enlisted in the U.S. Army in June 1941, six months before Pearl Harbor, becoming a specialist in military equipment and supplies as well as a graduate of the military intelligence school. He saw action in the South Pacific, including the New Guinea and Philippines campaigns. He rose to the rank of staff sergeant and was awarded the Soldier's Medal for Bravery for risking his life to rescue a pilot from a burning aircraft. Resuming his career with the Bartlett Company, he was successively named Vice President, a director, Executive Vice President, President, Vice Chairman and, in 1975, Chairman and CEO. A lifelong arborist, he counted among his most rewarding accomplishments the establishing of two major arboreta, the Bartlett Arboretum of the State of Connecticut in Stamford and the working arboretum located on the property of the Bartlett Tree Research Laboratories and Experimental Grounds in Charlotte, NC. He received a Special Achievement Award from the National Arbor Day Foundation, the Conservation Medal of the DAR, the Founder's Plaque of the Mountain Lake Vegetation Management Council, 1991 Man of the Year Award of Arbor Age Magazine and the 1997 Award of Merit of the National Arborist Association. Mr. Bartlett is survived by his four children, Rev. Jane Bartlett of Murrells Inlet, SC; Robert A., Jr., of Stamford; Elizabeth Hubbard of Stedman, NC; and Nancy Cook of Charlotte; and six grandchildren. Memorials may be made to Hospice of Georgetown, South Carolina, P.O. Box 1436, Georgetown, SC 29442. Services will be Wednesday, July 1, 1998, at North Stamford Congregational Church, 11 A.M. in Stamford, CT. Visitation will be 6-8 PM, Tuesday at Bouton & Reynolds Funeral Home in Stamford, CT.

She doesn't have her dancers engage in gladiatorial combat, either, though one could almost imagine her deciding to give such duels a try. She has already created dances that resemble boxing and wrestling matches.

description: In a long-running class-action lawsuit that may be finally going to trial, eight former employees have accused the Long Island Lighting Company of improperly withholding millions of dollars of their pension payments.

description: RAND-Edward Henry. June 22. Husband of Beverly. Father of Laura, James, Sarah and Janey. Brother of Helen and the late Marjorie. Grandfather of four.

Kaplan (Diane), grandfather of Sharon & Andrew Levine, Richard & Benjamin Eckstein, Michelle and Rachel Kaplan. He was a practicing CPA and was Treasurer of the Lefrak Organization until his retirement. Graveside Services were held on June 29, 1998.

title: Prosecutors Say Microsoft Case Will Be Honed
description: State and Federal prosecutors insist that while last week's Federal appeals court ruling favoring the Microsoft Corporation might force them to alter their legal tactics, it also offers a road map to help sharpen their new antitrust case against the software giant.

description: BECKER-Sofia. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, and its Sisterhood mourn the passing of the beloved mother of their devoted member, Dr. Inna Bakker, and extend heartfelt condolences to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Executive Changes
description: GTE CORP., Stamford, Conn., named Daniel P. O'Brien chief financial officer and executive vice president for finance, succeeding J. Michael Kelly, who resigned to become chief financial officer at America Online Inc. Mr. O'Brien had been GTE's vice president and treasurer.

title: Netherlands' Davids Comes in From Cold
description: Edgar Davids, the man the Netherlands knows tenderly as ''the pit bull,'' is back, lifting the Dutch side to a 2-1 victory over Yugoslavia today with a magnificent last-minute goal.

title: Sports of The Times; David Cone's Little War With Himself
description: THE conflict within the game matches a career-long personal tenet against a newly embraced view of medical fact. Halfway to 20 victories before the season is mathematically half over, David Cone also finds himself in the middle of a juggling act, trying to strike a proper balance between cockiness and caution, emotion and ambition.

title: HBO Signs Lewis To Six-Fight Deal
description: Lennox Lewis, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, has signed a six-fight extension with Home Box Office, the cable network. But the contract does not have a provision that will allow Lewis to shop a possible title unification bout with Evander Holyfield to another network if the fight can not be done by HBO.

title: A New Face on the Block; En Garde: A Very Different Cosmetics Retailer Is Coming
description: Standing in the middle of the first floor of Saks Fifth Avenue in Manhattan is a little like arriving in Tangier on the ferry from Spain. Peddlers with exotic wares are everywhere.

description: The home life of the ''Ching-a-Ling,'' a subspecies of the genus ''Biker Brotherhood,'' is inspected tonight on a new series unoriginally titled ''Inside Story'' and presided over by the ubiquitous Bill Kurtis. Known to some as a motorcycle gang, the Ching-a-Lings are here described as ''Road Warriors,'' dedicated, they announce, to ''family, freedom, honor.'' The black-garbed, ferociously decorated fellowship (they go in for Nazi symbols on their jackets and tattoos everywhere) is tracked to its home lairs and revealed to have a domestic side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, WILLIAM S.
description: NORTON-William S. The AllenStevenson School records with great sadness the death of Dr. William S. Norton, an alumnus from the Class of 1926 and father of Thomas Norton, Class of 1958. Dr. Norton served actively as School Physician and on the Board of Allen-Stevenson from 1947-1972, after which time he was elected Trustee Emeritus. To his wife, Priscilla Waters Norton, and his entire family, we offer our deepest sympathy. Ronald S. Rolfe '60, President of the Board David R. Trower, Headmaster

title: Rubin Defends I.M.F. Policies and Continues His Asian Tour
description: After a whirlwind visit to Malaysia, in which he defended the International Monetary Fund's harsh prescriptions for healing Asia's economies, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin arrived this evening in the place where the financial contagion began.

title: For J. Walter Thompson New York, winning the Merrill Lynch account ends a period of tumult.
description: MERRILL LYNCH is bullish on J. Walter Thompson New York, an agency that has suffered a spate of bearish news in the last year.

title: Serena Williams Is Out; Henman Uplifts Locals
description: Tim Henman kept the hopes of the British brotherhood alive and well today by reaching the quarterfinal round at Wimbledon for the third consecutive year with a smooth upset of sixth-seeded Patrick Rafter.

title: Lewinsky Case And 'Privilege' Fought in Court
description: A discussion of the possible impeachment of President Clinton served as the backdrop today to a historic legal fight over the attorney-client privilege.

title: 200 Innings Down Road, Cone Wants to Stay Put
description: David Cone sat between dozens of fans on a bench beside some softball diamonds in Central Park yesterday, stressing that he wants to stay with the Yankees even after the guaranteed portion of his three-year contract ends this season.

title: Pesticides Are Not The Main Problem
description: It's such an old joke that it's lost its humor, but it makes a point. A drunk is looking for his wallet at night at the base of a street lamp. Asked if he's sure that's where he dropped it, he says, ''No, but the light is better here.''

title: Police Reports Investigated In Shooting of Squeegee Man
description: The New York City Police Department is investigating whether some of the detectives who worked on the case of an off-duty police officer accused of shooting a squeegee man in the Bronx skewed their reports to make the shooting appear justifiable, police officials said yesterday.

title: Korean Bank Closings Prompt a Big Yawn
description: The Government's decision to close five small weak banks has drawn a tepid response from economists, who regard the move as a symbolic but largely ineffective start to fixing the nation's ailing financial system.

title: Feeding Children off the Spock Menu
description: PICTURE a childhood without ice cream or the occasional hot dog or burger at a birthday party or ball game. Picture in their stead organic applesauce, peanut butter and soy patties.

title: Furor Over School Prayer Stuns a Fired Teacher
description: Almost three weeks after she was fired for asking children in her Bronx classroom if they had accepted Jesus as their Saviour, Mildred Rosario says she is stunned to find herself at the center of a national debate over the division between church and state.

title: Health Watch; A Boost for Mammography
description: A new computer system recently approved by the Food and Drug Administration may help reduce the number of missed abnormalities in screening mammograms.

title: What Is a Real Mystery
description: U.F.O.'s aside, there seem to be enough weird goings on within the portals of accepted science. Take the method of dating ancient Indian rock art, known as petroglyphs, by means of the pollen and other carbon-containing dust said to be trapped beneath the rock varnish. Several paintings, which bear on the timing of the first colonization of the Americas, have been dated by Dr. Ronald I. Dorn, a pioneer of the rock varnish method at Arizona State University.

title: Car Strikes 2 Pedestrians As Driver Flees Police
description: Two people were injured yesterday, one seriously, when they were struck by a car in Chinatown that sped away from police officers trying to give the driver a traffic citation, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, HYMAN
description: GOLDENBERG-Hyman. The Mesivta of Long Beach marks with sorrow the loss of Mr. Hyman Goldenberg, of Blessed memory, our long time supporter, dear friend and neighbor. His caring ways and desire to always do kindness for others, along with his love and respect for Torah and Jewish education will long be remembered. We will miss him deeply both as a special man and as a representative of a bygone generation. Our heart felt condolences to Mrs. Ruth Gotthelf and family, Mr. Arthur Goldenberg and family, Mrs. Rosalind Alper and Mrs. Anita Goldenberg and family. May all of you be comforted and spared from further sorrow. HaRav Yitzchok Feigelstock Rosh HaYeshiva Rabbi Shlomo Lesin Executive Vice President

title: Six Generations of Strong Women; History Leaves Mark on Elizabeth Cady Stanton's Line
description: On a hot July day in 1848, a frustrated upstate New York housewife named Elizabeth Cady Stanton assembled a convention in a Seneca Falls church and made the radical demand that women be allowed to vote. In that moment, she changed not only American history but the expectations placed on the next five generations of women in her own family.

title: Clarity in the Court
description: The Supreme Court aimed for clarity and, to an unusual degree, achieved it in the term just ended. Decisions were supported by clear majorities, free of the ambiguities that often plague rulings on highly charged subjects. A review of the major cases, by Linda Greenhouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, JOHN H.
description: KRAUS-John H. Age 89, formerly of Middle Village, NY died June 28, 1998 in Dayton, OH. Widower of wife Gusti in 1976. Survived by son, Dr. Gary Kraus of Dayton, OH; daughter & son-in-law, Audrey & Thomas Carr, Corning, NY; grandchildren, Brendan, Daniel, & Michelle. Graveside service 2PM Tuesday (Today) at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, NY.

title: SERB FORCES OPEN A MAJOR ASSAULT ON KOSOVO REBELS
description: Thousands of Serbian special police units and troops, backed by artillery, tanks and other heavy armor, opened a series of attacks against separatist rebel positions this morning.

title: 'Ave Maria' of Flesh as Well as Spirit
description: An ambitious company called Complexions: A Concept in Dance is letting a big production evolve. ''Saturation,'' choreographed by Dwight Rhoden, will achieve its finished form in 2000. But before that, bits of it will be shown as they take shape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IVES, KENNETH APPLETON, JR.
description: IVES-Kenneth Appleton, Jr. 64. Died June 21. He was the retired founder and chairman of Appleton Partners, Inc. of Boston. He is survived by his wife of 27 years, Cornelia Spencer Ives of Boca Grande, FL, his sons Kenneth, Michael, Christopher and George of NYC and Edward of Seattle, WA, a sister Edith Reynolds of Loudonville, NY, and six grandchildren. Memorial service August 3, 2 PM at St. Paul's School, Concord, NH. Donations may be made to the Advanced Medical Research Foundation, 333 Longwood Ave., Boston, MA 02115, National Rowing Foundation, 67 Mystic Road, N. Stonington, CT. 06359 or to St. Paul's School, Concord, NH 03301.

title: Beatrice Snyder, 74, Generic-Drug Official
description: Beatrice Snyder, a co-founder and former executive of Biocraft Laboratories, a maker of generic pharmaceuticals, died June 21 at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 74 and lived in Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Metro Business; Restaurateur Ends Suit
description: Warner LeRoy, the owner of Tavern on the Green, has withdrawn his lawsuit against the restaurateur David Bouley, and their partnership in Bouley Bakery and several other projects in TriBeCa has been dissolved. Mr. LeRoy, who had accused Mr. Bouley of misappropriating money, reached an agreement with him on Friday.

title: Hilton Gambling Split-Off Seen, Then Merger With Grand Casinos
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation is expected to announce on Tuesday that it will split its hotel and gambling operations into separate companies and will merge the gaming company with the Mississippi gambling operations of Grand Casinos Inc.

title: Dictators of Influence
description: To the Editor:

title: Optimism's Bright Side: A Healthy, Longer Life
description: PEOPLE who look on the bright side have reason to be optimistic. Evidence suggests that they have healthier, longer lives than their gloom-and-doom counterparts. For years, research has shown that optimists weather coronary bypass surgery better and live longer with H.I.V. Now a new study suggests that positive thoughts are also good for healthy people.

title: Whitman in Deal to Raise Gas Tax 4 cents
description: Overcoming opposition from some Republican lawmakers reluctant to raise taxes, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman reached agreement with legislative leaders today to increase the state's gasoline tax gradually -- 4 cents a gallon over three years -- to help pay for transportation projects around the state.

title: Networks for Super-Linked Families
description: AS the planet becomes increasingly networked, shrinking the globe and redefining age-old concepts of community, all this digital connectivity has so far bypassed our most fundamental social unit, the family. Now, a rapidly emerging new industry is betting that the next ''killer app'' will be a network in your home.

title: Powergen Plans To Buy Utility For $1.4 Billion
description: Powergen P.L.C., Britain's second-largest generator of electricity, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy East Midlands Electricity for $1.4 billion in cash.

title: And What Is Really Hot
description: Some mysteries, of course, have robust, scientific explanations but depend on the human propensity for self-deception to be seen as supernatural. The trick in fire-walking, Dr. Churchland notes, is that there is no trick. The coals are red-hot and the fire-walkers tread on them, usually without injury. People expect to be burned by anything incandescent, but the coals, if carefully prepared and at a late stage of combustion, have the density of styrofoam and hold too little heat to burn the skin if touched quickly. The spectacle depends on expert preparation of the coals, and on indoctrinating the walkers to swathe their feet in bio-magnetic energy that repels the heat.

title: Prosecutor Calls King a Liar Who Defrauded an Insurer
description: A Federal prosecutor described Don King yesterday as a liar who fraudulently collected $350,000 in insurance after a 1991 fight was canceled and then repeatedly deceived the boxer Julio Cesar Chavez to perpetuate the scam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, LYNN
description: JACKSON-Lynn. On Saturday, June 27, of Brooklyn, NY. Family and friends are deeply saddened by the loss of Lynn Jackson. Devoted to and cherished by her beloved family, Ms. Jackson is survived by her parents Gilbert and Barbara Jackson, her brother Brian Jackson and nephews Messiah and Isiah. Rehearsal Director of the Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble since 1988, Lynn also served on the faculty of The American Dance Festival. Earlier in her career, she danced with the Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble and appeared in productions with George Faison, Donald Byrd, Sophie Maslow and Ronald K. Brown. In addition, she worked with Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane, The Jamison Project and singer Grace Jones. Service to be held Thursday July 2, 6pm at the Lawrence H. Woodward Funeral Home, 1 Troy Ave, Brooklyn, NY. Contributions may be made in her memory to the Lynn Jackson Memorial Scholarship Fund, c/o Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation, 211 W 61 St, 3 Fl, NYC 10023

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHWORTH, RICHARD G.
description: ASHWORTH-Richard G. Husband of Amy; father of Everard, the late Tucker, and the late Eric; father-in-law of Brooke, and grandfather of Henry and Emma died at home June 24, 1998, from cancer. He was a graduate of Princeton University and Yale Law School, and a former senior partner at Haight, Gardner, Poor & Havens. Throughout his life, Dick devoted himself to public service, most notably Parents and Friends of Lesbians & Gays. He will be remembered for his vigor, convictions and counsel. He is survived by his mother, Leonore Goodspeed Ashworth, sister Joan Nichols, and nephews Terry and Dick Nichols. A memorial service will be held at All Souls Church, Lexington Avenue at 80th Street, at 6:00 pm on July 7, 1998. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Southern Poverty Law Center (400 Washington Ave., Montgomery, Alabama 36104) or to New York City Parents and Friends of Lesbians & Gays (P.O. Box 553, Lenox Hill Station, New York, New York 10021).

title: GIULIANI CRITICIZED ON CHARTER PLANS
description: Its first public hearing does not take place until tomorrow night, but already New York City's newly created Charter Revision Commission is being criticized by good-government groups and others as a cynically conceived agency with considerable power to disturb the balance of government in favor of the panel's creator, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: U.N. Plans to Treat 30,000 H.I.V.-Infected Pregnant Women
description: In a new effort to slow the transmission of AIDS from mothers to their babies, the United Nations is starting a pilot program to treat 30,000 pregnant women infected with H.I.V. in 11 countries where the infection is spreading rapidly, United Nations officials said at the 12th World AIDS Conference here today.

title: Frank Scott, 80, Baseball's First Player Agent
description: Frank Scott, a former Yankee official who became baseball's first player agent and helped such stars as Mickey Mantle, Roger Maris and Yogi Berra earn more money off the field than on it, died Sunday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 80.

title: SNAP-ON TO CUT 1,000 JOBS AND REORGANIZE
description: The tool and equipment company Snap-On Inc. plans to cut about 1,000 jobs, or 8 percent of its work force, in a reorganization intended to save $60 million a year. Snap-On, which has a total work force of nearly 12,000, will close about 5 factories, 5 warehouses and 40 to 45 small offices in North America and Europe. The company, which is based in Kenosha, Wis., said it would discontinue some product lines and consolidate business units. Costs associated with a restructuring are expected to lower third-quarter earnings by $175 million. Snap-On also said it would buy back up to an additional $100 million of its stock, raising the total value of the shares to be repurchased to $150 million. Its shares closed yesterday at $34.9375, down $3.50, or 9 percent.

title: YOUNG BROADCASTING WILL CONSIDER SALE OF COMPANY
description: Young Broadcasting Inc., the owner of a dozen television stations, put itself up for sale yesterday in a move that analysts said could fetch $1.9 billion, sending the company's shares up 34 percent. Young, in New York, hired the investment banking firm Lazard Freres & Company to explore its options. Young's stations reach 9 percent of United States households. Young is expected to attract several potential buyers for its flagship station KCAL in Los Angeles and its group of middle-market stations in cities such as Nashville and Green Bay, Wis. Its shares rose $16.3125, to $63.8125, in Nasdaq trading of 1.78 million shares, almost 16 times the three-month daily average.

description: SCHWARTZ-Martha. Rofeh International extends sincere condolences to William Schwartz, Vice President Academic Affairs Yeshiva University and distinguished member of our board upon the loss of his mother.

title: Exotic America Surprises London
description: If New Yorkers have recently come away with the impression that British theater is taking over Broadway and its environs, they may feel reassured to know that American culture is alive and well in London these days -- and not just through those peculiarly American art forms, the Broadway musical and the Hollywood blockbuster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VESENYI, PAUL, PH.D.
description: VESENYI-Paul, Ph.D. Husband of Catherine. Brother of Mrs. Maria Kando. Died on June 23, 1998. A Memorial Mass will be held July 18, 11 AM, at Church of St. Stephen of Hungary, 414 E. 82nd Street.

description: A French court dismissed a lawsuit by former African soccer players seeking to have two World Cup games replayed because of poor refereeing.

description: ALL kidding aside, the Mayor's much-maligned crisis center is brilliantly conceived, and not just because it will be bulletproof and bomb resistant. The genius is in its location: 7 World Trade Center.

description: The remains of an unidentified American serviceman from the Vietnam War, buried beneath the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery 14 years ago, are no longer unknown.

description: It is a marvelous anomaly that many of the world's finest young ballet dancers spent the last two weeks performing in this otherwise somnolent capital city of some 200,000 people. Jackson, after all, can lay claim to some cultural sophistication as the home of Eudora Welty, but it is still small and rural enough that the lead newspaper article one recent day was about vandalism at a hog farm.

description: Though it was a small one, Greg Rohlf took another step yesterday in an attempt to establish himself as one of the New York metropolitan area's premier amateur golfers.
