description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOWITZ, KATE
description: MOSKOWITZ-Kate. Adored and adoring wife of the late Samuel J. Moskowitz, died peacefully at home June 28, surrounded by her loving family. She was a beautiful & beloved mother of Benita Rich and Barbara Levine, dear motherin-law of Richard D. Levine, much loved grandmother of Jeffrey and Olivia Rich, Marc and Debbie Rich, Lisa & Richard Singer, Betsy Levine, Meg Levine, James and Patricia Levine, proud great grandmother of Wyatt, Ryan, and Blake. Graveside services will be held New Montefiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, Long Island, Tuesday, June 30 at 11 A.M.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Delicate Balance
description: Two months after Secretary of State Madeleine Albright laid down an ultimatum to Israel to decide on a further redeployment from the West Bank or else, neither the decision nor the ''or else'' has appeared. Last week, in fact, Israeli papers were running polls on whether there should be a national referendum on whether Israel should accept the U.S. proposal for a 13 percent withdrawal. It was like asking Israelis for their opinion about whether the Government should ask their opinion before it gives its opinion.

title: U S West Selects DDB Needham
description: U S West Inc. in Denver named the Chicago office of DDB Needham Worldwide to handle its account yesterday, with billings estimated at $70 million to $80 million. The account had been handled for almost two years by N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York, part of MacManus Group, which declined to take part in a review.

title: Supreme Court Weaves Legal Principles From a Tangle of Litigation
description: The Supreme Court aimed for clarity and, to an unusual degree, achieved it in the term that ended on Friday after a deluge of important rulings in the final week.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There's not a real political downside right now. I don't think there are going to be a lot of horrified soccer moms.''

title: A Full-Time Scholar Now, Hubner Can Still Attack
description: The 32d running of the Capablanca Memorial Tournament in Havana concluded in late May with a triple tie for first place. The winners were the grandmasters Robert Hubner of Germany and Ivan Morovic of Chile and the international master Jakob Silberman of Israel.

title: A Small Matter of Acoustics
description: The double bill of Cubanismo and Los Van Van at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Friday night, as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, was an event, even if it was far from sold out. Los Van Van, one of the world's great dance bands, hasn't played in New York for two years, and since the band is from Cuba, all sorts of people showed up, from baseball players and bankers smoking cigars to Cuban groupies dancing onstage. They showed up to see a band sounding weak and tired, working at just a small fraction of its capacity.

title: Bronx Principal Accused Of Giving Test Answers
description: A veteran Bronx elementary school principal has been accused of helping his students cheat on citywide math and reading tests and of diverting school funds for his own use, say Board of Education officials who have referred the case to the Bronx District Attorney's office.

title: City Vendetta Is Alleged By Defense For Hikind
description: The Federal corruption case against Assemblyman Dov Hikind of Brooklyn originated with city investigators who were pursuing a Giuliani administration vendetta against Mr. Hikind and a social services group, a defense lawyer contended in court yesterday.

title: Israeli President Urges Netanyahu to Call Early Elections
description: Dealing a stunning and unusual slap to the Government over its indecisive peace politics, President Ezer Weizman publicly urged Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today to call early elections.

title: It's Their Ball, and N.B.A. Owners Call for Lockout
description: In a move that could lead to the first work stoppage in National Basketball Association history, the 29 league owners yesterday agreed to lock out the players and suspend all league business until the two parties sign a new labor agreement.

title: A Devious Attack on Choice
description: The Republican effort to curtail abortion rights took a stealthy and dangerous turn last week when the House voted 223 to 202 to prohibit the Food and Drug Administration from testing or approving any drug that induces abortion, including RU-486, a drug that the F.D.A. has approved for use in controlled studies. For several years now, anti-abortion forces have tried to win public support by focusing their rhetoric on late-term abortions. This latest move shows that they want to block all methods, including the earliest and least invasive forms of abortion.

title: Union Drive Wins Vote At Hospital In Rockland
description: More than 1,000 workers at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y., have voted to join New York's largest health-care union in what was one of labor's biggest organizing victories in the metropolitan region in years.

title: INSIDE
description: Challenge to Netanyahu

title: Clinton's Dream Media Opportunity
description: When a Beijing University student asked whether Americans had a distorted view of China, President Clinton answered by pointing to a gallery crammed with lights and cameras.

title: OLSTEN EXPECTING A LOSS ON HOME-HEALTH BUSINESS
description: The Olsten Corporation, the largest United States provider of nurses and other staff to care for patients in their homes, expects to close 60 offices and to report a second-quarter loss because of charges for cutting back its home-health business. The company, which also provides staffing for other industries, said it expected to report a loss of $34 million, or 41 cents a share, in the quarter. It had been expected to earn 21 cents. Olsten, of Melville, N.Y., reported net income of $25.3 million, or 31 cents, in the quarter a year ago. The charges and a loss from the home-health business will more than offset profits from other businesses. Olsten's stock fell 62.5 cents a share, to $11.4375.

title: President Arrives in Shanghai; Focuses on Talk With Citizens
description: With the heavily political, issue-laden leg of his China trip now behind him, President Clinton and his entourage came to the country's largest and most cosmopolitan city Monday evening. To put his finger on the vibrant pulse of modern China, his aides said, Mr. Clinton will spend two days and three nights here talking to regular people.

title: The Fate Of 'Peony' May Hang On Clinton
description: With barely a week to go before the scheduled opening of ''The Peony Pavilion'' in New York City, Nigel Redden, the director of the Lincoln Center Festival, said today that there was still a slim chance that intervention by President Clinton would persuade the Chinese authorities to allow the opera's actors to fly to New York in time for opening night, July 7.

title: The Expected Is Official: Sampson Out as Coach
description: Four days after his divided team unceremoniously exited the World Cup, Steve Sampson resigned today as coach of the United States.

title: 23 Dead or Missing as Storms Rage in East and the Midwest
description: Nancy Wheeler was home in her trailer by a trickle of a creek in Elkview, W.Va., when disaster hit on Sunday morning.

title: For Gresser, Departure May Be Just a Pause
description: This is Carol A. Gresser's last day at 110 Livingston Street, and it is safe to say that of all the people who will call and wish her well, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will not be among them.

title: Bronx Man in Assault Gets 15 Years to Life
description: A Bronx man who assaulted an emergency medical technician with a knife was sentenced yesterday to 15 years to life in prison in a rare application of a law aimed at career criminals.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with a front-page article about the consumer implications of AT&T's plan to buy Tele-Communications Inc. reversed the labels on two sets of figures. In January, according to a survey by Odyssey L.P., 40 percent of American households had cellular phones and 23 percent had on-line services.

title: New Alliances in Northern Ireland
description: The week ahead contains two important events in Northern Ireland. Tomorrow the region's new assembly will meet for the first time, and Sunday marks the date of the most explosive of the yearly parades. In both cases, a small group of determined opponents can thwart the desire for peace expressed by the great majority of voters.

title: John Malcolm Brinnin, Poet And Biographer, Dies at 81
description: John Malcolm Brinnin, a poet and literary biographer who witnessed and chronicled the alcoholic deterioration and death of Dylan Thomas, died on Friday at his home in Key West, Fla. He was 81.

title: Questions Remain After Paper's Apology on Stolen Voice Mail
description: Reporters are constantly in search of information that public officials or powerful businessmen want to keep secret. If they manage to obtain such information, they may find themselves showered with awards and accolades.

title: Deal Moving Ahead To Purchase Team
description: A group of New Jersey businessmen is expected to finalize a deal to buy controlling interest in the Nets today before the deadline on an option that they hold to do so expires.

title: KEY ENERGY OFFERS TO BUY DAWSON FOR $180 MILLION
description: Key Energy Group Inc. of New Brunswick, N.J., offered yesterday to buy Dawson Production Services Inc. of San Antonio for $16 a share in cash, or about $180 million. Key would also assume $149 million in debt. The deal would make Key the largest oil well-servicing company in the world and allow it to expand into California. Key had revenue of $162.5 million for the year ending today, while Dawson had revenue of $92.6 million for the year that ended on March 31, 1997. Dawson had no comment on the offer. Key shares slipped 37.5 cents, to $13, and Dawson Production was up $1.9375 a share at $14.375.

title: WORLD CUP '98: Owen Lets His Boots Do The Talking; At 18, Natural Born Striker Is English Lad Among Men
description: There is the same pace, the same explosive acceleration, the same killer instinct in front of the goal. No wonder, then, that Michael Owen of England is already being compared to Ronaldo.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GLOBAL MOTORSPORT GROUP INC., -- Morgan Hill, Calif., a supplier of custom replacement parts for Harley-Davidson and other motorcycles, said Fremont Partners L.P. had lowered its offer for a 94 percent stake in company, to $21.75 a share in cash from $23.

title: Trenton Ban on Prison Smut Is Too Broad, Judge Warns
description: New Jersey's broad new law banning sexually oriented books, photographs and films from a prison for sex offenders remained in legal limbo today after a Federal judge again refused to let the state enforce the measure and called its constitutionality into question.

title: In an Unusual Deal, U.S. Will Sell Stock In Its Uranium Mills
description: The Federal Government's uranium enrichment business, rooted in the development of the atomic bomb more than a half-century ago, will soon go on sale in the stock market.

title: Potboiler It's Not, Nor Is It A Turkey
description: At the vast cultural banquet that is New York, try to imagine a sorbet course flavored with something exotic, like loco weed. Anyone who can do that will be on the way to appreciating the wacky and wise, melodic and mischievous summertime refreshment being served at the New York Theater Workshop under the title ''Love's Fowl.''

title: A Change of Habit, Boy oh Boy!
description: Leopards may not be able to change their spots, but habits can change their nuns.

title: OIL AND GAS COMPANIES IN $565 MILLION MERGER
description: The Devon Energy Corporation of Oklahoma City said yesterday that it intended to issue 15.4 million shares of stock to acquire the Northstar Energy Corporation of Calgary, Alberta. Devon announced the deal after its shares closed at $36.6875, up 18.75 cents. At that price the deal is worth about $565 million. Devon will also assume Northstar debt of $312 million and other obligations. The combined company would have total reserves of 1.2 trillion cubic feet of gas and 117 million barrels of oil. Both boards have approved the deal.

title: Teen-Ager Admits Using Virus To Steal Computer Passwords
description: A teen-age computer hacker pleaded guilty in Manhattan Federal Court yesterday to stealing more than 500 passwords from America Online users last year.

title: Livery-Cab Driver Is Slain in Brooklyn
description: A livery-cab driver was fatally shot early yesterday morning in Brooklyn, the police said. The driver, Ediphene Joseph, 42, was shot by two unidentified men shortly after midnight while parked in front of 478 Empire Boulevard in Crown Heights, said Officer Theresa Farello, a Police Department spokeswoman.

title: More Unions Set to Join Strike Over Puerto Rico Phones
description: A coalition representing tens of thousands of workers has called for a work stoppage starting next Tuesday to protest the government's sale of a majority interest in the publicly owned telephone company here, turning an uproar that has roiled the island for weeks into one that threatens to paralyze it.

title: Mets Seek Last Year's Late-Inning Lightning
description: The Mets are still gamely chasing the Atlanta Braves in the National League East and are just a step or two behind the San Francisco Giants in the race for the N.L. wild-card berth. Yet while both teams present tantalizing targets, the team the Mets most want to emulate right now is none other than the 1997 version of themselves.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about the Northeast's heat wave gave an incorrect address for Baker Field, site of a soccer camp in upper Manhattan. It is at Broadway and West 218th Street, not 216th.

title: After 300 Years of Auctions, This Tea Break Is Final
description: LONDON  From the rise of the East India Co. in the 17th century through the glory days of the British empire to the country's subsequent decline, tea growers from what is now the Indian province of Assam and the plantations of Kenya and Zimbabwe have come to London to sell their tea at auction.

title: Fed Expected to Hold Back On a Rate Increase for Now
description: The most militant inflation fighters at the Federal Reserve will have plenty to fret about when the central bank meets Tuesday and Wednesday to consider whether to raise interest rates.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen ended higher for the first time in a week after a widely followed quarterly business survey in Japan suggested its economy was not as weak as believed. In New York, the dollar fell to 141.69 yen from 142.44.

title: Unraveling of a Giant Mystery Begins
description: IT came from the depths. But after being captured off New Zealand, fast frozen, squeezed into a cramped packing case, flown to Kennedy International Airport and trucked across New York City to the American Museum of Natural History, a 25-foot-long giant squid has now been thawed and is undergoing close study by scientists excited to examine one of the world's rarest and least-understood animals. The squid is 25 feet long -- a baby. Like all giant squids, it has eight short arms and two long tentacles, here seen curled up because of insufficient mat space. The arms and tentacles are lined with sucker pads, the better to grab prey in the sea's inky depths. WILLIAM J. BROAD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, FRANK
description: SCOTT-FranK, 80. Of West Orange, N.J., June 28, 1998. Beloved husband of Bette (nee Shapiro). Loving father of John Scott and Stacey Scott Fishman. Brother of Mrs. Sylvia Peris and Mrs. Phyllis Shapiro. Survived by 4 grandchildren. Funeral from the Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Funeral Home, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, N.J. on Tuesday, June 30, at 2 PM. Interment in King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, New Jersey.

title: Maj. Gen. Marion E. Carl, 82, Marine Air Ace in World War II
description: Maj. Gen. Marion E. Carl, one of the leading Marine air aces of World War II and a record-setting test pilot, was shot to death on Sunday night in a robbery at his home in Roseburg, Ore., the Douglas County Sheriff's Department said. He was 82.

title: Questions for the President: Give and Take With China's Students
description: Following are key sections from the question-and-answer part of President Clinton's appearance yesterday at Beijing University, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company. Beijing University selected the students for the audience, allotting each academic department a set number. Their questions were translated by an interpreter.

description: LEWIS-Julius, age 92. Died June 29, 1998. Dear and loving father of Abby Kosovsky & Carole Rifkind, grandfather of Jane Kosovsky, Robert Kosovsky, Barbara Rifkind and Nancy Rifkind, greatgrandfather of Hailey McInerney and Luke McInerney, and father-in-law of Richard Rifkind. Family and friends may call at the home of Abby Kosovsky on Wednesday and Thursday, from 7:00 to 9:00 P.M.

description: The LSI Logic Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Symbios Inc., a Silicon Valley-based subsidiary of Hyundai Electronics America, for about $760 million in cash, including assumption of debt.

description: Never have so many making so much lost to so many making so little. It is, without question, the highlight of this season's interleague schedule, the Montreal Expos' sweep of a three-game series from the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Officials Are Drawing Closer in Effort to Sell Coliseum
description: City and state officials inched closer yesterday to the end of a 14-year effort to sell the New York Coliseum, one of the most valuable parcels of real estate in Manhattan, even as they failed once again to meet a self-imposed deadline.

description: AMERICAN and European space officials reported yesterday that they had lost contact with the orbiting SOHO observatory and feared that this highly productive scientific satellite might be lost.

description: A jury ruled today that officials in an eastern Washington town had not violated the civil rights of four people who had been accused of being part of child sex ring that had church orgies and parents swapping children.

title: Case Creates a New Unit
description: The Case Corporation, a maker of agricultural and construction equipment, said today that it had created a new unit, the Case Capital Corporation, to expand the focus of the company's financial-services unit. The new unit will include the existing Case Credit Corporation, the company's equipment loan and leasing company, with a portfolio of $5.3 billion. It will also include businesses that offer loans and leases for other companies, commercial lending within the equipment industry, multiple lines of insurance products and private-label credit cards.

title: First-Round Pick Signs Six-Year Deal
description: The Falcons signed their first-round draft pick, Keith Brooking, to a six-year, $9.2 million contract, including a $3.8 million signing bonus.

title: Michelangelo's Heartbreak Comes to Life in New Light; Transforming His Pieta to 80 Gigabytes
description: HE was a sick old man when he started the monumental project, unable to climb stairs without pain. Often, he could not work. But at some point in the middle of the 1540's Michelangelo began carving what many art historians regard as his most mature and provocative sculpture, the piece now known as the Florentine Pieta.

title: U.S. News & World Report Decides to Replace Its Editor
description: James Fallows, the editor of U.S. News & World Report, said yesterday that he had been dismissed after less than two years by the magazine's owner, Mortimer B. Zuckerman.

title: $21 Billion Goes To Stock Funds
description: United States investors increased their stock mutual fund purchases in June, a month when the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose to record highs, and also put more money in bond funds.

title: Scientist at Work: Steven Chu; Master of Molecule Manipulation Works on the Wild Side
description: AN atom can be here, there and somewhere else all at once; it can be going both this way and that way; it can be rattling with internal energy and quiet. Such are the quirky freedoms of the quantum microworld that do not apply to automobiles, apples or people. But if there is an exception to this rule, it would be the mind of Dr. Steven Chu, the master of manipulating atoms and molecules who shared the most recent Nobel Prize in Physics with two other researchers.

title: What's Right With the Swiss Banks' Offer
description: For several months, the banks we work for -- Credit Suisse Group, Union Bank of Switzerland and Swiss Bank Corporation -- have been trying to work out an agreement that justly compensates families for Holocaust-related claims. The negotiations have been fraught with emotion on both sides. Recently, when the Swiss banks proposed a settlement of more than $600 million to Holocaust victims, it was denounced. For example, Avraham Burg, the co-chairman of the World Jewish Restitution Organization, called the offer ''humiliating.''

title: 90 Charged in Welfare Fraud, Including 14 City Workers
description: Government workers created false identities for as many as 50 nonexistent children to bilk the welfare system, prosecutors said yesterday, announcing that the workers were among 90 people caught up in ongoing investigations of welfare fraud in New York City.

description: The Redcoats have come to the airports.

description: The Knicks were still talking to teams about making a trade before tonight's midnight deadline while waiting for the Charles Oakley trade to become official.

description: The National Basketball Association, unlike professional football, baseball and hockey, has never had its games disrupted by a labor dispute. That may be about to change.

title: N.R.C. Gives Final Approval to Restart of Millstone Reactor
description: Millstone Unit 3, a nuclear reactor in southeastern Connecticut, is scheduled to begin transmitting electricity by Thursday after more than two years of being barred from operating by Federal regulators.

title: 3 Democrats Assail D'Amato Then Attack One Another
description: Sharing a stage for the first time in this campaign, the three Democratic candidates for Senate tangled today over their allegiance to the tobacco industry, fund-raising tactics and how President Clinton should deal with China.

title: Monsanto Set to Acquire Cargill's Foreign Seed Unit
description: The Monsanto Company will buy Cargill Inc.'s international seed operations for $1.4 billion, the two companies said today, in one of the clearest signs yet of expectations that biotechnology will play a pivotal role in agriculture's future.

description: He is a man on a mission, so it is easy to forget that Daniel Passarella of Argentina has won two World Cups.

title: The Threat of Police Perjury
description: Now that a former New York City police officer, Francis Livoti, has been convicted in Federal court of violating the civil rights of Anthony Baez, the focus of investigation should move to the officers accused of lying on the witness stand to protect Mr. Livoti. Allegations of policy perjury made by Federal prosecutors and a state judge are devastating challenges to the integrity of the Police Department that must be answered with utmost speed. The U.S. Attorney's office is looking into possible perjury and cover-up charges. But the department must not wait for the Federal authorities to take the lead. It should begin an aggressive investigation into the perjury allegations.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a decline of book editing standards misspelled the given name of an editor at Farrar, Straus & Giroux who commented. She is Elisabeth Sifton, not Elizabeth.

title: Earliest Known Fake Stone Is Discovered in Southern Iraq
description: ON broad plains layered with silt from the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers, the people of ancient Mesopotamia managed to build the first cities and spreading empires without local sources of such raw materials of civilization as timber, metal ores and stone. What they could not import, they had to do without or, as archeologists have now discovered, learn how to make synthetic substitutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, PHILIP
description: COLLINS-Philip. On June 29, 1998. Beloved son of the late Edward and Catherine (nee Nolan). Loving brother of Nancy and Cathy. Dear uncle of Kristina Collins Wiig. Dear friend of Martin McQuade. Visiting Wednesday 2-4, 7-9. Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Bklyn.

title: Rockwell to Cut 3,800 Jobs and Spin Off Chip Unit
description: The Rockwell International Corporation's transformation to commercial electronics from the military business suffered a setback today when the company announced that it would spin off its semiconductor division to shareholders, cut 3,800 jobs and take a pretax charge of $625 million.

title: East Timor Separatist Accepts Parts of Jakarta Autonomy Offer
description: The East Timorese independence leader, Jose Ramos-Horta, said today that he would accept an offer of limited autonomy within Indonesia now and a five-year delay on a referendum on the territory's permanent status. But he said he would not agree to a recognition of Indonesian sovereignty in the meantime.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; News Corp. To Sell Shares In New Unit
description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell to the public as much as 20 percent of its American film, television and sports businesses -- including 20th Century Fox, Fox Television and the Los Angeles Dodgers -- in an initial stock offering. The sale is aimed in large part at bolstering the price of the News Corporation's shares, which have lagged behind those of other media giants.

description: The United States' exit from the World Cup after the first round meant an earlier-than-anticipated return of some players to their clubs in Major League Soccer. For Mike Burns and Joe-Max Moore of the New England Revolution, as well as Eric Wynalda of the San Jose Clash, the results for their M.L.S. teams were similar to those of the national team.

description: He could not jump and he could not run, especially when his aching back acted up. But Larry Bird could play basketball, and yesterday he received the ultimate confirmation of that when he was elected to the Nai smith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: U.N. Council Looks at Rise in Number of Children in Combat
description: As a measure of how dramatically the face of modern warfare has changed in the last decade, the Security Council spent its day today debating the rapid increase in the number of child soldiers worldwide and what, if anything, can be done to keep children away from combat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERRY, CECILY
description: ROSENBERRY-Cecily. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York deeply mourn the loss of Cecily Rosenberry, a life-long volunteer and Director for more than 50 years. She began her association with the agency in 1944 and was a great champion of public health and home care nursing. Her unwavering support and generosity in responding to the health care needs of the NY community will be remembered always. We extend our profound sympathy to her daughter, Nancy, and to her grandchildren. Douglas D. Broadwater Chairman of the Board Carol Raphael Pres. and Chief Exec Officer

title: Review/Fashion; Masculinity Meets Romance in Milan
description: Romance has come to men's wear here, an apt development in the age of Viagra. Designers like Jil Sander, Donatella Versace, Dolce & Gabbana and Issey Miyake have been careful, though, as they infuse their spring clothes with soft, fanciful touches, to preserve the swagger of masculinity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLINICK, MARGERY ALICE (LINDA)
description: BLINICK-Margery Alice (Linda). Died June 19, 1998 in Princeton, N.J. Born on September 19, 1909, Curwensville, PA. She lived most of her life in New York City and worked as a nurse at Beth Israel Medical Center. Devoted wife of the late George Blinick, M.D. Beloved mother of Robert and Joseph and the late Ann Colliver. Cherished grandmother of Nancy, Cindy, Lindy, Andy, Bill & George. Loving great grandmother of Alice, Richard, Matthew, Katie, Laura, Ryan, Annie and Carter. A memorial service will be held at the Princeton United Methodist Church, Sunday, July 5th, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the American Diabetes Association.

title: Serb Charged in Massacre Commits Suicide
description: A Serb being tried for his role in a massacre of more than 200 people in Croatia in 1991 has committed suicide, the United Nations War Crimes Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia said today.

title: Voter Turnout Drops In 1998 Primaries
description: Continuing a downward trend in voter turnout, less than 17 percent of those old enough to vote have gone to the polls in statewide primaries this year, according to a new study.

description: FELSEN-Esther. Wife, mother and Bobbi extraordinaire to Gidon, Uri, Bina, Michael, Sarah and Jacob. We'll miss you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARAF, BEATRICE F.
description: BARAF-Beatrice F. Of Palm Beach, Florida. Died June 25, 1998. Wife of the late Samuel L. Baraf and the late Arthur Block. Born Brooklyn, N.Y. September 14, 1910. Beloved mother of Libby Lovett (Nelson), Charles Baraf (Jeri), Joseph Baraf, Donald Baraf (Marlena), Robert Baraf (Leslie) and Herbert Baraf (Cheryl). Beloved grandmother of Michael Lovett, Onnie Schiffmiller (Andrew), Andrew Baraf (Mayze), Susan Maness (Elliot), Josh Cender, Alison Baraf, Meredith Baraf, Arthur Baraf, Eduardo Baraf, Emily Baraf, Samantha Baraf and Zachary Baraf. She was an adored mother, aunt, great-aunt, grandmother, great grandmother and friend to many. She will be missed for years to come.

title: Eurosongs That Verge On an American Style
description: The Northern Italian singer Paolo Conte is a private man in a public man's outfit. With tuxedo and bow tie, he came onstage for a rare New York performance at the Supper Club on Thursday night as part of the JVC Jazz Festival and seemed snug in his own geometry of ritual: he kissed his watch, brushed his gray mustache, touched his ear. He repeated these actions during the performance, and never talked between songs except to introduce one of his band members.

description: Dr. Charles Rycroft, a British psychoanalyst who offered a generation of therapists new ways to interpret not just dreams but Freud's entire legacy, died May 24 in London, where he lived. He was 83.

description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, the 13th-largest United States oil company, agreed today to sell its Occidental Netherlands Inc. unit to TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. for $275 million and unspecified contingent payments.

description: The New York City Ballet ended its season on Sunday with George Balanchine's ''Midsummer Night's Dream,'' which featured several major debuts over the weekend.

description: For the Liberty, things are turning around almost as fast as they fell apart.

description: The surprising strength of ethnic Albanian rebels fighting for independence in the Serbian province of Kosovo is putting strains on international efforts to keep the violence from spreading, European and American diplomats said today.

description: The Census Bureau reported today for the first time that young women are completing high school and graduating from college at higher rates than their male peers.

description: It was a bad dream, one that recurred for months. ''I just couldn't get it out of my head,'' Nancy Lopez said.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN FALLS 4.8 PERCENT. Corn tumbled on forecasts for Midwest rains that eased fears of crop damage from hot, dry weather and raised optimism for a bumper crop. Contracts for July fell 12 cents, to $2.385 a bushel.

title: School-Choice Program Delayed for New Plan
description: Approval of a pilot program allowing students to choose public schools outside their district will be delayed while lawmakers write their own school-choice plan, the State Senate Education Committee's chairman said yesterday.

title: Science and Religion: Bridging the Great Divide
description: EVER since science began drifting away from religion, centuries ago, each has dreamed of subsuming the other. Scientists, in their boldest moments, speak of explaining away all the mysteries by empirical inquiry, leaving no need for ancient wisdom. And the faithful, fervently believing in spiritual forces unmeasurable by any meter, find it absurd that God's children would aspire to heaven solely by building telescopes and computers -- scientific Towers of Babel. They have longed for a reality beyond the shadowplay of the material realm.

title: Can Class Prayer Be Truly Voluntary?
description: To the Editor:

title: Swooning Love? No, Thank You
description: Diana Krall is about the farthest thing from a jazz diva you could expect to find in a world where loud, pyrotechnic vocal display is confused with musical insight and emotional depth. This singer and pianist, who led her trio in a quietly enthralling concert on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, is a low-key jazz minimalist who takes the meaning of the word ''trio'' much more seriously than most singers.

title: New-Home Sales Rise to a Record
description: Sales of new homes rose in May to a record level, fueled by low interest rates and high consumer optimism.

title: Relentless Germany Finds Way To Win
description: At the end, after two hours of playing in temperatures that exceeded 90 degrees, exhaustion replaced celebration. Jurgen Klinsmann raised his arms, but could not keep them above his head. Andreas Kopke, the German goalkeeper, collapsed on his back, and defender Christian Worns writhed on the ground as if all his muscles had cramped in protest. But, until the whistle blew today to signal the end of a 2-1 victory over Mexico, Germany had been as relentless as the heat.

title: People
description: * Max Lefeld was named to the new position of creative director at Siboney USA, Dallas, a unit of True North Communications. He had been associate creative director at Leo Burnett Venezuela, part of the Leo Burnett Co.

title: Recognizing What Is Real
description: IF scientists are too rigid in ignoring phenomena that cannot be explained by standard theories, they risk ignoring hints that may lead to new and better theories. But chasing every ''X-File'' anomaly guarantees wasting a lot of time. How can one tell the difference between real science and pursuits that may have the form, but generally not the content, of science, like parapsychology?

title: By Design; Saying It Small
description: Inspired perhaps by the tiny gold cross that Agent Dana Scully wears, women have been snapping up delicate chain necklaces with crosses or other diminutive drops.

title: ARTS IN AMERICA; Please Don't Eat the Tomatoes: They're Glass Beads
description: Liza Lou takes off her shoes and steps gingerly into her neat backyard, careful not to disturb the exuberant flowers. It has all the trappings of almost any other well-tended patch of suburbia, with its meticulously groomed lawn, its barbecue grill stoked with coals and its picnic table groaning with food. But what makes this life-size yard unique is that the lawn itself, along with everything on it, is formed by millions of tiny glass beads.

title: Pakistan Devalues Currency by 4.4%
description: Pakistan devalued its currency, the rupee, by 4.4 percent over the weekend as economic sanctions after its nuclear tests prompted foreigners to pull investments from the country.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend on Friday about a show of photographs by Toshio Shibata at the Laurence Miller Gallery in SoHo included an erroneous reference, from the catalogue, to the state where Nimrod Dam was photographed. The dam is in Perry County, Ark., not in Arizona.
